The picture is good, but there is NO audio out on the receiver and no 9v power supply.  Also the tuning knob is really a 4 button channel selector.  And why did they ship it with 3 nine-volt connectors and no AC adapter?  But hey, its amazing it works at all for this price.  And the receiver DOES work with a 9-v battery as does the camera.  I was able to get a decent picture more than 20 feet away behind a wall, more clear in the center than the edges, as long as it has adequate lighting.  I plan to use it for impromptu audience interviews and already have a wireless microphone I can tape this thing to, so it will do for now.  Pro-grade wireless cameras or bluetooth streamers sell for 10-x as much, so until prices drop, this is an OK product.
summary: Looks good, but not what it looks like

reviewText: If you do a lot of full-frame composition - whatever your camera body or sensor size or lens setup - this is a must-have. No, it won't support a 500mm lens, and it's not for birding. But for any number of photography situations - macro, floral, architecture, landscape, product, food - where you have time for a thoughtful and thought-out composition, you can't beat this. It's not fast - it's precise. You move your focal area in tiny, rock-solid increments.Manfrotto seems to understand (between this and the 460MG) that there are a lot of photographers who approach a shot one axis at a time. Loosen your ballhead, and your camera will probably flop in at least two axes, and then you have to find your way back to your shot. This doesn't happen with either this fine piece of equipment - which is preceisely geared - or the 460MG, which is separate-axis controlled. You lock down one axis to adjust the third.An absolutely critical piece of gear. I haven't tried or needed to try the big brother to this head (the 405). This one serves my need for lenses up to 200mm, and is also perfect underneath bellows -

I paired this head with a Manfrotto 776YB Monopod over a year ago and still think it was a good purchase. A tilt head is fine for a Monopod and the quick release system is great. One time it got a little stiff to release but that's done to me treating it badly whilst hiking, a quick clean and lube and it was as good as new.It also accepts theB-Grip Evo Camera Gripplate which is great, it mounts onto it at a 90 degree angle though which means the tilt isn't very useful. I'm now looking to purchase a Manfrotto Ball head (for a tripod) that uses the same QR plate.

This thing does exactly what it is supposed to do - exactly as it is supposed to do it. You can feel just how well made this product is and it is very quiet. I got tired of getting horrible haircuts at "stylists" in Miami Beach. A three-figure cut at a chic hotel was as bad as the hack job at SuperCuts. A few days ago, I went to a barber recommended by the local paper. I got up from the chair when it was apparent that he didn't speak a word of English. I gave up, showed the white flag and ordered this in desperation.The first time I tried this reminded me of my first raw oyster. Both require a bit of courage. However, it really is a whole lot easier than one might think to give yourself a perfectly good haircut. If you start with the longer guide combs, it is easy to then do some fine tuning with a shorter comb. Again, this is a precision made device and the combs snap perfectly into place.I would whack a half-star off, if I could, because the case is not the same quality as the clipper. It has no dividers; It's just an empty plastic box into which one throws everything.
So darn cute fits in your pocket and protects your ear buds, a.must have, and really cute.in pink!!! Fast delivery,just like advertised 6 stars
summary: love it!!! my pink travel case

reviewText: This GorillaPod is a good choice for small cameras like a DSLR with a small, light lens or a GoPro -- but it's an awful choice for heavy lenses like the 70-200mm as pictured with the item on Amazon.  If you have a heavy camera, you really can't have the legs all the way up, as they'll creak and come lose, which topples your camera over.  But, if you bend the legs up at the bottom and have the camera close to the ground, it will stabilize it.  As far as wrapping the legs around something, forget about it with a DSLR -- but it's perfect for wrapping around railings or similar with a GoPro.  It's not excellent, but it imperfectly fills that void between trying to balance a camera on a surface or lugging around a big, heavy tripod.
summary: Not fabulous, but has some uses

reviewText: I got this unit and tried using it to clean my lens, using the brush end added grease to my lens. After reading reviews, one of them said that it maybe a counter fit. The other side seems to work fine. I saw a piece of lint in the viewfinder so I tried using the brush to brush it away. When I looked through, not only did it get worse because the brush fibers fell off, now it left a greasy smear on the view finder. I called Canon about my T3i, and it has to be sent in for repair. After reading more about how to clean the view finder, it was safer to send it to the service center to have it done professionally. It is just sad that I will be without my camera for the duration of the repair.Don't make the same mistake I do. If you are going to use it, use it only for the front of the lens. Where at least you can clean the greasy residue off.

I purchased two pairs of these headphones for some lengthy air travel.  They were comfortable and the controls were easy to use.  They folded compactly.  The sound, on my laptop and over the airplane sound system, was decent.As for noise reduction, were they as good as the latest model (QuietComfort 3, for $350) from Bose?  No way.  Were they close?  No way.  But for less than one-tenth the price, they provided some genuine noise reduction.Are these the best under $50 noise-reduction headphones?  I don't know.  But for those of us in the cheap seats, they provided a significant improvement over regular headphones or the airplane earpieces at an affordable price.

Really not much to say here.  This is a small battery charger for various Sony 8.4V battery packs used on their video cameras, and adopted by the industry as a sort of "standard" for video accessories (lights, field monitors, etc...).  It is relatively small and has a hide-away 120V/US AC plug you can't loose, with a detachable 220V/EU adapter and a 12V/DC car cigarette-lighter cable.The charger fully recharged a Sony F550 batter in less than 90 minutes. The battery did not get overly hot while charging.  There is an LED that turns green when the battery is fully charged.I am satisfied with the product and would buy another in the future.
summary: It's small, inexpensive and it works.

reviewText: I needed two of these for my Sony batteries that power a 160 LED movie light. They do the job at much less cost than the "official" Sony charger.

I have worked extensively with this film - before I got into developing my own film I believed that this was a suitable substitute for Black&White; film. This film leaves me conflicted - as a black and white film it underperforms (since it is not a classical b&w; film), but on the other hand it can be easily developed.PROS- C41 development will be around (cheaply) for another year or two.- Dynamic Range is decent.- Contrast is good- Grain is fine for a 400 speed filmCONS- Lacks the depth and "feel" of a true b&w; film- Enlargements (in my experience) have been lackingWhile I have listed more pros than cons, the negative aspects of using this film are far weightier than the positive aspects. Aside from the C41 processing, all of the pros can be found in black and white film PLUS what the BW400CN is lacking. While I have made some shots on this film that I am proud of (one of my all-time favorites in fact), it was not BECAUSE of this film, rather I just happened to have this film with me at the right time.If you don't want to pay lab prices or you aren't able to develop your own film, this is a decent place to start. Anyone serious about black and white film however, should be prepared for the additional expense of creating true art!SUGGESTIONS:If you are looking for a decent b&w; film that has all of the qualities of this and then some, I would suggest:Ilford HP5 Plus, Black and White Print Film, 135 (35 mm), ISO 400, 36 Exposures (1574577)Kodak Tri-X 400TX Professional ISO 400, 35mm, Black and White Film
summary: Decent for a C41 black and white film.

reviewText: I needed to replace a noisy case cooling fan in a JVC micro-HiFi system. I was worried about the fit of the new fan, which was not a problem, because the size, case and blade shape, and mounting holes' positions of the Skythe fan were identical to the fan I was replacing.However, I made an incorrect assumption that all 40mm x 40mm x 10mm fans would be absolutely the same, which is NOT the case. The differences are in RPM and CFM. Skythe fan is very quiet, but it also runs at 60% RPM (3500 vs. 6000) and pushes 64% CFM (4.1 vs. 6.4) of the original fan. I discovered this after I installed Skythe fan and could not tell whether it was running because it was not making any noise and the airflow out of the vent was practically undetectable. The JVC stereo turns the fan on and off as needed, and it was not running when I soldered it on. I had to put the case back together and play a CD twice and then take the case apart while the stereo was plugged in to see whether the fan was indeed running.  It was, but very little air was being pushed by it.I am going to replace it with a fan with specs that are closer to the original fan's specs. I was looking at the Link Depot's ball bearing 40mm x 10mm fan, but several users on newegg complained about the noise, so I have purchased a sleeve bearing ARX Ceradyne-A FD1240-A2012A from xsfans.Overall, I think this is a good quiet fan, but make sure it suits your needs.  If you are looking for more cooling than your current fan , this fan is probably not it.

Not sure why they call these fans quiet.  I am hearing a constant high pitched whine since I installed these fans.  I have found the original fans for my device online for less money.  Your results may vary.
summary: Not sure why they call these fans quiet

reviewText: This is my 2nd device after buying a 5-port... and they both work just fine. I have not done any speed tests though for throughput.Easy to setup, plug-&-play.
It worked for my computer monitor, but not for my HDTV. A big disappointment as I hoped it would work for me.
summary: ((( DID NOT WORK FOR MY HDTV )))

reviewText: As a computer shop owner, I have to keep AC adapters in stock for a variety of notebook PCs.The 65 watt adapters get plenty toasty!The 90 watt ones, pleasantly warm.Sure, $10 to $20 more, but I recommend genuine Dell, 90 watt adapters.
summary: Don't buy a cheap AC adapter

reviewText: Was glad to be able to purchase this memory card through Amazon for my Cannon digital camera. It works very well.

These cards have become very affordable ,a great storage device for photo,video,and audio,soon they will replace mechanical hard drives, but as things improve many devices that use the older SD style are left behind. Be sure to check if you can use this one, the newer SDHC format. you may need a new card reader as well. Overall this one works well.

Power Bright VC1500W Voltage Transformer 1500 Watt Step Up/Down 110 Volt - 220 Volt. It was DOA. I looked around and found that fuse cap was missing. Yes it has a fuse holder with a screw type cap. When I looked inside the package I found the cap along with fuse. I tried to put it back in place. That's when I realized there is no thread at all on both sides (cap and the body), no kidding if possible I'll post photos. That shows that this piece of junk was never tested. I know how to fix that but didn't wanted to, because if I open it up and fix it and if there are any other problems then I can't even return it. So decided to return it. Amazon gave me a return shipping label. The only hazzle was to pack it again and drop it at the post office. So do I recommend buying this? definitely not.

The mic itself it's decent, you get for what you paid for. More like Semi-Noise Cancelling.But the cable length is extremely short to put from the back of my rig to my neck. I had to spend extra money on a new cable since the microphone is detachable.
summary: Decent Mic, EXTREMELY short cord length

reviewText: These devices are hard to find.  If you have a need and can find this model, it would be a wise choice.
is a cheep cable and for the price is OK i guess i wont go crazy for a cable ok bye.

It's not a bad product but definitely not a very good one either. I use it at work for occasional video calls and listening to music. The video conferencing part is fine. The voice quality on both ends is good, however I was satisfied with the voice quality of my previous $20 Logitech headset as well. However, I was willing to spend this much money on this product because I expected that I could get good music quality out of it too. Well, that's not really the case. I'm not an audiophile person so I can't explain why it sounds all flat and dull, but it definitely does.While wearing, it feels reasonably comfortable. It has basically ZERO sound insulation at the padding around my ears. That is a problem in two ways: I can hear the noises in my office while listening to music and other people can also hear whatever I'm listening to. That's annoying.

Need a lens that will squeeze a whole room into your frame while you're standing the corner of the room?  Or, a photo of the entire sky-scraper as you stand at its front door?  Need a lens that can handle large group photos that will fit everyone it?  A lens that will add weird (almost fisheye) perspective from a portraiture perspective?  Look no further, this is your lens.It was pretty important to me that this lens have the wider f/2.8 vs. the 17-40mm f/4.0 aperture (which retails for about half the price).  I will confirm with the professional and amateur reviews that this lens has distortion and vignetting in the corners at wide apertures (f/2.8) for 16mm to about 20mm.  But actually, for me it gives those photos a bit of charm - see this lens's interesting perspective in my photo of my sister-in-law's cats.  I've added a circular polarizing filter to this thing (albeit expensive given the monstrous 82mm lens width) and in the 20-30mm range, the quality and clarity is quite insane, my copy is razor sharp and makes for an awesome landscape lens particularly when using mirror lock-up and affixed to a tripod.  This lens is way too short for a standard portrait lens and you'd be surprised how close you'd have to get to someone for them to take up a significant portion of their mug in the frame - your subject might object to your proximity.  This might stand in however, as a specialized walk-about lens particularly if you're in a sprawling downtown neighborhood with looming skyscrapers or mountainous backdrops.Build quality is superb.  One small gripe is that we, consumers need to add some type of filter to the lens to finish its weather proofing.  For this much cash, that should already be taken care of by Canon.  But given I always protect my glass, a filter goes on anyway so I guess it's really not a a huge issue but I wanted to make sure everyone is in the know.This is the best zoom ultra-wide angle lens out there for Canon.  It's the best, but is available at a hefty ransom and only you can decide whether the price-performance ratio makes sense to you.  It has a reasonably wide aperture (f/2.8) with a good range of focal length (16-35) - but just keep in mind about the distortion and pincushion effects at the wide and zoomed-in focal lengths respectively.Otherwise, I really like this lens.  When I say that it is a guilty pleasure, I always get great shots no matter what.Best of Luck & Good Shooting!

To be clear, you use this to attach an IDE drive to a SATA connection on mother board, most likely because your motherboard either does not have IDE for what ever reason, and you do not want to throw our a perfectly good IDE drive.I was frustrated at first because I did not read the instructions.  I plugged this in and booted and PC hung.  Finally read the instructions and it tells you to move the drive jumper to MASTER.  HOWEVER, I did that and still did not work.  In my case for my motherboard, the jumper needed to be set to CS(CableSelect).  Once I did that the PC booted.  I suspect other motherboards/bios will recact differentlyHOWEVER, windows explorer did not see the drive when boot completed.  When I looked in Device Manager the drive was there with an "!".  I then opened Disk Manager and it did see the drive but called it "FORIEGN" or  something of that sort.  I had to right click on the drive and "Import FORIEGN DRIVE" or something like that and all was well.Summary, I know this may seem a little technical to some folks, but if you are in messing around with your motherboard and devices you should have the skills to understand the above, it is sort of windows admin 101 kinda stuff.Hope this helps someone and saves a little time.  But the device does do the job and works great.

Zip ties are so handy have around the house.  We like keeping them on hand in our toolbox, and we also keep a bunch on our boat.  We got these Tekton ones because our previous batch ran out.  So far we've used them to organize wires and cables, tie the bait cage to our crab trap, and reinforce our folding crab trap.  They do a good job at what they're intended for.  Great price on Amazon.
summary: Good basic zip ties for the toolbox

reviewText: i own 3 different kinds of Sanus mounts. there are incredibly sturdy, well engineeredand articulate well. instructions are clear and they have good tech support if one has questions.

The bottom line is that these speakers are flat. that makes them great for a studio but not very fun to listen to for most people.  They do have good imaging and a decent soundstage.I like the flat and true sound but its not for everyone so just beware.to buy or not to buy:If you...1) are looking for true sounding speakers for a studio or just enjoying music2) are looking to upgrade your HTIB3) like flat sound4) dont want to break the bankThen buy theseIf you...1) enjoy one spectrum of sound to be more present2) are looking to "bookshelf" speakers (these are called bookshelf speakers but they wont fit in most bookcases),Then dont buy em
works well you have to just try it to be leave it ,it has saved me a lot of money over the years

It works, sort of..............part of each VHS to DVD recording is ok but there are parts that pause, skip and just stop and hang up.  I don't know what the problem is........one disk worked fine until the last 10 minutes and I couldn't finish the movie.  Then some disks work ok through the whole DVD.  There is no rhyme or reason for the problems...........that I can find.  I suggest you use DVD R/W disks as you probably will have to do some over...................I am tired of throwing disks away.

The form factor of this is perfect for travelers and people who want something light to carry.  However, this product falls short by not including a USB 2.1a port somewhere on it.  If it had one, I'd buy at least 2 more.

I use this for travel, specifically when leaving the country. I only have to take one power adapter and I can plug all of my devices into this for charging. Overall, less to travel with.I've also used these in my house where I don't have room or don't want to place a full power strip, but need to get the power adapter away from the wall. Completely satisfied with this product and have been surprised at how many situations it's been extremely useful.
summary: Absolutely the best travel power strip

reviewText: This attaches very securely to myManfrotto 035RL Super Clampand reasonably well to a tripod.  Support is very good for compact cameras, flashes, or what I mainly use it for, a digital microscope.  If you want something capable of holding more, for example a dSLR, I would suggest theManfrotto 396B- 2 2- Section Double Articulated Arm.I find making adjustments can be a bit tricky with this model.  When you loosen one of the screws to raise/lower an arm it also frees that arm to pivot.  That can be a feature if you want to pivot the rod and a pain in the butt if you don't.  (That is a "problem" that is also solved with the double arm model.)I mentioned it works reasonably well on a tripod.  The supplied stud, which is permanently fixed to the lower arm, is tapped to accept a mounting screw from a tripod. The problem is that there's not a lot of stud to come in contact with the tripod and that makes it difficult to get it screwed down tight enough to keep it securely screwed down tight.  :)The camera bracket mount is as you would expect.  There is a rubber(ish) pad that helps keep what your are attaching from spinning around.Another nice feature is that you can only use one rod if that's all you need and that give you an even more stable platform.

Re-reviewed after some extra problems.  I got the coby CA-745 as a replacement for http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0050MX118/ref=cm_cr_rev_prod_title.  The Bionic FM transmitter broke a few months into ownership, but I was impressed by the sound quality.That said, the coby does not live up to that quality.  It works as any other transmitter, it dampens radio noise, and allows you to use the frequency for your own purposes.  It's good at that.  But it struggles with the input from my ipod.  Simply touching the jack will give you loud pops and grinding.  If my ipod is turned to high, the noise coming to my stereo will be garbled and nasty.  If I turn it too low, I get an unacceptable amount of static from normal FM noise.  At medium levels, I'll max out the volume on my radio dial and still not get a satisfactory volume. additionally, songs from my ipod come out murky, and lack the clarity I enjoy in my selection.But the final straw came a few days ago when my car was filled with a horrible stench.  Soon afterward the coby CA-745 died.  I tried taking it apart and replacing the fuse, only to discover that the wires had overheated and fused, and the interior of the device was a mess of melted plastic.I recommend avoiding this product.  It's not worth setting your car on fire.

"CushTop", they call it? What exactly is the part of this desk that's "cushy"? From the top to the bottom this thing is hard as a rock, HUMONGOUS, awkward and all round crappy.It feels cheap and is far too heavy for its design. The middle is hollow to "hold" extra electronics but my iPhone slipped out all the time. Last but not least, the surface would not hold my laptop in place for more than 5 minutes. I was CONSTANTLY pushing my poor computer back up while sitting up in bed.What did they expect not adding an ounce of rubber to the surface?!Hated this thing. Sent it back to Amazon to try another.

Based on the reviews I was afraid to buy this.I needed this to connect my Xbox to my new projector. But when the DVI output didn't work on my cable box I connected the RGB from the cable box to my projector and it worked like a charm.It's a decent length and although the cables are a bit thin near the RGB connectors, the VGA side is very strong.I haven't had the cable long, but so far so good.

Takes one SLR camera with medium sized lens attached, plus two other lenses of similar size. That would be most superzooms, standard zooms, primes or a hotshoe flash. The top flap opens outward for easy access when worn. The internal mesh pocket and outside pockets are also roomy enough for a fairly good spread of accessories.I've used it in all configurations, but not evenly. In order of highest to lowest frequency, I use it as beltpack, handbag and shoulder bag. I switch modes 2-4 times in a full day's outing. I admit I am biased against shoulder bags because of weight distribution.As a nice bonus, the handbag handle fits pretty darn perfectly around the handle of a rollaboard bag.This was my main field bag until I downsized to mirrorless. This bag is less appropriate for smaller equipment--the bag is too deep and does not have sufficient dividers for the larger number of things you could fit in it.
summary: Roomy and versatile for SLR system

reviewText: This VideoSecu 150' cable works well with the cameras that came with myZmodo Surveillance System with 8 Weatherproof IR Cameras PKD-DK0865-NHDand is generally good overall quality. The cable is thinner than the other cables that came with my system, but that has not seemed to effect the performance. This is a long cable and care does need to be taken to fully unwind the bundle before running the cable to avoid tangles.Works for my needs, recommended!CFH

What can I say about a fan.  It works.  It has been working in the system for over a year now without failure.  (The original fan failed in 1 year).  I can also say it is quiet and keeps the CPU cool.
microSD is rather ridiculously small and difficult to deal with, but if you find yourself forced to deal with it as I did, this adapter works just fine.

I've never had any problem using these memory cards in devices advertising they accept them. I've purchased many of the class 10 SDHC (or faster) cards. They've been so reliable and effortless, I won't buy anything other than this brand.

I think everyone knows the Sandisk has earned a reputation as a high-quality flash memory maker. Other manufacturers will often "stretch" the truth when they rate the read/write speeds. Sandisk typically is conversative when rating the speeds of their cards - you always get at least the advertised read/write speeds, and often more.The card I received was the Class 6 variety. Now here's the interesting thing: I have a Canon Vixia HF100 camcorder that is very finicky about the SD cards it works with. I have tried several other brands (both Class 6 and Class 10), and the Canon always returns with something like "Can't record in High Quality mode". Not so with the Sandisk - it works flawlessly. I think Sandisk cards are worth the price premium.

This allows my android tablet to play and scrub HD video directly from the card.  I still own and use Class 2 and 6 cards, mostly for MP3's and documents, but I wouldn't pay a the price of a Class 10 card unless high res photo/video were being used.There is an Extreme Pro out with twice the speed of this, but this one works so well, I can't see why I'd want to pay 3 times the price for roughly the same thing.

I bought two of these units to support my cable boxes.  I have verizon fios which requires a cable box for each tv to receive a cable signal.  I installed one of these in my master bedroom and one in the kitchen below two flat panel tvs.  The rear support has a cover that hides all of the cables so it is a very clean install, especially if you have your cable and electrical connections hidden behind the TV.  For installation, find a wall stud and mount it with the provided hardware.  Great product, unobtrusive and easy to install.

I needed a new charger for my Razr Maxx because my Verizon-branded charger did not provide enough power and took forever to charge my new phone, so I chose this charger and it performs well.  It seems to provide more power, charges my phone much faster, and for the price it can't be beat.  It is indeed genuine Motorola with solid build quality (I posted a couple of pics).  I'm satisfied with this purchase and would recommend this charger.
summary: A great deal for a genuine charger

reviewText: I bought the Adesso Browser Cat (USB) as a supplement to my mouse. Believe it or not, I've been working so much lately that my 'mouse finger' is swollen and sore from all the clicking and scrolling. My hope was to alleviate the problem by switching to a smoother gliding motion on a trackpad.For what it's worth, the Browser Cat was a step in the right direction. I experienced far less discomfort while using the trackpad. As promised, the Browser Cat was plug and play, and adequately responsive.HOWEVER, the device is temperamental with Snow Leopard on an iMac. If plugged into a USB port on the iMac or keyboard, it would occasionally cause the address bar of my web browser to populate with a rapid, infinite string of 8s (as in '8888888888888888888888...'). The same would happen with the Finder search bar. In each case, I'd have to un/replug the device. It was happening often enough to be a complete nuisance. I haven't noticed this happening when it's plugged into a powered USB hub, but it's annoying that there should be any issue at all. The performance of this trackpad shouldn't hinge on the user having a USB hub.Sadly, this cat is going back to the pound.
I ordered the wrong item and this company has been bothering me to upgrade the review. So here it is!!

Doesn't work for what I needed it for.  I was trying to hook a DVD player to a computer monitor and you need to have a specific frequency or this cable won't work.  I had to buy a converter box and use a different set of cables.

This product does exactly what it says it does. It protects the iPod dock connector/cable connector from most damage and foreign objects.Pros: Lightweight, simple to install, simple to remove, very reasonable cost.Cons: The lip around the outside (used to easily remove the cover) is a little bit unsightly, but is definitely durable.Recommendations: Provide a lower profile dust cover.
summary: Great value for a low cost silicon protector.

reviewText: I put this in my movie room and turned out to be perfect in size.  I have it out half power and delivers more than enough rumble and punch to satisfy my needs.  I highly recommend this for the price.

This wire is not Cat5e so why advertise it as such? it even says "even up to 1000BASET" in the description, when clearly the cable is not Cat5e and only holds a 100BASET connection. This cable will not allow gigabit speeds. Waste of money.
summary: Very unhappy, not Cat 5e like the description states

reviewText: I bought these headphones for when I am studying in a noisy environment. They are great at noise reduction. They sound pretty good too. Don't buy these and expect them to sound like audiophile headphones. The best audiophile headphones are open design and thus have no noise reduction at all. These are great for the purpose they were created.No one pair of headphones can satisfy every situation. You would not wear your audiophile headphones jogging for example. These are meant for noisy environments where your audiophile headphones or your little earbuds would be useless.

We bought this camera in 2008.  It was our first experience with a digital camera and we wanted better photo resolution than we were getting from our SRL Minolta we'd had for 20 years.The zoom is fantastic and the option of the standard view finder was a must. I also like the idea of not having to remember to recharge batteries. The image stabilization is great especially when in full zoom.  I was able to take pictures of my son at his college graduation from across the gymnasium.  The 'Sport' setting is also great for moving objects.  I've been perfectly happy with this camera until recently.  Over the past year it seems the picture quality has greatly diminished.  Fresh batteries and a new memory card improved nothing.  The picture resolution is a bit grainy.  Also the LCD screen has developed a yellowish oval in the center of the screen.I emailed the Fuji site with my problem and they said they couldn't help me but did give me a number to call- which I haven't done yet.I paid over $350 for the camera and I expected it to last more than 4 years.
summary: Loss of picture quality over time

reviewText: 1st of all there are lots of tripods on the market. I shoot with a Nikon D90 w/ 28-105mm, 28-300mm and my standard lens for now is the 24-85mm. This tripod works well in all of my shooting applications I intended on using it for. The low profile works well for Macro,low profile shooting and carries the weight of the D90 body with no slips or drifts. Do your homework when buying any product, read.... go to a local store and test it out...ask the supplier all the question you plan to encounter with the product... and finally it'll be a matter of choice and taste for the cash you put out. I'm very pleased with is tripod in all aspects.

reviewerName: M. Jobbagy "Follow Your Bliss - Joseph Cambell"
reviewText: I am not a fan of earbuds at all, and haven't found any that I really liked that much. I did review some awhile back that had a soft rubber loop that hung over your ear that was pretty nice, but still.... buds... that go in your ear.....These sound so good, I can just almost forget these are earbuds and enjoy some pretty good sounds out my mp3 players that I thought sounded bad, until I plugged these in.It's pretty cool about the eco friendly packaging and all, even the carrying case made of recycled tires... some marketing hype going on as others have noted, but better than not doing anything about trying to reduce packaging waste....The large variety of adapters to fit all types and sizes of ears is really great. Between the foam and silicon tips, you can find some combination to fit your ears comfortably.The sound is pretty superb. Hearing bass out of buds was pretty much impossible I thought.... but these bring out much more than any others I tried. They are a bit pricier than what I've got in the past, but for the sound, protective case, and variety of ear tips, it's well worth it.
summary: Hard to Believe These are Earbuds

reviewText: let me start off by saying this camera is very well built. its been through rain and snow and its still working well. i can see everything in the darkest of places without a problem the only issue is that it has allot of glare that comes off from any light source that is close to it. like if your going to parallel park and there is a oncoming car you will notice the intense glare that comes off the head lights. apart from that the camera is great for low light and even daylight conditions.

reviewText: I have bootcamp set up on my macbook pro, and my first bluetooth mouse finally died a month ago.  I loved my previous mouse, but couldn't find it again.  After lots of browsing -- I finally settled on this one. It's been great! I love it more than my previous one! Before it took awhile for my MBP to connect to my old mouse, both on Mac & Windows - but this one connects right away!  I was worried that there would be problems using it on both operating systems, but there hasn't been any! No complaints! The size, response time, everything -- perfect!

reviewText: I only have one DVD left in my pack of 15 and so far ALL of them burned correctly and work correctly.In the past, I've had some minor issues with Memorex DVD-DL discs, but I believe it was more than likely due to my laptop DVD burner becoming worn down/out.  Once I bought an external burnerSamsung USB 2.0 External Optical Drive SE-S084D/TSBS Super WriteMaster, Slim External DVD Writer (Gloss Black), I've had almost no issues with DVD burning.  As I mentioned, with this batch of blank DVDs, it's been a perfect 14 for 14 so far with no playback issues.Obviously for some people, these work fine and for others, not at all.  It's possible that is has something to due with the content being burned, the hardware burning the discs (and the speed it is burning them at) and/or the software used to burn the discs.  If all these discs are truly defective, I probably would have gotten a bad batch by now and I can't say that I have.Still, I can't recommend these discs to everyone knowing that others have so many problems with them, but if you take the chance and they do end up working for you, they are a good, economical option.  Good luck!
summary: If They Work For You, They're Great

reviewText: These cables were obviously homemade, but since the photos show that, I'm not going to hold that against them. The ones from MIRAMAX work great and came free with Prime, a major plus for me. Although I run plenty of cable, this is great to have around when you just want to connect two things across a room to troubleshoot and rule out the wall wiring, not to mention letting non-techies install their own cable. It works great at full gigabit speeds in every instance I tried it, though I haven't used all 5 yet. The price is a bit high for homemade cable with no rubber bumpers or any other niceties, though.

I connected this cable between my macbook pro and my 47" 3-D HDTV.  The picture looks great and there is no noticeable loss of any kind.I see that some folks have had some problems with the cable though.  As someone who's done tech repair in a computer shop, I can tell you the reason for this as I've seen the problem many times.  The problem is almost always with the pins in the cable.  They can be loose, bent, or simply missing/broken.  If the pins are bent, you can sometimes bend them back and the cable will work fine, but they can break easily.  If they're loose, there's not much you can do, likewise if they're missing/broken.  It would seem that some cables from the company are getting out that may have some issues, but overall, it appears as though most of their cables are good.  If you get ghosting or flickering colors, just use the Amazon return process and get a new one free of charge.  The chances of getting 2 bad cables in a row is pretty remote, and you really can't knock the price at all.  If you get two bad cables, well, they're probably 2 good cables and I'd start looking at your system.Another potential problem with your video cable might be your video card.  Sometimes, when you push the cable onto the video card, you lift up and unseat the video card.  This is very common and happens all the time because not everyone screws down their video cards.  Also, the connector on the video card may have come loose.But again, the cable works fine for me, and is freaking long as heck and a great price.  The cable is a bit stiff, but hey, it's 50 feet long and works flawlessly, so I can't complain.

reviewerName: Xbox gamers = REAL GAMERS unlike the sonymite...
reviewText: I have not had any issues and its a life saver since I can't connect my laptop to my 3dtv through my hdmi port. Picture quality is good. Great product.

We bought two of these cables about two years ago and were amazed by the quality, durability, and price of these cables. When one of the cables recently failed (not surprising given that we load them in and out at least once a week, throw them around, and pretty much just use and abuse them), I ordered two more without hesitation. Due to iPod classics are being phased out by their touch screen brethren, it is near impossible to find any case for the classic. My choices were very limited, but I am glad I chose this case. Is is cool/special in the fact that it is shiny works like a mirror when the screen is off. Though some say the mirror finish obstructs the screen, it works fine for me at about 50% brightness. Regardless, overall this is a good product and I would recommend it's purchase to those looking for something similar at a reasonable price point.

reviewText: Bought this product mainly because of its sata port and fast transfer speeds. Learned later about the variable rpms and decreased performance of Caviar Green HDDs. Not 100% 7200 RPM. Keeping it quieter, cooler and more energy efficient, which I liked in the beginning, but would have bought a performance based HDD had I known. Main use for the drive was to use with my WD Live TVs in different rooms on different flat screen displays. All of my music, photos and DVD/Bluray/home video content was shared between this drive and others.This was my go-to drive. Took this drive with me on vacations all around the world. Ski trips. Road trips. To work. I dropped it, knocked it over while on the desk, and probably a few other not-so-awesome incidents for a HDD. It lived, and survived for several years. I loved it. It died. Taking hours of home footage of my daughter, surfing, and other activities, plus HD movies and hundreds of GB's of multimedia content. Did I have back-ups of the family stuff? Darn right! Multimedia.... ... ...some of it on other HDDs. Not all was lost, mainly a great deal of time spent converting DVD TS/VOB files to joint .mp4, divx, .avi or the like. For years this device would pair seamlessly with my WD HDTV/live and my family could eliminate the need for DVD/Bluray players. Knew I should have had a mirror drive. Fail.Originally used this HDD with my PC by way of the sata port. Worked well and transferred files moderately fast. With XP the sata port had a patchy relationship. Did my computer recognize it 100% of the time, no. Did I have to plug and play it a few times on several occasions to get it to finally be recognized? Yes! Was it my motherboard/computer? Never hooked it up via Sata to other people's computers....So, possibly. It worked every time with firewire 400. That seemed to be the go to port. All ports worked great; will only say that after years of use the USB port became loose and didn't seem to align perfectly in the case. Made it work. Still worked, but wasn't a secure, sturdy fit and sometimes the USB cable would detach if slightly bumped the wrong way. A hassle at times.Once the clicking began, my frustration and utter resentment towards WD grew, mainly towards its Caviar Green series of HDDs. Seems that there are just a slew of people with complaints and mishaps with these Caviar Green HDDs...but then again, you look at any HDD and one will find reviews about issues they have encountered. But there are countless you tube videos, how-to's, data recovery, freeze it this way and that infos all over the web about these drives. Use that as a main decider for which HDD you choose. Affected my choice in the end. Literally looked for a list of WDD drives that had Caviar green inside and stayed away.Would I buy this HDD again. Hard to say. First instinct yes, because I have so many memories with it. Lame I know. But true. Relied on it. Grew to really like it. Then the Caviar Green HDD said F*** you, I'm tired, and I am taking a nice long nap.My other, older, 500GB WD My Book Essential HDD is still alive and kicking, and luckily, not clicking. Have only good things to say about it. So knock on wood..keep on keeping on champ!Just ordered 2 new 3TB Seagate HDDs this evening, and if that wasn't good enough, plugged in the old WD 1TB earlier today, for the first time in months, to have it, just as I remembered, begin its clicking away. So I laughed, hit it a few times with the blunt end of a pair of scissors (case opened and removed, hard drive exposed naturally), cursed at it some more, did my information-rain-dance, and went about my HDD research. Other brands, no doubt. Serves you right WD.After a good 10-15 minutes of HDD clicking the shortcut appeared on my desktop. Amazed I opened it to see what files remained. Most, if not all, but many corrupt were able to be seen, but being formatted in NTFS, was all that could be done with them. Went and downloaded NTFS for Mac, a program that would let me access NTFS drives from a Mac, and was informed I had to... ...RESTART! Would my drive be recognized again? ...was this the last time I would ever see the files I once had? Should I restart? After the restart it was backto the same old nothing. So, I did what any technician- who could give a rats a$$ about his job would do- and began, shaking it, banging it and hitting it with whatever I could find, pressing on both sides of the HDD until I heard grinding on the inside, and surprisingly the HDD came back to life, I got movies, music and other valuable information off, and it has been a happy ending to what was, months ago, a devastating blow, what felt like getting kicked in the gut, losing so much information.Note: Have another old 500GB Maxtor 3200, and 500GB Seagate Free Agent that have both been great. If you need a small pocket HDD, check out the Seagate FreeAgent Go 500GB. Lightweight, quiet, and does what it needs to. WD. Listen to your customers and read the reviews. Build us a product we can trust and rely on and we, your customers will be loyal to you. Look at Apple. Three word business model: Simple, reliable, service! And look where they have grown to after being near the brink of extinction. Learn! Or continue to find yourself in the run of the MUCK HDDs section, shunned by many, abandoned by many. Abandoned by me!
summary: Was great until it failed...click click click, cycle, click click click

reviewText: I've owned many Zunes since their initial release (which by the way are still highly desired by many). They're well made, feels much sturdier than other makes and, most importantly, sounds great. These 2nd generation Zunes added further refinements from 1st Gen ones, slimmed down and got better looking and delivers great value. One of the best things about it is that it comes with premium earphones that absolutely rocks.  As far software, Zune makes iTunes look clumsy.  If you can pick a used one up for less than $100, go for it.

Plenty of holes for mounting...make sure you're on the studs or at least something solid!It extends out a lot farther than I expected. reviewText: If you spend any time sitting in front of a computer, the idea of USB powered mini fridge probably has some appeal to you, especially if you are far from a regular refrigerator and a plug-in-the-wallMini Fridgeis for some reason not an option for you.  No doubt the thirst-suffering keyboard-slave inventors of this little item thought they had an instant winner on their hands, but they were done in by cheap materials and science.The science problem is worth dwelling upon; the sad truth is that hot plates will ALWAYS work MUCH better than cooling plates for a reason in addition to the fact that hot plates can make use of the waste heat from electrical resistance (either directly or as a byproduct of the Peltier effect) while cooling plates must dissipate it:convection.Hotter fluids rise and colder fluids fall, thus a container of any liquid placed upon a hot plate will quickly become uniformly heated while a similar container of liquid placed upon a cooling plate will get as cold as it is ever going to get at the bottom while the upper layers won't cool much at all.  That's why the instructions for this item say to use 8 ounce soda pop cans even though the product was obviously originally designed for 12 ounce soda pop cans; doing so removes what will always be the warmest 1/3rd of a 12 ounce soda pop can.It is no accident in my opinion that later (?) models of this productPortable USB Cooler and Warmer 2-in-1come with a switch so it can be used as a hot plate as well, which function can at least be presumed to work.There ARE ways to fight this, but doing so would require spending more on materials.  aries2110, one of the top reviewers of this version of the product shows what might have been by installing a stronger fan (for dissipating waste heat) and taping some insulation to the inside, reporting a significant increase in cooling.  The less handy can try setting it in front of a desk fan and putting acan insulatorupside down on the can.  I also noted some additional cooling but nothing approaching "refrigerator cold".Basically, about all it is good for IMHO is SLOWING the warming up of a previously refrigerated can of soda pop more than just setting it on your desk will.  I picked mine up on clearance, and I suggest you do the same,...if you even want to bother with it.

The idea behind this is good but once you use it, you'll find it's difficult to get a smooth enough surface to get your shots to look nice. Otherwise, using this without a BIG-ENOUGH, extra smooth surface to roll on is just ridiculous and will look like you placed your camera onto a child's toy car or something. reviewText: Wanted to originally purchase a bag that would allow me to carry my 60D and a few lenses so that I could have a lightweight back that would be easy to lug around the airport or while hiking.Thought the Fastpack 100 would be the best bag for me based on the product description and some of the other reviews I have seen online.However once I received the bag and used it for a few weeks, I determined it really wasn't the way to go.The primary issues I had with the bag are actually comfort. The straps themselves are not very comfortable at all. With minimal padding, they started to hurt my shoulders after less than an hour. There also was not much cushioning on the pad on the back of the bag itself which led not only to comfort issues but ventilation issues.The construction of the bag is fine, nothing to complain about on that end. But decided my journey to finding a good bag would continue after using this one.
summary: Not a bad camera bag, but not my goto bag

reviewText: I bought this for my Olympus G.Zuiko Auto-w 28mm lens. It's a pretty old lens. 1970's I believe. I was worried this would be the case. So If you're looking for an adpater for an old Olympus this isn't it.None of this is the product or sellers fault. Just a heads up so you don't make the same mistake I did.UPDATE:So here is what I found about this lens. I have a temporary lens they created for 7 months when the first OM was delayed.It is an M42 screw mount. Only about 1500 of these were made between 1971 and 1972.So, there's my problem.Again, not the seller's fault or Amazon's. I wouldn't even say it's fair to consider this as a review except to make sure you have the correct mount.It is a very nice looking, sturdy piece.

There is a fundamental flaw in these Logitech USB Speakers with Digital Sound. By "Digital" they really mean the speakers are either off at zero volume or on at full volume, there is no in-between. Even at the lowest volume setting they are disturbing loud. They actually have good sound, but unless you like LOUD all the time, these speakers are not for you.

reviewText: The clip that attaches to the GPS is good but the handlebar attachment attaches with zip ties - a pathetic and lazy engineering effort imo. My Etrex 30 always rotates out of place.  Additionally, in time the elements (ie Sun) is going to cause the plastic zip ties to deteriorate to the point of failure.  The design used on the prior generation of Etrex models was more secure and appears to be the focus of the MFX2 design -Motorcycle Handlebar Mount with Carabiner Clip for Approach Dakota Colorado Oregon GPSMAP 62 62s 62st eTrex 10 20 30 Rino 610 650 655T Astro 320 GPS

I now own two of these tripods, and have had the first for well over a year, and the second for over 6 months now. I have been more than happy with the results of this tripod, and they have paid for themselves in spades with the work I have used them on (mostly weddings, corporate, and local business commercials).Now, are they perfect fluid head tripods? Not exactly. Are they very good fluid head tripods?  They sure are. They have a slight snag when you start moving the handles, but this took me a very little amount of time to get used to. Once you do have them moving, though, they are smooth as silk.I have read some reviews that claim that they tend to be a little tight, making panning difficult. I do not find this to be the case. I do find them to be a bit tight, more so than my last tripods, but I actually enjoy it, and have grown accustomed to it. I find that the stiffer movement works well with my heavier cameras,Sony HVR-HD1000U MiniDV 1080i High Definition Camcorder with 10x Optical Zoom.The carrier bag isn't half bad either.  It was a nice addition, and I love that it comes with two attachment plates, so I always have a spare just in case.The design of the tripods is fantastic, and the build quality is exception. They are 100% all metal parts.  This is especially important on the leg-locks. My old tripods were a bit more expensive, and the logs were plastic.  They barely lasted a year before they started to snap and break. But I do not worry about that with these bad-boys.Bottom line: I recommend these tripods to any one starting out or on a budget looking for a quality tripod that they can expect professional looking results with.

I bought these for an "Ice Chest" radio I was building for my little sister.  In that application they work pretty well.  The sound was decent at best, but I have a cheap amp driving them.  It may sound better with better power.Bass was as expected from a 6-1/2" speaker.  It was there, but I kept wanting to reach for the bass knob and turn it up a little more.  I put the I-phone in "bass boost" mode and it did okay.  Nothing spectacular, but as expected for what they are.Overall I am happy with these speakers.  If I was going to start over, I'd buy them again.  If I had a larger budget, I'd spend it first on the amp, then on better speakers, If that helps any.One note, just FYI:  the tweeters are built into the grill.  It's all one and you can't remove it.  The screws go through the grill to hold the speakers in place.

reviewText: We use these mice with all our Lenovo bluetooth enabled laptops at work; they work and very rarely if ever fail.  The mouse is very well built and solid as a rock. It's sad that this model is discontinued now because it was performed well beyond my expectations. The advertising says 20 mile range but that's obviously under optimal conditions and optimal conditions being absolutely flat ground with zero obstructions between you and the other radio. In the real world, it'll get about 1.5 miles urban and depending on how heavily wooded a forest is, around 3 miles for forests (camping, etc.). The radio has a built in LED flashlight which isn't all that bright but comes in real handy when you need it. The stock rechargeable batteries aren't too great so I tend to use (3) AA batteries instead which proves to be much better in terms of performance and battery life. The belt clips broke on me and was a $7 replacement excluding tax and shipping which is ridiculous but it was a necessity for me so I was willing. The volume control knob is smooth but maybe a little too smooth. I often find myself constantly checking to see what the volume level is because moving around with the radio hooked onto my belt or pocket would sometimes rotate the volume knob. Not a big deal, though as it rarely ever happens. The only major issue I've had with this radio is that if I press the PTT button and then let go of the button at the end of my transmission, the radio would suddenly shut down and then I would have to manually rotate the knob to the OFF setting and then turn it back ON. I'm not entirely sure why this happens but it's most likely because of low battery power even though the battery level indicator might say otherwise. After replacing the batteries, the problem seems to go away. And if anyone was wondering about longevity, I've had these since September of 2009 and have rigorously used it even up until today. They are still working perfectly fine although there is some clear degrading in transmit/receive quality but don't mind that because I've used these way more than anyone would ever get close to using. Overall, 4 stars for this awesome product!

There are quite  a few reviews here that will give a perspective buyer a feel for the Pros/Cons of this product so I'll keep it short.We have a moderate sized home and have great connectivity in most of the home, but very bad connectivity in the kitchen, office and living room. While we typically have 4  bars in most of the house, we usually have 1 bar at best in the kitchen and it's not unusual to have no coverage. Even when we do , calls drop all the time and it's very annoying.  We took a gamble and bought the Wilson.Setup was a Pain in the butt, that's my big knock on this thing. In our case (and from what I understand) you'll typically have to have it installed outside to get much value for it.  We have really thick tree coverage in the back yard and each direction pointing to the nearest Cell Tower. In fact, if you are standing in the backyard, front yard or sides, you can not see the tower at all.  we didn't' have Rabbit ears so had nothing to really attach to on the high part of the roof that would give us line of sight.  To get it working correctly, we ended up cutting a small swatch of foliage in the back yard so we could get clear LOS to the tower. We ended up mounting it to the back part of the roof on the lower side (basically, top part of 1st floor roof).  It took about 45 minutes to tweaking to get both green lights on which isn't unreasonable - however after about 20 minutes you really start wondering if you're going to be able to make it work. Even after 30 mins, we still couldn't get both greens on. Frustrated I decided to get the swath cut out in the back which ended up doing the trick. Outside of that, we had to drill a hole through the wall to feed the cable. our choices were to drill it in the roof and drop the cable through the wall, then run it into a connector , or basically drill a hole outside right next to the one that the cable company drilled for our cable (not saying it had to be next to the cable co's hole, just that it was proximate and that just happened to be a place with no wires and easily drilled through).For a handyman that has a decent set of tools, the install is no big deal. However for many people, drilling a whole through the wall, drilling holes on the roof to add a mounting bracket etc is a bit much. We were lucky in that we had one handyman that does work for us that could do it all.  If we  had to use the indoor mount or rig something outside, it would have been a deal breaker (inside b/c we couldn't get any connectivity worth talking about, outside b/c the cable needs to connect the antenna to the signal module).On the upside, as soon as we got the green lights, ALL OF OUR CELL CONNECTIVITY problems disappeared immediately. Various family members have a few different phones, 4g, 3g's and a cheapo pay as you go emergency phone which I'm not sure about. The 4g  phone now has full bars everywhere in the house all the time. The ones I know to be 3g is pretty much the same.. it occasionally goes down by one bar, but it's still 3 bars and no calls have dropped. On the cheapo phone, there have been no connectivity problems and no drops.  It's also worth noting that since we got it installed, we've had some really harsh weather.  There's been cloud coverage that completely kills our XM stereos and our neighbors dish network yet we've had no problems at all. B/c of that, b/c it does what it's advertised to do and does it really well, I'm very pleased with it. We've been fighting connectivity issues for a few years now and had always heard too much negative stuff about boosters to really give them a try.  By now we heard enough good (including Amazon reviews) that I figured it was worth the risk and i'm very glad we go it.  My parents live on an island on the coast of SC with really horrendously bad coverage and we ordered them a unit which I'll post back about once it's installed. My guess though is that it'll help.The key seems to be that you need to have at least a week signal to begin with, so if you have no signal, I really can't speak to it. However we had one bar at best for most of the house and the problem was completely resolved.  The wife and i both work from home frequently and the daughter is a 13 year old who constantly talks to friends.  we haven't had a single call drop since this was added, and I think we've had a chance to really test it adequately since we use our cell phones for work meetings (and daughter talks frequently to other friends). Dropped calls are such a completely pain in the butt so the elimination of drops alone justifies the price. the fact we don't have to constantly say "Are you still there, can you hear me" over and over is just icing on the cake. It's a good unit, I'm very glad I bought it, bought one for the parents b/c I'm quite sure it'll fix their problem and would gladly buy another one.

Not a bad deal for a 12" dual voice coil speaker, but the metal frame is cheap, it rattels. Maybe mine was a factory dud.Updated (09-09-12)I did some tweeking and got the rattle out come to find out the speaker was slightly bent and I just rescrewed it all the way around with bigger screws to get a good tight fit and seem to take care of it.  It actually sounds pretty darn good. using a Boss 1200W 4ch bridgable amp only pushing 600W to it.  Be nice to max it out (1200W)

It works at cleaning cd's and dvd's but was it really worth the purchase? One might find it cheaper to buy several of these repair system sets rather than buying the repair accessory kit as the repair system is cheaper priced at the moment. I'm not sure if the repair accessory kit plans to bring it's price down. I thought over and over again as to whether I should buy some repair accessory kits. I decided that the price wasn't really worth it as these cleaners wear out easily. If the repair accessory kits price was brought down by half, maybe, just maybe I would consider buying it. I should also mention that if the repair accessory kit was priced lower, I'm sure that I would probably up the rate on this item by one star.

Sound quality is really great, but the buds are completely round and they hurt my ears after wearing them for a while. Im not a little girl so my ears are even average size. They don't keep out background noise like I had hoped but they aren't really noise-cancelling headphones. All in all, they are a good product, but if you have small ears, I'd think twice about getting these.UPDATE 2/15/12: To add to my previous review, one of the headphones quit working. I was using them while running and now sound only comes from one of the headphones. They are only about 7 months old. I am not pleased with these and I wouldn't order them again.
summary: Good sound quality, but it hurts my ears.

reviewText: We have a two-plug outlet where one of the plugs is on a three-way, so we can turn a lamp on or off from the wall switch. The size and shape of this little surge protector is just right to extend only the other plug and leave the three-way alone. The USB ports are convenient for charging the laptop and phone without needing an adapter.
It made life easy wiring numerous cables that had some slack into the wall instead of trying to stuff all of them into a little box.  Very easy to install, just measure, cut, and screw in to tighten.

I bought Apple Airport Express withe the intentions of increasing my home network area, which would in turn allow me to use my WiDi on my computer better.  I was wanting to use the Airport to connect to my printer from iPad and my iPhone, because my printer was already on the network, using the Airport as a go between, or maybe an Airprint station.  It has done neither of these things to date.  My printer would show up in the Airport Utility on my PC, but when I tried to access it from either of my Apple devices I could only access it through the printer's own apps. (I ended up getting a new printer that connected to Airprint)  As far as the extending the network goes, I still have not been able to find a way for that to work.  I have spent the basic amount of time on it, and when I set it up, it alsways completely removes the Airplay from my Utility, forcing me to reset it from my iPhone.  The signal is also a little week for some reason.Bottom line, I think that if you are going to purchase this it should be as: A. your only network device, or B. you know a little bit about network admin.I just didn't want to hastle with it because my network is ok for now and I am a little busy.

Should have known a $20 HDMI splitter was too good to be true. Tried it with multiple (otherwise working) HDMI cables. Nothing. Zilch. Nada.Save yourself the time and money and move right along. Nothing to see here.
Very good center channel for the list price, but a way better one when you get it on Amazon. Great way to upgrade your most important speaker with a top of the line item, while paying half as much.

Got this to replace the original HD in my Wife's 13" Macbook Pro.  Installation was some what tricky.  I cloned her hard drive to this hard drive and swapped them but the new cloned HD at first did not work.  I repeated the exact same cloning process and for some reason it took the second time.  Drive works great.

Ordered this for my Nikon D7000.  With Sigma 10-20mm lens, the camera was really moving around in the case. Also, the collapsible port didn't have a built in way to secure it close to the lens, so with the camera able to move around and a longish port, there was a lot of vignetting.  I decided to return this as it didn't handle well at all, in my opinion.  I used a different Dicapac for my P&S and while that had some of the same issues, it was much easier to jury rig and wedge the camera in so that there was minimal vignetting.  I had no leak issues with my P&S Dicapac.

This does a grat job. It is very easy to use and takes you step by step through what you need  to do. It displays on the screen what you need to do, plus there is video to demonstrating what to do. While you are calibrating you screen, it gives you an option to watch the vidos if you do not understand what to do. I like the fact that it gives me the chance to see the before and after, when it is done so I can see the difference.
