I ordered two batteries, but BrilliantStore shipped two AC adapters.  I notified them of the mistake, and they sent the batteries and a return envelope for the AC adapters.  I installed the batteries in two Dell M90 notebook workstation PCs, and followed the manufacturer's instructions for initial battery break-in and conditioning.  Both batteries charged to 100%.  Both PCs have remained plugged in for the last five weeks.  The battery charge indicator on the toolbar has been steadily dropping on both PCs, despite being connected to AC power.  One PC shows 60% maximum charge and the other shows 79%.  Again, this was not the result of any use of the battery.  The notebook PCs have been used as desktop units only.  We use them for only the occasional mobile use, and mostly got the batteries to essentially have a UPS battery backup in case of power failure.  They may serve that function, or they may die immediately if showing such a low charge while connected to AC power.  They certainly won't provide full power capacity for mobile battery operated use.UPDATE June 6th 2012 - I tried to use my notebook computer as a notebook computer last night, instead of a desktop PC tethered to AC power. The battery lasted ten minutes or less, and the PC died while trying to hibernate. I plugged the PC back in and rebooted it and the battery charge indicator is now stuck at 8% (essentially zero). I think a couple of cells have failed. I bought two of these batteries for two Dell M90 notebooks and both batteries are junk, so this isn't just one random bad battery.  They're 0 for 2.  I think there's a systemic problem. I've gotten essentially no actual use out of either battery. It was just a complete waste of my $50 and my time. Beware!
summary: Wrong Item, Then Batteries Won't Hold Charge

reviewText: This subwoofer takes a bit of time to break in, but when it does, it adds the solid low end needed, particularly for movies and the like.  It is punchy, not flabby.  Needs to be placed properly, so experiment to find the best placement in your room.

It took me a great deal of research to determine which camera bag would fulfill my needs.  I am a neophyte in the DSLR with a new camera for Christmas.  Prior to this I have been a point-and-shoot guy Nikon Coolpix 7900.  Got on the Lowepro website and used their bag suggestion search option.  Then back to Amazon armed with the information I needed.  The bag appears to be well made and I look forward to adding a few accessories to fill it up properly.  The padding seems sufficient and flexibility within the main compartment.  The water resistant cover and band across the back to fit on drag around suitcase are great extras.
summary: My first Lowepro bag for my new Nikon D5100

reviewText: I have a 13" MacBook Pro and though this is designed for a 15" - it still works pretty good, there is a little bit of wiggle room for the laptop to move up and down - but i'm not running with this bag or bouncing around for it to move much.I usually have my MacBook Pro and my Wacom intuos 4 tablet in main pocket of the bag with pen (for tablet), usb cable (for tablet), power cord (for laptop), iphone charger and usb cord, some paper documents or receipts, pack of gum, car keys, and maybe a small snack (protein bar or airplane pretzels) floating around in the smaller front pocket.My only desire would be to have that front pocket a little more square and padded like the main pocket, as its not as rigid as the rest of the bag - i often end up with a large lump of all the stuff piled together in there which make it stick out farther.The bag material is nice, water resistant and modern looking. The bag hangs nicely over the shoulder, and feels balanced. I generally wear it more messenger style - with the strap over the opposite shoulder as the side my bag is on.

After a week I am happy with the purchase. Works on 4 AA or AC cord. The AC cord is inside the hinged cover on the back and can be fully deployed or just as much as needed. Nothing fancy just a radio, exactly what I wanted.

There was none available at this focal length for DX cameras when I shopping for this lens. This lens is super sharp and well built. Although not a big fan of push-pull focus ring I haven't had big problems with it. Lens hood for this lens is only for screwing on filters and not for others reasons that we typically use lens hoods for. I have not tested Nikon 40 2.8 Macro and can't speak for which one is better. But Nikon has advantage of being AF-S which can be used with non screw drive cameras.
summary: The best normal macro available at the time of purchase

reviewText: We have a cat that loves to chew apart the thin electric cords that are attached to pricey transformers.  I was not happy with the price or the short lengths available in pet supply section.  The price on this split loom tubing is super low for 100 feet of coverage.  Takes a while to thread the cords into the loom but it cuts easily and so far is keeping the cords safe from the cat.  Got two widths so we can use as both protection and a way to keep cables together.  (have copied and pasted this same review for the other size tubing)
summary: Affordable way to protect cords from cats!

reviewText: It is what it says it is...I have a Tascam DR-40 and I'm not sure this is the best solution. This will fit on the DR-40, however it is a little tight and takes a little bit of practice to get it right.Pros: Does a good job of blocking wind. Makes good Don King hair for my desktop skellie...Cons: A little small for a DR-40. Little bit expensive.Thoughts: Cheaper than a Tascam windscreen.

Perhaps I misunderstood but I thought these were the same size as the $19.99 pads.These are longer and narrower  and don't fill out the ear canal as much as the other model. I guess if you have long narrow ear canals these will work but I've got big one (ear canals).

Maybe I have freakishly small ears, but I have the hardest time finding tips that actually fit and sound good.  I have Klipsch S4-i headphones, and the smallest tips worked well for me but were kind of uncomfortable.  When I lost one, I happened upon the Comply website and decided to try them out.  I got the smallest size in a 3-pack for somewhere in the arena of $15.Sound quality: five stars.  I'm seriously impressed.  The noise isolation is great, the basses are low and the trebles are high.Comfort: five stars.  I love deep sound, so I shove 'em in my ears like earplugs.  They only start to ache after at least six hours of continuous listening.Physical quality: three stars.  I've had them about a month, and the tips are starting to rip and lose their form.  I will say that I don't treat them gently - I twist and pinch the foam to get it deeply in my ear like an earplug.Bottom line: For about $5/month (probably less if you don't mangle the tips like I do), you can greatly improve upon the original sound and comfort of your earbuds.  I highly recommend them.
summary: Great sound quality, so-so physical quality

reviewText: I bought this because I was getting rid of my old desktop computer but still needed to transfer some files that were on my computer to my laptop. It worked great and was easy to do.

I'm an airline pilot that does a lot of international travel. I wanted something that I could use with 110 or 220 and plug in multiple items. Most power strips sold in the US only work with 110 and not 220. I have written several manufacturers of so called "travel" power strips to ask if they would work with 220 and almost all replied with a firm "NO". However outlets-to-go replied "yes" their power strip will work with 110 or 220. On that I purchased this through amazon and i have not regretted the choice.First, it is compact and easily fits into my suitcase. In fact, I stuff it into a shoe with my plug adapter. The pig-tail cord folds around the unit and stows by plugging it in to itself. The pig-tail is nice to have because at some hotels the plug is stuffed behind a desk with some kind of bar running in front (what were they thinking?). There are three plugs that are well spaced. two on one side and a single plug on the other. This is nice because some computers or cell chargers take up a lot of space. The USB outlet is a nice touch. It charges my cell phone, my MP3, and my sanyo battery charger with no problems. Since I don't own an I-pad, I cannot comment to that.So how does it work on 220? Just fine. There was no smoke, sparks, and the building didn't go dark when I plugged it in. Now, I will take time to caution you about something. If you plug this into 220..Guess what, you get 220 out. So make sure the item you plug in is duel voltage. this may sound like common sense here, but after reading some reviews over on the page where I bought my plug adapter, it seems common sense may not apply. This is only a power strip, not a voltage converter.Bottom line...If you travel worldwide and need a power strip that can handle 110 or 220, then this is it!! get yourself some good plug adapters and your set.

This system gives the sound of systems 3 times the cost.  The most impressive is the sub.  In my open floor plan (living room, dining room, kitchen, entry) home this thing really fills the space with sound- and the sub is large, powerful, and sounds amazing.  The speakers are great.  I always listen to the music and my movies a bit on the loud side (not 'teenager' loud, but close) and they sound great.  When I just want some noise in the background and play pandora on low volume, I can still hear these fine at low volumes.  The only downside I can find is that the mounting brackets don't come with any hardware, so you will likely need to buy screws with drywall fasteners - not a big enough con for even a one star downgrade.  My home was pre wired for a sound system, so the lack of speaker wire in the box was nothing to me, might disappoint others, though.

I notice alot of 4 and 5 star reviews. I'd give a 4 1/2 stars but you can't here. I plugged mine in and it worked immediately. I'm slightly concerned about its longevity as my cigarette/power adapter outlet in my truck is a bit tight and it takes a good grab and yank to take it out. This could prove fatal over time (to the transmitter). My solution will be to make an adapter that will be the contact point and use that as the removal point. Or maybe install an on/off switch so I can leave it in the socket all the time, but remove power via the switch. It's not recommended to leave the device plugged in during vehicle starts as the voltage spike could pop the devices internal voltage regulator. Anyway, this thing works great. I'll buy another even if this one craps out. Everything does eventually.

Noise Isolation: The inserts provide a bit better sound isolation than my cheap $10 Sony earbuds from target. Not as good as sound isolating buds of course, but it's a noticeable improvement. Ships with around 8 extra inserts of different sizes and types.Playback Quality: It's ok for an in-ear, cheap earphone. The bass is a bit punchy though which is nice. Voice quality is good even if music playback is somewhat lacking. Music quality seems a bit better after using it for a week (burn in). Note that JLab's has some special burn-in instructions on their website.Android Compatibility: This is the reason I bought this headset. The button on the microphone housing will pause audio playback on my Nexus S 4g. Works for both the default music app and my podcast app "BeyondPod".Other notes: Cable is fairly long (4'3" or so). Treble boosting equalizer settings make the audio output more to my tastes. Also, see the bulky nub right near the headphone jack in the pictures? I was worried I wouldn't be able to plug it into my smartphone since I have a case on it which recesses the headphone port. Luckily there's enough clearance on the plug for me to get it in.Microphone Quality: Jostling the dongle while talking to people (say if you're running or repositioning it) only produces a mild disturbance. Transmit volume seems a bit on the low side so you might have to speak up a bit. Haven't had a chance to test in windy conditions.Update:I recommend looping this earbud around your ear. It helps reduce noise caused by the cable rubbing against your shirt,it makes the earbud less likely to be pulled out of your ear, and it moves the microphone dongle up to shirt-collar level which gives better audio quality.I wish they would have included a volume control on the dongle. The audio playback and call volume on my phones are a little mismatched so it would help if I could adjust it without having to fish around in my pocket for the volume buttons on the phone.The manual does not offer a complete list of controls, so I thought I'd compile my own here:During Podcast Playback (BeyondPod Podcast Manager):One Press - Pause and resumePress and Hold - Skip 30s forward in current songTwo Fast Press - Manual says is should skip to next track, however sometimes this works for me and sometimes it doesn't.Three Fast Press - Manual says is should skip to previous track, however sometimes this works for me and sometimes it doesn't.During Playback from Android Music App:One Press - Pause and resumePress and Hold - Next song in party shuffle playlist (works inconsistently)Two Fast Press - Skips to next track (works most of the time)Three Presses - Seems to just be considered as two fast presses and a single press. Haven't gotten it to do anything else.Incoming CallOne Press - Answer CallPress and Hold - Dismisses call. Caller will still hear ring tone until getting bumped to voicemail.During CallOne Press - Toggles mute on yourselfPress and Hold - Hangs up call

I've owned and listened to a lot of different speakers over the last decade.  I'm a fanatic about good sound.  What I like about the TSi100 Polks is that the price is very reasonable for the quality of sound they produce.  The bass really surprised me.  It's ample and very tight.  The 5-1/4 inch woofers in this speaker puts out bass like you might expect to hear coming out of a much larger 6-1/2 inch woofer.  I also like the fact that these speakers are reasonably efficient.  I'm driving my pair of Polks with a small AudioSource 25 watt per channel amp and they sound great in my small office.These might not be the speakers you want if you are into heavy metal and enormous amounts of bass.  They also are not the speaker to use for large rooms.  However, for small rooms and for listening to jazz, classical, acoustic and folk music at moderate sound levels these Polk speakers are fabulous.  Polk did a great job with this design.  Just be sure to put the TSI100s on speaker stands to get the best sound.  Don't put them on a bookshelf!
summary: Great Sounding Speakers at Reasonable Price

reviewText: I would love to rate this item higher but there are some serious flaws in its design. I ran three cables through it (2 HDMI and a coax) which turned out to be a snug fit. The biggest issue was that it was impossible to run the wires with the plate installed and when I did install it it was so deep and the opening was so narrow and awkwardly placed that it took me a good 15 minutes to angle and wrestle it into a position where I could screw it into the wall. Those cable won't even consider moving without taking the plates off again. It works, but barely. I would suggest finding something with a more shallow cable inset.
summary: Looks great but too deep and too narrow

reviewText: I am 6' tall and this monopod is perfect for my height.  The construction is solid and I like the twist style locking mechanism, it is quick and easy to adjust; I would expect this to last longer than the traditional fold over locking mechanism.  The weight is light, so it's not a bother to carry this for many hours.

I carry about $12,000 worth of camera gear in this and I couldn't feel safer.  This box is constructed nicely and is extremely sturdy.  I photograph Real Estate and therefore am always loading it up and it get banged around in my vehicle.  The latches are very secure and the hinges are very firm but it's easy to open the box.  I look at this box as the cheapest "insurance" that is on the market.  I know that it will last me for a very, very long time.  Dang worth the money.

Don't be fooled the the Big Box stores telling you that you must purchase expensive HDMI cables - it is just false. These work great - I used them with XBOX, PS3, 3D Blu Ray, HDTV - picture is always clean and great. The cables are high quality and will serve you well.

I have taken the time to review this product, being that I don't do it sometimes, however I will just say this product is great; its built so sturdy and feels strong, not weak, or afraid that it'll break. simple yet elegant design, again great craftsmanship...(sorry not fixing any grammatical errors lol)what else? Buy it, you wont be disappointed.
summary: I am a PLEASED CUSTOMER! Monster doesn't stand a chance

reviewText: Extremely cheap 150Mbps router that supports DD-WRT, when I got this router I had to power cycle it almost everyday for a week then I place DD-WRT on it and smooth sailing began. The router has been so stable and only had to power cycle it twice in the last few months, the range is okay and the speed is comparable to my Cisco router. If you know anything about DD-WRT and looking for an inexpensive router this is it, don't think just jump. Extremely great value!!!

These are the best earphones as far as sound reproduction, from my MP3 player that I have ever had.  But, my first day with them doing simple tasks, where I play my music to enjoy activities more, I was constantly pushing them back into my ears, both ears all of the time.  I was shopping in the market, and when I would bend over to get something one would just fall out.  I guess if you are going to be sitting and listening to music, these would be great to use.  You will not want them for any type of 'public' activity where you may have to move around, even at a slow deliberate pace.  Anyway, I had to return them, because they would not be useful for me to go to school with, or do any activity outside of the house, and even many inside.  I tried the wire around the ear also, but to no avail, ugh.
summary: Great sound reproduction, but, they will fall out of your ears.

reviewText: Sometimes it works, sometimes not. Not sure what the problem is. Not reliable. There are other remotes, just a bit more money, that are well worth the difference.

The Thermaltake docking station is a godsend for anyone that likes a lot of storage.  I build a new PC every couple of years and my wife also has a PC that's updated every 2 to 3 years.  Needless to say, with each new build come larger hard drives for the storage needed for larger photos, audio and video files.  This dock helps put the old drives to use.You hook this device up via either a USB or eSATA connection and once connected allows you to hot swap drives into the base unit, letting you read or write to the drives.  It's perfect for backing up your PC and it's also perfect for storing files you don't always need access to all the time.I've found this unit to be durable and reliable and has simply just worked the way it should out of the box.  Don't fret any size warnings as this unit has worked with any drive I've tried on it so far.  As long as your computer can read the drive if it was inserted directly into the PC it will read here.Bottom line is this is a must have for anyone with a lot of spare drives laying around!
summary: Perfect Device To Put Old Drives To Use

reviewText: Since this is my first background stand, I do not have much to compare it to, but I received my purchase yesterday and wasted no time in getting it out of the box and placing a muslin backdrop on it right in my living room.Each stand comes in it's own bag (as pictured in the stock photo). The crossbar does not have it's own bag but there is plenty of room to split it into two and put one in each bag for travel.I was very surprised at how lightweight the stands are, and then even more how sturdy they were once I got them set up. My 2 year old son was playing around them, driving his cars up one of them and they barely budged. The stand even held up with my son decided to lean against the backdrop.Assembly was simple. I did have to push one of the crossbar end pieces back into place, but that was minimal effort.The poles and crossbar are spring loaded and that makes adjustments really easy for even one person.I will be looking into other PBL products based on my purchase.

Chipset is Silicon Image bpe-220si (ver 1.2 for mine) (SiI3132)Drivers come with Windows 7 by Windows Update download, but you can get even newer drivers via the Silicon Image website.  Search for SiI3132.  There is no BIOS update that applies to this card.The card only uses a 1-lane PCI Express bus so it is limited to 2.5 GT/s which means even though it supports SATA IO II (3.0 gbps) drives you will take a 0.5 gbps hit in performance.  You won't notice for traditional rotational drives, but with SSD you could notice and would really want a Sata IO III (6.0 gbps) controller instead.Controller drivers do NOT support hot swapping a drive.  The normal Safely Eject/Remove Drive in Windows will NOT show your eSata drives.  If you put Windows in sleep mode and unplug then repower on you will have data corruption.  Furthermore the drivers/controller do NOT allow you to disable the write cache.  Windows will give you an error that it cannot change the settings for the device (drive).One option to get around this is a free software called HotSwap!  It has its own Safely Eject menu that forces the cache to flush and effectively disables the drive for safe removal.  You must eject the drive before you put the machine to sleep or anytime before you attempt to disconnect it.  It can be found via Google search on "HotSwap! mt-naka"
summary: Does not support hotswapping nor full SATA 3.0 gbps speeds

reviewText: I hear that this cable is good yet it was not long enough to run to my cadillac deville dts.

I purchased this item recently to use for my Glidecam HD2000, only to discover that the base of the unit is not Flat. If you intend to use it for Glidecam look for other products. I am going to purchase the Manfrotto 577 now with hope that it serves my purpose. The product itself is of quality though if you need to use it for tripod.

reviewText: After ordering this system advertised as "wireless", I found that it was indeed a "wired" system. Amazon has many other home theater systems listed as wireless, that are in fact not. Week later get a new ZP90 or so I think. Plug it in a it says it needs a software update?What the? You would think they would send it with this already done. I am 28 miles from a antenna farm with an average antenna output of 37 decibels (that is how the signal strength is measured), and with a $50 radio shack indoor amplified antenna I can get about 15 channels, but have to increase gain for some and lower it for others-a pain (too high of gain and the TV can not use the signal, same as for too low of a signal, and get the same message from the TV for both "programming not available"). The Winegard tech support was excellent in helping me and describing the ins and outs of antennas and DTV signals. Put it in my attic using the Winegard mounting bracket (well worth the $17, heavy duty). Now this antenna is 11' long, so I assembled it in the attic between the upright supports (angled towards the antenna farm). Then turned it on edge and slipped it through the upright support 2 x 4's to center it on one 2x4 before turning it back to level. The upright support 2x4 in the middle of the antenna was where I put the support bracket. Then ran a 50' cable to the TV, rescanned for channels and got 37 crystal clear DTV channels at 99-100% signal strength!!! And because the antenna is not amplified, I do not need to adjust the gain. Many channels are in 1080 and as clear as a blueray movie. Very good construction and made in the US. Note: my roof has shingles and decreases signal by 50%, so original 37 decibel signal becomes 18.5 decibels; 50' of cable cuts out 25% of signal so signal is down to ~14 decibels at the TV. You need 6 decibels for a perfect picture. Welcome to free DTV and lots of great non-violent programing that you do not get on cable! The DTV signal is sensitive to things in the line of sight including trees, roofs (shingles, barrel tiles are worse), than an analogue signal, so take that into account when picking out your antenna. tvfool.com has a lot of very useful information, you can input your address and find which antennas are close to you and what is their direction and signal strength. I went for a directional antenna because the antenna farm was all that I wanted to get.

I wanted to add some outdoor zones to my yard without the expense of additional amplifiers/receivers. reviewText: I've forgotten to get around to writing this review, and figured that now was as good a time as any to write up a few notes on this camera.I purchased this camera from Nikon over 3 1/2 years ago, and since then have shot more than 35,000 images, and it still works as well as the day I pulled it out of the box.I did add the MB-D80, as I have very large hands, and also like having two batteries and a dedicated vertical hand-grip. The kit lens is awesome, not the fastest aperture in the world but the 18-105mm coverage allows it to work equally well in wide-angle through moderate telephoto.I've never had issues with it locking up or refusing to work with off-brand SD cards, and know that I will continue using this camera for years to come. I'm thinking about upgrading to a D7000, but this D90 is going to be staying in my bag forever.
summary: An amazing camera that does everything I ask of it, every time.

reviewText: Like most variable aperture zoom lenses, this will definitely serve its purpose and provide good shots across its range. Some focal lengths will be better than others and you'll be content with the image quality. What I had to accept about my various variable aperture lenses was this, I was always content with my shots and in awe of other people's shots. Their shots were almost always taken with prime or at least fixed aperture lenses. I've upgraded most of my lenses to F/2.8 or F/1.8 lenses and am now VERY VERY PLEASED with most of my shots! Let me be extremely clear, work within your budget and know how to work with the shutter speed, aperture and ISO of this or any other lens before you blame yourself or the camera...its probably a matter of finding the right setting or knowing the limitations of your lens.
summary: Very Usable Lens...Buy Wider Aperture if Funds Permit

reviewText: It s a nice price for a noise cancelling headphone.Pros.Noise Cancelling Tech worksCan be reduced to a small package for easy carrying around.Cons.is a bit cheap looking

I also own the predecessor, CX300B, which are one of the best earbuds available in my humble opinion.Since they have become a bit yucky after over a year of heavy use, and I lost one of the earpieces a few weeks ago, I thought it was time to replace them with the newer model. Also, the MkII version promises better, fuller bass transmission, which was also a reason for me to buy them. Fact is that the MkIs do sound a bit thin with my Microsoft Zune player (yes, there were actually real people who bought the Zune instead of the iPod ...) - which is not the earbud's fault, not at all. So, I expected a boost in bass, more oomph, less tin-can, and just a better sound overall. Well, yeah, kind of the MkIIs do that. But the difference is not that pronounced as I had expected. Let's face it, the Zune just sucks in the sound department, and no headset/earbuds in the world can change that.Next, I mated the earbuds to my very old Sandisk MP3-player from 2008 (four years - what a difference ...), and was equally disappointed. Thin, shrieky and only after heavy manipulation of the onboard equalizer, I was able to generate a tolerable sound.Then, I tried the MkIIs on my trusted old Sony MP3-Walkman (2010 vintage) - WOW!Like standing right in front of the band! Clear, powerful, transparent sound with full basses and overall a very distinctive progress over the MkI model.That was exactly what I had in mind when I bought the MkIIs.My little field-study showed, at least in my opinion, that you need a high-quality player to really take advantage of these earbuds. But with such a player, they are worth every Penny in Gold.
summary: Great sound - if you have the right player

reviewText: I have been using these mice (mouses?) since 1999, maybe earlier.I do not like the two little buttons on the big ones, but they no longer make them without those...and even when told to do nothing, they still affect things..my issue with these is the inability to take it apart...some kind of glue or snap prevents it from being taken apart..and in time the buttons fail due to dirt and start double clicking...and I have to chuck em out...if i could take it apart i could clean it..so...2 to 3 stars....too bad... After I opened the box and examined the pieces I had to assemble, I shook my head thinking it would be a chore, but after grabbing my phillips screwdriver it was easy. The instruction wording is confusing and I really think the words are unnecessary, but once you do some hands-on assembly, they become clear. I first tried hooking it up to my 21" HDTV, nothing happened, then I realized I forgot to do a new search for local channels in the menu. Then channels appeared on my screen perfectly clear (HD and SD). Most channels are stable and with minimal signal drops, but there is one local station (channel 8) that this antenna just won't pick up and neither will any other antenna I have around. I guess this station just has an awfully weak transmitting tower.Now I receieve stations like METV, LINKTV, and RETROTV which I think in all honesty, beat any channel I receieve on satellite. I love old TV shows and movies, and I'd pick them over any of today's over-dramatized programs.Anyway, if you want to pull in local stations, this flying saucer-shaped indoor antenna will do the trick, just don't expect to pull in stations further out than 40 miles. Plus, the flat design makes it easy to place on top of your TV or hang on the wall. It actually works better than the rabbit ears I have sitting next to my bedroom TV where I sometimes experience signal drops, and of course it takes up less space. You also can't beat the price.

reviewText: Great update from standard ATT Motorola modem, very easy to setup, works great so far....Just follow quick start guide book and that's it. I connected it in 5 minutes. All green lights are solid green, does not even blink, works well, half price then a regular modem and twice better, good deal !NOTE for ATT users:  when you setup connection to configure modem you will be on the page where it asks PPP username - usually your email, and PPP password - HERE,  make sure that you put NETWORK password, (3 letters and 3 digit, not the one you use for att email account)

reviewText: I bought this from a pawn shop for $199.99 to extend my three other stereo systems to the kitchen via Apple's Airport Express ($50 used), and so that my wife could listen to the radio/CDs while she grades papers/cooks/etc. This worked perfectly as I could fit an amp and cd player inside of the cabinet above our range, and place the speakers and woofer on top of the cabinets, with the woofer behind a large picture frame leaning against the wall and the L/R speakers on-top of our cabinets discretely in the corners. It is invisible because of the way I hid everything, and guests often ask where this great sound is coming from.For me this works as a non-primary stereo solution.I knocked three stars off for the following reasons:The "Accoumass" is a woofer, not a subwoofer. It is also not powered by its own amp. You are taking what is essentially a pair of two-way speakers, ripping out the woofers and hiding both of them together somewhere in your room.This is not a "powerful" stereo. As with all things Bose, if you want high quality sound, there are way better - way cheaper solutions for such things. Yet, even as a Bose system it's poor, and if you are looking for an experience similar to what you see in a demo at the mall, you will be disappointed.The price I see today of $428.88 is obscene.

UPDATE 9/9/13Remote still works fine. I still hate the contour of it though and I have modified it with tape and cardboard (which is fine for being my bedroom remote haha). I'd look for another one next time, ergonomics being the only reason. I'd buy it again if I couldn't find one that is more comfortable and just as functional.--------I guess I'm the odd man out, because I am probably going to return this remote. It works great and I have no problems with any of its functions. 3.5 stars.What I do not like is the layout of the buttons, and the contour of the bottom of the remote.My main gripe of the two is the contour of the bottom of the remote. The bottom half is very thick (beneath the numerical keypad), which is fine. But about halfway up the remote it becomes very thin. The remote tends to slide downward in my hand due to this, and getting back to the number pad requires either some wiggly action, or a second hand. This thing just wants to slide around too much. It's a really weird design, unlike any other remote I've ever used.The remote is also very wide. It is wider than every other remote in my house (including DTV) and I have a lot of them. I don't understand why they designed it so wide. It's also rather ugly, but aesthetics plays no part in this review.I sometimes hit the wrong button when going for the volume control. In the dark it's hard to distinguish them. The backlight is nice. I'm also not used to having the volume button up near the top. Once I slide up to it, the remote wants to continue sliding (I hold the remote somewhat vertically because I use this particular one while in bed).I really like the way this remote works but I will probably try another model. This is an awesome remote for the price, It's just wrapped in a very unergonomical package.3.5 stars total. Five for functionality, two for ergonomics and layout. I'll try it for a little while longer and update this review.
summary: Great Functionally, Poor Ergonomics And Layout

reviewText: I returned the $31 Terk after several days of trial because the tuning knob was in an inconvenient spot for how I need to position the antenna.  The tuning knob on this and the Grundig antennae are more conveniently located.Also, this Kaito is $9 cheaper that the Terk - and the bonus:  it works at least as well on the station I wanted to receive and better on the upper AM frequencies than the Terk.And finally, the solid platform base of this Kaito is more convenient to use in a variety of locations than the "style over function" spread leg designs of other models.The only downside is the cable that came with this antenna designed to connect the radio and antenna has bare leads on one end and the mini phone plug on the other.  The instructions that came with it show a mini phone plug on BOTH ends, and a photo shows the lead connected to the AM antenna on the same Grundig 750 I own, which requires a mini phone plug to connect it.If Kaito honors my request for a cable with phone plugs on BOTH ends, I will modify this review to 5 stars.

Needed a solution to use 2.5" ssds in an HP server tower with non hot swappable hard drive bays.  Do to the form factor, each bay is sized exactly for 3.5" drives and has to line up perfect when slid in.  After wasting a few hours trying to mold a solution from a 2.5" to 3.5" metal bay converter, I gave up and bought this product.  Within 10 seconds, I slid open the enclosure, popped in the ssd, and closed it up (which snaps the ssd into place, No screws needed).  This was a perfect solution to my problem, but if you just need an 2.5" to 3.5" bay converter for a standard desktop, anything will work.

I bought these wrappers mainly to go with a few ear buds I own. I usually throw my buds in my bag and they get tangled up with everything else.While these cord wrappers help with the tangled mess, they also make the headphone wire curled when you unwind them for listening purposes, which is annoying.I don't know if I specifically like using them for my ear buds, but they work very well for the extra wired attachment that I received with mySennheiser PXC 360 BT Bluetooth Headset with Noiseguaurd 2.0 SRS WOW HD (Black), which is a super long cord.I can see these working well with theBose QuietComfort 15 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphonesas well because they also have a super long cord.The cords seems a little rough to get into the grip slots, which I can see causing some wear and tear on your headphone's wire connections in the long run.These wrappers are great for the price and you can also tilt your iPhone upward if you leave the cord attached and place the wrapper under the the phone. I will take a picture and show you what I mean later on.I currently am still using this cord organizer for my buds, but I foresee me throwing them back in the bag at some point in the near future because it is easier and faster to do that then to wind them up on these wrappers every time I want to store and use them.

I purchased this item to complete the installation of a roof top wireless internet service on a multi-unit, condo residential building. There was no possible way to bring down the requisite Ethernet line from the roof however, there were coax lines pre-installed for use with satellite dish antennas. So, using this device I converted the Ethernet from the antenna to Coax, installed a weatherproof enclosure with power on the roof to power both the wireless antenna and one side of this coax converter pair. The other coax converter unit was installed in the customer's unit. The result worked great.We required a unit that would pass ALL Ethernet frames and we confirmed through testing that this unit will pass regular (untagged) and VLAN (tagged) Ethernet traffic transparently. So if you are looking for a converted to setup a 100M Ethernet link over a coax line that will pass both tagged and un-tagged Ethernet frames - this is the unit. Good value for the money.
summary: Works like a charm - even for VLANs

reviewText: Far and away the cheapest warranties for your stuff (especially through Amazon), and they are pleasant to work with.  Warranty info shows up in hours via email, and their website is actually pretty user friendly.  You scan or fax your receipt and they'll keep it on file for you to make it even easier.  As long as they keep up such great service, I'll keep buying their warranties.

My APC Back-UPS ES 550 started making a loud horrible alarm type noise. So I unplugged it. And looked up the problem online. Seems I needed to either replace the whole unit (around $60) or replace the battery. This battery did the trick and for only $16.99 + $7 S&H = $23.99. Item arrived in six days. It was very easy to replace the battery. Now my Back-UPS works fine!

I'll give you the skinny instead of the numbers details. I have been wanting this thing for a while but was not sure if it would fit in my LIAN LI PC-V354. I decided to bite the bullet and take a chance. This HSF DOES fit inside the LIAN LI PC-V354. It clears the power supply by mere millimeters, but it DOES clear it. My computer is MUCH cooler and quieter with this HSF.I was running a stock cooler on my first gen AMD Phenom 9550. The stock HSF was keeping it adequately cool at about 45-50c, but the fan was screaming between 5-7k RPMs. It was a nightmare. This thing keeps it from the high 20s to mid 30s Celsius and the fan only spins at about 2200RPMs to accomplish that. It is MUCH quieter.I have used this HSF before for other customers but this is the first time using it for myself. It's cool, it's quiet, MUCH better than stock, and does not require additional retention brackets to install. It was a little hard to install because of the cramped space inside my LIAN LI PC-V354, but other than that I highly recommend this HSF.

Previously, I have always bought the silicone soft cases for my phones and mp3 players.  However, due to the need for thin edges, they would often come partially off when I pulled the devise from my pocket.  I decided to try this one this time.  I was concerned because several reviews stated it was near impossible to get the cover on (personally, I took that as a good sign, since I can't stand loose covers).  Others complained on it making the track wheel hard to use and/or sticking to the view screen.  These all may be known "problems" as the instructions addressed each one of these.  Mine, however, went on with no trouble and fits perfectly.  The sensetivity of the track wheel is slightly diminished but not enough to create a problem.  In fact, I find the slight reduction in sensitivity a plus.  Fiannly, I did experience the screen stick once.  But, I followed the directions for fixing it and haven't had a problem since. So why not 5 stars?  Because the ipod will not fit into its dock with the case on.  This has been a problem with every cover I have used, so maybe a star reduction isn't fair.... Oh, yeah, although this doesn't affect anything, I like that the case is transparent.  Under certain light, especially on the back of the ipod, the case has a purple/brownish tint. It is subtle. I like it, but you may not.

I read a few complaints in the reviews but I assumed that these were people running serious gaming rigs or maybe their case was at fault, but I installed these two fans after 2 much louder (and cheaper) ones on my case.  At idle I had been looking at 37-39 Celsius with just one side intake fan running.  It was a $5 fan that I got off Amazon, a Cooler Master 80mm dual ball bearing fan.  I replaced it with an 80mm side intake and a 120mm rear exhaust fan, both SilverStone Ultra quiet fans and with both of them running I'm looking at maybe 43-45 Celsius at idle.  They're completely silent, but if I put my hand in front of either one of them I can barely feel any air movement.  Sadly, without any side intake or rear exhaust fans I'm looking at 46-47 Celsius at idle.update:I disconnected the thermometers attached to both fans.  They move noticeable amounts of air now, but are also louder.  Not nearly as loud as the Cooler Master 80mm mentioned above, but both 80 and 120mm Silverstone fans combined I'm looking at about 38-40 Celsius at idle at 62-64 under heavy load.  So they aren't horrible, but certainly can do better.  A large Zalman cooler will do more to cool the CPU, I havent checked the temps of the HDD's so I don't know if it's cooling them much or not.
summary: It's silent, but only when it isn't moving air

reviewText: I'm on my 3rd G9x. After 6 to 12 months of use, either the left or the right button wears out to the point that when you click-and-hold it will randomly register that you released the button when you didn't. The workaround is to press the button closer to the base instead of near the tip.  I had the same exact problem with a few G9/G5/G500 mice before that.  The larger size and longer buttons make it more vulnerable to the bending and wearing out of the plastic in the buttons.I've used a lot of mice for gaming, and this is definitely the best.  It has really high DPI.  The great thing about having high DPI is that you never have to increase mouse sensitivity in software. Increasing sensitivity in windows essentially makes the mouse skip pixels and be less accurate (but in-game mouse sensitivity settings are okay if they store the view angles as a floating point numbers).So Logitech has this obvious flaw in their product, but I keep buying it, because there is no better mouse.

This is a great flash for the price.  It works as a slave and on a hotshoe basis.  I have purchased three of them.  The only thing is do not drop it, the base breaks very easily.  That happened to me but now I am using it as a hand held slave.  Would recommend for anyone

I recently purchased the AWUS036H to replace my TL-WN722N in hopes to increase my signal strength and link quality. The first thing i did was download the drivers from the Alfa website. This was quite a pain because the FTP servers were offline so i couldn't even download the drivers. After waiting 30 minutes it was back online and i sat threw a 20 minute download because their servers were lagging. The installation was good, it also installs a utility which may be useful if you would like to check signal strength, link quality and throughput.At first i was amazed to see every signal i was able to get before, now has a signal of either 4 or 5 bars. It was basically a green light show. The signal i was connecting to had a RSSI of about -50 to -60, which was a vast improvement over the -80 to -90 i was getting before. Something felt a bit off though... i was unable to connect to the wifi network even though i was "magically" getting a signal twice as good. After running the utility i noticed the signal was good, but the link quality was extremely low at about 20-30%. With some adjusting i was able to find a location that was giving me around 50-70% link quality and i was able to connect now. After a few days i experienced a link quality that was all over the place. One minute i would get good speeds, the next i would get not so good speeds. No matter what i did i just could not get a proper link quality.The adapter is very light but feels rather cheap, definitely treat it with care. I found the omni and panel antennas to perform about the same. Although with the panel if you take the time to pinpoint the direction, you can achieve a better connection. The antenna cup could be useful depending on your situation.After using the adapter for a few days i decided to just plug in my TL-WN722N and use it with the panel antenna that came with this package. Readings were around -80 to -86 RSSI but i was getting a much more stable connection. Downloads, browsing and gaming were all faster. This seems a bit odd because i was getting a better connection with 2 bars opposed to 4-5. After doing a bit more research on the problem some people report the 1000mw adapter might actually be too strong for certain connections and causes interference. Personally i feel like the readings this adapter claims to receive might be inflated in some way. Whatever the case, i get better performance using an adapter half the price of this Alfa unit. At least the panel came in handy, but i would have rather just bought the panel and saved $35. I am not saying this adapter is bad, many people make reviews about how amazing it is. For me it did not perform.
summary: Better signal but lower link quality

reviewText: The 36H is one of ALFA's more dependable antennas, but by no means its most powerful. However, I have had one fail on me. In fact of the seven ALFA antennas I have bought over the last five years, all have failed on me except one of the two of these I have owned. I have had three 36NHR's fail and two 36NH's fail, along with a 36H. One 36NHR crashed my computer big time and a major rebuild of the hard drive was necessary. Another NHR also crash my computer but less work was necessary to recover it. The NH's simply failed with minor complications. One 36H failed with no complications. I have switched to the Crane antenna III which is in route. I am told it is much more reliable, less problematic, but also much more expensive ($99). I consider ALFA antennas undependable and the NHR positively dangerous to your equipment.

I really like the Microsoft Wired Desktop 600 but make sure you get the one listed on Amazon WITHOUT the mouse for $10 lessMicrosoft Wired Keyboard 600 (Black)rather than this listingMicrosoft Wired Desktop 600 (Black)WITH the mouse.The mouse is either defective or extremely poor design.  The mouse actually weighs less than the attached cord!  Mouse design is supposed to be such that the mouse sits on your tabletop and the cord is attached and may or may not actually rest in places on the table top.  HOWEVER, the one that came to me from Amazon in this order the cord would lay on the table top with the mouse not flat on the table and just a normal ocean breeze would knock it off the tabletop.  It is hard to imagine that Microsoft would not know that the mouse needs to be heavier than the cord so maybe mine was defective.  However, all the other reviews are discussing how lightweight the mouse is so I do not know.I do really like the keyboard so I would recommend saving the $10 and purchasingMicrosoft Wired Keyboard 600 (Black)without the mouse and getting a good mouse such asKensington Pro Fit Full-Size Mouse USB/PS2 (K72369US)which works very well for me.What do I like about the keyboard?  Well, first of all I like that it feels, looks, and responds like adult office equipment unlike some keyboards that seem more like a child's toy.  I like that the keyboard keys have rounded edges close to each other so that the keys are larger and easier to press/rest without getting poked by sharp edges.  I like the volume up/down, mute, and pause/play buttons.  I appreciate the hotkeys for calculator, print screen, scroll lock, pause, and windows toggle as well as the full 12 function keys one typically sees on keyboards.This keyboard is very good and an excellent value
summary: Fantastic Keyboard but mouse either bad design or defective

reviewText: Let me startby saying, I did not know what I was getting. I read the reviews and saw works good and is quiet.This is true I have to agree that so far it works great and is extreemly quiet.My gripe is the lousy installation instuctions and included hardware.The manual sucks and the way it shows to install the fan, requires that motherboard be removed from the case.I did this. I followed the instructions in the owners manual, I used the included hardware and it did not work!!!after multiple attemps to install I went to the website and watched the install video, it was almost as bad as the manual.There was one extra piece of info in the video that was not in the manual. It shows using the factory fan mount and using a providedlatch to mount the fan. I reinstalled the factory mount and then the fan. If this tidbit had been in the manual it would have taken about 15 minutes to complete.The fan itself is huge, I was not expecting a cooler of this size, looking at the picture on the website it does not appear to be a giant.this was not a problem my case is large enough. I will say it does look impressive, I would almost like to have one on the desktop just to give myself a cool breeze.After the install fiasco I am pleased with operation of the cooler and how quiet it is. That is the reason I bought it for anyway.The AMD factory fan drove me insane.

reviewText: I've never used headphone amplifiers before and didn't want to break the bank to satisfy my curiosity.  I use the FiiO E5 with a pair of Sennheiser HD201 and Shure SRH440 headphones. I'm sure there are better products out there, but overall I am satisfied with the E5 and would recommend it.I primarily use the E5 and my Shure SRH440's with my iPod Nano, iPhone 4s and Gateway NV79 laptopPros-Noticable volume difference/increase, great improvement on Bass boost-Really adds depth to Hip-Hop, Metal and Electronica types of songs-Small Compact, light weight-Competitive Price-Light notifies you when device is charged-Excellent battery lifeCons-Does not improve clarity for all signal levels, especially noticable on certain acoustic guitar songs, symphony scores and classical music-Does not come with a wall charger-Doesn't always play nice with device EQ

I owned a Sennhesiser hd570 for about 12 years (had since college) and about a years or so the sound quality started to dissipate badly.  The bass that was once strong got loose and the high or treble was cracking, I was getting ear fatigue.  I wanted to try anther brand like Grado, which I consider 12 years ago, but after reading all the reviews here on amazon took a leap of fate and just got it.  I couldn't be happier, it is exactly like my Senn 570 but better.  I took my old ipod into a Magnolia HiFi and tested theGrado Prestige Series SR325isandSennheiser HD 598.  The Grado easy has extreme high and treble or what some people might call bright, Sennheiser is has a tad more bass and over warmth feeling in the bass.  I do like techno, classic, some rock, basically everything, so i need a balanced headphone.  Grado would kill my ear in techno if I listen too long, Senn didn't have the detail I heard in the Grado 325.  Well I do believe, but 100% correct since I don't have a 325 or 598 to test right now, but I believe this headphone is between the 2.  Almost as bright detail as Grado and a tighter bass of the Senn, perfect.  I haven't even burn in the cone, and it sound good the first time I put it on.  I think the Senn 590 took awhile too and like 6 years ago it was at it peak.Sound quality:I prefer open-air headphones like in Senn, Grado and Akg.  I dislike the close sound of the power bass of Bose, Sony, beat by Dr. dre. While the sound is good it feels like I am in a cave.  I might considerBowers & Wilkins P5which is another bass emphasis headphone if I had a work headphone and needs privacy.The AKG high and mid excel for techno music like Armin Van Buuren, the bass is tight but not overwhelming (nor does it crack like the old 570), I can heard the vocal as the Senn 570.  The high ambient is sharp and clear.  For classic like Bob Acri- sleep away (free in window vista) the drum and bass, piano score are all excellent again. For example JaRule's let ride, the bass is tight, but isn't as powerful or warmth/full as one of those Beat by Dre, or Bower headphone.  But I don't listen to hip hop that much, just for reference.  Soft rock or vocal like Julee Cruise- Summer Night sounds great.  I be honest, why I don't give a 5 stars to this 702 is it sound very much like the Senn 570 back at peak period, except the 702 is a little clear and sharper toward Grado.  SO overall it is my favorite balance of high, mid and low that I was looking for long period of listening before ear fatigue creeps in.Build quality:it is almost exactly like my old 150 dollar hd570, the only noticeable exception is the headband is a tad tight.  Wished it was long or so.  The velvet foam cushion is like the 570, the detachable cord is the same concept.  Both are mostly plastic, bu the AKG band is a little different and also a tad heavier.  I give it a 4/5 stars too, because it is a tad tight and I notice it as wear it all the time.  Hopefully it loosen up over the years.  Cable is 2x as thick as the Senn.If somebody prefer the bright sound of grado, or the more bass of the senn, it is all good headphone.  I wish I had a bower for bass, senn as I am a fan of them, but if I had to pick one that I think sound the best overall to the music I like then it must be this 702.  for the record this headphone does not spasm-out on the bass like the senn 570 for enigma's Eppur Si Muove.  My favorite cd right nowSaturdays = Youth [+Digital Booklet] passed on all 3 sound levels with this set of cans.
summary: Best set of cans I used

reviewText: I purchased this DVD player after reading reviews and wasn't too sure about it.  As most of the comments stated, the FM Transmitter is horrible!!  You have to turn your radio up almost all the way to hear anything out of it.  And even then, the static in the sound is just horrible!  I have 2 older IR headphones that my kids use, but even then, they have a noticeable hum! Other than the sound, the lights on the unit turn on by themselves!!  I came out to my Suburban in the morning and found the lights ON...  when I open the door, they turn off...  quite annoying!  Thinking about returning it for a different brand/model.  Other than that, installation was a breeze and the video quality is great!!--------UPDATE 9/23/2012--------I have contacted Amazon for a replacement on this DVD player!  The unit quit working ENTIRELY!!!  The only thing that still works, is the ONE annoying blue light that dims, then brightens at night while your driving!!  When I receive my new player, I won't be connecting the lights!  They never worked correctly from the beginning.  I contacted Pyle's Customer Service about the issue, and they told me how to wire the lights...  DUH!  I already had the lights connected, YOUR people somehow messed that up!!A replacement is on it's way, and hopefully this one will be better!  Unfortunately, I have to buy a direct connect box for my '02 Suburban to get any kind of decent sound without turning my radio to the max!!--------UPDATE 12/9/2012--------A replacement arrived a while ago for this DVD player!  Just now getting to updating my review! The new player works GREAT!!  I would definitely take it over the $700 one that was installed into my Mini-Van when I purchased it!!  The one thing that I recommend... do NOT hook up the lights that are in the player!!!!!!  The lights are what initially caused the static disturbance in the radio!  The FM Transmitter built in works fine, just don't hook up the lights!!!

This is a great bargain for mounting mid-sized TV's.  I needed to mount a 32" LED TV in my bedroom that only weighs 14 pounds.  Because the VESA standard accounts for heavy plasma TV's, 32" requires 200x200 format.  Most of the expensive mounts in the store that would do 200x200 weighed more than the TV itself!  So I tried this one out and it did work well eventually.  However, I did have to make make one modification to use the 200x200 configuration.  The holes are there in the bracket for the 200x200 layout BUT they are not big enough for the screws typically used in a TV with 200x200 mounting holes.  A little quick work with a drill enlarged the holes and everything was fine after that.  It sits very close to the wall, too, so make sure that you order HDMI cables that do not have a large choke ring or you may have trouble getting them behind the TV after it's mounted.
summary: Decent Mount, but Some Modification Required for Big TV's

reviewText: This product works as advertised.  I had trouble with installation and would like to pass along a tip.  I installed the drivers for the printer on each of my computers and then installed the switch software.  A shortcut icon came up on the desktop but no symbol in the task tray.  I double clicked the desktop shortcut and nothing happened.  I decided to reinstall but was told that the process was running.  Simple mistake...the symbol for the switch was hidden and when I configured the task tray to show the switch icon, clicking on the tray icon gave me the drop down menu and everything worked.  This is common in windows 7 but there were no warnings in the instructions.  I deleted the worthless shortcut on the desktop and used the task tray icon as described in the instructions without problems.

I purchased this router because, at the time, it was $60 while all others were +$100. I read the reviews, I found it weird that it was so much cheaper. Disconnects were the biggest issue among the reviews. Why did I think it wouldn't affect me?Well, this router disconnects wireless a LOT. There are three types.The first type is the wireless drop. There will be no wireless signal, it will not show up in the list of routers available.The second type is the internet drop. There will be a wireless connection, but the internet will not work.The third type is the no-connection drop. Bring a friend's laptop over? Buy a new laptop? They can't connect. That's right, the signal will show up five bars, the password is right, but the laptop can't connect. At the moment, I know this happens to HP Envys.The WIRED connection has no problems, even with the above two drops.The router connects 1 wired computer and 3 wireless. Paying top dollar for a router shouldn't have such results.

First, let me say that I purchased this product to protect the palm rest area of my MBA, and really didn't care about the trackpad protection. The color matching is excellent and it blends extremely well. Fits with my incipio feather ultralight without issue.My only gripe is with the trackpad protector. I am a huge "tap to click" fan and enabling tap to click is the first thing i do with any mac laptop that i interact with. With the trackpad protector installed, tap to click does not work. Tracking worked fine and engaging the "button" of the trackpad was not hindered in any way. I just can't live without my tap to click. Upon discovery of this, the trackpad protector was removed immediately.5 stars for the palm rest protection1 star for trackpad functionI am very happy with this product, but the trackpad protector is going in the trash.

I ordered three of theseVideoSecu Day Night Vision CCTV Infrared Home Security Cameravia amazon.com for our home video surveillance system.Video Quality - 6/10:- The video quality from these cameras are almost comparable to todays average webcams.- You can see things moving in the picture, but the details of the pictures are pretty blurry unless you're within a few feet of the camera.- It's really hard to see faces and plate numbers of cars unless they're up close to it.- Colors comes out great from this camera, but nothing too fancy.- Wide angle lens practically covers our entire backyard.Infrared Quality - 6/10:- It just works! Things can still be clearly seen in pitch black darkness from about 50 feet away and also depending on ambient light.- Switches to infrared automatically when it senses that its getting too dark.Build Quality - 9/10:- Entire camera and housing is rock solid metal.- Housing may be hard to adjust/turn, but a little bit of WD-40 (or any other lube) does the trick.Overal Recommendation - 4/5 Stars:- If you're looking for cheap BNC camera dome solutions (video quality is sub-par, but build quality is excellent).- If yon't require the ability of reading plate numbers or clear pictures of peoples faces.- So far these cameras have been running for two weeks straight without stop and still holding up to everything including the weather.- Don't place the camera where there would be a lot of reflections as it would cause the infrared lights to bounce off of it.- Unboxing is simple. Comes with a cute little sticker for security surveillance. Installation is straightforward.- Does not come with BNC cable (but has BNC connections on the camera). Also comes with power supply (not required if running with BNC cable (power and video cable)).Installed without a problem with our LOREX ECO2 8CH DVR.

I have purchased this to share a DVI monitor between my two computers, one being a laptop with a DisplayPort output, and the other - a desktop with DVI output. It's a well-known fact that both DisplayPort++ and DVI are fully compatible with the HDMI standard (only video signal is transmitted for DVI, of course), and a small, passive adapter works well in either case.The following combo works perfectly with my Netgear HDMI switch (GCS1792):1st laptop: DisplayPort++ output, DisplayPort to HDMI passive adapter, HDMI cable to the Netgear HDMI switch2nd computer: DVI output, DVI-to-HDMI passive adapter, HDMI cable to the Netgear HDMI switchNetgear HDMI switch: HDMI cable and an HDMI-to-DVI adapter on the monitor endWhen I've replaced the switch (that costs around $200) with this tiny box that was supposed to do the same thing at my workplace, NOTHING worked. That is, the red led was on (and pointed to the right device), and everything seemed to be working, but I couldn't get the picture displayed on the shared monitor despite doing all required things. The same was true of the second computer with a DVI output and a DVI-to-HDMI adapter.Still, when I decided to check the hardware itself and connected this tiny box between my wife's tablet PC with an HDMI output, and an HDMI cable going to her monitor, everything worked perfectly. As far as the monitor is connected through an HDMI to DVI adapter, looks like there are no problems with adapters on the Output end.So it seems the box has problems when the input is converted to HDMI from either DVI or DisplayPort. A disappointment: the cheapskate has lost again. But it's a cheap disappointment, though :-)
summary: Doesn't work with either DisplayPort-to-HDMI or DVI-to-HDMI adapters for me

Despite what others have said, nothing I did could get Windows 7 to see the IR receiver. Instead, it kept listing it as a USB mouse. Manually installing the hardware as an IR receiver didn't work either as windows was unable to find any drivers that would work with it. There appears to be a known bug that only windows 7 updates (not clean installs) will load drivers for IR receivers. After many hours of trying to find a way to get it to work (not easy given the utter lack of support on the product manufacturer's website) I finally gave up and returned it to Amazon for a refund. Microsoft lists which IR receivers are compatible with Windows 7. This is not one of them. Save your money.

I heard the BOSE version of this style product but could not afford $300, so tried this $50 version.1st: the battery cover is flimsy: it was difficult to snap on and I was afraid I was going to break it.2nd: the stream was horrible. Maybe I got a lemon, but every 2 or three seconds the sound would stop and then start again... very irritating.3rd: the blinking blue night is also a huge irritation! Stop the blinking and make it steady.------------------My wallet said, "SPRACHT!!!" when it coughed up the dough for this toy.

To set your expectations right from the beginning the great tool is the website tvfool-dot-com . Go there and see what stations you can realistically receive with different antennas.I live in Salem, OR and the target trasmitter for me is in Portland - 48 miles away.TVfool predicts about 25 stations in the line-of-sight (LOS), with 8 strong enough for indoor antenna.First I bought in a local store one of those flat Ipad-like omniderectional amplified indoor antennas. It was able to pull in 4-5 major stations and then a few strongest analog independents, more or less consistent with TVfool report. The cutoff seemed to be about 50 dB of noise margin (NM) which left out 3 major networks with NM in 45-50 dB in VHF HI band and a whole lot of weaker independent stations. I just wanted those missing PBS, NBC and FOX channels, therefore I bought this antenna.Set it up on the outside wall with 30 ft of RG6 cable directly to TV. That gave me more than 15 channels (not counting all the decimal subchannels)and all the major HD ones come in clear and loud. The cutoff for the worst signal with this antenna appears to be about 25 dB NM - that's the lowest station on the TVfool list that I could identify. Very impressive - 25 dB improvement over amplified room antenna! And it beats the advertised distance of 40 miles handily.I managed not to break the transformer-balun thingy, but still bought on Ebay a good quality one (Channelmaster brand) as a spare. I am going to install it anyway - probably would make the signal even better.Overall very happy, despite one nut missing from the hardware pack. This antenna does it job, is not an eyesore and costs only a little more than an indoor antenna.
No camera-lens communication, no auto focus. This lens is capable of producing amazing images IF you take your time with it.

Forget the incredibly low price; it has no bearing on the quality sound of these speakers. Speakers costing 5 to 10 times as much don't sound as good as these little cans. Altec Lansing hit the winner circle here; for adding speakers to a computer or bedroom tv, these little speakers are perfect - they can be placed most anywhere, and they sound great - and if you do consider the price in the mix, then they sound fantastic.

Solid bass and overall amazing sound quality. After that...they just stopped working. The audio in the left bud got all scratchy and distorted. And from the beginning, the microphone never even worked. I was seriously disappointed with them. I may have just gotten a random bad pair tho...who knows.

I noticed because i'm a gamer, parents and others didn't notice till i showed them.Negatives-jittery hand motion thru sensor-gyro motion slightly off (still able to play bowling fine)-battery cover doesn't fit tightly, jiggles around a bit but stays on fine and works with AA batteries-using rechargeable batter pack doesn't work, the batter compartment isn't tight enough so it won't get powered (see above statement)Positives-Much cheaper, around 30 bucks cheaper (perfect for kids that break stuff, or if u need a second remote that won't be used often)-I personally like the wrist strap better as it doesn't clip, making it easy to switch people in bowlingWe shall keep this remote and just use rechargeable AA batteries, because it works well enough for the games we play.

reviewText: I get tired of the constant remote juggling in my living room between four separate remotes. I have a fancier universal remote, but I just don't like it and it drains batteries far too fast. I was excited about this remote and sat down to program it only to be disappointed. It worked out of the package with my cable box and the first Samsung code worked for my TV.Now the bad: there aren't ANY blu-ray codes for this remote. I tried every Sony DVD code and none of them worked with my Sony blu-ray player. I could not get the remote to work with my Panasonic soundbar either. There are four devices in my living room, and this remote does not work with two of them. I am very disappointed since I really liked the remote. My mom will hopefully get some use out of it in her bedroom for her TV and DVD player (though she still has to use the cheap Comcast remote for her DTA box).UPDATE: I finally got around to setting up the remote in my mom's room.  I was thoroughly shocked when I got the remote to work with the Comcrap DTA box.  I would bump this review up to 2 stars because it actually works with the DTA box, however, before I set up the cable box I discovered I could not change channels on the TV itself.  Whenever I pressed a button to change the channel, the remote would only attempt to use the not-yet-set-up cable device no matter how many times I pressed the TV device button.  Most of the time that's fine, but if you need to switch from channel 3 to 4 on your TV, you will need another remote or have to use the TV buttons.  Maybe I expect too much out of a remote, but I had a great one until Comcrap's mandatory DTA boxes came along and made it mostly useless.  Hopefully this remote will be of more use to my mom with her TV than it was for us in the living room, and at least for now she only needs one remote to watch cable TV (the Comcrap remote doesn't fully work with her older TV), and it seems to work with her DVD player.
summary: Doesn't work with half my living room devices

reviewText: The charger I received in this package (Zeikos ZE-DCQ3950 Rapid 1 Hour LCD AA/AAA Battery Charger) is not the same as the one pictured in the Amazon product image section. The product image shows a charger that has an AC plug, and it says the charging current is 2000mA max for AA, 1000mA max for AAA. The actual charger I got is a much smaller unit which accepts DC input from either an AC-to-5V adapter, or a 12V-to-5V car adapter.From the back of the charger unit, it says the charging current is just 450mA for 1-2 AA/AAA cells, 225mA for 3-4 cells. Obviously, this cannot be a '1-hour' charger. For example, to fully recharge a pair of 2900mAh AA cells it will take at least 7 hours (because 2900mAh/450mA = 6.4 hours). If you want to recharge 3-4 cells, then the charge time is doubled. So this is more like an 'overnight' charger rather than a 'rapid' charger.[Note: the actual charging current I measured is only around 330mA instead of 450mA as rated. That means the charge time is even longer]Speed issue aside, this little charger is actually quite smart. It can recharge each cell individually, which is much better than most cheap chargers that can only charge in pairs. The LCD panel has a blue LED backlight. It shows four battery status bars, each with three segments. During charging, all status bars cycle from low to high a few times, then they pause to display the relative fullness of each battery. Charging stops when all three segments are filled. If you accidentally put in an alkaline cell, the charger is smart enough to detect it and flashes the status bar to indicate an error.The AC adapter is rated for input=100-240V AC, output=5V 1A DC. But the actual current drawn by the charger is only 0.5A, which explains why it is so slow. The good news is that you can power this charge through any USB ports (5V 0.5A) from your computer or other USB adapter. Conversely, you can also use the included AC adapter and car adapter to recharge other USB-powered appliances - if you have the right cable.On the other hand, the four rechargeable batteries included in this package are very poor. They are rated for '2900mAh', but the actual average capacity is just 1940mAh (and this is measured after running SIX discharge/recharge cycles on myLa Crosse BC1000 charger/analyzer). They also appear to be suffering from higher internal resistance, which means they are unable to sustain high current under load.Bottom Line:If you are just looking for a small USB-powered charger and don't care about speed, then this Zeikos package is still worth considering. Otherwise, I recommend getting a package with better charger and batteries, such as theSony Cycle Energy BCG34HLD4KN Power Charger with 4 Pre-Charged 2000 mAh AA Batteries.
summary: Charger is smart but very slow, batteries are junk

reviewText: My Dell XPS 410 computer needed a new GPU to connect to an LCD TV, with an HDMI. This card was very easy to install. I only needed to find an updated video driver at the AMD site. I did not find this card to be noisy,in fact the computer is still very quiet.My older Dell is running Vista 32 bit windows(love it)with 4GB of memory, and a 375 W PSU.

reviewText: Was initially disappointed that it included only 1 speaker.  I bought a pair of "Rock" outdoor speakers, and I know having only 1 on while out on the patio gives the sound of an old AM radio.  However, I was buying this for a friend for Christmas, and told them that they would get the 2nd one for their B-day in Jan.  Well, they turned this one on out on their patio - and it sounds BETTER than my 2 "Rock" speakers combined.  So while a little unhappy that it comes with only one, AND, that I can't find anywhere I can buy the add-on speaker only (without buying another transmitter - which usually makes it slightly cheaper), I was pleasantly surprised with the sound quality coming form this one speaker.

I wanted to purchase a different TV table mount(basically the more expensive Omni options like 503FP)but I had the option of getting something else along with my order after saving 170 dollars or so from switching up on my bookshelf speaker choices for my new updated home theater system. I didn't quite have the 200 dollars for any of the center/2 front speakers I'll be buying in the coming weeks so I decided to down grade my tv table mount choice to this mount. Let me tell you, it's all I needed. Fantastic and stylish, this stand is truly a pleasure to own. 47" Vizio TV was easy to install. Cables are well hidden. Very very sturdy. TV sits at a perfect height for when my new Infinity center channel comes in, sitting on the top shelf just under the TV, not to mention it's perfect for my viewing angle tastes.I could go on praising this stand but I'll spare people. My only complaint is that it has no wheels for the feet to make access to the back a little easier but that is far from a major con. It slid around fairly easy on my carpet. Overall I am incredibly happy with this stand and I can't suggest it enough: Only bother buying the higher priced Omni stands if you need them. Don't "want" them and throw your money away. This one gets the job done like a charm and like I said, the viewing angle is perfect from a couch perspective which is far more important imho than mo' shelf space for stuff that at least the 503FP provides, which was my original choice.

This Onkyo amp has so much promise, and when I first got it I was excited about it. I let it burn in over 100 hours, and I just could not eliminate the persistent hum it has. This actually interferes with quieter passages of music, such that I had to return it.Not sure, as other reviewers have said, whether this is an inherent problem with this Onkyo. I tend to think not, and yet I also don't want to try another unit either.I am done with Onkyo. I bought a refurb receiver a couple years ago and the thing literally blew up on me (actual smoke coming out of the unit, after which it died). It was "repaired" under warranty, yet it never worked again. Should have sent it back again, but it just gets into so much trouble and shipping costs for these heavy units it just isn't worth it. Bought a Sony and am a happy camper; it's been perfect now for close to 3 years.Sorry for the aside; just a commentary on Onkyo. About the A-5VL, you should be hyper-aware of buzz from the unit. I didn't have a scratchy volume knob like another reviewer, but the buzz from the unit is intolerable in my opinion. It actually interferes with the music.Sorry Onkyo. I wanted so badly to like and keep this unit, but I couldn't. I gave it two stars under the assumption that not all these are flawed...but mine surely was.
summary: Buzzes and hums much more than it should

reviewText: I've had the original iPad for about a year and a half and have really enjoyed the increasing levels of functionality with each new iOS release. My only disappointment was that this model did not have a camera. When a cheaper product, the iPod Touch had a camera, there was no reason not to include one in this model. There are so many iPad-only apps that require the use of a camera that I'd like to use - and I can't use them on my iPhone. While I think the iPad is an awkward point-n-shoot camera due to its size, there have been a number of times I've been reading an iBook during lunch and I wanted to take a photo of something and had to claw around looking for my iPhone to do that. The ample screen size makes reading books (whether they are PDFs, iBooks or Kindle books via the Kindle App) very easy on the eyes. Even though I don't have a retina display on this original iPad, the text still looks nice and it is very readable.
summary: Should have had a camera from the get-go

With very little reconfiguration of the removable velcro partitions, I was able to set up the bag to my liking.  The camera is suspended high in the center in a nice supportive cradle and can easily carry a 200mm+ telephoto lens. Access is quick with dual zippers with adequate tabs.  The bottom is made of a molded plastic that will take scuffing and still protect the contents.  Stands up fairly well, but realize that the camera creates a high center of gravity.  Space for a 15" laptop along the back is well thought out.  Best to keep all your laptop accessories to one side to avoid mixing things up.  I have not taken this through a TSA checkpoint so refer to other reviews on that aspect.
