reviewText: The Vizio VSB200 is definitely a worthwhile investment in your home theater setup.  I replaced an LG 5.1 home theater in a box system with this sound bar because my new apartment is not conducive to rear speaker wiring.  I considered wireless rear speakers, but decided to give the Vizio sound bar a try instead.  I think I made the right decision.  The simulated surround sound is actually quite nice and does a great job at replicating the engrossing sound of a 5.1 setup.  I added a small powered subwoofer to fill out the sound, but really I only turn it on for movies.  The Vizio has enough bass for average TV watching.  If you are considering a sound bar, this Vizio model is hard to beat even considering the higher priced Pioneers and Polks.

This is a great sound bar for the money!  Big thing that I have noticed that I didn't know or certainly can't find the answer to, is there is no way to integrated this to your TV.  Meaning that you can't turn down the sound of your TV and it will affect the sound bar.  So you'll need a remote to turn the channels and then another one to run the sound.  I find that a bit cumbersome, but I deal with it.  It looks nice in front of our TV and it was easy to hook up.  I took the advice of another reviewer here and bought the amazon cable rather than using the AV cables.  The cable was fairly cheap and works very well.  Overall a good product.  Just a pain with the two remotes.

The front speakers in this car are CDT HD-65NX and the  front doors and rear deck are sealed using Fatmat.Pros- Can handle more wattage than your ears- Excellent good constructionCons- Lack low-end bass; less than the Polk and much less than the CDT front speakers- Pronounced upper mid-bass and lower mid-range can bother some (me included)- Sound veiled as compared to the CDT front speakersThree stars because I am sure some people will like these, but I am returning mine.

For a couple of years now I've suffered with an 8GBSuper Talent PicoUSB drive that's had a knack of corrupting larger files that I've wanted to store on it. The main reasons I put up with it (often packing files in a rar archive with extra parity info or using par2 files to survive the corruption issues) were its sheer size (or lack thereof) and speed.However, the time finally came for me to consider replacing it as I've bumped into the 8GB limit when moving stuff around for work. I'd looked at various USB flash drives on Amazon, but was mostly unimpressed. The faster drives all tend to be large, and the small ones (I'm looking at you,SanDisk Cruzer Fit) all tend to be abominably slow (4MB/sec would take more than 2 *hours* to fill a 32GB drive). I was seriously considering just living with a full-size USB drive on my keychain. I knew I'd sorely miss the size of the Pico, but reliability and speed were my main concerns.I'm not sure how I found it while poking around Amazon, but I stumbled this little elago reader, and it seemed to be perfect for my needs. It's definitely got the form factor right (it's actually half the length of the Pico), and I figured with the right microSD card I'd get the speed and reliability I'd been looking for. At under 10 bucks, I figured it was low-risk and decided to give it a go.I managed to pick up aSanDisk Ultra 32 GBmicroSD card for a little under the "normal" price to go with the reader. Formatted as NTFS (to allow for storage of files > 2GB and to offer better multi-platform support than exFat), this combination of reader + card performs pretty well. Tested under 64-bit Linux, writes of large files tend to run at 15-16MB/sec, and reads at a slightly higher 19-20MB/sec or so, which is a slight improvement in performance over the Supertalent device I've been using until now. If I ever need to fill the drive from empty, it should take about 35 minutes (instead of the 2+ hours I'd get from many other small USB sticks).On top of that, I'm impressed that the device this small has a standard USB 'A' connector. The Pico's connector is non-standard; it's slightly too large for most USB ports, resulting in more force than is necessary to plug the drive into a PC, and it's possible to plug it in upside down, with the unfortunate side-effect of shorting out the USB's power and ground connections.The main thing I can think of that would improve this little reader would be a proper microSD latch (it's basically just a friction fit) to hold the card in place, with a better eject mechanism. The little yellow tab to eject the card seems like it's too easy to accidentally push either when inserting the reader into a PC or when it's in a pocket. Frankly, the best mechanism I can think of would have been something you shove a paperclip into; something like that would have been easily accessible without a special tool, but hard (if not impossible) to eject the SD card by accident.For now, I just pulled the yellow tab completely out of the reader (it came out fairly easily using just a fingernail to remove it, and seems to go back in fairly easily), and the SD card can still be pushed out with a simple tool (a pencil, paperclip, toothpick or even a small twig will do) which seems to be a decent improvement. If that proves insufficient, I'll just use a dab of epoxy to make the SD card a permanent fixture.I'm also not sure why this reader bothers with an LED. There's a blue LED hidden somewhere in the guts of the thing that isn't easily visible (it sort of shines through the hole for the lanyard) but it's on all the time, and doesn't indicate device activity in any way. I just don't see the point of that, to be honest.For under $10, this turns a microSD card of up to 32GB capacity into a wonderful little USB flash drive. It's a great idea; it gives a tiny form factor, and you can choose a reliable SD card instead of having to put up with some 3rd-rate flakey flash.

Noise canceling headphones make a world of difference on even short flights. These do a solid job and the detachable cord is definitely handy. They also pass thru the audio when in off mode which is a nice feature, although the audio is not as crisp.There are some drawbacks though. The build materials are a little on the cheaper side. So on occasion when you move your head, the headphones will creak from the joints moving. The noise cancellation is very good but the Bose QC15 is a little better. They are also a little bulky, so they take up a little extra room compared to say the Bose units.Still a solid buy for the price and I would still pick them over the Bose if I had to buy a pair today.

I've been a huge logitech mouse/keyboard advocate and purchaser for a dozen years now.  The Performance Mouse MX was something I picked up in 2010 when it was on sale and it quickly surpassed the 705 so the MX became a favorite mouse (it's slightly larger, which makes it more comfortable in my male-sized hand).In early 2012 my Performance MX mouse starting to have trouble dragging and dropping files around...  and highlighting text for copy/paste operations.  Solidly held clicks were being registered as rapid multi-clicks and wouldn't hold.  This problem became worse prompting me to diagnose the issue by switching computers/receivers to determine the problem was in the mouse.  It turns out that something goes bad in the mechanical switch for the most-used mouse button (left click for me) and it becomes marginal.  The logitech support forums are littered with people trying temporary fixes, but an RMA is the only one that really works.  3 year warranty so I paid to send it in and got a new mouse.  Great, except that new replacement MX is now doing the same thing a mere 7 months later and I'm back to using my old 705 mouse as I'm packing the MX up to RMA again.It's a great mouse and I wish they'd re-design the switches to avoid this problem (was not a problem I've had with previous logitech cordless mice).  If you buy, be sure to have a backup mouse and understand that you'll be paying RMA shipping.
summary: A Great Mouse, Until the Mouse Buttons Stop Working

reviewText: I was hesitant at first to buy these speakers because of how cheap they were and since Logitech isn't known to have good speakers unless you shell out some money. Boy was I wrong. These are probably the money product for what the price is given. Very underrated speakers and the prices shows that. If your looking for a good, loud, substantial system and has a great subwoofer..look no further. Great speakers. Recommeneded if you want more than your computer speakers and are on a tight budget. Amazing!

First let's get this out of the way: you need to understand SquareTrade's warranties to appreciate them, and make appropriate decisions on them.  If you understand that the value of the warranty diminishes with your repair claims, then you're OK. The point of the ST warranty is to make sure your computer runs for the duration of the warranty period OR fix or replace it up to, or until, the face value of the warranty is met. Meaning: if you have warranted the computer for $1000, and it is repaired at a repair cost of $200, your remaining warranty is only good for $800 worth of additinoal repairs or refund during the warranty period. I understand this and think it is a fair policy which helps keep pricing affordable.My claims experience with SquareTrade is twofold. About a year into the warranty my touchscreen laptop had a screen problem. SquareTrade repaired it quickly. Unfortunately the screen still occassionally lost its touch ability, but this seemed more software based than hardware as a reboot would correct. All in all I was happy with the repair. The cost of the repair was valued at roughly $250, which seemed reasonable.About a year after that, in a rush, I unfortunately dropped the laptop and broke it severely. I felt terrible as this is my daughter's computer which she loves. Since we had Accidental Damage protection (thought we might need it for my daughter and not for me!) I frantically called SquareTrade. My call was taken care of quickly and professionally. I sent the laptop in and in 2 days was greeted with a warranty payment equal to the face amount minus the $250 previous repair charge. This allowed me to replace my daughter's computer quickly (and with less of a wallet impact) and not have an issue with her school work.Worked exactly as advertised by SquareTrade and I am very happy with their service. This experience will provide additional peace of mind to me should I ever need to make another claim (which I hope I do not) on any of the other items I have warranted with them.
summary: Good peace of mind at a good price

reviewText: I am so mad at myself for buying this piece of junk. The quality is terrible. The device only works half the time.  I thought my first one was defective, so I exchanged it, but encountered the same problems. The battery is a major problem. I buy new energizer or Duracell batteries for it often, and they only last two to four months.  Even worse, this device is SO STUPID, it shows you when the battery is halfway depleted, so each time you want to change the channel or do anything, you have to click 'Exit' to get away from the battery half-full message. So frustrating! I know the damn battery is half full.  Yet this stupid device has tell me after every single button I push. If you buy this device you will feel my frustration.

It also has an OIS  on/off switch on the lens and works well with Oly cameras. It is especially great for videos as it's near silent and has quick focusing.
I just bought these because they looked cool and for the Verbatim name.  I haven't had any trouble with any of them so far.  I just wish they came in larger quantities.

This system really works! I was skeptical due to the low price but after 2 weeks of use I am delighted. I have the sensor installed 600' up my driveway and the base unit is in the bedroom. Plenty loud, it's not turned up all the way and I can still hear it when standing outside on the porch. Signal is tripped by deer, people, and vehicles. No false alarms and no missed trips yet! Super easy to install to tree. When setting up follow directions closely, you must press a button inside the sensor unit to link it to the base unit. If you miss this step after installing the battery and screwing the back plate on you will have to remove the back plate and press the link button. No big deal though. Overall, a great system and I'm getting at least 2 more sensors as the base unit can handle up to 7 sensors. Awesome value!Update: 11.10.12 - Recieved 2nd sensor. Put in batteries (4 AA). Press learn button on base unit, wait for the beep, press learn button on sensor and wait for beep. Screw on plate cover and you're done. No adjustment on the 1st sensor needed. Now my first sensor is located 600' up the driveway, and the second sensor is located 300' up the driveway. 1st sensor beeps twice when tripped, 2nd sensor beeps three times when tripped. Perfect early warning system. Deer trip my first sensor when crossong my driveway but because they do not walk down the driveway they do not trip the 2nd sensor. Now I know when someone is walking or driving down my driveway. As with the 1st sensor, I have experienced no false alarms or missed trips. Great, reliable, affordable security system.Update: 3.5.13 - System still working well. The units have endured many storms and direct rainfall and still function properly. The freezing cold temperatures seem to have no effect on these little gems. I keep meaning to get out there and install a little plywood roof over each device but haven't done it yet. Just ordered 2 more sensors for a total of 4 so far. Like others I have noticed that a fast-moving object may not trip the sensor. 1 tip, install a 'Private Property' or 'No Trespassing' or 'Slow - Children Playing' sign near each sensor, this makes visitors slow down a little and ensures sensors will activate. Still very pleased with this low-cost security system.

I installed this product in a 2005 Mustang GT convertible with the Shaker 1000 audio system (pictures above).  I wanted to keep the factory radio because I was happy with the sound and use my iPhone for all my in car infotainment anyway.  I use the Pandora and SiriusXM Apps for music and the Adam Carolla and Stitcher Apps for my podcasts.  I use the free Waze App for navigation.  I also like the automatic volume adjustment with vehicle speed in the factory unit - a useful feature in a convertible!  Ford does not sell a dedicated iPhone cable that works through the factory head unit even though there is an Aux button on the radio.  This product got positive reviews and seemed to do everything I wanted so I decided to give it a try.The installation took one afternoon by myself.  I got the instructions on how to remove the radio from Crutchfield - they will give this to you for free if you purchase any car audio equipment from them or you can pay $10 for them without another purchase.  As recommended in another review, I used 2 splitters (1-male-into-2-female RCA connectors) so that I could use both the iPhone cable and the Aux headphone jack inputs.  I did not want to cut into my wiring harness for 12V power so I used a fuse tap (also pictured above) in an open fuse location for power.  This resulted in an "always on" power supply, even when the car is off (as opposed to the power just coming on with the car's ignition).  I was worried that this might put a constant power drain on the battery but it does not appear to do so as long as the switch is off and the iPhone is not connected.  I ran all wires in split corrugated tubing to protect them and went pretty zip-tie happy to make everything neat.  I would recommend removing the trim panel on which you are going to mount the switch and/or aux input jack and drilling the holes from behind.  My drill skipped a little bit on the hard plastic and made a few scratches.  The iPhone holder I used is a ProFit Bravo minigrip (model BR-200BG).  It is held on with a 3M adhesive pad that is not supposed to leave a mark when you remove it.  I think it looks nice and holds the phone securely.  It is also fully adjustable.I am very happy with the final result.  I have uploaded pictures of my install if you are interested.  It looks nice and the only exposed wire is the iPhone connector by necessity.  It charges the phone and all audio plays through this cable without the need for a second cable plugged into the headphone jack on the phone.  I did not have to adjust the output level on the box.  It is about as loud as the radio (but who really listens to the radio anyway, right? Isn't that why you are buying this thing in the first place?).  I'm not an audiophile but the sound is super clear without any static at all using either the iPhone cable or the Aux input.  I use a 3GS iPhone and it is fully compatible.  My wife has a 4S iPhone which I have not tried yet but certainly can if anyone is interested.Overall I am very happy with this purchase and the ease of installation.  It was hundreds of dollars cheaper than a new stereo and gives me exactly what I wanted - iPhone and Aux input capability.  Only time will tell how durable it is as some of the lower rated reviews report that their unit failed after 6-9 months.  I'll certainly addend this post if mine fails.  I would recommend this product to anyone who is looking for an inexpensive and pretty easy way to add a line-in to any factory (or aftermarket) car stereo.  Good luck!

In my opinion, it is destined to break, plain and simple. There are many other entities that have the very same product, so I'd recommend any of these except this one. It's just not destined to last in my opinion. Furthermore, they don't show the entire cable, just the tips, so you can't really tell it has a constitution that looks unusual and not solid, I can tell, I purchased it and was disappointed. Hope you listen!!

I've had this lens for 18 months now and use it on a D80. It's a brilliant all round lens that produces sharp images. The focusing is fast and accurate and the vibration reduction works well letting you take hand held shots in fairly low light conditions. I've got two D80s and leave this lens permanently on one of the bodies which I use as my go everywhere camera. If I could only have one lens this would be the one I would choose.
summary: If I could only have one lens this would be it

reviewText: Alot of people complained about the distance with this lens and what not.  This is my first telephoto lens of its kind (compare to the 55-200mm cheaper lens) and I like what I see.  I'm okay with the fact that you have to be at a certain distance and its not a problem that unlike the previous 70-200mm 2.8 vrI where it had more range when focusing at certain distances.  This is fine for me and I see more of the good things that bad.  Like everyone has been saying, its a sharp lens, fast and very responsive.  I also like that if autofocus can't lock that as long as you have the switch on auto\manual, if auto can't focus, you can manually rotate the focus ring and bring it into focus.  Also love the lens hood as its long to shade the lens unless you face it in direct sunlight.  Look at the example of the pictures for this lens and you can tell that this lens is excellent on bokeh.  I use this for a mixture of portraits, wildlife, etc.  Its a great lens and I'm not disappointed.I also like the fact that its quiet.  For me its a winner.

quick shipping, and an amazing price for 4GB of ddr3 1333mhz. works great, and now my system has max RAM [ :( only 8gb]. Also, the stick is about half the height of a normal stick, so you have a little more room for better air flow. LOVE IT!

Of course its a simple hood so what could be wrong if it looks well made and fits fine. I own a genuine Canon hood for my 24-105 F4 L series lens so I know there can be subtle things that differentiate a professional product from the after market brands. In this case, it was the lack of the fine velvet like coating on the inside surface of the hood that makes it zero relection. This one simply has matte finish overall and you could see some light shine when held at an angle. Time will tell if that will be an issue or not.
summary: You get what you pay for

reviewText: I bought this specifically to use as a usb stick for mp3s in my car.  The plug for my car is right in the middle of my console, so a large usb would look tacky, and probably break.  This was the perfect solution.Like others said, its as small is practically possible.  Much smaller than a normal usb, and great.:Pro:- Very small- Still easy to install and remove- Satisfying click for the MicroUSB and for the USB itself.- LED Light- Keychain tether.  I can't tell you how many of these are out with no way to attach the device to your keychain or phone.- Teeth is on the device, not the cap.- Upgradable.I've been using it for 4 months with no problems.  However, I rarely remove it from my car.  I think I'll be buying these instead of regular flash drives, since it just makes more sense.  However, I'll need to find a USB 3 one... if that's even possible with these SD cards.

I liked the way this boombox looked when I ordered it and also the fact that it has an aux input, iphone slot, a radio and cd player....  but, when it arrived, the box was so light I wondered if someone had stolen it - this sucker is light!  It's your typical piece of chinese electronics, with a very cheap feeling...The flaws are:It feels cheap.There is a wire that hangs out of the back that acts as the FM antenna - surely they could have put a telescoping or internal antenna vs a hanging black wire?Rather than a straight electrical cord that is easy to transport, it has an AC adapter.It has 2 small speakers that sound OK...but no separate tweeters etc.It's way overpriced.  It should sell for $40 at its level of quality.Pros are:It has a remote.It has good features: cd/radio/aux input/iphone slotThe radio actually picks up pretty well for a cheap-o radio.Overall - not bad if you expect to get a cheap-o boombox - it works but feels cheap - lower the price!
summary: Cheaply made but it works - has a few flaws....

reviewText: After reviewing some of the other slates out there, I finally decided on this one. It's sturdy and serves its purpose. I also like that its a bit different, color scheme-wise than the average slate sticks. It's not a bad price, either.

The radio worked flawlessly and I was able to link it to my Reciva account with my other radios. It did not have the remote included but I could run everything on the unit itself. I was also hoping to plug the phone jack into some larger speakers but the audio was very low when I did that. Still its main purpose for me was to be able to take it outside with batteries when I am working outside and can listen to everything including some local stations and Sirius XM.
summary: Most everything I was looking for.

reviewText: I just got this today and have watch part of a movie,  and part of a tv show.  Very good sounding system compaired to the vizo  bar, my Bose wave system and everthing else i tried. pleased with the purchase, but the price might not be for everyone. Don't have any of the issues others are talking about.  The voices are clear, but you have to set the player up for PCM.  TV voice is clear as well.  Good for a medium size room, not a large room.  Sounds even better on speaker stands. Perfect 2.1 speakers from Bose.  I had the 3-2-1 system but gave to my brother once he returned from Iran. If you need the DVD player that is a better system with hdmi output.

I ordered this Nano for my grandson's birthday. The item never arrived in time for his birthday.  However, when I called Customer Service they were able to rush another Nano and it arrived the day after his birthday.  He has been thrilled with it and has used his gift iTunes cards to download all his favorite songs.  Blue is his favorite color and it's the perfect size and shape for a 10 year old.  He's so proud of it.
summary: Great price for a gift for grandson

reviewText: Received theVIZIO SV370XVT - 37" Widescreen 1080p LCD HDTV - 120Hz - 50,000:1 Dynamic Contrast Ratio - 5ms Response Timea few days ago just in time to get it mounted on my Sister-in-Law's Bedroom wall for her birthday! She Loves it!I was a little worried about buying a "Customer Return", but the Vendors reviews were good. The TV arrived well packaged and in excellent (New) shape. The only thing missing was the owners manual which the seller had already warned me about. I just downloaded a electronic version from the Internet.TV is excellent and a great bargain at this price! The only complaint I have about Vizio is they set the connections up on the back so the point straight back (Into the wall) which can create some clearance problems when wall mounting the TV. The power plug provided is L-Shaped so it is not a problem, but one may need to consider purchasing L-Shaped HDMI and Antenna connections or any of the other provided AV connections.Picture quality is great, lots of tweaks are possible, sound is adequate for a bedroom. A Sound-bar may be a nice addition for a more Theater-like sound.

The Leica Monivid Monocular is very small (but not too small), very bright image, crystal clear image & has a real feel of quality. The back lens has a sliding hood so if you wear glasses you do not have to fold back a rubber cup (which I find is a pain) the hood slides back & forth with ease. The leather case it comes with is very nice (has a belt loop on the backside) & has a handy holder for the the close up lens. I use the close up lens more than I thought I would, it is very handy for looking at insects & allows you to stay a nice distance back. It comes with a very nice wrist strap, but would have preferred it was a neck strap. I bought the neck strap at an added cost & love it (is just like the wrist strap but longer. I must admit I use both straps. Is a lot of money but worth it, should last a lifetime with proper handling. Being small it can go everywhere with me without it being a burden. I love bird watching, so I am always prepared. Would recommend it to anybody that is prepared to spend the big bucks it takes to buy it.
I have been using this camera for quite awhile now. It was easy to learn how to use and it takes GREAT pictures.
summary: cannon powershot sx201s 12.1mp digital camera with the 20x wide ange.

reviewText: These flashdrives are perfect for me.  I bought a new laptop and wanted to copy and save files and photos off my old laptop and used these flash drives for that purpose.  They worked perfectly and I had no problems doing what I needed to do.  They arrived quickly and the price is great.I'm going to buy more and would definitely recommend these to other people.

I loaded the CD and read the install instructions.  Didn't mention Win 7, so I figured they were out of date.  Confusing, too.  I'd read the reviews here about how easy it was to install, so I followed one.  Just disconnected the cable and LAN cable from the Comcast modem and connected them to the Motorola SB5101U.  Then connected the power adapter as the reviewer had directed.  Opened a site in my browser but didn't get a Comcast configuration screen, as had several reviewers, so called Comcast.  Got a polite techie who asked for the MAC ID, repeated it back to me; asked for the Customer S/N, repeated it back, both first time.  Asked if I was connected to a router, which I was, the Cisco Linksys 1000.  He asked me to unplug it while he initiated the modem.  No problem.  He said, "Your modem seems to be initiating, so plug your router back in."  He added, "Okay, open a web page." I did and it worked.Don't bother with the CD unless you are going to use a USB connection directly to a computer.  Then, you might have to install the USB drivers on the disk.  Maybe not for Win 7, but I don't know.  The instructions on the disk said nothing about hooking up to a wireless router, so just forget the disk and hook it up and call Comcast for activation.I checked the speed on Speakeasy.net to several cities and got 15 -20 mbps.  This is more than I was getting with the modem Comcast furnished, so I am very pleased with the install and the performance.  I paid $48.99 and the Comcast modem rental was $7/mo, so it won't take but 7 months to pay for the modem.
Setup was very easy for my Charter internet.Called the cable company, gave them this product's id no.,plugged it in and, after 3 minutes,i was online at 15 mbs (my contract speed).

I like this player so much that I've bought 4 of them . I give them to family and close friends as a 'treat'. The capabilities ( has an equalizer) and sound quality for such a tiny device are unbelievable.I have experimented with various earbuds ( the ones that come with it are junk)and discovered that "SkullCandy" "Ink'd" or 'smokin Buds" are the perfect match for this player.My first player was a refurb which you really can't tell from new.However, the rechargeable battery didn't seem to last as long as the later "new" ones I bought. Amazon offers great deals on these 4Mb Sandisk "clip" players. If you like music, I don't see how you can go wrong with this player

My wife and I have been using this type e-reader for several years.  It's an extremely convenient size (fits in your shirt pocket) and is everything we want in an e-reader.  They are very durable, have a long battery life, and simple to use.  The reason we bought this as a replacement, is that the identical one my wife had before slipped out of her hands, and fell 20' on to a pile of rocks (durable YES, indestructible NO). We plan to keep using these as long as Sony will keep making them.

I bought this sub to replace 2 - 10" Kicker Solo Baric L5 subs that I had in the back of a 2002 Honda Civic.  My wife & I recently had a baby & needed to reclaim our trunk.  So, along with this sub, I purchased a Q-Form custom fit box by Q-Logic.  The box fits in the little pocket behind the wheel well, in front of the tail light.  So, I wanted a 10 that could fit the box but still produce some good lows!  I thought I was going to be disappointed since it was only 1 - 10" sub now...totally not the case.  I couldn't be happier with this sub woofer!  The lows that this reproduces are amazing.  It rivals the lows of some 12's out there.  The SSI (Selectable Smart Impedance) was the gimmick that sold me on it, not that I needed it, but basically because of Infinity's creative development of this switch.  It allows expandability of your sub woofer (quantity of subs) without being stuck with an improper impedance sub based on your layout or future layout.  Plus, Infinity is made by Harmon, so I knew this was going to be a quality sub.  I am powering it with an Eclipse 1000XA Mono Amp (450W RMS, 1000W peak) so it matches this sub woofer well.  I also like the styling/aesthetics of the cone.  There's nothing negative that I can even think of at this point.  I've had friends in the past that have owned Infinity subs & were total fan boys.  I've owned Kenwood, Pioneer, Alpine, Polk, Eclipse & Kicker sub woofers & this one is the best (Single) 10" sub I've heard from my past experiences.  If you're hesitant on buying this, don't be...you will not be disappointed!
Almost like the piece you get when you purchase an external cd-rom burner or similar device but it seems a little stiff for my liking. It hasn't failed on me yet and I do use it on a daily basis.
I had trouble with the comparability issue wirh this particular devie. Besides the item being defective, I really wanted to go to college before I die.

the lens is really nice, 15mm is nice and wide on aps-c, and iq is near my 135mm f/2.  only issue is it's a little heavy, but that's what happens with the better lenses, so that was expected.  so, i'd give the lens 5 stars, but i give the surprise packaging 2 stars - i got a kit lens, it was new and works fine, so no problem there, but i think it should say on the item if it's a kit lens or not.  so, i'll give the overall rating of 4 stars for it.
summary: lens is good, but got a kit lens, surprised by that

reviewText: I just got this little unit from Woot (an Amazon Company or affiliate) and plugged it in.  The sound is very surprising!  It is full and rich.  It can get a surprising amount of volume without distortion, for it's size.There are no adjustments for the sound except volume, but it is sounding nice.  This unit sounds as nice or better than my stereo unit I was using to play cd's (which are now on the iPod)and was lots less expensive too.I have not tried it in my bedroom yet, so I am not sure what to expect.  Currently I have it in the living room.  The living room is pretty large (about 650 sq ft) with wood floors.  Sound tends to bounce and echo in here but it is sounding pretty good!The contents of the box were the unit itself, a 2 part plug in transformer power cord, instructions, 6 different sizes of adapters for your iPod and the remote.  Find the size of adapter you need, THEN snap it in.  The adapters are difficult to remove so make sure of the size before putting it in.  I did not have the correct one selected and had to use a steak knife (my favorite tool) to remove it.  This will work on all of Apple's 30 pin phones and iPods.  I have a gummy case on my iPod 4g touch, so I am using my iPod without an adapter.Setup is fast as all you must do is plug it in!There are 3 small buttons (volume up, volume down and power) on the top right side, which are sort of firm to press.This does not take battery power.I am going to try using the iPod in the unit as my alarm clock tomorrow and am not sure if that will work, and will update this review after trying that.I really like the unit and might wait until when it goes on sale again and buy another.Pros:Rich, full soundRemoteSmall foot printFast setupStylishBrand name companyCons:Does not use batteriesUpdate:I used the unit with my iPod as an alarm and it was very good.  Also some people were complaining that your iPod or iPhone would damage the connector if it moved around while connected.  To make sure I did not do that, I put felt furniture pads behind the iPod.  The pads should keep me from pushing the iPod back too far while pushing it's buttons.  The pads are very in-expensive and can be purchased at most hardware and big box stores.I REALLY like this unit and probably will buy another for my wife.

This product is awesome.I gifted this to my wife who uses her Iphone4s to listen to music.. You can even use it for music from youtube on the iphone.I also connected this speaker to my tv and trust me. The output is awesome. The bass is sweet & clear.The packaging was perfect & excellent quality.(comes in a big box though)Pros : Awesome sound quality, Bass & compatibility with iphone4s & other phones or mp3 playersCons : None to my knowledge.If not this, the next level product with perfect quality & sound output would be BOSE which is 3 to 4 times the price of this product & 3 times the size.Will definitely recommend this to friends and everyone.

Like the few unfortunate I couldn't get this device to work on a new PC build with the Gigabyte GA-78LMT-S2P motherboard. This is my first build in a few years and was surprised that IDE connectors are a thing of the past at least with some motherboards. So I bought this gizmo hoping it would allow me to connect an older Western Digital 80 GB IDE drive to the motherboard using the SATA cable. I tried every tip and configuration listed from other reviewers here on Amazon without any success. The red light showing power came on but the drive never made an attempt to rev up and was never recognized by the BIOS or Windows XP. I'm returning it to Amazon but it's a shame since it would have simplified things for me.

This is a fantastic keyboard.I've had several Thinkpads over the years, T's and X's, and their keyboards were such a pleasure to use that I wanted them on my desktops.  I tried one of these for the office and have now bought a second for the lab.I love not having to leave the keyboard for mousing.  When I first tried a Thinkpad keyboard I really didn't like Trackpoint .  But, within a few weeks, it became second nature and now I prefer it over a regular mouse...  *unless* I'm doing anything with graphics.The keyboard has a fairly light touch, with just the right amount of movement and a slight snap to provide tactile feedback.It feels great.As to what others have said, now several years ago, about the shift or caps-lock keys having some sort of stickiness...  I cant' replicate that at all and have seen no issues whatsoever.  Maybe they have tweaked the design.  Who knows?

As soon as I took this out of the plastic, I noticed a broken piece fell out on the floor immediately.  Parts of the tripod look dirty and greasy like it was a used unit maybe? Unfortunately, I didn't open the box until I was past my 14 days to return it so I'm stuck with it. Would not recommend.
summary: Broken piece out of the box

reviewText: I am a "claw-grip" mouse user and I shopped around quite a bit for the best affordable ergonomic mouse. I'm so glad I chose this one. Not only is the pain in the back of my hand and forearm gone, but it has all the features I was looking for in a mouse. You use your thumb for the left click button, which is very nice and I'm convinced the reason my hand no longer hurts. The scroll ring is nice and does its job well, the software was a cinch to install and the mouse doesn't take up too much room on my keyboard tray. This was important to me because I have the Microsoft Ergonomic Keyboard and it hogs almost the whole tray. I find that with the trackball I'm actually using less space because it doesn't have to move around like a traditional mouse. It was easy to get used to, maybe just a day or two. My only complaint is that I have small hands and the left mouse click button seems a tad too far to the left, but if your hands are larger it should be perfect.

There isn't a whole lot to say about this card other than it arrived, and it has been working perfectly. I'm using it in Canon XF 100 and 300 cameras at 50mbps, and they're performing flawlessly. It's everything you'd expect from a SanDisk card.

I needed a monitor for singing gigs to work with my sound system. I decided to try this based on the good reviews and very reasonable price. When I first used it it seemed to produce a very robust sound. After using it a second time, though, it seemed that the audio level wasn't as loud as I needed it to be. I tried several different cables to rule that problem out, but didn't see a difference. I contact the company and explained the problem. They shipped me a replacement FAST and told me to return the original, which we all assumed was defective, and that they'd pay for shipping.When the replacement came I decide to test it and compare the audio to the first monitor. I found no difference. As an experiment I daisey-chained the monitors to my system's speakers. They both cranked out tons of volume. Apparently, the problem was the jack in my amp. Since I'd planned on ordering a second monitor if I liked the first, I contacted the company, told them what happened, and have asked them to let me know how I can pay for the replacement they sent.Not only is this a really nice little monitor, the company provided outstanding customer service. I highly recommend this product.
summary: Great product and great company to work with

reviewText: These headphones broke after only a couple of months use.  Able Planet does not back up their product without original packaging and a written registration.Embarrassing as they were a birthday present.I do not recommend these as they are not worth it.

These lights exceeded my expectations!  They are bright and a nice solid white (45W, 5500k).  The stands are very solid and won't tip along with having nice sized wing nut type screws for getting the hight and angle how you would like.

I have a cheap TV and the built-in speakers are awful, so I am very happy to have this home theater system by RCA.Pros:- It's very affordable.- It's very easy to set up. All the wires are color-coded to the corresponding ports on the main hub/subwoofer.- Sound quality is just fine.- The system comes with plenty of wire for a small living-room.- The controls are simple and intuitive.- You can adjust the subwoofer level, the center speaker volume, the front L/R speaker volumes, and the back L/R spear volumes.- The small, inconspicuous speakers are easy to hide amongst the decor of your room.- You really can't crank it up enough to disturb the neighbors. I think this counts as a blessing in disguise.Cons:- It has plenty of volume for attentively watching a movie, but if you're trying to listen to music while doing any noisy chores or if you're trying to fill the house with music, you'll wish you had more volume.- The back speakers are much quieter than the front speakers when playing music. I was hoping to fill my whole living room with surrounding music but instead the volume is heavily weighted to the front speakers. For surround-sound movies they seem to be at the right levels.- The subwoofer is ok, but you can't get great bass out of it. Don't even think about throwing a dance party.- The remote only works if you have an unobstructed beeline from the front of the remote to the front of the hub.- You're likely to put the subwoofer in a shadowy place (under your tv table or behind the tv), meaning that the black, non-backlit controls will be impossible for you to read when you try to adjust anything. I often use the remote just because the labels on the remote make it easy to see what it is I'm changing.- It only has the standard RCA inputs (like your regular red and white L/R audio inputs). I've heard some flatscreens these days just have hdmi output for audio, so make sure have RCA outputs on your tv before you get this.- The color-coded wire stands out against your decor if you don't have anything to hide it behind.Overall, if you're on a tight budget and your TV's sound is weak, this is a great buy. College students and apartment-dwellers would likely find this system to be their perfect match.

Over the past 5 years, I have purchased 3 of these mounts. 1 in the Boat, 1 in a Truck, and this one. Sure beats having to pay Sirius for extra accounts. Just move the tuner from one vehicle to another. The antenna is very good, and the dock comes with enough options to fit every application. This dock I installed in our 2012 CAN-AM Spyder. I mounted in the rear trunk and used the Aux plug provided by CAN-AM, and 12 volt supplied with this dock. Did not want to have dock out in the elements as it is not water proof. We usually listen to Coffee House on Sirius, so just set to this channel and will decide what channel to listen to before taking off.
summary: 3rd one, and well worth the money

reviewText: I am very satisfied with this product. Easy to put in and pull out the DVD, also has side packet for accessory. I was look for this case in variety retail stores and web site, only can get it from Amazon

First off I have to point out that the idi0t Amazon webmaster(s) is using ALL CyberPower UPS reviews for EACH of their models!  So WATCH what you read!  The review may NOT be for the UPS unit you actually want to buy!  The only way to know for certain is if the reviewer NAMES WHICH CyberPower UPS unit they are reviewing!I ordered the CP350SLG because it was only 10 bucks after an Amazon credit.  FIRST, I DID INDEED check on replacement battery costs!  But after getting this POS, even though it states on the battery "CPS3.6-12", it's not!  Crosses to that # (such as BP3.6-12) are much too large and do not fit!  This *particular* CPS3.6-12 is TINY: only about 4" long (101mm) x 2.5" H (64mm) x 1.85" W (47mm).  It is possible (as another 1-star reviewer said), to Dremel out some of the enclosure but you can only use a SLIGHTLY LONGER battery, maybe 115mm long, you CANNOT use a battery that is wider or thicker because there's not enough room!  (Also note you need a special tool to remove the battery compartment screw!  It looks like a "Torx" bit, but a tiny screwdriver worked for me).Be aware that when you search to try and find a "CPS3.6-12" replacement battery, DO NOT get it UNLESS they give the dimensions and they match!  So far I have YET to find a replacement battery that FITS, sites that give the dimensions are all way too long at about 5.24" long.  (That's about 1.5" too long!)The jerks at CyberPower FAIL TO DISCLOSE THIS replacement battery info at their webpage for this unit!  If I would have KNOWN this I would have ordered a different unit!So IF I end up keeping this, I'm just going to use any 12v ~3.6Ah battery (the cheapest you can find) and leave it outside the enclosure!  Not pretty, but it will work.  (BTW, ReplaceUPSbattery.com seems to have the best prices and with a 2yr warranty).1-star, due to the fact you can't find a replacement battery!UPDATE: Here's a direct quote from CyberPower in their reply to an email I sent asking about a replacement battery:"The information is on our website, I can't speak to the websites selling them though. These small UPS units (350, 425, 500, 550) are inexpensive to the point where buying a new battery is going to cost almost as much as replacing the whole unit. For what it's worth we do recommend these be recycled, not just tossed."My reply to that:"......Being a "disposable" unit is not at your website!  You must be looking at a different website.  In fact, it even says "REPLACEMENT" battery:"Replacement Battery | BB Battery - CPS3.6-12"At: [why do these jerks remove all URL's??  The CyberPower webpage's URL was here, where all could see the direct quote above for themselves]Websites, (such as Amazon), get the info from YOU:http://www.amazon.com/CyberPower-CP350SLG-Standby-350VA-Desktop/dp/B004OR0V2CNote the area: "From the Manufacturer".It's not until recently, that they put nearer the TOP, in their OWN info (a rarity for them), this:"Batteries 1 Nonstandard Battery batteries required. (included)".Replacement batteries are usually about $18-$24 delivered, with the most common types being about $20 (UB1280 & crosses).  That is about HALF the cost of the CHEAPEST unit.....IF it would use that battery instead of a extremely rare or NON-REPLACEABLE battery." [......]
summary: Read this BEFORE ordering ANY CyberPower UPS unit!

reviewText: Picked this up on sale before Christmas.  Can't beat it and the price was good.  runs quiet, does not get warm even after writing A LOT of data to it.  I also looked inside and there is a nice drive in there, there is a Youtube video explaining how to open the case on WD external hard drives.

I got this because I stupidly overlooked something on a purchase.I decided to build a new pc, and went about ordering parts I needed. I failed to notice the motherboard came without any IDE headers on it. I didn't want to buy an adapter, so I did away with my old IDE optical drive (stuck it in a box) and ordered this.I've used Liteon in the past, the drive I replaced was actually a Liteon as well and was still working. This one works fine, burns fine, honestly works as well as the more expensive drives I've tried. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

I bought this because I wanted something a little easier to control my subs. It does that and more for a great price.The only downside to this unit is how bright the blue lights are. They are almost to much at night in my single cab pickup. The ability to turn off the light would be great.Other than that this thing is great.(Update)Had this for a little over a year now, maybe longer. Still works great. I use it everyday.
Three of the 4 connectors are uncommon. The one common connector will notmaintain contact on my camera.This product is a waste of money.

Like some other reviews have mentioned, the negative reviews were starting to make me reconsider my placement of this UPS on my Wish List.  However, once I received and installed this unit, I could not have been more pleased with my decision to go ahead and purchase it.  The fan ran for 20-30 seconds upon initial startup, and I haven't heard it since.  The fan does run when operating on battery, and when charging afterwards, but this was expected as normal operation.  The LCD claims that I have over 120 minutes of runtime, which is plenty for my application, so I won't need the additional battery pack.  One feature that I hadn't personally seen before, and is lacking on the other units I have had is the mute button.  One press of the conveniently located button and I don't get any alarms when in battery mode.  That is the ultimate in WAF!  I haven't had the unit in operation long enough to give any marks for reliability, but if it holds up, I will certainly look at APC for my next purchase, after buying other brands previously.

i purchased this gps for my in-laws as a christmas gift. they are middle aged, don't like new technology, and have never owned a gps before. this one looked pretty simple and easy to use - it also has the bonus of walking directions which i thought they'd really like since they take their dog on long walks, sometimes in unfamiliar towns.as soon as we opened the gps and started programming it i noticed that i had to press some of the buttons a few times before they seemed to respond. after getting the 'home' address in i restarted the gps to see if this would fix the problem but did not. i then did a google search to see if maybe i needed to install a driver or something - that's when i found out that a lot of other people who bought this gps were having the same problem with the touch screen with no known solution. given this information i sent the gps back to amazon.from what i did see of the actual gps function (directions, maps, etc) this unit would be great if the screen worked properly. while i was disappointed with the nuvi 1450, i did get them this garmin,Garmin nüvi 50 5-inch Portable GPS Navigator(US), to replace it and they really like the new one. i'll repeat: they really like it! that's pretty amazing for people who refused to get dvr until just a year ago.bottom line: i would have recommended this gps to others if the screen worked - especially because it has walking directions which i thought was a really nice addition. because the screen does not work, i will instead recommend the garmin nuvi 50 which is very similar to this one - the only difference i noticed (aside from the fact that the screen has a very good touch response) is that it does not have 'pedestrian mode' which gives the walking directions.

Lenovo failed to update their wireless drivers for their Intel 4965A wifi card under Windows 7. Of course M$ failed to make Win7 backwards compatible. So after spending literally 40+ hours trying to solve this issue and posting on the M$, Intel and Lenovo forums I was coming up empty handed. One of the Lenovo forum techs did give me a link for Lenovo power management drivers that, when tweaked should have solved the problem. Well, this did not solve issue under 64 bit install. Then it dawned on me, quit messing around and get a wireless usb device that's plug and play and all of your problems will be over. I eagerly awaited the Medialink adapter! When I received it, I installed the software plugged in the Medialink adapter and bingo, bango, bongo! I was untethered from an ethernet cable and free to play the horses over at Twinspires.com just in time for the breeders cup at Santa Anita<video streamed flawlessly>! Highly prized product at a great price, super fast delivery! The relief I felt when I had when I was able to connect wirelessly was priceless. Quality product! 5 stars!

I bought this product because it was less than half the price of the other sellers, and assumed, based on the description, that it was manufactured by Epson.  That turned out to be incorrect, but I have no problems with its performance.  It seems to be just as bright as the original lamp, and has worked with heavy usage for at least two weeks now. In short, It is worth the price difference.

I have the original version of the keyboard the Eclipse and it's a great keyboard but assuming there is no difference between mine and this besides aesthetics it's not worth buying. I think I got mine for $25 a few years ago. If you're going to spend $50 on a keyboard there are far better options.
summary: A reissue with a bad price

reviewText: I purchased this cooler for my Dell laptop two years ago and it's still doing a great job of keeping it cool.  My laptop fits perfectly and the cooler plugs into a USB port.  The only thing that I have noticed now is that the laptop does slip down some while in use.  I just push it back up so it's resting fully on the cooler again.  Not too big of a deal.  It's nice to have a product like this last as long as it has and I'll definitely purchase another one when this one goes out.

I purchased two of these for my laptops. I've been using them for about three months with both my 15" and 17". They fit perfectly and are absolutely stable on the rubber pads.The three fans don't move much air, but they do ensure air is constantly circulating under your laptop. The open space under the cooler also helps improve airflow.I've found this cooler is only effective on hard, flat surfaces. You can use it on a firm bed, but it may move less air. You definitely can't use it on your legs, but that's not why I bought them.The fans are completely exposed and can be moved for ideal placement. They also have grills for protection.Overall it's a great cooler for my needs.
Was easy enough to set up and works great once you get the hang of it.  A must have for harry potter fans!

Okay, so this is a really great headset.  I was really blown away coming from a pair of Creative WP-300 bluetooth headphones which sound great, but still compresses the audio and thus resulting in degradation of quality.  First off, these things ship with AAA Sanyo Eneloop batteries which are top of the line and last plenty. Plus you still have the option to just swap them out if you forget to charge. I live in a 1200sqft condo.  I have the receiver downstairs in the living area and don't lose a single anywhere in the house and can get a good ways outside. My cap size is 7&3/8 to give you an idea of how I'm grading these on comfort.  I have no complaints in the comfort department.  Some people complain about sweaty ears, but I honestly can't say I haven't had a case where wearing any set of headphones doesn't give me sweaty ears.  I just grab a cotton swab when my ears get to sweaty, so I don't really go for the whole "they make your ears sweat" thing because of course they do.  I also wear glasses and don't feel any added pressure of my ears pressing up against the frame.  I also found the volume level to be more than adequate.  I really can't hear too much of anything else with these turned up half way, included my wife's television shows.  Turn them up all the way and I can drown out police sirens. The only reason I wouldn't recommend this headset is if you plan to get the 170 or 180.  The only bummer is that you can't remotely pause media when using these with a pc or phone like you can with a bluetooth headset.  However, I'm just nitpicking at this point. This is a win in my book.

I tried using these on my Pioneer Blu-Ray burner BDR-202BK and it will not accept these. Keeps ejecting them upon insert. Toast Platinum has been used with this burner before for burning Blue-Ray BD-R's but they were Sony and 1-2x speed. Not sure why these won't work and judging from other reviews here people having a terrible problem with these I have to return these before I play with them anymore.
summary: Pioneer Blu-Ray Writer will not accept these media

reviewText: I bought these headphones because earbuds tend to make my ears ache after wearing them for a while and I had a long flight coming up. The sound is great and, as long as you aren't the type of person who tosses them around or shoves them in a bag, they'll hold up well. I love how light they are, the fact that they fold up and that they look like high-end headphones. My only problem with them is that the ear pads are almost too small; they don't completely cover my ears. When I first got them I double checked to make sure I hadn't accidentally bought kids' headphones. Even with the size issue they do a decent job blocking outside noise.

i probably have 6 sets of skullcandy headphones and love them.  i hate these ones.  they are barely audible.  you can't use these to make a phone call unless you are are in a sensory deprivation chamber.  CANNOT use while driving or riding in a car.  I have a camry and a mercedes so my cars are on the quieter end of vehicles but i can't hear a thing on these junky headphones.  DO NOT BUY!!!

Not cheap but very well made. It holds Pentax K5 and Tamron 70-200f 2.8 with out any issues. The Adjustable Manual Drag Control comes handy when using telephoto lenses. It's light weight makes it ideal for travelling.
Works perfectly.  Seems solidly built.  Not much else to say.  We are using it with a Macbook Pro laptop to connect an older printer.

I love these remotes! I didn't really see the point in having them outside of the two I had for my two apple Tv's but recently I found out the remote paired with my mac mini  will also navigate not only iTunes but HULU desktop! This makes a slick t.v like experience for my home entertainment center! I do wish Apple offered different color options, it would make my life easier so that I could tell which remote belongs to my apple t.v and which belongs to my mac mini. I currently have a rubber band around the bottom of one but it would look allot sicker if the remotes where just different colors.***Update** When using this in Hulu desktop with the 10.6 update and beyond on mac the remote automatically opens itunes when navigating through Hulu. This is super annoying because then itunes movies start playing while your watching Hulu.I found a simple solution (I still want apple to fix this annoying issue) my solution is to open itunes and put it on the store front screen. Leave it there and minimize. This should disable it from starting any movies while your using the remote with Hulu.*****update 2**** these things are tiny and man do they get lost we have bought three so far and I just lost the third. Honestly now I am using the remote app on my iPhone and it works great! But I think the Apple TV might not work out of the box with just remote app because you have to set up home sharing etc on Apple TV first so it works.

Great item; lets me use all my old Olympus lenses on my new Olympus E-PL1. Works like a dream; you do lose a stop or so because of the length of the barrel but still a great item. Package arrived on time.  It mates the old lenses with the new technology very well.  I took many great photos with my new Olympus E-PL1 using my OM Lens 70-210 MM Zoom and this adapter.  It is light weight and connects to the E-PL-1 very easy but yet tight enough to be secure.  If you have old flash units, buy the Hot Shoe adapter from this seller and use your old Vivitar 283's and Studio Strobes, then you have an excellent low cost professional camera.  I recommend this product and seller to all my fellow "shutterbugs".

I bought this for my canon 60 d and a pair of lenses and it is really good!!. If you dont plan to carry lots of heavy equipment, this is the right bag for you!! Remember, this product is good only if you dont plan to use it with many items inside, otherwise get a bigger bag!!

Hopefully I will be updating because based on reviews uploading takes a long time, but after 20 minutes it s still not uploaded.I would never recommend this product to anyone who does not have above average computer skills. Installation of desktop software required a reboot which it did not say was needed, no discussion of how to add mobile hotspots,  instructions are poorly written, mobile software is confusing, hard to tell the status.I've read great things about the card for years and when I finally got my own hotspot I decided it was worth while. O far I'm not sold on the product because if the problems as described above. It's a great once put that would be so much better with instructions that discussed issues a d made clear what you need to do.  I provide computer support at my office and know that most of my users could never figure out how to set up and use this card.Update-I am still not real happy with the card or the software.  Pictures do not upload in any specific order, so they seem its easy to not notice that a pciture is missing.  As other mention, all the pictures go through the EYE-fi sight, and I've received an email 2 days later that additional pictures have uploaded.Its a great idea, but I have so little confidence that all the pics will upload, that I always copy them off the card dierectly.  The upload feature is jsut a nice way to check out pics before I am home and take all of the pics off the card.  I would not buy the card again.
summary: Doesn't upload-update may take days to uplaod

reviewText: I was skeptical when I ordered this, but the idea intrigued me so I made the purchase! I am not disapointed! Eye-Fi is amazing! You can take pics and they will show up on the laptop without batting an eyelash. visitors enjoy watching my lap top as I take photos using Eye-Fi in my Nikon D5100. It's all seamless! Love it Love it LOVE IT! If you are worried about battery life for your camera while using the Eye-Fi card consider an additional battery pack grip. It allows you operate a camera on two rechargeable batteries Neweer pro battery grip is one brand, you can get it for about $25  Plus the cost of an additional battery makes the Eye-Fi a great purchase!  With the set up I've done about 900 pictures before they died. 900 pictures? Who can complain about performance ???

The idea....is brilliant. The implementation is well........poor.To start with I was supposed to register/set up a new account after the software installed. It wouldn't let me - and a forum search found that this was a common problem.The iPad requires you to stop existing WiFi network connections (such as those at a coffee shop), and connect to the card's network. But it's not clear in the iPad interface that this is what you should do.Also it seemed to transfer a few pics, then die.Some of the problem is the attention (or lack thereof) to little details in the instructions and interface.As a technology professional, I can tell you connectivity is extremely complicated. To make something like this work, with the various operating systems takes a BIG BIG effort. It seems they assume people have a better understanding of tech - and have left out the extra attention to details that would have made the product work seamlessly.

This is the first time I've ever bought a sound card and I figured why not have one of the best ones on the market. I've always been against sound cards because I felt they were a waste of money and the the improvement to sound wasn't worth the money.Well after using the card for a few months I can say I was completely wrong with being against sound cards, at least this one. It eliminated some fuzziness I'd hear when I turned the volume higher, drastically changed the clarity of everything and separated different sounds brilliantly.If you've never owned a sound card you should definitely get this one. You don't realize how terrible the sound you have now is till you get one. Everything sounded so muddy and rough before and now it's literally like I'm standing right next to the person talking or the artist singing. Plugging in my Sennheiser HD 598's into the sound card and listening to vocal tracks in FLAC is nothing short of amazing! You really do feel as though you were at the recording studio listening to them sing or in the front row of a concert. You hear every breath, every string strummed, imperfections of somebody missing a note or voice slightly cracking, every breath the artist takes. You literally hear everything that was recorded whether you want to or not!My advice to you if you're going to buy a sound card of this caliber is to make sure you have fairly expensive headphones and speakers. You'd really be doing yourself a major disservice buying a $200 sound card and using some cheap $40 speakers and a pair of $60 headphones. If you don't want to spend the money on expensive headphones and speakers then please don't buy this sound card because it won't be worth it for you. You'd hear the same sound quality on a $20 sound card so there's no reason to pay that much money for something that won't sound any different.My only issue with the Xonar Essence ST so far is sometimes it won't work when I turn my computer on. When I bought the card a few months ago I was running Windows 7 64-Bit and it was a nightmare getting the card to work. I'd turn on my computer, I'd hear the card turn on, then I'd try to play something and there would be no sound. I'd check the input to make sure everything was right, I'd check the audio mixer in Windows 7 to make sure there's sound (Which there was) and there was no way to get it to work. I'd have to restart my PC and it sometimes would work again and other times it would require another restart to get it to work again.When I upgraded to Windows 8 Pro 64-Bit the new drivers completely solved the issue of the card not working. That solved the problem for about 2 months and then I did a update to Windows 8 and now the problem has returned. Granted, it happens way less now then it did before but it's still very annoying to have to restart your PC once you figure out you don't have sound.Overall this is an amazing card that should be added to everyone's computer that loves music, It's a lot of money to spend on just a sound card but I think you're ears are worth it. Your ears listen to a lot of garbage throughout the day, they deserve to be spoiled every once in awhile!
summary: Fantastic but the drivers need work.

reviewText: Had this for about 6 months now.  From time to time, and now more frequently (at least once a week), when the computer screen comes back on from power saver mode, the screen looks like it is having "bad reception".  The screen is all pixelated in weird colors.  I can only attribute this to the screen saver turning the screen power saver on, or something to that affect.  It's a pain in the ass, as the only solution is to either reboot the computer, or to unplug the device from the computer, and plug it back in.  Both of which are pain-in-the-ass solutions.Don't recommend this product to anyone.

I wanted to get some Apple batteries that they sell 6 for $30 but my logical side realize that I probably could find something similar cheaper. So I did some Google searching and found somebody who compared these Eneloops to the Apple batteries and they are identical. So basically you save between 25 and 30% instead of buying the Apple branded batteries. The one thing that I do appreciate also which you cannot do with the Apple batteries is by 4 packs or 8 packs.  I will clarify I ment but the 4pack AA with Charger & 4 pack AA = $30... but 6pack AA & charger $30 which is the same as apples.Buy the 2AA a the charger and then a 4 pack AA of Eneloops & save $7.00 on Apples price!http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000IV0RD6/ref=cm_cd_asin_lnkOne thing I will say is that the Apple charger is way more styling than the Sanyo but really I'm not that vain. When you by Eneloops you are getting the best rechargeable batteries on the market they just last forever and you can recharge them and are good for the earth so it's a win-win-win all the way around. I will never buy another disposable battery again.NOTE: THE SANYO CHARGER CHARGES AAA BATTERIES TOO!!!  So I fell it beats Apples charge it that respect too.  So Apples unit is not better even though it looks nicer.One thing I've come to consider is that since the Apple charger is so much nicer you might want to drop the $30 and buy that one (yes for that price you will get to less AA batteries) but the charger is so much nicer in my opinion. But then thereafter by all the other batteries you need here as they are the same quality (and as some reviewers have pointed out even better quality)Thanks for reading
summary: Wanted Apple batteries & didn't want the Mac Tax... PERFECT!!!

reviewText: Having never tried these brand of batteries I figured I would give it a shot.  So far they are decent quality batteries.  My only wish for this is the battery charger to be a little better and tell me if my rechargeable are bad or not.
summary: So far so good with these batteries

reviewText: I like this charger because it charges both AA and AAA batteries which is nice. I am partial to the eneloop brand so this was a good buy. My complaint is that I don't really understand what the lights mean. I put it known dead batteries and it started blinking a green light above them. I did not know what that meant but it never changed. The batteries ended up charged but there was no way to tell when the charging is done. I assumed the light would give me more information, but I guess not.
summary: Affordable battery charger but tough to understand

reviewText: After going through a few bags, I decided on this medium Messenger bag by Tenba.  For me this is probably the best of a lot of good bags available.  The bag can hold a lot of gear.  I have a Canon T3i with lens and hood attached, a 70-300 mm zoom with hood, a 55-250mm zoom with hood, two small primes, and a 430EX flash, all in the main compartment.  I also have a 6"x8" folded soft box, and various manuals.  There is room in the side pockets for my filters, extra batteries, lens and camera cleaning supplies, and other small stuff.  The front has pockets for SD cards, keys, note pads,pens etc.  The top cover of the bag has a zipper on top so you can access gear from inside without opening the bag for the world to see whats in there.  With all this the bag is extremly lightweight, so it won't kill your shoulder during a day of shooting.  The shoulder strap could be a little more comfortable, but I replaced mine with another strap from a Tamarac bag.  One downside is there is no waterproof cover available, but this bag is made from military grade materials, so that should help in wet weather.  All in all, this bag serves it's purpose which is to carry a lot of gear without making you feel like the world is on your shoulders. The bag is attractive without calling attention to itself (i.e. "I have expensive cameras, steal me.)  All in all great bag.

I bought these and the Koss KTXPro1 Titanium.  The Koss only cost $15 but sound a lot better than these.  There's essentially no bass.  I also have the Sennheiser PX 100-II, and they do sound good, but have no volume control.

When looking for a DSLR backpack i came across this one by AmazonBasics. This bag is anything but Basic, on the outside and on your back its Comfortable Looking and seems small on the outside, but when you open it up its like Narnia! is so big and holds so much I will probably have trouble filling it! the padding is great, the whole interior where the lens and camera goes is all adjustable, move the dividers around at will via velcro which holds super strong! It comes with the dividers place in already in recommended spots ill say, i moved 2 so that my telephoto lens is laying on its side taking up two spots and put that divider underneath it for its extra padding it offered! super amazed and SATISFIED!!
summary: SPOT ON! even bigger on the inside then expect but discreet on the outside?!

reviewText: I was so tired of hunting down my remotes,now I dont have too. Looked at alot of stores and couldnt find anything like it. This is just what the doctor ordered
I waited about 8 months to give a review on this guy - just in case. To this day I have never had a problem. Works beautifully and would definitely buy again.

I purchased a Blu Ray burner and use these discs to back up my pictures and documents.  My pictures alone amount to around 63 gigs, so I definitely pack them as full as possible.  I don't like to delete pictures I've taken and I've lost a few over the years that I would do just about anything to get them back.  No longer do I have to worry about a HD crashing or losing the flash drive.  Plus since the discs are so resilient against scratches, I have peace of mind that they're not easily destroyed.
summary: Perfect for backing up important material

reviewText: After formatting the card IN CAMERA as suggested in the manual, this card stops recording every 8 seconds with a Canon T3i DSLR, I thought something was wrong with the card and bought another one... still the same thing. So if you own a high end DSLR and want to shoot video, you won't have any luck with this card.
summary: Not fast enough for Canon T3i video

reviewText: Nothing less than a six pin to your PC from the digital port on your camera is going to work. It might be ok for transferring stills, but don't rely on it to get any decent video. You need a six pin - no way around it. It MIGHT work, but don't be surprised if it doesn't recognize the connection.
summary: It probably won't work the way you hope it will

reviewText: I needed an extension cord that I could plug a 3 pronged plug into. If you look at the photo, you will notice that one end has a standard 3 prong plug that goes into the wall socket. The other end has 3 prong "openings", but they are so close together, you could not put a 3 prong plug into it. Complete waste of money. Hope I can save some other people from making the same mistake.

Just received this early today. Made sure to update the firmware first thing. Using this primarily as a file for DVD/BR, backup device with Acronis True Image, and the add-on package "Gallery" for hosting photos and videos online since I have hit my limit with Flickr.Setup was easy. A simple TCP/IP assignment and it was on my network. Setup for Jumbo frame support and I am seeing writes in the neighborhood of 18MB / second. It's acceptable but no way optimal. I have have seen 50MB plus on my server to server copy's.The add on packages are a bit dated (old phpAdmin/mysql etc...) but it works. The Gallery is nice and works as advertised.I would imagine the FTP and WordPress portions would work just as well. SMB setup is a cinch and downlevel NETBios name works and advertises in the network neighborhood properly.For ~50-60 bucks I can't complain.
summary: Good device if you understand it's use and it's price point

reviewText: Product is what was described and I received quickly.  Would have prefered 6 gauge, but I ordered 8 gauge...  Will do the job for a small run from distribution block to amp.
summary: Product received as described - Fast shipping

reviewText: I bought this and hooked it up with no problems. Less than fifteen minutes and it was working. I bought it so I could do away with the HDMI cable running across my living room. My only problem was watching a movie from my laptop. As soon as I put the laptop to full screen it froze up. If I wanted to watch a movie in a little box, it workrd fine. Not much sence hooking up a laptop to a 42" screen if you can only watch it in small screen view. I returned it and I'm still looking for a replacement. Everything else workrd fine, including playing music from my laptop through my Bose speakers hooked to the TV.

wow, i was impress with this little gizmo, i don't have to watch avi movies in my computer any more, just hook up with little micca player to my lcd and i get to watch movies there. i love it, and very happy about it.
Many people might not share the same opinion, but anything I have bought that is Panasonic has given me great reliability. These batteries are no exception. The price and shipping was excellent

This mouse worked great for around 5 months and then failed.  Instead of moving smoothly across the screen, it pauses and is jumpy or sticky.  This is especially noticeable while playing games (Starcraft 2 became unplayable due to this).I was very surprised when it stopped working due to the great reviews it gets.  I thought it might be getting interference from my wireless router, so I moved that and it didn't help.I have bought a new Logitech Anywhere Mouse and so far that is working well.

I have 3 of these mice and they all work perfectly. They have an on/off button on the bottom, but you don't need to use it. They shut themselves off automatically after not being moved for a short time. The battery lasts for months and I am a heavy PC user. It's nice that they come in different colors too. I'm not sure what the range is, but it is at least 12 feet. They don't interfere with each other either. It fits comfortable in my hand, my wife's hand, and my 4 your old daughter's hand. This is really a great mouse and I highly recommend it.
Died the day I got it. I turned it on maybe five times, then it just stopped working. Maybe I just got a bad one, but this is the 2nd. Fenix that has let me down.
summary: Died the day I got it

reviewText: The DP-008 has a very simple to use interface and I specifically like the physical knobs since it makes mixing much easier and faster. The recording quality is superb...what you feed into it is what you get. My only pet peeve is when it comes to copying and pasting tracks for ex., it can be difficult since the unit is time based (versus bar based). But with an optional footswitch, the punch-in recording works great. You can search YouTube for MoodRays to hear my demo song recorded with the TASCAM.

Item did not work and had to be returned.  I tried to use it with eyefinity and I did not get any output signal from this adapter.  I also did not like the form factor of this adapter much as I like to keep my computer fairly close to the wall, and this adapter with a cable plugged in forced the computer pretty far from the wall.

I originally bought this for my old Canon EOS A2e, which is a film camera from the 90's, so I didn't want to spend a lot of money for a camera strap I won't use often.  But, this strap is more comfortable than the ones for my various DSLR's, including my current Canon 60D.  The neoprene makes the camera a little more bouncy, but I find it to be massaging as opposed to the stiff OEM strap.  So, I just ordered another one for the Canon 5D Mark III that I just ordered.By the way, mine came with small "D" rings (not pictured by Amazon), probably meant for the loops found on old film camera straps from the 80's. I simply removed the rings and attached the strap to the camera just like the OEM strap.  The width of the strap is about 1/4" wider on the neck than the Canon 60D strap and identical in width where it attaches to the camera.***UPDATE*** The strap falls apart easily on cameras that I often use. So, it's best on those cameras you plan to use only about once a month.
summary: Surprisingly Nice and Comfortable but Not Well Made

reviewText: I originally bought the Aputure version of this cable and returned it immediately. It was unbelievably flimsy. I decided to try the Yongnuo before going directly for the Canon unit. It is much better than the Aputure and I'm going to keep it. So I can't say how it compares to the Canon directly but it sure beats the pants off of the Aputure.

Every time I use this kit I am surprised by not only the quality, but the wonderful price.
