After all, compare it to the competition and it's clear.I know it's overly used, 'you get what you pay for' but in this case, that's not so.I highly recommend this to anyone looking to develop their first studio.One of the many great features is that it is so portable. And, I am able to set it up on my own. Although, having an assistant certainly helps.

I received the item in good time, well packaged and in good shape. The price was splendid for the quality and I am happy to have found this item on Amazon.com. Thanks to everyone involved in bringing this quality filled, beautiful monitor to me.

UPDATED REVIEW: OK.... I now must edit my once glowing review to a dismal one. After about 6-8 weeks my (once awesome) mouse is useless. The wireless USB dongle has become intermittent and disconnects/re-connects every time the dongle is bumped in the slightest. And unfortunately it's just past the warranty window from the seller. I didn't even try taking the warranty up with Microsoft as they have founded their empire out of telling anybody with a problem or complaint to "get-bent". Can you tell I used to work I.T. in a Microsoft-based company or two ?? ;^) lolORIGINAL REVIEW: If you have surfaces that this isn't working on............. then go to the Microsoft product support webpage and download the proper driver for whatever operating system that you're using!! BTW - There are now drivers for BOTH versions of XP, one for the 32 bit and one for the 64 bit version. This mouse works on everything that I've tried so far including pants leg, chair/couch arm, and even high-gloss table tops.
A really nice design.  It fits my iPod very snug and protects it from falls and scratches.  The material that the case is made of is very strong and reliable.  It's a really nice case.

For my petite head and ears these headphones fit comfortably and look just right (not too big not too small). They are on the small side compared to other over-the-ear headphones. However, for the price, the features can't be beat: foldable, big enough to cover ear (the bose ones were too small), comfy, good sound, and cool looking. I was very particular on finding a pair of headphones that were not  too bulky. I prefer the breathable thin fabric head band of the urbanearzz compared to the other heavily padded pleather ones (I owned the 'folding' medium-sized skull candy, and they kept slipping out of place due to the bulky padding on the head band). The only reason i give it 4 starts is because while the fabric is a pro for comfort, I think it may be a con for durability. Either way, for the amazon price, these pair of earphones and packed with awesome features. If you are trying to balance portability, sound, aesthetics, and comfort -- plus you have a relatively petite head -- then these are the headphones for ya!

I love this camera. It takes amazing videos and amazing pictures. It is the perfect companion for snorkeling or just to take to the pool. The reason it received such a low rating from me is because I bought this camera about a year ago and it's already broken. I have no idea what happened to it. All I know is that one day it worked and then one day it didn't. It was such a disappointment. I guess it's a good thing it's not too expensive. Besides, it gives me a good reason to upgrade. Overall, good camera though!

I really enjoy using these headphones.  I use them as my main DJing headphones, and beingSennheiser HD25-1 II Closed-Back Headphones's at heart, this is the classic pair of headphones many DJ's have come to love, now with a little bit of flair.Sound quality: Really good quality.  The sound is crisp, the lows reach deep and the highs have great clarity. The sound feels very closed in though, being tightly closed headphones, so I definitely prefer my open-backedBeyerdynamic DT 990 PRO Open Studio Headphones 250 Ohmsfor leisurely listening.  In the DJ booth, though, these sound great.Isolation: These headphones keep out sound pretty well.  As you'd expect it cannot match the isolation you'd get from most in-ear earbuds, but as far as conventional headphones go these do a great job. You'd think that over the ear headphones would do a better job than on-ear ones, but this beats out my old headphones, Audio-Technica ATH-M50 Professional Studio Monitor Headphones (excellent headphones by the way), as far as isolation goes. As for leaking sound out, I don't really care about it so I don't know (I use different earbuds when I'm on the go) but they're decent at that, too.Comfort: They are more or less comfortable, although over time they start to get a little painful since, in the name of isolation, they clamp down on your head fairly hard.  I can't use these for easy listening usually just because my head starts to hurt over time, as these press my ears against my head hard.Style: This one is really up to you.  I think they look pretty cool (the all black original version of these headphones are pretty bland if you ask me) though they can rub people in two ways: a) some people presume they are cheap and plasticky (which perhaps is a plus against thieves!); b) they look a little immature/tacky.  Sure, I can see where you're coming from, so if you ascribe to these groups, try the originalSennheiser HD25-1 II Closed-Back HeadphonesHope this helps those of you who are deciding which headphones to go for!
summary: Great headphones, and Adidas fit it with style.

reviewerName: Fiat Lux "A man with a bass just walked in, a...
reviewText: This is a HDMI Category 2 cable. It looks well built. The cable is thick, yet flexible. The end fits snugly. It's cheap. It works.I was at Best Buy the other day and saw a HDMI cable for almost $200. Yep, you read right. $200. That's $100 per meter. That's as much as forty foot longs at Subway, or a 1994 Ford Aspire. My videophile friend tells me that high-priced HDMI cables are better than cheap ones, since it's expensive to make 99.99% deoxygenated wire, which apparently prevents degradation of the signal.Who knew that oxygen degraded a digital signal? Too much oxygen also probably destroys the Higgs bosons in the cheap HDMI cable, which is probably why I cannot view my Blu-rays in the 2160P that my videophile friend's expensive HDMI cable allows. I told him he should buy theDiamond HDMI Digital Audio/Video Cable W/ Ethernet Connection (5M)for a bargain $2694.75 (at the time of this review), but for some reason he hung up on me.I did consider buying the Audioquest Diamond HDMI cable myself since a simple exercise in logic determined that this cable would be approximately 450 times better than the BlueRigger HDMI cable ($5.99), right? So I almost ordered it but then I suddenly realized that the cable was more expensive than my TV by a magnitude of almost 10.  I went for the BlueRigger cable instead. But that's OK, because it allows me to save up to buy theRelaxman Relaxation Capsulethat I want. Buying HDMI cables can be so stressful.

I tried this unit for a few days and while it does a nice job when used at home, it is difficult to use while mobil.  First the screen is almost impossible to read in the car.  It's almost impossible to change bands, frequencies etc while moving as well.  Trying to do so is more dangerous then texting which I also won't do.  That makes the unit unfit for mobil operation.  Used while stopped or at home stationary it works fine.

I bought this as a gift. I however I do own the 3ft version and it has taken a large amount of abuse and continues to work great. The person that I gave the 4ft one to seems to like it and says the reception on his radio is far better than it ever was in the past.

I bought it because it is a market sleeper. In other words, it is more powerful than you would expect. Compared to others in the same basic class it is loaded with RAM, has a huge hard drive and a duo core processor. It is very fast.Great buy.

Heard good reviews on this RAM but when installed in my 2011 Mac Mini, it failed memtest86 over and over. I was so frustrated when trying to edit a movie and it would crash over and over. I was so frustrated when I wanted to surf the web with Chrome and would get the "Aww, snap" error message.  I went with another RAM supplier and everything is working great now and no crashes.

Let me start by saying that I bought this primarily for geocaching. Without any experience with GPS units it seems to me that the PN-60 has geocaching as a focus. After loading pocket queries from geocaching.com I have everything I need - descriptions, previous logs, hints, D/T ratings, the works.The GPSr itself is ergonomic and fits comfortably in my hand. The buttons are well placed and one hand operation is easy. The 3.5GB of internal memory is a big plus, leaving little need to purchase a SD card at this point.The provided maps are just what I need, showing roads, points of interest, and even businesses. If that's not enough there's the option to download maps from DeLorme's online library. I used the included certificate to download some TOPO maps but haven't had the need for more detailed maps. The deal is pretty sweet though, $30 for a year of unlimited downloads.One issue to raise is that I'm a Mac user and the included TOPO 9.0 software isn't compatible. What that means for Mac users is that we can download maps and load them manually but are missing out on extra features the software provides.Overall I'd recommend this unit to anyone but it's worth doing your own research.
summary: My first GPS, pretty good so far

reviewText: Since I do a lot of hiking and work in the mountains and woods, I needed a good sensitive GPS. The PN-60 is overall a very nice device that works well and doesn't let you down. I owned a PN-40 and liked it, but this unit is head and shoulders better than the 40. It's batteries last much longer and it picks up signals better under the tree canopy or in hollows. It maps nicely, tracks good, has no problem with waypoints, and with the PN series maps keeps you from getting lost. Don't rely on a compass, get one of these. I don't regret the purchase at all.

The insulation is thick, and i think the connectors themselves are a little bulky when compared to originals...the shielding isn't what it could be... but for 98% of applications, i don't think you an go wrong with this cable.  it arrived  in good time, makes an excellent replacement cable for your VGA monitor or to run between your PC and a flat screen TV, which is what i used this for.  as you may know, the longer your cable, the greater your signal loss (i.o.w. the worse your picture resolution).but for short distances - this cable will work perfectly!

I've had this for two years.PROS:It is small, cheap, light weight, with a very long battery life.CONS:It is PAINFULLY slow.  Don't expect to be able to run two programs at once (like IE and Word), or it will come to a halt.  Even just running the latest version of IE is insanely slow.  Infuriating, really.  I tried installing additional RAM, using the recommended RAM.  But it did not increase the speed noticeably.  And it let to many other problems, like the special HybridEngine thing not running correctly, and issues with shutdown, and batter life.It also has a sharp plastic edge along the front which digs into my palms and really starts to hurt over time.  It's as if the plastic wasn't cut right, or didn't fit together right when they constructed it.I can no longer use this.  I decided to spend the extra money and get an ultrabook.

I bought this camera in the summer of 2010 as a birthday present for myself and it worked perfectly fine for about 6 months, then the BLUR monster must have attacked its insides. It takes blurry pictures most of the time now and the steady shot features does NOT work properly at all, neither does the automatic take when smiling feature. It's just decent overall.
First of all it's a bargin and well made. It holds my Lumix GX1 with 14-42X and 45-175X perfectly. And it has plenty of zipper pockets for cards, batteries, lens caps, and car keys.

reviewText: I grabbed this for travel because I ripped the grip off my 7D just to cut down on some weight.  The grip has an RRS AS plate & I didn't want to pay the price for one for a non-gripped body.  My tripod has an AS clamp so had to get something compatible.I figured I would grab something cheapish as a stop-gap and was really surprised at the quality.  This is great and works no problem at all with my arca-swiss ballhead.  The build quality is good and it's stable as a rock.If I had to pick something - the edges are a little sharp compared to the nice finish on the RRS stuff but at a fraction the price, it's a small issue.  If you comparing this to similar, just click the buy on this one.

I used several different drivers from the internet and the disc included. The unit could find other networks, but did not connect and there was never any error code given. This thing does not work. Pay a little more for something that works right.
The Sony carrying case arrived quickly and is a good value.  The Sony Cyber-shot DSH-HX30V fits perfectly and the pouch for SD cards is an extra benefit.  I would recommend this seller.

I've used this with 4 different 3.5" drives, (1) Seagate 1.5TB, (2) WD 3TB and (1) Seagate 4TB. When I first cut the device on, my PC (Windows 8 Release Preview) recognized the drives instantly, via USB 3. When I started copying my music to my 1.5TB drive plugged into the device, the connection was lost after about 45 seconds. I couldn't see any of the drives. I went straight to my control panel/System/Device Manager. There I noticed an exclamation mark under Universal Serial Bus controllers. I deleted this item, restarted my PC and the unit was back. Before continuing I unplugged/re-plugged the device several times, and it was recognized when plugged in each time.NOTE:There IS NOT a USB transfer problem in Windows 7 nor Windows 8 Release Preview during large transfers. This IS an issue with early versions of the USB 3.0 drivers. I had a problem during large transfers of the drive's in the docking bay disconnecting randomly, until I updated my USB 3.0 drivers. Go to your control panel, System and Security, System, Device Manager. Scroll down to your Universal Serial Bus controllers and look for your 3.0 Host Controller or 3.0 Root Hub. Here you will see the mfg. and know where to go to get updated drives for your system. Mine was Renesas, so I went there, found the latest versions of the firmware and drivers for my USB 3.0 and have had no problem transferring files since I updated my drivers. You may need to update the firmware on your StarTech docking bay, there are instructions on there site for this. Hope this helps anyone with problems using this docking bay.I've copied 2.5TB of movies to one of my WD drives, 1 TB of music and about another TB of pictures to my other WD drive and a backup to the Seagate. After I finished copying the movies, (my movie drive is shared via my network to my TV via my WD HD TV box) my daughter watched movies most of the night with one of her friends. When I asked them about the movie quality, they said it was "as good as any picture on DVD or satellite", so the device was constant for 8 continuous hours of use. I've kept the fan's off, they aren't loud but are noticeable, because after I woke up the next morning after my daughter watching movies all night, the drives didn't feel any hotter than I would expect.I will say the included USB cable is very short. I ordered StarTech.com SuperSpeed USB 3.0 Cable A to B M/M - 10 feet (USB3SAB10) from Amazon.com and it worked as well, allowing me of course to move the device to a more suitable location.The device is in a plastic case, not very heavy, but I would say well made. The power buttons light up blue when on, and have a red activity flash. I would recommend this device.

PROThis product works as advertised.  I'm getting great throughput on the drives that are plugged into this bay.  Installation is easy, access to drives couldn't be any easier.  They are a good product, I have several of them but this is my first time using the USB 3.0 version.  This is a great way to add mass storage to your laptop or desktop PC and still have the drives accessible.CONSThe USB cable is very short, only 3 feet.  I had to purchase a USB 6ft extension cable ($8).  Keep this in mind if your drives will not be located right next to your machine, and order an extension separately.  A USB 2.0 extension will work but you won't get the high transfer rate you get with USB 3.  The cable does matter!
summary: + Works great, - cable is really short.

reviewText: I had been using aThermaltake  BlacX eSATA  USB Docking Station, but it failed to work with a new WD 3TB hard drive (Western Digital Caviar Green 3 TB SATA III 64 MB Cache Bare/OEM Desktop Hard Drive - WD30EZRX). A little bit of research revealed that this is a known shortcoming of the Thermaltake device. Fortunately, the StarTech unit fills my needs. It does not have eSATA support like the Thermaltake unit, but it more than compensates with USB 3.0 support. And it recognized all 3TB on the WD drive, unlike the Thermaltake which only recognized 746GB. I especially like that the two on-off switches in the StarTech are in recessed slots in the front of the device. The Thermaltake unit had its switch sticking out in the back. I've been using the StarTech unit for over a month now with no problems.** Update 2/26/2014 ** It's been 18 months now and the device is still working fine.
summary: Worked great out of the box ...

reviewText: this item worked then i was told that an upgrade was available. after upgrading, it stopped working and calls to netgear went nowhere. i think you have to buy the more expensive version of this product to accomplish the goal of connectivity with your laptop widi feature. the vendor did give me a refund as was good about the entire transaction.

No frills, solid build quality. I popped in a 120GB SSD that had been cloned from my internal boot drive and plugged it into my elderly 2006 Mac Mini which has been hacked to run the storage-hungry Lion. This ADSL Modem is work well with CenturyLink.I hate to pay the bill for their modem, that cost me about $4 monthly. So, when I ordered this modem and I'm really satisfied!It's really faster than a regular ZyXEL ADSL modem (EQ660R). Unbelievable FAST! And it won't slow me down.My internet speed is 4Mbps.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Don't forget to download LATEST VERSION of FIRMWARE. It's important!http://www.tp-link.com/en/products/details/?categoryid=221&model;=TD-8616#down----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------How does it work? I will show you how to set up this modem.STEPS:1. Plug Ethernet (LAN) cable to this Modem and to your computer(Laptop or Desktop) LAN port,2. Make sure that "ADSL" links are SOLID (GREEN).3. Open a browser (Ex. Internet Explorer or other browsers)(there is no internet yet),4. just type on the web address box: >>>>*** If this isn't working, read my "***NOTE***" below ****<<<<Type: 192.168.1.1Press Enter key on your keyboard.5. A new window appears "Authentication Required"The following are default the username and password:Username: adminPassword: adminPress EnterTo login to your TP-Link Modem.6. Change settings:Click on "Statistics" tab:Virtural Circuit: "PVC1" instead "PVC0"7. Save it.8. Click "Basic Setup" tab9. Again, Virtual Circuit: PVC1 then click "Save" button.Refresh your browser and make sure it showVPI: 8VCI: 3510. Open a browser, is there still NO internet connection? If no, you need to set up a new IP address. Very simple...--------------------------------------------------------------------------------***For Windows XP Only***Start, Run, Type " cmd ", press enter. Go to "Command Prompt" below.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------***For New Windows Version Only(Vista, 7, & 8.1)***To run Command Prompt as an administratorClick the Start button Picture of the Start button.In the search box, type " command prompt "In the list of results, right-click Command Prompt,and then click "Run as administrator."Administrator permission required If you're prompted for anadministrator password or confirmation, type the password or provide confirmation.Go to "Command Prompt" below.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Command Prompt-----------------------Type: "ipconfig /release" and press EnterIt should read:IP Address: 0.0.0.0Subnet Mask: 0.0.0.0 so on...Type: "ipconfig /renew" and press Enter.By now, the network should have assigned a new IP address to your computer automatically.----------------After you got a new IP address.That's it. Open a browser. There you go.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------***NOTE***If step #4 isn't working, you need to change your IP Address in Windows.To change your network IP address in Windows XP, Vista, or 7:1. Go to your desktop, and right-click on something called "Open Network Connections" or "My Network Places"(If you're using Windows Vista or 7, look for the Network and Sharing Center through Control Panel)2. Click Properties. You should now see something called Local Area Connection or something similar3. Right-click on your connection (titled Local Area Connection if you're using an ethernet cable)and click Properties4. Under the General tab, double-click on the "Internet Protocol (TCP/IP)"5. A new window appears. On its own General tab, click the box beside "Use the following IP address"6. Type in ones until you fill the box up (it should read "IP Address: 192.168.1.2")7. Press Tab. You'll notice the Subnet Mask section automatically fills up with numbers(it should read "Subnet mask: 255.255.255.0")(Don't change this!)8. Type in ones until you fill the box up (it should read "Default gateway: 192.168.1.1")9. Click OK10. Click OK to bring you back to the "Local Area Connection" screenGo to Step #4.------------------------------------***When you're done after Step #9, go back to your Network settings.1. Right-click Local Area Connection and Click on Properties again2. Again, under the General tab, double-click on the "Internet Protocol (TCP/IP)"3. Select "Obtain an IP address automatically"4. Click OK5. Click OK6. Go to Step #10.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Note: If you want to add another router like a Wireless or Wired router. You need to repeat Step #10.I hope this will help you.-------Updated on March 4, 2012-----------------------------------------Default Settings:IP Address: 192.168.1.1Username: adminPassword: adminNo cap letter "A"-------Updated on October 8, 2013---------------------------------------Revived my review-Added more details

I'm always on my computer, usually more than 12 hours per day. I never turn this mouse off. I've had this mouse since mid October 2011 and the software tells me I have about 870 days left of battery life. Wow. I've used it for 9 months and have never had to change the batteries. I do use 2 batteries with it instead of one though. So that I'm sure helps the battery life.This mouse is smooth and quite good. I like the forward/back buttons above the thumb rest. I use them all the time. I don't use the hidden thumb button though. I did set it to the copy function but that was just done yesterday.I didn't have the software installed (it works fine without it) though my laptop screen would blank when it goes to sleep but right after it blanks it would wake right back up. I found out that installing the Logitech software fixed that issue. So I recommend installing the software, even if it's just to get more functionality from the mouse. The software tells you how many days you have left of battery life and what the percent is of battery life that remains.I have smallish hands. Medium mostly but my hands are fat (I'm fat) and stubby and this mouse feels like a good fit for my hand. When this mouse goes bad if it ever does, I'll definitely be buying another Logitech mouse. I previously had a Logitech M series mouse and the scroll wheel quit working so I bought this mouse. I'm quite pleased with it. I like the feature where you can click the button on top and do a super fast scrollup or down such as on a very long web page. It's handy. That feature also worked without the software installed.One con of this mouse is when using the scroll wheel going down it kinda pops up the screen. It's not smooth scrolling. If you scroll down, a lot of the time the text on the screen jumps down. I lose my place and realize it's not scrolled down at all even though I scrolled down. It's annoying. It has something to do with the clicking of the scroll wheel.

This is a great product. You can drive relatively fast and it will stay planted. I much rather friction mount compared to the suction mount because the it won't leave the circular marks on the windshield and last time I checked, it is illegal to put anything on the windshield anyway.

I got this to replace a .Audio 470 that stopped working (which I loved). I tried it out, and audio works well, and the mic quality also is good (although a bit quieter than the old one and compared with a Logitech headset I have). However, as soon as I tried it on, I noticed one major problem: It's VERY tight. And I don't at all have a large head. The old Plantronics sat nice and loosely over my head (wouldn't fall off, but didn't squeeze my head). But this one squeezes my ears and I can only tolerate it for a couple minutes. So basically that makes this worthless. My two options are to try to bend the plastic at the top and risk breaking it or to return it, and in all practicality I'm going to have to go with the latter option.

I decided to try these V-Moda earbuds because, quite frankly, the cost of most of the Bass Freq models is absurdly high these days. The V-Moda "Octave" Hi-Def earbuds sound pretty fantastic with a balance between clear, higher ranges (treble) and thumping lower ranges (bass). The rubber earbud protectors are comfortable (I prefer earbuds so if you have trouble with this headphone style you should continue to stay away) even after hours of use. They feel and look pretty durable, even when compared to the Bass Freqs so I thought I'd picked a complete winner. Unfortunately, I kept getting a nagging feeling that I was missing something. For my test music, I played a hip-hop song I knew to be full of bass and listened to it with both the Bass Freqs and the Octaves. The 'thumping' base I thought was quite acceptable on the Octaves turned out to be no so much when compared to the Bass Freqs. I don't listen to a lot of hip-hop/rap, but I do love to hear bass in whatever I'm playing and so I am a little disappointed that the Octaves aren't quite as powerful as the Bass Freqs.On the other hand, for about $30 you do get a very good-sounding pair of earbuds with their own carrying bag, a set of earhooks to attach to the earbuds, a splitter so another listener can enjoy the beats with you (assuming you want to sit that close;) and extra silicone fitters for the buds (which, by the way, appear sturdier than the Bass Freqs, which seem to go a little soft after a couple months of use so the noise-canceling seal isn't as great). I've decided to stick with the Bass Freqs for iPod listening, and I've been using these Octaves for my part-time transcription job; they cancel noise better than any other headset I've tried and because the higher tones come through darn-near crystal clear, recorded speech is amazingly easy to pick up.Verdict: I love the headset, just not for what I originally purchased them for. If the bass was as rich and deep as the Bass Freqs while still maintaining clear higher tones, the Octaves would be 5-star for sure.

I absolutely love this camera. I spent my first day getting used to it and I still have a ton to learn because this camrea offers so many features. The picture quality is excellet and the video quality is the best I have worked with.

I have had this camera for about 3 months. When I first got the camera I didn't realize all that this T2i was capable of doing. The 18mip CMOS sensor is outstanding, the quality of the photo's rival any DSLR out there. It is light and a joy to use.Auto Mode - If you want to point-n-shoot, this is the best option, Takes great photo's and very fast auto focus.Scene modes are terrific - landscape, portrait, close-up, sport etc.Where I found this camera to shine is when you switch to program, Tv, Av, manual or A-Dep. I have found a whole new world of taking photo's, molding a photo to what I want to see.Video is superb, last weekend I shot over 45 minutes of different video's at Daytona. The quality is great, it focused in every video and the cars were doing over 200mph.I am getting about 800 photo's on one battery charge without flash. I very rarely use LIVE MODE, because the camera is about 25% slower in focusing when in that mode.If I had to pick a camera today, I would still choose the T2i,Before I forget, invest in the Blue Crane DVD's to learn all you need to learn at your own pace for this DSLR.I got the kit lenses when I bought the camera, but since then I have added the CANON 18-135mm IS, CANON 50mm f/1.4 and the TAMRON 17-50mm, f/2.8 VC.

So, for the price, you get a fixed-memory MP3 player.  8 gigs.  Let's take a look:I understand that you can watch videos on here, but I'd never do it seeing that the screen is so tiny.  The menu that uses the screen is nice, however.- The design is all right - that stainless steel body is cool.  I like the actual buttons to press to get to menu or play/pause.- The power switch on top is a pain.  You have to slide this miniscule switch and hold it to turn it on/off.  Bad design.- The headphone cord is on the bottom.  Weird!?!- The included USB cable is TINY.  Like 4 inches long?  Maybe 6?  TINY!- Headphones are surprisingly OK.- Sound quality was all right.  I loaded a ton of MP3s on here.  I didn't use the software included because everyone here said it was garbage.  You can just plug this into your computer and it will see it no problem.  I just dragged and dropped files into the Music directory on this thing.- It doesn't play the itunes files.  m4a? Whatever.  It wouldn't play them.  I had to convert a ton of stuff into wma files so that they'd play on this thing.  Kind of a pain.  Who uses mp3s anymore?- The FM Radio is cool.  I don't know how much longer FM radio will be around, but I thought it was cute.- It's not an iPod.  Or Apple product.  Does ANYONE use anything other than iPod or iTouch/iPhone for music this days?  Wow.----Do you need a simple music player and aren't with the times and don't use itunes?  Then this is for you.  Otherwise, why are you looking and this and not buying an ipod?!?!?

Ok, I was fooled by the low price.  These bags are almost a third the cost of the next cheapest saddle sandbag that I could find. I bit, and wish I hadn't.1. The bags have two zippers - good.  The bags have a single stitch - terrible!  I couldn't believe the single stitching design.  Once sand is in the bag, the seam stretches, and sand leaks right out!  The single stitching thread is also a complete joke.  I dropped one filled bag from waist height and it burst open along the seam.  So cheap.2. The size is a complete lie.  These bag hold 10 lbs. MAX. No matter how I tried I couldn't fit more than 5 lbs in each pocket.  It's no wonder - they are half the size of the 20lb rental house bags that I currently use.It's a shame in this day and age people sell Chinese made garbage for super cheap in hopes of making a quick online buck.  Gone are the days when Craftsmanship, Quality, and Manufacturing Pride took precedence.  My advise, spend a little more and get professional quality saddle sandbags elsewhere.

reviewText: My initial 1 star relates mainly to the shipping. Shipping a hard drive in an OEM box with no foam, no padding, no protection is probably not a great idea. The box it came in wasn't even taped shut. I received it by REGULAR mail with the flap half open.Update: I did install the drive and its working fine six months later. I expect that if there was any shipping damage it would have shown up by now. You never really know though, do you?

RELIABILITY is the key factor when it comes to data storage. While not failure proof, this drive is the most reliable from the most common 2TB high performance drives. An article by Marc Prieur, published on BeHardware web site, lists hardware return rates during warranty period for return of products sold between April  2011 and October 2011 and returned by April 2012. His breakdown for the return rate of most common 2TB drives is as follows:- 7.53% Seagate Barracuda XT 2 TB SATA 6Gb/s- 5.78% Western Digital RE4-GP 2 TB- 4.53% Hitachi Deskstar 7K3000 2 TB- 3.18% Western Digital Caviar Black 2 TB- 3.07% Western Digital AV-GP 2 TB- 2.55% Seagate Barracuda LP 2 TB- 2.31% Western Digital Caviar Green 2 TB WD20EARX- 2.15% Western Digital Caviar Green 2 TB WD20EARS- 1.80% Samsung SpinPoint F4 EcoGreen 2 TBWhile WD Caviar Black (in the middle of this list) is not a 2TB reliability winner, it is the most reliable high performance 2 TB drive on Marc Prieur's list. All drives with lower return rates (bottom half of the list) are slower energy efficient "green" drives: the next line down, Seagate Barracuda LP, is a 5900 rpm drive, and all further lines down are notebook-speed 5400 rpm drives.PERFORMANCE. This drive replaced my OEM drive Hitachi HDT721010SLA, which is also a 7200 rpm drive. The average read speed has increased from 90.2 MB/s to 117.7 MB/s, and access time has dropped from 18.7 ms to 11.7 ms. Burst rate, as measured with HD Tune Pro, has increased from 179.5 MB/s to 195.1 MB/s. Quick access time is likely the reason why WD recommends this drive for photo/video editing.LOUDNESS. Indeed, as many people pointed out, this drive creates quite audible clicking sounds, much louder than the Hitachi drive which it replaced. It is not loud at the level of being annoying, but loud enough to notice the difference, and louder than any other hard disk that I work with at home or at work. In fact, it reminded me of clicking from floppy drives from the old times. The sound is the only reason why I did not rate it 5 stars.INSTALLATION. It is a plug-and-play disk with very simple installation process. There are either no instructions included with the disk or they are minimal, but it is very easy to find on the internet how to partition and format a new disk under your operating system (the disk comes not formatted and not partitioned, so one has to go through several steps before it is recognized by the system and one can write on it). Since it is SATA, there are no switches or jumpers on the disk to worry about.  I used an external eSATA/USB enclosure to partition the disk and to move my files to it before physically installing it in my desktop.
summary: Good reliability in its High Performance 2TB class, fast, but noisy

I have a pair of these well over a year now and trust me; these are QUALITY. These earbuds responds to every frequency. Makes listening to your favourite songs a real pleasure. Right now as I'm typing this review I'm listening to Usher's Confessions Album. I have had great earbuds before but none lasted as long as this one has and maintain the same audio quality over the life span of the product and both sides still work :-). I purchased a set of these for my wife and another set for myself for use on our frequent airplane trips. Although I was skeptical about the quality of sound and noise canceling when I purchased these, they have been great. The noise canceling is good enough that I can listen to music or a movie on a loud airplane without turning up the volume. The sound quality is also excellent. The highs are crisp without an annoying emphasis on sibilance and the bass is deep and balanced but not overwhelming. It is easy to understand softly spoken dialogue (even on a noisy airplane). To test the effectiveness of sound canceling, I recommend that you turn this feature on and off in an environment where there is a continuous source of loud noise (airplanes are perfect for this). The sudden reduction in noise is astonishing, almost like diving underwater except that the music or dialogue is now perfectly clear. Ambient noise is not completely eliminated but it is remarkably reduced. You will need to be attentive so that you do not miss the stewardess speaking to you or the announcement of your upcoming landing. Another great feature for traveling is that these are small and compact, especially compared to the larger over the ear type of noise canceling headphones. The earbuds are comfortable once you select the appropriate size.Perhaps the best testimony regarding the quality of these is that my wife, who is not infatuated with technology, loves these and will not travel without them. These are available at a good price (especially if you can get them on sale) and are highly recommended!

If you have manual focus lenses from your SLR days, this is currently the best deal on a camera body to bring those lenses back to life. There are inexpensive adapters for using lots of SLR lens types, and some old rangefinder lens types, with Micro Four Thirds cameras such as this one. With your old lens mounted, just set the camera mode to A for aperture priority, set the aperture on the lens to your desired f-stop, and the camera will automatically adjust the shutter and ISO for a good exposure. Manually focusing your lens is made easier because the viewfinder can magnify the subject you're focusing on.Moreover, the camera has in-body image stabilization, so the sensor compensates for camera shake. You just choose your lens's focal length from a menu, and the camera will permit slower shutter speeds without blur. Other camera lines put their image stabilization in their lenses, but the Olympus PENs have it in the body, so it can be used with any lens you mount on the camera.The camera has a full range of other digital features, and it produces images of excellent quality.Note that the Micro Four Thirds sensor, while several times the size of the sensor found in point-and-shoot digital cameras, is half the size of a frame of 35mm film. Consequently, any lens on an MFT camera will have the same angle of view as a lens with twice the focal length on a 35mm film camera. For example, a 50mm lens on an MFT camera will give the angle of view that a 100mm lens would give on a 35mm film camera.I should add that the lenses Olympus makes for its PEN cameras are excellent. The combination of the 14-42mm and 40-150mm zooms would cover a range equal to 28-300mm on a 35mm film camera, and with crisp autofocus and full autoexposure. I actually have both those lenses, and they're great. But I'm also enjoying again the great lenses I had for my old SLR, which had been sitting on a shelf since the last millennium. Film is still dead, but good lenses can live again.

I bought one of these as a replacement for another set of cheaper fans in my home theater PC.  As the PC is the source for most of my music and video in my home theater any noise is annoying.My old fans didn't make any noise, and moved a significant amount of air, but also sounded like a mini tornado.  Fed up with the racket I bought one of these as a test.It turned out to be fantastic.  Each fan has a dial on the power line allowing you to manually set the max speed.  On the lowest setting the fan is truly silent, on the highest setting there is a slight wind noise but it was still noticeably quieter than my old fans.  I bought four and using the dial set them to a mid-range setting.  The noise difference between my old fans and these is startling, these are much quieter.Based on how much air I feel each individual one pushing out of my PC it seems that these, on the high setting, don't push as much air as my old ones.  However as they are so quiet I put four into my PC case (which has the venting/mounts for this) and feel comfortable that they are all together moving far more air than my two old fans did.The PS3 is now the loudest component I have on the rack.
While the cost may be more than others, the reception of FM, sound quality and the continuous play feature of the CD make it worth every cent.

In short, this is the best router out there on the market. The RAM and the Flash space beats all other routers by a mile. Seriously. Other routers don't even come close.For those of you less advanced... stick with the original firmware. It actually works well (the original firmware even contains snippets of Tomato's VPN code), is easy to set up, and didn't have a problem dealing with the wireless and torrents I threw at it.A bit of advice though for advanced users, I've been using this router for a couple months now, and in my experience Tomato firmware works *MUCH BETTER* than DD-WRT for this router. I've installed about 5 different DD-WRT builds on my RT-N16, and Every single DD-WRT build I use, the wireless connection would slow down from about ~20 MBytes/s to ~5 MBytes/s after about ~20 minutes.Switched to Shibby's Tomato Build, and the router has worked flawlessly since. For those of you who want to try, get the following build from the tomato.groove.pl site:tomato-K26USB-1.28.RT5x-MIPSR2-083V-AIO.trxor just search for Shibby's or Toastman's latest K26 MIPSR2 Tomato build.Tomato Fixed everything for me. DD-WRT is good firmware, but they support so many different types of hardware that sometimes support slips through the cracks, like for this router.
summary: Best value router out there right now

reviewText: UPDATE 01/27/2013 I ended up returning this item because I cannot contact ASUS customer service for product support without waiting hours on the phone. It ended up being no better than the $30 trendnet router I had. Not happy and sending it back.I'm not sure if they shipped these out without resolving the old firmware, or what they did. But I had reset the unit (unplug the unit, hold down the red WPS button, then plug it back in and wait until the PWR light starts flashing). Then I had to connect the unit directly to my PC (via one of the LAN ports) and open a browser, bypass the Quick Setup program, and go right to the main admin screen (192.168.1.1)  I went to the ASUS website and downloaded the latest firmware available (v 3.0.0.4.260) and update the firmware,  then reboot the router.  After doing so, I was able to very easily connect to the internet and everything works fine. ASUS gets a 5 star for a great product at a great price, with loads of features I may or may not use. But they get an "F" rating for shipping out units with old, unusable firmware that won't work without an update.  A great router for tech geeks who can flash the firmware. But probably not for the average Joe who wants something to work right out of the box.

I have done a lot of research on the different options (Roku, Apple TV, and the boxee box) and I must say that so far so good.My main concern was being able to stream my personal collection of movies and TV shows over a hard line (powerline network). I have a lot of 720/1080p that requires a lot of bandwidth. As such, I was playing with the idea of building a home theater PC, but the cost/benefit is not great.The things that sold me on the boxee box are as follows:*  Local file playback*  File format support*  Ethernet connection*  Cost*  Ease of useI did a lot of looking around and I was stuck between this and the Roku. I decided to go with the boxee box because of its local streaming ability and I have been pretty happy with it thus far.There are a few things that I am not too happy with, which is why I deducted a star. They are as follows:*  No Amazon Prime Compatibility (this is pretty big)*  It takes a long time to scan and ID my media library*  It did not recognize a lot of TV shows that I arranged by folder/season/episode and named 1, 2, 3, etc.In all fairness, I can still go to files and browse them manually, but it doesnt have the cover art/information as when it is identified. That makes it harder for my technologically challenged better half to use.I have started to manually identify files, but that is more difficult as it does not show the folder path so I have to play an episode, figure out what it is, and have it try to ID the rest of the folder. It would be so much easier to be able to see the file path and ID it as such.These complaints are fairly minor and there are workable alternatives. I must admit, the boxee box is the best thing short of a HTPC. The cost and ease of setup/use make it a much more viable option for me. As of right now, it is the sole thing that is streaming my media and I am pretty happy to have it. I would recommend it for those who are looking for a similar set of requirements.
summary: Works for local media and some internet apps (No Amazon Prime)

reviewText: I've lived in a Windows household for many years.  I have a number of Win7 PCs in all flavors and have a WHS 2011 with 5TB of space set up.  I wanted to serve my media seamlessly to my TV.  I bought a Mac (Mac Mini) for the first time and the kids are happy with it - did this hoping it would see WHS media easily.  I also bought an AppleTV hoping it would be good for my purposes and work in a MAc ecosystem.  I also wanted to be able to update my media on the WHS media server and have a streaming device detect updates and changes automatically.  AppleTV was *not* the solution to this problem.  Getting iTunes to run on WHS 2011 was tough, but doable (separate user ID that doesn't log out and has iTunes running Home Sharing).  Updating the media in the iTunes library and having it recognized by the streaming device - now THAT was a pain.  I also wanted to keep the media in the WHS media folders (Music, Pictures, Video) without it being moved to another location, so "Automatically Add to iTunes" folder wasn't a solution.  I ditched the AppleTV and went for the Boxee.  It was recommended by friends and got some great reviews, so I thought I would try it.  It is AWESOME.  Great interface, automatically scans your home server, or whatever file share you set up, works with AirPlay and other sharing protocols  (had to set my WHS 2011 up by IP address as using the server name didn't yield any found media folders - weird).  I set up a specific user ID for the Boxee on the WHS to see the media in Read Only mode.  I LOVE the Video interface as it goes out and finds cover art for your MP4s and M4vs - some were unrecognized, so I have to figure that one out (maybe it's naming).  I have 18,000 songs, so as of this morning (12 hours of scanning so far) it's through about half of the songs.  I love the Boxee apps, but the one big one missing is Amazon Video (no, I don't work for Amazon and this is not a plug).  I subscribe to Prime and have the video app on my Panasonic Bluray player.  It would be a great addition to the Boxee as it competes directly with Vudu and is priced better for rentals - I'd also get more movies with Prime.  I like Amazon better because of its interface, too.  The Slingplayer built into the Boxee was also great.  It looks exactly like the interface on the iPhone - and you don't have to dish out another $29.99 for it like with all the other Slingplayer clients.The Boxee remote is great and reminds me of the Lenovo wireless handheld keyboard, minus the Lenovo trackball.The Boxee refurb worked like a charm out of the box.  The bottom of the Boxee was definitely dirty - but, it's the bottom.  As long as I don't lick it or keep the Boxee upside down, I'm fine.  I did get the Squaretrade warranty as the refurb clearly states "Warranty for 30 days only" right on the serial number sticker as another reviewer noted, so I had the heads-up.I have the Boxee hooked up via wired gigabit (not that it needs that kind of bandwidth, but it can't hurt).  I run 9k Jumbo frames from my home server, no hiccups so far.  Getting the battery for the remote inserted properly is the most important part when you set up.  I don't read instructions normally and couldn't figure out why the remote wasn't working and the box wasn't turning on.  First, I found the power button on the box in a place I didn't expect (kind of hidden on the top, back).  Next, duh, the battery was inserted upside down. (I figured this all out, still without reading the instructions).  I downloaded the Boxee app for iPhone but it seems to be very barebones and I haven't tried it yet.  Hopefully, some development will be done on it to make it a more interesting and functional interface - something to mirror the Boxee's excellent interface.The Mac sits in the house and keeps the kids entertained, but doesn't play nice with WHS 2011.  Time Capsule does not work, even with the 2011 connector installed and a read-write folder mapped to a drive.  All streamed media is playing through the Boxee.I still have iTunes running on the WHS with Home Sharing for the other iTunes clients in the house, but updating media is a pain.Overall, I'm VERY happy so far with the Boxee and the refurb was worth the 28% savings (50/180).

I purchased two of these switches. This is the AV model versus the standard switch of the same model number offered from Netgear. The difference is primarily the auto-QoS (Quality of Service) configuration that is built into the AV model.100-mbit switches are cheap and handle device and Internet connectivity without problem. If what you are doing is browsing the Internet and copying some DOC or MP3 files from laptop to desktop then any type of cheap switch should do the job for you. You're probably looking at a gigabit switch for a reason though. You want gigabit speeds because you have large media files that you store on a network attached storage (NAS) server with multiple devices accessing the content. If that's the case then this might be the switch for you. This switch will operate at close to gigabit speeds. I have seen over 700mbps transfer rates through this switch by copying large movies between systems. Take into consideration that when we start to achieve these speeds we must consider every component of the transfer to determine the maximum throughput. At gigabit speeds, a mechanical hard drive could become a bottleneck.The switch is plug and play. Connect the network cables, plug in the power, press the power toggle button and it's running. The connectivity lights on the front show the status. One nice feature is the lights on the front are dimmed relative to other switches. They won't light up an entire dark media room or draw attention. It uses some type of smoked plastic with lower power LEDs.The back of the switch has colored ports to indicate priority of the attached device. The switch will allow traffic from that port, based on the type of traffic it is, to trump trump traffic from lower priority ports. Therefore, I might allow my media server a higher priority than an XBox. This means if they were both reaching high throughput and the switch had to start making decisions on what to do with traffic it would allow the media server to achieve its objective. The switch also has settings to allow sensitive streams like streaming media to be prioritized over block level transfers. This is nice when someone is watching a move on a media center and someone else starts to copy a large file to/from one of the systems involved in theater experience. The switch will attempt to ensure that the movie is not interrupted by the file transfer.For QoS to work effectively, you need it to be configured at both ends of the network. This means if you have a living room media center and a NAS serving media in another room; you might want this switch to be deployed in both locations. You definitely want a gigabit switch in both locations but I'd recommend a QoS switch in both as well.Keep in mind, all of your network switches should be of the same speed throughout your network unless you know what you're doing. If you connect a fast ethernet switch to your NAS server and a gigabit switch to your media center PC then you're not going to get gigabit speeds between the two.This is an excellent price for this product and I would purchase it again.

I've had a number of intermittent issues with these and contemplated returning them. My experience is with an iPhone 4.PROS- Price- Sound quality - surprisingly decent when they are working correctly - not great but good enough for music while exercising or playing games & watching video- comfortable- easy to pairCONS- poor range: easily blocked by your body, will usually work with phone in my right pocket but not in the left- connection stutters, particularly if anything is blocking the line of site between headphones and device- frequently turns itself off (generally after a text message is received)- controls don't always respond (particularly play\pause)- WEIRD - occassionally it sounds like the music speeds up and plays about 1.5x too fast- kind of flimsy construction- no charger included (charges with standard USB cable)

reviewText: awsome for its price the only reason im not giving it a 5 * is the cheezy interface it has and ya cant just hit the eject button to get the screen to pop down to load a disk there is a seperate button for that other than that the SQ of the radio is awsome and the other down side is if you run a amp for this and want to use the SW out you would have to buy a 1 to 2 y splitter for your mono amp the picture quality is awsome .. and if you read the install manual it tells you everthing you need to do for the video to work @ all times ..all in all the bluetooth works flawless... paired my phone and my gf's phone .. only one at a time though worked great with both phones .. have tried the usb feature yet to have an opionion on that .. and fyi this radio is in an 02 saturn L200 which crutchfield and amzon said it wouldnt fit but i put this in no trimming neccisary and a single din install kit is needed only thing is the screen over hangs the bottom trim that goes around the radio and climate controlls .. would recommend this radio for a cheap touchscreen for anybody who doesnt want an exspecive one stollen

Great fit, but not 'great' sound quality. Still worth a 5 in my mind. Nicely packaged, quality build, fits in and over the ear well. Great ear hooks; the best I have found. Very nice cording, too. Almost like tangle free but more comfortable. Other more expensive sets may have better quality sound but you can't beat the price and fit of these, and the sound is still very good. I would rather look for fit and price as a priority. Extreme bass and mids and highs don't mean that much to me as they are mainly used for audio books, and just some MP3 music; better bass, mids, and highs are improved with patience chosing the right ear insert (4 sets) and seating it deeply getting a seal. Great customer care and concern! If I wanted mainly top quality sound I would get Shure, Bose, or Klipsch, but the cost is not really worth it for me. I wear glasses and these do not interfere. Highly recommend for fit and finish and price. This is a great set!! I have hard-to-fit ears and some hearing loss. It gets 5 stars from me as it is perfect in the most important ways.

This is a tough little guy with great photo quality through the  Leica lense.  Photo quality is quite decent and I've used it on extended winter mountaineering trips, whitewater kayaking, and out in the ocean.  We also have a non waterproof version of the Panasonic with better photo quality but this one has stood up to some pretty extremes conditions.  It would be nice if they had a threaded mini tripod tapped into the case, but ie had good luck just propping it on a case, etc.

I looked for a LOOONNNG time for a monitor to perform how I wanted.1st... 2 problems that you will find MUCH talked about with this monitor:a) Do not worry about the dual DVI cable that will work as Dell ships a working DVI cable with the new monitors. And you DO need that cable. A regular DVI cable will not display.b) Make sure it is the LATEST revision number. Older revs. were faulty and will have alot of the problems other people mention. I believe mine was ver. 08. Build Aug 2011.Before I write anymore, I also want to say that I am an AVID gamer. I play 1st person shooters as well as RPGs and strategy games so an excellent monitor is a must for me.Now, I had a GREAT monitor before this, but I wanted something bigger and better and believed that I could find it. I bought several monitors and TVs and had to return them because they wouldnt do.The thing to remember is that you are not getting better than a good 24" monitor that can run a 1900x1200 resolution or better. Forget it.Obviously, the bigger the monitor, the higher the resolution needs to be. So if you have a 27" monitor sure you can run "HD", but so can any monitor nowadays. If you try and play high detail games on that monitor, you will be losing out BIG TIME.And that is what this monitor does well. It is a 27" monitor with a high enough resolution for its size that you will get all the value of those intense graphics. Any 27" monitor that has a resolution less that this one is only good for surfing the internet, using office, and watching movies.If that is all you will be doing, save ALOT of money and buy a monitor nhalf the price of this one.For me, this is not my dream monitor. I still want MORE vibrant and MORE "WOW", but like I said, I am an avid gamer and I LOVE graphics. I just dont think the next level of technology has gotten there yet.I think if Dell creates an LED monitor with this monitors resolution, it will be damn close, but that's not the case yet.Anti-glare: I have a window at my back so I am grateful for it. NO refelction AT ALL!problem 1) HARD TO CLEAN! You will have a heck of a time cleaning smudges. I dont notice the smudges when playing, but it annoys me when I see them.problem 2)you WILL see a LITTLE bit of greyness (what LOOKS like pixelation) on whites, but it's really forgettable. This is because the antiglare screen is like a hard piece of plastic with a very fine rough finish.Games: Works perfectly. I was a bit nervous going from a 5ms to a 6ms, but I tested a 2ms monitor and NO DIFFERENCE that I could see. High graphic 1st person shooters played smooth and just as well as my old turn based games.I would not worry about the ms rate, but REMEMBER to buy the latest revision monitor. Dont get fooled by some of these companies that are still trying to get rid of "brand new" monitors but OLD revisions with problems.Price: Well, I just had to suck it up. I wanted a great 27" and I had to pay for it. I sold my other monitor for 250.00 and bought this one on Black Friday for 750.00. No tax and including shipping.Power hungry? Yes. Compared to an LED or smaller monitor, it does eat electricity.Monitor features are excellent, height and swivel adjustment: check. HDMI able? yes (though the DVI is better for computer graphics)So bottom line is that YES, this is the BEST 27" monitor you will be able to get until Dell releases an LED monitor or another version of THIS monitor that increases resolution or colors, etc.I wanted to wait for something like that, but made a decision on Black Friday to go ahead and buy this one.When something better comes out, I'll sell this one and get it. ;)
