reviewText: Finally... Someone has a replacement foam earpad for the Motorola S305 Bluetooth Headset.After reaching out to Motorola for a replacement earpad, the best that customer support could offer was instructing me to buy another $40 pair.As this didn't make any more sense than me simply buying another pair at retail, removing (and keeping) the pads, then returning as "inadvertently purchased as damaged" for a full refund, I took the honest route.The retainer ring measures around 42mm so I opted with the 40mm rather than the 45mm earpad. You have to be extremely patient and careful with fitting the earpad on the retainer ring (as not to damage the ring or tear the earpad). But in the matter of about two minutes the Motorola S305 is fully functional once more.Many thanks to Zanyzap....

this unit does not have the original hard drive ment for it inside. it came with a 2tb which is now causing issues with the data i have stored on it. my pictures and movies are all now distorted and would not recommend getting this product unless from a store like best buy. i guess i got what i paid for and thought that by saving a couple bucks i'd be ok with atleast a year of use but i don't think i was able to use this for even a week with it being somewhat useless now.
summary: Western Digital WD Elements SE 1 TB USB 2.0 Portable External Hard Drive

reviewText: I purchase this device to serve up my playlists from my NAS so I can eliminate the RCA cables running from my computer to my home theater receiver.  Unfortunately, so far I have been able to do so.  I have been dealing with Lacie customer service now for 6 days and so far no improvement from any suggestion they have offered.  I am about 3 or 4 days from returning this device for a refund as the whole point was to serve up my music off the network.  Everything else I have seen works pretty good and I would rate this unit a 4 or 5 if playlists worked.Apparently Lacie support is non-existent.  I keep being run around in circles so this device is being returned to amazon for a refund. Hopefully I can find some other media player that will handle existing playlist over a network from my NAS.
summary: unable to play music playlist on this device

reviewText: This is an exceptionally well crafted holster bag. Everything about it screams quality, particularly the padding, zipper seal and inner lining. The integrated rain cover is icing on the cake, and came in handy a few times during a recent month long trip. I've been carrying a Canon T3i plus attached EF-S 15-85mm lens and hood with room to spare, which I use to store my RF remote trigger kit and padded camera strap. Except in the case of a really long lens, you can suspend your camera above the bottom of the bag using the movable (velcro) platform wedges. In my case, I didn't even need to reverse the lens hood, which was really convenient. The front pouch is great for thin items like filters, lens cleaners or extra memory cards. You could probably shove a spare battery in there. The inside of the top flap has two additional pockets sized for memory cards, which is where I put mine. The fact that the top flap opens away from your body was also appreciated. Really, I have nothing bad to say about this bag. At all.

love the size on this camera and the video quality is fair but had one before and it had time / date stamp ,was suprised when this one arrived and it did not have time/date stamp ;i felt that was a negative for a product that you may wish to keep a record of events that you were involved in on certain days of a certain year

First off, I'd like to point out that I am not a douche-bag "audiophile", but I am an audio engineer. Second, I bought these on sale for $13, originally $25. I wasn't expecting much but, if I would have paid full price, I would have been super pissed! Instead, I'm just pissed.CONS: These headphones are NOT surround sound headphones. They are just regular headphones. The buds are a very awkward shape that applies too much pressure (IMHO) and pop out or slide out easily. The size down from that is just too small. The sound is decent if they stayed in place. I find that you have to really shove them into your ears to get a decent sound but never stays in. The cable is very thin and tangles easily when you're active. After they start to slide out, the sound becomes very boxy.Pros: Came with a case that I'm going to use for my other headphones :)Overall, I think you'd be better off buying a pair from the 99 cents store. At least your expectations will be met and will have headphones with equal quality sound. Plus, they might actually stay in your ears. I didn't buy these as a replacement (thankfully), but just out of curiosity as to the surround effect. I will keep them, however. I'll use them in my office. If I were to recommend a pair, it would be Muzx Core MZX20 by Altec. They don't claim to be surround but, the overall quality is excellent. And, I don't mean that for a category $20, I mean that in terms of overall quality.
It is very useful device especially if you can't have your computer along. Moreover, taking into consideration its price, it is just for free.
summary: Fits all Philips mp3 mp3 players

reviewText: I recently bought a new Panasonic HDTV with crummy sound, so wanted to add a soundbar. I narrowed it down to 2 choices in my price range: this Sony and a Panasonic SC-HTB10. I chose the Sony because of the subwoofer. I am not disappointed with the bass, nor the treble -- it performs well at those ends of the audio spectrum. What is missing for me, though, is midrange.The audio sounds "hollow," and I miss some dialogue in movies or speech in variety/comedy shows. (Full disclosure: I have a mild hearing loss, corrected by aids, so this may be my peculiar sensitivity.) I've experienced a similar sensation with my car stereo, but that has a midrange adjustment, so I can boost the midrange and it corrects the issue. Not so with the Sony soundbar. I have compensated a little bit by de-emphasizing the bass and treble response to hopefully emphasize the midrange, and emphasizing subwoofer to provide ambient bass -- it helps, but not the best.I read a consumer review online by someone who stated they had done a direct comparison between the Sony and Panasonic, and that person also claimed the Sony sounded hollow. If I were going to do it over, I'd try the Panasonic. I'll keep the Sony, though, because it works well enough and I don't watch a lot of TV.Regarding setup, I've noticed many purchasers stating dissatisfaction with how to hook soundbars up, especially not being able to integrate the soundbar with their TVs (i.e., not being able to have the TV HDMI control the soundbar volume and on/off). I was able to integrate the Sony soundbar with my Panasonic TV just fine, but the setup was not at all clear. I have an electronics background, so I may be more flexible and patient, but I can see how the average consumer could become confused and frustrated trying to follow the product instructions, especially if the TV and soundbar are from different manufacturers using different terminology.UPDATE Jan 2013: After trying various settings for over a year, I finally gave up on this soundbar because the lack of midrange just didn't allow me to hear everything. After further research I bought a Yamaha YAS-101 because some users stated they had hearing loss and found it worked well. That's been my experience too. The Yamaha has excellent frequency across the audio spectrum, and although it doesn't have thunderous bass, the bass is solid and appropriate.
summary: Solid bass, crisp treble -- but where's the midrange?

reviewText: works ok, seems like a good player, have had it for a about a month , HOWEVER, if you plan on trying to plug into your large TV to watch a video via the a/v out with the  RCA cables that come with it you may be dissapointed!Mine doesn;t work. I cant see a picture or hear sound and I tried several different cables and tv to troubleshoot it. I plan on returning it and getting a refund.
summary: don't buy if you plan on connecting via a tv set using an rca plug, doesnt work!

reviewText: This works great on and off the mouse pad. I've had it for almost a year and have had no problems yet. I definitely would recommend it!

Finding DDR memory that works in my old IBM/Lenovo desktop system is a challenge, these days. Most modern computers are using DDR3 and the previous generation are using DDR2. Then after finding the right memory, the price is usually pretty high. So when I saw the price at Komputerbay,I was skeptical. But since this was listed through Amazon Marketplace, I figured that I would give it a try. The memory installed easily and was immediately recognized by the OS. I have had it in place for several weeks and have not encountered any issues. The next time that I need memory, I am going to check with Komputerbay first.

I received the RAM sticks on time, and they worked perfectly.  I just fit them in their slot with no problem, and the computer immediately recognized them.  This was a huge boost in speed coming from a computer that only had half a gig of RAM to begin with.  And if it ever fails, then its under lifetime warranty. I would definitely buy from this company again, they have the best prices of any other seller, with a product just as good.  Whenever I help friends with building a computer, I recommend this brand because its the cheapest they can get, yet I know its good quality from experience.  If i eventually add another two gigs to my computer, you can bet where i'm buying from again.

It took a while to get this up and running. The image quality relayed by the camera is very grainy.You need a power source for the camera, as it is outside, so be prepared to drill a hole or run a line for that.Once everything is connected, it is pretty easy to use. You can connect the receiver to a TV. There is supposed to be a way to get it to work with your PC, but it must be wireless because the only outputs on the base station are for  connections to a television.Maybe this product is beyond my comprehension, but it isn't what I thought it would be.I was under the impression that I would be able to have it connected to a PC, in order to view the images from the camera. If there is a way to do that, I haven't figured it out.
summary: Not the best picture, not completely wireless

reviewText: As other reviews in here... you will see that the code (SDSDRX3-016G-A21) is for a 20mb/s card if your camera dont support the UHS-I.I have a Nikon D5100 with the firmware 1.0 and it took pictures.... but, gave me an error...  I updated to the 1.01 and it works as expected. The speed really fast and rated at 30mb/s.  The NIKON D100 DOES support the UHS-I.

I went out of my way to get the newer version that's labeled 45MB/s.  It definitely is fast when paired with the right equipment.  Via USB 3 port on my PC it was doing 35-38MB/s read&write transfer of a 2GB MKV file. Via USB 2 port it was doing 28MB/s read&write.  This was using a Uspeed USB 3 SD card reader.  Good stuff so far!

I bought these for my 5, 7 and 18 yr olds for Christmas.  I got tired of them stealing my portable speaker which they broke. Anyhow, I was so surprised at the sound thise little gadgets have.  WOW and they light up to the beat of the music. The girls love them.  They hook up their kindle fires and listen to music on Prime all the time.  GREAT PRODUCT FOR THE PRICE..
I use this for my garmin while im traveling and its held up well in my backpack over the past 6 months.

I received two batteries in the box.  I charged them and worked nicely shooting video and stills with my Canon T3i.This is an amazing value (around five bucks each when I bought them) for a lithium-ion battery.  I searched for the OEM battery and it is multiple times more expensive in comparison. They charge fast and very light as opposed to older types of batteries like Ni-Mhs and Ni-cads.
plus the transfer cable & some spare batteries. Fits nicely in my purse to be handy whenever I need it!
summary: Handy case for Sony digital voice recorder

reviewText: After about 2 months of use, this just quit working. It's a great idea however.  I wouldn't buy one again. Looks simple so I'm not sure why it quit working. It wasn't manhandled in any way.
summary: Quit working after a couple months

reviewText: The battery I purchased works perfectly and is a near-exact replica of the OEM battery I had already.  I followed the directions for charging (around 6 - 8 hours) and I don't have a single complaint!  I almost seem to get better battery life out of this battery than the OEM.  Highly recommend this product if you have an Inspiron 1525, 1526 or 1545!

This is the first remote that I have owned that actually promised to work with every brand.  That is quite a bold statement but its one that it, no doubt lives up to.  This remote is extremely universal, and with its learn function it can learn just about any IR signal that you can find(and I do mean ANY!!!). As a matter of fact just yesterday I programed the remote to fly my remote controlled helicopter around my apartment.It seems like a complex process at first but just read the instructions carefully and you will memorize the steps to program buttons in no time.So overall, this remote is a fantastic buy and I would definitely recommend it to those people who are tired of having like 5 different remotes for their TV, DVD, VCR, Surround Sound System, Cable and yes even your helicopter.

These plugs are "pretty" but not real functional for my applications.  First, the 'squeeze crimp" ("strain relief") between the rear and center pieces will only work on wire with about 1/4" diameter insulation...I have no idea what kind of wire smaller than about 6 gauge meets that spec...nothing I've ever found common.  I thought from the pictures there would be some sort of insulation between the male banana pin and the housing but no, they're all electrically connected...that's just not good practice, there's too much chance of a short between adjacent connections.  On the batch I got, the length of the setscrew is less than the inside diameter of the barrel so it would be impossible to tighten down on a wire smaller than about 22 ga (not that I'd want to but I'm contradicting another reviewer).  I ended up throwing away the center part of the plug and just using the rest for my jumper and patch wires, it's not perfect but there is a lot less 'hot' metal sitting out in the breeze to make short circuits.

Not terrible for the price but I will agree that that the bass is lacking, basically just a high tremble.  I didn't realize it but I had a pair of these before that I found at a store a year or so ago.  They still work so I can't complain, other headphones I had lasted for only a few months before they stopped working.  So I will give the product some points for "going strong."If your not too picky about sound quality than these are perfect for the price.  They have three different sized "buds" so you can choose the right size for your ear.  I have to use the large size even though I have small ears to get good sound quality.  However they do bother the inside of my ears due to the way they are designed, as the plastic seems to rest on the outer walls of my ear.

This is a great value for casual listening.  I usually fall asleep listening to old spoken-word recordings which means I go through a lot of earbuds (tossing and turning pulls on the wires).  So to remain well-rested and financially solvent I need earbuds that are inexpensive and comfortable. I'm also a former (alas) musician and am demanding of sound quality.These Panasonic units fit the bill as decent, semi-disposable earbuds. They're very comfortable for my purpose. Since the earbud part is offset from the body of the driver, the driver doesn't press against the ear when sleeping on one's side. They've also held up to a couple months' use.The weakest point is sound quality. While not really objectionable, these buds are weak in bass and have a noticeable upper-midrange peak that the casual listener may perceive as "clarity." I'd rather the response was more even. But for 6 bucks who can complain?Bottom line, if you have reasonable expectations these earbuds are an excellent price-performance value.
summary: Good value if your expectations are realistic

reviewerName: W. French "Well hello there, fellow Amazon sh...
reviewText: I bought these to replace a $30 set of Sennheisers after one of my pet rats chewed through the wire. These sound just as good if not better. They are very well designed, and fit perfectly inside of my ear. They are angled a bit in the middle which makes a huge difference. Panasonic really did a great job on the ergonomics. The sound has nice solid bass, and the mids are very pronounced in relation to the highs. A bit of adjustment to the WinAmp EQ settings brought back the sparkle (I use these to listen to internet radio on my computer, and will also take them to the gym). I should mention that these headphones have not been burned-in yet, I expect them to get a little sweeter once they have logged a few hours of playtime. Overall I am very impressed with the quality for such a low price. I'd definitely buy these again.
I would give it 5 stars if it wasn't for the fact that the Bluetooth mic sometimes doesn't work very well.

Could be my new computer or monitor, but this connects a bit loosely. Even a light touch will either knock out my screen or give it lines. But it does the job, and I don't mess with it much, so average it is.
There is NO difference between this and the $70 "gold" cable you can buy at Best Buy, Target, etc. The expensive ones, and the cheap ones carry the SAME quality signal.

I noticed that the price has increased on this pair of speakers. No wonder, they are great to have, especially if one owns a laptop. They look great and are solidly built. The speakers sound really great too, but note that these do not come with a sub woofer. The bass is sufficient enough in my opinion though. With the volume knob turned all the way up, they really push out air!Another great feature the SPA7210's has is the USB charging! You can charge your mobile device here without using a wall adapter. Note that the USB will not charge an iPad, much like how a computer does not charge an iPad.Overall, aside from looking amazing and sounding great, the cables are easy to manage! I have a pair of Logitech speakers that has so many cables it's ridiculous. These are simply and travel anywhere you go.I definitely recommend this product. Unless you are looking for serious audio solution, you won't find much that will beat this price.

I was excited to receive this product, and being as much is it was, I guess I figured it'd have more than a 10ft range. When I put it beyond that to literally 11 or 12, it intermittently cuts out. Beyond that, it just plain doesn't work. When I put it back within the 10ft range, it works fine. Unfortunately, unless you have a living room 10 feet long or shorter, and don't want your rear speakers a few feet from your back wall, then this product will not work for you.

Got this item to replace a pair of Kliptsh's that broke off. Needed something right away but didn't wanna spend too much money. These are cheap and they sound cheap. I'm somewhat surprised only because Altec Lansing makes good gear. The sound is scratchy and not deep. Not that much better than the crappy Apple earbuds you get w/the iPhone. Save some money and get good ones. These will get some use but only as back ups to whatever I get next.

pros: cheap and 1080p and include speakercons:speaker horrible, screen flicker from time to time, not led, when viewing in dark room theres white light at edgesbuy this if you as cheap like me and upgrade at some other pointif you got a bit more money get led ones dont buy this

Update 5/5 - Wow. I must have jinxed myself. The day after I wrote this review, I started getting a crackling noise in the left earphone. Probably because I had my volume up too high and it got blown out.Original review:Picked this up at Walmart last year after blowing out my old Trittons because I could not wait for a new headset to be shipped to me. It was supposed to be a stand-in headset, until I could get a new one. Ten months later, I haven't ordered a new one because this one is still going strong.Let me start by saying that I am a constant user of Skype. I take conference calls for work, I talk to my family, I talk to my friends, and I talk to the people that I'm gaming with. The only time I'm NOT talking to people on Skype is when I'm working on a project or sleeping. I think it is safe to say that I have gotten a lot of use out of this headset.I can hear people just fine. I haven't had any crackling sounds like the two previous reviewers, and after 10+ months of use, it's still going strong. Nobody has ever complained about the microphone quality. When I hear a recording of myself, it sounds perfectly fine. The microphone is pretty sensitive, because I can hear myself click and type. A lot more clear than a regular telephone, but then most microphones are. It's not super crisp, but it's more crisp than most of the people I speak to. Are these as good as Trittons? Hell no. Sound-wise, Trittons would blow these out of the water. However, that isn't to say that these aren't decent. Unless you are doing hardcore gaming, I think these are more than agreeable. As for the microphone-- it isn't as good as the one on the my old Tritton headset, but it comes pretty darn close. For sixteen bucks (compared to 100 something for Trittons), that's impressive!I unplug this headset frequently because I switch between my laptop and desktop. Usually wires start shorting out after 2-5 months of this, but these ones have not yet! I've also rolled over the cord of this (probably 10 times or more) with my computer chair. Whatever casing they used for the wiring on this is great.If you wear glasses, you should consider a different headset. I used to wear some pretty thick frames, and because these go over the ear, they would pinch the tops of my ears. If you wear thin/wire frames, you probably won't have any issues.
summary: A fine headset for the price

reviewText: I ordered this to convert my spare bedroom into a "photo studio" - not a place for professional shooting but as a way to push a photography hobby to the next level. I'm what the camera circles call a "prosumer". Please remember that my assessment of "cheap" isn't compared to great studios I've shot in.First, the backdrop support system. It doesn't really support itself. The telescoping bar bends and flexes under it's own weight, with no backdrop or clips on it. This wasn't even my first sign of low-quality though, since the process of putting up the bar was difficult. The stands on each pole are wobbly. The legs aren't wide enough to properly support this while holding just the bar and the legs move laterally, decreasing stability even more. I can LITERALLY tip over the entire thing with one finger, pushing above where the legs meet the support pole. It's wobbly.The backdrops are thin. You'll notice you can see light through them as soon as you start unfolding them. This was noted in many reviews, and I am okay with it, as I shoot against a solid white wall that has no light behind it. Factoring this in though, I have to wonder... The light construction of the drop stand is attributed to "ease of portability" and yet, the sheets are so thin that they need to be against a dark, solid wall. Seems the entire set was not engineered. The backdrops have the texture of cheap sheets and the creases associated with it. Products sit and settle as they're in inventory which I have no issue with. I would expect that after several days spread out, the creases would disappear. They did not, lending more to the feel of overly starched cheap sheets.The umbrellas are similarly cheap. I would be SHOCKED to learn that these umbrellas were designed for photography, rather than picked because the colors suit photography. By comparison, with this set I also purchased a pair of gold reflecting umbrellas for about $7 each and they're leaps and bounds better than these in terms of construction.The CFLs included in this set are the best part of it. They're brilliantly white and put out quite a bit of light. That said, so do $3 CFLs from the local hardware store. I know, because they're actually the same color temperature I've been buying in CFL for years from Home Depot and they compare very well. Test shots under my normal home CFLs and these are nearly identical.Pairing the lights with the umbrellas is disappointing. First, the CFLs are large and spread light in every direction rather than directing it. The smaller CFLs I mentioned from the hardware store are actually better, as the smaller surface of the tube directs light to the umbrella better and bleeds less ambient light into the room. Unfortunately, the gossamer umbrella material fails here too as it's thin enough to bleed light as well.The kit also came with a bag. I haven't actually used the bag, so I have nothing bad to say about it. I'm sure I will, given time. And that makes me a sad panda.

This TV has some fantastic features (covered well in other reviews), but it produces a high pitched whine while turned on. And it is loud enough that i can hear it over the tv volume (at level 10, whichmis our listening level for most shows). We upgraded from a LG  to this tv and had it mounted on our wall before testing it out. We would not have kept it if we knew about the noise before we mounted it. I will update after I contact Vizio support.[...]
summary: High pitched whine when the TV is on.

reviewText: This is a very attractive piece of furniture, that came at a good price, and was easy to assemble.  It looks as good as its picture, my wife and I have had to move it a few times to address issues with the cording of assorted devices, and it feels solid during these efforts.

I've had this product for 24 hours now and used it at a live Karaoke session last night.  I was sitting closest to the speakers and the recording was amazing.  I know the first thing anyone is going to think about this is.. But it is $200.00.. As I told others, you get what you pay for.  At first, I bought a different unit for 1/2 the price and it had major problems for live band and Mixer recording.  The split feature works well so I can split the recording without having to hit stop and record again... It is so small, It fits in my shirt pocket..Pro's for me:Amazing Sound: nuf said.. The recordings seems true and clear. No detectable hormonic distortion, compression noise or anything that I've heard from cheaper recorders.Battery Life: 16 hours recording, confirmed with power saving turned on. (peak and red recording lights turn off)Immediate Recording (Setup and Start):  The cheaper units go through an "Initialization phase" when you hit the record button.  The R-05 is immediate.  When you press the REC button, it automatically pauses for level adjustments and start of song queueing.Options: Too many to list; Very well done and well thought out for recording live instruments / voice / etc.Sensitivity and Direction  I noticed pattern that I could use to dampen back group (audience) sounds.  This is useful when your primary interest is the music.Power Saving Features:  Lights can be turned off automatically when you want to conserve power.Ease of Use: Very simple and easy to use.. Well thought out interface.Cons:V1.03 is required to use NI-MH batteries.. If you have V1.02, it will show the battery is dead within an hour of use.  After the update, I have tested it so far for 3 hours recording with 1 bar drop..The aluminum case is only a shell, it is mostly plastic with what amounts to a phone case around it.  If it is dropped, it will respond like plastic so don't drop it.While corners were cut to bring a very good recorder to be affordable at this price point, I would highly recommend the R-05 to anyone who wants a recorder that works exactly as advertised.
summary: This is it, a real recorder done right..

reviewText: Item was needed for a PC I had and it was shipped VERY quickly. Drive is fast and quiet. Little heat buildup, even after transfering my 300+GB music collection to it. The warranty is good and honored by the mfg without ANY problem. I have dealt with them in the past and they are real good about getting a new drive out to you and you can use their packaging to send back the old one. I have yet to test this drives read/write speeds but, can already tell the difference as it took about twice as long to do this backup to an older Western Digital drive I had. I will be buying a cpl more of these at this price. Not fond of the huge drives because when you loose them, you loose a great deal of things with them.. Would much rather stack these solid 500GB drives.
summary: No Complaints here. Great Drive and Price!!

reviewText: Most websites and individuals will say to get any HDMI cable. That is not true. I bought a cheap one and the Monster Cable and you can tell a huge difference between the two. Without changing any settings on the TV, we plugged in both cables. The Monster Cable had more vibrant colors and better clairty. Highly Recommend to get this cable.

I have not had any of the heat issues that other reviewers describe.Sturdy metal connector fits perfectly and snugly in my MacBook Pro. Great for use with computer on lap when a cheaper adapter might dislodge.Transfer speed is a touch faster than with USB, but not more than 50% at most. This continues to be limited by the drive speed in my external drive.When using this adapter to transfer form a SATA SSD, transfer was significantly faster than the USB equivalent.Reasons to buy: A bit fast with a better physical connection while leaving USB ports free for other uses.

The metal footplate is a strong point. It can also pose a problem if you mount it on a bracket that has a metal cold shoe resulting in short circuiting. I mitigated this by inserting a piece of paper between the footplate and the cold shoe. Other than that, a useful tool affordable price. 4 stars not 5 for the flimsy battery door.

This speaker bar does a good job of supplanting my junky laptop speakers.  It doesn't have much low-end range obviously but to me this isn't a big deal as I need it to be able to hear spoken audio rather than music reproduction.  It's a simple device, the USB plug is used for power while a standard headphone jack gets the audio.Overall a good value.

I was procrastinating and distracting myself by taking apart my grip pen for my intuos4 wireless tablet when I accidentally snapped it in half. After a bit of cursing at myself I calmed down and told myself as a consolation at least I can now buy the classic pen. I purchased one for my intuos3 a few years back and loved it much more than the clunky grip pen. I'm taking one star off as this pen should cost no more than $50- in fact it should ship with the tablets as a default. Oh well, at least I don't have to deal with that monstrosity of a brick anymore.
summary: S#%T! Accidentally snapped the grip pen in half...

reviewText: I'd never pay $200 for an overpriced Sony battery grip, but this knockout copy is not an alternative as described below.  I like consumer friendly priced item, but designer need to think little harder before sending it to full production; and it shouldn't cost too much for a manufacture to make a decent yet a functional part.  Why can't they just copy everything from Sony?First, its manual states to remove battery grip when camera is not to be used for an extended period.  This really baffles me.  Is the manufacturer not that knows to create excessive battery leakage?  For any electronics device, I have never seen anything like this, advising user to remove battery when not in use.  That's what the switches are for, to functionally isolate and disconnect a needless power drain.Second, Battery door locking latch is too loose, makes it prone to slide inadvertently.  The memory compartment on Sony camera implements a similar mechanism; but Sony's door snaps and locks tight in the place, unlike this one.  On can always tape and re-tape the door area every time battery door is accessed, but that is outright ridiculous.Third, they should have provided the some kind of lugs on the side for the hand grip.  Without it, one must use the external bracket tied to a tripod mount, which make it awkward if not impossible to hold the camera vertically, while adding unnecessary mass and weight to camera.Lastly, on the bottom of Sony camera, there a little provisional hole on the opposite side of battery slot, conceivably to provide necessary alignment of the grip with the camera chassis while preventing unintended torque of the grip in case of mishap.  This feature is not implemented in this grip.My observation from further testing:Unless I received a totally defective unit, this one doesn't seem to implement a switching circuit, an algorithm to allow sequentially draw of power from one battery and then switch to another one, once the first one is completely discharged.  This to me is a critical feature connecting two batteries for an electrical isolation.  This probably explains why manufacturer wants user to remove the battery from the holder when camera is not in use.It's a serious design flaw, hooking up two batteries in parallel without a minimal protective feature.  This will force each battery in continuous charging/discharging mode regardless of status of main switch.  Consequently, it will severely degrade battery's useful life.It's only my assumption based on my quick testing, but if it turns out to be true, I wouldn't put this thing nowhere near my camera even if someone pays me to use this part.Do not claim 100% compatibility, if not meant to be.  This false advertising practice is not only unethical, but illegal in accordance to our law.
This little beauty has been going strong for over a year, perfect for my project at the time and I highly recommend!

This antenna is no better than RCA rabbit ears in the Green Valley hills vineyards area. I moved from Cordelia area and bought this to pair with the Leaf in the bedroom. It does OK and paired with the Leaf via a signal combiner and a pct amplifier it increases the number of channels but only by 5 to 10 more than the Leaf gets by itself. The Leaf is by far the best indoor antenna I've used. Compared to RCA rabbit ears at $8 and LEAF at $29, Winegard at $34 or more has to get 1 star for my area.
summary: Just OK as Indoor in Green Valley Hills Fairfield CA

reviewText: These earbuds are great replacments for my Sennheiser CX300's. I tend to lose them alot (bad build quality on part of sennheiser) that the earbuds constantly fall off.

I own 5-6 different types of security cams (mostly because I am trying to find the best deals and collected them over time), this is probably one of the best deals for an indoor wireless IP cam.I like the fact that you can fully pan and tilt, almost cover 360 degrees in your home easily so when you are not home, you can easily rotate the camera remotely to check everything going on in your home.Also, this camera is compatible with Android app like TinyCam (set it as Lofttek camera though not Wansview!).The night vision works well but don't point it outside (because the infrared LEDs will reflect off your window and you won't be able to see anything DUH!), it's really only for the indoors.  The camera itself can be used outside also if you have a hangover the area and you don't get crazy storms that might get to it.For the price you pay this is a neat little security camera.  I suggest to set it to FTP mode to an FTP server outside your house so if robbers steal your computer, you will still have images of them.  I've got it uploading to one of my web servers, works well.  If you don't have an FTP server, you can also create a GMAIL account for the cam and have it send photos to your GMAIL on motion detection.
summary: Pretty solid security cam, Full Pan Tilt

reviewText: This is my second set... My dad needed some headphones to use with his iPad and liked mine so much, I had to order him his own set.  He said they fit comfortably over his hearing aids and didn't cause any feedback problems.  They helped cut out external noises to help him hear better!  I used them on my last flight and while they didn't cancel out the airplane noise completely, I hadn't expected them to so was pleasantly surprised with how well they did do!! You can't beat this price for an awesome brand and product!

I downgraded this case one star for three reasons:You have to be very careful when propping the iPad in the viewing position.  If the cover is not inserted into the rear flap exactly evenly, the case is not stable, and you risk the iPad falling forward.The case adds considerable weight to the device, so be aware of that.It's a nice, protective case and well designed.  For the most part, it looks classy.  Then, on the inside, they inserted a cut out with a tan and brown ad for the company....  It's far from subtle, doesn't match the color scheme of the case, looks like a business card stuck in the case, and, in my opinion cheapens the case.  This may be perceived as a nit, but to me it's very objectionable.  I'm providing detail, since I tried to figure out what this was on the photos, and couldn't decide what it was.  I'm going to see if I can cover it somehow.  I'm also concerned about how this cut out part will wear. It's difficult to know what the insert is made of.Aside from these cautions, it's a nice case.Enjoy!**** UPDATE April 3: ****My new iPad flew out of my hands and hit the floor near a fireplace (landed on flagstone).  It, luckily, was in the Snugg case, and landed screen side up, but it was open with the flap tucked back.  I wasn't a fan of cases which were "closed" on all sides, but had it been in a case with the corner attachments, I don't think the iPad would have survived.  It's fine after the fall!  FYI.  I thought this was a tale worth sharing.
summary: A couple of things you should know

reviewText: I actually bought this case, so don't let the title deceive you. I read about many cases out there where that Wake/Sleep Function doesn't work, but this one works.For the people complaining, it's $30. You aren't going to get genuine leather for that price and if you think you are, I feel for you.The Stylus holder at the top is awesome (I purchased the amazon basics stylus and it fits perfectly into that holder. $10 for stylus and also worth it)I had an ipad 2 and i purchased a Miniot Cover for $130 and that thing was complete garbage, pardon the language. It wouldn't stand/fold right, the magnets were horrible, and didn't protect a thing.I can honestly say, if you need an Ipad3 case.. This IS THE CASE (Period)
summary: Spectacular Case for Ipad 3! (On/Off Wake function WORKS!)

reviewText: I've had the Snugg on my IPad 3 for a few weeks now and love it. The fit is perfect (Snugg is an apt name) and access to the buttons and cameras is good. The faux-leather finish is beautiful and the magnetic toggle is GREAT. A few minor issues keeping it from five-star status: 1) When the cover is open and folded back, the hand-strap is on the right. Being right-handed, it would be more comfortable for me on the left. (Better yet, if there were two, no one would be forced to choose.) 2) The device on the back into which you insert the flap to form the stand works great when it's set up so that the iPad is at close-to-a-90-degree angle. However, I like to flip it upside down so that the angle is much less, probably more like 30 degrees. This is a much more comfortable angle for viewing and typing when you have it on your lap while sitting on the couch. However, the insert device is not really set up for this configuration and the flap sometimes slips out. 3) The outlet at the bottom where you insert the plug for recharging could be a bit wider. I have a connector for hooking up via USB to my computer that doesn't fit in the space that the Snugg provides for the connector. However, other connectors fit just fine.On the whole, these are minor issues. This is really a great cover at a great price.
Software bundle it comes with is basically useless.  The pen and tablet are not as responsive as high-grade products that use tactile feedback deliver.

I purchased this for my Surface RT and with the touch keyboard attached, fits perfect.  There is plenty of room without it being loose.  There is ample padding on the outside of the case so I am confident that my Surface will be protected if/when there are bumps or dings that I may encounter.  If you own a Surface, I would highly recommend this affordable case.

I use this product on my Sony a77. It works exactly as advertised as a wired remote shutter, or remote intervalometer, or remote timer. For the price I couldn't ask for anything more.It comes with a small pamphlet that very useful and explains all the features.Minor quibbles....1) there seems to be no way to turn it off short of removing the batteries. Since AAA batteries are so cheap I don't really mind.2) a wired remote is not as useful as wireless would be- but that would dramatically increase the price.3) The built in light is not very bright, but I carry a small flashlight to read the display at night.

This hub seems to have a problem when an USB audio device is connected through it. If there's any electrical power line interruption (fridge starting), it causes a drop in the audio.  For all other uses, it worked fine.Honestly, many hubs seem to have this issue, including the Pluggable and CablesToGo ones.  The Belkin and the one built into my Dell LCD monitor do not seem to have this problem.  (I've bought a lot of hubs looking for a good one!  I knew they exist bec my Dell LCD's built-in worked but I needed one for a different PC.)It must be a matter of one chip set vs another but I do not know which chipset is in which hubs.And yes, I do have some decent power filters / voltage regulators, but they don't respond quickly enough to short drops in voltage. (Online UPS would work fine but those things are noisy!!!)
summary: Problem when used with USB audio

reviewText: I wouldn't recommend using two HDMI cables for plugging in just one device. I expected to get a signal from the receiver with an HDMI hook up, but it's only a video connection. The fiber optic port has to be included to hear the audio.

The Belkin Grip Swell does not fit the IPad. It is too large by about half a centimeter all around. The IPad itself moves around inside the cover, meaning the holes (where there are holes) do not line up with the various sockets for the plugs. Also, the swell covers the back-facing camera - no opening at all.My recommendation - take a pass and try another cover.

I bought this for the T3i (600D) and it fits well. The T2i and T3i have the same size screen.The protector doesn't interfere when pivoting the swiveling display to face the camera. I saw some complaints about some of the rigid plastic protectors being so thick people couldn't close the display on the T3i. This protector installed easily and was easy to remove when I was positioning it. It's stayed put ever since. I had no problem with bubble when installing it.
The only problem I had was I ordered a 10 pacy and got in the mail 1 of 10 shipped. But that was the end of it. I emailed the company and got a refund but got to keep the one that was shipped.
This item is awful. It causes a lot of static. Constantly gives static-y feedback sounds. Not worth it even if it were free.
Love the idea and that is keeps the cords in my car under control, but broke after two weeks.  I guess you get what you pay for.  Took FOREVER to get it though.

I purchased four of these Vertex 2 SDDs for my business to go into 4 identical computers. Everything worked fine to start. Then after about a month of use one of the computers started to lock up seemingly for no reason. I reinstalled windows and everything looked good. Four months into the usage of these SSDs, one of the drives just died. I turned the computer off for the weekend came back tried to boot and the motherboard did not recognize the drive anymore. Called OCZ, got an advanced replacement sent out to me. Two days later the drive that was locking up before started to freeze the computer again. Didnt have time to deal with it, came back the next day tried to boot that machine and the drive was dead, bios no longer recognized the drive. Called OCZ again told them that I would be replacing two drives. Come back to the office next day a third Vertex 2 has died on me... 75% of the computers in my medical clinic are inoperable. Later on in the day I got the replacement drive, OCZ sent me an Agility 3 60gb. Plugged the Agility3 into one of the computers. Boot into bios everything looks good, reset my boot sequence so I can boot off the dvd drive, reboot, the drive is gone, no longer recognized by the bios... granted the motherboards do not have AHCI support but that shouldn't matter all the drives had the most up to date firmware versions from the start and should have worked fine, if not to full complicity, in IDE mode. Three out of four drives that I purchased from OCZ died on me after just four months of operation and the replacement drive they sent me does not function properly. At this point I am rather upset I call OCZ and request a refund instead of a replacement, after several calls and email exchanges they blow me off saying their policy was to give replacements and not refunds and they also insisted that I pay for the shipping of their faulty drives back to them. I will not be using OCZ SSDs any longer at my business or home they are much too unreliable. Then when I asked to have advanced replacements sent to me at first they agreed over the phone, then later in an email told me that they dont send out advanced replacement drives even though I just got one a couple days ago. I am still battling with OCZ over their lemons and all the while my business is take a productivity hit.Paloma Women's Clinic and Medical CenterHuntington Park, CA

The pics and description of the item on Amazon are unclear...some may say misleading (to say the least). I had thought I was getting a patch cord with identical USB plugs on the ends. Found out upon opening that this was actually a micro USB to mini USB patch cord, not the mini USB to mini USB cord I needed. I now have to get an adapter so I can use this cord for what it was intended.
summary: Needed mini USB to mini USB patch cord - got micro to mini instead

reviewText: I've been using a wired Microsoft mouse for a few years. I have had a wireless mouse in the past and was unimpressed, but this time I figured maybe things have improved. I already have a wireless Logitech keyboard so the unifying receiver is nice. I was very disappointed in this mouse. The tracking was very poor, it skipped quite a bit. The receiver was maybe a foot and a half away from the mouse (I have it plugged into a USB port on the top of the tower). The mouse cut out a lot, I assume to save battery life. I returned this to Amazon and will be sticking with my wired mouse. I'd suggest anyone looking at a wireless mouse stay far away from this one.

I use this mouse mainly to play SC2. I love how easy the buttons are to push. It connects very quickly once you plug the USB into your computer as well. The trackpad is good. I have not had any problems out of it.

Do you like hearing a loud *BEEP* every two minutes or so? Is your computer too fast? Perhaps you like your computer to freeze up for 20 seconds at a time over, and over, and over again? Do you want to be told there's nothing wrong with it, then told it's the firmware only to have that make it much worse?? THEN HAVE I GOT THE PRODUCT FOR YOU!! The Seagate Momentus XT 500 does all that and more! Besides the features mentioned above, the Seagate Momentus is also capable of flight for short distances out my window! And NO, I did not get a single, rare drive with these amazing powers. In fact, both the drives I bought performed all of the above activities with gusto. Especially flying.

I like the camera for many of the reasons given in the other higher rated reviews on Amazon. I previously owned a "pro-sumer" Fuji which I loved but it was a bit clunky (bulky) to keep at the ready and heavy to pack and haul around. Plus the technology (2002) was becoming dated. I bought this Lumix model about 18 months ago (Aug 2010) and was initially pleased. Drawback was mainly too many features and I was overwhelmed and confused by the menu. It did not help that there was no included manual and that I had to download a 180 page pdf for print out.Then there was the problem that it only takes jpg formats; there is not a raw or tiff format option so I needed to set up a workflow during import so that I could convert the images to an archive stable format.Today's exasperation has me searching for a replacement camera. This is the 3rd time in the last 4 months that it did not recognize the SD card. The first time I replaced it and gave the original SD card to my daughter. That original SD card still works flawlessly in her Kodak camera. The second time I fiddled with it a bit, gave up and saved my images to the Internal Memory. Then, magically, a few weeks later, it suddenly recognized the SD card again.This third time, after working fine all day, it suddenly went to Internal Memory Only on a capture. I knew it was nearly full (1.8 out of 2 GB on the SD card) so I hooked it up to my computer. To my surprise, only the 6 images captured to the Internal Memory showed up on my computer!Anxiously I fiddled with reinserting the SD card a few times and then decided to place the SD card into my Wii. Thankfully all the photos showed up. Next I put the SD card into my husband's computer (his has a card reader) and once again they showed up. He moved them over to a USB for me but when I re-inserted the SD card into the Lumix it decided to recognize the SD card again and all the photos displayed both on the camera LCD and through my computer's USB camera connection.I then went online and discovered quite a few posts in various forums describing this same behavior. The sporadic nature of the camera being unable to recognize or access the SD card is quite frustrating. The forum suggestions to blow compressed air inside the slot, clean the points with alcohol, try a new card and turn it on/off did not work for myself or the others.I want a camera that I can rely on to capture photos and it's not this model! It is time to pitch this one out and look for a reliable replacement.

SHORT REVIEW: Well-made, robust wired XBox Live headset with a very adjustable mic. Perfect for anyone looking to upgrade the standard 360 wired set. A few minor concerns keep it from a full five stars.LONG REVIEW: When I went looking for a new wired headset for XBox Live (I have surround sound, so I didn't need a set with built-in speakers), the Turtle Beach brand and fairly reasonable price caught my attention. Then, I started reading reviews. It seems about 33% to 50% of people who bought these headsets claimed they stopped working within days or weeks. I decided to tempt fate (I mean, everything breaks at some point) and fall back on the one-year warranty that all electronics have.Over a full month later, I can safely report the XC1 is still fighting the good fight. I have had no problems with it whatsoever.The headset itself is rather nice. The headrest is firm and flexible, with a faux-leather pad so the top of your head doesn't get sore and a grippy foam pad on the non-speaker side to keep it from falling off your head. The ear cup is generously large and should do any age range's ears fine as long as you're not an elephant; I particularly like the cup's padding which is cloth instead of faux leather. Sound quality is decent, a step up from the Microsoft base model. The really nice feature is the adjustable mic, which holds whatever shape you feel like putting it in, and rotates to various positions, including backwards, to make it a left-ear or right-ear design as needed. The cord is a decent length, has a standard volume and mute/on toggle, capped off by a jack that will fit the 360 controller, with or without the text pad attachment.So what's holding me back from five stars? Three little things.1.) Volume: Although I don't want my ears hurt by chatter, I was surprised that even on "max" volume, the XC1 is not appreciably louder than the Microsoft base model.2.) The mute/on toggle: Since it's going to dangle out of both your field of vision and the controller, you might lose a precious second here or there making sure the mic is on or off. If you're the kind of gamer who leaves their mic on all the time so other players can hear you cough and breathe, this should not be an issue.3.) The ear cup has two large cutaways that promise to "let game sound in". I'm not sure of it's my ears or head size, but whatever ear I have covered is not going to get nearly the same volume levels from my speakers as my uncovered ear. After a session, there's a noticeable difference between ears to ambient sounds levels. The culprit is the speaker pad, which is large and raised, so the cup might have holes but your ear is going to be covered by the speaker.In sum, a good upgrade from the standard 360 kit. I will report back if (and when) the XC1's decide to stop working, but so far, so good.
summary: A Good Upgrade from the Standard 360 Wired Headset

Extrudes a very high quality that reflects the price, but just a tad less so for performance.-= Performance =-When held up against a computer lcd monitor, the highest coefficient of extinction is at a level where the CPL does not completely block out the polarized screen. My Hoya CPL, Vivitar Linear PL, and polarized Ray-Ban sunglasses all can be orientated to show complete black. The difference however is small, and, the effect on your photos is probably smaller. In terms of possible degradation of image resolution, the Marumi CPL shows minimal loss in detail at the 1:1 pixel level. Its very hard to notice, and moreoever, all my CPL's perform similarly if not worse. This indicates a high quality foil and resin that Marumi uses for polarization. In terms of flare, the multi-coating on the Marumi CPL is outstanding and helps minimize internal reflections when adding the filter.-= Quality =-Absolutely exceptional. The rim is very slim for a CPL and comes slightly knurled texture at the front. Threads screw on smoothly. Most importantly, the rotation of the filter is nicely dampened, buttery smooth with just the right amount of resistance to keep its position but allow easy turning with just one finger. This is essential if you have a lens hood attached. The multi-coating looks great. Shining a bright light through the glass show no obvious imperfections.Overall, this is an outstanding CPL worth its cost. Whether or not you need a CPL is another issue. Be that as it may, when used appropriately, this high quality Marumi CPL will not disappoint!

Since Logitech stopped selling G7 batteries I had to buy this third party battery for use in my MX Revolution. Snapped right in. Now my Revolution has another couple years ahead of it. Charges just as quickly as the Logitech official battery and gives me the same use time with a full charge. Overall was actually a few bucks cheaper then the two I ordered directly from Logitech.
summary: Great replacement for an aging MX-Revolution.

It looked like a toy with elastic and everything, but it was really the only digital kids Timex watch without silly graphics.After we decided to return that gift, we looked a little more carefully and decided to risk choosing a women's watch. Purple color was a given once this model was found. The strap is a little too long for her very thin wrists, but she says it is much more comfortable compared to the returned gift. It looks OK to me and she is growing like a weed so I expect it to fit much better soon.Setting the watch without use of the manual was easy. The buttons are a little stiff though so I did have to do it for her. She can push them for use of the mode or indiglo buttons, but repeatedly pushing for her is harder. Sony has 2 Adapter for their own A-mount lens to E-mount NEX series camera.  I have another third party Canon to NEX adapter but the quality is so-so (the price is very good though).  But this Sony adapter is solid build which last forever.  It comes with the tripod mount which is very considerate.  It also includes aperture information to camera (so you can treat it as normal e-mount lens).  It even supports auto-focus for some sony SSM a-mount lens, which is a big plus if you have those lens.  The only drawback why I cannot give 5 star is the price, if it is in 50-60 price range, I will give 5 stars for sure (but it is still way cheaper than the other adapter which supports full auto-focus but too expensive).I am hoping Sony or another third party vendors will publish another Canon to NEX adapter which has the same function (including auto aperture information feed back to the camera for control) and have the same price range (one vendor does have it but over 300 dollars and way too expensive).
summary: Solid and great NEX-5N A-Mount Adapter

reviewText: These PC speakers are simply superb and a delight. They produce a superior sound and music to any other PC speakers I have heard (mainly Creative and Altec Lansing). They are of course also more expensive than most other PC speakers. As someone who listens a lot to classical music I must say that these speakers are amazing to listen to - given how small they are. Overall they are well balanced and have plenty of air/space in the high registers as well as plenty of bass (including for rock) at the other end of the register. Here are a few subjective impressions (for what they are worth): The horns in Sibelius' Finalandia are crisp and clear with lots of space around them, giving a very dynamic impression. Equally the strings are deep and dynamic in the opening of Mahler's 2nd (not quite like LP though). In the last loud movement of Shostakovich's 11th symphony the whole orchestra is well defined, the beats precise, and the sense of space between the instruments is truly impressive (again for such a little speaker). Despite their small size they can fill a reasonable large room. My office is 4x6 metres, but they are sufficient for even larger rooms, would say 6x8 or maybe slightly larger. If you need a speaker for parties with loud music look for larger speakers (and the quality matters less). If you look for a really good musical reproduction for your desk look no further. These speakers will make you play album after album, and that is, in my view, the finest accolade Hi-Fi equipment can get. Enjoy!

Six months ago I bought a Tivo Premiere XL with 150 HD hours of recording (has a WD10EURS 1TB Western Digital Drive in it).  Shortly later, after recording numerous high density videos I ran out of space.  Since it was more than 30 days since I had my Tivo, Tivo refused to allow me to swap out my player for an upgrade or put in another hard drive, other than buying another whole new Tivo!.I considered simply adding an external hard drive built specifically for Tivo, a simple fix (by the way, Tivo charges about twice what you can get them from Amazon, etc).  However, since I am familiar with computers and after reading how the external drives seem not hold up so well in the long run and how you might loose the programs stored on both the main drive and the external if it ever dysfunctions or you disconnect the external hard drive, I decided to just have one larger drive inside the Tivo with more recording capability.I searched on line and in the Tivo forums found that upgrading my Tivo Premiere XL would be easy and that I could increase my recording potential from 150 Hrs with the 1 TB drive in it to 300HD hours with a 2 TB WD20EURS drive (already maximized with reliability, power saving and compatible functions for Tivo and Video recording - 3 Yr Warranty).  All I needed to do was copy the contents of my current 1 TB Tivo which is already a WD10EURS to 2 TB using a Western Digital WD20EURS Hard Drive as the target drive.  By the way,  Tivo software at present WILL NOT support a 3TB drive, so do not buy one of those.To do that, I found a reference to a program called JMFS, rev 104 in Tivo forums after a Yahoo internet search.  I downloaded it, and and when I clicked on the download, I was given the option of burning the disk which I did creating a boot cd with the JMFS program on it.I then repeatedly hit F2 as my computer was starting to change the boot order to CD Rom before hard disk (change this back to hard drive when done with the copy procedure). I unplugged my Tivo, then using a Torx T10 and T15 screwdriver (purchased at Ace or online), I removed the four screws to the Tivo cover and then slid back the cover to my Tivo, and being careful not to touch anything else inside (possible shock), I removed the current Tivo hard drive which has four Torx screws holding the rail inside .  I then inserted the JMFS boot drive into my computers second CD drive and turned OFF my computer, opened the side of my computer and disconnected the power and sata belt to my computers main hard drive (leave the computers hard drive in the machine) and then connected the power and SATA plugs freed up inside my computer from disconnecting the hard drive(s) in the machine to both the old Tivo drive taken out of my Tivo and the new 2 TB drive I am copying to.  (hard drives now sitting on floor both connected next to computer).  I then started the machine allowing my computer to start and boot up from the JMFS boot disk in the CD Rom.  The program showed me both the older smaller Tivo Drive and the Newer Larger Drive and then gave me the option to copy from the smaller to the larger (make sure that you have this right), and after the copy finished (about 3-4 hours), I was given the option to expand my new drive to 2 TB for tivo, and then to supersize which only took about one second each.Done!  Nothing else needed to be done since the WD20EURS is already optimized to work with Tivo (no need to worry about parking or seek speeds or running the Wdidle program).  I simply put the new drive into my Tivo, and now it says 320 Hrs of HD recording available.Naturally, to make my computer usable again, I turned it off and  disconnected the Tivo Drives, and reconnected my hard drive power and sata belts, and started my computer hitting F2 again to access the setup and bios program and changed back the order of the boot to hard drive first.Note, that the WD20EURS needs to be aligned if instead of puting it into a Tivo or video recorder you leave it inside your computer running with Windows XT in place unless you align the hard drive first (a jumper setting), however, this is not a problem setting up a tivo drive as the JMFS boot disk that you made has its own operating system that you use when you boot and the fact that windows XT might be on your computer is totally irrelevant to the copy procedure.  So don't worry about windows XT being on your computer for this copy procedure and don't add a jumper or alter or align the WD20EURS when you get it!If I had known I was going to buy an upgrade drive, I probably would have purchased the $400 Tivo Premiere XL4 machine (cheaper on Amazon) with 300 HD hours already available and the ability to record four channels at a time instead of 2 channels and only 150 HD recording hours like the Tivo Premiere XL.  By the way, you can get a refurbished Premiere XL from Tivo with 150 HD hours for $150 at present.  And of course, it may be wise to save the old Tivo drive removed as a backup should your new drive ever fail or to put in the machine for a factory return if you need service later.The instructions to do this upgrade may be slightly different for an older version than a Tivo Premiere, however, they are readily available on the internet.  If you are not confident about doing this and are out of space, the external drive may be a much better option for you.Of course, a computer shop or hard drive cloner tool may be able to clone your Tivo Drive onto the larger drive.  However, you may still need to run the JMFS boot disk to expand the new drive to the full 300Hrs recording time and supersize (for another 20 hours) the disk and if you have less than a Premiere machine, you may need to use a different program to supersize (instructions on line).The new drive does not invalidate the ownership of your Tivo, which is recognized from a microchip in the machine.  Also, this process works fine with a machine with Windows XP as mentioned since you are using the Unix Operating system on the JMFS boot disk.  My drive although bulk OEM, was easily recognized and used for the copying of my older drive to the new.  Other drives may work for this procedure, but the WD20EURS is an AV drive optimized to conserve its resources when not being used and to be more reliable in the long run.As a side note, Comcast in our area only broadcasts at 720dpi even in high definition.  When I set my Tivo to record higher than that, the picture looked terrible, some sort of bad upsampling apparently.  So, if you don't like your picture, try setting your tivo for recording at 720 dpi.
summary: WD20EURS is the Drive to Get to Upgrade Your Tivo Hard Drive

reviewText: I use a home brew tube radio with tuned rf, 3 if stages custom tuned extra sharp, amplified avc with a tuning meter. I use a long wire antenna and had reached a dead end on picking up any more stations. As my antenna is directional north east/south west I needed a directional antenna to pick up any more. Connected to the antenna stage and ground thru a .05 uf capacitor I was able to pick up 5 new stations the first night. This Antenna does work if properly used. If it is to be used passively its performance is reduced. Just laying a wire or a loop of wire near radio will not work. You need to place a flat loop of 15 to 25 windings depending on size of wire next to radio. Experiment as its part of the hobby. If you do not hear a peak as you tune the antenna the number of wires are off.  I tried several radios with mixed results. Using 2 of my best radios, there was no improvement. A cheap Bell and Howell I have, it improved it but not worth the effort. If you expect it to pull in that weak station free of noise, maybe, if it is only a directional problem. You must use both the ground and signal lead.

I have been using this strap for a Canon Rebel T2i (550D) for several months now and I must say that this camera strap is very comfortable to use. As I've seen from previous reviews about the strap sometimes getting in the way I have found this to be only a small problem as I had the strap itself mounted on the camera and the battery grip attachment for the camera. I have now upgraded to a 5D Mark III and attempted to mount this strap to the new camera and found that it just did not feel right. So I had come up with a solution based on some of the Black Rapid straps that allow you to mount from the tripod mount at the bottom of the camera. So I had fashioned each of the connectors for the strap to each face out in differing directions from the tripod mount, then screwed my Manfrotto quick release plate tightly through the two loops at the end of each connector then placed the strap back on to the camera and attached my Canon EF 70-200mm L lens to walk around and test the durability of the makeshift fix. And it worked very well.So, all in all, I would recommend this strap to anyone.

reviewText: I've had great luck with Vanguard products, - binoculars and tripods, and this tripod/ball-head combo is no different. For reference, I used this product with my Canon 5D Mark III and 24-105L combo.Pros:1.) The construction of the 263AT tripod is great. The legs open easily, and it's great to be able to turn the stem 90 degrees for those low shots. It's got a nice weight to it so it won't fall over.2.) The padding on the legs will prevent against the legs scratching each other up. It also means the legs aren't freezing cold/boiling hot when you handle them!3.) The SBH-100 ball head is a great, very portable head. It's very, very smooth. Another reviewer said they had to lubricate the head to make it smooth, but mine was silky smooth out of the box. You shouldn't have to do any DIY to make this work. It locks excellently, and I had NO fear with my expensive setup attached to the head.Cons:1.) You need a coin to tighten the tripod mount piece to your camera. Other heads on the market (including some of Vanguard's) have a D-shaped ring to tighten this piece down, so it's a shame the SBH-100 isn't one of them. Not the end of the world - just keep a coin on you!2.) The finish on the SBH-100 isn't perfect (at least mine isn't). Just some minor imperfections toward where you connect it to the tripod.Overall, though, this is a very solid combination. I've actually used the SBH-100 head with my carbon fiber Vanguard Alta Plus 225CT. What a fantastic, light combination, too.Despite a few minor nit-picks, this really is an excellent tripod+head, and I have no reservations about recommending it.4.5 stars out of 5.
summary: Another excellent Vanguard tripod and ball head.

So, you would think an unenclosed USB fan might be dangerous while running.  It isn't.  It doesn't spin fast enough for that and the blades are harmless.  However, it puts out a surprising amount of air flow.  Note, however, the airflow is not tremendous.  In this small of a form, you're not going to get tons of air.  So, don't expect that.  However, I'm giving this fan 5 stars because it does exactly what it claims and it does it well.  It's also packaged nicely and it arrived timely.  Some other reviewers have stated that it's hard to adjust while it's spinning.  Yes, if you try grabbing the fan by the gooseneck, you're likely to get hit by the spinning blades.  No, they don't hurt as they don't spin that fast, it's just a little startling.However, to adjust this fan, it's very simple.  Pinch the center of the fan between the back and the front to stop the blades from spinning.  You have to straddle the spinning fan in that space between your thumb and index finger.  It might take a few practice tries, but it's really easy.  Once you pinch the fan, the blades stop.  Then adjust the fan how you need it. Release and the fan spins again. It's actually quite simple. It also makes it simple to unplug the fan.  Stopping the fan in this way doesn't hurt it for small adjustments.Now, the amazing thing about this fan is that it's nearly noiseless.  I've had other small desk fans and they always have a certain degree of noise and rattle.  This one has nearly none.  It appears that the fan motor used in this unit is a low CFM motor similar to those used inside of a computer chassis.  Also, if you buy a USB battery, like the Instapark MP1800U2 5,200 mAh External Battery Pack, you can plug the fan in (along with your other electronics) on the go.  If you get aInstapark 10 Watt Solar Panel Portable Solar Charger, you can run this one from sunlight or charge the aforementioned battery.This is a simple little gooseneck USB fan that works exactly as described.  No more, no less.
So far vrery reliable, no problems around 100 ft and beyond even with some obstacles in the way! def recommend this if your on a bidget like me!

As it states in the product description, this is made for G-type Nikon lenses.  It -will- work with AF and old manual lenses, but not well.Here's why: it doesn't play well with anything with an aperture ring.  I find that if you combine this with a lens with an aperture ring and haven't stopped it all the way down, the larger tab on the aperture ring may press on the lens release lever of the adapter.  I suspect that many of the reviews of this adapter that say it won't open the aperture full are a result of this issue.  If the lens is not fully mounted onto this adapter, sure enough, you won't be able to open the iris all the way.  Properly attached, the following lenses work through their full aperture range: 20/mm Sigma, 35/2D Nikon, 50/1.4G Nikon, 85/1.8D Nikon, 70-200/2.8 Nikon, 17-55/2.8.I'll reiterate: make sure you have the lens' aperture ring stopped down and the lens fully mounted to the adapter, or else the aperture may not function properly and the lens may come off the adapter.Other than issues with non-G lenses, this absolutely behaves as one would expect.I'd give this five stars except for one real issue: the aperture adjustment ring built into this adapter does not move smoothly.  It's operation is a bit jerky, and you will notice this lack of smoothness if you adjust it while shooting video.  However, even if it could be done smoothly, adjusting the aperture during video can be jarring, so this is a non-issue to me.  I have not compared this to other models of adapter.I've used this with some sizable/heavy lenses and I feel pretty confident about the build.  There is no slop on either rotation or perpendicular to the plane of focus.  At least that I could discern.  I have two and feel they're indistinguishable from one another.  Consistent quality (for better or worse!)Used with G lenses: 4 or 4.5 stars.Used with AF-D/AI lenses: 3 stars.Hope this helps.  Happy shooting.
summary: Made for G lenses, not great with others
