Overall, I'm very pleased with this product.  My speeds are as advertised, I'm getting near 200 mbps (172) between my upstairs D-Link DIR 655 Extreme Wireless N router and the downstairs hookup.  I have the downstairs unit going into a D-Link Gigabit ethernet switch and ran Cat 6 cables to a Roku, a Samsung 6700 3D Blueray player, and a Samsung U55D8000 3D Smart TV.  I also run a laptop off of the downstairs switch and have a lickity-split connection to the internet using this unit.  Way faster than running off of the Wi-Fi even though it's an N router.  The units found each other immediately and the only snag I ran into was the encryption process.  It just isn't explained well in the literature that comes with the unit.  Well, they tell you how to initialize the encryption, but it fails to follow-up with any kind of trouble shooting possibilities when it fails.  Also, having to depress the button until the light flashes, then going to the other unit to depress it's button within a minute is quite a workout when you have to try it over and over again to get it to work, with one unit upstairs and the other downstairs, especially when it's not working.  In the end, I just didn't worry about the encryption part due to the fact that the info is not being broadcast like it is with wireless.  All in all, I'm a happy camper and am glad I bought this kit.  I chose D-link because I already had the D-link router and gigabit ethernet switch and wanted maximum compatibility with no issues due to a lack of.

This lens is easily the best deal in digital photography. I could not be happier with the image quality I am getting from this lens paired up with my Canon 60d. I could have spent many many hundreds of dollars more for a wide aperture lens with a similar focal range, but under good outdoor daylight conditions I hardly think I'd get image quality worth hundreds more than what I get from this Tamron. I replaced a Canon 55-250 IS, a great low cost lens in its own right, with this Tamron lens. This lens is one purchase that makes me feel that I have found a really incredible bargain, and it feels good to get a great deal once in a while. The $100.00 rebate is just icing on the cake.

We bought this unit for the keyboard, and when we first got it, we thought it was great.  We have since changed our minds.This thing eats batteries, possibly because the Bluetooth is always on, and there is no way to turn it off.  Good quality alkaline batteries last maybe two weeks, sometimes less.After a few months, it began to be less and less responsive, even on the basic, non-Bluetooth functions.  A "standard" TiVo remote works fine on both of our boxes, but the Slide is unresponsive and unreliable on both of them.TiVo's customer support was monumentally unhelpful.  It's out of warranty, so they don't care.I never really cared for the cramped layout of the standard control keys, anyway.  For some reason, they decided to make this unit about 2/3rd the size of the regular remote, and "adjusted" the button layout to make it fit.  It's too cramped, and the remote feels slightly "wrong" in your hand, while your thumb gropes awkwardly, trying to find the danged "reverse" button without hitting the "pause" instead.TiVo needs to try again on this thing.

I would characterize this printer just like the other good reviews. Quality excellent. Accommodates many media. Prints have die cut snap-off sides to make a borderless 4x6. Hopefully it'll last long - which is hard for these reviews to assess. I'm very happy with the 1st print. I plan to use these for on-location event "couple" shoots, and will test it on a studio photo shoot (like the Polaroids tests of olden days).

I got mine really fast. However, it not only did not read the card--it trashed all the pictures! The card is now empty and no way to get those photos back. It does work in the camera again, so the problem is not the card. Pay attention to the other people who have gotten one of these--the number of bad reviews is trying to tell us something.

everyone -- please stop spending money on cheap earbuds.  do yourself a favor and buy some products from etymotic.  i have these and some er4ps -- for the money, they can't be beat and provide outstanding sound.  make sure you get a good seal in your ears to get good bass response.  highly recommend getting some comply foam tips -- much better and more comfortable than "stock" etymotic tips.

Ok, I bought this as what I thought was a relatively inexpensive, but solid solution for home security.  When I received it I decided to hook it up as wired on my desk at home with the expectation that once the kinks were worked out and I better understood the product I could remotely mount it in a wireless configuration.So it is now hardwired on my desktop and I find that it quits responding to the UI at times.  I can then attempt hard "reboots" of the camera (toggle power).  The bottom line is that the UI response is glitchy and at times goes away without letting you know whether your device configuration changes actually were saved.So getting past this obstacle, I got some configuration setting in and thought I would test it using an alarm to notify my gmail account. Ok, I enter configuration parameters for gmail (and the associated alarm settings) and press test (oh, but wait, you aren't supposed to press test unless you have saved the configuration settings first.  Ok, unsure of the state of the camera I restore factory defaults and proceed again.  As of this writing I don't have email alerts.The bottom line is that I am guessing that there is a way of making this camera (and it's associated features) work, but the cycle time between making changes and testing to see if it works is really long and I've wasted hours!As an added note, I am a software engineer.  A little rusty at networking topics but I understand the various protocols (dhcp, dns, ...)...
summary: Hours to configure and still not working?

reviewText: I needed this for my speech class online and when i got it, it had no instructions on how to use it. I used a google search to get the instructions only to find out I needed to download a program to even work with it. Once I did that, I found out it didn't work. The mic was broken and all you get is static. I contacted the company several times and all I got was one response from them saying I need to plug it into the right ports. I know what ports to plug it into, I am not a moron as they make you sound. Then asked for a refund. NO one contacted me again. I filed a claim with Amazon because even though it is cheap, its a crappy piece of equipment and had to go out and get a new one from Walmart because it was a waste of time and money to order this from this company. Save your money.
summary: Didnt even work and TERRIBLE customer service

reviewText: I've owned many tower of the years, but this one, this one I just love. So lets get started:1) Positives- Durable- Nice simple design- Lots of inside room due to removable parts- Cable management is alright- Able to fit large aftermarket parts- Good airflow2) Negatives- Interior was not black (had to paint it black myself)Other there than one small negative, the CF Haf 912, is a bang for the buck.

For the average user who needs to read various external cards, this product is okay.But for forensic purposes, where a write-blocker must be used, it doesn't work at all. The reader and any cards will not be recognized.This limitation doesn't apply to many people, obviously. But for those, like myself, who would be affected, you've been warned.Jerry
summary: Okay, but not for forensic purposes

reviewText: I bought this lens because I knew the 18-55mm would only do so much. This lens is AMAZING!!! The zoom is awesome and pictures that are right up to 300mm are clear. Some people say that it starts to get fuzzy or the edges feather, but I have not had this problem whatsover :)  I can't wait to take this lens on the road with me this summer!  The only problem I had, and it was my own fault not the len's ... we went to see a new rollercoaster being built, and I left my 18-55mm lens in the car in my camera bag .... the 55mm-300mm was to close to really get any great shots of the coaster, so make sure to have a smaller lens with you ;) lol

I purchased this lens and was not as thrilled as other reviewers were. The lens performs well in optimal situations but what lens doesn't? As soon as the lens was challenged in low light everyday situations the photos were less than average and just performed like a cheap lens even at 28-50mm. At the extended range there was quite a bit of distortion and the image stabilization is not so great despite what they say. I don't agree with people who say this is a great walk around lens. It's not! If your going to use 300mm get a really good lens and spend the money. If you are going to take this to Italy and shoot for fun it's OK. This should really be a $500.00 lens.In short; for what it costs, it should be better. NOT AS SHARP as other lenses in the Nikon portfolio. I was really looking forward to getting this lens and I liked the build quality and weight. I ended up returning it and getting the Nikon 24-70MM for another $800.00. I have to say I am satisfied and my next purchase will be a 70-200mm expensive but worth it.p.s.I used it on a NIKON D600

This is a big, powerful lens to be placed in the hands of a newbie like me.  There probably should be some regulations requiring training and permitting.....  But, it is fantastic, bordering on I would sleep with it but my wife would not be happy.  The lens and D5100 have me in over my head with their capabilities.  Whenever I go out and get a few images I cannot wait to see what they look like on the computer.An important reminder coming from a big boy used to big boy toys: This lens is a heavy, large diameter contraption that is a real handful to hold steady.  And, I don't mean my comment as a criticism...it is the nature of the beast.  Just be aware of it if you decide to buy.I am happy with my decision.  I am very satisfied with the image quality.

This is an excellent camera and easy to use.  I expecially like the flash feature.  The flash won't fire unless you raise it.  I like the big LCD screen to review pictures.  I would like to advise everyone to use the wrist strap.  I didn't with the first one and dropped it on a hard floor and ruined the lens.  This time I purchased a camera warranty which will replace the camera or pay for repairs.  I liked the first Canon enough to buy another one almost like the first.  I really like the 12X zoom lens.  I haven't found anything about this camera I don't like.

I love this product! If you have a person in your family that is getting along in years, this is the product for you! I have to get up a few times during the night and with my eyesight the little night lights don't really do the job. I use the remote switch on my lamps and keep the control on my night stand. Great range and very quick response! I have not found ANY cons about this product!

In May of 2011 I won this case in an iPhone Life Magazine contest. They had it shipped directly to me from Amazon. It was very versatile and offered good protection for my iPad 2. About a week ago, at only 8 months old, the case began to disintegrate. The corners where the magnets that turn the device on and off are located came unglued and the magnets fell out. The stitching around the edges of the cover began to unravel and the cardboard stiffener inside the cover was exposed. Small string like pieces of black fabric or leather have begun to peel off the edges of the case.Over the years I have owned many leather cases and portfolios. I have never had a product come apart like this one has. The workmanship and materials are shoddy to say the least. I STRONGLY recommend against the purchase of this case.
My case has no smell.  Fits my new iPad 3 perfectly.  The pouch is a nice extra(although it could be slightly bigger).  Also, smartcover function works 100% of the time.

I guess the most disappointing part was the varying sizes of the lens threads.  Some of the lenses fit my camera, others did not. The items were tightly packed together in one box, so it was very difficult to get them all back in the box when I needed to return them. Making the return has been a nightmare.  The seller claims he did not receive the items although I have delivery proof from the post office.  Had a file a claim with Visa.

reviewerName: Clifford B. Farris "Cliff and Ann the Chefs"
reviewText: My first real test, which the Garmin 2460 passed with flying colors, was on a trip to a remote plant site on the Roan Plateau in NW Colorado.  The unit found all the dirt back roads and took me to the front gate.  It also got me to an obscure medical supply place and Asian Market here in Denver.  This has the best HMI (human machine interface) of any device I own, along with my keyboard Kindle.The features work extremely well that I have tried.  The voice control is excellent.  The directions clear, the intersection views most helpful.  I highly recommend the Garmin Nuvi 2460.Yes, you can use a smart phone, but it is a terrible drawdown on the battery, is not continuous, and much less helpful in a congested situation.Excellent unit.  Especially like the 5 inch screen.  Far superior to the 4.3 inch.  Built like a tank.
Works exactly as described. I downloaded the latest maps. It took a while but went smoothly.I like the posted speed limit feature on the screen.

I had never owned a GPS before, so I decided to purchase this one, because the reviews were real good. It is just as I expected, a great product! It isn't hard to use, and it has a nice screen on it. You get lifetime map and info updates when you register it. I would say this as one very nice GPS!
I don't want to repeat same words written by a number of users. It's amazing product. It may be entry level DSLR but good start for a new photographer like me.

Does exactly what it states in the item description.  It works as promised with my Sony Alpha-55.  It does not seem to eat batteries like I expected.  Honestly I was very pleased given the value of this purchase.  It's better than the standard built-in flash on the a55.

I bought this tv at the begining of december on a gold box special.By the middle of april it was dead. would not turn on. blue light would temporeley brighten, then dim , no picture, nothing. i have not contacted coby yet as warranty was only 90 days. i cant decide if having it fixed will be throughing good money after bad..But one thing is certain, i will never buy another coby product again. CAN YOU SAY CHEAP JUNK. i have owned many tv's but never had one die this quickly...........

I installed 4 of these over 4 months ago, and they have been working very well.  I also installed two other cameras, from a different manufacturer that provide a live feed to the house, so these NightWatcher cameras are for backup/alternate angles (and also for their motion tracking lights).  Since the NightWatchers record directly to their on-board SD cards, they are not useful for live-monitoring.  However, they work well in their designed capacity.  The tracking function is really cool, and seems to make for an intimidating deterrent.One tip: One of my NightWatcher lights was coming on every time a car drove by on the street, because the motion detection has a pretty long range.  I made it "near-sighted" by placing electrical tape over the upper portion of the motion detection window on the NightWatcher.  Now, it only "sees" when there is motion on the driveway and near the garage. Perfect.  Raise or lower the tape on the window to adjust the range.I am satisfied with these camera/lights.

Unfortunately this appears to be one of those instances where the thing arrived in non-working condition.  Considering the number of reviews that indicate this happened, I'd say buyer beware.  At this price it's not worth the effort to return...but others beware.

very disappointed with the lack of apps. the only thing i like about this unit is the keyboard because it's light and compact and that it has netflix.I love my asus transformer and i expected unit to act the same or exceed the capability of the transformer. . otherwise it's like any paperweight i have at home. don't get this product. i understand why the person i bought my unit from sold his/hers.can't play hulu period and there's no crackle app.THIS DEVICE IS LACKING AND SHOULD NOT HAVE BEEN RELEASED. KEEP YOUR MONEY AND SAVE UP FOR A TABLET OR A COMPUTER!about me: i own an iphone, an asus transformer and prime. i love android and i can't wait to get rid of my iphone (11 more months!)

OK, i bought this remote for my Pentax *istD.My intention was to use it with the bulb function for long exposure like the Pentax Brand remote.Unfortunately it only activates the shutter like a standard press of the shutter button, if you hold the button down the shutter still closes immediatelyYOU CANOT USE IT WITH BULB FUNCTION FOR LONG EXPOSURE ON Pentax *istD (and i assume others as well)otherwise its OK for self or family portraits.I have since ordered this cable release to replace it.EzFoto Wired remote Shutter Release Control compatible with CANON RS-60E3, PENTAX CS-205, CONTAX LA; fits Canon EOS 60D, 300D, 350D, 400D, 450D, 500D, 550D, 600D, 1000D, 1100D, Rebel XTi, Rebel 2000, Rebel T1i, Rebel T2, Rebel T2i, Rebel T3, Rebel T3i, ...Side note: The remote will be very useful for STOP MOTION ANIMATION allowing more time to focous on the subject

reviewText: You call tech support in normal business hoursand they say they are closed, call during business hours.If you try to create a "ticket"...it says your phone number is incorrectand your address is wrong...WHAT? How would it know this.This is cheap chinese crap...save your moneyStuff is so full of bugs U need to spray it with bug spray

This is a good modem but Clearwire is/was bad.  The person above that doesn't understand all of the negative reviews obviously wasn't part of the class action lawsuit that we just won.  I got a large credit to my bill (it's paid for 6 months, roughly) because of the speed caps.  Its illegal and they did it to ALOT of people.  I'm a "mild" downloader, and never abused my service.  Further, I live 1 block from the 4G tower so I am a very small "strain" on the resources.  They had me capped to .25Mb/sec which means a typical webpage took 10-15 seconds to load.  It was like this until 3 days after the lawsuit was filed.  Been fine ever since, so now I have no complaints!  It works great, and the closer you live to a tower, the beter.  They guarantee 3MBit and I get 13MBit with a tower 1 block away. =)  I do have service issues about twice a month, where the tower rolls my connection for a few hours.  Usually in the middle of the night, so maintenance maybe?  Kind of a pain at times but minimal.  I've changed to this modem hoping it will help and to drop the 4G hotspot I have in lieu of a router so I can share my internet throughout the house.Enjoy!

Got it to display the family pictures. The screen is very nice and sharp. Sometimes it's even too bright, but you can reduce the level of brightness anytime. Nice templates for clock and slideshow feature. Cool Sony logo on/off in menu switch. Changes photo orientation if you set the frame vertically or horizontally. Very nice product from Sony. No regrets.

I purchased this device to extend signal throughout our rather large house. Setup was a bit more difficult than I expected, but it came out OK. I got confused when I had to enter an IP. Our router uses 10.*.*.*, but the extender was suggesting 192.168.1.1 for the IP address to use. I tried changing it, but got an error. When I just left it at the default it went fine.Once set up, I had difficulty in getting it to keep the connection from where I had originally placed it. I think it would work at first, then drop the signal and would not try to reconnect. For that reason, I put it closer to the base router, in a more direct line. Now it seems to work fine, and has been working for a while now with no problem. It does get slightly warm, but you should expect that from most such devices. It probably doesn't help that I have it kind of surrounded to keep it out of sight.Overall, I'm satisfied with the purpose. Now that I have gotten configuration and positioning figured out, its been cranking away for about two months with no problem. If you need higher reliability or need an extender that can pick up fringe signals, you'll probably want to spend the extra to get something a little higher end. There is a version of the extender with three antennas. I haven't tried it and so can't vouch for it's quality, but it seems that the extra antennas might help.
summary: Works well if set up correctly

reviewText: This sim card cutter works well. You just insert your card and have at it!Note, for people whose sim cards aren't aligned properly, you'll first need to prune down the sides that are too big, then align it by eye prior to making the cut. I did this with no problem, just shaved little by little with a knife (I didn't want to use scissors in case I bent the plastic too much) until I could fully fit the actual card into the cutting zone properly.

This thing works GREAT. That said, it doesn't work like they say, and they don't tell you how to use it properly...also, what they consider minor or major may differ GREATLY from what you think minor, or major, really is.Buy this with confidence...but also helps to get the AC adapter. That said, use the 'rejuvinator' fluid liberally...and forget the 'number of times' they tell you to let it rotate...and start off by tripling that count.  A minute of operation on a 'roughed up' disk is a MINIMUM of time to get it playing again...normally takes 2-3 minutes...and is hard on that abrasive wheel (the purple wheel). Really rough shape CD's will cost you in replacing that wheel often...it is your 'abrasive disk', after all.That all said, if the disk isn't cracked, then chances are high that you can recover the disk at least well enough to play it (or with CD's, just rip the CD and then burn a replacement). This device will pay for itself quickly...as long as you have realistic expectations and understand, most-likely, your 'minor' is really a 'major damage' issue that will take a bit to fix.I gave 4-stars, because their instructions make it sound easier than it is, almost to the point of unrealistic...but the machine works better than advertised.
summary: Works great - but not so good on the instructions

reviewText: DVI mode works cleanly but the VGA mode always shows shadows. I have connected it to my xbox, my mac and my pc and all of them have shown the shadows in VGA mode. So if you are getting this for VGA then I would recommend against it. DVI has been working perfectly though.

Very pleased with this monitor. Arrived quickly from Amazon despite the shipping estimate stating it would be a month (it only took a few days.) Obviously this monitor is a fraction of the price of "brand" models out there, which is a plus, and it included a screen hood and chargeable battery pack.The menu control system on the monitor takes a bit to get used to, but it is not a deal breaker. One tip is to turn off all of the display info on your DSLR when using the monitor to shoot, this will provide you with the largest picture on the monitor. (When the display information shows, the image is cropped down to make room for the shot info; ISO, Shutter Speed, etc.) Also note that even when the display info on your DSLR is turned of, the video image won't fill up the entire screen, since this is a widescreen monitor and most DSLR's LCD screens are 4:3, not 16:9.Finally, you will need to need to dial in your monitor's color balance to match your camera. It took me about 20 minutes playing with the different color channels (red, green, blue) and the saturation.Overall, great screen at a fantastic price. Perfect solution for DSLR shooters who don't have a swivel screen on their camera. I would also suggest purchasing a Manfrotto 492 Ball Head & HDMI to Mini HDMI cable.Manfrotto 492 Ball Head Replaces the Manfrotto 482RiteAV - HDMI to Mini-HDMI Cable - 1.5 ft.

reviewerName: Rexomus "One man with courage makes a majority."
reviewText: I purchased this monitor for use with Canon 7d Cameras. They worked so well that I just ordered more of these for my rest of my cameras. The monitor works as described. I am very impressed with the battery life. I shot a six hour wedding and only used about 20% of the battery life. This monitor makes pulling focus a cinch. I really like that the display features are customizable; color temperature, brightness, contrast, etc. can all be changed at the touch of a button.I noticed one reviewer complained about not being able to view full screen but that is not true. To view the feed in full screen just hold down the menu button for two seconds and "wala" full screen feed.All in all I highly recommend purchasing this monitor.

I've been using Netgear wireless routers almost exclusively for years. This one has good specifications on paper, but in performance I've found it more problematic than previous generations. Strange DHCP behaviors, devices unable to connect, log files not showing the expected information...I find I have to reset it every 14 days or more frequently to get all devices working normally again. The QoS management interface also cause me grief, it just lacks a certain intuitiveness. Signal strength seems less powerful than the previous generations as well. Also missing a key feature to be able to bump wireless clients off the network. I expect to be trying a different vendor altogether for my next purchase.
summary: Seems a bit flaky at times, missing a desirable feature

reviewText: I was able to rip and store 100 movies on this thing, now I need another. Highly recommended.  Am about to buy another one right now.  Especially if I can piggy back.  Terrific for backup storage.  Almost small as a Droid.

I bought this soundcard along withASUS PCI-Express x1 Sound Card XONAR ESSENCE STX/90-YAA0C0-0UAN00Zfor my newly built PC (Major components: Windows 7 ultimate 64bit + AMD FX8150 + Asus V formula 990FX + 32GB corsair memory + 3-way CF Radeon HD 6950 + 120GB corsair SSD for boot drive + logitech Z906 + these two soundcards). I expected this soundcard to bring me good gaming experience, but I did not notice a significant difference between it with either Xonar Essence or the onboard chip(SupremeFX X-Fi 2). I am kind of disappointed about Creative because most of current games are no more specially designed for EAX5.0 or other Creative's technology that they advertise. Now, Creative is only a good soundcards provider but no more a specialist for gaming.
summary: Good product, but not as great as expected

reviewText: I bought this Kingston DataTraveler 8GB after I lost mine and needed another. It was on sale, so I decided to try it and see if I liked it.Pros:Swivel designFast upload2GB of cloud storage (vDrive)urDrive (that is able to be uninstalled)Portable Maxthon browserRemovable pre-loaded contentSmall size (perfect for keychains)GamesCons:Keychain hole would be wider/bigger to allow for a bigger keyring

I have 3 computers and I sometimes need to transfer programs from one machine to another, comes in real handy for that. I also put pictures from any of the computers onto it and plug it into an HP Photo printer and print right from the flash drive. Also on the the drive is a Linux Distro called "Puppy", you plug that into the USB port and hit the F8 when you start the computer, you can then boot to Linux go on line and do most tasks you want to, it is it's own operating system. All in all it's a very handy little device and being so small you hardly know you have it with you. Oh, and I also have a ton of music on there so I can play my tunes whenever plugged into a machine.

I have burned 6 out of 10 discs to the edge so far and have not had any failures.  I have a LG BH12LS35 drive I have burned the discs with.  The media code on my batch of discs is VERBAT-IM1-000.  The top of the disc has a white, flat surface with the only markings on the disc being 'Verbatim BD-RE DL for VIDEO 50GB 2x' in small, gray print.

i am a very satisfied customer.this adapter arrived on time with my 2-day shippingi have been using it daily for about a week so i can use my new tv as a second screen.both the sound and picture quality are transmitting perfectly.the macbook i am using is circa 2010, the tv is brand new, and i have used two hdmi cords with this- gold plated (expensive) and not (cheap) and it works great with both.i noticed a LOT of reviews mentioning sound problems, which confused me at first, too.but i figured it out:go to your system preferences, then sound settings, then click the 'output' tab.lastly, you click your tv name/brand and boom, your sound comes out of the tv. :D

reviewText: I bought this at full retail (about $99.00) when I bought my Sprint EVO 4G about a year ago. I treated that set roughly, jamming them in my pocket or behind a visor when not in use, wore them in hot, humid, dirty conditions when exercising and doing lawn work, and generally pulled and tugged them roughly when putting them on and yanking them off. No surprise, a few weeks ago, one of the earpieces came loose as I pulled at it. Sprint gave me a Jabra Sport as a replacement, but the sound quality didn't compare. When I found these at about half price and free shipping, I decided I'd try again and treat them with more respect this time. SO, if you really are an active, high-impact type of person, these may not be for you. However, if you want to hear your stereo music and your phone calls VERY clearly and have a headset that does not need to be removed in order to hear conversations, then THIS is for you. I am SO happy to have this again, and I'm treating it with the respect it deserves.
summary: Second set of  My Favorite Headset

reviewText: On paper this Drive has it all. Remote access, itunes,mac support, space, everything. I tried to ignore all the bad reviews on speed and figured how bad could it really be. It is horrible. I was getting under 10Mbps transfer rate using cat6 cable via my verizon router. Transferring large amounts of data would take me forever. I just can't live with this kind of a system. Back to Amazon  it is and i'll have to keep shopping around. Such a shame.
summary: I wanted to love it but Speeds are horrible

reviewText: This NAS device eliminates the need for 3rd party services when accessing private data. It works as advertised with intuitive graphic user interfaces.

I bought two of these Wasabi batteries to power my Sony CX550V camcorder, based on the very positive reviews I read and I am very happy I did.  They worked just fine with my camcorder without any issues.  So far, I have used them once for a full day of shooting.  I didn't measure exactly how long each battery lasted, but the capacity was long enough for it to not be a concern.  These batteries are a fraction of the cost of the Sony NP-FV100 and are inexpensive enough for you to easily buy a few of them.  The 3-year manufacturer warranty is an added benefit that will give you additional peace of mind.  I highly recommend this battery!
i had trouble getting it to work with anything really i then found out i had to change the settings on everything just to get it to work

reviewText: I don't understand the complaining about this case. Mine fits my P7100 like a glove and the magnetic clasp never opens accidentally.

This Belkin Matte Screen Protector comes three to a pack at a very economical price.  I applied it in less than a minute and was surprised at how super-easy it glided on.  I've had problems with other protectors adhering too quickly and producing small bubbles.  This one went on without a hitch.  The screen shows through brilliantly.  The anti-glare feature is a plus.  For the price of the three protectors, this is a good choice for Ipod Touch 4G screens.

Optically, this is an amazing piece.  I also have the 24mm 1.4G and 85 1.4G which are all equally as impressive, but I find this 35mm focal length to be much more useful as an "everyday" lens.  35mm on a full frame body can pass as wide angle for landscapes and architecture as well as a portrait lens.  And because of its close focus ability, it serves as a semi-macro lens as well with about .2X magnification and close focusing to about 1 foot.  Background defocus is also more pronounced than the 24mm due to the focal length, and bokeh is almost as beautiful as the 85 1.4G.  I've used it on a D700 and now on a D800 and when I pixel peep the 36 megapixel file, I'm even more amazed at how sharp this lens is.  It's tack sharp wide open at f/1.4, which was not something I expected, so much so that any increase in sharpness when stopped down was only really noticeable near the edges upon close inspection.  Perhaps Nikon designed the optical formula to be this way?  If so, I applaud them because if you're going to spend $1600 on a big and heavy fast prime lens, you'd want to shoot it wide open, otherwise there's no point in carrying the extra bulk.I'm such a sucker for prime lenses that I've amassed a large of collection of Leica M primes, Zeiss, Voigtlander, Nikon, and Canon primes from new to older classics.  This 35mm has to be up there among my top 5.  The only sharper 35mm I've used is the latest version of the Leica M Summilux, but dare I say even that might not be as sharp wide as Nikon's at f/1.4.  And this 35mm is certainly in the same class as the sharpness king in my collection: the Zeiss 100mm Makro-Planar ZF.2.  But it's not about sharpness that makes this lens great.  It's about usability.  This is the lens that I'd likely keep if I could only have one, or bring with me if I could only carry one, simply because it can used for almost any type of shot.  While it doesn't focus as fast as any of Nikon's pro zooms, it's fast enough for most purposes and that includes focus tracking fast moving subjects like kids or pets.  On the D800, continuous AF works well and is often spot-on.So what are the cons?  There are very few but I'll list them: 1) AF motor is somewhat noisy (sounds cheap and even noisier than my copies of the 24mm and 85mm 1.4G) when the the lens is hunting for focus, 2) it's somewhat large and overly heavy for a regular prime (though nicely balanced and doesn't seem as large when mounted on a D800 or D4), and 3) the filter size is 67mm (why oh why did Nikon do this?  The 24mm 1.4G is almost identical in barrel size, form, and overall dimensions and that lens uses the 77mm filter thread that most of the modern Nikon pro lenses use, so why 67mm for the 35?  Does not compute).  Despite these things, I'm still giving this lens 5 stars because they are far from deal-breakers and doesn't change the fact that I really love this lens.Get one for your FX Nikon body today, you will love it.  But if you shoot with a DX body, save your money and get the excellent 35mm f/1.8 DX version instead.  The 1.4G version is expensive, big, and heavy and its optical advantages are only really exploited by a full frame sensor.
summary: Phenomenal Lens!  One of my favorite primes despite some issues.

reviewText: There were many positive reviews about this camera in Amazon. Like many buyers I chose to ignore the negative reviews. My first purchase with the camera was the kit with 18-105mm lens. After hundreds of shots, only about 15% of them were sharp. I thought the problem were the lens. So, I returned the kit and bought a D7000 body, along with Nikkor 105mm f/2.8G micro and 85mm f/1.8G prime lenses.After testing the new camera body with two new prime lenses, I discovered there was a serious back-focusing problem with the camera. The AF Fine Tuning feature in the camera is quite good. However, I needed to adjust -15 for the 105mm and -4 for the 85mm. Then again, the AF Fine Tuning does not solve all the focusing problems. Depending on the shooting distance, I would have to calibrate the AF again and again. So, the calibration is hit-and-miss.Having trusted Nikon for 30 years, I believed I just had a bad batch twice in a row and I should still have a good chance of getting a good copy. So, I returned the camera again got another copy a few days later. To my dismay, same serious back-focusing problem still exist in the new camera. Then I did some digging in Amazon review (paying attention to the negative ones this time) and Googled more discussion forums to see if I am not alone.  Sure enough, many people had reported the same problem dated back in July 2011.So, I returned the camera again and decided not to try another one.In all fairness, I like the features the camera offers. The body is very responsive. The AF accuracy with the LCD Live View is extremely high (though very slow). However, the Phase-Detect AF system is a complete disappointment.The best thing I got out of this experience is the knowledge I gained from testing AF and fine tuning it. So much information is available on Amazon and photo forums on this subject.  If you own a mid-range camera like D7000, you owe it to yourself to learn how to test and calibrate your camera with your lens collection. Based on my experience, having tried 3 copies without success, it's fair to me to give it a 1-star rating. A camera that cannot focus is not a usable camera on my book.  I will probably wait for the new Nikon cameras coming out this fall (if rumors are right).With this writing, I am hoping all the buyers of this camera (or any camera) thoroughly test their cameras AS SOON AS they receive them. Do not wait until 30 days pass and you have to send them back to Nikon for service. If you pay for a new precise instrument, you expect it to work out-of-box. I chose not to send a brand new camera to Nikon for calibration because it's brand new! Plus, some people have reported same focusing problem even AFTER Nikon service center told them their cameras have been repaired. I am glad I did not need to go through that.Hope this is helpful. Your feedback is welcome. Thank you!

Although on paper D7000 is more advanced / has better specifications than the D90. Nikon clipped this camera's wings.Tons of D7000s are suffering from back-focusing, or hit and miss auto focusing issues. The images are out of focus frequently or systematically back focused. My D40/D3100/D90 does not have such issues.Worse still, the images at 100% are fuzzy and blurry, losing details. It's as if there is a dense fog surrounding everything in the picture, including the objects supposedly in focus.

I needed a DAC/ Amp for  my iMac and Beyer 990 Pro (250 ohm). It was OK, I guess. I like having a knob control rather than a clicker or rocker button, but there were times when the volume wasn't sufficient. It was quiet, and the bulbs were cool if not a little affected. I couldn't really hear any difference between these and my Fiio E7, so I returned this in favor of portability.

I'm not an impulse buyer.  However, there are times when you need an item and just want it to work.  This was the case in my purchase of these cloths.  For years, I have used microfiber cloths made by 3M.  At that time,  they were quite popular and highly recommended.  Fast forward to the year 2012, and there is a better product out there.I recently bought a $700 smartphone and needed a way to keep it clean and shiny (without scratching it).  I pulled out my old 3M microfiber cloths (only used maybe 3 times) and tries it on the old touchscreen phone I was replacing.  I was shocked when I was able to see minute scratches after cleaning it.That is when I knew I needed something better.  I ordered these and were very pleased with them. They are much softer to the touch and come individually wrapped.  They cleaned my phone really well.  One thing I do want to mention is about GojaDigital customer service.  I have never seen such personal service from a company.  They made sure I got the product and was satisfied.I am definitely a satisfied customer and do highly recommend this particular microfiber cloth set.  They do work wonderfully and do NOT scratch.
summary: Great Product From A Company Who Stands Behind Their Product

reviewText: I own this harness as well as the "swat vest" offered by Lowepro. I use the harness for outdoors events due to breathability or when I feel like working light. I have nothing but good things to say about this product and would give the S&F series my highest recommendations.

When you first turn the call reached and could not take it.When you press reception, nothing happened.I started upset.Then I downloaded the update from the official site Jabra.And everything was working.So keep in mind.Works well.I recommend this product.

There is a reason why all the pictures and descriptions do not include the picture of the 3.5mm plug.It is not an L shaped or "right-angled" plug.At $100, you'd expect a more robust plug.  I'm listening to my iPhone4S in my pocket. and the bend in the cable is slowly damaging the joint.  It is matter of time before it breaks and it will be my $100 lesson.It was designed for a i Device, but what were they thinking?  That we will carry the phone in our hands all the time???  Who runs the design at these earphone manufacturer joints???The etymotic HF3(?) has the buttons and a better sound with an angled plug.  Although the Etymotic has it's faults, I think the extra $30 is warranted in this case.If they came out with a L-plug adaptor for $5, then I'd give it a 4 Star.Sound quality score for me it is 70/100.

Great product.  Compared to the run of the mill earphones found at Target or Walmart, these are amazing. My family has several low end brands of earphones, JVC, skullcandy, Phillips.  Klipsch is simply the best we've heard on our small budget.

I was looking for a replacement for my Microsoft Trackball Explorer and this is what I decided on. The M570 is not the same, it uses your thumb instead of fingers to move the ball. It woks well and seems like it should last a long time. I took a few days to get used to the layout, but now I can do everything without thinking about it. I tired various other trackballs and mice and this one felt the best in my hand. I just wish Microsoft still made their trackball explorer since they don't this seems to be the best alternative.

I bought this at my local store.  As I saw good reviews on this I thought it would help with the pains I get.  Out of the box, the ball movement felt a bit stiff.  The scroll wheel made clicking noise.  There's no button for smooth scrolling like the M705.Since I already had a USB bluetooth, I assumed that it would be recognized once I turned it on.  It did not.  I then downloaded the driver for it, and rebooted but still no response.  What was missing is that I needed to go into the Logitech mouse/keyboard settings and startup unifying.  This gets it recognized.  This was missing in the instructions.  Not a big deal but it would have been a time saver.After using the ball for awhile, I started getting used to it.  It wasn't as stiff once I adjusting the movement in the software settings.  It takes some time to get use to it and re-adjusting the settings helped.  the back and forward buttons was a nice convenience and the left and right buttons were responsive.  What I didn't like was the scroll wheel.  It just wasn't scrolling as smoothly as it does with the M705.  It required more effort to scroll so therefore more finger movement.  The clicking noise was annoyance as I could not turn it off.  After a few hours of use, I decided to pack it up and return it.I'm not sure if it was a defect as someone else who posted a review here, had the complete opposite issue with the scroll wheel.  But doing a search, I see that others had the same complaint about the scroll wheel being slow. So, I'm going to assume that slow is the norm.I would have given it 3 stars but I felt that was too much of a neutural recommendation.  If I'd had kept it, then I would had given it 3 stars.  AS I wasn't going to live with it, It doesn't deserve 3 stars.

Excellent product for cleaning away smudges on my cell phone and iPad.  The price is great and free shipping you can't beat.  I shopped around locally before purchasing from Amazon, and I couldn't even find a cleaning cloth at Wal-Mart.  I also use this for my camera lenses.  Great service and fast delivery too.  I ordered on Sunday evening and the item arrived on Thursday same week.  I'll probably order a couple more packs just to have on hand.

I am giving this one four stars currently in Oct of 2012. It is priced at about $60 and is still a good purchase. However as with everything technology related it is not the great deal it was earlier this year. I would give it 5 stars if it were half the price, but with newer cameras coming out on the market at a similar price point with better specs I think 4 stars is in order. The quality of this camera is great. The mount could be a little more robust, but overall it will serve its purpose well. Don't think anyone would complain of its video/audio, but the price is no longer such a great deal. Still I think it is a solid performer.
summary: Good Camera for the Price, Not Great

reviewText: Was easy to install the part to my laptop. Watch the video and it will be easy to install.. So far my laptop hasn't been stolen,..soo not sure if it works.. but it makes me feel better that if someone tries to steal it, that it will take them some time to do it.

These anti-microbe earphones is what I needed. After going through about 2 pairs of earphones shorting out on me within 6 months of use, I resorted to this to see if they will last. My ears sweat after only an hour of listening to music, and I have to clean them after each use. Hopefully these sweat- and waterproof earphone can last at least a year. I did not buy them from Amazon, but from my local Meijers.Downside is sound quality, as I am an avid bass listener. Upside is snug fit, even if the design is inversed.
summary: Good if you want more sound but less bass.

reviewText: I am disappointed.  I bought this to attach to my lens cap and fit around the back of the lens to hold the cap when removed.  I had one on my previous Nikon cap.  My previous lens keeper construction is a round black piece with pressure sensitive adhesive that attaches to the Nikon cap, an elastic string and an elastic round hoop at the other end to stretch around the lens.  Perfect solution and it still works even after 25 years.  This has a looped string attached to the cap and you have to figure out how to loop the string and where to loop it. It's too long to drape around the lens once (18-55mm lens) as there is a lot of leftover string hanging down.  It's too short to double loop around the lens to keep the looped string attached to the lens. So if you loop it around the lens, it feels insecure.  I finally attached the loop around the camera strap and even though the cap gets in the way when using the camera, it's better than losing the cap. If I can find a better solution, I will buy it.  The supplier did provide good packaging and the microfiber cloth.  It arrived on time, and there are no quality problems with the item.  It just doesn't work well for the application.

Ordered from Electromaster. Item came quickly but it is not what is pictured. I chose this particular 'looper' because it shows that it covers the buttons to keep dust out and it shows that the bottom goes slightly over the nano to give at least a small bit of protection on the corners and casing. The item received has holes for the buttons, offering no dust or particle protection, and has no covering for the bottom at all so slips up on the nano. I would return it but it it would almost cost as much as I paid for the item.
summary: Not the same item as pictured

reviewText: It's not a $5000 HD video camera and it doesn't perform like one. But, if you want an inexpensive, well-built, small, pocket HD video camera then it fits the bill. The 1920x1080 video is a bit pixelated at close range and low light is not great. One tip, because of its size there is a tendency to move it around quickly, but that makes for dizzying footage. So, remember to hold it steady and move it slowly. Use a highspeed SD card (class 10 is best). The GUI controls are easy to use and work smoothly and quickly. This camera can takes pics while filming, so that's pretty handy. I'm not taking it swimming, but I think waterproof means it will fare well in the rain. Finally, the 4x zoom is a bit grainy at full zoom. Overall, not bad for a sub-$100 full HD digital video camera. Although, true videophiles may disagree.

February 9, 2013 updateI still love these headphones, but after wearing them for a while, half hour or more, my ears start to hurt. Not from the sound but from the fit. It becomes very uncomfortable, and for the price, you should be able to wear these for longer. So, if you like to wear headphones for a long time, these may not be for you. The sound really is so great, otherwise I would have dropped it down more.I have heard a lot of headphones and I have heard a lot of in-ear buds, and while most sound good when you plug them into your computer, these Diesel headphones are superb, especially plugged into my sound system! Even without a high-end system, you will hear things you wouldn't normally hear. The words will be a little clearer, the highs a little sharper and the bass a little stronger. Putting the diesel through its paces was a real pleasure. I should mention that this is really a 4.5 star product, for reasons I will mention, but I bumped it to 5 stars because I feel that it has enough to go over the top. Let me get the little negatives out of the way. The cord is a little too short I would like to have had it another foot longer. Not a big thing, but still, it would make a difference. The real issue is that the padding does not fully cover my ears. I don't know if that is good or bad, but I currently do not like it. If the actual headphones were a little bigger I think it would be more comfortable and also provide a better experience.....the thing is it might also get your ears a lot hotter. I'll let you know if I change my mind on this. The last thing is the case. It's soft. If my sun glasses come with a hard leather case, so should these. For the amount of money that these cost, these should have a little more protection, especially when travelling. I am actually nervous to take these on trips for fear of damaging them. With that said, these are VERY well made and very sturdy. The wire seems nice and thick and since the cord can be removed, there is less worry of damaging the unit if they accidently get pulled (believe me, cheap ones just fall apart if this happens, I learned the hard way).Back to sound for a second. I would also like to mention that the little speakers on the Diesel really are MONSTERS! I was able to EASILY hear down to 5 Hz, and the range between 300-5 Hz was really awesome! Most subwoofers won't get to 5hz (unless you spend quite a bit of money). For the high end, I was able to hear up to 12kHz. Pretty darned good for my age (over 30 norm is between 12-14 kHz, I believe). This is awesome. The Diesel also looks great, and is easily adjustable. This should please most audiophiles. The talk button is of no use to me, as I only expect to use this for music. I tried it on my computer and I was unable to control it. No worries, as I wouldn't need to any way. I'll try it on my iPad tomorrow.If you are seriously into music, these are the pair for you. Just remember to fold it without putting pressure on the headphones!

Hey, I'm not hung up on speed of thumb drives. They're temporary storage. I use this one to store photos long enough to get them back to my computer and 2T external hard drive, so I really don't care as much about the speed of this thumb drives as some of the other reviewers. How fast do you want to go, anyhow? It downloads a full thumb drive of pictures in a minute. You want blazing speeds? Get a portable 3.0 external hard drive. Or not. The only concern I have with this one is that I know I'm going to lose the separate cap. Sooner of later, I will. Then I'll just get dirt and grunge into the USB connector and have to trash it. An integral cap would be much better.

I always buy based on reviews and this router was the best. I am not sure why, I think it may be a lot of fake reviews (watch this review get taken down). I hate writing bad reviews on something with good ones because we often choose not to believe them.  I have very fast cable internet and while the router does provide the speeds it does not have any range. Even in the same room I only get 3/4 bars. When I go to my bedroom in my one bedroom apt, which is about 35' from the router with a clear line of sight, I barely get one bar and the speed is basically dialup. Notes: The router is in the open with a clear line of sight to all areas I work and any farther then about 10' the internet is super slow. I also changed the channel within the router to a free one and that only helped slightly. I will be sending this one back and getting something with physical antennas. Hope this helps.

I'm leaving this 'review' only to inform others like myself who may think this item would replace an existing internet provider modem.  I have At&t Uverse and use their modem/router.  I thought I could return that piece of hardware to them (and save the monthly fee for it) if I simply bought this router. Wrong.  You still need a modem that would connect to this router (or any router)..  Yeah, I know, most of you tech heads out there are chuckling-but in addition to your amusement I hope to help others avoid my mistake.  It's a cool looking little router with great reviews...but it needs its' own modem!!

reviewText: This charger does more than any I have used so far. One of the nicest features is it gives you status info on each battery so you can actually match up like cells and get best performance overall. It takes a bit longer to re-condition cells but it has been amazing in bringing back to life batteries I thought were hopeless.
summary: Best Charger I've had so far

reviewText: I got this for our 2007 Odyssey and it is great: It charges and plays from iPods and iPhones, it doesn't produce the "Not made for iPhone" error and its AUX port let me plug in a Bluetooth adaptor that we use with the iPad when the kids are watching a movie.We only use it in its "dumb" mode, where we control the music from the iPod/iPhone, so I can't comment on how it lets the radio control the device, hence the 4 stars.
Purchased the (2) 9v and charger for use with the tens device. So far so good! They are charging great and are reliable. Very satisfied and would recommend.

Purchased this to keep anything from happening to my 500 mm lens and accessaries.  Very pleased with the foam and the ease of being able to make a pocket which holds my lens very tightly.  Double lock latches are impressive.  Well constructed case.  Thank you

reviewText: I purchased this device to help with an older parent recovering from an injury. I wanted to be alerted as a precaution to any movement during the night to avoid any accidents. While the unit was easy to set up the motion detection is a bit too sensitive. You have to play with the positioning because rolling in the bed could set it off. The chime is like walking into a dry cleaning store or the other option is a cowboy-like tune.The chime choices are a little annoying but it delivers what its intended for - alerting you to movement. I think its better than the more expensive bed pressure pads if you want a basic alert unit - just make sure you get the positioning right so it triggers at the right moment.

This is the cheapest quality sounding upgrade you can get from on-board audio and it does the job! I have a very expensive PC build with all solid parts, but the audio from the m-board is still a bit bland. I'm not too much into gaming these days but listens to a lot of music on my Klipsch 2.1 speakers as I work. I was a bit skeptical about how much will this card improve over my $300 m-board on-board audio since on-board sounds already fine. Until I got it installed and fired up Pandora ONE's 192kbps tracks, wow was I amazed. The mids and treble clarity are truly different and the bass is more accurate and tuned. I can hear the detailed difference.The integrated headphone amp will drive up to about 120ohms with good clarity on 60+ohms mode with decent volume, but higher impedance pairs will start to lose fidelity. So if you are a hardcore audiophile, this is probably not your card, the Xonar Essence ST will do it for you.There is only one drawback with this card I can think of, it is the build quality. Every other component in my PC have all high quality solid capacitors/parts with precision soldering points the eye can see, but this sound card does not. I can see micro resistors and capacitors mounted on almost sideways but still functioning. I'm not sure if this quality control issue would cause problems down the road or not, but so far this card functions flawlessly with no noise in sound production.I would recommend this card to anyone looking for tremendously better PC sound without forking out too much! This card outperforms ANY Realtek on-board chipset, ALC889 ALC892 etc...
I personally like the matte look. I hate reflections. It does however make the screen a little dimmer and the picture isn't as "crisp".

Ok, so I am not an "audiophile," but someone who is rediscovering 2 channel music after being away, missing the entire surround sound thing, except for a Niro Surround System, which I may add is crazy amazingly good for movies.  Maybe I was late, missing Woot's $99 deal and also not hearing about those T-amps from Sonic, but am back, digging out my CD's and my old Sony amp and an old Marantz (not from the 70's) integrated amp.  Maybe, it's reading Reina and Guttenberg and Meija rant on Stereophile.  I even found my old 5 inch Polk speakers- they had a 20 year old layer of crap all over the drivers which I couldn't even remove completely.  The Polks hurt my ears after 5 minutes, sounding very crisp and sharp, but very detailed.  I looked online for something cheap and good.  Online, people rave about Energy speakers, but I also missed the CB-5 $79 deal (and good thing I did).  So, I kept reading and listening to the Polks.  I also had a pair of Teac 4 inch kevlar speakers sounding very detailed, but having no mid bass.  So I kept reading...  Then, last month I missed Newegg's $99 deal on the 51 floor standers.  I was so mad, but I didn't want clutter, so I went to look at the BS41 bookshelf speakers.  It seems like they have been discontinued by apparently pricing themselves too low, so low that retailers are afraid people will compare them with an upper line of speakers.  Well, I had to audition everything within the ballpark and have this to say:  The BS41s are a great, easy listening, realistic, wall of sound.  I auditioned B&W 685s, 686s, Energy CB5s, CB10s, CB20s, low end Martin Logans, Magnepans- albeit in a not so great closed room full of speakers.  The Pioneers have a more cohesive lows-mid-highs to them.  They don't sound crispy, but realistic like wood instruments sound like wood and string instruments have the right twang.  Vocals sound present and not shouty, but not lip smacking detailed.  With my Marantz int amp, the bass is round and full, being even, but with a small T-amp, the mids and highs dominate.  Both those amps sound smooth as butter.  I remember the first old days of my old Sony CD changer when sound was so accurate and ear piercing, making you wonder why it hurt to listen to CD's.  MP3's streaming from my PC to Iphone or directly from the Iphone are clear, but you can tell that CD's sound more dynamic.  Unplugged Eric Clapton's, "Tears from Heaven" sounds live and wide.  To me, Energy's are too crispy unreal like oversharped LCD 1080P Bluray movies.  B&W's 685, the vocals seem like they are delaye and way behind the speaker and hollow, but the sound is fuller than the 686's, which have a better vocal feel, but lack midbass.  Those high tech MLs and Magepans remind me of the titanium JBL speakers from the 80's like smacking a thin tin can, super accurate and, sounding like a tin can.  These Pioneer speakers are even, not superdetailed in the vocals, but easy to listen to for longer sessions of enjoying your music.  I'm guessing they can tolerate anything from a sharp accurate amp to a warm amp because they are so smooth sounding.  Some notes:  They are fairly large "bookshelf" speakers, more like a 685 than a 686.  The grills are permanent and very subtle, making you focus on the music not on whether or not they sound better with their grills on or off.  Their bird eye's view look like Wharfedales, not some old boxy speakers.  I wish I got them at the Woot price, but I would hate to miss such a great little speaker for 2 channel music or a small setup for watching movies because they reproduce a wide soundstage that sounds realistic.  With vocals smack in the center, I wonder if I would need a center.  A sharper sounding set may impress some people more for movies. This is a great set of speakers for people who want to listen to music for music's sake and not need a sub for movies or anything like that.  Add a great old cd player, a small amp (T-amp or old Marantz) and these speakers are a little bit of fun in a world full of schedules, diapers, car maintenance, bringing out the garbage, doing laundry.  I appreciate the famous designer attention, but it does sound as good as I've been reading about.
summary: Nothing AMAZING about these, but a simple cohesive sound wall.

reviewText: I purchased this because a laptop by used by our kids had one of the letter keys keep falling off.  It is a great price and worked as it should.  We did have the "FN" key come off however after about 6 months of use.  Not a critical key so we are still using it.  Kid use may be a factor.  Would recommend if you need a new keyboard due to great price but buy knowing that it may not be the most durable.

I plugged this little guy into my Toshiba laptop--a laptop notorious for muffled audio--and was immediately impressed with the sound.  What an improvement over the flimsy laptop speakers!  I did not have to do any additional tinkering with the cable.  Its compact built also fits well into the laptop carrier.Charging this device took about two hours.My only complaint is that the cable is too short.  It could benefit greatly if it were at least a foot longer. I understand that perhaps this device is meant more for the traveling iPod user, but this device works great on laptops, too.  A longer cable would allow the user to place the speakers farther away than on the laptop itself, thereby enjoying the sound better.  This is especially crucial when the laptop is on an uneven surface.  The foot-long cable only allows use of this speaker system with the laptop on a table.  This would not work so well with the laptop in bed or in the back of a vehicle.
summary: Excellent sound from such a small device

reviewText: There were few reviews for this card when I had purchased it and all seemed to be quite positive.  I have recently purchased a DSLR (Canon T3i) that I am using for video in full HD.  I purchased two of these cards and everything was working well at first, but every once and a while the recording would stop because the card could not keep up.  I am a wedding videographer and this cannot happen during my shoots because I only have one opportunity to get a good shot.  Unfortunately, I would not purchase more of these, yet if you are doing photography, or something that can be re-shot if it times out, they will be fine.Keep in mind that this is not a constant problem and it only happens here and there.  But for what I do it is not acceptable even if it were only to happen once.  I will use these cards during the bridal preparation and reception during those shots that are not nearly as important as the ceremony itself.So overall, as a casual user, these are fine.  As a professional, I'd shy away from these.  I have had luck with the sandisk extreme, yet they are quite pricey.  I hope this helps in your search!UPDATE:  I have just noticed there are more reviews then when I had purchased these, and many seem to be really enjoying this product.  This may be an issue with the canon T3i, so it may be worth a try and if you have issues you can always return it.

I have had this SSD drive for about three months.  I use it for paging in my memory challenged A31 Thinkpad Laptop to help performance.  It helps a lot. This drive has made my old laptop work like new again.  My laptop comes out of hibernation very quickly now.  After some research, I decided to create a 32 GB partition for paging only.  The "wear leveling" algorithms will spread out the "memory cell" wear evenly across all allocated and unallocated space.  I am very glad that KingSpec built an SSD that is IDE/PATA vs. SATA only.  It saved my laptop.
summary: KingSpec 64GB 2.5" PATA/IDE SSD SOlid State Disk

reviewText: Let me start off by saying I am no audiophile but I do listen to a lot of dubstep and house, and also have recently begun to make them.  Well anyways these headphones are outstanding.  I have gone from beats by dre solo which in my opionion these are way better.  The solo's have a lot I mean a lot of bass which isn't a bad thing but can give you a minor headache if you listen to them to long.  The Bose ae2's in my opinion deliver the perfect amount of bass and does not distort the sound quality whatsoever.  After having my Solo's break at the top headband part even with the reinforced headbands and they broke with very gentle use, I moved on to the studios.  For the amount I paid for these headphones I was very disappointed.  There was a buzzing almost staticy noise whenever you turned them on.  After I sent them back to monster they replaced them and the noise was still there.  After I sold the studios I heard about the Bose ae2's and how they were very nice and delievering headphones.  After a couple of days debating whether to get the ae2i's or the ae2's I decided to go with the ae2s because I was not paying for a microphone for 30 dollars and I'm pretty sure u can just buy the cable.  Well anyways the sound is amazing!!  The first time I ever put them on I swear I had an eargasm and don't even get me started on the comfort after 10 minutes of having them on u will forget they were even there.  Oh and even though they don't say they are noise cancelling when u have the volume at 50 percent u can barely hear anything else.  These are the best pair of headphones I have ever had hands down
summary: way better than beats by dre solo or studios

The LP240 is well-built, and offers a decent set of features. The vertical tracking adjustment makes it easy to set up for a variety of different cartridges. Tracking force and anti-skating adjustments are easily accomplished. A holder for a spare headshell (sold separately) and a 45 rpm adapter (included) are nice touches. Although the unit has a strobe, the speed is not adjustable. It has a built-in preamp, which can be toggled on and off using a switch on the back of the base. This is handy if you're using an amplifier or receiver without a phono input. A USB port is also included for connection to a PC. As with most turntables, stylus overhang adjustment is the most difficult part of the setup. There are several good web sites describing the procedure, so if you're in doubt just do a web search. Note that the LP240 doesn't come with a cartridge, so you'll need to choose one yourself. I'm currently using an old Shure V15 Type IV (out of production) with a new stylus, and it sounds pretty good on my audio system. Take a look at the Shure M97xE. It's a great cartridge for about $80-90.I have mixed feelings about this turntable, because I wanted a multi-purpose deck - one with a USB output so I could bypass my PC sound card when digitizing some LPs, but also good enough quality to use on my audio system. The specs on the unit are just OK, but I was willing to live with that to get USB. However, I've been disappointed; I was unable to get enough signal from the USB port to make good recordings. I also can't get sufficient output from the analog outputs when I connect to the Line In on my PC. I even tried using a USB sound card with the analog connections, but simply can't get a strong signal. (I have had success with an old Sanyo TT, so I have to suspect the LP240.) The only way I was able to make recordings was by using the Mic In port on the PC, and setting the input level to max. I haven't heard of anyone else with this problem though.For everyday use, the LP240 has decent sound. My main turntable is a Technics SL-1200 MK3D, which definitely sounds better than the Audio Technica. I have no doubt that Amazon would have allowed me to return the LP 240, but I decided to keep it. It's a good quality piece of equipment, and it should last a long time. So it'll make a nice backup, and gives me a place to play some LPs that aren't in the best shape. If you're looking for something around $500 to use as your primary turntable, shop around and compare - you might just settle on the AT LP240.

I bought this to use at times when I don't particularly need speed. I was quite surprised as how effective it works for this purpose. I certainly can't expect the buffer to drop when taking a burst of raw images, but it works quite well none the less.Here's a speed test through the CF converter and by itself with a Philips 32GB Class 10 SHDC card done via ubuntu disk read/write benchmark:CF converter:Min Read: 14.5  Min Write: 1.6Max Read: 14.7  Max Write: 5.1Avg Read: 14.7  Avg Write: 3.4By itself:Min Read: 16.8  Min Write: 2.3Max Read: 21.3  Max Write: 12.2Avg Read: 21.1  Avg Write: 3.9As you see, the average write speed isn't even really much lower. It's hard for me to tell a difference when using a comparable CF card. I love it!

These bookshelf speakers are amazing. For the price, I have not ever heard such definition in music. These make lossless audio through a decent DAC sound incredible. There are lenty of other expensive bookshelf speakers from other companies that could never touch the definition that these provide. I ahve them wall mounted and angled slightly downwards and the soundstage is detailed and realistic, the speaker location is unknown to me while listening. A pair of these will produce a wall of sound. They are unable to profuce frequencies below 80 Hz, so make sure to pair them with a good subwoofer that is able to roll up to around 100Hz. A nice 8" sub will do nicely. I paired these with the Energy ESW-M8 and it provides all of the missing frequencies like a natural crossover.Excellent, excellent, excellent speakers. If I could rate these 10/5 I would. They are quite possibly the best speakers I have ever owned, and I have owned much more expensive speakers in my day. These blow them all out of the water for a small listening room application. A friend of mine saw one with the dust screen off and said "they look like little bears... how do those little bears make so much noise?" I will post a picture of the speaker overlaid with the bear so you can see what he was talking about. :)

reviewText: Just as a number of other purchasers have mentioned, this card seems to fail (so far only once in my case, but far more frequently for other people), particularly in Android phones. I'm using a Galaxy S 2 from AT&T; (so, the i777 version) and my card was force-wiped this morning. No issues to indicate a failure would happen - no dropping the phone, no exposing it to water, nothing. It just decided to stop working (or Android is mis-diagnosing the card, but who can tell).I've wiped the card using Android's format option, but I don't think that has accomplished much other than getting rid of my files. It occurred too quickly for me to believe it's doing a proper wipe and locating bad sectors. I don't know whether the flash file system stores things in a special way, but my guess is that it didn't actually do a full format.Bottom line, do what other people are saying and buy a slightly slower card, you're most likely not going to use the 1080p recording option as often as you think you are. The high speed isn't worth the hit in reliability.Other notes: The reader is flimsy-ish, but works as advertised. Keep the packaging around if you do buy the card and are forced to call Lexar for customer support. Based on the other reviews and comments though, you're not going to get a refund, only an exchange at best.EDIT: Got home in the evening, the computer could read it. Added a tonne of music, spent a couple of hours doing that. Eject, load into phone... and, dead again. Put it back into the card reader to check that the computer can still read it, and it can't. Absolute rubbish, this device.
summary: SD Card errors in my Galaxy S 2.

reviewText: I had been on the fence for a long time before deciding to get a Drobo. On the one hand, Data Robotic's products seem to be very popular among professional photographers, but on the other hand I was put off by so many one-star user reviews here on Amazon warning of lost data due to the performance of their Drobo. But, I can report that after purchasing my Drobo S nearly six months ago it has worked brilliantly for me every day. The only trouble I've had was with a USB 3 adapter that would sometimes interfere with the Drobo at startup. Sometimes my PC would hang either at start-up or shut-down until I switched off the Drobo. It was not a serious problem, but annoying enough for me to experiment with replacing my adapter. After replacing the USB 3 adapter with a superior Western Digital model, the problems have been vanquished. This speaks to the fact that for a Drobo S to perform best it needs quality companion components.The Drobo S has a power-saving mode that puts it to sleep if it's not actively being used. This is nice, but it can be slightly frustrating during times of frenetic production to wait a few seconds while it re-awakens when you're trying to access the data. But, I'm happy with the trade-off (energy-savings), so no complaint about that. Another very slight negative is the fan noise. It is not loud and it is a pleasant-enough white noise, but it's noise nonetheless. I would prefer a quieter solution.Quality Western Digital drives were purchased for use in my Drobo S, and this has proved an excellent choice as well. Based on my experiences thus far, I am happy to recommend the Drobo S for those, like me, who need an easy-to-use scalable digital content storage solution. My Drobo S works perfectly on my Windows 7 64 bit PC.
summary: Drobo S: It Works as Advertised!

Pros: It's reasonably priced and it looks cool. You'll get lots of comments on it.Cons: It barely fits - it's too big for the Ipod Touch 4 (but not quite big enough for any model of Iphones - I checked with a few friends'). If you put it in your pocket, the case will most likely fall off. There's no hole for charging. I took an exacto knife and sliced myself a hole, but honestly it would be easier to just pop the case off and on when you need to charge. (The case is so loose it's not a problem). The part of the case over the volume buttons and the "sleep" button are ill-fitting and don't feel like they're at the right angle to easily push the buttons. (the buttons are at a sloped angle on the device itself, and the plastic buttons that go over them are not)All in all, get this only if you're determined to have a cassette-looking case. If you actually value form or function, look elsewhere!
