We ordered two of these for our laptops, so we could have two locations setup to use for work without having to move power cords.  These are labeled as genuine Dell power supplies, and while one of them worked great the other one was DOA.  These supplies have a blue LED light near the end of the cable to indicate power, and when I plugged it in that LED light came on, then went out after a few seconds before even plugging in the laptop, and never came back on.  The other one has worked fine.We returned the defective one and the replacement is also working fine.  One thing I noticed is that when I put this power supply in place, the brick was near my LCD monitor, and it created flicker and scrolling interference lines.  My original Dell power supply brick had sat in the same location and did not create interference.The brick in this power supply is much thinner and lighter than the one that came with my laptop, so it may be that it is just less shielded by design. I was able to reorient the location of the brick to eliminate the interference.  However, I wanted to point out that this thinner, lighter power supply also appears to throw out more interference.  Note that I validated the interference with the second power supply, which did the same thing, so it was not a one-off issue.However, all in all I recommend these power supplies.  They are genuine Dell, and although returning one was a hassle, they were still significantly cheaper than buying from Dell.
summary: Genuine Dell power supply, but one of two ordered was DOA

reviewText: I had to drill out the terminals for the connection that went to the battery and the connection that went to the ground, and I used an aftermarket battery post specifically made for installing aftermarket equipment. The ground wire provided is a little short (my fault for not checking the specs). The 4ga wire seemed more like 6 ga as well (My 5ga scosche kit had more copper in it than this did). Overall, I'd probably buy it again for the price, but I wouldnt say it's fantastic. You may want to get a different kit if installing into an SUV, as i had to extend the remote wire to make it reach.

From the initial impression of this keyboard:1. Well made.2. Has everything you need to connect to your computer.3. Cherry red switch really does not assert a lot of force to actuate the key, very fluid.4. good full size key layout.I never get the chance to really use it, after unboxed the keyboard and made the above observation, I plugged in the keyboard to my system and power up, three indicator lights stayed on after the boot, the keyboard did not respond to key pressed, I reboot the system one more time, same thing.To rule out other possibility, I changed to another PC, same thing, I even tried a note book, nothing happened, I am pretty sure this keyboard is dead on arrival, packed it up yesterday and send back to Amazon. Disappointed.I ordered a Cooler Master mechanical keyboard instead. It is the same Cherry red switch, received it from Amazon. it is working fine with my PC.
summary: Open the box and it is DOA

reviewText: I bought this cable to get my Pentax AF201Sa flash off my Pentax K-x camera.  I use it with a DIY flash bracket and the whole package works great.  I didn't lose any function of the flash and it works just like it did when it's mounted to the camera hot shoe.  The cable is of high quality.  Others have written the cord doesn't stretch too well and that's true.  For now I'm not worried about that feature so not a big deal.  The unit locks securely to the camera hot shoe and the other end mounts solid using the 1/4-20 tripod connection and the flash slides nicely and is secure.  Love it.  Arrived in just a few days to WA State in good shape.Follow-up - I've had the cable for a week or more and it's working out great.  Initially the cable fit was a little tight on the camera hot shoe, but now it slides off much easier.  The quality of the cable and it's plastic hot shoe pieces is top notch.  I made a good choice buying this cable.

The Kodak PlayFull HD Video Camera is a nice, compact mini-video recorder. Advantages include a good design and an elegant, small form factor. Picture quality is decent. If you are buying this camera, make sure you have an SD card, because otherwise you get exactly 8 seconds worth of onboard memory. Although the memory is replaceable, the battery, unlike the Flip, is not.If you want a dedicated mini-video camera, the Kodak PlayFull is a good bet. But, if you own an Iphone, you already have a camera just as good as this. Do you really want to lug another device? On the other other hand, the Iphone's battery is not great. If you need to record your kid's soccer game but don't want to have your phone die, maybe you do want one of these guys. Think about your needs.Recommended with caveats.
summary: A decent form factor and recording quality but perhaps obsolete

reviewText: Used this in my D600.... I shot/video a 4hr long Cheerleader Competition and it was nice not having to worry about keeping batteries charged.
I use this micro SD memory card with the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0. It works flawless and the price is fantastic - it can't be beat anywhere.

This fits perfect my  Nikon D5100, I bought a BlackRapid Rs7 instead of carryspeed strap, but this mount works better than the atachment of BR, so in combination with my BR its perfect, Ilove this Mounting plate, because1.- you can use a tripod instantly2.- it balances better my camaera in my hip3.- If u can see in the photo, there is a little extended hole where you can tie up a cord, and then tue that cord to the camera, so it is more safety, just incase the tripod mount fails
Was looking for a Blu-ray 3D  and found this- at a very good price. Very easy set up and works without problems.  Would recommend!

I received this monitor today and had it set up in 15 minutes or so. Mine actually came from Amazon and arrived just as expected.  Packaging was perfect.  Picture quality is wonderful.  This is just what I was looking for and is well worth the price.  I'm not a computer expert so I can't give a technical comparison but I can say I am very pleased with this monitor!

I've had this monitor for a few days now and didn't come across anyone mentioning the auto switching inputs upon either HDMI and DVI devices turned on. I mean if I turn off my PS3 and Xbox the monitor sets it self to sleep VIA HDMI!!! Unlike my Asus VH242H. With the Asus it would stay on, with a blue screen and never turn off unless you get up and turn it off manually. I'm lazy so if I'm in bed I'd have to get up before I went to sleep unless I wanted the sky lighting up my room. The Asus went to sleep with DVI which was fine but just wanted to let you know this HP monitor sleeps on HDMI. Also if the monitor is sleeping with no devices turn on, the monitor will auto switch inputs if you turn on your PS3 or PC so you don't have to press any buttons. It does it automatically for you. The screen is WIDE! and very nice.That's about the only pros I have with this monitor. Here we go with the Cons.You can only set one custom video settings. So if you like multiple settings for either gaming, movies, photo editing then you'll have to go in the menu and change the settings each time you switch from movie to gaming or to photo editing. It's not difficult but for a $300 monitor you should be able to change default settings and save them under their names. The Asus was able to do that and it's half the price.There is no saturation setting. The monitor gives you a "color" option which is just setting the warmness of the monitor. Either it be standard (6500k), RGB (customizable), warm (5000k), and cool (9300k). The colors of the monitor are very flat and not vibrant/vivid which I prefer.The blacks are more black, the whites are more white then my Asus but I prefer the Asus blacks because they're lighter. You can see different shades of blacks better on clothing in movies, and objects in shadows in video games. You can notice it in Minecraft inside the ground with no lighting. You can see better in the dark with the Asus.The backlight bleeding is outrageous. I put the brightness down to 20% and the bleeding never goes away. The left side and bottom are the worse. The entire screen is hazey in pitch black scenery. Say if a video transitions from a commercial back to the program, that 3 seconds of black are grey. Happens on everything I watch. Sometimes it looks dark blue to purple if it's black long enough.Follow up: I set the Dynamic Contrast Ratio to on (really should be off at least on hdtv's) but the way this works is once the screen shows a darker image, the monitor dims down. This helps tremendously on the backlight bleeding. Reminds me of the HX800 I had that would dim down also.

I don't understand the good reviews. After about 3 weeks of use this stylus does not work. When using Penultimate it misses strokes too often to be of any help at all. Very frustrating to be with a client taking notes and have this stylus completely fail. So I'm off to try another brand....

Get yourself a pencil with an eraser.  It will serve the purpose a whole lot cheaper and be useful in other ways.The thing comes with a lanyard and a fob but no way to fasten it to the Kindle.  It'll be lost within a week and I will replace it with a yellow Eberhard-Faber #2 with eraser.  Live and learn.

reviewText: Got this in hopes that I could use it with my Kindle Fire for apps and games.  It works well.  I even have an anti glare screen cover on the Fire, and the stylus still works well.  It isn't perfect, but I cannot imagine anything will be.  It lags a tiny bit occasionally, but nothing that isn't tolerable, and it isn't any worse than lag with using your finger on the screen.  I would recommend this product to Kindle Fire users.
This card works great with Windows 7!However, there was no software available that would let me use it when I upgraded to Windows 8!Western Digital SuperSpeed USB 3.0 PCI Express (PCIe) Card
summary: Western Digital SuperSpeed USB 3.0 PCI Express (PCIe) Card

reviewText: I bought this case along with a power supply that was deeper than 140mm and a optical drive..  Big mistake.  Should have read the reviews to save me return shipping costs on the initial PSU I bought for this case.The case is great, it's small and fit's a microATX motherboard and a ATX power supply.  If you plan on installing a optical drive, make sure you buy a 140mm deep power supply, it states in clearly in the case manual, unfortunately I didn't see the manual before I purchased everything.  If you think you're going to find a modular PSU that's 140mm, think again.  You have to buy a 140mm PSU which means you're going to have to find places in this case to store all the extra un-used power connectors.  I shoved them all under the optical drive.  It's a tight fit, but if you route all the other cables nicely, you can still get good air flow by buying 4 80mm CoolerMaster fans as outlined in some of the user pictures that were uploaded.Great case overall, just wish it was 3 inches deeper to allow for a modular power supply.
summary: Nice HTPC case, beware the power supply size requirements!

reviewText: This thing was fabulous while it worked. It dropped signal a couple of times but nothing that unplugging/replugging in didn't fix. Unfortunately, the return window (through Amazon)expired today and it just so happens that as I was leaving for a road trip it quit working entirely. It's not communicating with the radio OR the application. It still has a pretty blue light but yeah not what I bought it for.Update #1 - New Potato has a one year warranty on their products so once I am home from my road trip I will contact them and exchange the defective equipment.Update #2 - Contacting the company was quick and painless as was getting a replacement once I sent them the defective unit. The last unit worked for  month so I can't really judge the new one until that time has passed but so far so good. At the very least, New Potato is great.Update #3 (November 2012) - In the last month I've no longer needed this but it still works all this time later.
summary: Stopped working (updates at the bottom of review)

reviewText: I'm completely impressed with this viewfinder.  Solidly built and snaps onto a frame which sticks to your LCD.  [No magnets!].  Very little distortion. Gives another point of stability when shooting. Works well with my Zacuto Target Shooter rig. Highly recommend this for a 5D mk2.

Quality of video from PC to TV using this device was poor.  I had to return it.  Wanted to make it work, did not want to run wires,  but finally ended up running DVI and sound cables from PC to TV, that worked fine and we got video quality on TV same as on PC screen.
summary: Warpia StreamHD Wireless PC to TV

reviewText: The Quirky Cordies Cable Management is the perfect solution to a common problem. With so many chargers and cables, it can be a mess to keep everything on a desk when not plugged in.I have a media cabinet that I park my laptop, iPad, Kindle, and iPhones on when charging. I have 5 or 6 wires and an ethernet cable that need to be accessed on top of the cabinet, but I don't want them falling behind easily. I have used stick on clasps to hold the wires, but it can be a bother when I want to pull a cable out to take with me, or leave plugged in while I use a device, also 4 or 5 clips don't look to pleasant all together with wires hanging out of them.This is perfect for this. I can slide the wires into it and keep them from sliding when not in use, but if I want one free it slides right out of the top of it. It has a heavy counterweight on the bottom of it, so you don't need to use adhesive and you can pack it up and take with you if you need to.
summary: Clever solution to a common problem.

reviewText: Lofteck CXS 2200 is a great product for its price.  The image quality of this IP Cam is acceptable. Installation was easy. I was able to setup LAN,WAN, and Email alert in less than 4 hours. I already ordered another one (3200 Model). So far, I am very happy with this Loftek CXS 2200.
This cable works perfectly with our 2011 Hyundai Sonata.  Hyundai wants $35 for the same things.  Don't waste your money.

I waited to write a review on this for many months. The reason why is that for what this device has to do it does a good job. Trying to draw on an iPad really requires something like this. And from what I hear and read many of these types of stylus fall apart. This one has served me well since I bought it. And for the price you'd think otherwise. Not so. This stylus lasts. But...I recently bought a Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 which has a regular WACOM style stylus. If you still have an iPad, you need a stylus like this one and this is the one I'd recommend. But if drawing is important to you, I'd drop the iPad and get the Galaxy Note 10.0" which comes with a proper stylus. I can finally draw without zooming in and out to gain precision that the stylus lacks. Blame Steve Jobs for that as he seems to hate the idea of a stylus. But everyone in the art world lives and breaths with a stylus in the hands. I've been lusting after the Cintiq 24" HD tablet since it came out.I think for artist types there are few good products out there for us. Cintiq is obviously one of them. The Galaxy Note 10.1 just became another. Thank you rooCASE, you've been great but I've finally found a proper system.
summary: Okay, but I have moved on

reviewText: A very nice looking charger, and it works great too. My old charger stopped working so I got this one and it works perfect.Edit 12/28/2012So a few months ago the charger started acting and it turned out the wiring inside got messed up. This is not a charger worth getting, I highly recommend the Anker Golden Slim & Multi-function AC Adapter. It works much better, does not get hot, looks much nicer, and much thinner to fit in places easily.
summary: WORKS GREAT WITH N5010, does not last long

reviewText: I have been buying internet camera systems for years beginning with firewire cameras hooked up to computers to baby monitors to the VueZone system.  This system is incredible, particularly for the price.The system is great because:1) It just works.  People say this about Apple products all of the time, but it is absolutely true of the system.  10-20 minutes of setup, and I had great cameras.2) The batteries last forever.  I have used these for almost six months and the battery levels are not even down one bar.  This is phenomenal for a wireless system.  I was afraid that the batteries would die all of the time; they don't.3) The picture quality is amazing for the size of the camera.4) The clever magnetic attachment system makes these work anywhere.  I have a few fixed places, but I attached one to a GorillaPod, and I can do anything with these small, lightweight cameras.  I have even hung them upside down and the magnets are much stronger than gravity.5) They have never crashed or been unavailable.  I have had zero down time in nearly six months.In short, they are excellent. I will note that I have never used the motion detection feature (except as a quick test the day I bought the system), so I cannot speak to its effectiveness or its effect on battery life.If you need a system for keeping an eye on things or to see in a blind entry way or watching a sleeping child while doing yard work, this is an excellent system.  I am sure that it would work as a pet or nanny cam too.
I purchased this for skype and I gotta say it's amazing so far and I havent even tried out the software yet.
summary: crystal clear video and audio for chatting

reviewText: Awesome speakers. I'm no audiophile but I know good sound when I hear it. I have the Klipsch Quintet SL Series surround package which sounds great. I also have the BicF12 subwoofer which I also highly recommend. I just wanted to step up the sound to the next level but didn't want to spend a fortune. When I saw the VF-36's on sale for $198.00 I jumped on it. Wow! What a difference! I love the sound of the Quintet SL's but these just put those to shame. I knew that the VF-36's would sound better but I did not expect this big of a difference. I replaced the rear double speaker SL's (1 woofer; 1 tweeter) with the front triple speaker SL's (2 woofer; 1 tweeter) and put the VF-36's up front. I have a mid-range Yamaha RX-V467 5.1 receiver (which I also love) and the sound is outstanding. You could almost get away with not having a sub with these VF-36's if you are on a tight budget. The sub does give it that extra punch though. More important though is that the F36's just have a beautiful, crystal clear, clean sound to them. The treble is outstanding. I could clearly hear the tambourine in a song that I could not hear at all with SL's. They are very heavy and quite attractive as well. Only complaint is that the cover cannot be removed. The top cover for the tweeter is magnetic and can be removed but not the cover for the bottom. This seems strange for such a high end speaker. Overall, Highly recommended if you can get them anywhere near the price that I paid. By the way, I got the free standard shipping from Vann's and got them Overnight! Outstanding!

This is a great little zippered, padded nylon storage case / bag with a zippered outer pocket & a little carabiner attached via a fabric loop at the top.  At this price, think "outside the box (case!)" regarding the uses for such a nice little protective case.  Yes, it is small (the external dimensions are about 4.5" x 3" x 1"), so only the smallest of cameras will fit into it.  But, think of other uses - at this low price, I got one for my iPhone 5's rechargers (NOT the iPhone 5 itself!).  In the bigger, main compartment, I can squeeze in a 12V USB car charger, the Apple AC charger, and an Apple Ligntning to USB cable.  Then, in the small outer zipped pocket, I can slip in the Apple EarPods that came with my iPhone.Really, this little bag / case could be used for many small electronic devices or their accessories that you want to protect and, in the case of accessories, keep together...

I received this camera for Christmas, and so far I'm really happy with it.  My previous digital camera, an Olympus, wasn't bad, but it had a few faults that this one doesn't.  This camera is thin and very portable, more so than my Olympus.  It comes with it's own rechargable battery, which is better than my old Olympus which used AA's like they were going out of style.  I've recharged the battery once since I got it, and though I have used it, I didn't think I'd used it enough to require a battery recharge, so I will be getting a spare battery before I travel with it.  It's got a good zoom.  The picture quality is excellent.  I can even go in and change the size that I want the picture to be, which helps me be able to store more pictures on a memory card.  It's pretty easy to use, which is always a plus.  All in all, despite the battery (which I don't consider a downfall after all the AA's I went through with my last camera), I would totally recommend this camera.  Though, I hate to say this on here, I would recommend getting it somewhere else, cause the prices on here are higher than most stores sell it for.

I have been playing with my new Asus Transformer Infinity TF700 Android (Jelly Bean 4.1.1) Tablet for about a month now and love it. I love the 4 row on-screen keyboard that includes number keys always present in the main mode. It makes entering data and phone numbers much easier than on my 3 row Ipad.But when I write a longer email or memo, I still long for a real keyboard. Hence, I began a search for a reasonably priced, well rated, lightweight travel keyboard that I might use occasionally. I devoted the better part of a Sunday afternoon to surfing the web looking for alternatives. I looked at many Bluetooth keyboards and folio case combinations, but they were too bulky and/or too expensive to meet my goal. But, after a while, I began to notice an interesting keyboard that went by several names at several prices, but appeared to be the same device. I even found a Youtube video showing someone installing and using it. [...]The reviews I read about it were favorable by a large percentage. Best of all, it was under $20 and available from Amazon. (I usually find that when something is on Amazon and has accumulated a few dozen favorable reviews over a period of months, that there is a good chance that it is not a shoddy product.) Anyway, at under $20 delivered, it was worth taking a chance.This keyboard is sold under various names including Sanoxy and Anker. Mine was advertised as a Sanoxy Blutooth Keyboard for Ipad - at a cost of $13.50. (I have seen it advertised for over $30 on some sites.) The box it came in had nether name, but it was the same device. The unit is all plastic, but looks and feels like a much, much higher priced Apple keyboard. It is advertised to have Apple function keys, but I did not test those, since my plan was to use it for my Android tablet.The keyboard arrived in about 3 days, and worked with my Android tablet directly out of the box. It runs on 2 AAA cells, which I prefer, since I did not want to have to discipline myself to recharge yet another device. (We shall see how long the batteries last, but at least it is easy to carry or buy spares.) The battery box underneath at the rear provides a nice wedge to hold the keyboard at a good typing angle.The unit arrived with no instructions, but I just followed the general Bluetooth mating steps for other devices, and it worked fine. (Especially after I remembered to un-mate the Android Tablet from another Bluetooth folio keyboard I have first!)  The keys are well spaced and have a very nice feel to them, with a silent click and a satisfying displacement. They work about as well as my main home computer keyboard. I would say that typing a several page memo on this would not be a chore at all. However, since the on-screen tablet keyboard is quite good for a few sentences of email, this unit will stay in my suitcase most of the time, only coming out when there is a lot of typing to do.Once the unit automatically mates with the tablet (takes a second or two), it is very response and follows my typing well. Some of the function keys (meant for Apple) also work on the Android tablet (e.g. home, media player controls, sleep). Others are still a mystery. As you can see from the Youtube video mentioned above, this keyboard can also mate with a phone.I just returned from a trip in which the keyboard (in the small but sturdy cardboard box that it comes packed in) bounced around various airplanes and waiting rooms for a week. Before writing this review, I just turned it on to check, and it mated and worked perfectly.I would say that this is a superb product, especially at the price,and can recommend it highly.

UPDATE TO REVIEW BELOW:  I gave these a second (and third) chance by trying out 6 different type of rubber tips for them for my ears.  Meaning, to try to get a decent seal, I tried these with 6 additional brands of tips for ear buds, including some that fit me well on other models of ear buds I have.  These "phones" are just not worth $50 much less $250 (what I paid). I wish I was able to return them.  There is no dimension on which I'd recommend these. See point number 1 below for problems getting a good seal, including with all these other tips I have tried.* * *I have tried many brands of ear buds. I have a number of nice headphones (cans) as well, including the Bose top of the line noise canceling unit.  But that is so bulky to carry along on the plane that I finally decided to try some serious brand ear buds with noise canceling. Since sound is a matter of personal taste, I should note that I like clean, full sound that includes excellent bass response.  The latter is very important to me. So, if that is true of you, keep that in mind.1.  With ear buds like this, everything about sound quality is about if the rubber pieces seal your ear canal well. I could not find a combination of the included ones that sealed my ear canals ideally well. Part of the issue with these is that the stem that the rubber parts fit onto do not  extend as far out from the bulky part of the bud as other brands, and since the bulky part is, well, bulky, one cannot get these as well seated into the canal as ANY other type of sealing type bud I've ever tried.2. Partly as a function of the seal, but I think for additional reasons (you can tell what the sound would be if sealed great by pressing on them and listening a bit), I could not get very good base response out of these even when forcing the seal to be good.3. Again, partly as a function of the seal, but again, additional to it, I think (same test as above), the sound canceling ability of these is really low quality.  Inadequate. I have other ear buds of similar design that are not noise canceling and they block out more sound than these do.Summary. For me, a poorly performing, expensive set of ear buds from a solid company. Totally disappointing for me, anyway. The sound is not remotely as good as the Bose noise canceling cans. I'm back to thinking I just need to bite the bullet and carry more bulk and weight on airplanes. These Senn buds don't cut it for me. They sound no better and are not quieter than the $30 buds I got at Brookstone.  They sound far worse and do not suppress noise as well as the passive noise suppressing Klipsch model Si4.
summary: Lousy bass, and not because of difficulty sealing canal

reviewText: Very disappointed. Case does not fit iPad 2. Doesn't hold it in place, iPad is falling out the case. Definitelly I am returning it.

There's a lot of good functionality built into this unit.  It has pretty much the widest variety of connectors that I've seen on any cable tester.  There are two of each connector:  for each pair one is an "output" and one is an "input" connector.  Output connectors transmit a funny digital test signal, and the input connectors detect this signal and display the results (of which pins on one end of the cable are attached to which pins on the other) on the LED matrix.  You attach one end of a cable to any output connector and the other end to any input connector -- so you can have different connectors on each end of the cord.o You can test a cable with different connectors on the ends.o There is a row of "intermittent" LEDs next to the matrix.  You connect a cable, press the reset button, the wiggle the cable.  If any of the wires are intermittent the corresponding LED will light.  You can repeat this at will to track down a problem spot.o There is a built-in tone generator.  It generates a reasonably clean squarewave at either 440 or 1,000 Hz.  There's a slide switch that selects one of three volume levels, but the output levels are not quite correct:  The peak-to-peak output levels are: "-50MIC"=> 280mV (I think about 28mV would be more realistic),  "-10dBV => 3.0V (should be 0.9V), +4dBu => 3.2V (this is about right).o There is a way to test for shorts in a cable.o There is a way to test cables where the far end can't be plugged into the tester:  you short pins on the other end then test for shorts.o The two pins on the side labeled "SPEAKON" are banana jacks, but are not the standard 3/4" apart so can't be used for testing dual banana plugs.o The LED matrix can only test three pins at a time.  So if you are testing a cable with a plug that has more than three pins (e.g a MIDI or an ethernet plug) then there's a workaround:  The mysterious slide switch that is not described in the manual and whose positions are labeled "SW1", "SW2" and "SW3" is used for this.  The first position lets you test the first three pins of a connector, the second position lets you test the second three pins, and the third position lets you test the third set of three pins.o The LED matrix looks identical to the one on the Behringer CT100 cable tester.  The two units look identical except this one has way more connectors.  I can't believe but that they're the same design and made in the same factory, so I'd buy this one because it tests more connector types.o The instructions (which are printed on the box) don't mention that you need to install two AA batteries.o The box is painted steel, made with reasonable precision, with some scuff marks.  The PC boards inside are clean and well-soldered.  There are some mechanical hacks in the construction:  for example some of the connectors have plastic parts crudely trimmed off to fit, and the sliders of the slide switches have been partly clipped off to make them fit through the narrow, short slots through which they protrude.  I get the impression of these being built by a garage-type operation, but none of these things looks like they would affect reliability or longevity.  I'm confident this will be a rugged and long-lasting tool.
summary: A good, capable, inexpensive cable tester

reviewText: I've used this camera on Skype a few times, it works great.  I don't think there's a zoom function, but the mic works from a few feet away and the cam quality is decent.  Can't go wrong for $5.

This is a nice sized little pocket camera that has some features that are desirable such as an optical view finder and the ability to run on AA batteries.  I bought it as a backup for my wife to take to England but because of the problems she had with it it never got used.  It constantly required batteries after taking only 4 - 6 pictures.  I tried batteries out of different packages and by different manufactuers to no avail.  Canon agreed to fix/replace it under warranty but it's an additional $6.00+ to ship it to them so you might want to consider that as part of the cost.
summary: Nice little camera with major battery problems.

reviewText: We were looking to replace our Sony H55, which took great pictures but somehow the "review" button broke after the warranties elapsed. Shocking, no?  Anyway, we asked around, read reviews, watched CNET, etc., and the choices came down to a Nikon 9100 or the Sony HX9V.  Because the Nikon was (at the time) $70 cheaper and we had the button issue with the H55, we went with the Nikon.  That was a terrible choice.  We played with it for 3 days, and for every "decent to good" picture you took (great seemed like a pipe dream), you took 5 terrible shots.  It was jittery, it had issues with focal points, lighting...everything about it sucked.  We're pretty good photographers, so it was very frustrating and surprising.  We returned it and ordered the Sony.  In the week that passed, the Sony dropped $35, which was a pleasant surprise.  It came 2 days later, and it's been a dream ever since.  Portraits, back light, low light, full zoom, action, pets, aquarium...every picture, every setting, it's been awesome.  The auto scene selector just works, and there's very little you need to do in fiddling with it.  Just turn it on and go.  We haven't tried any video yet, so I can't comment on that.  One thing to be careful about, though, are batteries.  We bought it with the expectation of reusing our H55 batteries, because the H55 and the HX9V use the same battery.  However, the HX9V said the Delkin (decent brand, not a $3 knock-off) batteries we had weren't compatible.  That statement actually appeared on the LCD.  So, we're using the Sony battery that came with the H55 (that works, so I know it's not a form factor or voltage issue) and the Sony battery that came with the HX9V.  The Delkins are going to operate the H55, which we'll let the kids use.  We also bought a 3 year warranty because "fool me once..."
summary: We're loving the HX9V so far! Vastly superior to the Nikon 9100.

reviewText: Great camera with 16X zoom (optical) plus 4x digital capabilities. Excellent video's (full 1080p) and panoramic feature are all I could ask for. The background diffuser is a added program that does just what it says. Small enough to fit in the case logicCase Logic DCB-302 Compact  Case for Camera - Blackwith an extra pocket for second battery, that you probably will need for extended shooting. Pair that with the Transend class 10 memory cardTranscend 16GB Class 10 SDHC Card (TS16GSDHC10)and you'll not be disappointed.Pleasantly surprised with the image quality but not being able to shoot RAW is a minus. But what do you expect at this price?Overall, well worth the money and a real shooting pleasure for your next adventure. Check out some of the YouTube videos. This camera is a small and capable shooting "brick" that will amaze you.Sony Cyber-shot DSC-HX9V 16.2 MP Exmor R CMOS Digital Still Camera with 16x Optical Zoom G Lens, 3D Sweep Panorama and Full HD 1080/60p Video

This is a great deal.  I purchased this to replace the original batteries that were only lasting about 20-30 minutes.  I'm on conference calls all day and rotate between three cordless phones located throughout the house.  These new batteries were an exact match for the originals.  They fit perfectly with no wiggle.They last 3.5+ hours on speaker phone.  You can't ask for any better than that.  I've been using them for a month with no issues.  I would highly recommend this to anyone looking to avoid the cost of the manufacturer batteries.
summary: A great replacement for the original battery

reviewText: Since the first tablets came out three years ago, have not been a fan on typing in the same surface where the screen is (like the HPs Touch Screens) as your arms and fingers get tired, so had not been too interested in one.  Nevertheless, as I have been following up the tablets and due to a sale on the Internet, ordered a Refurbished Thrive for a very inexpensive price.  It is a 32 GB model with the Tegra Dual Processor and all the thrills characteristic of the Toshiba brand.The Thrive is not the Tablet that Anne Hathaway will bring to the Manhattan office (if The Devil Wears Prada was filmed in 2012) but it's more a tablet that would be used in Iron Man or The Transformers.  It is heavier and bulkier than the Samsung Galaxys and the Ipads (due to the expansion capabilities) and replaceable back cover.  But it looks Avatar alike.The main reason I selected a Thrive vs the well rated Motorola and Asus counterparts was the expansion capacities.  These Thrive Tablets have things used commonly with other electronic devices; USB, Mini-USB, SD, HDMI, replaceable battery and a regular jack for charging, unlike the Ipads which use "proprietary everything" and accept nothing.  Even though I have had this device for a week only, have found some surprising positive features and decided to write this preliminary review.Have been running some tests and here are the initial results.  Battery life with Google Maps, the GPS on and some movie playing is from six to seven hours.  Recharge time is two hours with the factory charger.  The Wi-Fi connects immediately to the Router I use and the Honeycomb (3.2) Android system which is very simple to use as have had a Droid phone for over a year.  The Android Marketplace has now been replaced by Google Plus and the software provided by Toshiba has been surprisingly good.All the applications downloaded work on the Thrive although some (used on the phones) vary considerably when used in these larger devices.  Many of these are similar or identical to their counterparts in the OS Systems but limitations exist.  As of now, the most surprising thing has been the Toshiba Multimedia Player.  There has not been the need to install supplemental VLC or Real Players as the Toshiba does everything in an unanticipated way.Unlike other devices such as the Apple products, the Toshiba Player does play videos in multiple formats, including the classic Audio Video Interleave; AVI that dates from the beginnings of Windows in the early nineties.  This video format allows you to record and watch movies up to an extremely small compression factor and the Thrive plays them like the Creative Zens do, perfectly.The Zens were manufactured by Creative Labs from 2005 to 2007 and unlike the Zune and Ipods, they play every format you may want to record.  AVIs take grossly one fifth the space comparable to other formats.  Thus in a 32 GBs SD card you can store five times the number of movies you may store in an Ipod or Zune.  You will not have aspect / ratio issues as the Toshiba systems compensates for that as does in the Zens.The Thrives audio consists of two mini speakers on the bottom (if placed horizontally/landscape) which have a half an inch aperture on each side.  They can be loud but cannot reproduce the usual low frequencies from regular sized speakers.  But as there is a Bluetooth in these tablets, an external auxiliary larger speaker might help with the lack of bass.Internet capabilities are the typical Google ones; just start typing and you will get it.  MS-Word is being replaced by Google Docs but free software of "Documents to Go" allows you to access al Office features as long as they have been saved in the system.  Skype works perfectly but the tablet cameras are not the best.So far I am satisfied with my new toy and continue experimenting with video compression to evaluate how much can I load into a 32 or 64 GB card.  But, thinking of overriding the Honeycomb System and installing the Ice Cream one in the next month or so.  Let's see how it goes; more to come.  Meanwhile, do not dare to try new things with your Thrive.
Purchased this when my old card did not work with Win 8 upgrade.  Running on an old HP media center system, win 8, 300W power supply.

I got this to use with game lofts N.O.V.A games, but it didn't hit the on screen control pad correctly and out had the nasty habit of sliding when extra pressure during exciting times was exerted on the controller.
summary: Not enough apps designed to use this

reviewText: It worked fine for about a month, but now the ends that connect to the phone has to be manipulated in some way(by wife) in order to work. So now we're back to basically sharing my original HTC data/charging cable. Guess I wasted my money there.
What can you say about a charger? It juices up the device in good time and doesn't catch fire. This one does and didn't.

Although this camera has great specs, I am not impressed with its ability to get focused when zoomed out.  I have taken numerous photos of stationary wildlife while zoomed out, but very few of them turned out to be acceptable.  Most of them were blurry.  I noticed that the camera was having trouble getting focused during the shots, so I tried to time the press of the shutter release to catch it in focus in the viewfinder.  That worked about 20% of the time.If the zoom is not used, then the camera takes good, even very good, photos, but it should work in zoom mode, also.I would not have purchased this camera had I known about the focusing issues while zoomed.  One of my other cameras is a Lumix.  No issues with that one.

I purchased this camera to replace my aging Powershot SD870IS, which I had been very pleased with. The 100 HS exceeded my expectations. After reading several reviews and looking at images taken by this camera on various photo sharing websites, I decided to jump in.I only had it for about a month when I purchased one as a gift for my mother. The pictures are sharp and show great detail especially in low light. Canon has simplified the controls on the back making it not only look less cluttered, but kept changing the many settings simple. There is plenty of control in manual mode for those who make use of it, and fun to be had with the scene modes. (Miniature Effect is a personal favorite.)But where this camera really shines in the the automatic mode. It is truly a great point and shoot when you want it to be.Pros -Great photosEasy to use/change modesOutstanding battery life, I shot for almost 3 weeks, including several minutes of HD video, on a single charge.Small enough to fit in a pocket, yet large enough to be usable by larger hands (like mine)Cons -One minor complaint: the lighter construction doesn't feel as sturdy as the heavier metal body on my 870 IS.All in all, a fantastic camera, great for everyone.

This camera is a great value for all the features you get with it. I bought this for my mother for her birthday and she loves it. It was very simple for her to learn to use, and she isn't very techy. This is only her second digital camera (the other was an old kodak for about 13 years ago). She had it for about 3 days and we went over and she already had figured out how to take pictures, review them, and delete them.It has a large screen, great resolution, zooms smoothly, and it was taking good pictures in a not so well lit room.
summary: Great price for what you get

reviewText: I have been a shutterbug for a longtime.I had a slr film camera with many accessories. Along came digital, so sold the camera and jumped into the digital era with the purchase of many compacts. I wanted more control(m,a,s,iso) so after research and knowing Canon this was my joice.  I am very happy with the purchase and am have fun with the various Modes.Would highly endorse this model for anyone as an entry level dslr.

I bought this camera primarily to use in a claymation class that I was taking.  I've used a dslr before (a Sony Alpha) so I'm fairly familiar with their controls and workflow.The Rebel T3 has an impressive range of functionality.  All the basic (and not so basic) manual controls, plus an option to take decent video (minus external microphone or many options).It worked fine for me for exactly one month, but now every time I try to take a picture I get "Err 30", which apparently means the shutter mechanism is toast.  We'll see how they do on doing a warranty repair, but it's disappointing that after such a short amount of usage there is a basic mechanism failure like that.  I'd say over that time I've taken maybe 300-400 pictures, and all in a nice controlled studio setting.Meanwhile, my Sony Alpha which I've had for quite a few years now continues to perform like a champ.

I love this camera!  It takes such great pics and has alot of scene modes and fun things to play with on it.  Picture quality is great too!  My husband is a professional photographer and he thinks this takes good pictures too.  This camera is perfect for me to carry around and get snapshots of my kids.  For a compact camera, this is a great buy!

Bought product for a long trip in USA. Set it up and all seemed fine. When I went to use it at the start of my journey in the States two days later it would not power up. I tried to charge it in the car thinking maybe it had lost charge. After 2 hours driving it would still not power up. It was totally dead. I did everything suggested in the handbook which basically gave no information at all. So I had to complete my 1500 mile journey using maps with no GPS that had been bought specifically for this particular journey. I really don't know why I bothered with buying it at all. on my return from the trip I emailed the supplier regarding the problem and was told to send it back complete in a way that I could track and then once they had checked everything was there they maybe able to send me a replacement. It cost me over $30 to send it back and as yet NOTHING has happened. I would not buy a TomTom again and I would not use the Amazon supplier concerned.

Did lots of research when I was in the market for a screen for my PC about a year ago.  Went with this one and have to say I've been impressed for the price I paid.  Haven't had any dead pixels or other annoying issues.  Overall a pretty solid monitor that looks great for basic browsing and watching videos online.  Colors are vivid and true and motion is not blurry. Has easy options for good calibration.The only cons I can think of:-As expected, the internal speakers SUCK.  Just turn them off and use your own setup.-All black screen is not as uniform as it should be.  This is hardly noticeable and only happens when the screen is all black.  Otherwise everything appears as it should.-Wish that the stand was adjustable.For the price of $170 and still having this monitor a year later without any issues gives it a 5 star rating.
summary: Purchased Over a Year Ago.  Still Works Great.

reviewText: I bought one of these and it works pretty well BUT, if you power down the other devices except one, it stops working.You have to leave at least two devices powered up for this thing to function.It draws power through the HDMI cables from the devices connected to it.  The TV set on the output side doesn't count, it's passive and provides no power backwards to the switch.I have a Dish network tuner, a HTPC system and an FTA satellite tuner connected to this thing, it then feeds into a 4x1 splitter (1 in, 4 out) to send video to TV's around the house.I don't want to leave the HTPC powered up all the time or the FTA tuner either.  Most of the time I just want the Dish tuner on.But if I turn the other machines off, the LED gets very dim and it ceases to pass the signal through.  Once you power up any other device, it comes back to life and works fine.It doesn't matter which ONE device is left powered up, none of them will power this device alone.They say it doesn't need an external power supply?  BS!!  If that's true then why is there a jack on the thing for external 5vdc ??  Hmmmmmmmm?????????My problem is, I can't find a 5vdc power adapter for this thing with a plug that tiny.  I don't have a clue what size plug that thing takes except it's tiny.The manufactures website has no information and they don't sell adapters for it that I can find.  The crummy instructions in Engrish have nothing of value in them either.I give it three stars because when you have two devices powered up, it works great.  I would give it 4 stars if they would of at least offered a power supply for it and not LIE that it doesn't need one or even tell you where you can buy one or what kind to search for.  And if they would have included a power supply for it I would have given it 5 stars for an excellent gadget.Good luck finding a power supply for this thing.  If you do, please post a link where you can get one.  A power supply should cost less than $5 including shipping.So be warned, it will not function at all if you power down other devices and leave only one device powered up.  That can be worked around by leaving two devices powered up at all times OR, if you're really lucky, you find an external power supply for it..
summary: Ok but has one glaring problem

reviewText: This product delivered exactly as it says it does.  It was so easy to install.  And I have some experience with trying to attach a touch screen protector.  This was a cinch and I can't believe no air bubbles either.  The little space that it leaves is really no issue.  I am glad that I did purchase this brand of protectors instead of another brand I was also thinking of trying.  Get it, you won't be disappointed.  By the way, I used this for my Kindle Touch and it looks great.  You can't even tell that I have one on.
Can't beat the price.  Very bright. Bought another light with better specs at the same time for more. The other one died and this one is still going.

I've had several systems, but I wanted to upgrade after I got my LG 3D setup. This system is great for people who aren't sound perfectionists. Yes, the sub is passive, but still gives a good kick. Setup is very easy. I have it in a mid-sized living room, but it might not be good for larger rooms. The HDMI pass-through works great as well. The sound from my PS3 and Blu-Ray is great, but remember, this isn't a $3000 Bose system. I had an Onkyo system before this, but it let me down, so I tried a Sony. Much, much better!

Was initially worried about this device based on the reviews, but with the review by A. Brooks saying there was an optimal configuration if you have any problems, I took the leap and bought it. I quickly got it setup and I am using component cabling because this old and cheap LCD doesn't have HDMI. I mainly bought this for streaming Netflix and playing DVDs in our bedroom. We have not had any problems like others have stated. I feel for the others, that is so frustrating when you buy a new device. I can't wait to hook it up to a HDMI TV with a BluRay disc. I do not know much about Network configuration, other than setting up home networks and configuring home routers, but I don't think DHCP would ever be a problem. It just dynamically assigns an IP to devices on the network vs. manually assigning one to a device. DNS could be a help, but again, I don't know too much about that. Not a do-it-for-a-living IT guy, but a code writer. For the money this device cannot be beaten (if it works for you). Good luck!
summary: Great so far, was worried but no WIFI problems

reviewText: [Unlike some reviewers, I'm loathe to condemn Insignia for a technology that did not live up to expectations.  Insignia tried to make some creative uses of HD radio that larger manufacturers like Sony and JBL completely ignored.  As the following reivew will reveal, there are two HD products made by Insignia that I've enjoyed and for which I've written positive reviews. This one is the aberrant "stinker" that every manufacturer--even Apple--has, no doubt with good intent, at some point inflicted upon the public.  To Insignia's credit, the HD02 was quickly discontinued by the company.]To the best of my knowledge, no manufacturer is currently making HD radios--not for distribution in the West, certainly.  Insignia may have been the last hold-out, and consequently anyone serious about a new HD radio probably has the best chance of picking one up by looking for left-over Best Buy stock.  Two Insignia products have proven their worth in my experience--either of which is infinitely superior to the pictured radio. The HD01 served me well before I discovered my favorite HD stations on an iPod app (below), and the Insignia Table-Top radio (the simplest, least expensive version, which was listed at 49.95 but is currently unavailable from Amazon) continues to be a convenient companion (it runs on AC or battery, requires no charging, has a telescoping rod antenna, has clear stereospeakers (weak bass), along with handy inputs and outputs. And it travels well--whether in a household or a flight bag).The pictured tuner (HD02) may be a step up from its predecessor--in terms of cosmetics and perhaps durability of contruction--but the touch technology strikes me as a complete disaster.  After working with this tiny screen, tapping and swiping it for a couple of hours, I'm elated to simply toss it in the trash.  I wouldn't wish it on a worst enemy let alone the friend (and radio listener) I had planned to give it to.  Forget the 60 pp. instruction manual, which proved of little, and eventually no help.  There are 3 external buttons--2 for volume (the original Kindle Fire had none), and one for on and off.  Once you've charged this little bugger (which in itself is no mean feat, given the unreadable meter in the upper right-hand corner of the minuscule screen), you're probably best advised to simply experiment with tapping and swiping until you've locked into an HD signal.  I can't fault this tiny gadget on sensitivity or audio quality--both are quite good with a stereo wire with earbuds extended from the audio output.  But when you hear something you like, stop any additional movement--forget about trying other stations or setting pre-sets.  You'll soon be back to where you started from, repeating the "return to default" direction again and again.In short, the operation of this gnatty nightmare is sheer punishment to all but the most desperate gadget freak or touch screen geek (or, for that matter, any masochists hard-pressed for pleasure--i.e. pain).  It didn't help that the model I received was apparently a refurb with a weak battery: I was unable to get more than a single hour's use out of the device (touch screen technology is notorious for robbing numerous devices--for example, cameras made by Canon and Panasonic--of power and time--one of the unfortunate copycat side-effects of Apple's singular success with touch screens).But let's end this review on a more sanguine note--perhaps a ray of light for those wishing to tune in a favorite HD station with 24/7 jazz, classical music, or narrated books.  Suddenly, the quickest, easiest, and surest way of picking up most stations in the HD universe is not through an expensive HD tuner or radio (if you can find one) but an "app" that you can download to an iPod. In fact, at the advertised price of this discontinued Insignia Touch tuner, a consumer would do well to consider an iPod Touch--even a low-capacity previous edition.  It helps to have a computer with the free iTunes program (downloadable to Macs or, in an altered version, to PC's), though thanks to Apple's Cloud, it's not even necessary to use a computer if your device is less than 2 years old (the same may be true of Amazon, though its Cloud is not as efficient as Apple's).  From iTunes (whether on your computer or an iPad, iPod or iPhone) you can access iTunes Store, click on "Apps," and proceed to download a free App called "Tunein," which instantly locates AM, FM, HD channels--locally or internationally--without the hassles of subscriptions, passwords, social networking.  Moreover, if you have a ROKU box you will notice in the line-up of approximately 12 channels--along with Netflix, Amazon Prime, Pandora, etc.--one for "TuneIn."  Give it a spin, especially if your television is connected to a full-frequencied audio system.So there you have it!  Consider my loss your gain.  As for this menace, I'm torn between tossing it in the trash or giving it to a 2nd-hand store for the compulsive "clutterer" in search of a bargain and time-killer.  The trick is not to allow this alien specimen to get the upper hand: it's capable of inflicting serious, even lethal, injury.
summary: The worst argument "for" or the best argument "against" HD radio?

reviewText: Just received this and checked the fit with all my small primes.  The lens I bought it for, Rokinon (Samyang) 8mm f/3.5 Fisheye, was a perfect fit.  Height wise perfect, width with the lens cap attached was snug.  I also checked the fit with my Nikon 50mm f/1.8D, Nikon 24mm f/2.8 AF-D, and my Nikon 28mm f/3.5 AI and all three swam in this case but the good news they all fit perfectly in the smaller 8x6 case.  I love the two velcro strap connection on the back.  It offers extra security of the double connection and still quickly slips over a bag strap or belt for attachment.  Overall I am very pleased with the quality, level of padding, connection type, and size.

How totally betrayed I feel by Panasonic!If Amazon had a negative star rating, this would get the maximum.I'm a real camera junkie - over the past 2 years alone, I've bought (on Amazon) 4 Panasonic's, 2 Leica's, and an assortment of others. That's in ADDITION to all the cameras I've had over the years. Bought my first Nikon in Japan in 1970. I should know what I'm buying? Right?Until today, I've never returned a camera or written a negative review. So this is a first.What was Panasonic thinking?????The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black), simply does NOT perform.Here is what is disappointing:(1) does not focus! Really, DOES NOT FOCUS!!!(2) does not take photos quickly(3) photos are "grainy"(4) color comes out worse than my old Sony's (my apology to Sony - even your most primitive cameras were better)(5) just should NOT be sold.Perhaps this is a "one off" manufacturing problem. But I take LOTS of photos with LOTS of cameras and this is the absolute worst experience I've ever had! What a shock, too.I have several really good Panasonics back at home but left for 2 1/2 weeks in Florence with only this one. THAT"S HOW MUCH I TRUSTED PANASONIC. Did not even charge it up before packing for the trip. Wanted to save space so I only took one camera. Leica, please forgive me for not bringing one of you along! Normally I take one Leica and at least one Panasonic on all trips for photography assignments, but this was pure vacation and I wanted to travel light.In the words of Michael Corolone in Godfather II:  "Panasonic: 'you disappointed me.' "Not only do I urge you NOT to buy this Panasonic model, I suggest any Panasonic camera you purchase should be checked out thoroughly upon receipt to make sure it performs as advertised. And if you also own this model, check it to be sure it is working properly.Please forward this review to anyone you know at Panasonic. They need to be responsible for their quality!!!
summary: Shockingly inferior for Panasonic: Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1

reviewText: I loved the FinePix F30 and tried to replace (and upgrade) it. The ZS10 is a great camera and almost fullfilled all my expectations. From other review I learned already that under pore light condition the F30 would still be better - and it's true - the ZS10 can't compete with the F30 in low light without Flash.As for the rest I'm simply blown away! The super zoom combined with the image stabilization is something I have never seen before. I really love this and also the overall handling of the camera. One Example is for instance that there are two push buttons: one for taking a picture and one for making video. No fidelling around with menues or dial switches - just push and the thing starts.I'm very happy with my decition, especially because I had to return a Canon camera which has very similar specs but poor picture quality.

As an outdoor enthusiast and backyard astronomer, I own many pairs of binoculars or various sizes and quality.  Most of them are mid-prices Japanese optics such as Nikon or budget priced models made by Celestron. The Celestron Granite Binoculars are my first pair of truly higher end binoculars. After using them for only a day, all I can say is "Wow". The "Fully Broadband Multi-Coatings" make all the difference in the world. Image sharpness from edge to edge is unmatched compared to any of my other binoculars. Things that plague my other binoculars such as Chromatic aberration, internal reflections, ghosting, etc., are non-existent on the Celestron Granites. Normally I'm not a bird watcher, but I enjoyed sitting in my yard watching them because the sharpness and detail were so incredible. They are also good for Astronomical viewing, although 42mm is a little small for low light objects. Bright objects such as the moon look incredible though. All in all, the Celestron Granite Binoculars are by far the best binoculars I've ever had the pleasure of using. I have a hard time finding anything negative to say about them other than perhaps the price might turn some people on a budget away.Pros:Fully Broadband Multi-Coated Optics providing incredible sharpness, contrast, and detail.Waterproof and Fogproof.8.2' Near FocusFairly Wide FOVExtremely well made and rugged.Eco-Friendly: lead and arsenic free.Lightweight.Good accessories.Cons:Price.42mm Diameter a little small for Astronomical viewing.

Edited 6/2013 - 30 rolls in.This film is the best deal on ISO 400 B&W; medium format I have found.  I thought this was Fomapan re-brand, but I'm pretty certain now it's HP5+ re-branded. Flat tone with D-76 / TMax DV, I prefer with HC-110, and better punching it 10%. Lays nice and flat for scanning.  Pushes to 1600 with acceptable results, 3200 and 6400 not so much.  So far I've gone through 30 rolls and found 1 defect in the form of a coating bubble which was also in the corner of the frame and easily corrected.  For the price it's certainly worth keeping around for everyday shooting.Kudos to the seller who turns around shipping very quickly.

Works well with my EVO, my Photon, my GSIII, my nexus 7,and my GT 10.1 onlytthing that keeps it at 4 stars is that it takes AA batteries and the preprogrammed macro keys only work with the photon which is no longer my primary handset.

Beyond saying this thing is simply amazing for the price I don't even know what else to say. It just is.Price no object and I still think it would be a contender although for all but a few in the world, price is a factor and the Asgard is a champ in that fight.From high end in-ear units like Klipsch, Etymotic, ThinkSound (all pairs I own and tried) to the Hifiman HE-4's I bought this amp for this unit is just incredible. I think it could make just about any headphone you already love and make it better. Be sure to start on a low volume and go up with in-ear types! It can make the "magic smoke come out" as the company says on their website referring to the Lyr (a higher end amp from Schiit) when using headphones that don't actually require a lot of power to push.Besides the great sound, great build quality, ridiculously good price for what you get... How could you not love a company that has an owners manual so funny you want to carry it around and show your friends?And as their website says the unit does get hot. Not as hot as I thought it would, my laptop where the battery and fan are near each other feels hotter to me, but it does get really hot. And per the company this is normal. Just keep it in mind as you place it so it has ventilation and is not where it could harm anything else. Come to think of it my first generation AppleTV gets considerably hotter than this does.

It plays Blue-Rays great but I could not get it to work with my network.  I replaced it with a second one and had the same problem but when I bought the Sony Google TV Blue-Ray player and used the same network cable, it just worked with out any problem.  Great Blue-Ray player but not good for network or streaming movies.
I bought this for my win 7 64 bit asus laptop. I installed it, and it does not detect any bluetooth devices at all. It is completely non functional. I do not recommend this item :(
summary: Win 7 64 bit- Does not work AT ALL!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Unlike some other reviewers, I had absolutely no problems installing this on a system with Win7 Ultimate 64 bit.  Unfortunately for me, my Samsung Exhibit II 4G model SGH-T679 from T-Mobile does not have a bluetooth driver. Though it does allow me to play the music on phone, I can't sync it with Windows Media Player which is what I wanted bluetooth for in the first place.  If you are buying this adapter for that purpose, make sure you check the support site for your phone to make sure they have a bluetooth driver!
summary: Check for blutetooth drivers for your phone first!

reviewText: This was a great idea and I was very excited as I was unpacking the box because the accessories and carry bag were better than I imagined!  I was very disappointed to find that the white panel insert system was sewn into the built-in carry bag incorrectly so that the tent could not be set up as described.  One could turn it upside down and make it work but it was very awkward and there was nothing to keep the side panels from spreading apart in that orientation.  Too bad!  Great idea but bad execution.  I was afraid to excange the item for another thinking that they might all be made incorrectly?
summary: Made incorrectly - nice idea and accessories, though

reviewText: I ordered this thinking the read speed for Blu-ray movies would be faster than my Pioneer 205. Not only is it slower to read and rip, the burn speed is much slower on 3 types of media I have. I would avoid this drive and go with the Pioneer if I could do it over again. The plus is you get software and cables, but for me that's not a plus as I did not need anything but the drive, which for me is a weak drive compared to my 205.

I have a pair of Martin Logan Sequel speakers for my main 2 channel listening and have always been impressed with the bass the 8" drivers deliver. So when I setup my home theater, I got a Grotto sub and was really impressed with the definition and extension of the subwoofer. I've got a smaller system that features a pair of Mission speakers and a low cost receiver with a sub output and was looking for a low cost sub. I found this the Dynamo 300 for less than $250 on Amazon and thought I would give it a try.It was delivered the next day (WOW) and is a bit smaller than the Grotto, but had the familiar look and feel of an American made product from Martin Logan. One problem was the port extension had come lose inside and needed to be reattached. Rather than send it back, I just took the amp out and fixed it myself. Setup was pretty easy with my Onkyo receiver, I set the crossover frequency at 100 and started playing with placement. After a couple of days of break in, playing with the placement and reducing the crossover in my receiver to 90, it started giving me the results I was looking for. It has enough power to fill my small room with very good bass and works well on movies and music. Don't let the 70 Watt rating fool you, this thing tumps.The sound is accurate and tight. The extension is very good, it goes much lower than I expected and without being boomy like so many woofers. Some notes: Setup the system to crossover to take over where your main speakers leave off, as low as you can. My speakers can go down to 50 Hz but don't do a good job at anything below 80 Hz so I set the crossover at 90 Hz. At 100 Hz it was way to boomy. I then used the receiver crossover to remove anything below 90 Hz going to my main speakers and that made a huge improvement. It is VERY HARD to manage multiple speakers reproducing bass in the same frequency range. Letting the sub do it's thing without interference will provide much better results. Another benefit to removing the low frequencies from the main speakers is the amplifier in your receiver will not have to burn power on pushing low frequencies that can be reproduced better by the sub. This improves your overall sound. Warning, While the 300 has an adjustable high pass filter, this sub will not provide a crossover that will work for your main speakers. You will need to manage that from your receiver. If you receiver does not feature a crossover, set the high pass filter lower. You can pick the frequency by looking up the frequency response of your main speakers and go just a bit higher than the lowest number usually between 50 - 90 Hz.In summary, I can't imagine a more accurate sub for the money. Much better than anything costing less than $350 from any other manufacturer. If you are in the market for a sub on a budget, stop looking and get this.
summary: It Thumps - hard to beat for the money

reviewText: I purchased a warranty for my Kindle Fire, but had to cancel it because I ended up returning the Fire.  I called Square Trade, and was put through immediately; after explaining, I was told I would receive a full refund, even though I had use of the Fire for a month before returning it.  Their tech was friendly and helpful, and their refund was very quick.  I have since purchased a Samsung Galaxy Tab and was delighted to find that Square Trade also insured them.  I purchased coverage and I know they will be fair and quick if I ever need service.  Very satisfied.
I haven't actually done a shoot-off, counting the shots, but in everyday use it seems to last longer than the official battery. It is certainly no worse, and it is a lot cheaper!

I've tried to like this product, but, quite honestly, it isn't worth the trouble.I should have known that I was in trouble when the product description didn't say a word about working with Macs. It doesn't.So I had to load the software onto a PC to use it. The software wasn't all that intuitive, but eventually i managed to load on some songs, but it wasn't easy.I loaded a variety of pieces, so I could get a feel about the quality on different types of music. None of it was very good.The batteries discharge quickly, the screen display isn't intuitive and the plugs for the mini-USB and earphones aren't very secure. They rarely stay in enough to play music through them and, if y do, it only coms into one ear.I get MUCH better sound quality from a computer's built-in speakers or from my iPod.Not worth it in my opinion.
summary: Not intuitive, not easy to use, poor sound quality

reviewText: This product was just what I was looking for, easy to use and very compact. The manual is a little overwhelming, but if you just use it as a reference then your fine. The only thing that would have been very useful is a backlight. The only problem with this purchase is now neither my wife or I, can deny we snore

I fly small airplanes and use an iPad for navigation and for documents (Procedures, airport information, etc). Usually I go with RAM mounts because the build quality but, alas!, They won't have iPad Mini specific mounts in until February.This mount was very good on the wallet and seems to be decent. For those of you who want this to mount an iPad in the car you are probably going to be okay. For being shoved in a flight bag and bounced around....eh, the plastic seems like it may not be up to the task.I'll use this until RAM can get their act together. Until then, this will TOTALLY work. Fits iPAD mini WITH OR WITHOUT case. If it can survive the 2 months I'll be one happy camper.
These bookshelf speakers are fantastic!  Easily driven by a small class-T amp they make a compact, superb listening experience!  For the price these really cannot be beat.
This will not charge my kids' Nikon S3100.  I ordered two and plugged them into a standard USB charging block as well as a USB port on a computer and it won't charge.
I don't know if its this card, my computer, my new hard drive cable, or a combination of all three that i get such speeds. I expected faster speeds.bought refurbished item,. seems to be working fine.

I lost my cord that came with my camera and couldn't charge the battery. This cord worked like a charm and did its magic. I did have to leave my laptop screen open to keep it from going to sleep and cutting power to the USB port but that is normal. This cord was much cheaper then other cords, but worked!! Highly recommend.

Recieved my HT-CT550 Sony soundbar system yesterday & set it up this morning. I followed another reviewers recommendations for initial set up as I've read that the default settings are somewhat under-welming. Well, it was a very easy setup & yes; there is some nice 'punch' to the sound now!! As a test I put in my new Blu-Ray disc of 'The War Horse" that just came out & screen selected to a scene. I won't spoil anything about the movie but it's a scene with a large number of thundering horses. First you hear the wind clearly through the tall grass & when the horses thundered across the field, MAN the room shook!! It was great. Dialog is clear, not muddy and I think the highs & lows are nicely defined. I was wondering how easy the wireless sub-woofer would be to setup. There WAS no set up! Once you plug one tranceiver in the back of the reciever & the other behind the subwoofer & plug in the sub-woofer...that's it! No detection errors.All-in-all I'm very glad I got this to complement my new Sony Bravia TV (46" EX820; the price is good, no speaker wires all over the room & good punch to the sound.
summary: Great Soundbar!! Sony does it again!!

reviewText: I have the same TV, but last year's model GT25. They are essentially the same with minor changes.  I bought mine at Costco.My TV just failed after 8 months service. Blue lines advance down the screen along with the picture. I did all the obvious tests to eliminate external interference, but no joy.I think it's still in warranty, but I'll have to find the service station and haul it around for the repair - not easy with a 50-inch plasma TV. No doubt it will be down a long time if my experience with electronic repairs is an indicator.This one may have been a lemon, or maybe it says something about Panasonic plasma TV quality. Great picture, but pay your money and take your chances.UPDATE: 1/31/2012I had contacted Panasonic on the problem as soon as it happened. They had a local repair facility call me and I described the problem.  The serviceman was able to determine that it was probably a discrepant main board and had one shipped to him. 6 days after the original call to Panasonic, the serviceman arrived on site and replaced the main circuit board. No charge since it was still in the 12 month warranty period. Works fine now.
Needs to be longer than they are.  While helpful to manage endless cords, for larger, longer cords a longer tie is required

they're comfy and sound good. it'd be hard to find better quality at this price point (though i think i did get them on a sale price). the case is cool, but in day-to-day i don't end of wrapping them up every time. i recommend.

When it comes to computers and networking, I would be considered a power-user but as of late (kids, career, etc.) I place a tremendous value on the ability for hardware to be plug-n-plan and this unit doesn't disappoint. I uninstalled my old router and installed this baby in under 10 minutes. I've been using it for two weeks and haven't had a single hiccup.If something goes awry, I'll report back but so far this unit gets a perfect score.

8 routers now and counting. I have taken to setting up specific routers for specific devices to better allow me to test the ONE most important thing to me at this point, stability....This router has serious stability issues for me so far and has given me more than a fair share of aggravation. Set up was painless enough using the included disc and GUI. To be honest, some folks may think this is the easy part but MY experience, especially with my Netgear routers have not been so easy in this department....So at least the set up portion was easy enough.So I get set up and I begin to tinker & see what is what. I like that it has a vertical footprint as opposed to my Linksys models that take up more room. But my contentment mostly ends there. While I am tinkering I begin losing connections and the router is reboot happy. I understand it does this to clear chache to then restore itself to factory default settings. Now if this happened occasionally, I might be able to be more forgiving. I do NOT like preset SSID's and with my 10+ devices to configure to my router I need what is easy for ME. I mean who wants to reconfigure ALL your devices every time this router reboots which for me was every few MINUTES?  So this became a living nightmare for me to the point of giving up in the end and putting this back in it's box. When it is up & running and before it goes all PMS it is fast enough but no faster than I ever got with any of my routers purchased in the past year. On the 5GHz, it was actually noticeably slower in fact. If you plan to use this with your ROKU box, good luck! I would heartily recommend you not use it for any PURCHASED  movie content anywhere. I highly suspect you will lose yourself some money.I come away (or in my case-WALK AWAY) from this router feeling like Belkin just didn't have their heart in this product? It has some nifty ideas but executes them poorly. I am being generous in giving this 2 stars. Only as I will consider it a possibility mine is defective? Belkin....if you are listening I will be happy to return this to you to check? As long as YOU pay the shipping. Sorry I couldn't be more through but I simply gave up after days of fighting with this.

I want to protect my investment in my MacBook against accidents. I want a case rugged enough to protect against drops along the edges and corners,  or against perpendicular impact to the screen.I am quite willing to pay for what I believe is about the best lightweight, protective sleeve. Thule's sleeve is engineered with the same waffle design seen in its bike and cargo racks for good shock resistance. The stylish blue closing tabs are lockable and add security. To my mind, the good news is that buying superior protection for my valuable MacBook does not cost more than other, lesser brands.Thuele has developed a lightweight, high-density, semi-rigid sleeve that looks good and is a good choice for business, school and personal use. My only caveat: Consider removing your MacBook from the case for extended use to protect the battery from getting too hot and blowing out your chips and other components. Should you prefer a carrying handle or strap, consider theThule 13 Inch MacBook Pro Laptop Attache Case. The Thule Protection Sleeve comes in a 13" and 15" size and is a snug fit. Regretably for many, it is not yet released in a 17" size  but hopefully, those guys at Thule are listening...* Clamshell design allows use of your MacBook while in the case, perfect for ease of access. The exterior mat surface is non-slip to my fingertips and is easily maneuvered.* An elastic cross band keeps the computer secure as you unzip your case to help prevent any accidental spills.* Water resistant zipper and exterior shell provide some additional all-weather protection.* 25 Year quality guarantee. (The zipper works fine but if it were to fail, I'll keep my receipt and send it in for repair.)Simply, I like this case and recommend it highly. I also am comfortable highly recommending this case to parents of newly wired children who may be young to be fully careful or perhaps a little clumsy about transporting their MacBook around the house.
summary: A carrier worthy of Thule Sweden, a trusted name in protective bike carriers and cargo racks

reviewText: As a case, this one's simple - it fits the 13.3" Macbook Pro to a T.  There's little to no extra room inside, though I've been able to connect the magsafe charger while the case was unzipped.  Bonus points for being *extremely* light.
