Being only a very thin, light molded material, it barely registers as extra weight when the Macbook is inside.  And the zipper design is claimed to provide a level of water resistance, which is an excellent thing indeed.  The Macbook can easily be used inside of the case, it doesn't hinder usage and won't create any clutter around you if you need to use it in a cramped space (such as on an airplane, bus, small table in a Starbucks, etc.)But in terms of protection, I have to wonder about Thule's claims.  This is not truly a hard-shell case.  It's a semi-hard molded material that will deform if impacted by the right thing in the right way, and there is no impact foam inside to absorb any of the energy.  In contrast, I also have aCase Logic QNS-113 13.3-Inch EVA Molded Laptop Macbook Air/Pro Sleeve (Black)that doesn't have the rugged construction that the Thule has, but instead has a thick layer of dense foam protecting the top and a ridged lower section.  I'm torn on which one I feel is the safer of the two for my Macbook - the Case Logic doesn't fit the Macbook very snugly at all, but provides much greater sense of protection over this very thin case.  Perhaps you understand my dilemma here.At the moment, I have settled on keeping the Macbook in the Thule case at home, and since I rarely travel with it, the case it simply protection from my kids.  The Thule is fine for that.  We have a short vacation upcoming, and that's where I'm again torn - Thule or Case Logic?  Contrary to my review, I'm leaning toward the Thule because of it's light nature.  We'll see...

I purchased this keyboard because it allows switching between devices. I can hotkey between my desktop, iPAD, and Android phone. I think I can hotkey between up to 6 devices, (I only use 4 at the most). This is a fantastic feature.That said, the layout is a bit strange. There is no 10-key pad. Instead there is a touchpad. And the size is smaller than a standard keyboard but too large and heavy (in my opinion) to be considered portable.Also switching between devices can be a bit 'laggy.' It can take a few seconds of waiting. Connection seems to cut in and out at times. But overall, it works and keeps up with my keystrokes quite well. (I type at about 60 words per minute.)Build quality seems good, and the keys have a good feel. I have not had it long enough to comment about battery life.Overall, I am happy with the purchase but I would not have purchased unless I needed the device switching feature.** UPDATE AFTER USING IT FOR A MONTH**I have to agree with many of the other reviewers. If this was a standard keyboard, it woudld ROCK! But some engineer got it in his head that he could do it 'better.' Well, he failed. It is a great idea but a bad, poor, rotten design.
summary: Does one thing well, but why so strange?

reviewText: I couldn't believe my ears when I first listened to music with these headphones.  I'm not an audio geek or audio snob.  The idea of spending $200 or more for brands like Beats by Dr. Dre makes my stomach churn.  Couldn't do it.  I'm also usually not wild about in ear headphones.  I've had several pairs of in ear headphones for the gym and for travel purposes and most of them have been okay.  They got the job done but nothing to get excited about.  I do have a pair of over the ear Bose headphones that I received as a gift that I use at home and they are quite nice.  I ordered the TS01 headphones a while ago when I got a nice deal on them.  I loved them.  Best pair of in ear headphones I have ever had.  Unfortunately, after a few months one of the ear buds came apart.  I glued it.  No biggie.  Sounded fine.  Then a month later the other side came apart. This time I put aside the gorilla glue and decided test this great customer service I had heard about.  I e mailed them expecting that I would never hear back.  Within an hour, I had a response from Ray Fournier, Director of Operations with Thinksound.  Most importantly, not an automated response! A real, tailored to me response!  They then sent me that Return Authorization and I mailed out the headphones.  Exactly a week later, I received a brand new pair in the mail.  Then I received an e mail from Aaron Fournier, President, CEO and Engineer of Thinksound, apologizing for any inconvenience and he admitted they had a batch of headphones where the glue wasn't quite right.  I've always felt that I don't get worked up when a mistake gets made or something gets messed up - stuff happens - I'm more concerned about the actions that follow when something goes wrong.  That's where you see the character and integrity of whomever you are dealing with.  And that is where this company gets it right.  Buy with confidence.  If something goes wrong, they will take care of you. Can you say the same of other headphone makers?  Anyway, so impressed with customer service that I felt I would get an extra pair - one for work / on the go and one for home.  So I moved up to the TS02.  Wow.  I couldn't believe what I was hearing.  The sound is incredible.  Like I said, I'm not an audio snob so I won't use technical terms, but I will just say that I can't imagine finding another pair of headphones even at twice this price that sound this good.  It just doesn't seem possible.  Buy them.  Great product.  Great company.
summary: Wow! Get These! Great Product - Great Company!

reviewText: I love this blue-ray player, the size and the speed of loading the disc definitively impress me. and 3D is perfect for my TV. There are plenty of apps for this little box like Netflix, pandora, ect. there "con' about this it takes a little time to install everything but what more could you ask for. I defiantly recommend this Blue-ray player to anybody even without a 3d tv you should buy it.

I totally love this tv. I was so happy with my 32 inch from Samsung that I bought the 40 inch version for our smaller living room. For the price of $500 you can't go wrong. I did look at the competing Sony version. The Samsung just seemed to have a better picture quality and much more features for the same price. The Sony version didn't offer picture in picture, USB playback of video files like mkv and avi. Also the Sony only had 2 hdmi ports versus the Samsung which has 4. Finally the sony doesn't dlna which this Samsung has. I am very impressed with the picture and sound quality.  I can't really think of anything I would want that isn't included for this price. I guess it would be nice to have wifi included and apps. I can add wifi with the Samsung adapter for about $60. This will allow me to use the dlna feature and the wifi remote with an apple or android device. Again at this point I can't think any negative point about this tv. Just make sure to properly calibrate the picture and sound settings to get the tvs full potential. Also make sure to use hdmi cables for all hd sources. I've tried this tv with my Sony blu ray player, my pc and my hd pvr all with hdmi cables all with excellent picture and sound quality.

Got the 32inch flatscreen.  Came in two days with amazon prime and in perfect condition. Everything was very easy to hook up and I was able to program my dish cable remote so that most of the changes to a newer system weren't even felt.The picture is truly sharp and crisp.  Several options for sounds, picture, quality are at your fingertips. Unless you have never had a tv before, programming is very simple.The base is pretty cheap and at first with the packaging i thought the one part to the base was missing.  The box has two long pieces of foam to hold the tv securely, indicating which end is up. Make sure you REMOVE both pieces as parts to the base of the stand are inside the one at the other end, completely out of eyesight unless you pull out the foam.I found the sound a bit tinny after trying out all choices; srs, movie, basic..but also noted with srs (surround sound) it wasn't that bad.  I have Bose external theater speakers so didn't really care much about the sounds.  What I did care about is finding that my Bose system wasn't compatible with the newer models of HDTV so had to get a RCA dual  adapter.  Pay the 12-13 dollars and get a good one or else the speakers will hum like crazy, distorting everything.Using any other device , connecting with a hdmi cable is idiot proof.  End one to tv, end two to the dvd, roku, or any device that has this sort of connection.  Then you just hit source on the tv's remote control and scroll down to your hdmi 1, hdmi2,hdmi3  etc and there is your other sources.  Click on it and your dvd is ready to play on the screen.My dvd isn't blue ray but over this tv I was amazed how wonderful the picture quality was.  I have a ROKU player for internet viewing so netflix, huluplus, crackle and amazon prime is simple and cheap.  Do not get this if your internet connection is slow because it will not be streaming, rather start and stop-driving one to drink..more. <G>So far i have hooked up my dvd, roku, dvr and cable to the system with external speakers.  I have plenty of connections left if i want to add a wii, smart phone with hdmi or use the two usb connections for my camera or computer.This tv offers so much for the price.  I am pleased with my purchase and pleased with myself for setting everything up with very little instructions.  Well done Samsung!
summary: Great price for this..sounds so -so but an easy fix

reviewText: I bought this camera to replace a Kodak I wasted my money on last year. I wasn't sure about a Panasonic brand camera, but went with the reviews. I am so glad I did. It produces sharp clear pictures with a simple point and shoot. I enjoy the easy of use and I don't have to worry about blurry pictures anymore...

We purchased this item to place in our young son's room.  He sleeps better with some kind of music playing at night.  And, he also likes to have a night light on.  This item fills both requirements nicely.  We've been using it for a little over a year with no issues.  Please note that we do not use the alarm or the custom App, so I can't comment on them.Best Features:-iPod/iPhone charging and playback-Lighted base doubles as a night light-Color can be fixed to 1 color or change continuously-Clock display color changes to match the base color-Size is about right ... big enough to use easily, small enough to place anywhereDrawbacks:-Sound quality is ok at best (not awful, but not impressive at all)-The slope of the front face can make the clock difficult to read at some angles (it's best when placed below eye level)Summary:This is a nice bedside clock radio that does double-duty as a night light.  But, the sound quality is only so-so.
summary: A Clock Radio and a Night Light

reviewText: This TV is amazing. Its the first TV I have purchased online, and I will be doing it again in the future!This TV looks incredible. From BluRay movies, to games, to using my computer, this TV handles it all brilliantly.If you are on the fence, don't be, you will not be disappointed.

I have been purchasing several products of Case Logic, and what I can say is that its really  worth the price.I own this sleeve for my macbook pro 13.3" and it fits perfectly fine. I would recommend to have a pocket or something to place the laptop charger, but other than that, its a really good product.Love the color, material, everything.really worth it!

These speakers sound really well for the price!The tweeter is a bit on the bright side, but still good sounding.You'll immediately notice the quality drivers in this cabinet!Too bad only 2 of them are real drivers, the others are passive drivers.These cabinets shine by themselves. Because of the passive drivers there's some booming lows, but no real deep lows.Also pairing it with a subwoofer is rather difficult, because of phase issues with the low frequencies between these speakers, and the subwoofers or speakers of other kind. For that reason, if you plan on pairing these speakers, just pair them with the same kind only.Also, I get great results with this amp:LP-2020A+ Lepai Tripath Class-T Hi-Fi Audio Mini Amplifier with Power SupplyThe overall sound is a bit on the bright side, doubtless it's the amps fault, but also the slightly bright tuned cabinet in combination with the brighter amp.Both are a perfect combination for a stereo Home Theater.The amp uses only 4Watts of power on the AC, and the speakers sound awesome, on volume levels just topping normal conversation!Even at 10W this setup can be very loud!I also tested these speakers with a 100W power amp, and they can get really loud; but I prefer my LP2020 amp.
summary: Great sounding speakers, too bad only 2 woofers

reviewText: Hi everybody!  I took a chance with this product.  I didn't expect much for $7 but was reading it was working for the Nexus 7 tablet.  So I ordered it on a Wednesday and it was delivered on Saturday- that was free shipping!Now I knew by reading that the usb plug needed an adapter.  I already had an OTG (on the go) adapter to expand the micro usb port for card reading- I hoped that it would work on that too.Plugged it in and at first I got nothing.  Hmmmm....  Unplugged, and replugged the micro usb plug into the tablet, and Voile!!  Keyboard was working fine!! ;-)  For $7, this is great for taking away when you don't want to bring a bigger laptop.  The keyboard is pretty small, but it beats using the touch screen to type on.It has a built in stand, and my top clip was spring loaded to adjust for different width tablets.  I didn't need to add anything else.  Very securely held.  The fake black leather is not the most attractive, but what do you want for $7??Definitely works great for the Nexus 7!! Don't forget to order a micro usb to usb adapter- probably the OTG one- couple dollars at the most.If you are into good looks and not function, you might be disappointed.  It's plain black- but with some pretty embelishments, it will be beautiful!
summary: Great for the Nexus 7- needs a micro usb adapter

reviewText: My IEMs of choice at the $50 range if you like crystal clear vocals. Excellent cabling, accessories, and durability. Very comfortable though you might need to get used to over the ear placement. Only think I would have preferred is an L connector instead of a straight one.

Don't hold a candle to my Etymotic ER-4P headphones, but they're fine for working out at 1/5 the price (I got them on sale)Compared to the Etymotic ER-4P, the treble seems attenuated and the clarity is not nearly as good.Bass is there, but not accentuated - similar to Etymotic.  People who like a "boomy" sound will be disappointed.

If this USB key were any slower it would actually delete data instead of saving it.I am currently transferring a 4 GB film from my PC to this piece of antiquated garbage : 4.56 MB/s.That's 15 to 20 mins of transfer time.Imagine filling up this 8 GB key : you'd need around 40 minutes !Incredible.I've had this for 2 days and i've had it. I thought Lexar was a synanonym of quality. Well, i'll think twice before i buy from them again.THIS THING IS SO SLOW IT SHOULD BE ILLEGAL.I am selling this to the first fool i find. Useless.
summary: Slower than a Swiss Snail - avoid like the plague

reviewText: I am so mad at myself for buying this piece of junk. The quality is terrible. The device only works half the time.  I thought my first one was defective, so I exchanged it, but encountered the same problems. The battery is a major problem. I buy new Energizer or Duracell batteries for it often, and they only last two to four months.  Even worse, this device is SO STUPID, it shows you when the battery is halfway depleted, so each time you want to change the channel or do anything, you have to click 'Exit' to get away from the battery half-full message. So frustrating! Change the channel one time, then click Exit, chenge the channel, then click Exit...and so on.  I know the damn battery is half full! I don't need a constant reminder.  Yet this stupid device has tell me after every single button I push. If you buy this device you will feel my frustration.

Lg LG 32-inch 32LK330 720p LCD HDTV (32LK330)I purchased this TV on March 10, 2012, from Amazon.com, (it was delivered on the 15th. of March). It came in the original box, which did have some minor rips in it, but that didn't impact the inside of the box when we opened it, the protective wrapping was untouched, (no rips in it). My husband put the stand together and he said it was very easy to understand the instructions in the booklet on how to do it, we also received all the needed screws to put it together. Before we took our huge 25" old TV off the stand in the living room, we took the new LG to our bedroom and hooked it up to our antenna cable in there to see if it was going to work, (we don't have cable or satellite here, just a regular antenna).  We turned it on, went through the setup process, which for us was very simple and the TV did most of it by itself. When it got done scanning, we had channels on it, yes, the sound was low as read in earlier reviews, but also if you read all the reviews, some do tell you how to get that sound level up, which is going into the main, advance setup and adjusting the audio to the higher level, (also where you adjust your screen size, your clock, timer, child lock, etc). Since buying this and using it daily, we have not had any problems with this set at all!! It works great, the picture is very good, the sound once adjusted is good too, you don't have to turn it way up anymore once you make the initial setting in the advance setting area, (but we have noticed some channels do have lower volume then others), that is not the TV's fault though.  One of my biggest questions I had about the TV, (since we don't have anything but an antenna), was if we needed to use our digital box we had to purchase years ago, which was answered if you read all the reviews on, but the answer is no, you do not need the digital box to run this TV, it's made right into the set. It also picks up anything in the scan process that you might have hooked up to the set as well, such as cable and/or satellite, it even has a hook up for the computer, (which we have not used), but we have used the USB port to look at some pictures on the TV that I had downloaded into my flash drive, it read the flash drive as soon as I put it in.  The only thing I can comment on that I don't care much for is the remote control, the buttons are set pretty funny on there or it might just be me, but I'm always hitting the wrong button to try and mute the TV. Other then that, I have not found a thing wrong with it! I also went online to e-bay and found an extra remote for this TV so we both can have our own. I'm am very pleased with this TV we purchased, though some reviews weren't good, but we've had no problem out of ours. I would certainly recommend this set to anyone who is looking for a new digital TV.

I ordered these because it is a good deal and comes with 3 screen protectors. I've always had trouble applying these things in the past, so the extra 2 is there in case I screw up. These aren't the BEST screen protectors for the Playbook, but they aren't crappy either, especially considering the price. When it comes down to it, they do their job and don't seem to take away from the sensitivity of the touch pad. One thing to note however, is that after I had successfully applied the screen protector to my device, I noticed that there are two small circle cut outs for the holes on the front of the device. I did not notice them before, so I had to slightly lift up the screen protector at that area to remove the two plastic circles. Because of that, I got a few specks of dust around that part and it also seems that the air bubble around those holes will take some work to get rid of. Perhaps in time it'll settle in but for now, I'm satisfied with it. And I still have 2 more screens in case I get bored one day and redo it. This time I will remove the plastic circles before I apply it.Tip: Look up a Youtube video on how to apply screen protectors, it helps a lot. It involves using tape to help align your screen protector and keep it in place while you remove the film. I recommend you try that method for a better application!

These are really great headphones that give good sound quality and the mic works really well too (I used it to make calls on my ipod and for listening to stuff on my laptop).  The best part is its in my favorite colors.

First off I love my Sony Cyber-Shot DSC-HX100V. I bought four other cameras and returned them before finding it and I LOVE LOVE LOVE it, which is why I bought this case verses some others.The Good:1. Snug fit but not to the point of using the jaws of life to get the camera in!2. The cover is sleek and very well cushioned3. It comes with a belt clip which I did not care about but now that I have it... I use it ALL the time... so glad I have it and now I could not live without it.4. The tripod is cheap... very cheap but we have actually used it and it did serve it's purpose! Would I trust it to hold my camera on a thin ledge... heavens no... but on a big surface that would catch my camera if the tripod collapsed... sure.5. Well made... very well made. The stitching is solid and strong6. made in the USA... that alone is a top selling incentive for me7. The buttons at the bottom are solid and good strong buttons, not cheap clip kinds. Why such a big deal on the buttons? Well this case does not come with a carry strap so your camera's strap becomes the strap for camera and cover. The buttons are what keeps the case on and in place even when you are wearing the camera over your neck and all the pressure is placed on the buttons to keep their hold so that the case stays on and does not fall off.8. The price is incredible at 18.00! WOW... it is worth more!9. No strap - now you may thing I am crazy for this one but hear my logic. My camera's strap could hold a boat to dock it is so strong and I would not want my camera in any other strap or manufacturers hands. What if the strap broke on the case and my camera fell into water or a lake or whatever. I would much rather trust my strap especially since this case is built to work with your camera's strap that comes with your camera whether you want it or not.The bad:1. It came with a label stating made in the USA which I love but then the tripod is made in China???? No points off or anything but it takes away from the bragging rights of MITUSA (made in the USA)Overall I obviously love this case and the construction of it. I would recommend anyone to buy it!
summary: Fits perfectly the Sony Cyber-Shot DSC-HX100V

reviewText: I LOVE the CONCEPT and FEATURE SET of this Samsung combination Blu Ray 3-D DVD Player and 840 Watt Receiver !!!But quality control in manufacture is HORRIBLE....My first unit bought at a local big box electronics retailing chain FAILED IMMEDIATELY on removal from its factory sealed box and would NOT EVEN POWER UP...My second unit bought via Amazon.com arrived with a dented box, damaged faceplate, and would also NOT POWER UP.... No fault of the SELLER !My third unit, ordered yesterday, will arrive tomorrow.Please add a prayer for me and #3, so I might finally experience a working unit....More to follow shortly.I have now received refunds for my first two units of this item purchased, and via Amazon took delivery of a WORKING model that is superb !I highly recommend this combination Blu Ray 3-D DVD Player and Receiver. Just be aware you MIGHT have to go through more than one purchase to obtain a properly operating unit.  A real hassle, BUT worth it in the final end....

For a few years, I had been using my old Sony EX71's (which still sound great). I've wanted to upgrade for a while and have tried various earphones along the way, but none have impressed me. After some online research, I decided to order four pairs of earbuds - the Ultimate Ears UE600 and UE500, Klipsch S4 and the SE215's, with the hope of finding at least one pair that's a keeper. I was looking at the under-$100 price point.The UE500's sounded okay, though the bass was a bit boomy and the highs could be cleaner. They also seem cheaply made and I wouldn't expect them to last. The UE600's are excellent and I may keep them. The balanced armature driver provides amazingly detailed vocals and instrumentals. They don't provide very deep, extended bass, however they do seem to handle lows accurately and are fine for everything but bass-heavy genres like hip hop. After hearing the S4's, I'm surprised that they have such a large following. They sounded very average, with exaggerated, boomy bass and rather harsh (sibilant) highs. Just shows you what one good CNET review and effective marketing can do. For the current price of $59, however, they're worth it if you need some loud earbuds with good sound isolation to use in noisy environments.The last pair I tried were SE215's. To be honest, I wasn't too excited about these, as I expected them to be uncomfortable, with the over-the-ear style and relatively bulky design. But that all changed as soon as I heard them. These are the nicest sounding earbuds I've heard by far. Smooth, balanced, warm, distortion-free sound from the highest of highs to the lowest of lows. And the bass is not only deep, but tight and controlled. I can see the sound of the UE600's or S4's being fatiguing after an hour or so, but the 215's sound so sweet I think I could listen to them all day. While no audiophile, I think I'm pretty picky and I honestly can't come up with any criticism as far as the sound. Shure has been around since the 1920's and has a good reputation, which gives me confidence in the design and engineering that goes into their products. Many of today's trendy brands probably just outsource design and manufacturing overseas and are more about appearance and bling factor, rather than sound quality. I've always had this image of Shure appealing to purists who prefer a totally flat frequency response and who listen mainly to classical music. The SE215 is the first model that has more of a v-shaped curve, with some bass enhancement. The amount of bass is just right - somewhere between flat and extended, as with bass-heavy earbuds. The result is a rich, full sound that is great with all genres of music and which most regular, non-audiophile users will probably prefer.The quality is top notch. There are substantial strain relief moldings at all cord junctions. The cord and plug seem quite rugged and furthermore, the cord is replaceable. The 215's have a 2-year warranty, which is great for earbuds. Six sets of tips are included (3 silicone and 3 foam). I went with the silicone tips, since I'm too lazy to mess with the compressable tips each time.Putting them on is fairly quick and easy once you get used to it (though slightly less convenient than under ear buds). They're also very comfortable, once you know how to position them properly. If you wear glasses, there might be some discomfort after a while due to having both the wire sleeve and the arm of the glasses resting on your ears. There are some photos online of people wearing the SE215's incorrectly (left and right sides reversed). Obviously, using them correctly makes a huge difference in comfort and bass response. The over the ear style helps keep the cord out of the way, where they're less likely to snag on something. The sound isolation is very effective, which means they shouldn't be used anywhere you need to be able to hear. If you're considering these but are hesitating, give them a try. I'm glad I did.
summary: Shure SE215 vs Ultimate Ears UE600, UE500 and Klipsch S4

reviewText: It works exactly as advertised, but runs a little fast. I would like to know what genius decided to put the buttons for setting the clock & alarm on the bottom of the clock, however. Also, Buttons are very difficult to read because the lettering is the same color as the body of the clock.

I already have a full version of Windows 7 Ultimate and installed it on a new build.  I just used the key to activate it and it worked perfectly.  This is an OEM version so the key can only be used once.

Great device!  Purchased for $74.99 so it was a great deal too!  The sound that comes out is excellent.  We had the house blasting yesterday when we hooked it up.  Easy set up too.  The fact that it comes with everything you need is a bonus.

I probably spent a good 6 months researching DSLR cameras before committing to the Canon Rebel T3i.  First, I was debating between a Nikon or Canon.  After borrowing my friend's Nikon and another friend's Canon and playing around with both for a few months, I decided on getting a Canon and after looking through all my Canon options and price points, I felt like the Rebel T3i was the perfect match for me.The Canon's lighter than Nikon, which I prefer.  I like how the keys/buttons are situated and it feels comfortable on my hands.  I also love how the LCD display screen can be moved around.  Not only does that make it easier to shoot some difficult shots, I also like to swivel the screen around to face the inside of the camera to protect the screen while I'm not using the camera.This kit is also great!  I've used everything in the kit and it's great that I didn't need to go out and buy things separately.

Overall, I'm pleased with my purchase of the Metz 24 flash.  I don't need an extremely powerful flash, just something to brighten things up in low light, usually around the house.  I shoot an Olympus E-PL2, and the built-in flash is frequently too weak.The Metz 24 is fairly inexpensive for a TTL flash, but it does a nice job of getting a correct exposure.  The head tilts up for bouncing the flash off a ceiling.  It takes four or five seconds to charge the capacitor after turning it on, but it recharges in just a couple seconds between shots.The build quality is good enough, though not stellar.  The tilting head has a bit of play back and forth, and the battery cover fit could be bit tighter.  The shoe mount base is plastic, which is my biggest worry.  But I can't be too hard on the thing, as it feels like it'll hold up pretty well.The flash head makes a really loud clicking sound when tilted up or down.I would have liked the AF assist lamp to work with the E-PL2, but it doesn't.  This probably isn't the fault of the flash, though, but a firmware issue with the camera.The power of the flash cannot be controlled manually from either the flash itself, nor from the camera.  It's TTL only.  You can, however, use flash exposure compensation, which makes up a bit for the lack of manual control.Sometimes, a flash will come with a storage pouch.  No such luck with the Metz 24.  If you want to protect it, it'll fit in some lens pouches, and some inexpensive pocket camera cases.  It's not amazingly compact, but it's light and doesn't look weird atop an E-PL2.

Light strong easy to use. I suggest the Manfroto bipod head for this product. I used this for a trip to England. I liked it for use when dark, easier to carry then tripod. I have looked at a lot of bipods this one is small and tall.

The microscope works OK but I would not agree that the magnification is variable 10X - 150X.  The unit works more like an electronic 10X loop, with the control wheel functioning as a focus device and not really changing the magnification.  If you look at how the unit is labeled this is misleading, I would expect that once the subject was in focus the control ring would make it larger or smaller -- not so.  To change the magnification you need to change the distance between the subject and the lens.  I was not able to produce any clear image with a magnification of more than about 10-15X.  Even so, this would be fun for kids to fool around with since even mundane things can look pretty interesting at those low magnifications.  The image capture is a nice feature of the software and supports both stills and movies.  The construction seems very solid..

My wife and I decided to cut cable tv since we were spending $100 a month on it, but really only watching netflix anyway.  We didn't want to give up the local stations though, so we started looking around at options.  One of the reviews on this product sold us, so we ordered one and tested it.  When we hooked it up to the living room tv, it picked up 21 digital channels, many of them looking better than they did on cable.  So, we ordered a 2nd one for the bedroom tv.  In the bedroom, it was a little more difficult to pick up a clear signal.  It needed a direct path to the windows.  If we tried to place it where it would be less conspicuous, it does not get a signal.  So, we ended up with a very visible cord leading up to a painting we have above the tv.  But, for saving us $100/month on cable, I will live with it.  Thank you Mohu!

I have been using this antenna now for just over 1 month.The number of free to air channels depends greatly on the positioning of this antenna.By trial and error it is now mounted indoors on a window pane via a 25 ft extension cable to the TV.It pulls in nearly 70 channels, most of them at more than 50% signal strength, with excellent HD reception.  I have discontinued my cable subscription as I can now get all the channels I normally watch.

I've been streaming for a couple of years using a roku and other methods. I researched antennas on and off since cutting the cable but wasn't willing to go the outdoor route and the indoor antennas I checked got dismal reviews. I'm in a valley with a house and a tree obstructing the view and still got 40 channels! I added a 6 foot extension to the provided cable and placed it on the window closest to the TV - this location is obstructed but still the best spot available with the amount of cable I had on hand. My research led me to believe I might get 5 or 6 channels! Boy were those sites wrong! Many of these channels are in languages I don't speak, 7 or 8 are radio, but I'm also getting several PBS and all the network channels in English and some quirky San Francisco stations which is a big surprise! I was really hoping to get the SF channels so yep, very happy. FREE TV, but way better than the analog version of old. You can travel with this too which is great for people who live in different locations seasonally or for taking to the vacation house or for the RV.  I have it connected to an LG Infinia 42LV5400 120 Hz Smart TV which is a newer model.
summary: 40 Channels in a Valley in Fairfield CA!

reviewText: I got sick of paying so much money for DirecTV service that I finally canceled and got this HDTV antenna after reading the positive reviews on Amazon. It works great, and the picture quality is much better than DirecTV or even cable. I get NBC, CBS, FOX, ABC all in HD along with PBS and a bunch of other foreign channels (Spanish language, Chinese, Vietnamese channels). You have to move it around to get all the channels. Only complaint is the cord is too short to move it around to test and get all the channels, I had to buy a cable extension cord to make it long enough to move it around my condo. I would recommend keeping it attached to a window to get the best reception and all the channels. Would recommend, but make sure you also get a cable extension cord too.
summary: Great Antenna and Better Picture than DirecTV!

reviewText: While not as good as the HDMI connection for the iPad, this UBS-HDMI provides acceptable picture quality and good audio.  The directions are OK, but I needed a few email exchanges with customer service before getting it to run properly.  The documentation could be improved, but the response time and quality of responses from customer service was outstanding.

Updated May 28, 2012.Like other reviewers, I looked at similar Onkyo, Denon and other AVRs and the number of negative reviews of those products, along with the positive reviews of the Yamaha RX-V671 drove me to buy this one - and I'm sure glad I did. With the price occaisionally dipping below five hundred, I'd say it's a real bargain, price/performance wise. You'll notice that with the competitors in this price range there are too many complaints about difficult setup, difficult configuration, software problems, need for constant updating, heating, etc. The RX-V671 has none of those issues. I haven't even bothered to update the firmware and the unit works great, right out of the box!True, it doesnt support Airplay, as is, but CNET made too much of this missing feature - Apple users are not the majority, yet. Otherwise, it should have beat the Denon 1912 in their 2011 ratings, and CNET almost admits this.Clearly, on-screen graphic menuing is the wave of the future and Yahama is the leader. Today's HT setup can be complex and tedious, dealing with all the different standards for audio and video and all the possible tweaks and configurations. Before the Yamaha, I was behind, technically, with an old pro-logic setup receiver and had to spend some time reading and getting up to date on all audio and video standards and features. Even if you are an expert, you still have to apply that knowledge to set up a new HT system and the Yamaha makes that part much easier.The intiutive, on-screen menuing makes configuration and on-the-fly adjustments relatively quick and easy. There's always room for improvement in menuing and I can't say it's perfect, but it's far better than anything currently in this price category. One reviewer wished that adjustments per port and input/output sources were grouped together, adjustable all in one place. I agree, but I'm whining because it takes a bit more menu surfing than it should. Keep in mind, whatever configuration annoyance the RX-V671 has, the competition is far worse! For those who don't want to slog through the manual, I suggest you locate the following buttons on the remote: Onscreen, Option and Display. These three will open the onscreen menus and displays for all the adjustments and configurations. The Info button will tell you the current configuration from the front panel if your TV isn't on.That said, the YPAO does a great job of automatically setting up the speaker adjustments and you really don't have to do much configuring.For easy setup:Set your BD player to bitstream HDMI output. Select "Straight" on the remote and make sure your HDMI input ports Decoder Mode are set to "Auto" (Onscreen -> Input, select the port and then Up-Arrow to select Auto). Use the "Display" button to verify that "Straight" is selected.With the HDMI input ports Decoder Mode on "Auto" and the "Straight" button activated on the remote,  the RX-V671 will automatically configure the speakers according to the input.  The cable TV channels my have varying audio quality and surround but the Yamaha detects the input quality  and configures itself optimally in less than a second.  I keep this as my default setting because I like pure sound, the way the producer intended it.  But it is still easy to cycle through the "Music" or "Movie" settings on the remote for special effects or to synthesize 2 channel into 5.1.You can monitor the input quality and speaker configuration with the "Onscreen" button, then select "Information" and the port. The screen will show a detailed list of the input info and a graphic of the resulting speaker configuration.Once you are settled watching video, you'll probably like to try repeat pressing these buttons: Movie, Music, Sur. Decode, Straight and Pure Direct to see what you like of the various sound settings. That's it!I've had the unit about 10 weeks and and have explored over half the features and probably will stop there, that's all I need, and it's probably all most HT users will care about using.Samsung PN51D700Yamaha RX-V671Samsung BD-5500 (free with TV purchase)Cisco Explorer 4642HDC cable boxMagnavox DVR VCRZV457MG9old CD turntable and old cassette deckMartin Logan Motion 12 Front towersInfinity Primus PC350 center channelPolk Audio PSW 111 powered subwooferPolk Audio RTI A1 speaker pair rear surround
summary: Best in its class - Zero problems

reviewText: I bought a Visio LCD TV from a warehouse store 3 years ago (but I do a lot of purchasing on Amazon also). The same day I got home from total knee replacement surgery the thing wouldn't come on. The light changes from Orange to white, but nothing but black on the screen. I had been planning the knee replacement some time and had spent the previous couple years accumulating things like this TV and an adjustable bed so I would be comfortable so you can Imagine my frustration.I unplugged it and all that stuff to no avail. Next step was a Google search to see if anyone had any suggestions. OMG, see for yourself, Google "Viaio TV black screen of death". That's right, there's a name for it affects various models and sizes.Visio's response? "One Year Parts And Labor" $800 repair quote.Under no circumstances would I ever purchase a Visio product again. ZERO STARSGoogle "Visio TV Black Screen Of Death" Before You Buy VisioI have recently purchased a Sony 55" Bravia, FAR better picture than the Visio, no comparison.
summary: Google "Visio TV Black Screen Of Death" Before You Buy Visio

reviewText: I ordered theMarware C.E.O. Hybrid for iPad 2 Black (602956007722)from Amazon.com for my brand new iPad 2 and received it in the mail today. I was honestly very excited when it came in because I spent the last week almost trying to pick the right case, and this was it.What I loved about it:- Very hard outer casing, and soft insides.- Slim. No bulk.- Looks great. Like something a C.E.O would have.- Good pricing compared to other cases at brick and mortar stores.- Exactly what I needed and reviews were good.What I disliked about it:- Unfortunately, the camera hole on the back was completely misplaced; the hole was more than halfway to the right of the camera. At first I thought maybe the iPad wasn't installed correctly, but all corners of the iPad is clipped on correctly (it's straight forward) and closes like it should. In comparison with the back of my iPad to the picture on the box (which was one of its main features) the hole is definitely somewhere else by like four millimeters or so. I posted a photo on the images section of this product for reference.- Removing the iPad was harder than I thought and requires a lot of force to pull out, and this is without any screen protectors on the front and back of the iPad. I'm the kind of person that would sometimes take the iPad in and out of the case frequently for whatever reason.As much as I want to love this case, I am going to have to return it and look elsewhere for another case. My second choice would be the Case Crown version of the case. I gave two stars because I loved the construction and looks because it's one of a kind, but it's either Marware needs to double up on quality control or I'm just having a really bad day today.Fortunately, this doesn't happen consistently. I just happen to be the unlucky one to get this one. But if the hole was correct, I would've kept it without a doubt.
summary: Received a defective case. Camera hole out of place.

reviewText: if you want a cheap effective fish eye then here is your product. it was kinda confusing to figure out how to orient the "macro" lens part but then i realized it didn't matter. the pictures come out very interesting, im glad i got it. it will be perfect to take pics at a live event.

reviewText: The case is what I expected and just like the picture.  It is the perfect color and the 3rd generation iPad fits perfectly. Thank you! Great doing business with you!

But, and this is a big but, the cover doesn't really turn the iPad on and off very well, or every time.  My Smart Cover works MUCH better.  I admit I am disappointed. reviewText: Works as it should and the built-in level was a help.  It's probablly overkill for a 22" LED LCD, but I'm all for that.  Holds it pretty close to the wall so you may have trouble if your TV has inputs that would have a cable stick directly out of the back, but it's a slim wall mount so that should be expected.

Love this Tripod. Slick look. Matte Black Finish. Folds up upside down for convenient storage. Quality Contruction. Super smooth pan control for seamless side to side shots. Love the screw type leg locks over the clip ones. Clip ones usually snag on things in my trunk so this is awesome!Use it with my Canon 7D with a heavy zoom lens and have NO WORRIES WHATSOEVER about it falling or failing me. You bought an expensive camera. Don't let a cheap tripod drop it. 5 Stars! :DOn a side note: One of sections of one of my legs sticks a little bit when contracting... Not sure if some dust or something got in there making it a little harder to collapse. May be my fault. Isn't enough of an issue to knock a star...

I use this for computer backup. I run 1tb and 2tb 3.5" hard drives only and have had excellent luck with it. I have not tried hot-swapping the drives so I don't know if it will do that or not. Just make sure the drive is fully seated when you slip it in. Normally the weight of the drive does the job, but twice (in over a year with several dozen drive changes) one of the drives was not recognised by the computer. I shut off the computer, reinserted the drive, restarted the computer and it worked great. Being USB3 the drive access speed is just like the drives were internal. Way faster than my old USB2 backup drive. I recommend this.
summary: Connects 2 external bare hard drives to your computer

reviewText: I followed the instructions perfectly.  Had their YouTube video playing and everything.  I've installed many covers on iPhones and iPod touches, but this one was very difficult to align perfectly (took several tries and I'm very experienced with this sort of stuff).  At first there were 10 billion tiny bubbles, and it looked HORRIBLE, but per the instructions I left it alone for a couple days and sure enough the tiny ones disappeared.  However, there are still several bubbles of a larger type -- about the diameter of a metal clothes hanger if you cut it off.  These I could not get to move out initially with the tool provided so I figured they'd too go away as well.  But they didn't.  Fortunately they are close to the edge and I'm not going to rip the sheet off, but I'll never buy another one.

These are high quality headphones for the money. First of all the free shipping was very fast, it came two days ahead of time in a protected box. Second my friend has the new Beats by Dr.Dre and i had a bet that mine had better bass and sound.We got our other two friends who tried each one on, they said that mine had better bass and clearer sound.His tremble was only a little bit better, mine won though.Finally they are durable, they got dropped down my flight of steps by my nephew and didn't even have a scratch, just great.
summary: As good as Beats by Dr.Dre

reviewText: I bought these headphones to replace another pair that I've had for a few years.  I have to say that comfort wise my previous JVC's were more comfortable. It seems that the sony's have relatively small pads for the ears that sit on your ears as opposed to over the ears.soundwise, I would say that they are somewhat comprable.I do like that they come in red as opposed to all my black headphones.
There are some other hard drives out there, but I got this one because WD knows how to make them to last and this is no exception. It is great, and I have had ZERO problems with it since I got it!
I have used Verbatim's for a long time...I have nothing but good things with them.  AS LONG as you take care of them.  I keep all of my discs in cases.  They all work fine and I'd recommend them.

These are by far the best ear buds I've ever heard in my life. Highs,mids & low sounds absolutely extraordinary. These are definitely better then (Monster Beats By Dre). I definitely recommend these to everybody who wants great sound quality 5*****

They are really uncomfortable. My ears get sore after wearing them for like an hour. The big ear plugs get along best with my ears, but it still hurts after a while. I've gone to sleep while using different earbuds before with no problem, but these are a nightmare.They sound good, not great. First time I used them I wasn't too impressed, they sounded a bit muffled. The bass is good, not overpowered nor too weak. The highs are 'ehh' like I said they sound a wee bit muffled.For $18 they're nice headphones, and look really cool, but it's such a pain to wear them :(

Excellent Out Of Box Experience (OOBE).The stand was very easy to install and the box included a cheapy phillips screwdriver! Thank you Vizio for recognizing and addressing a very annoying issue. Little things like that make for a very happy customer.Batteries for the remote, two AA, were included also.The TV will need to be laid face down on a clear clean spot. Take a minute to make sure there is nothing, like the included screwdriver, in the way that might scratch your new screen. Last year, I scratched my new computer monitor like that on a power supply that was covered by a thin blanket on the bed.Setup was easy as pie. Just plug in the coaxial cable and set the channel input. We don't have an HDMI cable yet.Picture quality is excellent.On screen menus are intuitive for the most part. Lots of adjustments can be made - you can tweak broad parameters or nitty gritty.Here is a tip for you if you have DishTV. The picture was too big for the screen. I looked at a lot of settings but couldn't find the one that was causing this problem. Finally, with a lot of Googling, it turned out to be the *Format button on the Dish remote. Set the HD to 'Normal' and SD to 'Normal'. The TV remote is set to 'Wide'. That gives me a letter box picture that fills the screen correctly. We don't have an HDMI cable yet but I will update this review once we get one and switch over.Another bit of information that I gleaned - traditional coaxial cables are only capable of 480i resolution. You need at least RGB for higher resolution and HDMI is, of course, optimum. HDMI cables have version numbers. Unless you research it for your specific TV you'll want the highest version number you can afford. So watch out for clearance bin cables. It does make a difference. There are two broad categories of HDMI cables. High Speed and Standard. Standard HDMI data are rated at 76 MHz which is 1080i. High Speed HDMI are rated at 340 MHz which is full 1080p. Standard HDMI cables are fine for TV classes below 32 inch. Those TVs do not benefit from the higher bandwidth of the more expensive High Speed version.There are some conclusions to draw from the HDMI information I found. You can buy the less expensive Standard cable and rest easy in your purchase. Or you can buy the more expensive High Speed and future proof your purchase. The evolution of cable standards, reflected in cable version numbers, means that getting the High Speed now may be self-defeating since better cable specifications in a year or two will kill any advantage to buying the more expensive one now if you get no immediate benefit from it. The current highest version number is 1.3 as of July 7th 2012. Version 1.4 is on the horizon.This is a 6 foot one:BlueRigger High Speed HDMI Cable with Ethernet 6.6 Feet (2m) - Supports 3D and Audio Return [Latest Version]... in particular, even if you go with the shorter version, read the review by A. Dent about this cable. From what I've read, TVs 32 inch and up will benefit from the High Speed version....and this is a 3 foot one:BlueRigger High Speed HDMI Cable with Ethernet (3 Feet) - Supports 3D and Audio Return [Latest Version]Back to the TV itself:Really an excellent value for the dollar. If you aren't familiar with the Vizio brand, they are the largest LCD manufacturer in the world. They make LCD screens for other TV companies and computer companies.[UPDATE October 15th 2012]Wow! What a difference a cable can make! I recently got -AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable (6.5 Feet/2.0 Meters) - Supports Ethernet, 3D, and Audio Return [Newest Standard] - to use with the satellite box and this TV. The difference in picture quality is truly amazing. So, this 720p 32" HDTV does benefit from an upgrade of the coaxial to HDMI. I have the HDMI version 1.4 which is the latest standard but I think any HDMI version with 720p or greater capability will give you the best picture you can have on the TV. Shop around. That one I linked is an Amazon Basics item and it is a great value.[/UPDATE]
summary: Very pleased with this TV - Updated 10/15/2012

reviewText: This projector is awesome. I currently have it ceiling mounted projecting a 102" diagonal screen. The picture looks great even at that size. It is obviously a little washed out in normal light ie. Ceiling fan light or open blinds, but it still looks pretty good. It won't replace most everyday tvs, but it is really like being at a theater with the lights off. I highly recommend this projector for games, movies, and definitely sports watching. Having an a/v receiver makes cables so much easier. You will only have to run 1 hdmi to the projector and switch inputs through the receiver.
It fits snug and feels really good around the kindle. My only issue and reason for a 4 star rating rather than 5 stars is because of the high price.

The first one I ordered didn't work, so Amazon sent a replacement, and tat one didn't work!I called customer service and they sent me a new Kindle Touch.  It arrived today and the covers works fine.  I've not had a chance to use it in the dark, so I will have to update my review in a few days.I do like how I can fold the cover back flat on the back.  Not as bulky as the other covers I've tried.  I do wish it had a way to fasten the cover closed to protect the Kindle screen better when I carry it in my purse.

This is my first foray into A/V receivers and surround sound.  The receiver is very nice and can handle basically any type of input/output combination.  Has plenty of options and functions nicely.  The speakers and subwoofer are excellent and could easily fill my two story living room with sound loud enough to hurt.  Product arrived quickly and was exactly as advertised.  Came with enough speaker wire to wire all 5 speakers, but if you might need more if your back speakers are far away.  Haven't used the remote since we programmed out Tivo remote to turn the power on/off and adjust the volume.
Good idea, bad design.  iPad fell out given it can slip in and out of the top.  My iPad did fall out when removing the case from the car.

I really didn't know what to expect when I bought this little recorder.  I knew that it would record, and that I would hear playback, but I was truly amazed at the sound quality that this little gem gave back.  talk about being crystal clear - oh boy, this little recorder sure was.  And its volume level left nothing to be desired, either.  I have read complaints about the lack of a USB connection for getting files into the computer.  But that should not be a deal breaker.  A simple mini cord connector costs next to nothing, and will afford the opportunity to have said files duly transferred.  If you want something better than the recording program that came installed in your computer, there's a FREE audio program (Audacity) that would be all you'd need.  I paid $29.99 at my local Walgreen's store, just tonight, but am getting ready to return it.  So, why would I be doing this when I gave the unit 5-stars?  Well, the absolute most important thing to me (because of the way in which I will using a recorder) is the time/date stamping.  It is absolutely critical that I have that, and this device doesn't feature it.  I will be paying double the cost of this recorder, at Walmart, but it is needed. If it wasn't for that, I would most certainly be holding on to it.UPDATE:Reading through the product description of the next model up (forgot the model number) I came across nothing which referenced any Time/Date stamping.  So, methinks that I will be KEEPING the one I have.  This unit records so nice and clear - even while in my shirt/upper coat pocket, and I can't take the chance of standing away from that.  Yessirie - I will be holding on to it.

Excellent TV. Excellent quality image. Wireless setup worked great: give your wireless password and it just works. Every widget works great, with one qualification for the DLNA widget. The DLNA widget is great for watching family videos stored on our Windows 7 PC, but the current (August 31, 2012) DLNA widget got confused by my big music and photo collections and did not show the files in the right directories. I find passive 3D is more convenient (no batteries) and more comfortable than active glasses, as did my daughter who has an active 3D TV. The 3D looks great, as tested with the free online previews available on the VUDU widget (search for "3D"). My shipped 32" model did not come with the keyboard remote, which would have been nice for searching movie titles. The on-screen keyboard works and is as good as any other. Very low energy consumption (less than 0.5 watt) in standby mode.

I am very pleased with the tv, i thought i could only be happy with a Samsung but this one is great. I still need to check out the 3d and should do so tonight. there is a full keyboard on the bottom of the remote, netflix is built in if you have an account , same thing for hulu. It is basically a 47" tv. it was advertised wrong for some time & i hope they have fixed that part of the ad.it sounds good for a tv sound system , the hd picture is good also when hd is available. it was easy to set up including the wireless , there is a base that holds the tv nicely on a horizontal surface or you can buy a mount & hang it. buttons to turn it on without the remote are on the L side, the lower L corner is where you aim the remote. The first tv did arrive on time but the box was beat up real bad & the tv did not work so i had to wait on the replacement that did take another 8 days from when i had gotten the bad tv & i was all kinds of ready to watch & play with the tv right then. But the seller did take care of that as quick as he could and it did not cost me anything more. That was the first time i had any trouble with shipping from anything through amazon. I will update this as i find more things out about the tv.Update 11/16/12 3d looks amazing, almost and basically the same as in the theater. You will need a 3d capable bluray player and there is only so many 3d movies out there. I am very happy with this tv, facebook is easy to get on with this tv if you have internet at home, the keyboard on the bottom of the remote is very nice and works great when logging in or adding wireless codes. I also own a 46" Samsung that is hd but not 3d, i paid a couple hundred more for it 2 years ago & this tv is better for less $.UPDATE-12/9/12 the tv is only 47" i did measure it myself rather than trust the written description, although it did take another customer to make me check, it works good but was falsely advertised & i am emailing Amazon now. It still works great.UPDATE - 12/9/12the tv was described in the ad as 49.96 viewable inches it should state 46.96 inches, i hope & think that Amazon will fix this soon. they did make me happy after some time & reviewing of the situation.

I bought this on a black Friday sale at Wal-Mart for $300, I honestly didn't know they even made 3d tv's that were below 120hz. When I saw "3d" on the box I assumed it was 120hz. I tried playing some games in 3d on my PC with it and there was major flickering issues that gave me an instant headache. There is also A LOT of input lag with PC.I also tested a 3d movie, "The Amazing Spiderman", The quality of the movie was actually decent and the 3d was as good or better than the theater, the picture did seem a little washed out, and I'm fairly certain it was not running in 1080p.If you only want to watch regular tv and experience some 3d blu-ray movies then this is a good tv, you wont find a cheaper 3d tv, just remember that you get what you pay for. I am returning it to Wal-Mart tomorrow, thankfully they have an awesome return policy

summary: Love that it has 2 light levels

reviewText: I brought one of these from a warehouse club to go with aVIZIO 42 Inch Class Theater 3D LCD HDTV with VIZIO Internet Apps, E3D420VX. The unit was on sale for $105. This player was great for regular, blu-ray  and 3D videos, but I could not get any of the built-in internet apps to perform well .  Netflix would only load 20 seconds of playback at a time. I had ATT high speed DSL.  I then upgraded to ATT U-verse and WWOOOOOWW!  What a difference!Recently I saw the player on Amazon offered by QuickShipElectronic for $75 (refurburished).  I brought two more.  This was an inexpensive way for me to upgrade any TV to internet capability. If I buy another 3D TV I will already have a great player to go with it. There is also a wide variety of free programming.I would have given the unit 5 stars, but the USB port does not support a wireless keyboard for data entry on the web browser.

To set the stage for my review, all of my wireless access points are 802.11n (I've been upgrading over the years) with some being dual-band, and my wireless router for the past two or so years has been a Qwest Actiontec Q1000.  The Actiontec broadcasts all 802.11 protocols like this Linksys, but the two differences are that it works over a single 2.4GHz band and does not allow a USB device to be attached and accessed over the network.  I wanted to see if the second band at 5GHz would increase my throughput.  I use wireless for both internet access (on a ~25 Mbps network speed) and streaming HD video to my PS3 (which is wired to an 802.11n access point).Overall, I think that this is a good router with good performance.  I can't compare this against any of the other routers available today, but the following might help you make your decision.SETUPInitial, basic setup was incredibly easy.  Just follow the instructions in the box (load the included CD, plug in the router, run the software) and things should work smoothly.  Advanced setup (such as not broadcasting your network SSID, running two different networks from the two bands, running 802.11n only) was a bit more time consuming for me because there were no included instructions on how to do it.  There is a good manual available in PDF form on the manufacturer's website (it just took me a while to find it) that includes recommendations on improving performance and talks about how to set things up.  I wish that they would have at least included the link to it in the box (maybe they did, but I didn't see it).  As an aside, the browser-based setup on the Actiontec is a lot more graphically refined and a bit easier to use, IMO, than the browser-based setup on the Linksys.SPEEDWith my Actiontec, I was achieving wireless speeds around 70 Mbps.  After hooking up the Linksys and going through the setup, my speeds were also around 70 Mbps.  So, whatever is limiting my Actiontec is also limiting the Linksys.  I had hoped that the newer design, better antennas, or dual-band would have boosted it.  However, it is no worse and is still plenty fast for my needs.  The online manual recommends splitting the 2.4GHz and 5GHz bands into two networks for increased performance, which I did.  I still have yet to see if that provides me with overall better performance (as I'm surfing the web on my laptop over 2.4GHz while streaming video to my PS3 over 5GHz).NETWORK DRIVEI connected a USB drive to the Linksys and am able to access it from my PC and from my Mac.  This is my first network drive, so it took me a while to figure out how to map it to both - but once I did, it worked smoothly.  Unlike another reviewer, I could see the entire contents of the drive from both computers.  I had messed around with the router settings for sharing the drive before I figured out how to map it, so that might have done something, but I'm pretty sure that I ended up with the original settings when it was all done.  I do wish that my PS3 could see the drive, but if I understand correctly, I would need to step up to the EA4500 for the DNLA support.MAC TIME CAPSULEI tried running the network drive as a Time Capsule drive with my MacBook that is running Lion.  Unfortunately, I received an error like many Lion owners that the drive doesn't support a newly imposed protocol.  Perhaps a firmware update will allow it to work with Lion, but for now, it won't.  Older Mac OS's might work with it, though.  Linksys doesn't advertise that it will work with Lion Time Capsule, so I'm not upset - I had just hoped that it would.APP ENABLEDI might be missing something, but I think that this just refers to the app available for Android and iOS devices to control the router.  I downloaded it to my iPad and checked it out.  It works just fine with this model and allows you to change some settings.Pros:- Dual-band that can be set up as two separate wireless networks (one on the 2.4GHz band and one on the 5GHz band)- Four gigabit ports for wired connections- Sleek hardware design with all antennas being internal (the Actiontec antennas are externally attached)On my wish list:- Updated firmware to make it compatible with Mac OS X Lion in regards to using an attached USB drive as a Time Capsule drive- Inclusion of the user manual on the CD, or inclusion of a link in the box as to where it is located on their website- Mounting holes, or an included base stand, to mount it vertically to free up some desk space- A more refined browser-based setup

much easier to install than older WRT series routers but the Cisco Connect software has some serious flaws. Worst was that advanced settings couldn't be accessed. After two sessions with chat help, reinstsllling software--no help. then I decided to try a diff browser than IE8 and was able to access the router.  "Oh yeah," the chat technician said, "it's a browser compatibility issue. Why the chat people didn't suggest this two hours earlier, I guess was just to torture.The 5ghz band has much weaker signal strength than the 2.4ghz band, so even those few newer devices that can see the 5ghz do better on the other band. So, the dual band feature is nearly useless, certainly not worth paying for.Most of the devices I had set up on 5ghz kept having trouble finding the network so I had to reset them to the 2.4ghz band.This model gets pretty warm. It is designed to only lay "flat", you can't stand it "on edge." And since the top isn't truly flat but has a swollen curve to its shape, you stack it-- so the footprint is large.I'd recommend looking for a nice Netgear model. Cisco, who took over Linksys several years ago makes a lot of bussiness equipment but never really got the knack of the consumer product or service.
summary: You can do bettter for the money

reviewText: Okay, I gave this thing a 5 star review after hooking it up and configuring in within 5-10 minutes. Everything sorta seemed fine. I was connected to the internet...what could be wrong? Everything connected to the device wirelessly just fine.Then I started speed testing...What a shame... my speed tests are 1/4 the speed of my wrt54g - now how can the company that made this masterpiece (WRT54G) make this hunk of junk?I'm a huge researcher when it comes to buying electronics and I have to say - this thing might work great for N devices (I'm guessing here) but, it sucks for everything else including the wired connection.Pros: you get internet, it's easy to configure (although wi-fi drops frequently on wireless G devices - at least this one did)Cons: very slow internet compared to wrt54g, wireless signal is very weak - if you need a decent range router go with one that has actual antennas - also consider a dual band router.After reading many reviews and having first hand experience with this device - I have to believe they are having some serious quality control issues.other thoughts: I now have a bad taste for cisco/linksys products - ever since cisco bought linksys, they have products substandard equipment. I'm starting to think N routers are a myth. At least ones that work well.. I've tested a couple now and am hesitant to buy one due to none of them living up to my WRT54G standards.
summary: Okay I have to eat crow on this one...

reviewText: The device was easy to set up, offers guest access (they have to go to a website to logon rather than just selecting the network and signing on, which is not my preference) but configuration was a breeze.Looks sleek with a low profile.  I like that I can add a USB drive on the device for sharing, however I have not utilized this feature yet.Wish it had slots on the back so that I could have mounted it to the wall, but really, that's about it.

This router is very good, not as pricey as its bigger brothers but is very strong indeed, signal wise and processor power wise, i got this instead of one of the EAXXXX because i cant stand the ridiculous way Cisco is trying to push routing management to the cloud and making you agree to a TOS that wants to limit the kind of websites and traffic you can use through the router
summary: Amazing Router, not pushing the Apps stuff from Cisco

reviewText: I have a Canon Vixia HG20 and the Canon brand BP819 batteries run about $50. I've seen OEM batteries for sale on Amazon for about half that price, but I've always worried about whether the camera would be able to read the battery status of the OEM battery. I bought 2 other OEM batteries for about $15 each and the camera cannot read either of them. The other OEM batteries still power the camera so I kept them, but after using them for a year I don't want to buy another battery that the camera cannot read. The reason?  When I turn the camera on, the camera puts a dialog box on the screen saying it can't read the battery. You have to dismiss the dialog before you can use the camera. It's not hard, but it slows you down just long enough that I find that I miss shots. As a work around, I've learned to keep the camera constantly on so as not to miss a shot. This drains the battery faster so I always carry the second battery if I plan to shoot more than a couple of hours.Now that its time to buy new batteries, I was determined to get batteries that work with the camera. I bought this product because one of the other reviewers said his camera could read these batteries the same as if they were Canon batteries. I decided to take a chance on this kit because of Amazon's terrific return policy, and I'm glad I did. My camera can read these batteries! The charging cradle which enables me to charge batteries off the cigarette lighter in the car is a nice bonus.
summary: Works with Vixia HG20. Very happy with this purchase

reviewText: Just bought it so I could charge my things at work.  It works so far.  Not much else to say.

The look and feel of this product is VERY cheap.It is poorly made and describing it as having a fake-leather appearnce is not very accurate.....It really looks more like it was made out of an old picnic-table cloth.The look doesn't mtter tho, because it does not work as advertised.If you are considering trying this out there is something you should do beforehand.....Determine wether or not your device supports USB Host mode (acka USB Bus mode).If your device doesn't do that (and unless it is rooted it probably doesn't) then in order to make this work you will need a powered USB hub..... which is a tough item to find...and also a costly one....If you are trying to save a few bucks with this forget it....... sink an extra 30$ into a bluetooth keyboard and a folding case.

As the title states, I am using this in my bedroom.  The sound bar is hooked up to a computer and a Roku.  I use my bedroom HDTV to act as a computer monitor and to watch TV while falling asleep.  The sound bar replaced wired surround sound speakers that just looked "messy."  In my particular set up the following is where this system fails:- The sub-woofer and power box are two separate entities.  My living room Sony sound bar has both the power and sub together which uses less space. Not a deal breaker, just a minor bummer.- The remote works on line-of-sight and there isn't much forgiveness there.  Do to the angle of the set up in my room I have to get out of bed to change the volume/input/etc.  My bed is at a 40 degree angle from the power box and it will not register from that angle.  I am using brand-name brand-new batteries and have tried other batteries to no avail. (Note: Sharp does not supply batteries for the remote.)  If you have a funky set up and aren't going to get a straight shot from the couch/bed/wherever you watch TV to the power box, don't bother with this sound bar.- The FAN!  I have to say fan noises do not bother me.  I have a laptop which runs its fan the whole time it is powered up.  I could care less.  We have a air purifier with some fan noise, no biggie.  However, this things runs so loud at first I didn't make the connection and thought my desktop was going to blow.  If you are using this in a living room set up this may be ok.  However, using it up close while working at my desktop computer, it is unacceptably loud.  Also, since I watch TV before I fall asleep I play the sound at a low level and I find that I miss a lot of what is said due to the fan noise.  Had other people not mentioned the sound of the fan I would have thought it was broken or the fan was going bad.  Unfortunately it is not the case.On the pro side:- Set up was a breeze, they color code everything and you can truly have no audio experience to be up and running in just a few minutes.- The sound is actually quite good.  When it is loud enough to drown out the fan it is much more powerful and words are a bit more intelligible than my Sony sound bar.Sadly, I have actually only watched TV a couple times in my bedroom, rather than my couple decade long habit of nightly, since installing the sound bar system.  I now read until I fall asleep (a pro and a con since books have me staying up way too late).
summary: Not for a bedroom and/or desktop computer set up
