I travel a lot and mostly use my camera for travel photography.  I started with the wonderful D40, so I lean towards Nikon since I'm familiar with the menus and controls.  I have tried these cameras for travel:Canon G12 (401 grams) and S95 (190 grams) (very good but not wonderful picture quality bc of small sensor, very light and easy to carry);Nikon D7000 and D700 (964 grams w/ kit 18-55 zoom)(unbelievable picture quality but to heavy to carry for 6-8 hours of walking);Fuji X100 (440 grams)(great picture quality, very light but lens is fixed; andiPhone 4S (140 grams) (easiest to carry, fixed lens, but good picture quality under most conditions).At over 750 grams, the D5100 with 18-55 kit lens is heavier than most of these options and is almost too heavy to carry 6-8 hours.  The padded Crumpler strap really helps, and I don't load up with any accessories (no extra lens, no flash, no extra battery, etc.).  The quality, range and lightweight of the kit zoom is really what clinches this for me.  The Fuji is amazing, but I find there are too many shots I miss because of the fixed lens.  Plus, if I want to go super light and fixed lens, my iPhone is not a bad option.

...bought this camera about 25 days ago. So far I am impressed. This was my first DSLR. My other cameras are a Canon G12 and a Canon 310hs. The Nikon D5100 is a decent camera, and being a somewhat novice I have learned the suttle nuances of using the various Modes, Scenes and Effects. If you are a new buyer, read a few books on the D5100 first and plan your purchase. Learn all that you can about fast prime lenses, (1.4 and 1.8 35 and 55mm) zoom lenses (18-200mm and 18-300mm) and the kit lenses sold with the camera. For the money you can't go wrong with the Nikon 18-55mm kit lens purchased with the D5100. But do your homework, and read tons reviews and decide for yourself. You may end up buying a kit lens that you may not need. The 3 lens trilogy may work for you, or you may just need 1 or 2 lenses depending.

I take thousands of close up macro pictures always using a 35 inch high  copy stand. It was challenging for decades using  SLR cameras because I had  to gaze down into a viewfinder with one eye. Focusing was difficult.  I've used NikonNikon D100 6MP Digital SLR Camera,Nikon D70S 6.1MP Digital SLR Camera, Fujis, Sonys, Panasonic, and others going back to the 1980's. Because of uncertainty of exposure caused by back lighting, I've made three sets of triple bracketed photos for each item.Recently some photos were needed using the copy stand where the camera  needed to be over 3 feet high above the table of the copy stand. I had reached my limit as I used a ladder to be able to gaze down on the subject. There had to be a better way. MyPanasonic DMC-FZ150K 12.1 MP Digital Camera with CMOS Sensor and 24x Optical Zoom (Black)just does not cut it for back-lit photos, but it has an LCD screen which swivels out and I would not have to climb the ladder. But the FZ150 does not work well with back lighting.Then I saw the reviews here of the D5100.  It had the articulating LCD screen and was a Nikon SLR! But did it have bracketing of exposure?  It does! With such a screen maybe I would not have to use one eye looking down on a ladder. I could not order the D5100 fast enough. While waiting a day for my D5100 to arrive I watched  a videoBlue Crane Digital zBC141 Introduction to the Nikon D5100 : Basic Controlsseveral times to learn about the camera.Now for my experience with the D5100: It is much better than expected!  The spot focusing actually works, even with back lit objects. I never could auto focus before for these photos. The AF-S stock lens is constantly focusing in auto focus mode, so I don't have to press the shutter button half way every time I want to focus. That method did not work well for  macro close up shots with the older Nikons. With the D5100  use spot metering/focusing  option, and move the little box around the screen for the exact spot to focus on. The auto exposure  on aperture priority actually works too. I bracket anyway, but only have to take one set of 3 pictures for each item rather than three.The articulating screen is highly functional, and with the convenient position of the "live view" lever it's fast to go into that mode.  The AE+- functions works in live view, so I can adjust the exposure while seeing the results on the LCD screen instantly before the picture is taken.  The included 18-55mm lens does work for close-up work, and I can still use my old beloved Micro Nikor 60mm AF but without auto focus. Same with my Tamron 90mm f2.8 Macro, also without auto focus. The exposure functions work perfectly though. But it's just a matter of time  that I get more an AF-S micro lens such asNikon 85mm f/3.5G AF-S DX ED VR Micro Nikkor Lens for Nikon Digital SLR Camerasfor this camera.The battery life is so long I'm not using an AC adapter, which is a first for me.In summation, for production macro close up work using  a copy stand:Great swivel LCD screen with Live ViewAuto Exposure Control that works in difficult conditionsAuto Focusing on close up objects that works well in real time using spot focusingBattery life that goes on  and onConvenient buttonsReal time exposure control in LCD screenUltra sharp photosTakes old lenses (no auto-focus)Accurate white balance (after calibrating preset, see pdf manual)Brackets 3 photos quickly, no shutter lagProbably a great point and shoot too, but I prefer to not change all my macro settings for that such as white balance, bracketing, exposure, so I use myPanasonic DMC-FZ150K 12.1 MP Digital Camera with CMOS Sensor and 24x Optical Zoom (Black)with the Leica Lens for that...
summary: The Best Camera for Close Up Photography using Copy Stand

reviewText: for the price and the quality you cannot beat it. Night vision is great as well. I never have to get up and see who is at the door anymore. Stupid sales people drive you nuts and refuse to take no for an answer.

I found the basic set up easy enough. Resolution is good. I still have not hooked it up to the internet so no comment on how easy that is or isn't. I received one for Christmas. After 2 hours of troubleshooting and time on the phone to Vizio and to Panasonic, it turns out, this Vizio is not compatible with Panasonic Viera since the Viera only has an optical output that is encoded in Dolby. Vizio did not pay for Dolby license for this product and therefore can not decode the Dolby signal! It was a total waste of time and energy that could have been avoided if Vizio was more explicit on their packaging.... I was able to get the unit to work through my Panasonic Blu-ray player because there was an option to change the Blu-ray player's optical output to a standardized format instead of Dolby but I want a soundbar for the 98% of the time I am watching TV, not for watching Blu-ray movies in a non-Dolby audio format.  The sound was decent when I got it to work but not exceptional enough to rave about. Thank goodness the product was purchased at Costco so the return was painless.
summary: Not compatible with Panasonic Viera - NO DOLBY !!!

reviewText: This is a very well made device, its sturdy and durable in construction.  Also easy to connect to almost any audio system.  I connected this to our surround sound system in our home so that we can wirelessly stream music and podcasts from our iPhones to our home sound system.  The range is great, no line of sight issues at all, we can be in our kitchen behind cabinets and walls and it streams perfectly fine.Things you need to know:1. Only one device can be connected to this receiver at a time, but switching is easy.2. Volume control remains at transmitting device - which does seem weird, but it works.3. Just press the connect button on top of the unit and pair your devices, quick/easy.I'm very happy with this device, I looked at several options before buying this one and I'm glad I went with this model.  The other solutions out there look cheap and although they might work, this particular unit is great quality and works flawlessly.  I highly recommend it.

I just received this in the mail and after I got the *#%!* clamshell package opened, I had my first-ever Bluetooth connected audio up and running in less than five minutes.  Absolutely fool-proof, and works perfectly.  Overall, I am very happy.
summary: Simply awesome to the easily imressed

reviewText: I bought this TV after reading some good reviews. When I bought it, I was led to believe that it was a 120hz set, as was stated in the description until just a few days ago. It is a 60hz set in actuality. I'm unhappy about this, but it's not the end of the world.Pros:*Thin and light, as it's supposed to be.*HD media looks very good.*Holds colors very well from side-to-side angles.*Volume is very sufficient for the smallish room it is in.*Sleek design.*Very low electricity consumption.*Fairly inexpensive.Cons:*Not 120hz, as advertised.*Non-HD media looks anywhere from crummy to just okay/kind of good. From my reading, this is not restricted to just this set, and is prevalent in many HDTV monitors.*Picture washes out quickly when viewed from even slightly below or above level.*While cost is manageable, there are similar sized(even slightly bigger) sets that cost $10-$20 less, though I cannot comment on their comparative quality.I like this TV. I do wish that the original description had been accurate, as I spent more on this set for a feature it did not in actuality have. For non-HD media, I usually have to scale down from the 16:9 ratio to 4:3 ratio to make it look good enough to not be bothered. As stated though, this is a widespread problem with many HD type TV's and monitors. I personally paid $249 for this set, and it has since been as low as $239. I think it is a pretty decent product for either price.Thank you for reading.

I was shocked at Samsung for having a TV that did not work.  I have five Samsung TVs in my house with no issues.  I reorder a Samsung again and wilthout a hesitation.  I knew I was in for trouble when the box came re-sealed finger prints on the screen too.  I knew it was a returned product and they ( Amazon) sent it back out.  I sent it back to Amazon within 24 hours.  I give two stars only because Amazon sent out a defective product.  I know Amazon will make good on any product they sell, not an issue.

TV looked good in store but is actually quite poor when installed in home. It receives HD signal from Direct TV the same as our other Flat screen TV's but the aspect ratio is always streached and even after weeks of effort to correct this problem it still looks terrible.
summary: Amizon is gerat, Vendor is great, TV is poor

reviewText: This is just a speaker stand. You might be able to find this cheaper in a pawnshop or craigslist. The quality is just fine, but it's not a specialty item.
Keyboard/mouse combo was a good deal. Do pay attention that the keyboard is PS/2 and the mouse it USB, not BOTH.

Bought this for my early 2011 17" macbook pro.  The price was the unbelievable.  However, the performance was not at all what I had hoped.  There is apparently a known issue with this vintage mbp and this drive.  Every 10 to 15 minutes, the OS would beach ball and freeze; absolutely no response for about 20 seconds.  Then it would pick right back up where it left off and start clicking away at its tasks again.  That made it not able to be used for my model laptop. Similar issues are posted all over multiple Apple forums. Can't speak to how well it works on a Windows machine. That all said, I was not overly impressed with the read and write speeds either.  ~300MB/s Read and 180MB/s Write.  THe write speed is particularly lacking for an ssd.  I sent this back and bought a Samsung 830, which has turned out to be an absolutely amazing drive.  490MB/s Read and 390MB/s Write with no glitches or freezing.
summary: A very economical price, middle of the road, not for some MacBook Pros

reviewText: There is only one con with this (or any good SSD). Once you use it as your boot drive, you will pull your hair out using a computer with a traditional HDD.This thing is super fast. I put the 64GB in my MacBook Pro (don't need much storage on my notebook). Anyway, it boots in about 11 seconds from off to ready to use.Launching apps are snappy, opening files etc. It doesn't matter how awesome your computer is; if it isn't using a SSD as the boot drive- it's not fast enough.Trust me- everything runs faster on a SSD.People say these things degrade much quicker if TRIM isn't enabled, etc. But I haven't seen any issues yet. I've had this drive for about 1 year.I have a Kingston SSD in my wife's MacBook, and a Crucial 128gb SSD in my Mac Mini at work. All have been flawless and super fast.

Drive brings new life into an aging MacBook Pro laptop.  Super speedy, was able to get a third party utility to enable TRIM support for this drive.  Seems reliable and speedy for several weeks of initial use.
summary: Fast SSD for a 2008 MacBook Pro laptop

reviewText: For an elderly friend who also read the AARP ad I have been researching these computers.  Anyone in I.T. knows that you become tech support for friends/family...just how it goes.  After two decades in this field I have a fairly solid grasp on it.  So as I read the product descriptions and reviews I cannot help but think two things: (1) This computer is about twice the price of an identical computer that does not have the customized operating system shell.  What you are paying for is obviously the time and effort that went in to, and continues to go in to the development of it.  Is it worth it?  That brings me to...(2) All the reviews sound like they were written by the same person - conveniently listing each spec exactly, etc.  I have read thousands upon thousands of reviews over the years and the company crafted ones easily stand out.  I would caution people to take these reviews with a grain of salt.  Normal owners just do not write reviews broken into neat little spaced sentences each extolling another wonderful feature complete with the exact spelling and terminology the manufacturer uses.  I would also caution people to take the same suspicious approach with AARP, NRA or other organizational ads - since many of these advertise anything that they get a percentage of.This may be the greatest computer ever invented for elderly folks.  It may be a piece of crap.  Unfortunately no one is going to get an honest answer from the reviews here.

I like this sleeve. It protects my MacBook Air so I can carry it with another laptop in a standard laptop bag or just carry it alone. When I first got the sleeve, it seemed as though the MacBook Air did not insert far enough into the case for the tab to easily snap shut. After about a month I realized that this was because there was a pouch of desiccant jammed into the bottom of the sleeve. After removing that, I found the sleeve is a perfect fit. The sleeve is not made of leather but it is stiff and protects the MacBook Air from scratches and bumps well. The eject tab works well. You can charge the computer while it is in the sleeve because one side is exposed. I haven't found anything else as easy-to-use and functional to protect the MacBook Air as this sleeve.
summary: Nice sleeve for the MacBook Air

reviewText: I'm using this device now for the last Year on my sons car to keep track of my insurance premium :-)It does not look as professional as some other devices, but thats also reflected in the price and does not make any difference in function.I have the device hard wired into the car and the power consumption is minimal. My son does know I am tracking him, and it will be removed once he pays for his own insurance, and he is OK with that (well he has too). Nice feature is the possibility to set up boundaries in areas I dont want him to go as well as speeding notifications, which I had several over the last Year.Sometimes I do not receive the latest position but that's due to a weak cell area, however the units keeps track of it and send an update once it is back online.So far no issues at all and does what it is supposed today at a low price. Can't go wrong on keeping track of the little maniacs :-).

I own two of these and just bought one for my mom. It's an affordable stand that folds up to store in a computer case or purse. The stand is sturdy and has enough positions to make it very useful. I use mine for my Nook Color. My mom uses hers for her new tablet PC so she can use the device and not accidentally touch a part of the screen she doesn't need. I'd purchase one of these again.

This is a fairly nice unit (for the $$).  Other than that it does not work very well.  I will continue to try to make sense of this unit and if there are any other developments.  I will amend this review.
Use it to clean all of my optics.  Never streaks or leaves residue.  Dries completely and very quickly. There is no other liquid like this medical quality, refined solution.
summary: It's refined, it's pure, It's a fantastic cleaning liquid.

reviewText: I got then watch when I started training for my marathon.  I also do Insanity/P90x type workouts, and previuosly used a watch with a heart rate monitor to track my HR and my calorie burn.  Let me just start this by saying that this watch is not the watch for you if you want to just track calorie burn during indoor workouts.  I'm now going to spend a few minutes discussing the main function of this watch--tracking your run.I used both the shoe pod and the GPS to track my runs.  They work well together, and having the quick-start available for times when the GPS was a little slow to connect was good.  I liked the fact that I only had to tap the face of the watch while I was running to change laps, or check my stats.  I liked the fact that the buttons were big and easy to use while running.  I liked the fact that the numbers were easy to see even when I had sweat in my eyes.  The GPS function worked pretty well, and I liked the ease of use of the Nike website.I didn't like the fact that it simply couldn't function very well as a calorie counter.  It did fine when I was running--calorie burns were about what I expected.  But when I was using it for Insanity, it only worked calorically for some of my workouts.  Also, it tried hard to assign a distance to the workout--whatever workout I was doing--unless I turned off the shoe pod.  That was ok, but interestingly, the distances would vary wildly depending on the day.  Sometimes, a p90x workout was given a distance of 2 miles, when I did it all in my living room--and sometims, it was only given 0.3 miles.  That was odd, and would have been of no big importance, but if you are using the Nike software to track your stats, there was no option to declare one of your workouts purely a weight/calethenics workout and keep the "nike fuel" earned but not include distance totals (which were meaningless).  This was a mild frustration, but one that Nike should have forseen.There is no capability to monitor bicycling distances, speed, etc.It worked variably with indoor equiptment--it didn't work at all with my elliptical.  It worked fairly well with a treadmill.Here is the watch killer for me--This watch is supposed to be water resistant, and I put that to the test, to my sadness.  It worked fine for a while in the pool as I was swimming laps, although it never could track my distance that I swam, or even my heart rate when I was wearing an appropriate heart rate monitor that should have worked in the pool.  But ultimately, after one of my swims, the watch just stopped working.  I had only had the watch for 4 months.Also, the interior portion of the band broke, which chafed my wrist.This watch has a lot going for it if you are only planning on using it to track your runs.  For that purpose and that purpose alone, it is a great watch.  But for what I wanted to use it for--swimming, running, p90x/Insanity, bicycling, elliptical running--all around sports--it was a failure, and now I have a broken watch that does not function because I swam laps in it.I hope this helps other sports enthusiasts know what they are getting.  A great marathon training watch--but not the right watch for anything else.***Update:I called Nike, and explained the problems I'm having with the watch.  They quickly replaced the watch, and I'll give it another try.
summary: A good start, but a bad finish.  Ultimately, unreliable for the all around sportsperson.

reviewText: I bought this for a HTPC setup.  The fan run around 15% speed at most times and is basically inaudible.  Really helped with the Windows experience index.  Plenty of option to optimize video quality.  Very happy with the purchase.

I purchased this tripod to support my Nikon Action 10x50 (7218) binoculars, which tend to get heavy with prolonged use. The tripod is a perfect fit. I'm not a professional and this is my first tripod, so I don't have a point of reference to speak to. I tested the tripod in my backyard with the legs fully extended and the multi-level locked in the 10 degree position. With the center column fully extended, my binocular lenses were exactly at eye level (I'm 5ft9in). The pan and tilt worked very smooth for me, as long as I did not over-loosen the tilt tension knob (which would allow the binoculars to free fall). NOTE: There is a bolt that secures the quick release plate to the tilt ball head. I had to really tighten this bolt (it uses an Allen wrench) securely to prevent excessive jittering while moving the binoculars. After that minor maintenance, I had no problem with jittery focus while panning and tilting. However, when I released the binoculars (removed my hands), there was a one second jitter of the focus on the subject (hope I'm explaining that correctly). Once the jitter stopped (one second), the subject (Venus) was once again in perfect focus. For my purposes, that's not a big deal. The extension, retraction, and overall adjustment of the legs worked very smoothly. The quality of the construction feels very solid to me. I am completely satisfied with this Dolica tripod.
NEEDED A REPLACEMENT MODEM.USUALLY USE MOTOROLA MODEMS.WELL WITH THE DOCSIS 3.0, HAD TO GO FASTER.WITH THIS MODEM, I GOT A GOOD PRICE.AND WITH AMAZON PRIME. I GOT IT QUICK!!

This is an excellent modem.  Does everything the manufacturer says it does.  I just got Amazon Prime, so delivery was very fast.  I've only had the modem for one day, so more details when I add to this review in about six months.It was very easy to set up.  Three connections and it was all powered up and set to be activated by my service provider - Comcast.  The actual time it took for Comcast to activate the modem was less than five minutes, but it was between the time I first dialed Comcast until the modem activation that was the aggravating part.I called Comcast on my cell phone because my home phone was voip.  After the initial recorded "Thank you for calling Comcast", I was asked to enter the telephone number of my service.  Then I was given a menu.  Press "1" if you want this, "2" if you want that, "3" if you want that "4" for everything else.  Since modem activation wasn't on the menu list, I pressed "4".  I then got another menu.  Press "1" for this, "2" for that "3" for that, and "4" for everything else.  Since modem activation wasn't on the list, I pressed "4".  Then another recording "I'll connect you to a customer service representative.  There was the sound of a phone ringing "I'm going to finally activate my modem and see how it works", I thought. I got another recording. "All our customer service representatives are busy.  Approximate wait time is ten minutes".  I really wanted to activate my modem, so I waited.  Finally someone answered the phone in a very cheerful manner.  "Hi.  My name is... Who am I speaking with?... how are you today?"  I told him what I wanted to do.  He said "I'll connect you to our internet service dept".  I got another recording telling me that "All our service representatives are busy.  Approximate wait time is three minutes".  At this point, I was shaking and I accidentally pressed the disconnect button on my phone.  Ordinarily I would be happy about that, but I REALLY wanted to activate my modem, so I called Comcast back.  I had to endure all the number pressing I was required to do.  Then I finally got someone.  I told her that I had accidentally disconnected the phone and apparently she had all the information already. "Oh, you wanted to be transferred to our technical dept".  "Yes".  She transferred me.  After waiting a few minutes I finally, finally got to a person that could actually activate my modem.  I gave her the model number, serial number, and mac address.  I was all set and back on the internet in five minutes.One thing that was particularly aggravating was the fact that every single person I talked to at Comcast tried to sell me something like upgrading my cable tv service or getting their telephone service.  I had to listen to their spiel and explain to them I was very happy with what I had and I had no desire to upgrade.  All I wanted to do is activate my modem.I think Comcast should cut back all the ads they put on tv, all the junk mail they send out, and the sales calls they make to their customers.  I've had several calls from them trying to get me to upgrade, so much so that I've blocked their calls.  Even though the calls are blocked, my phone lists who called and when.  Last week, they called twelve times in one afternoon, even after I told them not to!The bottom line is:Amazon - FIVE stars for a quick deliveryMotorola - FIVE stars for a great productComcast--ONE star for crummy customer service, but friendly people and who finally activated my modem.I suggest that if you have to call Comcast, be retired or set aside some time to deal with them.I have a little postscript to this great adventure.  A half hour after I got my modem activated, a car hit a utility pole and knocked out cable service to my area.  I didn't know it was an accident at the time - I thought I had a faulty modem.  I called back Comcast.  I had to endure the same menu items, then had a ten minute wait for a customer service rep.  When someone got on the line, I told him the problem I had with my modem.  He said "Just a minute...Oh, I'm showing an outage in your area.  Turn on your tv.  Are you getting a picture?"  No I wasn't.  "As long as I know it wasn't my modem..."  "Can I interest you in upgrading to 60 channels or maybe getting a dvr.  For at least the fifth time, I said "No.  I'm very happy with what I've got".Six hours later I got my cable service back.

I was concerned that the minute difference in thickness may be an issue between the iPad2 and iPad3 but my case fits great! Only negative so far is that the edges are a bit rough. I will take one of the wife's fingernail files and solve that problem quickly though so not a big deal at all. Especially at this price!This case will scratch and show scuffs. There are many quasi-generic sturdy tripods to choose from in the $100-$200 price range and they all appear very similar on the surface. I have owned 3 different sturdy tripods in that price range, and this one is the best overall. The hinges are very easy to work with and the drag head is very smooth (and slow), which will not allow for rapid pans. I've used this tripod with the Sigma 800mm lens (weighs 10 lbs) on multiple shoots and it functioned flawlessly. Having used this "CBA"(cheap but amazing) tripod on demanding shoots for 6-12 hours a day over the span of 3 weeks with no problems at all, I'd buy another without hesitation.

While this product does exactly what it says and works great, I just don't see how it's more useful to me than switching out the occasional two AA rechargeable batteries.  First, it has a giant USB cord that means one more cord on my desk and another outlet that I can't use on my USB hub.  No big deal, but again, is this really necessary?  Second, charging means putting up with a blinking green light that, while not all that large, still ends up being distracting and annoying.  Third, the size of the battery stick that you use instead of the AA batteries is just large enough that it sticks out of the side of myIncase CL57575 Origami Stand Sleeve for Apple iPad and iPad 2, Black, which means it's gotten scratched up in my purse.  Again, not a huge deal, but for what end?Lastly, the charge actually seems to last a LITTLE bit longer in theDuracell Value Charger With 4AA Pre Charged Rechargeable Nimh Batteries, CEF14DX4I was using than in the charger bar.  I ran a somewhat controlled experiment (granted, with variable amounts and times of work from a normal month) with each.  The Mobee Magic Bar charge lasted from February 20th (out of the box) till today, March 8th.  Once it got to the end of the charge, I slipped it into the charger and that part was admittedly easy.  However, I just don't know if I use the keyboard so much that this ease is really worth the price.  I'm a writer and graduate student, so my whole day is spent on the keyboard, whether on my laptop (use the keyboard on the bottom level of the desk and set the MacBook on the top level) or on the iPad2.  The AA batteries I had in my keyboard had lasted from December 30th till February 20th and were still at 25% when I put in the Magic Bar instead.  I think they're a better value and less hassle.In all, this thing works great, but only if you really need it.  As other reviewers have mentioned, you should consider your usage level and the price before committing to this expensive solution to a problem that might not exist for you.
summary: Lots of product for little use in my life

reviewText: I've only had the battery for two months at most and only drained it about 9 times and it's only reporting 50% maximum charge.  Even at a low cost this was a bad purchase.  Also just to note but doesn't bother me (it's the run time of the battery that does)... the color is off and it sticks out about 1mm more than it should.

Let me begin by saying I first bought this for my Fuji X-Pro 1 and extra lens, but then I sold the Fuji and "came home to Jesus": a Nikon D600.*** Comment updated on Nov 13 2012, after a month of traveling in Europe with the bag ***Make no mistake, as is usual with Think Tank, this is THE BEST, most well built and assembled camera bag you will find anywhere. This and the wapiti straps (not available @ Amazon but Mr Google can solve that problem in 5 seconds) are a perfect combination. This is a solidly built bag and for someone to snatch away they would need to take you with them, it is that good! I traveled with the flap turned toward my body whenever I was in a crowded space or worried for safety and it is perfect. Also, it doesn't scream "camera bag". I'm even buying my new one in black to make it even more inconspicuous (although this color is nice too).Also, it is a beautiful bag. The flap has the "silencer" mechanism with the velcro and that is a very good thing to have in many places. The strap pad is very comfortable and, at least for me, the bag sits nicely where it is supposed to and it is not a bother to carry for longer periods of time (no, I would not go jogging or doing sports with it, it is not made for that). And there is the added bonus that it does not screams "camera bag" from looking at it. Even my wife, when she held it for me a couple of times, remarked how comfortable the bag was (with the D-600 with Nikkor 24-70 f/2.8 attached inside it).Having said that, let me divide this in two parts:First for the mirrorless and small DSLR crowd - it is a good sized bag and I was able to take my Fuji X-Pro 1 with the 35mm attached + 60mm lens + extra batteries on the loose inside side pockets (don't like this aspect of it...). On the front compartment I took a couple of filters a cleaning pen and the rain cover which I have never used. It is sufficiently padded and offers good protection for the camera.Now, for the BIG DSLR owners... I thought I would have to give this bag as a gift when I got my Nikon D600, even though I loved it. But, to my surprise, the D600 fits with the Nikkor 24-70 f/2.8 attached just fine. You won't have space for anything else (I'm buying a Retrospective 20 for that) but for a day shoot with just one lens it is perfect. If you put the camera lying down sideways it fits perfectly, but mostly I used it with the camera "standing". The flap closes fine and for those hours when you are just taking it out or putting back in repeatedly, it's great.Obs: when using the Nikon D600 I need to take all padding out. I guess I could put it beneath the camera for extra protection, but I feel it is just good as it is, never thought twice about the amount of protection I got. Also, for the plane rides, the camera was inside my Pelican case and this became my "messenger bag", with documents, my Ipad, a pocket sized book, candies, toothbrush and other stuff, so I didn't need to get my overhead bag for nothing.Obs 2: the inside zipper pocket and outside back pocket on this bag are, in my humble opinion, useless for anything other than a map, perhaps one or two filters. I used it for that end, carrying the city maps of were we were, plus tickets, cleaning pen and tissue for the lens and a circular polarizer.To sum it up: again in caps to reinforce it THIS IS A VERY, VERY GOOD QUALITY BAG, you are getting what you are paying for, trust me. I based on it and the other bags I've seen and the other one I'm buying, I would definitely recommend any product from them. I've owned more than 20 camera bags in the recent years and this ranks at the top in terms of quality.OBS: I've recently parted ways with this Retrospective (gave it to my mom for her Sony NEX system) and bought aThink Tank CityWalker 10 Messenger Bag, Blue Slate Nylon, to go with aThink Tank - Sling-O-Matic 10 Sling Camera Bag. A great combination for travel, as it gives me lots of room and 2 day bags to choose from for my camera gear.
summary: Exceptional - And I use it with a D600!!!

However, the Kaito 801 is doing all the same and is actually thinner (although a tick wider), but costs $ 20 less at Amazon. Note: It has 4MB built in storage, even if the the text is stating 2MB.Both are from the same manufacturer and I assume that both are much alike inside. I couldn't spot any difference in performance, only the minor body size variations and that the areal of the Degen is slightly longer.If you want to save the 20$ go for the Kaito KA 801, if you want the slightly more upmarket looks, have the Degen DE 1126. Booth are highly recommend and available at Amazon.

reviewText: I couldn't figure out where to put all the screws. Instructions consist of diagrams that leaves you scratching your head even though it seems simple.It is two pieces. One hooks into the other. It seems very stable without all the screws being used so I'm very happy with it compared to paying out the nose for other mounts. I'd buy it again.UPDATE 9/23/13 : Moved my bedroom around so i had to move the tv. I was able to remove the mount easily and placed it on a different wall. Note: you will not be able to align all three holes to a stud, but go for the top and bottom. I did in each installation and the result is excellent. Very sturdy. I love the fact that when i need to mess with wiring behind the tv, i just lift, bring the bottom toward me and unhook it from the mount. So easy to deal with. So glad i purchased.
summary: I just hope nobody touches it

reviewText: I have had this computer for about 6 months and I adore it!  I use it every day for at least 7-9 hours, so it has been fully test-driven at this point.  It is fast, reasonably quiet, has tons of storage, and has been very reliable so far.  The quality you get here for a very budget-friendly price makes this an investment I haven't regretted one bit.  Acer really hit the mark with this gem.

This power supply blew out after 3 days of use.  Not only that but I'm surprised it worked that long considering the shabby way it was packaged.  There was no packaging/padding at all in the box when it arrived meaning it had been banging around in the box all the way from the shipper to my home.  VERY dissatisfied.

I love these things. They're much easier to deal with than those little plastic boxes that hold four batteries each.  All you have to do is pull one item out of your bag and pop batteries out of it. Quick and simple, no fumbling with a bunch of little boxes, dropping the batteries, etc.Unfortunately the first one of these that I ordered was damaged, but that seems to be due to improper packaging. Whoever packed my order put  the storacel in the same box with a larger heavier box inside it, and the air inflated pilow packaging wasn't enough to keep the heavy box from sliding around. So I'm guessing that the heavy box hammered into the storacel during shipping and cracked it. This sort of repeated hammering while the storacel is empty doesn't seem very likely to happen in normal use, so I don't really fault the durability of the product.I'd rate these 5 stars, but they just seem more expensive than they should be, so I'm subtracting a star for what seems to me like a somewhat inflated price.
summary: Awesome holders, just a little expensive

reviewText: No question that this is a fine product, and if you're in the market for a radio that will receive 17,000 radio stations, this is it. But I find that I listen to only two: Pandora and my local classical music station, so this radio is really overkill. Moreover, though it must have been built in the same factory with the Logitech Squeezebox, the latter is a more attractive product overall. True, the Grace has a larger screen with color to boot, but usually when I'm listening to the radio, I'm *listening* to it, so the screen isn't a high priority. Both screens are adequate and readable; truthfully, I think the Logitech screen is a little easier to read. Finally, there is that big button sticking out of the top of the Grace. I suppose it's just me, but I find it detracts from the "graceful" lines of the product.Note to Pandora lovers: I miss the ability to "look back" on both the Grace and the Logitech. Perhaps I'm spoiled, but that ability alone is why neither the Grace nor the Logitech will ever replace my Chumby.

As a scientist, I first started using computers in 1958 when many of my fellow scientists were content to use only slide rules. Fortunately, the world eventually woke up to the importance of computers which have been one of the most important inventions of the past century. But much as I fell in love with the power and potential of computers, I was disappointed with desktop computers until I got my first Macintosh. In my opinion, Apple computers, including this iMac, make PCs seem awkward and clumsy to use by comparison. Yes, Macs are a bit more expensive than most PCs, but they are still quite affordable and definitely worth the extra cost because of their superior performance and convenience. The people I know who have tried a Mac are very glad that they did. This is the most powerful new iMac available and has a huge 27" screen. If you are looking for a great desktop computer, this is it.

I got this item from Amazon.com as an open box item for $1499, I couldn't pass up such an amazing deal. The machine rocks as does Amazon.com and their customer service. I was able to get next day shipping for $3.99 as a PRIME Member, and we all know this was probably around $100 to ship next day.iMac is fast, I installed an SSD in it to make it faster. I just followed this guide. [...]
summary: It's an iMac... what else to say?

reviewText: This is my eighth Mac. The sleek slim appearance of the new iMacs is a matter of taste. It does mean laptop chips are used to save space (and power), along with a compact, slower hard drive. This is not exactly the latest and greatest technology in all respects. The absence of an optical drive (CD/DVD) in the new 2012 iMacs is highly controversial. Apple is pushing us toward internet connections instead, increasingly wireless, and deeper into the Apple ecosystem of iCloud and App Stores that it controls, and gets 30% from. Question is, how often do YOU need CDs on your Mac? If you do need a drive, Amazon has several that are actually less expensive, faster, and more reliable than Apple's own optical "SuperDrive." So hopefully we save a little money not getting one built-in. Most of them can sit quietly on the iMac's stand discreetly under the screen, stacked with a compact back-up drive if you wish. (Lacking a CD drive could be much more problematical with a laptop.)Less explicable is omitting FireWire, a connector that Apple pushed so hard, and now abandons in favor of Thunderbolt (to which few products currently can connect), and right alongside speedy USB 3.0 (a great improvement on USB 2.0)! There's no longer a pulsing light to let you know a dark screen is only sleeping.The new screen, allegedly 75% less glossy (reflective) than the previous models, is a great selling point, IMO. There IS less glare, while the bezel is as shiny as ever (lovely fingerprints), but maybe you don't have to grab the iMac so hard to adjust its angle, for the machine is much lighter than before. The screen is a bit shorter as well as wider than the old 20" model. Because it stands a little lower, it should be easier on your neck if you wear bifocals.I am now using a trackpad and gestures, another direction Apple is pushing us (a la iPhone and iPad). I hated the one on an old iBook, but the sensitivity now is much better controlled to eliminate close passes in favor of an actual touch--all sorts of touches in fact. (No idle drumming of fingertips!) I find it odd that in order to get a "right click" I need to also hold down the Shift key, just like in the old one-button mouse days! I think trackpad use may be tiring: it takes a harder push than on a mouse to produce a "click," and there's no place to rest hand or wrist without activating something unexpected, eh? The trackpad and keyboard both slant up rather than downwards, and have no tilt adjustment. I thought ergonomists showed the healthy trick was to keep your wrist straighter, by keeping your hand level, or even sloping downwards away from you.Customer service: I spent a very pleasant 1.5 hours online with two Apple technicians getting OS X Mail to work. For the first time in years I can open Apple's OS X Mail (rather than continue with a different email client). These folks are amazingly good! This experience is also a warning about using Migration Assistant: it can bring forward arcane bad settings from your earlier computer. It can also "break" some of your non-Apple software (e.g., Microsoft, Adobe, Epson), requiring you to re-enter product codes, or even insert an original program disk!!! (You do still have them, right?) Apparently not a problem if you bought them recently from Apple's own App Store. The Apple website has vital information on what to do on your old machine before using Migration Assistant.Otherwise, setup is fast and amazingly easy. Apple does it right. It then took me about a minute per GB to migrate old files, twice the forecast time. Startup time with OS 10.8.2 on this machine is just 20 seconds!

Replaced our 24in iMac with this Thunderbolt display and 13in i7 Macbook Air.  Only hiccup was I couldn't get all the top button functions on our wired Apple keyboard with the number pad to work.  For example, the screen brightness could not be adjusted with the keyboard.  But a simple initial reboot was all it needed.  Now we have an awesome replacement for our iMac with a bigger screen and greater portability.Still had to remove a star because there is still too much glare.
summary: beautiful and pretty much plug, reboot, and play

reviewText: The articulating bracket is solid metal, HOWEVER the coldshoe is soft plastic. When clamping my flash in the coldshoe for the first time (note--I was tightening it with my fingers rather lightly), the metal screw stripped the plastic. I never even got to use it.

reviewerName: Mark R. Davenport Jr. "Mark R Davenport Jr"
reviewText: This is a excellent powerline network kit no lag what so ever when I'm playing SWTOR aka Star Wars the Old Republic and Battlfield 3. It was sooo easy to setup just plug in and play. Download and web page loading times have gotten better over wifi gotten over 10mbps speed increase!

Camera is compact, but well designed and flexible to mount on several monitors or use with laptop.  Video and photo quality is good as is microphone.  I have used with Mountain Lion.  Install software, run update, execute software, plug camera into USA port (supports 3.0) and camera is recognized.  Capable of 1080p widescreen video.  Comes with a USB extension cable.  Also supports Photobooth, Facetime, iMovie, etc.  As for Windows, I haven't tried it yet, but I have the Webcam Pro 9000 running under Windows and I am sure this will be good in that environment.  Also, this camera can be purchased at the forty price point on sales so I think it is a good value.

These headphones are overrated, poorly built, AND NOT BETTER THAN THE EP-630s. The connection between the wire and the earbuds is cheap, flimsy, and weak because there is absolutely no support. It seems like I could pluck the earbuds off the wire like a pair of grapes. The covering of the input jack is also poorly built. It slides along the metal base, and so I can see that the second layer of insulation beneath the outer layer is ripped. The difference in sound quality is hardly noticeable between the EP-630s, but I feel that the EP-630s are a better bet for your money, time, and peace of mind.
summary: Overrated, Poorly Built, Worse than the 630s

reviewText: Does the job and the price is good.  The software included is minimal and doesn't include playback of blu-ray movies.
summary: blu-ray r/w at a good price

reviewText: I'm going to keep this review short and sweet.I purchased the MediaDevil screen protector for my iPhone 4S, and was extremely satisfied with the quality of the protector, the ease of application, and the great communication by MediaDevil. They emailed me right after my purchase (even thanked me for a positive review via Twitter!) and wanted to hear from me if I had any trouble. I didn't of course, the instructions were simple to follow and the installation went smooth.The package includes two protectors if you were to mess up on applying the first one. A quick note on application, I recommend dabbing the screen down with a strip of tape to make sure all debris is removed from the screen so there isn't any stuck under the protector after application!I purchased two more of these for my friends, and also recommended the iPod touch protector to my friends. I highly recommend MediaDevil for quality products and service.MediaDevil is like the Apple of accessories in the sense of the level of quality and service they have to offer.
summary: Quality product, always recommend MediaDevil screen protectors!

reviewText: From begining to end, OWC has not let me down.  Great product...a very essential tool for any computer tech.  You've gotten a loyal customer from the Aloha State.  Hope to do business again soon.
summary: Swiss Army Knife for any technician

reviewText: These adapters are great and I use them almost daily in my business. I've had them for about eight months and I can't see any reason to buy any other brand especially given the price. They are way faster than any drive I can test them on. They work out-of-the-box with Ubuntu and other linux distros I've thrown at them.The best part about these adapters is that they allow for the transfer of SMART data, which can give you important information when diagnosing drive issues. Many adapters and enclosures don't provide this, so I love having one that does!

Got this unit after reading excellent reviews on this line of XFX, Seasonic sourced PSUs.The rebate that was available by the manufacturer at this point and time was also making it a great deal for a 80+ Silver 850W modular PSU. Surely more and more 80+ Gold units are getting more affordable, but 2% efficiency difference will need more than 5 years of 24/7 operation @ 400W load to make up the $50 or so added initial investment - at least in the continental US were electricity is dirt cheap.Building quality appears to be solid, and the cables were easy to tidy up in my CM 690 II. Keep in mind that the 8pin CPU cable (part of the non-modular bundle) was a tight fit in this case and a Asus P9X79 Pro motherboard. Users of bigger, full tower cases might have an issue with that an could require an extension)Some people complain about semi-modular PSUs but I doubt that anybody will be likely doing without the 24pin motherboard connector or the 8pin CPU connector, while most cases can easily hide those behind the motherboard tray.Unfortunately I was unlucky with my purchase, and got a defective unit. After experiencing weird ripple on the +5V (at least that's what my eye caught), I had the PC shutdown itself while under F@H load in the middle of the night. Seconds after my attempt to reboot it, a loud noise - probably from a capacitor blowing inside the unit - killed the PSU. I do believe I was unlucky, as there are numerous satisfied users of this line of XFX PSUs in enthusiast forums, yet having this happen to you on a unit that was out of the box for 4 days, and really working for around 20H, is something I wish to no-one. No other component was killed by this failure (CPU/Mobo/Wifi Card/RAM/GPU/SSD/HDD) all working fine.Amazon was extremely fast in responding to my return and refund request. Returning the item did not cost me anything more than printing a UPS label and delivering it to a nearby UPS store.I did not opt for replacement, as I went and bought another PSU the day after, and did not want to wait for the RMA process in order to get the unit replaced.
summary: Great PSU on paper, with some QC issues.

reviewText: OverallA company called Dunu creates headphones (or earphones) that are well built and come with plenty of accessories. You can visit their website for more information or to view other headphones in their inventory (dunu-topsound dot com). They retail for $73 and were sent out to me for review (price may vary).ReviewThe DN-11's feature a single balance armature driver. The earpieces are coated with 50 ' 24k gold. The 3.5 mm jack is also gold plated. The Ares headphones have good build quality and have clear & good sound quality. The bass is lacking compared to other headphones as it does not have a thumping sound. The cable management system does what it is suppose to do but it's not an adequate solution when the cable tangles and keeps it shape (headphones are wrapped around the hand in a circular motion to use the management system). The price is very high for these headphones so I would suggest passing on these and finding other headphones that have better sound quality.ProsMany different ear tips to choose from for the proper fitDifferent cases/pouches to useGold plated jack for better sound quality (than silver plated)1.2m cord lengthFairly clear sound qualitySeparation of sounds such as being able to hear the guitar or piano and when the instruments are being used at the same timeCord management directly on the headphonesCord is thin (may or may not be good to some users)ConsSmall tips are hard to installSound seems jumbled in some songsCord tangles and keeps it shapePrice is a bit highBass is lacking (could use a bit more)

I bought one of the generic composite-video-to-hdmi converters. It sucked power like crazy, had no on/off switch and worst of all, it had so much lag that Mario Kart etc. were completely unplayable. Not just bad, impossible to play.This little gem got everything working properly again. No cable clutter, powered by the Wii so no wall wart external power supply needed. Seems like decent build quality, time will tell.

reviewText: As a travel mouse it is perfect. It has an off switch, it is low profile and stores the adapter for you. As a desktop mouse the low profile nature is off putting for me. My wife hates the touch scroll but I find it interesting after you've gotten used to it. it definitely takes a certain touch to get it to work right every time. I have the adapter on the back of my PC about 5 feet away and it works w/o issue. I really think it's a nice solidly build mouse that just isn't quite right for either of us. I'll keep it for travel so I'm not really out anything.
summary: Great travel mouse okay desktop mouse.

reviewText: I'm giving this 4 stars only because it didn't completely cover the screen on the new ipad.  Other than that, it was a good product.  The package comes with a sticky paper to clean the surface (screen) of the ipad.  The screen protector went on very easily - no bubbles.  I was done in a matter of a few minutes.  I purchased another screen protector awhile back, similar to this but a different brand (that I couldn't seem to find again on Amazon>  That product was a bit better.  It covered the entire screen.  Also it was washable and reusable.  I think this one would work the same way if it gets dirty underneath, wash it with dish soap in warm water, rinse well and let it dry (actually I was in a hurry so I dabbed mine with paper towels).  This was done on a similar screen protector for my old ipad.  But, overall a good product - just a slight bit too small around the outside edges.

Over many audio apps, radio.com, iheart radio, shoutcast.net I find buffering delays. Even Skype will only stay active on a call for a few minutes and then quit.  Not hard to restart a call or music but why bother?  Look elsewhere if you like to listen to music or make phone calls.  The web is rife with buffering delay complaints for this tablet.  I don't know if it is hardware or softare but Android apps that play music work fine on my Android phone for hours but quit after a few minutes on the K1.  I have had two automatic upgrades in two days and it is now running Android 3.2 with no change in the buffering issue.  Youtube seems to be OK.  Not sure if I will take it back.  I did not get it from Amazon.

I think this tablet is a really good one. With some software bugs but thanks to Acer and their up-dates they are already fixed.Love the Andriod Market and their apps maybe a less apps than the apple market but good and getting better.The screen is nice and I love to watch movies and you-tube videos.

Terrific tablet. Acer has provided significant support. Purchased this item about 9 months ago. Acer has provided Android updates. Now using 4.0 (Ice Cream). Better visuals than the competing non-Android system. At half the price you get twice the performance.
Excellent compact external hard drive.  Works fine on USB 2.0.  Used my own backup software without problem.  I recommend this hard drive.

reviewText: Its a great board I suppose but I have just two problems with it. The audio channels cannot be modified....I had an MSI board before this and I was able to plug two separate (regular) speakers into the audio ports i.e., the green and blue ones and they played with out problems. On this  Intel board I can ONLY use the green port for my speakers, therefore I'll have to purchase an audio splitter to facilitate my previous set-up.My other gripe is with something I haven't totally checked out as yet but so far the Virtu software for my unlocked i7 2nd gen processor refuses to install, it claims there is no onboard GPU present!! Now I've read where this may be due to me having already installed a  video card, but come on, isn't this software supposed to be able to decipher between video cards and the onboard GPU and choose which to use regardless of which one's port my monitor is plugged into??!!! I can't be bothered right now but one of these days I'm gonna uninstall the video card and try the alternate set-up using the onboard GPU of my processor and gain attempt to install the Virtu software.Oh one other thing, the Integrated Assistant software doesn't install easily (if any at all). After downloading it, I had to unzip it to a folder from which the executable file worked but wasn't really installed in the traditional sense to the computer. I ran it and tried, with some effort, to update the BIOS as it was reportedly out of date...a lot of problems ensued after a "reportedly" failed attempt at my BIOS update...my Intel Desktop Utility software (monitors the temperature etc., of the system hardware) stopped working, and my computer crashed so I had to "system restore" it. After running system restore, surprisingly enough the BIOS was actually updated but the Integrated assistant software no longer worked as it claimed it was no longer compatible with the motherboard (sigh). I no longer use it (ppbbt!).Outside of all this, it's an ok mo'board.

I got the diffuser along with the flashhttp://www.amazon.com/Neewer-TT560-Speedlite-Digital-Cameras/dp/B004LEAYXY/ref=pd_ys_iyr19Very nice product,its fits my flash and  the quality is fair for the price I paid.

People on here are given the wrong impressions of this DSLR Stabilizer. For the price that it is, its well worth every penny. People on here complain about the stabilizer not balancing correctly is because they don't take the time and balance it right. I am going to be honest and say it did take me some time to do so. (About 2 hours) But what do you expect? You pay less and you just have to put in more work to balance it correctly. You can pay more for a stabilizer that is already balanced for you. The only thing is that once you add or subject an item on this stabilizer the process does have to be re-balanced. But i'm fine with that if i can save myself a couple thousand dollars. It's not bad once you get the hang of it and now what you're doing. Just give it a try. All these negative reviews are of frustrated customers not knowing how to work their equipment. It takes time and patience to understand what you're doing. Leaving negative reviews doesn't help anyone out if you don't know what you're doing with your stuff. It not the product's fault, it's your fault.

Very compact and good looking. It is actually smaller than my old WD Passport 500GB in terms of length and width. A few things that would have helped1. A Carrying pouch or case is missing2. Any software to take backups and restore data.

As has been said before, this takes 8 "D" (not C) batteries.The sound is much better than I expected. boomybass and crisp highs for a boombox.The remote is strange as others have mentioned, but not really that bad. Just remember to turn the remote led blue to control the boombox and orange to control the ipod/iphone. Its not that tough.The thick instructions book is pretty bad and only a few pages long for each language translation. There is no control for sound like bass or treble in the boombox. You have to control sound through the device. I have an ipod nano 3rd gen so I have no "direct" device control. I do have all the ipod control I need through the boombox mode (next, last, pause, on/off). I cannot control the ipod menu through the remote. I have to use the ipod ring to play shuffle or a certain artist, etc. The ipod sounds great through the box.I hook up my XM to the box through the 1/8 aux jack and it sounds great.I really like this box. Its quirks are pretty minor.
summary: Its a nice unit with good sound

reviewText: It works with my iphone 4 perfectly. I can now watch Netflix with my projector through the iphone. Only downside is it doesn't have a pass through for charging so it's best to have a fully charged battery before connecting this thing.

This is a great monitor. First off the stand and monitor are very sturdy, especially for a LED monitor. The default height is actually a bit higher than most with quite a lot of room to go even higher. This is because you can also view the monitor vertically. I only needed a little tweaking to calibrate it, and the colors and black levels are spot on. This is my first IPS monitor and the extra price was definitely worth it. When the price drops a bit I am going to switch out my old Samsung 23'(which now my secondary monitor) with another one of these.
