reviewText: Great monitor to mount using a desk stand. Better than combining two samller ones becasue we can easily change orientation (portrait/landscape) and watch HD widescreen movies. It is less expensive, too - considering the cost of a decent tandem desk stand. Very lightweight and great image quality.

I purchased this 24" HDTV for a gift for my mother for her birthday.  Limited space in her bedroom (where the TV was to be placed) made me choose something smaller, and for less than $140 shipped I received a solid LED HDTV with a 2 year warranty.  A great buy and a purchase I would make again in a heartbeat.The picture is bright and clear, with several settings in the 'Set-up' menu that allow you to easily customize your viewing with pre-set views like Cinema or Eco, or with manual adjustments to contrast, color, etc.  The channel labeling is a cool feature that allows you to rename channels or inputs so you know exactly what it is, the way you want to remember it.Scanning for channels is also done in set-up and it took approximately 3 minutes with 'antenna' vs 'cable' as an input (rabbit ears attached to the TV) to find 10 local analog channels and 8 local digital ones.  All the major networks in HD came in clear through the digital tuner in this TV.  We will be hooking up cable to this TV, but I wanted to set it up with an over air connection first to check the tuner out, and it works well.The remote doesn't have back lighting so that you can easily see it in the dark, but that's not a big deal and certainly not expected at this low price point.  It gets the job done!This set would be perfect with aPaper Thin Leaf Indoor HDTV Antenna - Made in the USA!orLeaf Plus Amplified Indoor HDTV Antennain your RV, or in an urban area with lots of over the air channels, and aRoku HD Streaming Playerwith Netflix and Hulu Plus subscriptions.  That combo could make cable unnecessary!I love that it has inputs galore! VGA (15-Pin D-Sub)- for PC monitor function, composite, component video, RF input, USB and 3 HDMI ports.  Outputs: SPDIF Out.This HDTV would be a great buy for someone who wants a 24" monitor for their PC and a TV.  Ideal for a dorm room in this way as it could serve as a media hub for a Roku, game system, PC, DVD player or just as a sharp 1080p capable HDTV.Sound and picture can be set to automatically adjust to what's going on in the room.  This is a cool function and I played with it, leaving the sound on 'auto', but changing the picture back to manual as it seemed to be too dim for my liking when I was testing it.My Mom loves the TV and that her Roku pops up as a channel versus having to switch to a specific channel like '3' to view it.  Amazon Instant Video movies come through crystal clear via the Roku on this set, generally streamed in 720p or 1080i.  She also loves the Sleep Timer function for Late Night viewing.This is a small HDTV with room for expansion via it's many input ports.  Great picture, nice sound with ports to add speakers for an even bigger sound if you choose.The TCL 24" is also one of the thinnest LED HDTV's I've seen.  Unobtrusive stand that's easy to attach to the TV, and an updated look that would easily fit into any decor.  The TCL 24" HDTV is really impressive when compared to theVIZIO E220VA 22 Inch Class Edge Lit Razor LED LCD HDTVI own in its design, inputs and performance.This HDTV is a super choice for anyone who wants a quality TV backed by a 2 year warranty for versatile use, without a big price.  You can't go wrong with this one.  Buy with confidence and enjoy!
summary: Versatile with multiple inputs, excellent quality and picture

reviewText: Well, although i dont realize much difference from my $15 sony headphones, the construction, engineering, and quality put into these headphones is tremendous, there are different sounds here and there i couldnt listen to compared to my other headphones, but doesnt meant they dont sound great, and i bet theyll last 10x longer than my previous headphones.

After getting my tax return in March, I was wanting a decent Android tablet in the $200-$300 price range.  I wanted something with at least a gig of ram and decent hardware.  I found the Flyer on Buy.com refurbished for a can't refuse price of $189, and at the time it seemed like a no brainer.  But if I had to do it again I'd would of waited a couple months, here's why:I really prefered something with Honeycomb or ICS on it, and upon hearing the Flyer had an update to Android 3.2 I was sold.  However I had no idea how bad the honeycomb update was.  More or less Honeycomb breaks the Flyer.  It becomes slow and laggy, animations are choppy, game performance regresses, the GPS is broken, and compatibility is half what it was with gingerbread.  But thats ok the Flyer has plenty capable hardware, and its less than a year old so surely HTC is going to update it to ICS right?  Wrong.  HTC left the tablet broken with no further support because they decided they didn't get enough sales, so they ditched the 3 tablets they made and exited out of the tablet space all together.To make matters worse, now that I'm stuck with my flyer, Samsung made an excellent Galaxy Tab 2 7.0.  My roommate bought one, and it is excellent, and comes with ICS already.  And now their are talks of an Asus google nexus tablet coming out in a sub $300 price range with an Nvidia Tegra 3 Quad core, really makes my decision of the HTC Flyer seem bad.But now I got all the bad stuff out of the way here's the good stuff.  The tablet is fast and responsive on gingerbread, and HTC made a lot of tweaks to Sense to make it more tablet like and less of a gigantic phone.  The screen is vivid and gorgeous, and you'd think it was a Super Amoled the contrast is so nice, but its not its just a regular LCD.  The Battery life under moderate use is excellent and you can easily get a week out of the battery if your a light user.  The hardware is nice enough to run any game smoothly (on gingerbread) so if you want a tablet just to play games this tablet will suite you fine.  It actually has the same SoC as the Sony Ericsson Xperia Play, with an extra 512MB of ram so games are no problem for this tab, also the processor is clocked at an insane 1.5 gigahertz, so while its a single core, its faster than a lot of dual cores.  The Build quality is nothing short of excellent in classic HTC fashion.  It is a bit thicker and heavier than the competition but the overall feel is solid, and its not by any means massive, it still small enough to be portable.  The Back camera takes excellent pictures if your into that sort of thing, and the front camera is, well a front camera, but one thing I never understood is why manufacturers put the camera in the top right corner in portrait orientation on a tablet.  This works fine on a phone, but on a tablet your face will always be off centered.  HTC apparently had the same thoughts I did on a front facing camera, and put it dead center on the top, holding it in landscape orientation.  This makes the Flyer excellent for video chat with google talk, or skype.  The Pen is also a very unique feature, but I don't use it as the pen is still to this day expensive even with the flyer being discontinued.Overall if you want a small portable tab for note taking this tab is for you, but otherwise if you can't find it cheap I'd look elsewhere.  It's ashame because the device is really brilliant and has excellent hardware but it was a poor effort on HTC's part with marketing and giving up on it so quickly.
summary: Great hardware, solid build quality, poor support from HTC

reviewText: As described fully in the product description it is really good to have for people who travel lot and work off office most of the time. While in office you would prefer to use a scanner which is quite cheaper than this.As it works in both mode, scan and can be use as a mice. But I would recommend only use it while scanning, if you want to use as a mice, buy another cheap one and keep both in you laptop bag.I bought it for my friend in India and he loved it, because its not like US that everyone have personal scanner at home. It is off much much use for him while making presentation, the software it has can easily convert the scanned page text which can be edited in MS Word.I would say it is a quality product.
summary: Tech savvy people should keep it

reviewText: it does what it says it will do.  Very sturdy, doesn't slip. Holds my iPad 3 in any of a number of positions.  Saves me from propping the iPad up on some random item on my desk and watching it fall.  The only slight negative (which is the only issue that kept this from getting 5 stars) is that when I opened the box for the first time and removed the little strip of packing tape that kept the stand folded during shipment, some of the finish peeled off with the tape. (I bought the silver finish.)  But so what, it's on the back and doesn't affect functionality.  I would buy it again and recommend it without reservation.

At the time I purchased this unit I had checked literally every tablet available on the mainstream market.  While other tablets were going at three-sixty and above, this was available at two-sixty (and has lowered in price since then).As a note:  every review I've read giving this one star had indications the individual received a defective pad (and likely would have changed opinion if they'd exchanged it for a good one).  While defective units are quite annoying and perhaps quality control needs stepped up a bit, it does mean the resulting reviews are based on failed units.  One cannot judge a tablet from a single defective unit.  The comments about a "hypnotic screen" are not visible on my unit, and the statement from the same reviews that the battery only lasted an hour or two indicates a problem unit.  My unit lasts, as advertised, 4-5 hours.  If one puts the screen on max bright or regular wifi use, of course that will reduce significantly (wifi does suck down a lot of energy).  Other bad reviews indicate the user didn't know how to use Android (ie, shut down non-used applications) and could benefit from reading online manuals and forums.The gravometric unit works fine, and it accesses all the popular Android markets (including Google and Amazon).  Included software can be somewhat garbage, but there are always alternatives.  Camera and video work well.I find only two flaws with this tablet: 1) There are better viewscreens (this one fairly blurs out in daylight) and 2) It cannot power from the USB port (which means power drains while plugged into your computer rather than charging).  That does mean it won't drain the power of a laptop, but it is inconvenient to have to plug in a separate charger (which is included with the unit).Those two flaws mentioned, the system rocks.  The dual core is fast.  Screen response is very good.  Dual speakers (unfortunately both on one side of the unit, but does provide better volume).  Lots of plugs (USB, HDMI, MSD card slot, ear phones) as well as Bluetooth and wifi.  No availability for Internet access other than wifi (a definite disadvantage, but then, no monthly charges either), but that's not unusual for units of this type.The system is well-built and sturdy.  I've dropped it twice (once on concrete) without serious damage (thankfully) so it can handle some punishment (not that I'd recommend banging it around).  It is small enough and designed well so that it fits in a suit jacket pocket (be careful when bending forward, that's how I dropped it) or purse.  Overall I find this unit to be well-made.  The screen is all but useless in daylight, but one has to realize it doesn't cost five hundred bucks.  Since buying it I've received two major Android updates from the company free of charge.  I have no real complaints with this unit, especially for the price.

I bought this tripod collar for my Canon 70-200mm f/4L IS lens.  I considered the Canon tripod collar but at it's ridiculously high price I opted for the Fotodiox mount.  Am I glad I did!  This is a solidly built piece of hardware.  All metal construction.  It feels extremely solid.  The inside is padded with rubber so it doesn't scuff up the lens.  The locking nut is solid and very securely attaches the collar to the lens.  Don't waste your money for the Canon name - this Fotodiox mount is superb!

There's not really much to say about a product as simple as this. They appear well made, and they work as advertised.  I have over tightened them and had a time freeing the elements from each other. Placing the female end next to a warm surface, like your body, and allow it to heat up. The ring will expand enough to loosen the ring.I use these with legacy lenses and an adaptor. There is no electrical contact for auto focus and aperture, so you might as well go with manual lenses.With macro, the act of capturing the image is as satisfying as the results, so forget about auto everything and delve into the joy of being part of the creative process.

I have purchased a few longer cables for my iPhone in the last year, but all 3 of them have failed in a matter of months. Two were like a regular iPhone cable (only longer), but they either broke on the external case or the wires internally. The 3rd seemed to be more heavy-duty, but als it only lasted a few months before it just stopped working for no reason. Now these cables were only used for bedside charging/using the iPhone while charging & never treated roughly, but they still crapped out in a matter of months.....then I found this one. It came today & holy crap I must say I don't think this cable will be failing any time soon.....it's quite MASSIVE!!! The cable itself is right at 3/16"...which is about the same size as the cable of my keyboard, but it feels much more rigid. I use it with my phone in an OtterBox, so it is a "snug" plug-in. It takes a slight bit more force to push it in all the way versus the standard iPhone cable, but nothing too bad. At least I know it won't accidentally come unplugged LOLI tested it for charge & with iTunes transferring a few pics off the phone to the pc & it worked fine. I haven't used it yet to transfer large amounts of music to say whether it's faster, but I would be VERY surprised if it wasn't given the size of the cableThe 10ft is probably longer than I really need for what I use it for (bedside charging/using phone in bed while charging), but looking at the companies 6ft version this one looks ALOT "beefier" so I'll deal with the unneeded extra length ;)
summary: RND Power Solutions black EXTRA long sync & charge (10ft) cable made for Apple

reviewText: OVERALL:  A good MP3 player which operates on a single replaceable AAA.  Good for audiobooks and other general purposes.  It is also sold under the Coby brand at 2x to 4x the price of the Irulu version.  Despite comments of other reviewers, it DOES play standard WMA files (e.g., made by ripping CDs with Windows Mediaplayer).  I have not tried protected-WMA files.FOR AUDIOBOOKS:> Folders play in the order loaded.  Tracks (within folders) play in alpha-numeric order.  So, if your audiobook  is in multiple folders (as it will be if ripped from CDs using Mediaplayer), then load the folders, one-at-a-time in the order you want them to play.  The tracks within each folder will play in the proper order.> If you stop play, turn off the player and restart, the player restarts where you left off--perfect for audiobooks (oddly this feature is NOT available on most other MP3 players).> Plays MP3 and WMA files.  Also plays many other file types such as WMV, ASF, WAV, etc.> The included earbuds are adequate for listening to audiobooks.FOR MUSIC ALBUMS> Folders play in the order loaded.  So, load your albums (folders) in the order you want them to play.  Tracks (within folders) play in alpha-numeric order.  If you want individual tracks to play in a different order, then add alphanumeric prefixes, such as "aa", "bb" or "01" "02" to the names of each track.  If you stop play and turn off the player, the player restarts where you left off.EARBUDS:  The included Airline/Apple-type earbuds are poor.  I recommend Coby J-budsJBuds Hi-Fi Noise-Reducing Ear Buds (White)J-buds are great for use in public or noisy places.  At home, etc., inexpensive behind-the-neck headphones are the most comfortable.GE 95352 Lightweight Behind-the-Neck Headphone (Black)PROS> Nice swiveling connector.  With a key-type clip or "caribiner" (not included) can easily attach to beltloops, etc.  Alternatively, an easy way to carry the player is from a short light neckcord.COSMOS 5 pcs Black Neck Strap Band Lanyard For Camera, Cell phone, mp3, mp4 and other Lightweight Electronic Devices> Takes a single (changeable) AAA battery, which I consider more convenient than having to plug into a computer when the rechargeable battery (of other players) dies.> Unlike many MP3 players, can be operated by touch because the three control buttons are at distinctly different locations (top, front, and bottom)> Built-in full-size USB plug is nominally a plus, but most computer USB connectors are recessed, which means you need a short USB extension cord anyway.> Numerous options (equalize, shuffle etc.), if you want to bother to explore and set them, but works fine "out-of-the-box" with the default settings.> Thank heaven for the lack of a stupid "repeat" button, which can accidentally get you caught in an endless loop.  Repeat is available via the menu if you want it.CONS> Neither the USB plug cover nor the battery cover are attached, and therefore are easy to loose.  To replace the battery, you have to remove both covers.> The "mode lever" is too easy to move--probably a problem if you carry the player in your pocket, but not so much if you "hang" it from a belt loop etc.> Most functions depend on pressing either quickly or less-quickly, etc. It often takes alot of fiddling to do what you want to do. It could use a dedicated "navigation" button.> It is hard to tell which selection is chosen in the menus, because selections are indicated only by a slight shadow.> Unnecessarily large and bulky (compared to the Creative Zen Nano {no longer available} which also ran on a single AAA battery.> When you turn it on, a tiny message "starting" appears which is hard to see.> There is no indication on the main display what folder you are playing. (although a great amount of other useless information is displayed)> Other than the display freezing, there is no indication that you are in "pause" mode.BASIC OPERATION:> Insert an AAA battery, plug into your computer USB port, "drag and drop" MP3 or WMA files from your computer.> To turn on, press the big "ON/OFF/PLAY/PAUSE" button in front.> With the "mode lever" select "MSC" (music).> To play, click the "ON/OFF/PLAY/PAUSE" button.> To adjust the volume, click the + or - toggle at the bottom of the player> To move forward one track, click the "mode lever" to the right> To move backward one track, click the "mode lever" to the left> To move forward within a track (to "fast forward"), push the "mode lever" to the right> To move backward within a track (to "reverse"), push the "mode lever" to the left> To pause, click the "ON/OFF/PLAY/PAUSE" button.> To turn off, press the "ON/OFF/PLAY/PAUSE" button> To restart, press the "ON/OFF/PLAY/PAUSE" button."click" means to press and quickly release; "press" means to press and hold for a second or so; "push" means to push and hold as long as necessaryIn short, the "ON/OFF/PLAY/PAUSE" button is very easy to find by touch and handles all routine operations (except "forward" and "backwards"), which is very convenient.MAXIMIZING BATTERY LIFE:  The best strategy to maximize battery life is to use J-buds (or similar in-the-ear earbuds) mentioned above.  They are very "efficient" which means that they produce the same volume at a lower power drain.  To test the efficiency of headphones, just plug them in and listen (without adjusting the volume)---the loudest will be the most efficient.INSTRUCTIONSDespite the complaints of other reviewers that the "manual" is poor--in fact it is better written and more complete than most inexpensive Chinese electronics.  Oddly the instruction "manuals" vary between the colors.  If the three players I purchased (red, blue, black), the black one came with the most complete instructions.

Some of my friends have already bought these headphones for themselves after I raved about them. I fly almost weekly and grew weary of crying babies and sinus-snorting neighbors. These fit comfortably and block most of the noise. They fold neatly into the carrying case which has enough room for my Ipod and reading glasses.

Bought this to use in the ocean and at Atlantis water park with my Nikon AW100 Waterproof camera (awesome! see the review).Twice my camera floated out of my pocket when I didn't have it on my wrist and my shorts pocket velcro failed me. Twice I quickly discovered my camera floating nearby. Once in the ocean and once in the pool.  Very cool! The orange was highly visible as I had hoped. It floated just enough above the water that it was easy to see.Some people complained that the clasp looked flimsy or would break. I didn't have that problem and the plastic seems to be of good quality and so far not brittle. The string that attaches to  your camera seems thin but did the job for at least 9 days in the Bahamas. The whole thing had also done a 2 day stint in a chlorinated pool and no wear and tear seemed to occur.  I learned to have faith in the clasp. The only thing I would warn is that it has a right way and a wrong way to connect. If you don't align properly I could see it coming unclasped, but it takes very little to get in correctly and snaps satisfyingly when correct.The floating portion of the strap was not as bulky as it looks online and while not a fashion statement, also doesn't look ridiculous on my thick wrist or my daughter's slender one. It adjusts to wrist size as well, so no worries about fit.All-in-all, I highly recommend this strap, especially at this price point.
summary: Small, comfortable, and does the job. Saved my  camera!

reviewText: The keyboard works great and has great controls for the iPad.  However, the main purpose of my purchase was to use my iPad instead of my laptop, but the weight of the weight of the iPad and the keyboard was about equal to that weight of my laptop.  It was also less convenient to carry both the iPad and the keyboard instead of just the laptop.That aside, the keyboard and stand work great and I would recommend it to someone who wants to use their iPad to write notes, do emails, or other tasks that require a full keyboard if they don't have a small laptop they could use.

Pros: The size (it is pretty small and lightweight) and case, which doubles as a tablet stand. The keys feel good despite the smallish size.Cons: No Windows key, and I cannot make my tablet respond to the function keys. I would certainly appreciate any pointer on how to do this.On the whole, convenient but flawed. Not horrible, not great. If you want a smallish, easy to carry Bluetooth keyboard, this is not a bad choice, if you are not too picky.
summary: Decent, but it has some flaws

reviewText: Really like this, as it is lightweight and matches my iPhone 5. Get about 2.5 full charges of the iPhone 5 in less than 20 minutes. The only thing is that I have to carry around a Lightning cable with me, and it is kind of long and awkward with the charger. Will update review after a few months of usage.

This is not a very polished product.  It can do many things, but none really well.  The interface is clunky and the sound is marginal.  I listen to podcasts.  I bought it for use in my kitchen when cooking, working outdoors and for use in the bedroom.  The sound barely overpowers the kitchen noises or the ambient outside suburban noises but works well in the bedroom.The speakers sound tinny (poor lows) and by no means entertaining or lively, but functional.  The internal battery (probably one of the best features) charges quickly and holds a charge for a reasonable time.  The screen is small, and weirdly half-gold and half blue.I definitely wouldn't have bought this knowing what I know now, and struggle to find successful uses for it.
summary: A jack of all trades, but master of none.

reviewText: I have purchased three of these. They connect well together and pack a punch. Battery life lasts forever. Easy charge easy connection. Small, compact, and amazing!
The internal wifi on my laptop was acting up. I disabled it and plugged in this device solving my problems.
summary: Great replacement for laptop internal wifi

reviewText: I put this in a new build, and as one would expect from a Corsair product, it functions flawlessly. Memtest86 shows this memory to be a very good price/performance value.

I really wish I could respond with unbounded enthusiasm for this device because that's what I was hoping for but unfortunately, at least for me, it is a complete bust.  In either mode on my Lenovo laptop all it did was create a profile that was slightly brighter.What it created for my Samsung T260 secondary is hard to describe.  The colors might be all right but there is absolutely no contrast nor black level.  It is totally washed out and unviewable.  I got the same with easy and advanced modes.'Fraid it's got to go back.
summary: Wish I could say it worked.

reviewText: This calibrator is simple to use and full of features IF you get the latest version of the i1Profiler software from Xrite's website. The version on the cd is v1.11 for me at least. It lacks a few important features like manual control for the color gain and offsets, which the latest version as of now v1.32 allows.
summary: Awesome product But make sure you download the latest version of i1Profiler from Xrite

reviewText: I feel like I could drop my ipad 2 no problem now or even leave in on the coffee table in dog range and not be worried. I was handling the ipad with kid gloves until this arrived, now I'm not worried about the ipad taking any damage. Style wise I really love it, if mad max could have taken an ipad with him to the thunderdome, I'm confident he would have used this case. For me, I just don't understand the leather bound cases that have zero functionality...If I fell down the stairs with a pot of coffee in one hand and my ipad in the other, I have no doubt that I could play angry birds on the way to the hospital.

The need for this product arose because we had moved into a new home where the wireless bandwidth dropped dramatically in some parts.The quick installation guide made set up very simple. The built-in diagnostic lights established a problem with one of the network cables (not one of those supplied), and after replacement, the network was in operation. Now, network speeds throughout the house are excellent.Using powerline for networking was an experiment. With this product it worked beyond expectations.

Bought this board to update the machine that I use as my home media server. I coupled this with an ASUS F1A55-M/CSM motherboard and it does all that I ask. The most work it gets besides sharing files is running Plex media server. While running Plex, it has transcoded all of my videos with ease and I have had no hiccups while playing the videos on various devices.
Why would anyone get this product? I wouldn't buy it again, maybe it will work for someone else. On the plus side of things, it wasn't super expensive.

-The Trackpad: It sucks. No driver updates have changed that. It's not that it has a problem distinguishing between gestures, but it seems to lack any sort of sensitivity. No, I do not mean mouse movement speed, I mean the accuracy of it detecting fingers present on the pad. I have a 5 year old laptop that you could glide your fingers across and the mouse would move accordingly. This one only seems to pick up fingers gliding near the center of the track pad, leave the center and it actually requires some pressure for it to pick up your fingers. Considering that the track pad is central to a laptop, this is incredibly disappointing.The only gesture I really have a problem with is scrolling up and down. There is major lag between the time you scroll with your fingers and the time it takes the page to scroll. You will either scroll too far or not far enough because of this insane delay.-The Screen: I understand that Samsung decided on a matte screen for anti glare, but on a laptop that is designed around aesthetics, it's hideous. There is a distinct lack of clarity which becomes increasingly noticeable on lower brightness settings. I thought ClearType was disabled when I bought it, but it turns out that is just how to the screen works. Want to simulate it on a glossy screen? Go turn ClearType off and look at the jagged artifacting around the text on the desktop icons and various windows. That is what a matte screen looks like all of the time.Now for the positives:-Battery Life - The laptop has three power modes you can choose with the fn keys. Power saver, balanced, and max performance. On power saver, I get an average of 5-6 hours of battery life with wifi enabled.-The Keyboard - It has very quiet and sensitive keys. I find it very enjoyable to type on.-The Duralumin Body - Other than the fact it looks awesome and is very light, everything about the body styling is perfect. The screen closes and opens smoothly, the edges are nicely tapered, and it feels much more solid than the mac book air without being much heavier.-Runs Cool - it won't warm your lap. After watching a 2 hour movie with the fan partially obstructed by my blanket, the bottom of the laptop is barely warm.-Very quiet - because of how seldom the fan comes on, and because of the solid state drive, the laptop is virtually silent under all conditions.-The Wi-Fi- I haven't had any issues with Wi-Fi connectivity. Supposedly it has been resolved with the latest drivers.Bottom Line: Get a portable bluetooth mouse, if you can stand one, and the laptop is easily the best ultrabook out there.It gets 3 stars, because to me, the trackpad is the center piece of the laptop, I hate carrying around extra stuff, and needing a mouse for a laptop is absolutely ridiculous. The trackpad apologist reviews are saying you know, "oh you get used to it". No, the lack of any consistency with mouse movement is not something you simply get used to.

I bought this digital frame to be a gift for my parents.  Until now I have programmed it and uploaded it with several pictures.  I also have a Kodak Pulse digital frame wich is touch screen and easier to use, but the screen has is deffective, so I am wishing this Pix Star DF works better.  Only time will tell.

The Good:Fits the iPad2 very nicely.  A very tight, snug fit.  The hinge feels very sturdy and I don't have that feeling that the hinge is going to give out anytime soon.  The keyboard looks like a full QWERTY keyboard with a few buttons specifically designed for tablet use.  The iPad feels well protected.  The style looks and feels like a netbook.The Bad:The keyboard is too small.  The design is cramped and poorly designed.  The RETURN, TAB, CAP LOCK and DELETE keys are way to big for this design.  They take up space for the entire keyboards layout making the keys too close together and if you have med to large hands, you will feel it. to turn on/off the keyboard, you will need to hold down the power button for about 5 seconds.  Doesn't seem like a long time, but when you are in a hurry, it feels like 5 minutes.  Maybe it's a setting on my iPad, but the ipad doesn't "sleep" when I close the lid.The Ugly:When closing the lid, a magnet keeps the lid closed.  Along the top of the case is 3 metal-like strips.  The middle strip with the CRUX logo is the longest and on each side of it is two smaller strips.  These smaller strips started to come off.  The clue that held them on, is starting to fail.  I put some crazy clue on them to hold the in place permenately.  The casing has a coating on it that is starting to rub off.  Maybe due to my sweaty palms holding it, but nonetheless, it's noticeable.  I've managed to drop my iPad twice so far (once off my lap onto carpet, and again from hip level onto wood flooring).  The casing separated a little, but it slipped back on snugly, however, I noticed a crack near the hinge.  I may put some crazy clue on that to stop it from spreading.Bottom Line:Does as advertised.  a little pricey for something that isn't perfect.  Not that anything is perfect, but for the price, you'd expect a little better craftmanship and design, specifically with the keyboard.*UPDATE*The nice people at CRUX were nice enough to replace my case with a new and improved design.  Most of the issues I've had have been remediated.  The keyboard is still a little cramped, but they must have listened when it came to the quality because this case is much better in that regards.  The coating is either gone or improved and the state of the case stays consistent. The material is much stronger and does not crack upon impact.  The power button turns on/off very fast now.  The only hiccups I have with it now is the fact that the magnets are gone and now you have to squeeze the hinge after you close it to get it to seal.  This is a minor setback as I do it now without thinking about it.  I'm looking forward to the next case the Crux SKUNK.  Looks promising.
summary: The Good, The Bad and the Ugly

reviewText: Doesn't even reach 40 feet down the hall through a few walls.  Substandard in terms of wifi signal strength compared with other reasonably priced routers.

Easy to install. Received it in 2 days with Amazon prime.  Fits anywhere and very discreet.  No annoying lights too look at other than a power on green light.SEAGATE Expansion 3 TB USB 2.0 Desktop External Hard Drive STAY3000100 BlackIf you have problems with it, customer support is fast and professional and they can install it for you, if you need to.

This drive is NOT compatible with OS X Lion. Some Seagate reps know this. It's a USB 3.0, and not capable of working with OS X Lion. As a result, it will power off.Kudos for the rep that understood the problem and replaced the unit with a Mac-compatible drive.  Rasberries for the five other Seagate employees who kept wanting to send me the same (incompatible) model.
summary: Do NOT purchase for Mac OS X!!!!!

reviewText: This is my second Apple Time Capsule that I bought to back-up a MACBOOK PRO and an IMAC.  My original 500 gb Time Capsule that I bought in 2008 is still operational and I have depended on it heavily.  When my 2007 IMACs hard drive reached the end of its life, recently, I replaced it and restored the system and my files in less than two hours . . . far cry, time wise, from a windows machine.  I have been very impressed with the back-up features and router capabilities of the time capsule.  I can easily say I have gone back at-least 15 times to recover files that I accidentally deleted, goofed, or overwrote, sometimes, these files were several years old.  Although I no longer use it as my primary router, it worked well and was a very flexible with respect to configuration when I did.  Albeit these devices are pricey, they are simple, reliable, predictable and dependable.  When my 2008 time capsule begins to reach the end of its service life in the next year to year and a half, I'll move my back-ups to the other time capsule using the  provided feature. Additionally, because it is convenient, I move files between computers using the time capsules.  Although they don't seem to do automatic backups on Linux, Windows Vista, and Windows 7 (with Parallels the later seems to work, but I'm not 100% positive), I did a network restore of my Windows Vista Machine when a windows update wiped the operating system two years ago.  I had previously manually stored the back-up on my time capsule.

I purchased this mount to keep everything neat and hidden and it worked great, particularly the hidden part. We were recently burglarized. The thieves came in and grabbed what they could carry out, basically anything Apple (computers, etc.). AppleTV is so small and portable, I have no doubt that if it had been on the table next to the TV it would have been taken too. So, thank you TotalMount for saving my AppleTV!!
summary: Saved my AppleTV from being stolen

reviewText: I tried a keyboard that looks suspiciously similar to this one (made by Poetic) but this one by QQ-tech is hands down better than the Poetic one.  It syncs with ease. Nice responsive key feel and sound.  The case is protective AND light. I wanted the protection without the bulk.  This is fantastic.Update.  It is now 7 days later and the top row of letters just stopped working.  It is fully charged and had only a few uses to it.  Submitted a request for return.  Back to the drawing board.

First let me say that the 2 things bring its rating down.  Build quality and the poor feel of the keyboard.  Now, the 3 stars are deserved because a, it works exactly as described on my iPad 3's.  b, though the keyboard feels funky and small, you can definately type quickly with practice and all of the keys work.  c, it looks half way decent.  The iPad 3 can be as much of a notebook as you need, this really helps when taking notes.Unfortunately this isn't a good keyboard.  Save your money.

I have been using a Nuvi 255W for the last 3 yrs but have never updated the map. Prices have come down so much on GPS units that it is more cost effective to buy a new one. The Nuvi 50LM is almost an exact replacement except it has a 5" screen instead of 4.3 and it comes with free lifetime map updates. You can only update 4 times per year according to the fine print. Another new feature is the lane assisst which splits the screen in half vertically and shows you which lane you need to be in to take an exit while still showing your current route. Nice feature but only works in certain locations. They added a new female voice, but only the original one speaks street names, therefore the 4 star rating. There is no reason all the voices shouldn't be able to speak street names. There was no owners manual with the unit and I can't even find one online. If you aren't already familiar with this brand that might be a problem for some people. It is fairly easy to setup however. When you power it up it will take you through a setup menu. Most of the preset options are all it takes to get going. My previous unit never had any problems, so if this one is the same quality it should last for a while.If you are wondering how to charge it when it arrives besides plugging in the vehicle charger, you can plug it into your computers USB port and it will charge. Also if you go to the website on the card that comes with the unit you can register for the lifetime map updates. Mine alerted me to a new map already so I went ahead and did it and it worked fine.

I order this Garmin to replace an older GPS I had for years. The product arrived in great condition and on time. I consider this product to be the best bang for you buck! I highly recommend this product.

went from Garmin Nuvi 350 w/ 3.5" screen to this beast, which I swear you can land a plane on. Color is bright and clear, and UI is sensitive enough for me...love having lane direction for turns, and the junction road sign views....other than those two features, my GN 350 was every bit as good except smaller screen, but I began having trouble loading the newer map updates due to lack of memory, and didn't want to fool with SD card. At roughly 120.00, this GPS is a steal, working right out of the box and never failing to find my destination...so far....glad they got rid of the "recalculating" voice that was so annoying when you missed your turn...all in all, I'm still a big Garmin fan.

Mad Catz Wireless Force Feedbacking Racing Wheel, Xbox 360The Mad Catz wheel set is designed for the Xbox 360 and is advertised to be directly compatible with modern racing games like Forza 4. I evaluated this wheel set with Forza 4, but I have also owned the Logitech G25, Logitech G27 (both designed for the PC and PS3), and Logitech Driving Force GT (designed for PC/PS3). My favorite is the Logitech G27, although the Driving Force GT is a far simpler (keep it simple) approach that does the job just fine - mainly because there isn't a single racing sim that accurately models a clutch either by design or programming issues.There aren't many good steering wheel sets available for the Xbox 360. The PC and PS3 have several decent wheel sets to choose from. Several people have recommended the Fanatec, but I have not used it in person. Everyone raved about the G25/G27 when it first came out, so I am hesitant to shell out big bucks for another wheel set that is just going to sit in my closet.First off is the installation and mounting. The wheel itself has several rubber base nubs that provide a friction grip to a table surface, or you can opt to use the screw-on lap pads (which I do not recommend for a good racing experience). If mounted incorrectly, the wheel will slip around. The locking mechanism is a cruder version of that used on the G25 and G27. There's one gigantic threaded knob that clamps the desk but this is a very big clamp and interferes with my gaming desk slide-out keyboard tray. The clamp also has to get well under the table, so many coffee tables won't suffice either. If you don't clamp it as deep, the wheel will slip because the biggest rubber pad is no longer gripping the table.You can opt to use the sequential shifter knob on either side of the wheel, to simulate left-hand or right-hand driving. There's nothing special about this knob other than that the knob itself is wrapped in a metal shell. It is not tactile, so you don't feel/hear a click to indicate successful up or downshifting. The paddle shifters are not tactile either, you don't hear or feel a click like on the G27.The steering wheel uses straight cut gears, so it sounds like the Logitech G25 and Driving Force GT, it whirrs and whirrs like a cheap toy, but it does the job. The Logitech G27 solved this by using helical cut gears for a silent approach. The steering wheel also has VERY limited steering lock. I count about 270 degrees lock to lock, and this is far too small to negotiate many hairpin turns in FOrza 4. As a matter of fact, I had difficulty in turn 1 at Laguna Seca driving a Ford GT. I had it at maximum lock and felt that I could have turned the in-game wheel even more had I used the controller. I am used to the Logitech G27's far more flexible steering lock adjustment (up to 900 degrees if I recall correctly). The steering wheel itself is a very small diameter wheel, and I'm not as used to it since the steering wheels in most cars are several inches larger in diameter, but the G27 and Driving Force GT are about the same size as the Mad Catz.The pedals on the Mad Catz are abysmal to be truthful. The foot rest and assembly is feather light so it tends to flop around. It relies on your heels to hold it in place, unlike the G25/G27/DFGT pedals that have a heavy base with spines that stick into your carpet or rubber pads for smooth floor surfaces. The actual pedals on the Mad Catz are cheap plastic with rubber pads, and there is zero resistance for the brake and throttle pedals. They feel exactly the same and I kept locking up my brakes in Forza 4 because it was way too easy to bottom out the brake pedal. The G25/G27 pedals have different resistances to simulate the feel you get in a real car.In addition, the Mad Catz pedals are spaced very very far apart like it was designed for an old person car like a Crown Victoria or Buick. This is a very far cry from the closely spaced pedals on the G25/G27 and real cars like the Mustang, Nissan 370, and Audi S5. Since they are spaced so far apart, I find myself using both feet to drive, Formula 1-style, but the lack of resistance/force on the brake pedal makes it hard to modulate the brakes properly.Setting up the wheel assembly with Xbox wasn't too bad, finding the CONNECT button on my Xbox 360 Slim took longer than I'd expected mainly because I rarely had to use it in the past. With the G25/G27/Driving Force GT, installation on the PC was a bit more involved followed by countless hours of adjusting and tweaking the settings in Windows as well as the game itself.The overall construction and quality of the Mad Catz wheel is very good. The buttons are well designed and simulate a hybrid Xbox controller with a wheel and paddles. The metal parts feel very refined, but do little to add to realism. Turning on the wheel always freaks me out because I hold the Xbox Guide button and the wheel spins a little.Playing Forza 4, I found that the force feedback was a bit strong by default. I was fighting the wheel a lot of times, but it was MUCH easier to control my drifts and to recover from a spin. However, the lack of feel from the brake pedal really diminished the visceral driving experience. I was much better in Forza 4 using the controller versus this wheel set. I wish the wheel set had more steering lock, closely spaced pedals with a harder to push brake pedal, and tactile paddle shifters. I went back to the controller after giving the Mad Catz a good try in Forza 4.Overall: 3/5, great for beginners and intermediate racing sim players. Lots of room for improvement in the steering lock, pedal spacing, and needs more brake pedal resistance. It was hard to establish an immersive gaming experience in Forza 4 as I was struggling to get acclimated to the wheel and pedals. I like the G27 and Driving Force GT much more.
summary: Needs to be improved in several areas for better gaming experience

reviewText: I held off on buying an SSD for a long time because I was just not convinced that the performance was there to justify the high prices and small capacity.  My only regret now is not buying one sooner.  Prices have also come down significantly and continue to fall, making the decision an even easier one.  This is by far the single best upgrade to enhance the day to day performance and usability of your computer.  Once you experience 15 second startups and instantaneous program launching, you simply will not be able to go back to archaic spinning metal platters.This particular SSD is a top performer and has proven to be perfectly reliable in the several months I've been using it so far.  One of the best SSD's available, regardless of price.

Charger takes 1 battery at a time no issue but 2 high drain battries at once you will detect over volt(smells of plastic). Those were 14 bucks batteries I trusted with "Trust Fire". I will consider their company with more care next time.

reviewText: I only have one word for this item and it is Great! It is small and fast and works perfectly.

i've been taking pictures for over 30 years and a few lenses stand out.  This is one of them.Construction-wise, yes it's plastic.  But until or unless someone can prove to me that it matters that it's made out of plastic, I would discount the worries.  I don't find it weak or flimsy or suspect in any way.  I guess I'd prefer black, but it does have kind of a throw back look to it and being silver has no impact on images.This lens has the most beautiful bokeh I've seen in years.  Coupled with it's eye cutting sharpness and excellent contrast I'm just blown away.  Reminds me of some old Zuikos and Nikkors from my manual focus 35mm days.  Wonderful.  And having that f1.8 aperture again is nothing short of splendid, only driven higher by it's excellent optical design.  I know fast primes have been out there in DSLR offerings, but since the switch to M-4/3's, these 2 are my first foray.This prime (and the Lumix 20mm) have taken me back to the days of creative DOF and "zooming" with my feet. But this time it's in compact, lightweight heaven.  Nothing ever taught me more about pre-visualizing an image and nurtured creativity like leaving the house with a single camera and prime lens.I'm a Panasonic user, so no image stabilization since it's not in the lens, but that's a small price to pay.My only beef with Olympus is the lack of a hood, and the cost to acquire one.  It's a beautiful piece, but the $40 price tag seems unreasonably steep.No regrets with this purchase.  Nothing but praise for this product.

I bought this motherboard on December 19,2012 and received it on December 22,2012. I quickly installed it, easy to set up, drivers took about 20 minutes to install everything. When I connected my Logitech Z5500, it didn't have a option for DTS or Dolby Digital, like my old Foxconn Motherboard, Which was one of my main reasons for getting this motherbaord. I contacted Asus about this since RealtekACL892 supports DTS and DD. I never got a reply. I thought I needed to get the Xi-Fi software, since some companies require you to get the license separately, but that didn't work. Also, unlike my old motherboard, I only had Digital under Realtek HD Audio Manger, on my old motherboard, I had Digital and speakers, even if nothing wasn't connected to speakers. I tired using analog instead of my coax, and When i did the surround sound test, it thought my rear speakers were the front speakers, and I didn't hear sound from the others at all. Another thing about sound is when I plugged in a audio cable, it didn't say audio cable plugged in, which its supposed too. I assumed something was wrong but didn't want to rule it out yet, thinking its software, even though I'm using the drivers that came with the motherboard. I also couldn't configure my speaker setup using coax, no matter what it says 2.1 speaker when mine is 5.1. Today, I woke up, turned on my computer and sound didn't work. I re-installed drivers, everything, spent all day on Google, but its the sound-card, as others have the same problem with ASrock.Right now I'm using a really old creative Sound Blaster Live-24Bit, from a old Dell computer until i can replace this motherboard.The motherboard itself is a great motherboard when it comes to price, features and ease of use.I currently have:-FX6100-8GB DDR3 1333-460GTX-600Watt PSU-1.5TB Harddrive-640Gb harddriveSo while I'm happy with almost everything, audio is a big part for me, I looked for good, budget motherboards, with Coax out, and found this.Personally I would recommend this greatly if you dont use onboard audio, but I cant afford a good dedicated sound card for a while, so i was really sad when the onboard audio had so many problems.I feel like might just be defective, so I'm going to replace it with the same one, and see how well that goes, if the same thing happens again, I'm going to get a different company.But until I get a working motherboard, that works fine, im keeping the rating low, as Audio really is a big deal for me, as I game and listen to music, and watch movies.Update-New motherboard has been good for 2 months now, but i still decided to buy a sound card as i want dts.\Update-9/29/2013. Motherboard still going really strong, no problems. Works great!
Like the title says it looks great and is doing well in my computer it isnt the most compatible RAM for my PC but it still works great

A great router / wireless AP overall. Good, strong signal throughout the house.My only problem is it the Bonjour protocol support stops working randomly about once or twice a week. The only solution is a reboot.  This can fortunately be done from the Advanced Setup page of the router's configuration web page, but it is still frustrating when all my Apple gear stops working like it should.(Bonjour is used by Apple software/devices to detect other Apple devices on the network, such as AppleTV AirPlay.)

This is an excellent monitor. I purchased three of them to use as a triple monitor display. The specs speak for themselves, but the color is vivid, and the 2 ms response time is fantastic. The monitor has a clean design and are very slim. It is also pretty lightweight and can be mounted as well.

We have a DMC-FH25 camera, and needed a spare battery.  The camera manual is very clear they do not recommend the use of aftermarket batteries, but in shopping around we found that Panasonic has taken the low road withtremendously overpriced spare batteries.The good news is that the Wasabi batteries and charger kit work well. The kit comes with two batteries, a charger, a car adapter, and a European plug adapter, all for less than just a Panasonic-branded battery. Oh, and the Wasabi batteries are 1100mAh, compared with the Panasonic batteries, which are 660mAh, so each Wasabi battery gives almost double the life of a Panasonic battery on a single charge.The car charger and European plug adapters are a bonus, as well.  Overall, this kit is a great addition for anyone looking to make life with easier with their rechargeable Panasonic cameras, but who don't want to pay for needlessly overpriced, name-brand accessories.
summary: Fantastic value, works perfectly in the Panasonic DMC-FH25 camera

reviewText: Got the JOB DONE!  WOrks GREAT... bought two more! I was a little worried about getting something like this online, but the price and the size was perfect.If you want a Wireless lan to use when repairing machines, this is the one!

These little things have some big sounds coming out of them.  From the lows to the highs everything is well represented in the EPH-100.Talking about the low end its amazing how much bass this 6mm driver puts out, it has really good depth and texture with awesome punch and rumble for such a small driver.  Its not to much bass but more than say my TF10's and FXT90 and it doesn't bleed into the midrange like on some lower end IEM's.The mids are smooth and sit just right in the frequency range as there not recessed or to forward like say Shures are.  It has good texture and detail with a nice warm feeling exactly what you want from a good dynamic driver.  Vocals sound great and it brings out all the midrange melodies and sounds in my electronic music beautifully.  So far I only have a few hours on them (like 10) so I think the mids will get even better after a good 50 hours of play time as will everything else.Highs are, I hate to say this twice but very smooth also and never get harsh or to bright.  They're there and have great detail but its just more mellow than my most of my other IEM's like the TF10, FXT90 and Ety HF5 though its still well defined.  As I listening to them at the moment certain tracks bring them out more so than others but after they burn in it might get a little brighter but if they don't its still very good.The soundstage is about average with decent width and depth but the instrument separation is superb and you can hear every little detail of a track.  Where they really standout in the soundstage area is with their 3D presentation its got great side to side and makes my EDM sound amazing.  It has a nice relaxing presentation and never gets harsh or in your face perfect for late night listening before you go to sleep.If your looking for a smooth, neutral, detailed IEM with fantastic bass under $200 you really can't go wrong with the EPH-100.  This is a very capable IEM that has good detail for a dynamic driver and is very musical in a smoother way, if I were to rate it on a scale from 1 to 10 I give it a 9 and well worth $150 (but you can get it cheaper if you just search around).Update:After having them for almost 2 week and putting about 60 or 70 hours on them they have really started to open up and sound even better.  The highs have more sparkle to them but still very smooth and with better detail.  Mids still are very smooth and at times a touch forward which I like and the bass has evened out, it still makes me think WOW just how good it is in quality and quantity for a 6mm driver.  The soundstage seems wider and with a bit more depth and the separation and 3D imaging are just great with IEM.I like this IEM as much as my TF10's which have been my favorite pair since I got them.  They have 2 very different sound signatures with the TF10 being brighter with a larger soundstage and the EPH-100 more laid back and intimate but both have good detail with the TF10 having slightly more though not by much.Now I'm not a veteran audiophile but I have been getting into IEM's more and more over the past year while being on a search for the best bang for buck IEM under or around $150, and the EPH-100 being my 7th pair its one of the best I've heard so far.  I just can't find any real flaws with them and since I've had them they have been my go to IEM for everything.  I'd love to see Yamaha come out with a dual or triple balanced armature because after hearing these I think they could compete with the rest of the big boys in the IEM world.

I have a Swiffer 360 - so far these things leave those in the dust (pun intended) the Swiffer does not get the dust and cat hair like these things do. I got a cat about 6 months ago and his hair and dander are super attracted to my electronics. Cleaning it off of them was a pain, since the Swiffer left most of it behind, it meant going over them with something damp and then something to dry it. Cat dander is kind of "sticky" these tacky clothes wipe over the surface and from what I can tell leave nothing behind. I used it barehanded, after awhile it does leave your hand a little tacky. I'm going to figure out how to use these on the Swiffer extending handle I have (an awesome tool). I didn't use them on the screen of the TV or anything that delicate, but wiping down even the wood bookcase was like a miracle. So far, I love these things. Thank you 3M!

summary: The Good and the Ugly,no bad though,UPDATE :IT is just UGGGLYYYYYYY

reviewText: I'd probably give this a 4.25 or so if allowed....For Vizio's first try out of the blocks, this horse runs well.  Perhaps this is a premature review, since I haven't rec'd my 32 GB class 6 SDHC micro card yet, nor my Targus stylus or the "Poetic" leather folio case I ordered from Amazon. But here goes.Fit and finish are top quality.  There's a ton of functionality with it, the kindle and Nook apps work great, all of my books from my 'dead' keyboarded kindle appeared as "archived" and were there to read.  Don't miss the Kindle at all-(never liked the handling and forgotten bookmarks, and inadvertent page turning)  This tablet has been well thought out.Things I love about it....The landscape and portrait backlit buttons for main navigation ("back", "home", "menu") are great, they never occupy precious lcd screen real estate, and they switch on and off depending on orientation.  Similarly, the 3 speakers are cool, and only two are ever heard, so stereo works well in both portrait and landscape positions.  The speakers actually sound amazingly well to me, after having listened to music as well as many UTubes.  Plays UTube videos very well; may take a few seconds to load, but I'm working with G wireless as opposed to the N which is much better no doubt. The fact that it supports N wireless is good also, btw.  The capacitative touch screen is good but not perfect, sometimes not responding, but 98% of time responds well with very light touch. It seems like the 3 nav buttons (also capacitative) sometimes require a firmer touch, as opposed to the LCD panel which is seemingly more sensitive.  Game playing is very nice.  The screen resolution is excellent imho.  Angry Birds, a free download from Android Market plays really well, although sound cut off a few times without notice or reason.  If you really wanted the sound back, one had to reboot the device and there it was again.  The other game I've installed in the first few days of ownership is a neat tennis game called "Cross Court Tennis". Unbelievable what they can do with tech now.  Variable power strokes, topspin, flat shots, lobs, slices....what more could you want for a measly 2 bucks - and the action is fast and realistic with a choice of two 3d perspectives.  Also like the speech recognition option to replace keyboard.  It's a beta product from Google, but it's the best recognizer I've ever used. Makes only a very few mistakes if you speak distinctly.  Not being perfected yet, I wished that I could speak multiple sentences and tell it when I'm finished. As is, after speaking and pausing to reflect upon one's next words, it leaves you, and you have to press a few times to get it back.  But for me, much faster than using keyboard.  I'm new with the Android system, and this Vizio currently uses Android 2.3.2 which is a far cry from the very latest Ice-cream Sandwich OS, but this tablet really works well overall regardless.  Having purchased from Costco in Richmond, VA for $189 plus tax (199.99 ttl) I consider this a real value.Have not tried high def videos or movies, we'll have to see about that. Haven't tried bluetooth either.  Interestingly enough, the nav map loaded, and inside our home was able to find our location on the map.  Was that from the GPS sensor, or the fact that google knows where I live??  Can't tell.  Impressive, nonetheless.Negatives:  So far, the biggest negative for me is the limited life of a charged battery.  With wireless connected, plan on 4-5 hours of constant use.  If used sporadically and in "airplane" mode (disconnected from internet) it will eek out more time before exhausted, but not significantly more.  Up to 10 hours advertised is simply not realistic unless it was put in sleep mode for 7 out of the 10 hours while also in airplane mode.  There's a neat page if drilled down to "settings> about device> battery use" that shows a bar graph representing each app used and what percentage of battery used for each one, over time. It's cool. Haven't tried video chat, but camera will require  a strong light source if you want the image to look ok.  No rear camera at all, but I don't need that since I'm heavily invested in digital cameras.  Weight is a little much, but under 1.5 lbs like most in this size range.  Again, some of the newer ones I've held are lighter and larger and faster as well.  Just need to come up with 400-500 bucks.  All in all, at this time I'm a big fan, and am enjoying the Vizio VTab1008.update:Feb 3, 2013: Well, Its been a while now, with over 30 books read in the "white letters on black" b'ground mode so as not to disturb my wife's slumbers in the middle of the nite, and I am quite happy with this tablet.  Seems like Vizio's not going to come out with the anticipated larger one w/more bells/whistles as it's now putting efforts into all-in-one computers, widescreen t.v.'s, and other electronic devices instead of tablets.  But for $189 at costco wholesale, I'm lovin' it.  Must admit tho, that I had to return it and get a replacement unit, because it failed to reply to input commands after a while.  The procedure was reasonably easy, however, and the replacement has been working well for at least 8 months now.  You know, the processor is only a single one, so the tablet can't perform up to the ability of the best ones out there, but it plays movies from Netflix really well, and makes for a decent game playing platform for most titles but the very most demanding of speed and memory types, so I've had a boatload of fun with it, and can say that there hardly is a day when I haven't used it for at least some reading at night.  The interfaces could be smoother, like looking at internet sites that don't have an android based app for tablet viewing, for example, and navigation around gmail is a clumsy, but it's certainly easy to read your emails anyhow.  As a relatively early adopter of the tablet tech, I'm happy with this, and can wait s long time to make a subsequent purchase for an upgrade, since I just don't feel the need.  the camera function is not good, and it's only one sided, but I use full DSLR camera anyway, and have very low expectations for cameras in phones or other electronic devices, even tho they are improving dramatically and quite quickly. Guess you get the picture that I like it for what it is, and that's the gist of it.

I wanted more memory to keep some movies on my notebook and this one holds plenty at the right price, is always there, & is fast enough even for 1080 upgrades. No more dark quiet nights when storms knock out power.

Anyone who uses Apple keyboards (that are generally always well spaced and designed) will hate this keyboard.  The keys are too tight which is done to make it the same width as the iPad is high.  Unfortunately, it's just a frustrating device.  I bought several models to test for our company and found the apple bluetooth keyboard to be the best. It is clunky to carry it and the iPad around but for typing it's well worth it.  Amazon just came out with a less expensive BT keyboard that is wider then zagg but shorter then apple.  I haven't had the chance to test it but will soon.In short $100 is a lot of money for a poor typing experience and lesser touch experience due to the case.  I would recommend it.

The Cooler Master X Slim Notebook Cooler does an excellent job with it's single 160mm fan of cooling down laptops and other devices.  Since it uses a single large fan it's significantly more quiet than many other cooling pads that I've seen or used.  The cord from the pad to the notebook is a tad short in my opinion, but worst case you can simply add a USB extender onto it.  Since the USB cord has a built in splitter you don't lose one of your scarce USB ports (like the laptop I'm using this with does).  I don't know how well this works if someone has it in their lap, since I never use mine like that.  Overall I'm very happy with this product and would recommend it to others.

This wireless pan/tilt IP camera from Loftek is much easier than Foscam. The price is compatible but the easy of installation and setup make it a better choice. I ordered two newest Foscam recently and had to return both of them because of difficulties in installation. Unless Foscam, Loftek setup is much simpler. The IR cut capability render true color and sound quality is excellent. It is a very affordable way to monitor your properties while away using any computers or even your smartphones.
It a wonderful little keyboard, I use it with my Mac Mini. it worked seemlessly. I use it as a secondary keyboard and one I can use in bed when I use my Mac.

First of all, let me say that I really wanted this device to work.  However, wishing for things will not make them happen.When attempting to connect to sync with my PC, I first noticed the problem.  For the Bluetooth radio to recognize the remote in discovery mode, it had to be within 1 foot of the receiver.  At first, I thought it was because I didn't charge the remote when I received it.  Realizing this may be the problem, I charged it overnight.  However, this didn't help.  I still had range issues.Once I had everything synced up, I attempted to use it in my living room.  I tested by moving the mouse pointer and slowly moving back away from the Bluetooth receiver to determine its range.  It worked for about 3 feet and then intermittently at best.  It definitely will not do 30 feet as advertised; heck it will not even do 10 feet.  So unless you plan on being directly in front of your TV/PC (within 3 feet), don't buy this.Maybe I have a remote with a bad transmitter, but it seems horribly under-powered.

I wanted to use this to extend the iPod cable that is built into my car (a 2009 Infiniti G37).  This cable did not charge my iPhone 4, nor did it pass through the audio signal.Overall the cable seemed well built, but it didn't do what I needed it to do.
summary: Did not work for my connection type

reviewText: Hooked it up to my digital to analog tuner and used it to watch tv while on the computer. Worked great for that application. Has a very good picture.

I'm so upset about this case. It's cute, pink, fits snug and tight and very is sleek. BUT..the manufactures didn't take their time to make this product and carefully align the cut outs for the charger and headphone jack with that of the device. It is absolutely impossible to plug your charger into the device without removing the bottom portion of the case. Additionally, the head phone jack barely goes all the way in. It's highly inconvenient and a pain in the ass!! Maybe it's a handful of cases that aren't aligned properly, while others may not face this issue, but newcomers, save yourself the trouble from the possibility. That said, BUYER BEWARE, do yourself a favor and kindly skip this worthless case.

Got the ROKU to see if I could leave Cable TV out of my life entirely in the near future.  My viewing needs are pretty light and with Amazon Prime, Hulu, Netflix, etc. offered thru Roku, all I will need soon is the internet from my cable provider.The wifi option just would not work for me and it may be that my old Belkin router and the Roku did not get along.  The Roku would see my home network just fine but even after changing many settings on the router, wifi just was not working very well.  Did get it to work a few times but it was only after disabling most of the security settings for my network (which I could not live with).  Put security setting back up and ended up using cables to connect router, Roku and TV.  Roku works just fine with cables and the picture quality is excellent.  Have not had any problems with speed of playback or downloading.So, I am very happy with the Roku and how it will be saving me money in the future.  When finances allow, I may pick up a new router and that will probably make it possible to use the wifi connection feature.
summary: Like this Roku even if though we had to use cables...

reviewText: Don't get me wrong, I love my new Roku 2 XS player.  The picture and sound are outstanding (using Netflix as the baseline service).  I have made sure that there is a strong wireless signal in the room with the device and couldn't be more pleased with the quality and continuity of the picture. Even older movies look great on my 67-inch Samsung. I expected more interruptions during playback due to a wireless signal, but thus far playback has been flawless.However, I have a had few issues keeping the device connected during downtime, meaning after I am not using the TV or Roku player for a while, I have trouble getting it to "wake up".  This does not happen every time, but enough that I felt it worth noting in this review. A simple reset of the device solves the problem, but unplugging the payer and then waiting for a it to re-boot, even if only occasionally, will get a bit tiring over the life of the device. Otherwise, I would give this product 5 stars.
summary: Great picture, but device is a little buggy...

reviewText: I own both the new Apple TV (1080P/2012) model and the Roku2 XS. I found myself doing a side by side comparison of the two products and here are my findings.AppleTVPros: Works out of the box, minimum effort to setup, really easy to use interface + wifi. Can Restream old purchased episodes. Netflix App much cleaner and more superb. Streaming and buffering causes no delays or degradation of picture. AirPlay makes up for a lot of the limited channels (with Mountain Lion the functionality goes up even more). iPad Remote easy to useCons: Limited Channels...needs an open API like Roku to build more channelsRoku2 XSPros: Many Channels available, Cheaper ($10), Free Movie Channels like Crackle, AmazonPrime availability, Vendor neutral. iPad Remote easy to useCons: Missing iTunes integration, Poor quality and buffering (constant downgrading the image quality on NBA League Pass and Netflix). User UI is just bland and could be cleaner. Bugs and issues. Most channels you have to pay extra for. Roku disconnects from my wifi network randomly whereas the AppleTV never does during side by side streaming. Setup takes longer and more tweaking needed by the user.Summary:While the Roku offers you many more channels the end user experience on the AppleTV makes it much more simple to utilize. If you have some form of Apple Eco System then the AppleTV is for you. If you hate Apple then the Roku is for you. Each product has their own advantages and disadvantages. For me in the end it was about the user experience and ease of using the player and the AppleTV edged out. It's not to say I won't be using my Roku but until there are some updates to fix some of the buffers and issues the AppleTV is by far the better product.

I love this little device. It has saved me so much money by not needing to have cable. The channels are mostly around 5 bucks, which, even adding in all the ones I want, is still cheaper than my cable was...for more options. The fact that the remote is radio waves instead of infrared, means I don't need to have a clear line of sight to the box, which is nice as I can just mount it on the back of my TV.The games are fun, but kind of overpriced, in my opinion, though there are a few free ones and it comes with Angry Birds.I give it 4 instead of 5 stars because in USB playback mode (so trying to play stuff I download) it only supports a very limited amount of file formats, so there are often things I download that I cannot play on the device. I also think it would be greatly improved if there were channels for FOXOnDemand and the other networks that offer their OnDemand on their websites for free. A way to interface with those would be fantastic.Overall I love this product and would recommend it to anyone.
summary: Great device, elimnates my need for cable

reviewText: The Roku 2XS is the top of the line model of the Roku family as of Dec, 2011. The main difference among other models is 1080p resolution, built-in Ethernet port, and a free Angry Birds game. Like the other Roku models, the 2XS has a growing library of channels that include Netflix, Amazon, Flixter, Crackle, NBC, AOL, and a big selection of user-made private channels.InterfaceAll Roku devices use the same simple interface. Channels are represented in a horizontal grid, and once a channel is selected, further grids of selections are then displayed. This barebones sort of presentation means anyone can understand it, but finding any particular show requires many button presses.ContentNetflix, Amazon Instant Video, and Hulu Plus require a paid subscription, but they have the best selection of TV shows and Movies. These channels cost about $6-$10 a month each, and they have a side benefit of being accessed from your mobile phone, tablet, or computer - not just from the Roku device. The Roku also has a lot of free channels that come from Internet-famous websites like Cnet, Giantbomb, Chow, Crunchyroll and more. (Unfortunately, Youtube is not officially supported as of yet.)Lastly, there are the private channels which are made by the enthusiast community. These channels vary in scope, but the wide range of subject matter can be surprising. There's channels devoted to late night tv, sports, specific sitcoms, firearms, cars, tech, gaming, and more. Best of all, most of the private channels are free. (As of Dec. 2011, there was a Youtube channel available as a private channel, but that was pulled because Google did not sanction it. Roku however, has stated it is working with Google to bring an official Youtube channel to the device.)If you care a lot about sports, the Roku might not meet your needs. There are Football, Baseball, and Basketball channels, but they tend to not to be live broadcasts - most are pre-recorded. Cable and satellite TV is still a better choice in this regard.QualityGoing with the wifi connection on the Roku won't be as consistent as using its Ethernet connection. I often get varying degrees of quality even though the Roku's status says that its wireless connection is "good." And if you use the Roku a lot, you could run the risk of hitting your data limit that your ISP allows. (I typically get to about 200-220 gigs of data in a month, which is about 80-90% towards my own limit.)ConclusionIf you are thinking of replacing cable or satellite TV with this - it maybe a good alternative for you. However, it all depends on what content you want. In my case I opted to keep the most basic cable package so I could still get local channels. (There is a private channel on the Roku that has local channels, but the quality of the broadcasts vary.) The Roku then, provides the rest of my viewing content, and I am happy with it. I still miss the live broadcasts of sports from around the country, and having my favorite shows in consistent 1080p resolution was always great with digital cable tv. But Roku allows me to save a lot of money (cut my bill in half!) and still have most of the shows I care about.
summary: Cable TV cost cut in half, has lots of content, but quality varies

reviewText: I bought the roku and was very disappointed in about every aspect but the looks.  The thing looks great and has a good controller, but OS is sluggish so expect lag when u scroll through the menus.  The main reason I bought the roku was for PLEX streaming and it really didn't work well at all.  This product would be great for non powerusers because it is easy to use and things like menu lag wont bug them.  I would buy it for my mom and grandma, but not my brother.

If you purchased a ROKU for the sole reason of watching HBO GO and are a DirecTV subscriber, you are in for a big disappointment.I probably should have done more research on this before buying the ROKU so I guess that's on me.I have a PS3 which I hoped would get HBO GO but I doubt that will ever happen.Sure, I could watch HBO GO on my iPad while sitting in front of my home theater but that just seems pointless.The search goes on...On to the actual review: Setup was a breeze. I have a wireless 4 port router setup in my home theater cabinet in order to run an Ethernet cable to my A/V receiver, cable box and PS3 so plugging the ROKU into that and my internet connection was instantly setup.I then went online and registered as well as activating Netflix and Amazon Prime subscriptions.I was also able to set it up with my Logitech Harmony remote which was pretty easy as well (Harmony users, the ROKU is listed under 'DVD' in your software).The streaming quality of Netflix actually looks better on the ROKU than the PS3.I am still exploring different channels but there is no lack of content to be sure and after signing up for Amazon Prime I may just stop getting discs from Netflix and rent them from Amazon which seems like a much better deal if you don't watch a ton of movies.
summary: Warning for DirecTV customers (but still a great product)

reviewText: Setup of the Roku was pretty simple, started up downloaded new software update and was simple to create an account.  Creating a account does require a credit/debit card.  The main reason I got this was mainly to have access to Pandora and Amazon Prime Instant Video on my TV without hooking my PS3 or laptop to the TV.Although I bought it just for Amazon and Pandora to start, I figured with all the channels they had there would be something useful I liked.  After awhile I realized that almost (not all) but a lot of the channels are junk or nothing that I care to watch, or that can be accessed freely on other devices such as a PS3, or Blu-Ray player.  And while there are many paid options available, all of the options are available on other devices I have.After a couple weeks the Roku started having issues loading any videos and would give a "Service Unavailable" message every time I'd load a video (from Amazon, Netflix, Crackle), if by chance I didn't get the error the movie/video would load for awhile and stop randomly and then give the error.
