The only way I found to reduce this is to change video output from 1080p to 720p  (and I know for a fact that my internet speed is not the problem).Ever since Amazon has released their video service on the PS3 (Which streams HD with no problems at all) I have little use for this box now.  While it is a neat box, and really wish it worked better for me, it just falls short of my expectations so I'll give it 3 stars.  If the Roku was able to load all the video services for me under 1080p setting (Which my PS3 and Blu-Ray can perfectly) I would definitely keep using this box, but as it stands, it just has too many issues for me liking.
summary: Good player, just not for me

reviewText: I've purchased three of these Roku devices for my TVs.  It's easy to set up and operate.  Set up took less than 5 minutes.  It provides good streaming content and it appears that they are adding more content providers by the day.  I would not use it to replace cable TV, but it does a nice job of providing additional quality content that you would not otherwise get from standard TV or cable providers.
summary: Nice easy to use streaming device

reviewText: We've had one of these for years now, alongside an AppleTV, and I have to say the Roku wins hands down.The ONLY thing the ATV has going for it over the Roku is a more elegant interface. The Roku's is less flashy and doesn't have animation. But you do get a ton of Channels that the AppleTV doesn't have.We have a channel for Amazon Instant Video. There's a TED channel with nothing but TED talks. There's VUDU for renting hi-def movies and tv shows. Those are the main ones we use, but there are literally hundreds of others to choose from.Like the AppleTV, the Roku has an app in the iTunes store so you can control the device from your iphone or ipad. This is great for searching... you can use a virtual keyboard to type in your searches instead of using the remote to move from letter to letter.Finally, the Roku almost NEVER crashes. We have to reset one of our AppleTV units perhaps once a week, but this Roku has been rock solid. The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because of the lack of glitz in the UI. But the picture quality and content are great!

I ordered these with the thought of if they are identical to the Bose but at half the price I am a fool not too.  Well while the OEM Bose that came with my units held up for almost 6 years and left leather like, these cloth like replacements are pretty much done in less than a year (uploaded a photo).  Ordered the OEM Bose ones this morning.You get what you pay for... AGAIN.David Art[...]

I recently purchased 4 of the 2TB drives to use in a Mediasonic eSATA RAID enclosure.  They have been running as a RAID 5 array 24x7 for a few weeks now with no problems.  No dropping out of the array, no funny noises.  Knock on wood.  Cheap way to get 6 TB of storage space with some redundancy.  I also have 6 more of these drives running without trouble for several months now in a FreeNAS-powered NAS box.  6 2TB drives in a RAIDZ2 ZFS array, works great and gives me 8TB of space with excellent redundancy.  Also have 2 more of these 2TB drives in a RAID 1 array in another computer.Which means so far I have 12 of these drives up and running in drive arrays with no problems so far.  Can't complain.  I also have 2 spares on hand just in case.

I purchased this for my Garmin Nuvi 1450 (5" screen).  The GPS fits really well and is secured by the elastic straps.  Black plush lining is better than expected.  I like the mesh net "pocket" to keep my cords in place.  I also like the hook on the back to attach the case to a backpack or travel bag - one less thing to carry (if it's attached to something else).  The double zipper is great! It allows the case to open & lie flat AND it is easy to zip/unzip.The exterior is nice.  It is water-resistant, and can wipe clean with a cloth.  It appears to be very durable, but I've only had it a month.  I chose a hard GPS case over a soft one, because this one could take some "bumps" without damage to the contents.  Overall - it's a very good product!  I would purchase again.  (I may even consider getting another one - this time - in gold.)KOZMICC 5.2" Inch Hard Carrying GPS Case (Gold Color) For for Garmin Nuvi 1450LMT, 1490T, 1490LMT, 2450, 2460, 1450, 1490, 5000. Magellan Roadmate 1470, 1475T, 2035, 5045. TomTom XXL 535T, 550, 540, 540T, 540TM and more

I have loved Apple products for a long time but I am amazed at what they are producing these days. Simple, solid, sophisticated performance is delivered in a size not much bigger than an iPad! This computer is essentially a replacement for my 2007 vintage MacBook Pro 17 inch which has served me very well. I elected to buy the 11 inch MacBook Air with 4 gigs of ram and the larger hard drive. Performance-wise, this computer flies past the old one. I am going to do a lot of music recording with the Macbook Air and it's perfect.... So portable yet powerful. And the Apple software for writing, music, and photography is also well-designed and reasonably priced. I got a LaCie external hard drive for backup and any extra storage I might need. I'm really good to go! Other Apple products (I have an iPod touch) sync together beautifully and seamlessly. I'm very impressed!

After having been a user of Windows based computers for the past 21 years, I felt it was time for a change.  My last computer was a Compaq Presario that I bought in '07, and after a little over four years, its on it last legs.  I bought it with Vista installed on it and was sick and tired of the irritating crashes, screen freezes, time intensive updates, etc.  Additionally, it reached the point a couple of months ago where, I started getting messages saying an application failed, and shortly after that, the screen would flicker, and the entire taskbar along the bottom of the screen would just disappear.  About 15-20 minutes later, it would flicker and reappear.  If I was downloading anything when it flickered, I would lose it and have to start all over while dealing with the screen continously freezing.  So yesterday I went to the Apple store and bought a Macbook Pro and the only thing I have to say after having had it for 24 hours, is what took me so long?  Its a breeze to setup, not to mention it boots up in like 10 seconds and is ready to go.  No more waiting two or three minutes for my computer to boot up, followed by another minute or so for my home screen to populate itself and finally be ready for use.  I really like the Facetime camera and all of the effects you can create in it using iPhoto.  I'm still getting acclimated to Mac OS X Lion but thats not a problem.  To anyone considering making switch, I say go for it...you won't regret it.UPDATE:  3/1/11 Just attempted to create my first DVD using iMovie and I had planned to use iDVD but found that newer model MAcbook Pros are no longer being shipped with iDVD as a part of the iLife suite.  After speaking with Apple, I found that iDVD was discontinued because you can now create DVDs using the Finder menu.  This is a great product.

Was going to get the 11 but if you work on it, the ad card makes it pretty fly. It's fast. Really fast. Screen great. But I saw some pc's that had better screens on them. This is the computer that you see all others try to look like. I always buy the Mac base models. These things change so fast, why she'll out the big bucks for all the extras? In a few years you'll have an old machine anyway. It's nice. Wifi is better than on the iPad. Mountain lion is good with iCloud. That's the only reason to buy a Mac, all your stuff everywhere!Grab this thing. It's awesome.

I own both a Pogoplug Pro (black) and a Pogoplug (V2 pink) along with Pogoplug Premium software and Pogoplug Backup software.  Pogoplug used to work well until they made changes to the software and firmware last year.  Now the Pogoplug devices are worthless as the fail to work most of the time and when they do work they are so slow it is worthless.  My media never updates properly to the hard drives connected to the Pogoplugs anymore.  The mobile apps for iPhone and Android are horrendous as it takes 2 to 3 days on a LAN to reindex your media when you add new songs or videos.  Transcoding of videos takes days to weeks.  The web view also takes forever to reindex.  It is too bad that instead of getting better with time Pogoplug has gone in the other direction and gotten worse.  I now just use Google Play or Amazon cloud player or Spotify or Pandora to stream music.  Stay away from Pogoplug.

As a true camera bag junkie, I have a closet-full of camera-bags of various shapes and sizes. Some were bought when I wanted to carry my entire kit, to this one, bought recently, which can accommodate what I really need - a camera with a general purpose lens, a specialty lens, a flash, and the other bits that one carts around. As well, while traveling, I always take a couple sachets of headache pills, a few band-aids, antiseptic cream etc. You never know.The first thing for me was to reduce its weight. So I removed the heavy metal rigs that seemed to serve no functional purpose, by cutting off the fabric where the rings were sewn to the bag.The second thing was to make the closure easier. Pushing and pulling the snaps was tedious. So I got four disk magnets (size of a nickel) from the local hardware store, some iron-on tear-repair fabric from the fabric store, and fixed the magnets under the flap and matching locations inside the pocket (takes a bit of fiddling, not a big deal). So the cover flap stays put when I flop it over, and for more permanent closing, I do the snaps.The next thing was to add velcro to places where it was missing inside, so I could use other inserts and partitions, not just the one insert provided. You can get iron-on velcro at a fabric store that sticks awfully well. I found my locations, ironed it on and gave it an hour to cool and set.I also added on, on the outside, a small bottle of sanitizing fluid dangling from one of the strap loops.The only other thing that I plan to add is a collapsible mesh bag outside for a bottle of water.With these three modifications, I now have a bag that is not at all flashy, can carry all kinds of stuff - the back pocket is great for an ebook reader like the Kindle or Nook, you can configure the inside to carry a SLR plus lenses etc, or a micro four thirds, lenses and a good microphone for video, the small outside pockets carry the bits and pieces, the magnetic closure makes opening/closing painless, and it looks sufficiently nondescript - but not dilapidated - that nobody gives it a second look. The color is nowhere near as green as in the image, its more of a faded yellowing green, a bag that you might have left out in the sun a bit too long.Plus, not being over-padded, it remains a manageable size and weight.I like it.Added Oct. 2nd: Just discovered that the outside rear pocket can accommodate an iPad (barely) when inserted vertically. About 35% of it pokes out, but you can put it in, in a pinch.
summary: Very interesting bag, lots of customization possible

reviewText: I haven't had this for long (only two days) and so I have not had adequate time to fully explore it's functionality. However, I did want to submit a preliminary review to address some concerns I had when researching this particular unit. For one, I have played with the voice command feature a lot, and it's fantastic! I've had no problems communicating with the device and it has understood me each and every time. I have turned down the radio and closed (mostly) the windows. But this is hardly anything unexpected. If you're going to have a conversation on the phone or use voice dialing on your cell phone, you'll have to roll up the windows and turn down the radio in those situations as well. But minor background noises have not caused any problems for me.Another feature I think is pretty cool is that you can scroll through the menus by swiping your finger across the screen, like you'd do on your touchscreen cell phone. I had wondered if this was possible, but had trouble confirming online. So, in other words, you can press the up/down arrows to navigate through menus, but you can also swipe your fingers across the screen to move up and down or side to side.Thirdly, some folks have complained about the lack of (or quality of) voices on the unit. This has not been a problem for me. If you go to the Garmin website, you can download - for free - many different voices. Some will say street names and some won't. But I've got about six or seven different voices that speak English and identify streets by name. I've also got another six or seven voices that do not identify streets by name. They have varying accents, but I haven't run into problems yet.I've also seen some complaints regarding the Garmin software for map and software updates. Based on my experience, these software complaints are 100% justified. It took way too long, with too many restarts, to get my map updated and to update my software. The system got hung up repeatedly and I had to restart after letting it stall for approx fifteen minutes. I got it done in under an hour, but it didn't need to take that long. I have an extremely fast internet connection (fastest non-business connection available) and it was the software hang-ups that slowed the process.Volume on this unit is LOUD. Admittedly, I prefer my GPS at a lower volume, so as not to interrupt my audiobooks/music/phone calls. But I've got this unit down to ten percent and can still hear the voice well enough to follow instructions.Looks: this device looks fantastic. Has a glossy black finish and looks upscale, in comparison to my 255WT. Also, the 5in screen is a nice size. This unit is very customizable and I'm glad I went with this higher-level model. The voice commands are probably my favorite feature! Beyond directions, you can adjust settings via voice as well. I'll update my review once I've had more time to use it and better evaluate the traffic alerts, re-routing, etc. Oh, and regarding the missing "re-calculating" notice being removed: I was concerned this might bother me, since I liked having that feature. However, the unit recalculates quickly enough (faster than my old unit) that by the time you realize you've passed/missed the original turn, it's already got you going a new route. So it's not been a problem at all thus far.

I owned an older Garmin (the non-flat panel version) for a few years and felt it to be a lifesaver on numerous occassions.  In a pinch, I decided to buy the newest model without much review, trusting the brand that has guided me so well in the past.  As you might expect from the title of this review, I was extremely disappointed, especially given the price of the unit and the quality of its predecessor.Pros:- Flat panel display allows the unit to be more portable and less prone to falling off the windshield as the older, heavier models did.- USB connection allows relatively easy updating of maps (though this takes several hours to complete)- Allows for "Economy Route" driving, where if you input your car's mileage it will figure out which way saves the most gas.Cons:- Takes an unusually long time (> 2 min) to 'find satellites' initially.  This has been the case in a number of locations in and around New York as well as other states I've traveled to.- Touch display is not precise, often resulting in typos when inputting addresses- "Traffic" feature, while in theory should be a 'pro', has not worked at all from my experience.  It's either never correct about where traffic is, or it provides an update when I'm already stuck in said traffic.- Map updates take several hours and Canada maps are not available by default.- Design is much less intuitive than previous models - for example, the volume control (which I use often - turning it down when I don't need as much guidance and turning it up when I need to concentrate in an unfamiliar area) takes 3 touches to get to the volume menu on screen.  Why not leave this as a physical dial like the previous models?- Most people have experienced a situation where the GPS takes you on a strange route to your destination.  The previous Garmin models did this on occassion.  However, this model uses unusual and impractical routes much more frequently.  I have tried various options (Economy gas, Shortest route, Fastest time) but have not been able to get the system to provide the most direct path during a majority of uses.I'm sad to see the Garmin brand fall so low but I cannot recommend this product, especially given its price.
summary: One of the few occassions where the older version was better.

reviewText: I bought this keyboard because I use my laptop in multiple spots around my house, and occasionally directly connect the laptop to my big screen TV in my fairly large living room.  I use this mostly while I'm in my living room because I like showing friends/guests the shows I download and online streaming videos (YouTube, comedy sites, ect).I originally had a wireless keyboard/mouse combo I had picked up a few years ago, but in my living room that just wasn't as comfortable as I thought it was going to be.  I was constantly looking for a good surface to use the wireless mouse on, and usually resorting to having the mouse in an uncomfortable position in order to use it correctly, having to pick the keyboard back up when I want to go to a different site, and just generally feeling like everything was taking up too much personal space.Enter this keyboard.  I love the smaller size, and I got it for the included touchpad.  The two finger scroll takes a little getting used to, but now that I have it down it does not scroll too fast for me to handle.  The keys feel similar to a laptop keyboard, but that's not a bad thing.  It is very responsive, the keys have a good tactile feel, and I have zero problems with the trackpad doing anything I don't want it to.  I cannot report any of the problems other reviewers have had with the trackpad, I love the tap-to-click and I really like the forward thought process that added a left click button in the upper left corner of the keyboard.  It makes clicking and dragging easy enough that even a novice trackpad user can do it.I can't comment on the battery life yet, because the included batteries are going strong after three weeks.  I live alone, so I don't bother to turn off the keyboard when I'm done with it, as no one else will pick it up and cause me any headaches.  This is NOT my main keyboard, when I'm doing heavy typing work I have my laptop connected to a full-sized usb keyboard, so I do expect the batteries to last many months.  The keyboard does go into a low power mode after a bit of time, and I notice it because there is about a half second delay upon first using the trackpad if I've not touched it in over an hour's time.In terms of range, I typically use this at a distance of between 10 and 20 feet, depending on where I'm sitting in my living room.  I see absolutely no problems with range, and I've tested it through a few plaster/load-bearing walls and had no problems with it not receiving the signal.  I usually have the laptop with the receiver sitting on my entertainment center using WiFi, which has a 40" LCD TV, XBox 360, and stereo equipment, and with everything running I still do not get any interference.Used as basically an advanced remote for my laptop, this is a fantastic solution.  I don't recommend it for full-time duty though, if only because it is NOT a full-sized keyboard and if I had to write a long paper or do full-time work on, it would become uncomfortable over time.  However if you are in need of a good solution to having very little space to work with and don't mind the slightly smaller than normal keyboard, you could do much worse than this keyboard, and for the price there isn't much out there with the same high-quality build of Logitech.
summary: Great solution to an uncommon problem

reviewText: This keyboard is a good add-on / replacement for a computer keyboard/mouse combination.Unlike the comments from many who have reviewed this product as a "Media Center" keyboard; I would not recommend it as a good media computer as the keys and hand controls are just not as well suited for HDTV control. However it will work and is as described....as a keyboard. The two day prime shipping was a joke however. It took nearly a week to get it.

Picked this up during the black friday sales for my recently finished Home Theater PC (HTPC). Just what the doctor ordered. This coupled with XBMC on a mid-powered computer and a 3TB hard drive and you have the best combination of media consumption available (in my opinion).The keyboard feels solid, the keys are responsive, the touchpad works good, the media keys (previous, play, next, mute, volume down, volume up) are very handy and i use them constantly.One gripe is that the backspace and delete keys aren't standard sized, so web browsing and text input can take some getting used to (if this is a HTPC though you probably won't be doing much text input).Overall I recommend it. For the price it's a great wireless keyboard that functions perfectly for my needs..
summary: Just the the keyboard to complete any HTPC

reviewText: I tried the Lenovo N5902, the SolidTek Bluetooth Keyboard with touchpad, the generic "Handheld Bluetooth Keyboard," and even the wired Thinkpad USB Keyboard with Trackpoint, but only the Logitech K400 has fulfilled my need for a wireless mouse-keyboard combination when my laptop is hooked up to my TV.It's really that simple. Everything else had severe flaws: The Lenovo N5902 gave me an arthritic pain in my thumb (and I'm 20-something), the SolidTek was heavy and depleted the batteries in two days, and the Thinkpad keyboard is wired and has driver issues with Firefox.The K400 just works, with near-instant plug-and-play installation and seamless performance.No product is perfect, so in exchange for its light weight and thin profile, there's no palm rest. The Thinkpad USB Keyboard rules there. And the asymmetrical mouse buttons are hard to get used to. But other than that, I've stumbled upon a near-perfect solution here.
summary: The only wireless keyboard that's worked out for me.

reviewText: Bought something I don't need so do not use it.  It is still in its package.  I have no reason not to recommend it or to recommend it.

I use Apple's Magic trackpad all the time and had gotten used to it so much that I was having problems working with a standard mouse on Windows, especially on my desktop treadmill. So I got this one and it works well enough for me. Don't try fancy stuff but it does the basic job of moving the pointer, clicking and scrolling reasonably well.Also, the boundary problem, if it bothers you, can be easily rectified by circumscribing the active area with thin strips of velcro.I have noticed some unstability issues with it. For example, tap-to-click option would stop working sometime and the functionality is restored only after a full reboot. Overall it is not a A+ finished product like diNovo but it is still the only game in town.
summary: Not Magic trackpad but works well enough except...

reviewText: used to upgrade 160gb PS3 to well a terabyte. fit in the playstation slim's hard drive slot perfectly and works well, i have had for a few months now with no problems will re-post if it dies or anything.

Great router - reliable with good range. Works great on both 5GHz and 2.4Ghz bamnds. i used it with MacOS Lion, Tiger and Snow Leopard together with Windows 7 and Linux. No problems at all. I will recommend it highly.

This is a very nice bag, holds an iPad 2 perfectly as long as the iPad is not in a large case like an Otterbox. Lots of useful pockets for smaller items, pens, etc. The construction quality is actually quite good - as good as any other bag I've purchased from Brenthaven, Briggs & Riley, etc. The cover flap closes with a magnetic latch which could stand to be a little bit stronger but that is a minor quibble. The dedicated pocket inside for a tablet or e-reader is lined with soft cloth and has a quality zipper closure so you don't have to worry about it falling out. My Kindle (2nd. Gen.) can also just fit into the rear pocket, even when my iPad is in the center pocket. There is a clip inside to hold onto car keys as well, and two slim pockets for pens/pencils.One thing to be aware of, is that this case is too compact to hold an 8.5" x 11" piece of paper. I knew when I ordered it that it would be on the smaller side (I wanted a compact bag), but I had hopes that I could squeeze a few sheets of paper or a single file folder into it. Alas, it is about and inch too small in each dimension for paperwork unless you want to fold the papers in half. So although this is a very nice carrying case for a tablet, it can't replace a traditional briefcase if you need to carry any paperwork around.
summary: A very nice bag, a little small

reviewText: You can't beat the performance of this router for the price.  I have a top of the line Asus router as my primary wireless hub.  I use 2 of the RT-N12/B routers as wireless repeaters in my house.  They are excellent.  Setup can be a bit confusing.  If you are performing setup using a computer with wireless make sure you turn the wireless on the computer off before you proceed.  Connect the router to your computer with a network cable, type in 192.168.1.1 in your browser and you will see the setup page for the router.  Next, go to your favorite website in the browser.  If you see the page it means the router is working and you are in business.  Disconnect the router from your computer and place it anywhere in your home.  Make sure you remember to flip the switch in the back and set it to REPEATER.  I have owned these for a few months and they have been flawless.

A case is only useful if it allows you to use your tablet without any inconvenience to the user. This case fails in the fact the buttons on the tablet are hard to get to. There are other cases on the market that you can get that don't have this flaw and because of that even though this case protects the tablet it fails for me since I have to work hard to get to the buttons.
summary: Skip this one, buttons are covered and hard to access.

reviewText: It is a comfortable ballpoint pen, and initially nothing special. But with some use, I found that the stylus was more "accurate" PERHAPS because the pen is longer and the stylus a little smaller (pointier) than the 8 others I have. Another plus is that the barrel doesn't slip as much as than the others I've used.But I'm taking off one star because it seems a bit pricey for an inexpensive (though quite smooth) ballpoint with a rubber tip, although the reader should note that I only have a Kindle Fire and admittedly use my cell phone for emergencies only.Other than price, I would certainly recommend this stylus.
summary: More comfortable and accurate than most of the styluses I've used

reviewText: I got a nexus 7 a couple of weeks ago and I really don't like using the keyboard on the screen ...fatfingering the main issue so I got one of these key boards and it works great.  It took me a little time to figure out what the instructions were telling me to do... (my ignorance of the tech world).  It finally got connected with my nexus 7 and all is well now that I can use an actual keyboard.  This unit looks to be very well made. I found a zipper bag of foam backed nylon and the nexus 7 and the keyboard fit just fine.  What amazes me is that with these two devices you can do most of your computer needs on the road and it all fits into a small area.  The keyboard really does make for a nice addition to the nexus 7.

The mount is excellent in holding an iPhone or any device that fits within its crosslinked arms, but the assembly instructions are less than spectacular.  How to assemble the strap and mount to the bicycle appear to be just OK (not spectacular, but OK), but the assembly came in pieces that you have to assemble yourself.  The strap and pin assembly are explained fairly well.  The instructions were not a problem IF they explained how to insert the ball into the socket.  I could not even find how to assemble it on line at Ram's home site.  Since the reliability and stiffness of the ball in the socket is important for a reliable assembly, some effort should be made to describe how the balls are to be pressed into the sockets.  It apparently takes quite a bit of force and it also appears that you should use a tool to press the ball into the socket.  Does anyone know where it is explained how to insert the ball into the socket???  Has anyone inserted or asked a RAM support person how it is done?This is an addition to my previous review about a year or so ago.  I think I was too hard on this product.  Sure, the mounting to the bike could be slightly better, but it has performed well.  The design of the arms to hold your device is FANTASTIC!  All the older designs I have had (and I have had a few) did not give you a comfortable feeling about the safety of your smart phone.  I think this would hold ANY smart phone well and with confidence.  I never have the feeling that the phone might fall off no matter how much shock it sees.By the way.  They do not mention the iPhone 5.  I am using an iPhone 5.

It works about as well as these things do, which is to say better than my built in antenna but still not terrific, I have to fiddle a lot and the software seems unstable, sometimes it's there and sometimes not.  A learning curve to be sure, but it does improve my computing ability.
I use these for storing my earbuds. They are perfect and 3 for the price is really hard to pass up

Why buy this tablet?It isn't inexpensive (yet).But it is a solid performer.  Very nice screen and good build quality.  By update, it runs ICS (Android ver. 4); I updated the OS right out of the box.  The device runs fast enough for me; I accept that I have to have a few milliseconds of patience.  I'm not running streaming video.  I'm using it to get e-mail, to browse the web, to read Kindle/PDF books, to do some note-taking and to mark up documents.The key benefit/selling point for the device:  It includes a nifty battery-powered stylus.  The stylus has a small tip and is pen-like (not finger-like).I bought this specific tablet because I prefer to use the "one of these" that the brilliant Steve Jobs assailed when he spoke of tablet computing -- the pen-stylus.I really like the pen-stylus input.  I don't like using my fingers.  And I don't like the smudged-up screen that results from finger/touch input.  If you are sort of a neat freak in that regard, you will love this tablet.  And I'm just not good at finger-on-touch-screen typing.There are quite a few apps to try out -- I haven't yet found a perfect one for pen-stylus input.  But a few work well-enough for me.I put the tablet in a folio case (the one from MoKo) and it is a nice fit (once you have the full-size SDHC card installed first -- you can't remove the card when the tablet is in that case).  The folio protects the tablet well.  The tablet-folio combination is brief-case friendly; it is very nice to be able to leave the computer behind now and then.I also purchased a short right-angle micro USB cable that I think will protect the USB plug from mechanical stresses that apparently have caused problems for others.  And I try to handle the device with care.The tablet is not light but it is a good weight; and it feels solid and not fragile.  Battery life is nothing notable in either direction.I like the tablet.  I love having a smudge-free screen.My wish would be for a screen that is closer to letter size.  That is I'm sure an available-someday-soon option.I recommend this tablet to you if (like me) you want a solid Android ICS tablet device where you have a "no-touch" option for the touch screen.
summary: Solid performer with one key benefit (pen-point stylus)

reviewText: I used these cables between my audiocontrol LC6i and Polk PA D5000.5 amp.  I get a clean signal and they are clearly marked as front rear and sub.  They are flat and wide in the middle instead of round which was interesting.  Overall great RCA's and I get great sound from them.

This camera strap is very comfortable.  It distributes the weight of the camera so it doesn't feel so heavy on the back of my neck, and the material of the strap doesn't irritate my skin.  It's a great value for $7.99.
summary: Great camera strap for Canon PowerShot SX40

reviewText: This is a great alternative strap.Much more comfortable than the cheap ones that come with the cameras.looks like it will hold up for a while.I would have given it 5 stars if it was just a little longer.But all things considered, a great buy for under $10

I have been working in the technology business for 20 years, and have seen it all. I would not blame Cisco for this product not working for me, I think that this method of extending wireless N puts a band-aid on the problem of "dead spots". YES it worked for me, but marginal coverage at best in the "dead zone" where I needed it. In order to get this to work, one would have his or her home carefully surveyed for wireless, or just have good luck. I had high hopes that this extender method would work for me.  I am sharing this with people, so that when you purchase this you should expect that there will be a 50-50 chance it wont work. Best of Luck to you, and I hope my opinion helps you with your purchase.

I've tried other extenders and not had much luck.  Well this extender works very well and I am adding another extender in my back yard to extend the range even more.  The first extender was to widen coverage in my 5,000 sq ft house and extend the range outside.  The 2nd extender I just bought will be to extend the range outside as the first extender worked great inside and increase outside a bit so an additional extender on out porch will cover the full back yard.Highly recommend and is very easy to setup and the first extender that was easy and worked.

I had a wi-fi dead spot in my house and I bought this to fix it. It worked exactly as advertised. Setup was dead simple (and I always HATE networking stuff, which is notoriously hard) although it should be clear that you run the setup CD on a computer connected to your wifi network (not on your computer hardwired in). and the extender just works.  where I used to have no/1 bar of wi-fi connectivity, I now have about 4 bars and the connection is very fast and very stable. Perfect.

The sound through these GR07 IEM earbuds just gets better and better the more you use them. After the initial burn in time of about 200 hours, you'll find the depth of sound you can hear in each song is incredible. I find that even after the initial burn in time, music will still sound better after you've had a few initial songs play through them each time you use them again. The highs are amazing and the clarity is like crystal. Not heavy on the bass by any means, but after some burning it, they definitely do have enough. Voices sound clear and you can literally detect every layer of sound in a song. Rather than everything blending together into one sound, you can actually detect the different volumes of each of the different instruments and voices. The sound is much more like listing to music in person, or on a high quality set of speakers, rather than that of typical earbuds.Their design is unique, so take some time to make sure you have them in the correct ear and also that you adjust the posts that hold the ear tips, as they can move forward and back to best align with your ear. Without realizing the posts adjust, it may look as though the left ear and right ear bud should be in the opposite ears. Also these have an over-the-ear design, so the cables should wrap over your ear, not hang down like most people are use to. There are a ton of tips in all different sizes that come with this set. I find that using the smallest one works best for me, since I have very small ears. Once you have set the posts to the right angle for best fit and also found the correct tip for your ear sizes, you will find these offer stellar sound and amazing noise isolation. I can be in the same room with my two kids playing video games right beside me, while they are yelling and hollering and when I have music on, I can't hear a single thing from them. Nothing at all. I've never had earbuds with such effective noise isolation before, it's amazing.The cable is slim, but thicker than most, which is a good thing since it will be less susceptible to breakage. It feels quality in design and I have no issues with tangling. The earbuds come with two forms of storage, the first being a small round case for the earphones themselves. It zips around and is a about the size of the palm of my hand (small hands). The second form of storage is a small pouch which is for holding all the tips. The whole set arrives in a plastic case with a black velvet setting.I'm completely blown away by the sound from these. Once you take a little time to get these all set perfectly for your ears (the tips, adjusting positioning, etc) and you've let them burn in for a good amount of time, you'll find they play music unlike any others. Just amazing!I was provided a sample of these for reviewing purposes.

I just received this and set it up.  I am impressed at how easy it was to connect with to Bluetooth and how great the sounds.  The unit seems very well built and solid.  The buttons are conveniently placed and logical.  Had a little problem installing the batteries, they are stacked 2x2 and getting the bottom set in without bending the negative terminal coils to some patience.  The sound is amazing.  Listening to it right now on my desk and music is Omni present, meaning it does not sound like it is emanating directly from the device, like you would expect from a Bose Wave Radio, I guess.  Used it as a speaker phone and it work great.  The voices were clear and people on the other end said the same.  Two things that would make this better.  A bag to carry it around in and a more secure power button.  The power button protrudes from the ridge around the unit and is subject to turning on when transported in my backpack.  Oh, and I wish it wasn't so shiny...gets finger prints all over it.
summary: Wow!  First Impression is "THIS IS GREAT!"

reviewText: Seriously, Microsoft?  This is for watching movies and DVD's and there's no stop button?  I bought this to control Media Center on my Xbox (used as an extender).  If I accidentally start a recording, I have to fast forward all the way to the end to get back to the screen that lets me delete or restart or adjust the series options.  Sure, I can hit the back button, but then I get that funky screen that makes the recording small and keeps playing, then overlaps the two faded screens, all the while, the recording yammering away in the background, while I (on a reduced screen) surf around to get to the recording that I actually meant to watch.  Sure, I can hit pause, but can't get back to the full screen media center menu unless I fast forward all the way to the end, which can take over a minute on a 30 minute TV show.  What a pain in the rear.  All I need is one silly little stop button, and this thing would be great.  This is almost as bad as removing the Play button!  Good thing they didn't do that.Seriously, this is a nicely designed remote except for the infuriating feature of NOT having a Stop button.  The size and feel are nice.  The lack of Stop button is so annoying that I don't want this anymore.
summary: Why in the world would you remove the Stop button?!

reviewText: The Scansmart Laptop backpack doesn't look very large in the pictures, but when it arrived, I was pleasantly surprised to see how the various compartments were designed to isolate the laptop and still provide a lot of useful storage both inside and outside the backpack. Two mesh side pockets can carry moderate sized water bottles and the two side pockets can carry a lot of smaller items. I was thrilled as I packed it with my various things and still had lots of room to spare, until I tried to insert my Dell 17R laptop . . . it's about 1-1/2" too deep for the case, so the zippers won't close with the laptop inside. I even tried the large center pocket and found it would not close, either.Unfortunately, as much as I like this backpack, it's heading back to Amazon while I search for a bigger backpack. :-(
summary: Well designed and carries a lot more than expected

reviewText: The Sony NWZS764 is a great mp3 player.It sounds great, has a bright display and has the ability to access songs quickly and easily.However, I bought the S764 to replace a stolen NWZ-E354.  It's got only four stars because it's exactly like the E354 except with the couple of extra features that make it, oh, $10 or $20 more expensive have problems of it own.The Bluetooth headphones sound great and are neat to use when you want to clean the bathroom and your pajamas have no pockets but they cause the battery to drain ten times faster and the mp3 player to heat up like a sun kissed rock.  Definitely did not have fun realizing the battery was nearly dead after three or four hours while I'm used to the 354 model going four three or four days.Speaking of the battery, it's been said before but for some reason Sony decided to give this model it's own charging plug instead of the universal USB type.  So if you lose it, you'll be able to charge the Bluetooth headphones but NOT the mp3 player, which I find really inconvenient/dumb/useless (Pick one.).All in all, the S764 is a wonderful mp3 player in its own right.  However, if you're one of them old fashioned types (Just kidding) who like to keep their headphones attached to their mp3 player, save some money and go get the more convenient and less slippery (Would it kill Sony to make a mp3 player that's easy to grip?)Sony NWZE464BLK Walkman MP3 Playeror a similar, cheaper Sony model.
summary: Great Sony Product With A Couple of Kinks

reviewText: Fit:I found them to be lightweight and comfortable.Usability:The controls were fairly easy to use, but they were still a bit awkward given that the only resistance to the button press is your ear. However, given what the product is, I think this is fine.Sound Quality:The sound quality and volume simply isn't what I would expect for the price point. It's about the same as what you'd probably get from a $10-15 set of corded headphones.Issues:The Bluetooth connectivity kept dropping. Not instantly, but maybe once every 5-10 minutes. At first use, I had left my phone sitting directly in front of me, sitting on the treadmill's tray. I checked the instructions and strapped the phone to my right arm as indicated. Same problem... At this point, I just gave up on the headphones and haven't used them since.Conclusion:When running outdoors or on the treadmill, the last thing I want to do is worry about Bluetooth issues. If you're going to have to strap your phone to your arm, why not just use nice corded headphones designed for that (i.e. Sennheiser PMX 680)? Given the poor sound quality and connection issues, I don't think this device is worth using at any price point.

just installed this drive in an MSI Windpad 110w and it's performance is great! Windows experience index for this drive is an impressive 7.6 on Windows 8. 120GB is in HD manufacturers numbers. Real size is around 110GB. It's way faster than OEM mSata drives installed in netbooks and tablets and has plenty of storage. I'm dual bootìng Windows 8 and Ubuntu with plenty of room to spare...Bottom line, I love this drive!

The tiny SanDisk "Cruzer Fit" USB Flash Drives are the perfect solution to adding conveniently-removable storage space to your laptop without fear of the device becoming snagged or caught on nearby gear and/or clothing. The part that sticks out of the USB Port extends only ONE-QUARTER INCH beyond the surface -- it's actually kinda hard to remove, due to the tight fit and the small gripping area of the device -- BUT -- you can be sure the thing won't just FALL out when you're not looking.;>)The product illustration is ACTUAL SIZE of the Cruzer Fit 4GB. What you see is the COVER on the left, and the USB PLUG-IN on the right. The BLACK portion of the USB plug-in is the part that sticks out of the USB Port. It's practically snag-proof, and near-perfect for convenience and ease-of-use.I'm just wondering what to do with the "Cover" while the device is in use.There's a teeny-weeny, tiny-winey, teensy-weensy, little-bitty hole in the device -- presumably for a "carry-strap" -- but a piece of 10-lb.-test fishing line is about all I could get through the small, partially-obstructed hole.As they say, size matters -- and the device's conveniently-small size is kind of a penalty, since it's so small that it's hard to keep track of.I plan to leave mine plugged in to my PC, to be used as a Portable Family Photo Library.SanDisk quality and Amazon's low price made this a great deal !!

Well, I really don't have anything to complain about when it comes to this diminutive storage device. I've owned several flash drives over the years, all of them SanDisk. They've all  been great, but this one is my favorite.I really don't get all the complaining about it being too small. I like it that way - I can keep it in my pocket without noticing it at all, and I can even leave in in my laptop without fear of it breaking off like longer flash drives can do. It has a small metal loop on the end that I managed to fit a lanyard through (although I needed one with a very thin end on it).Plus, you get the status as the person with the smallest flash drive on the block :)Overall, as long as you don't have a tendency to lose small things, I would highly recommend this to you.

I tried this and I liked the texture of it. The stand itself works  when it's using the lid/flap of the case at multiple angles (not the "A" frame style. When the case is acting as a stand from  the lid/flap with multiple positions it is stable. HOWEVER when the stand is in the "A" frame position as pictured it is highly unstable at least in my testing. I really like this case, it has cutouts for all the items, camera, microphone, light sensors, etc and I am happy with it even though it isn't stable with the "A" frame design, but it is just fine with the multi-position design using the lid/flap of the case to choose your viewing angle.I would say this is a buy if you have the 10.1" Acer tablet.
summary: nice texture, fold back design not stable.

reviewText: THIS EYE CUP SERVES A GOOD PURPOSE WHEN WEARING GLASSES OR NOT WEARING GLASSES. IF  YOU NEED GLASSES TO SEE A GOOD FOCUS THIS EYECUP IS EXCELLENT.  IF YOU DO NOT WEAR GLASSSES YOU CAN STILL USE THE EYECUP.  THE EYECUP WILL HELP YOU CONCENTRATE ON YOUR SUBJECT BY LETTING YOUR EYE ZERO IN ON JUST WHAT IS IN THE VIEWFINDER.  VERY REASONABLY PRICED ITEM.

This bag is great and sturdy- met all my expectations. I use it to secure my laptop in my home when not in use. Plenty of interior room to store power cord, portable hard drive and USB mouse. And padded enough to feel secure.

I would NOT recommend the Adonit Jot Pro. Many people--including myself--have complained of scratches due to debris getting stuck between the plastic disc and the iPad screen. While the makers are staunch that the stylus itself is not the problem, it is impossible to keep your screen completely dust-free and very difficult to know (until it's too late) that a piece of something is etching away at your screen.So, first of all, GET A SCREEN PROTECTOR. There's NO other way around it.That being said, it works horribly with a screen protector, and wasn't much better without it, either. With it, it's very, very unresponsive and quite frustrating.Whether you're drawing or writing, it's often too slick and doesn't pick up what you've done. I have to press very hard, slow, and deliberately to get it to be consistent. I find my hand straining from that and it's just too slow. I have to "click" things multiple times to get it to work, often. Even though the "fine tip" was designed for fine and detailed writing, I actually find a nub stylus like the Wacom Bamboo to perform MUCH better -- it's faster, quieter, and much more responsive.
summary: Unresponsive and results in scratches; would not recommend

reviewText: The mirror is simple to use and setup.  The cable is long enough to route it around almost any car, and the video is great.  It came with a 4 Gb SD Card so I can test it right away.If you don't need a double camer (front/back view), and don't want to put another suction cap at you windshield, this is for you.
summary: Simple, work as advertised, excellent details

reviewText: I guess i dropped the ball and didnt read reviews on this.  i wanted to use a split screen for my 2 monitors.  this cable only shows the same picture on 2 different screens.
summary: This cable does not let you view 2 differnt screens.

reviewText: This access point is amazing.  I get a very strong signal in places where I barely got coverage with an older G consumer access point.  Also, the guest network feature is very interesting... it can use the same subnet (and thus, uplink without vlans) as the primary wireless network, but firewalls off the guests from contacting the restricted subnets.I'm only using one of them (for home), so it's not really an issue for me, but there only seems to be a way to set a RADIUS shared secret for the entire set of UAPs you're using, not individual APs (as you would want for NAP on Windows).  Also, I haven't found a way to upload a custom SSL certificate using Windows, although there is a way if your controller is running on Linux.

I bought this tablet for my Graphics Design class in college. We have some Wacom Intuos 4 in the graphics lab, I really enjoyed using it for Illustrator and InDesign assignments, so I wanted one for my own use.This is definitely not an Intuos, but it is really good. Since I only have used Intuos for about three weeks before buying the Capture, there aren't any feature that I miss (except the smaller size, but more on that later). Some reviewers mentioned lack of eraser as a big deal, maybe because I never used it on Intuos, I don't miss it at all. Erasers are only a shortcut key away anyways. Maybe for a full time designer that spend 10+ hours with their tablets, an eraser a big deal, but for casual users it's totally fine.Tablet size is enough for casual/non-professional use. Be aware that not all of the gray surface in the pictures is usable, about 75% of the total area. It is clearly marked by lines on the edges of the working rectangle.Speaking about the size of tablet, the screen size should also be taken into consideration. I use the Capture on my 16" laptop, and I feel that's a good combination. We have 27" iMacs in the graphics lab, so using Intuos 4 would make more sense on those huge screens. I'm sure even with smaller screens, bigger tablets = more precision = better results, but once again, for beginners, Capture's area is big enough.This tablet allows me to make some decent drawings on Illustrator. Using a tablet doesn't enhance your drawing skills, but it is definitely much better than drawing with a mouse. There's a learning curve to it, but it's not impossibly difficult.I read a lot of Wacom users complain about the nib wear on the latest generation of Wacom tablets. I haven't used it long enough to comment on nib wear, but it doesn't seem to be used at all after two weeks of use. Perhaps I just don't use it as much as those hard-core design enthusiasts.I like having the 'paper-like feel' drawing surface, but personally I don't like that feel when I'm using it for InDesign layout purposes. I'd rather have more 'glide' on the surface. So I bought a clear plastic folder, cut a tablet-sized piece and taped it over my Capture. It glides around easier (and perhaps saves the nib from wearing out too quickly). The folder only cost me 50 cents. Also, if I need to have that paper-like feel for precision drawing, I'll just remove the plastic cover and re-tape it afterwards. If you want to do so, use a low-tack tape to prevent tape residue build up on the tablet surface.For me, the biggest advantage of using a tablet is less fatigue on your wrists. When you're clicking and dragging a lot, such as when you're doing page layout in InDesign, using a tablet will be much easier on your wrists, and also much more precise.The multi-touch feature is a nice addition to the tablet; sometimes I use it for browsing. I still need to practice the multi-touch gestures, such as flick and scroll up/down, but so far I found the scroll and zoom feature really helpful when I browse. I didn't buy the tablet to use it as a full time track pad, but for me it is an useful extra feature.Overall, I'd highly recommend this tablet if you're a beginner / early enthusiast of digital graphics design. Or if you're looking for a giant trackpad. If you are a serious enthusiast, perhaps you'd like to consider Bamboo Create (a bigger version of Capture) or Intuos.
After having gone through several Apple docking cables (which always seem to fail at the point where the cord enters the adapter) I decide to try this new design.  It has held up for me flawlessly!

Never owning a headphone amp in my life, I thought I'd give it a chance since buying the new Audio Technica ATH-M50 headphones. I charged it, plugged all the cables in and the sound is definitely improved. Not that the Audio Technica ATH-M50 sound prior to the headphone amp is anything but crisp and spacious with pretty good bass, but this definitely gives it MORE. More of everything - highs, miss, lows, depth and it sounds really full. 5 stars.
summary: Quite good. Better than expected. Full sound.

reviewText: I have only had this unit for a day, so this is not particularly meaningful, but as an external hard drive it seems to work fine. However, the backup software is fatally flawed and I see other reviewers have had the same experience.I went through the setup process fine, and backed everything up. The only glitch was I was forced to supply a password. I did it, but I checked the box that said my user name could access the drive without the password.I tried to restore a test file, and was told I needed a password. I typed in the short, all lower-case letters one that I had supplied, one I have used many times for no-security passwords. I was told the password was incorrect. After trying it again, and no password, and a few other things, without warning I was told the number of attempts had been exceeded and the drive was permanently locked, with no recovery possible. The user name access obviously didn't work either. Incidentally, I used the same password to set up my Western Digital support account, and it was also refused when I tried to use it. I checked "forgot password" (an option not allowed on the drive itself, without a password the data are completely and forever unrecoverable). They sent me a new one by email, I cut and pasted it in, and it didn't work either. I tried a second time, and succeeded. This company is password-impaired. I know you may be thinking that I'm the world's worst typist, but I don't think that's the problem.If you're using the drive to carry files around, or just for spare capacity, this isn't a problem. But if you are counting on the drive backups as insurance for rare events, having even a small possibility of not being able to retrieve your data due to a software glitch on the drive makes it worthless for the purpose. I cringe at the thought of backing up files carefully for years, then finding out the drive is locked when you need to recover them.I had to erase the drive and start over. I searched the manufacturer's knowledge base and some Internet sites and found mine is a common problem. There were two likely causes. First is that I updated the software after backing up the files, but before trying to retrieve one. Apparently software updates sometimes scramble passwords. Second is that I powered down the computer in between backing up and trying to restore. Apparently powering down the computer or removing the USB cable without ejecting the drive can scramble passwords. If either of these are the correct answer, it obviously is impossible to rely on the drive to get back files you have backed up. For one thing, if your hard drives dies (the most common reason to need a backup), it would likely scramble your password.I thought about returning the drive on the theory that a manufacturer this sloppy about software might be sloppy about other things. Clearly Western Digital has no idea of required functionality for a backup drive, absolute reliability over years of use. Passwords should not be allowed, much less be mandatory, and if you have them, they have to be completely reliable.I think I'll keep it, however, and use it with some good quality backup software. The drive seems fine and it's a nice price.
summary: Do not use the backup software

reviewText: I have had this external drive for about three months now.  The drive sits in my backpack most of the time until I need to use it.  So far I have had zero issues with this hard drive despite it being jostled around in my backpack. I primarily use this hard drive to store photos and Adobe Lightroom catalogs.  The USB 3.0 connection is quite fast and I can copy a couple of gig of photos from a Compact Flash Card on a USB 2.0 reader between 1min and 2min.I regularly use the hard drive on Macs and PC's.  It works well on both machines, but I should add that when loading large Adobe Lightroom collections its noticeably slower when hooked to a USB 2.0 port.  To get this drive to work on both systems I had to format the drive into the FAT32 system.Given its performance, I intend to buy another of these drives.

I tried to persuade my wife to buy this for her Kindle Fire. She bought something else instead and was very disappointed. I bought this without her knowledge. Once it arrived, I removed the one she bought and replaced it with this one. When she "discovered" the new enclosure, she was thrilled. A perfect fit, protects well, and is slim and compact! Now she recommends to everyone who has a Kindle Fire to get one for themselves!

This is a great Kindle Fire Thin & Lightweight Folio Cover Stand.It adds very little thickness, weight or bulk to the Kindle Fire.The stand works well on stable & flat surfaces. The inside of the screen cover is soft and protects the Kindle Fire screen whike keeping it clean.It is a decent value at $30 to protect my $200 Kindle Fire.
summary: This is a great Kindle Fire Thin & Lightweight Folio Cover Stand

reviewText: I've had Marware Kindle covers before, and while they were ok, they were merely "good enough" budget covers compared to Amazon's official cover. After being disappointed by the step down in quality they took with this generations official cover, I gave the Marware a shot. I am super critical of covers, so I expected this would get 3-4 stars and I would have been content with that. However, Marware really stepped up their game with the Eco-Vue. The name makes it sound cheap, but it's one of the nicest feeling, most solidly built covers I've seen for the Kindle. The K4 sits so nicely in there it just seems like it was made for the cover rather than the other way around. I'm not a big fan of the strap system, but it's done very well here, with the black version of the Kindle looking especially nice inside.It's actually worth the cost, which is not true of almost all the covers of any price. Note: The cover did not fold flat on its own right out of the box, but that is actually a good sign with leather covers, and in time I have no doubt the K4 and Eco-Vue will grow into each other. In the meantime the elastic strap makes up for that. I was a little apprehensive about the internal hand-strap, because I prefer a plain, clean interior, and thought it would be aesthetically displeasing or leave lint or markings on the screen. So far my concerns have been unwarranted.Best thing this has over the official cover is it actually has padding, which you can't tell from the photos. Some covers claim padding but don't quite deliver. If you're looking at it wondering about that, let me assure you it is a pleasure to hold. I never expected this level of quality from Marware, but I gotta say, I have an $80 Italian Kindle cover that is not as nice as this. The brown is a really nice chocolate color as well.It is highly unlikely you will not be pleased with this cover. Keep this up, Marware, and maybe make some different colors/textures or a model without the hand-sleeve thingy for us purists.

I usually like Corel Products but this one did not work as I had hoped it would and I have removed it from my computer.I was hoping this would add to my viewing experience when I watched DVD's on my computer. I was excited with the idea of watching movies in 3D. While I was impressed with the menu that appeared while viewing a movie and found it an improvement over the Widows Media Menu that I had been using, I found the overall quality of the picture to be a minimal improvement and could not get the 3-D feature to work.I called Corel wondering if it could be my computer screen or which is a few years old (my computer is fairly new)or whether I was doing something wrong and was not given a definite answer as to why the 3D options did not seem to work or why the picture quality was not enhanced considering the box says that Corel's "upscaling technology" "delivers near-HD quality videos from DVDs." The technician was not sure, and did not seem able to help me address my concerns or willing to find someone who could help me.Most annoyingly, I found that when I went to listen to a CD in my computer WinDVD appeared instead of windows media player or the music library that comes with Windows 7. I contacted technical support through the Corel Website instant messaging option because when I called customer service by phone I kept getting disconnected. I was told that Corel WinDVD automatically becomes the  "preferred program" for all media programs and that I would have to go to the other media programs and make them the preferred programs once again. As a result, I just decided to uninstall the program. I should have the option to determine whether Corel WinDVd automatically becomes the preferred program or not.Perhaps someone more familiar with computers and video could have gotten more out of Win DVD. Yet, I did contact Corel twice and I did not find the support all that helpful.I gave this 3 stars because I did like the menu that appeared when I watched a dvd. Perhaps someone more familiar with computers and video could have gotten more out of Win DVD. Yet, I did contact Corel twice and I did not find the support all that helpful. If Corel support either can't or won't help me figure out how to get the most out of a product they sell, it is not for me.
summary: Did Not Live Up to expectations and Corel Support Could Not Help.

reviewText: The Rosewills work as advertised.  My reason for buying the strips is to save money.  I have a wall of electronics that sucks power even when not in use.  I purchased 2 strips and intend to install them with the eaziest access so anyone can turn devices on/off without trouble.  The strips are great but nothing is perfect, I can think of several redesigns that would make the strip more pleasing to the users.  There nothing wrong functionally but the wife commented that all the wires hanging down was unslightly.  Sorry I promised I'd mention her words.  Simply moving the switch to the side or top, depending on how installed, can put the wires almost out of sight.

I researched extensively on an affordable tablet just for playing games with and settled on this model as it was the lowest price.  Seems like the various Coby models are pretty similar so I didn't see any reason to pay more than necessary ($93/free shipping).  It's totally true:  you do get what you pay for.  I won't be using it to surf the web much since it is pretty tedious to use the keyboard option.  I didn't find any apps I cared for on the GetJar site.  I have called the Coby Cust. Serv. # on a few occasions to get help and advice - they were awesome for service!  They suggested the Amazon App Store and there are LOADS of apps for this tablet through Amazon, so I am pretty happy with that aspect.  Unfortunately, the one reason I bought this tablet was to play Bejeweled 3 and Bej. Twist; neither of which PopCap has for the Android tablets, yet.  The stylis that is included was pretty narrow and made my hand cramp after much use, so I picked up a larger diameter stylus with a fine tip at Best Buy to utilize since finger swiping is a little less than optimal with this tablet.  If you want a tablet to do everything on, figure on spending several hundred dollars.  If you just want to play a game here or there, then this one will be adequate.

A must for this brand is downloading 1Mobile Market onto your new or exisiting tablet, due to many who want Android Market access and have frustrations, this application will enable you to download many apps you really can use and make your tablet run smoothly;1Mobile Market - appsZD Box - many programs to move certain apps to your micro SD card, uninstall programs etc.Cache Cleaner - removes temp filesVoice Search- the best for one touch voice command to navigate the web, or .com sitesSkyfire- a much faster browser for andrioidsTV flash - across the world TV networks and programmingCrackle - Movies and TV showsFlash Player 11 - so your youtube or movies run smoothly
summary: download 1Mobile Market for EZ loading of apps

reviewText: I have a Samsung Galaxy S3 phone and a Nexus 7 Tablet as well as a Samsung GalaxyTab 10.1. It works well with all these gadjet's. I use it alot. It has great sound and the sound doesn't bother my neighbors. I live in a four plex and if I play my surround sound system they get bent. Not so with this handy little unit. And the alarm works great to. The FM reception is better than you might expect from a unit of this type. Don't know what all the complaints are about. I have none. I would reccommend it for what it is. A glorified clock radio/bluetooth device that works well with android devices. Which are the only devices I will own. Android rules!

I saw a lot of reviews from people complaining about the price of this device. Unfortunately, Android Bluetooth docks/speakers are a relatively new product, so the price range is above what it feels like it should be. But, look around, and you will find that there isn't really anything cheaper available. Even ones that aren't Bluetooth enabled, ones you need to physically plug your device to using a cable, aren't much cheaper than this one, so you're paying for the "new technology" and this type of device should be much cheaper in a couple of years.That said, I was very happy with my Fidelio. It is nice-looking, very light and portable, and it delivers very good sound. Pairing it with my phone was very easy, actually, so easy that I wonder if other people can't pair their devices to it, now that I think about it. It feels like any neighbor might be able to pair with it as long as they're in range, since there isn't a step to confirm the device being added from the dock. Once paired, plugging the phone onto the dock is also very easy, no cords hanging, just a very moveable plug that can be adjusted so that you can fit your device onto it. Or, you can keep the device with you and use it as a remote. Brilliant!Like I said, all things considered, I'm very happy with it. At the time I purchased it, the price was in the high 80's, so not as high as it was before. And I'm sure in a few months it will be much lower, which is why I will wait to get a couple more to place around my home. But I feel it's worth the price for the convenience and quality.Enjoy!
summary: When you take everything into consideration, it's a good value

reviewText: I got this at a brick and mortar store for $12 which makes me like it even better, I'm not sure if I would have paid $25 for it. My Nexus 7 tablet fits in the sleeve snugly, it's the perfect sleeve to keep it protected around the house or keep things from scratching it in my purse.
summary: Perfect sleeve for a Nexus 7 tablet

reviewText: When I bought this, I told several people I had and they only had kudos for me.  This is a great purchase for anyone in need of a camera, and, from what I've seen, it HAS GOT to be one of the better digital handheld cameras out there on the budget market.  Buy this, and you'll be happy with nearly every single shot that comes out of it.  NOTE: I bought a memory extension, so that may be why the capabilities are at 100% and no less.  This will be one of your better camera purchases, and if you attempt to print out the photos at a facility, they appear crisper than any photos I've ever seen coming out of a camera that costs less than $700.  DEFINITELY RECOMMENDED.

I researched the heck out of this and did read that some were having concerns with motor noise while zooming in video mode.  This is a real problem I hoped not to have since the complaint was few and far between.  I read from others that origination of manufacture might be the problem.  The first product I had made the noise and was made in China (according to the box).  I requested replacement, which arrived timely.  The second camera was made in Japan (according to the box).  It, too, has very upleasant motor noise while zooming in video mode.The camera functions are good, and this camera performs much better in low light than any I've had.  If you don't care about the video noise, this camera is a good investment.  Camera and video quality exceeds all other small Canon camera's I've owned.  Too bad they just can't get it right.  The video noise is a deal breaker for me.  Personally, I haven't found anything that beats the TX1, but it is very poor in low light.Amazon should list this in the Product Information.  It's a buyer beware world out there.....
summary: Motor Noise is a deal breaker

reviewText: UPDATE: Still camera shots are great.  Video is usually good, but if you are filming a performance where there is silence at times (say a play), you can hear the zoom motor and a definite click as it stops and locks.  This does not make for good video as any zooming is underlined and attention is taken away from what you are filming.  I rarely do that kind of filming, but this is a disappointing camera in that aspect.  However, to be fair, I don't notice the zoom noise when taping musical performances or when speaking is pretty much non-stop as with a speech, sermon or lecture.  But zoom motor noise is glaringly there when there is silent or very low volume action going on.Also, battery life doesn't do much better than 30 minutes even with freshly charged batteries.  So, if you want to film a longer event, this is not your camera.  Also, if you carry the camera around and expect to pull it out for events you just happen upon, don't expect more than 4-5 minutes of battery life for video footage.After 8 months of use, I would now give the SX150 a three or four star rating.  It's a good camera, but with real limitations.-----I bought this to replace a Canon A2000 IS.  It doubled the optical zoom, still used AA batteries, and added manual mode and all for only $165.This is a beauty.  I've tested it on people photos, hand held photos of the moon in manual mode, and macro close ups.  It has performed very nicely.  Even the flash has performed well for a little flash. The video footage is well lit and even does reasonably well in a semi-dark room when you zoom in on the subject.The battery indicator is way too sensitive.  At a child's birthday party not long after I had put newly charged batteries in it warned me that the batteries were getting low.  I decided to see how long the batteries would last.  Twenty-one minutes of video and various still shots later the batteries were still going.  Those batteries (NiMH) lasted for another week of relatively light photo taking before finally needing to be recharged.  So, I have learned to disregard the low battery indicator.Though in a pinch the camera can fit in the front pocket of not too tight jeans (though it is visually evident you have something bulgy in your front pocket), I use aPolaroid Studio Series Universal Compact Camera Case (Black) For The Canon, Nikon, Kodak, Sony, Polaroid, Panasonic, Olympus, Pantex, Fuji, Casio, Samsung Digital Camera.  It just barely fits (only one way with the lens end up and fits best with the lens facing the front), but the case is nicely made with a good strap.  In the case it can fit in a purse, briefcase or bookbag easily and is protected.Besides the overly sensitive battery warning indicator, I can't think of anything I don't like about this camera.  This allows me to carry a first class compact camera with me all the time with the great flexibility of a 12x zoom and manual mode and no worries about battery replacement that using standard AA batteries brings.
summary: Great little camera; battery strength better than indicator; zoom noise & clicks

reviewText: I got this for my wife, who has been shopping for a cover for her Kindle Fire for months now.  Everything she found in the stores was too cheap looking and she was afraid to order more expensive things on-line because she wouldn't be sure to like it.  I took a chance on this, but it worked out well: she thought it was very good looking and is happy with how it holds and protects the Kindle.  It looks like a real leather book - very well done!Her only complaint is that it adds a lot of weight.  I don't see how you can avoid that without looking or actually being cheap and she agrees.

I am using this beautiful cover on my Kindle Keyboard.  The four corner bands hold my Kindle securely in place.  There is a bit of silicone on the back of the elastic, so there is no chance of my Kindle coming loose or falling out.  The front and back of the cover is thick and padded, so I feel it offers good protection against minor knocks.The left side of the cover can be folded back behind the right side, making it easy to read my Kindle one handed.  The spine is a little thinner, less padding, which makes it easy to bend and/or clip on a stylus on the outside.  With my KKeyboard, there is no space to clip a stylus inside.I was surprised to find this cover has no clasp.  None at all.  It is just a cover.  At first, I thought it was magnetic because it seems that way when I unpacked it, but I quickly discovered the magnets are on the cardboard inserts that you pull out and discard.  Not having a closer/clasp doesn't bother me, in fact I think it makes it more like an actual book cover.  I just thought it worth mentioning.I love the design and styling of this cover, from the luxurious 'leather' and the classy embossing.  It really feels good in my hands, like an old leather book--I can't believe it's not actually real leather!  It's a beautiful, functional cover, and I can't gush enough about the way it feels in my hands and looks on my Kindle.  Love it.

I tried several times to use the drive to create disk images of my several computers. It always failed. It may have something to do with its non-standard configuration as a more than 2T drive. Years ago we hit similar barrier at seval Gb (I forgot all the details) and the manufacturers who were able to offer drives larger than this limit worked faster than Microsoft updating their FAT file tables (I think this was during the days when NFTS was not much used).It worked in a fashion then and, perhaps, it may work now if Seagate solved the problems as well.Since I cannot handle non-standard (read non-Windows 7) stuff any longer,I had to return the otherwise functional drive to Amazon and UPS picked it up promptly.I read some of the comments here but I am just too old to learn new tricks.Standardization (read cmpatibility with ALL features of Windows 7) is the name of the game for me now.
summary: Could not ceate a disk image

reviewText: The Seagate FreeAgent GoFlex Desk 2TB USB 3.0 External Hard Drive is a great option for those that want to perform local back-ups, and still have plenty of room for off-line storage.  This drive worked right out of the box, and installed easily on Windows 7.  The USB 3.0 makes it fast for an external drive.  I have been using this drive for over a month without any issues.Pros: Fairly inexpensive drive, performs well, installs easily on Windows 7, back-ups are much faster due to USB 3.0Cons: None, but be aware your computer will need USB 3.0 ports to get the best performance from this drive.

I had purchased one of these within the past year.  Worked fine at first, then started noticing problems.  Using it on Windows Vista.1) Started making noise intermittently.2) Computer could not find it, pending back ups started piling up.3) No power switch, so you have to unplug it to refresh it and get the computer to see it again.4) Slow transfer rate.  Transfers would sometimes get hung up halfway through and have to be cancelled.5) Now, as of this week, Computer does not see it, powering it off and back on again has not fixed the problem.  The LED on the front just fades on and off in an intermittent fashion.  2TB of data are stuck in this thing, and I can't access the drive.Will try and replace the power adapter with a new one I just ordered on Amazon though I doubt that is the problem.  This thing has been questionable for several months now.  Have other Seagate drives that work well, but this one is horrible.  No more Seagate drives for me.

Perfect fit in a Thinkpad T61 (type 7663-B15).ProsFunctional directly out of the packagingMaintains its charge well (a couple hours of heavy use)Good price/performance ratioConsNothing observed. It has not come loose, developed shorts, started making ominous noises or caught on fire.Other thoughtsAfter seven months of service, it is still going strong and holding a charge properly. I'll say this confirms a 5-star rating in my book. I'll be thrilled if it goes 1.5 years longer (since that means that we also didn't have to replace the laptop this powers). The Thinkpad battery minder determines that it's a non-Lenovo battery (just so you know if you see the warning).The main photo doesn't show this well, but the battery does not mount flush with the rear of the laptop; this is expected in today's higher-drain machines. So you know, it protrudes 1.5" off the rear of the laptop, and has an angled portion for some of the batteries so it doesn't protrude even further. This is not an issue for me, but may be for you if your laptop sleeve is already tight.

Used this for a few weeks on a river trip, lake trip, and swimming pool trip.  Takes great still shots and video.  Look on youtube for examples of the 1080p video it can do.  After reading a ton of reviews, I was sold on it, and am very happy that I went with this one.  The still images are great for a small point and shoot.  This is my camera that I carry the most, and have great confidence that my pics always turn out great.  It has a TON of great features and picture settings as well that really help you take great shots.  I won't go into all of them here, but rest assured, they work well.  As I use it, I'll post back with updates if anything changes, but as of right now, this thing rocks!
summary: Great camera!!!  Awesome picture and video quality!
