reviewText: My dad has a Nikon D3 and I have been envious of his DLSR for quite some time now. I am an amateur when it comes to photography, but I have always had a good eye for a well taken photograph. So I can make a pretty crummy camera like my old Kodak digital camera still take some neat shots using the light and knowing the camera's limitations.This baby can be as simple as you want it if you are an amateur like myself, or you can fool around with every setting on the sun. It is touted as the worlds fastest shooting DSLR and well, I can believe that because I've seen my dad use his Nikon and this is a lot faster. Point, click and you are done. Sharp pictures, no mess no fuss.Included is the USB cable, which I find a little thin, the CD and a booklet. A really thick booklet which I am still trying to filter. I've come to the conclusion that I am basically going to have to learn a lot more about photography terms in order to hang with the more techie opinions here, but it has always been an interest in my family and I have a rather good teacher.The camera build feels incredible. It is heavy, but not unweidly. It is very solid. The LED screen is bright and vivid. The wall charger is a breeze, you might want a lens dust cover, an extra battery, a carry case and an HDMI cable.I will be sure to update this with any further thoughts and opinions. I think the price tag here is pretty reasonable for the value of the package. So I highly recommend.

I've had this for about a month now, and wanted to wait a bit and use it a while prior to writing my review.  I have been using a Canon SLR for the past five years, so a lot of my experience (and basis / comparison for this review) is using the Canon as a benchmark.  I am not a professional photographer, just a husband and a dad that takes a few pictures in our walk of life.The shutter speed is pretty darn fast - a lot faster than my Canon.  Sony has done a good job with the technology that allows rapid-fire clicking and if you aren't careful you will have whipped out 3-4 shots when you only meant to take one.  I had to practice for a bit to get the method down.Switching the lens out for my Canon-branded zoom lens was easy, but I needed an adapter.I took several indoor pictures with medium and bright lighting, and several pictures outdoors of the flowers in my garden, at the same time, as a comparison of the Sony and my trusty Canon.  I then put the pictures side-by-side on Photoshop and the ones outside with the Sony and the same lens were much more crisp, colorful, and printed a lot better than the Canon; the ones taken inside with either lighting situation were just a little bit better in looks for me - I will attribute that to the larger megapixel of the Sony vs. the Canon.This is a fairly well-built camera, and has a smaller profile than I thought it would and really doesn't weight too much.  This is not something you can put in your pocket or a smaller purse but, depending upon the weight of your lens, you're probably not going to have a pinched nerve in your neck after wearing it to a gymnastics meet.I have not used the video that much, maybe about 30 minutes or so, but the resolution and sound is pretty good - I think my standalone Sony video camera does a better job, but when you want to quickly revert from one to the other this model does an acceptable job.The battery understandably drains down quicker on video mode, so if you plan on doing a lot of video with this camera you might want to consider buying a larger-capacity battery or a backup that is charged.  For straight photo shooting, I didn't notice a large degradation in the battery power after several  kid events (50-75 shots per session), and I usually put it back on the charger at the end of the day.  Your results may vary.One neat thing to me is you can look at your shot on the digital screen, but if you put your eye up to the viewfinder it automatically detect s you looking through the viewfinder and switches the view to it and turns off the LED screen which will conserve your battery.  They also have GPS tagging, which could help you when you review your pictures and the inevitable question "where was that taken" question comes up.Overall, I think this is a really nice camera and I am using it exclusively now - since I have additional lenses, I am liking this one even more.  If you have extra lenses, I would recommend this one - if you are a casual photographer, seeing this one is fairly pricey I would recommend something more economical as $1,400 is a lot of money to pay for just a few pictures a year.
summary: Great Camera and Excellent Picture Quality

reviewText: The first outing with this camera in my wife's hands was a complete success.  She is graduating from a pocket digital to the bigs.  She had great fun with the camera and got some great shots.  It will do all the work for you as a novice, or let you work yourself as much as you want.As always, the Sony images are fantastic.  The settings can be intimidating until you remember to let the camera make the decisions if you are in doubt.  Excellent in low lighting situations.

Modern design and production techniques have made it possible to mass market complex, automated lenses like the Sony E 55-210. But, can a modern consumer lens compete with an old legend? Gots to have a test...I have a 40 year-old Leica Elmar-C 90mm, off of the "entry level" compact Leica CL of the day. And while it is old, nothing is really all that new in the actual optics, especially in this focal range. Even the coatings were just fine then. It is a heavy little sucker, made of glass and brass, and nearly the same weight as the far bigger Sony.Nothing like the Big Sur coast for photos of rocks and water. Perched on a rock above a cove where the ancients once gathered abalone, I shot away with all of my lenses and my newly arrived Nex-7 from Amazon. Yay! Not a horrible way to spend an almost 75 degree sunny day in early March.After downloading and enlarging the results at 100% it was evident that at 90mm the Sony was just a hair less sharp in the center than the Leica. At the edges, the Leica was clearly superior. Wow! To me that is both a testament both how good Leica was making entry level lenses 40 years ago and how an affordable, automated zoom can compete with a quality prime lens at the length and sunny lighting conditions that the Leica was optimized to work at! Awesome.I believe that even a laboratory sort of test would find the same results. It was pretty clear in a real world sort of way.And, in the real world the Sony goes way beyond what any prime can do. You can zoom in and fill the frame, avoiding cropping. This will equalize the sharpness factor in many cases. It can focus automatically, has optical stabilization so that even the longest telephoto shots are sharp. It can be hand-held and allows for high shutter speeds, an aid to sharpness in itself of course. It is capable of fully being controlled by the camera and in essence becomes one with the camera in a way that is different than the past when you manually operated your camera, then manually operated whatever brand lens was on it.In video mode it tracked a big buzzard as it flew by. It focused well on waves coming at me, with the sun glaring from directly behind them.It worked well with a 49mm polarizing filter.The manual focusing is very smooth and precise, with a decent feel to it. It is a very good looking design, again modern in look as well, but the turned aluminum parts are more likely to be scratched than the rubbery, plasticy lenses on my old Nikon D40. I really need to get a decent little divided case. You can't just throw these new Sony lenses into a pile.In the end, this is a quality, useful and well-priced lens, one I will always have with me when I go shooting around. You can get good results with the old technology, but modern lenses like this, mated to the cameras they were designed to work with, are just another thing altogether. The five-star rating reflects the value and utility of this excellent lens.
summary: A modern lens for modern times

reviewText: Pros (5 stars):* This is a great (very) little piece of hardware from a functionality standpoint. It has a nice Web interface that's fairly straightforward and most of the same options and functions as the "big boys".* At $17 or so, the price is definitely right.* It gives me a good, known SSID to program into my EyeFi cards.* I used it constantly during a 4-day trip and it worked flawlessly.Cons (minus 2 stars):* I connected the Ethernet port (WAN) to my local LAN so I could do the initial set-up as a router/AP and happened to do a scan of the network (using Fing on my Android phone) and found it had TCP 23 (Telnet) open on the WAN side - which would be the public/Internet side when actually in use. I was able to telnet into the device using the admin credentials and access a command line prompt. Fortunately, I was able to use port redirection to send the port to a non-existent IP address. This could potentially be a real security problem. I probably should have taken off a lot more stars, but I really like this box and the fix was very easy. I may also try using a port filter with the firewall functionality, but I knew the port redirection would work and I was in a hurry to get ready for my trip.* No custom firmware (dd-wrt, tomato, etc) available yet* No links available for OEM firmware updates (that I could find)Overall (3 stars): I like it and I plan to keep using it, but I think the firmware should be fixed so that it doesn't have telnet potentially open to the Internet.
summary: Good little router with a security problem

reviewText: I bought this cable because I can't find anything that says it is genuine Samsung equipment in 6 ft. long.  the stock cable that comes with the note is pathetically short.  However this cable is a piece of junk.  I plugged it in once and it fell apart.  the 30 pin connector was too wide and got stuck in my tablet and I feared it would ruin my $500 tablet.  luckily I got it out but the connector completely fell apart wires were coming out I shocked my self.  I will never buy non genuine parts again,  what a waste of my money.  Shame on you Amazon,  show some discretion.

These days I listen to music on my iPhone primarily in the gym while exercising, and for those purposes the Bluetooth wireless headphones are mostly adequate. However, almost all of those headphones have very subprime sound quality, to say the least. The standard iPhone headphones are not much better, but they are usually the ones that I reach for when listening to music in other situations. Unfortunately, as a consequence of these choices of headphones I've been inadvertently forced to settle for a rather inferior music-listening experience. So when I came across XePort's headphones, I had felt that my ears had been opened. I've used high-quality headphones in the past, and in terms of sound quality the XePort headphones are definitely on par with many of those.***** The Sound Quality *****The sound quality is definitely one of the biggest selling points of these headphones. They make a crisp, loud and well-formed sound. When listening to classical piano works I can hear each note reverberating clearly and distinctly from the others. The high notes don't have the "tinny" sound that I've been accustomed to from many lower-end headphones. The lower notes are rich and warm, but the bass leaves something to be desired.. The high fidelity of sound is particularly noticeable when listening to the older recordings - all the subtle "noise" of such recordings comes clearly through.  The overall sound quality is not quite as good as the one of the XePort 5010-8 model, but it is definitely above most low-end headphones.I particularly liked using these headphones with dance/electronic music. They can really push the beat through.***** Noise Canceling *****These headphones don't have the active noise-canceling capabilities, but their passive noise suppression was more than adequate for most of my purposes. This is particularly the case when listening to music somewhat loudly - all the surrounding sounds were completely blocked, and hardly any of the headphones' own sound leaked out.***** Accessories *****In addition to the actual headphones, the packaging includes three sets of silicone single flange tips. The tips ought to fit most ear sizes. They are comfortable and easy to replace.***** Look and Feel *****These headphones look pretty elegant and fashionable. I am not too thrilled with the woven nylon cable, but it too has certain charm and can be a fashion statement in its own right. The white ceramic unibody look is very pretty, and it comes closes to the "replacement" look for the Apple's signature in-ear headphones. So if you'd like to stick to that particular visual aesthetic, then thee headphones will be a perfect choice for you. I would have liked to have some playback/volume controls placed on the headphones themselves, but this is not a deciding feature for me. The headphones are very light and they fit smoothly and unobtrusively into your ears. Even after a few hours of listening to the music on them they did not become uncomfortable. Oftentimes I have a slight pain in my ears after wearing some other in-ear headphones, but so far I have not had any such experience with XePort 7010-0.***** Conclusion *****These are really very good headphones and they will make any music lover pretty happy. They are solidly built, have a good sound quality, and an unbeatably low price. Highly recommended.
summary: Elegant In-ear Headphones with Good Sound Quality

reviewText: Amazing to buy , many costumiers buying with my services this brand , i only wish to get good services such this

Having tried another product, JLab Go with the air plugs, I was looking for something else.  The Go worked ok but leaked into the ear and became distracting and did not always stay on - would not survive a flip turn.  That said it's great for running and biking.So I ordered the swimp3 on the mere suggestion of the existence of such a device by a lifeguard at the pool.  Tried it this morning for first time and it was fantastic.  I also bought Finis goggles so leaking was not much of an issue.  Songs loaded easily and sounded great with slightly better than expected bass too.  I could hear it out of the water as well so being submerged was not a requirement.Don't know about long term durability but love it so for.
Overall a nice mouse. Could have a tad bit more heft, but it is fine as is. Got it because it is compatible with the Logitech unifying wireless dongle.

I have quite a few backup drives, and have to keep upgrading them due to the nature of the current media-storing habits, and Fantom drive was a good buy for the price and storage capability.  It worked from the get-go with Windows XP and Windows 7, and I formatted the drive (just to be safe).  No problems so far and I would recommend this drive for anyone who is looking for a desktop backup.  One problem - it does not have side stands (like my older drives did)!

reviewText: I keep this at work as an extra charger.  The USB port plugs into my computer (PC) and I charge my iphone.  The only drawback is that it doesn't charge my ipad too.
It does a good job in diffusing the light and I really like that it folds down to be put away when your done.

A headset that works with a PC, Xbox or PS3 sell for as much as the Xbox or PS3 itself... better be worth it.And, to my surprise and delight, this one is. The 'over the ear' headphones alone are up in the league with stand-alone versions in that price range. So, if 'quality and comfort' count well... they come at a price. But let me discuss/rate the package in its entirety.CONTENTS, INSTALLATION, DOCUMENTATION WARRANTY (4.5 out of 5)This is what you get out of the box:* Sound Blaster Tactic Omega Wireless Headset (the headphones)* Detachable Microphone* Sound Blaster Recon (module that connects to the PC or gaming console)* Tactic Link wireless card (plugs into the Recon)* Installation CD (for PC only)* Inline volume control (for Xbox only)* Micro USB-to-USB cable (2 of them, will explain why)* Optical cableSetup is clearly illustrated by the Quick Start leaflet. It's as easy as attaching the wireless card to the Recon module and connecting the module to the PC or gaming console. Consoles are also using the optical cable. The Xbox requires that the Inline volume control wire is connected to the wireless controller (I only used it with a PS3 and a PC).The headphones charge from any PC or standard USB charger (not provided) through the provided USB cable. I used successfully both a PC and a third party PS3 charger. If used with a PC/laptop you should be able to use the second USB cable to charge the headphones while using them if needed. Once charged, the headphones will link to the Recon module within seconds of powerup.Half a star is lost for the warranty terms. It only lasts for one year and the shipping costs are the owner's responsibility. Make sure that you save the dated purchase receipt to avoid any surprises.OPERATION AND USER EXPERIENCE (5 stars out of 5)When used with a console, the Recon module and headphones all controls are good enough to provide a superior gamer (and not only) experience. Besides volume controls on both the module and the headphones, there is Mic Gain switch (low/mid/high) to control voice input. When playing games you can select the 'scout mode' especially on FPS which will enhance the sounds made by your opponents. The other option is THX TruStudio Pro mode, perfect for listening to music or movie watching.On a PC the options expand dramatically. You don't need to use the provided software on the PC but if you need total control over your THX setup - surround mode from 2 to 7 speakers, bass, crossover frequency - over how you are heard when you speak into the microphone (we're set to 'alien brute'), the dynamic range control plus a mixer and an equalizer that allows you to pick any of a number of preset profiles or make up your own... you will be using the software.I found the adjustable headphones to be extremely comfortable. Hours of use at a time caused no noticeable discomfort.RATING (5 stars)After trying this set out for a couple of weeks I was turned from a skeptical tester to an enthusiastic proponent. Yes, they are not cheap but to anyone that sound matters when playing game, the quality and features that this set provides is hard to beat.

reviewerName: Valerie J. Douglas "Author and Dream Weaver"

Bought the second one and about to get the third one for the guest room. I bought other brands in the $50-$150 price range and returned them all. The remote is a good indication. If it is a flimsy one, do not even open the box. I tested (OK) but did not use the wireless as I use the ZyXEL powerline switch to extend the LAN into every room. The best thing about this gadget is that there isn't a single file it cannot play - rmvb, AVI, MPx, full HD etc.. A couple of AVI files that won't play on my W7 desktop played in this box! I hooked up a 1.5TB drive to the USB port and it works great. There are 2 USB ports for the Y splitter power of some of my SATA shell drives. Overall, all my media files are in the server because of this box and I can watch the movies in every room. No problem with sync of sound and video. The connection speed varies from 20-40K. For $100, this gadget is worth it.

This is my favorite router ever.  I have been a Belkin fan for years but this Netgear really kicked the heck out of my Belkin.  I recently purchased a Belkin AC1200 at the same time as this Netgear router.  I put both on line at my home and left them both wide open, no encryption.  Then the test began.  I walked around the house with my Lenovo laptop and tested signal strength.  Inside the house both seemed equal.  I then went down the street, even crossed the street and sat on the steps of another house.  The Netgear N900 gave me 5 bars where the Belkin gave me only 1 bar.  I was able to get 3 to MBPS download with the Netgear N900.  The Belkin would cut in and out and loose signal.That completely sold me.  Plus I stream HD BLue Ray on my DVD player and the Netgear N900 never misses a beat.  I have always been a Belkin fan but I have to say the Netgear N900 really kicked it out of the park...Setup was very easy, the web interface is very good.  I am very pleased with this purchase and would recommend it to anyone as a great home router.Tom

Keep in mind that this entire product category has fallen to a $30 price range.  So I do not view this as a bargain basement item.  Especially since this is a name brand Samsung item versus a generic enclosure.The enclosure is light weight glossy plastic on top and sturdier textured plastic underneath.  Light weight is probably good if you want to carry this around.  On the other hand, I have a tiny laptop without a DVD drive so I don't have to carry around a DVD drive built in to the computer or otherwise.  I expect this thing to never leave my house and only be used for occasional software installs or re-imaging.NEGATIVES:When I first connected the device it did not power up.  I examined the plugs and decided the micro USB connection on the device itself did not look like it was fully inserted even though I firmly pushed in the cable.  I gave the USB plug a very, very hard push (harder than I would have been willing to do on a laptop or camera for example).  It slid further into the connector and the device powered up.Then I push the open button on the CD tray and I get a grinding noise.  I try a few more times and the tray will not open but sounds like the open/close motor is just grinding like something is holding the tray in place.  I get a paper clip and start poking at the emergency release hole next to the release button.  The tray still won't pop open even using the "manual" release method.  I decide to try the electronic button again and suddenly the tray pops open.The dual USB power connection method is a good idea but poorly executed here.  The included dual connection cable is too short to reach any pair of USB ports that are not directly over/under.  I only see those on old laptops and desktops.  I deal with numerous laptops at home and work and all have USB ports spread around at least several inches away from each other even if they are on the same side of the computer.  Only because I have lots of random PC cables did I happen to have a USB extension that allowed me to connect this at all.  Be aware that you will likely need a USB extension cable at least 3 to 6 inches long to reach 2 ports on a typical laptop unless you have a pair of directly over/under ports.POSITIVE:I put the unit through it paces by burning a 4 DVD recovery media set from a new laptop and then writing back those discs onto a new SSD.  All discs were created and read without error.I suspect that I probably put more effort into getting it to work out of the box then some other user may be inclined to (hence some of the other negative reviews).  Quality control seems a bit lacking for a Samsung product.  I would happily pay another ten bucks for a more substantial enclosure and a better USB cable in the box.  I think Samsung really cut a few corners trying to get to this price point.Bottom line is this works.

I'm thinking, yeah, yeah, another integrated bluetooth keyboard case, but at the low price point, it's worth the gamble.Wow! When I opened the well-done package and caught my first glimpse of this beautifully designed keyboard case, I was stunned.  This can't be right.  It's too good for that kind of money.  The back of it is seamless aluminum and the controls and indicators (on-off, connect, status) are intuitive.Okay, so it's very attractive and looks well-made, but will I have issues pairing it with my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 tablet?  Nope. The BT settings function on my Sam 10 (my name for it) scanned and discovered the Logitech BT keyboard almost instantly and provided the four-digit code to enter on the keyboard to complete the pairing.  I entered the code, it completed the pairing.  No muss, no fuss.It looks great, but how does it feel?Feels good like a keyboard should.  The keys are comfortably spaced with lots of special keys at the top like cut, paste, email, internet, microphone, sound functions and screen lock, and a couple I haven't figured out yet because I haven't needed them.  Needless to say, it leaves nothing to be desired in the special keys department.The tactile feel of the keys is just right for me.  Not too sloppy and not too tight.Oh, did I mention the perfectly dimensioned grove at the top of the keys where the tablet fits in to make it a kind of laptop configuration?  No? Well it works fantastic.  My Sam 10 fits in that groove and I type away as if it was a for-real notebook.  (I'm still wondering how they can do this for the low price I got it for, but hesitate to include this because they might want to take it back, and they can't have it.)When done with the keyboard, I reverse the Sam 10 so the screen is facing the keyboard and it fits snugly into the slightly raised, about 5mm, walls of the keyboard housing with cutouts for the Samsung cable connector, and a long one at the other end for accessing the power switch, volume rocker, microSD card slot and earphone jack. The result is a compact and slim package affording the Sam 10 screen max protection and exposing only the durable back side.There are no batteries to worry about with this keyboard.  It comes with a USB cable that connects the keyboard to your notebook, netbook, PC, or whathaveyou to keep it's battery charged between uses.The only downside I can come up with, and it's a humongous stretch, is that the Sam 10 doesn't like to sit in the keyboard grove in portrait configuration.  It tends to fall backward.  But, in landscape configuration it sits like a rock.Do I recommend this keyboard to Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 owners?  You betcha!
summary: Best Bang for the Buck, Period!

reviewText: The Philips DS8530/37 Fidelio Docking Speaker, made in China, comes with a headphone cable & remote.  PureDigital sound processing delivers clear and crisp sound while the tuned bass pipes add deep and tight bass reproductions providing exceptional audio quality. The modern appearing docking speaker, measuring 17" wide, 6" tall 6" deep, consists of a black plastic backing and black metal mesh front. A power port and auxiliary input are located on the back, and a brushed metallic ring on the front serves as the docking area with a 30-pin connector and includes volume + and - buttons.The iPhone / iPad AppUsing the Philips' iDevice DockStudio app is required to utilize many features and get the most out of the Philips DS8530/37 Fidelio Docking Speaker.  Controlling the Dynamic Bass Boost (DBB) and equalizer settings can only be set through the app while physically connected.  The DockStudio app features also includes playback controls, a multi-function alarm clock with sleeptimer and alarm, music collection browsing, sharing via Facebook and Twitter, access to more than 7,000 internet radio stations and podcasts using TuneIn radio, plus displays current local weather conditions.I'm indifferent to using the DockStudio app.  The alarm clock requires the app to be running for use, browsing and listening to the internet radio stations and podcasts is tedious, and the app doesn't integrate with Pandora accounts.  Plus the weather feature tells me I don't have an internet connection on my iPad, even though I do.  Philips attempts to enrich the Fidelio experience may successfully do so for some, but not for me.  If it weren't for the audio setting capabilities, I would remove the app from my iDevices.The Fidelio DS8530/37Setting up the Fidelio DS8530/37 docking speaker is as simple as plugging it into an electrical socket.  The included Quick Start Guide uses nothing but images to indicate how to use the docking speaker and is most likely unneeded.  Even though the docking speaker should work without removing protective cases, my iPad'sBelkin covermust be removed to attach.  However, docking my iPhone to the Fidelio DS8530/37 doesn't require removing the case.  Once docked the remote provides typical music player options, which also works with Pandora.The Fidelio DS8530/37 docking speaker isn't designed to include Bluetooth connectivity.  However, it's painfully obvious this common feature is missing.  As a result, I must choose between relinquishing all control to the docking speaker and using my device for other purposes. At the current MSRP, Bluetooth connectivity should be included.The Fidelio DS8530/37 is a stylish, modern looking docking speaker with great sound.  Plus the lackluster DockStudio app provides expanded usability and is a tool for setting the various sound options.  However, the lack of Bluetooth capability would be reason enough for me to consider purchasing an alternate docking station.  If this missing feature isn't important to you, the Fidelio DS8530/37 docking speaker is worthy of your consideration.PROS:Great sound & Dynamic Bass BoostRemote controlFull, rich sound at all volumesModern black mesh designOne-year limited warrantyCONS:Lackluster appNo Bluetooth connectivity
summary: Obsessed With Sound: A Philips DS8530/37 Fidelio Docking Speaker Review

reviewText: I have to start by saying that I'm not a photographer. I just wanted a camera with loads of zoom for not too much money. This camera ticks all of my boxes and I've taken some great pictures with it. I'm not very good at taking pictures in low light, I don't know if this is due to the camera or my lack of photography knowledge.I'd considered buying a compact system camera but was put off by the price. I glad that I bought this one as it does everything that I need it to very well.This camera has plenty of functions for me. I never use most of the functions anyway as I don't really know what they do. I'd like to take a photography course some time, maybe my opinion of the camera would change after that. Either way it's a good stepping point between a compact camera and an SLR.

I was very impressed with the lack of distortion in these headphones. The high end transients were very good but the bass was slightly muted, not having the overly bright sound of theMonster NCredible NTune On-Ear Headphones. With the lack of exaggeration in the low end and the frequency response in the high end, the Inspiration would suit most purposes. While probably not my headphone of top choice for funk or rap, I found the Inspiration gave astonishing clarity on old jazz and blues sides. It also performed exceptionally well on classical and lower percussion pop. Really, except for deep bass music, I preferred the Inspiration to most headphones I've tried. It's hard to find a pair that can handle the deliberate distortion ofHolland, 1945as comfortably as the silence between the verses ofStrange Fruit.The weight is heavier than some on the market but not a huge issue for me. They're comfortable enough for my smallish ears and don't slide around. I was pretty unimpressed with the ANC aspect. It seemed to boost the sound volume slightly and add a bit of a hiss to the audio without truly blocking ambient noise. Turning it off made the audio performance seem faded or muted. Bose still owns Noise Canceling. Swapping out the headbands is simple enough once you realize the entire band is magnetized. It's actually an insert swapped on the top, like a headband for your headphones. I don't see myself doing that often, perhaps once to get a certain look. Packaging is nice but allowing the carrying case to fully open would make a world of difference. Low light levels, black accessories and a black interior 3/4 open case can be a frustrating experience. Overall these are minor complaints on a very nice product.
summary: Good High End Transients, Moderate ANC

I pined over which case to get for a few days, narrowed it down to a few and ended up with this case. I love the simplicity and minimalistic design. My girlfriend got the rooCase before I got my kindle and ended up getting this case. It doesn't have a vertical stand option, but really, if that is what is worrying you fret not, because reading the kindle fire horizontally is great, no issues. Also, if you are in bed and like me a book is more like a sleeping pill anyway and I'm out in no time. Save the reading for pre-bed, and play games or watch a video which look awesome on the kindle. The rooCase is very bulky, and one of my favorite features of this case is that nothing frames the screen or gets in the way of the touch screen, because you typically swipe off the screen or to the edge of the kindle more than not. The case holds the kindle securely but pops out of the bottom so you can use the 2-position stand. You can also easily fold back the flap which makes it feel like a book when you are reading, and the 'latch' that just fastens the case gives you extra security when you hold it. It closes tightly as well every time, and makes the fire easy to throw in a book bag or purse or just transport in general. My only issue is that I'd like them to come out with other colors. if this case was damaged tomorrow I'd run out and buy it again without thinking.

Note that the software requires 10.6 (Snow Leopard) or later.  According to the web site the current 2.0 version will already work with Mountain Lion.  You must download the software from the web site; it isn't included in the box.  Be sure to get the software serial number inside the box before you throw the box out.What is included:- 3 overlays: NUM10, NUM20, and NUM30- marker to write on the overlays- cleaning cloth- plastic card to apply the overlay- card with the software serial numberThe overlay does not appear to affect trackpad sensitivity at all.  It is smooth, so sliding your finger around on the overlay doesn't feel funny.  The adhesive on the overlay doesn't leave any icky residue on the trackpad if you remove it.With the original 1.x version of the software there were a lot of quirks.  Things like a massive calculator appearing (2-4x normal size), issues switching between modes, slow response.  It was annoying enough that I gave up trying to use any of the Magic Numpad functionality even though I left the overlay on the trackpad.Under the 2.0 version, some of the quirks have been fixed.  Calculator is now the expected normal size.  It's responsive.  However I'm having a heck of a time getting any of the items to activate when in trackpad mode.  I should be able to tap the upper right corner to switch to numpad mode.  Used to work in 1.x, doesn't right now in 2.0.  If I go to the menu bar and manually switch to numpad mode I can tap that spot to switch to trackpad mode, so the overlay position is correct and it sort of works.Same problem launching the calculator.  It will not launch at all while I'm in trackpad mode.  Manually switch to numpad mode via the menu and then I can tap the calculator spot to bring up and close the calculator.I thought I checked and confirmed it worked correctly when 2.0 first came out, so why it isn't working now I don't know.  I tried restarting the Magic Numpad application and that did no good.  Rebooting isn't really an option at the moment so I don't know if that would fix it.When it does work, it still has some limitations.  You can't program all of the buttons, only a subset.  Trackpad / Numpad toggle is only an option for the top right button.  Calculator is only an option on the button right next to it.  On the NUM20 overlay, there is a button for Delete.  You can set it to either forward delete (how it's pictured) or backward delete, but you can't set any other button to delete.  In other words, you couldn't have one button as forward delete and the other one as backward delete.I don't know if I recommend it or not.  It does work, but for me it's far easier to just use the full sized keyboard.  Maybe if I had the smaller keyboard, but with the full size keyboard there really isn't any need for it.  I'm going to leave the overlay on the trackpad, but probably won't mess with it much until the next software version releases.

I always buy Hewlett Packard, except for the Acer (lap top)that I do not even want to talk about, it is in no way comparable to the HP.I first heard of HP while I was working in the Hospital, not many people realize HP started out in medical machines.Since then I have been buying them, this unit is wonderful and it has not failed me yet. reviewText: For creativity I give the AIOS a 5 in a few years this could be an awesome unit, however by releasing the units with subpar operating systems they will lose repeat customers. The idea of the hot swap HD is awesome. USB ports, this awesome also. The packaging is excellent, but that only lasts until you take the unit out of the box.For appearance I give the AIOS a 4 ( the clock on the front is 90ish)For functionality I give the AIOS a 2, the hardware it there but the operating system needs an overhaul. Read on and I will explain the why.The HTML5 Browser I give it a 0, several pages did not render correctly. I was never able to log into Amazon Prime with this unit. I could navigate to Amazon's main page but the login page to access the prime account would not render correctly therefore I could not log in the CSS didn't render. To put this in perspective the browser turns your TV in to a very large version of the first smart phones. Any text box requires you to go to the online keyboard even with an attached keyboard. This is a very big hindrance had I know this I would not have purchased the wireless keyboard and mouse. The documents say you can add a keyboard and mouse for ease of use. I think that got lost in the translation to English. The keyboard is semi functional but it still requires the use of the remote for several functions. Remember there is NO direct input to any text box you MUST use the built in on screen keyboard.The remote control is very sluggish, even with direct line of sight to the unit. Like I mentioned earlier I attached a keyboard and mouse hoping to turn this into the unit the website boasts about. As it turns out it just as slow to respond to keyboard input as it is with the remote control. For this I give the remote control a 1.Apps I would rate these as a 2. To be fair the company from what I read on the forums is making several upgrades. But I would like a robust unit now and not wait for several upgrades. It's OK if you just want to look at the weather, yahoo and last night's news broadcast.I sent my unit back, I was very disappointed with AIOS. Overall I would rate this as a 2.3. I would be willing to give the company another chance but I would have to try one hands on. As I would never buy another Pivos product on blind faith again.

Ok so I know that buying cheap filters is not recomended. However, I am on a limited budget and cannot afford to spend $100 for just a single filter right now. You cannot go wrong with Vivitar series 1 products. The filters are made well and do the job they are intended for. They come in a nice padded case that keeps them protected when not in use. The MAIN reason I chose this set was because I wanted to experiment with the ND filter. With it being a ND8 it is a great deal. It DOES indeed stop the f stop down 3 times as it should. Works perfect for my vintage manual lenses for outside work. Excellent Value. I would recommend this to anyone looking for good filters.

is much better than i expected far above the 930's and close to the 1500's, the bass is superb for such a small wireless set the 930's bass is terrible and you know it cannot beat the 1500's but it is closer than i could have imagined but the highs are a little lacking the 930's highs are very crisp and clear where i feel these could do better but overall the Wrath win in my taste.Sound in games is a mixed bag overall these are better because explosions and the like sound better where the 930's just distort but with that said since people walking and a lot of movement sounds are higher pitched the 930's come through clearer i still give the edge to these due to overall sound of course there again the corsair's generally dominate but they are wired.I do like the g buttons on the 930 so i can change the eq on the fly or pause my video while im away.The detachable mic i can take or leave i like 930s push up better.Maybe sorta consThe surround on the 930's can be set in the windows audio properties and not the wrath so in some situations "please yes i know its simulated surround not again" like testing on a surround audio file or a video with surround these do no work sometimes and ive heard some games may not see them as nothing but 2 Chanel although i haven't played any yet with that problem.On the few games like l4d2 or CS:GO i have to give the 930's the edge they are amazingly accurate at sound location even better than my 1500's with my Sound Blaster Recon3D  Fatal1ty Champion Sound Card powering them but the Wrath ore OK just not as spot on as the 930's which may be my biggest con i really wish creative could have nailed that one.I guess it comes to this my 930's are fairly unused and im giving them to some one else and i am using these, for the short time Ive had these i have left them on much more than i would have  the 930s, i hope the next gen improves i would certainly upgrade there is room on both sets for that.Your takeaway from all this is that i have spent way too much on audio for the little i use it O did i mention the $600 stereo with 7.1 infinity's and 2 10 inch powered subs, Now if i can just get a refund on this stuff......

We've been using this player for a couple of months now, and I'm glad I waited to write the review. The first couple of days were plagued by hangs, hard locks, and resets - to the point where I almost gave up on it.I'm glad I didn't.For some reason, after a couple of days, it really smoothed out and we haven't had any problems since.The sound quality is excellent and the player is intuitive and easy to use. It isn't a touch screen, but has touch-sensitive buttons on the sides.If you're looking for a good MP3 player as an alternative to an iPod, then I would recommend this little player from Creative.

I got this Streaming player in order to stream from a Network Attached Storage. It worked wonderfully and attached very quickly and easily via UPnP; however, if you plan on using this player on wireless, you should also plan on not using any other wireless device (even if the Media Player is online and not streaming). Of course this could be changed by adjusting the UPnP settings on your router... but ultimately we solved this problem by simply running a Cat5 cable to it.File browsing is a little messy if you're trying to keep your media organized on your NAS. It makes several instances (or links) of the same file despite the fact it is thirty folders away from root. This isn't really a problem unless you have a lot of movies because the folders get mixed up in the alphabetical list.Also, the media player doesn't distinguish separate folders (ex: music & pictures). It throws all the files into one big happy list as they relate to the type of media that you are searching for (ex: you're looking for music and it throws all music files into the first list even though they may be from completely different directories).If you plan on using this for NAS, make sure your media is compatible!! There's a really good list of the compatible media formats on the Sony product support page for the SMP-N200, but for quick reference for anyone reading this: the player does NOT support Mpeg-4 H.264 Codec or M4V (iTunes movies). They simply don't show up or do not play. Also, different types of .wma do not work either, but I didn't really investigate this.All in all, despite its flaws, it's a very good media player and does much more than the Roku ever thought about doing.
summary: Good Streaming Player for NAS, But...

reviewText: As a long time user of Canon cameras, presently the 50D DSLR and the G10 compact, I bought the S100 as a camera I'd carry in my shirt or trousers pocket, taking it everywhere.Image quality is little short of amazing for such a small unit. I think that even at base ISO, the S100's detail rendition is as good as that of my G10 (which is almost as good as the excellent 50D DSLR). In that regard, it's wonderful, capable of taking images which very few could tell were taken by a small sensor camera.Performance at higher ISOs is also surprisingly good, far surpassing that of the G10. Up to ISO 400, image noise is no problem unless one wants to make a moderately large print, 12X18 inches or more. Even then (at 400) a modest touch of noise reduction preserves all the detail while eliminating visible noise. At ISO 1000 or 1250, very good images are obtainable, when noise reduction is applied. At 1600 and above, color rendition drops off and noise becomes a problem for anything more than small web displays.There have been a few mild criticisms of the ergonomics of the S100, but I think those criticisms are probably the result of people trying to use it for an hour or so and finding the interface slightly different. After using the camera for a day or two, one almost never needs to access the menus. Aperture, shutter speed, ISO, white balance, and exposure comensation can be set so they're "right out in the open" for the photographer who needs to change something quickly during a shoot. Even with my XL size hands, using the camera is easy and comfortable.For me, the S100 is not really a "shirt pocket compact", and it's only a "trousers pocket compact" if the trousers are pretty large, with roomy pockets. But it is small, and it rides comfortably in a small Sony camera case, looped onto my belt.The S100's limitations probably would not be noticed by a casual family photographer. Focus is not as rapid as it is with a DSLR. Shutter lag is noticeable, even with pre-focus. Dynamic range isn't as broad as that of a large sensor camera. These are limitations common to almost all small sensor cameras.Finally, there's no "hot shoe" which could accomodate an external flash unit, and the camera's small built-in flash is of very limited use. The workaround is to use an external flash as a slave unit, but that does complicate things a little.There is no perfect camera,but for a small, very portable camera, it's almost impossible to beat the S100.

I had LX5 for almost a year.  I bought both LX7 and S100 when it's on sale.  If you are looking for easy to use, great image quality especially at low light, high ISO environment, S100 is a clear winner.

I loved this camera for about three weeks (5x zoom,raw format, great pocket size). Then in a little less than 4 weeks, 10 days into my trip, the camera began to fail. The camera sometimes wouldn't turn on, when it did the lens would not retract, wouldn't turn off. I was traveling in hot/humid Hong Kong, Macau, & Hanoi going in and out of A/C spaces. Condensation apparently form on the inside of the camera. It was never rained on, exposed to liquids, etc. The few times it worked, the images produced continued to be very good. By time I returned to the USA and shipped the camera in for repairs corrosion had formed. Canon service said that the warranty did not cover this damage. BTW my Olympus EPL1 going through the same conditions never had a problem. I take extra care of my cameras when taking them between extreme temperature changes, but I have to question the durability of S100 in the conditions I described above. The conditions I was working in were not extreme, but I did have to monitor the fogging of the lens and LCD on both cameras.
summary: Loved it, then it began failing

reviewText: I have a digital SLR camera with a couple professional-grade lenses.  Yes, I can take technically better photographs with them - but only in limited circumstances! If I want a picture of a goldfinch at my feeder, this is the camera I grab!  The pictures this takes are so good, and the camera is SO versatile, it's just FUN!  I don't worry about changing lenses, changing settings, or getting tripods.  I can respond to almost any situation just by zooming and pressing the shutter button.  The DIGIC-V processor/HS sensor used in the camera really makes the most of the 35x zoom.  The images show remarkably little digital noise - almost to the quality of my first dSLR!  And the integral anti-shake image-stabilization makes that monster-zoom range entirely useful!  I took a photograph indoors at night with room lighting - no flash - at full-zoom.  That's the equivalent of an 840mm telephoto on an old 35mm film camera.  The SX40 HS used a shutter speed of 1/20 of a second with a film speed equivalent of 1250 - and it looked good.  No tripod.  No blur (at least, not on my computer screen).  I was ecstatic!  PLUS - the camera I got was still made in Japan (which I happen to find reassuring).  If you want RAW picture files (a common criticism of the Powershots, because they don't use them), you'll have to make up your own mind whether to splurge for one of the competition's models.  For me, if I need a RAW file, I need a dSLR to start with anyway.  However, if you're one of the vast majority of folks who hasn't a clue about the difference between a "RAW" file and a jpg file, don't worry about it - I'm confident you'll have all the camera you need to have all the fun you can imagine in this unit.  I do highly advise to take time to read the user's guide completely - a few pages at a time (there are about 120 pages).  The guide is on a disk with the camera - or you can download it from Canon.  Print out the pages that seem the most interesting or appealing to you, try them out with the camera to get some experience with the features - and soon you'll be taking pictures you would never have believed possible!

As my title infers, I've been building systems for friends, relatives, business associates, my businesses and personal use for years. Can't think of a motherboard brand I haven't encountered. Regardless of the brand and like almost any product, I've encountered good and DOA boards from all the major brands.This was my first ASRock. I was a bit nervous since they're not in any major retail stores. Took a chance after reading a few reviews by industry insiders.I am VERY impressed with a number of features:1. All the SATA connections face UP instead of the frustrating sideways on most other 1155 boards.2. More space around the CPU socket so my Hyper212 isn't pushing against my RAM chips.3. UEFI BIOS is easier to navigate.4. My i5-2500K runs cooler. On my prior P67A-GD55 MSI board OC'd at 4.6Ghz, always ran in the 50 to 55C range. Using exact same case fans Hyper212 and Arctic 5 paste, I used the Auto Overclock setting CPU never gets above 50C.5. Clean Audio. No matter what drivers or settings I used on my prior MSI board, sound would often stutter or delay. Using exact same Nvidia drivers, ASRock sound is flawless.6. Best of all is the cost. Can't remember the last time I bought a board with the current bells & whistles for only $100.
summary: Great board, based on 32 years as system builder.

reviewText: These are good batteries, but they die QUICK without much warning.  The charger only charges one battery at a time, don't be fooled by the picture on the product listing.  I have about 6 Wasabi batteries and they are a good Cheaper alternative, but you still get what you pay for.  I'd recommend them as a BACKUP source for your GoPro batteries.

It's nice to have a decent prime lens for the NEX system, and the Sony 50 is a decent lens at a decent price. Center sharpness is good. Edge sharpness, even at F/8 is a bit soft. Shooting into bright light, the Sony is prone to flare and noticeable fringing near the image edges. Neither is bad enough to be a deal breaker. This makes a pretty good portrait lens, where edge sharpness isn't that important anyway. It also works well shooting theater rehearsals where center sharpness is most important and the low light capability and image stabilization are the most important qualities.When compared to my old manual Pentax 50mm 1.7 lens with an adaptor, the Pentax is so much sharper, with better contrast, that, the comparison is not fair. On the other hand, the Sony lens does have very capable image stabilization and focuses quickly and accurately. I compared the Sony lens with the Sigma 30mm E-mount lens and the Sigma is somewhat sharper, center frame, at all apertures, and a lot sharper at the image edges. Again, the Sigma lacks the IS, but does focus quickly. It is also a bit over a stop slower.One other point: The Pentax 50mm lens, including adaptor, is actually a couple of mm shorter than the Sony lens. It's a shame that we have such small and lightweight cameras with such bulky lenses. Samsung NX cameras are similar in size to the NEX series and Samsung has managed to make some pretty good and small prime lenses, so it is possible when made a corporate priority. The Sony cameras are better cameras, though.All in all this lens is decent and worth having, and it's at a reasonable price.

I use my flip stand every day with my iPad. It's perfect for reading magazines and papers online and is easily adjustable for reading and sending emails. It folds neatly and easily into a convenient carrying size. It will travel easily and adjust without difficulty to prevent sun glare outdoors. It would be a great gift for the iPad, Kindle or Nook user.

This is a really nice product and comes with nice documentation and was very easy to set up. It gave me a stable and cleat connection and really cut down on the wired clutter.All the components were made of very high quality - recommended. It has four ports to handle a nice number of devices. A must for some installations.
We have 3 DS's in our home and someone is always losing one. This is the biggest pack I have found and for the price, you just can't beat it. They work great on the DS lite.

These headphones don't offer great sound quality; they're a little thin on the midrange, and the high end is significantly lacking.  But the sound is adequate, the price is reasonable, and they seem like they'd be a lot more durable than most headphones.  You can bend them, twist them, stuff them in your backpack and they (so far) hold up.  If you like over the ear headphones and are active (jogger), a business road warrior, or a teen who stores his or her sound gear in a pack, these will likely work for you.  They remind me of some low end Sennheisers that I had about 30 years ago.  They were very practical with adequate sound and lasted about a dozen years.  I doubt these will last that long, but if they stay in one piece for a year or two, they'll be worth the price.
summary: Light weight, can take a beating, adequate sound

reviewText: To say that this device is a disappointment is like saying the Titanic was a small sailing accident. I'd like to think that I'm relatively computer savvy and an easygoing/forgiving consumer, but this one raised my blood pressure and boggled my mind. I have two harmony remotes that have given me easy and reliable use. Set up for these was easy and the remotes perform as expected.  While its slightly annoying to have to set up a different account for each of my devices I can work around this as the log in information can quickly be retrieved from the remote. However the link requires an internet browser to set up and program. I went in a circle with two different browsers on my windows 7 laptop for almost three hours just to get the additional software installed to log into the machine. Logitech is of no help. The only way to talk to someone is to pay $29 for a live person. If a device costs this much, I'd like to think that I could at least talk to someone. For those of us cheapskates that don't want to dish out the money for that there is a forum where you post your problem and other users get to do the work Logitech should be doing from the start.I finally used my old computer that hasn't been updated in 6 months and is running Vista and it loaded right away. Most would say problem solved, but I really don't want to be forced to keep a laptop I've already replaced simply because Logitech can't work with the latest operating system. Once I was in the system the set up was almost too straight forward.  My DVR requires multiple commands to put it in stand by, something which my older harmony remotes could easily be setup to do using the computer interface. The link however can't do that unless you have the original remote to program it. However I like many people purchased the universal remotes because the original remote no longer works.Now the I have it set up the best I can I've placed it according to the supporting document and website have said and it cannot see the wireless. As I use my tablet, our Itouches and a wireless enabled Blueray player in the same room, I know its not the signal strength. Would not recommend this to a friend.
summary: Love all of our other Harmony remotes, but not this one

reviewText: I owned recently a Harmony 300 remote which was just OK for 3-4 devices and its buttons were  so well situated. Later I decided to go on for Harmony 200 as I was planning to use it only for TV+Set-Top box.Well, this is so drastically worse then Harmony 300 that I'd advise to keep away from this fiasco...WHY?The most "tortured" navigation key landscape (in contrast with H 300) is made of same (monolith) latex material and pressing any of five keys on its surface is same as playing in Vegas casino... good luck...
summary: This is a nightmare of logitech

reviewText: I bought this thinking it would assist me in being able to pick up Vera TV and other types of Streaming from my current DVD Streaming device. However, after much research, trial and error, it really doesn't do anything at all to pick up streaming media coming from my wireless DVD player. Perhaps I simply can't figure it out, but it only has Ethernet connections, so if your LCD or LED television has no Ethernet connection capability, you are out of luck

We purchased this unit so that we would be able to travel with our 36' travel trailer and not worry about the route that we were taking.  We have only used it for one trip so far and it has performed okay so far.  The only problem that I have found is that the screen is too touch sensitive.  During our trip my wife accidently touch the screen and the unit returned us to a previous screen.  This may not sound too bad but we were in a small city and in heavy traffic.  By the time that we had got the unit back to where we needed it to be we were going right through the middle of downtown.  This was not good with my large trailer.  I had some very bad moments with getting through traffic.  The screen is also hard to see in bright sunshine.  I am going to try to mount the unit below the dash where I can shield it from the sun.  I am glad that we purchased this unit but we will need to get more familiar with it before our next trip.

When I first saw this camera, I was in awe and was so excited to get it.  When I got it, however, it really looked nice.  But being the clumsy guy that I am, I knew I'm going to end up dropping it when I switch lenses.  It's really a great camera, but I wanted to write this review for anyone who thinks it's like a point-and-shoot camera.  I opted to buy the Nikon AW100, which is shock-proof and water-proof (to 10 meters), and had much more fun using it.
summary: Ended up returning it.  Not for the clumsy!

reviewText: After lugging around the Canon 7D with the 70-200 lens for 3 years to capture my duaghter's Nordic ski events, I decided to try something a little easier to carry.  The Nikon 1 V1 is an astonishing little camera that takes remarkable photos and videos.  With the 10mm lens (which is also astonishing), I can pout the camera in my pocket to keep warm on frifid days.  As noted, there is not much manual flexibility, but my experience so far is that this little camera takes exceptionally good pictures and absolutely stunning videos.  By all means get the 10 mm lens - you can shoot indoors without extra lighting!

I had a lot of spare parts hanging around and wanted to build a budget HTPC, but needed a motherboard for them. This is a great buy for the price. Gigabyte makes a good product as well and has been very reliable for me in the past. I wanted to go for a smaller Mini-ITX board, but when you compare a Micro-ITX to a Mini-ITX you aren't really looking at a huge difference in size. If you are needing compatibility with older LGA775 Socket CPU's then please note this is compatible with the Intel Core 2 Extreme/2 Quad/2 Duo/Pentium/Celeron processors. The available Mini-ITX boards that are out there for LGA775 don't have any additional PCI-E slots which was a requirement for me. The added PCI and PCI-e slots are nice to have for any additional add-ons in the future. When it can no longer handle my media decoding needs I'll most likely add another NIC and turn it into a Linux based Gateway/Firewall.It's nice to see Gigabyte including older connectors on this board as well. Most users won't need IDE nowadays nor the parallel port or serial port. They cold have left these out and added some additional connections like HDMI, or E-Sata.I am using a core 2 duo e6600, 60GB SSD (boot Drive), 2 x 1TB HDD for Internal Media Storage, 8GB of DDR3 Memory, a Low Profile HD 7750, a generic ASUS Bluray Rom, and 450W Power Supply. All this is inside the Silverstone ML03B case. I've slightly overclocked the CPU and am able to play any content out on the market. A lot of people will have you think that you need to spend a lot on a very powerful machine to playback the most recent high bit rate Anime or Bluray content, but that's just not true. I spent $54 on this motherboard and pieced it together with parts from older computers and was able to achieve the same results that other people would have you believe can only be done with new and expensive hardware.
summary: Works well for budget HTPC Build.

reviewText: I liked this keyboard and it seemed to connect and work flawlessly, at first. I did have the problem that others have mentioned about keys repeating, but only occasionally and I found it happening only when I was trying to type very quickly. Unfortunately, I have now returned this product since after three weeks of limited use, a number of the keys simply stopped responding. I was hesitant to try this given the mixed reviews, but have had good success with other items in the same boat. Maybe it's a mixed bag on quality that's the issue. I am now in the hunt for another bluetooth keyboard.  :(

I got this keyboard for use with my galaxy note 2. It is junk. It has a very weak bluetooth connection and when used with another bluetooth device it constantly loses connection or repeats keysssssss. Also, the period key does not work well. It will place a period in by double tapping the space bar but that is useless if you are trying to enter a web address that has a .com and if you try to go back and put a period in the period button works as a delete key. I will mess around with settings for a while but I will probably end up returning this keyboard and getting a logitech one.The keyboard is very stylish and keys do feel nice and if it wasn't always repeating keys and if the period key worked normally I would love it.
summary: Junk. Keyboard repeats keys all the time. Extremely annoying

reviewText: Strangely, this radio is advertised as a bedroom radio. Yet it sorely lacks many of the desirability of bedroom functions. To start with, it MUST have physical bottoms for memory presets to be accessed even in the dark. None! It needs some physical controls that one can "Feel" and use in the dark when his/her better half may be fast asleep. Not only does one need to turn the light on to find the controls, but, while intuitive, it simply is way time consuming to bother when one is ready to go to bed or trying to go to bed. The so called auto diming while not that bright, it does not dim to darkness like many of the competition do. What were the engineers thinking when they provided 5 physical buttons for Alarm settings and none for favourite presets? Lastly, while many people may like its size, I like to have a radio that won't slide all over whatever top it is placed on when one is pressing the control buttons. It is too small for my taste.

Speed and responsiveness of this device are just amazing and pure joy, thx for the most part to the 128 GB SSD. I re-partitioned it (fortunately very easy job in Win 7) to make room for Win 8 developer preview in dual boot; both OSs work great, and the touch functionality shines in Win 8 and makes for a great great dev/test device. Battery life is very good in my opinion; you can work for it for 5-6 hours no problem at all. Since I keep it in the dock most of the time so that I can freely type and use a mouse I've never had any power issues.On the downside, other than the hefty price tag - the lack of SIM card support is puzzling. For that much money it should have been part of it, as well as a protecting sleeve or at least some rubber surface on the back for a safe grip; I'm always concerned when it's not docked on the table. Also, a second USB port would have been nice, but then again I guess that might simply not be possible due to the slim and compact design.Lastly, perhaps I just haven't figured out how to do it but using the stylus (which is included) really sucks because the resting hand will constantly sabotage your input.By and large I love this computer, it's surprisingly powerful. If the apps on an iPad are enough for you though then you're definitely better off getting one (or even two) of those and still save a good chunk of money.

Similar to Maureen Swan's review of this product, I'm reviewing the $199.99 Hauppauge 1445 HD-PVR Gaming Edition (same as the normal version, which is $179.99, but with a special cable used to connect to various consoles) from the perspective of recording games from game consoles only. More specifically, I'm attempting Wii video recording.Firstly, a disclaimer: I'm not a huge recording buff, so don't expect much fancy lingo in this review. I got this product because I love recording "casual" playthroughs of games I like, and until now have made do with emulating games on the PC and recording them with Fraps. I figured it was time to move to recording physical games I own, so I bought this.FIRST GLANCEUnboxing the product, I discovered five components: the Hauppauge HD-PVR itself, a USB 2.0 connector for connecting the Hauppauge device to a PC, the power supply, and 2 more cables used for connecting the Hauppauge HD-PVR to the target recording device (one being the 3-in-1 cable that connects to the Xbox 360, PS3 or Wii). There is also a CD that contains special software for recording. The Hauppauge itself seemed a bit dirty on top and is, unfortunately, plastic and cheap-looking. But as we know, not everything appears as it seems, and in a bit I'll explain how the device handles.On the front of the device, the HD-PVR has a power button and the following connectors: SVideo, and the traditional Video (yellow), Left sound (White) and Right sound (Red) plugs. On the back, we have the following connectors: Stereo audio, Component Video, Optical audio. There are two sets of these, one being for game consoles and the other being for TV. The back also contains the USB port that connects the Hauppauge to the PC, and the power supply connector. There is also a Blaster port on the back, but I am not sure what that is used for.INSTALLING SOFTWAREFollowing the included instructions, I hooked the Hauppauge up to the computer and began installing the software on the CD. As outlined in the instructions, the setup software did not pop up immediately (I'm running Windows 7 64-bit), and I navigated to the Setup.exe file on the CD to continue. I proceeded to install device drivers for the HD-PVR, as well as the ArcSoft ShowBiz software. I also decided to register my Hauppauge, but the registration option on the CD software menu didn't seem responsive, so I skipped registration.Just to make sure, though, I went to the Hauppauge website at [...] to download the latest drivers for the HD-PVR. Unzipping and installing the newest drivers was straightforward. Hauppauge provides release notes on the website for the driver updates, which is nice.PREPARING HARDWAREFollowing the included instructions, I hooked up the test console (Nintendo Wii) to the Hauppauge using the 3-in-1 game console connector, and my small 19" TV (a pittance, I know, but I'm a college student so I have to travel lightly!) to the Hauppauge using the other 5-connector cable. The connections are labeled and color-coded for convenience. Hardware setup was a snap, but there is a lot of hardware involved in this setup.PREPARING TO CAPTUREOpened the ArcSoft ShowBiz software and changed to the Capture tab, then switched on my Wii. Black screen at first, but then I changed the input options to the following and it showed up on my screen:Source: Hauppauge HD PVR Capture DeviceVideo input: YPbPrAudio input: RCA BackPC Audio Mode: 2 Channel Stereo (AC3)There appears to be no lag at all in the transmission of video from the Wii to the Hauppauge to my PC. Excellent! There's a preview screen that shows on the Capture tab in the ShowBiz recording software and it will be "behind" timewise compared to the actual display on the TV, so keep that in mind. That said, the preview is very smooth and the sound is amazing. One thing I noticed is that you have the option of choosing where the recorded videos go (so in theory, you could record them to an external hard drive if desired).CAPTURINGThis is where the review goes a bit downhill, but again, this is for the Wii only. I hear many glorious things about recording PS3 and Xbox 360 footage with this thing, so don't discount it just yet. The software and settings took a bit of time to wrap my head around, but I ended up using the standard Wii Composite Video cable (the yellow, white, red connectors that attach to the Wii) and plugging it into the HD-PVR's front Video and Left/Right Sound plugs (instead of using the 3-in-1 cable provided in the box). That said, you might not want to spend the extra $20 on the Gaming Edition for the 3-in-1 cable, but it could be that the Xbox 360 and PS3 don't have proper composite cables. I haven't researched those yet since I have yet to claim ownership of them.Some additional pointers:-Capturing at 13.5 Bit Rate will give you the best quality, and the file size was not considerably large either. Then again, the test video I produced (see below for link) was just over 2 minutes, so keep that in mind.-The Wii is NOT for recording HD. There is a reason why the Hauppauge advertising keeps mentioning the PS3 and Xbox 360, trust me. Don't expect the highest-level recordings for Wii games.-Occasionally, the ArcSoft ShowBiz software will hang in Windows 7. This is not a huge issue, but it becomes a very large one when the program refuses to quit (unkillable process) despite what you may do to it. Never found a workaround for this aside from restarting the computer, which is frustrating.-If you want good quality videos, do NOT use ShowBiz to publish them. Just trust me on this. I've heard you have to have at least 720p video clips recorded at 60 fps to even have the option to publish at that level, but I haven't gotten to test it yet. Again, this is all from the standpoint of trying to publish lower-quality Wii videos that were recorded off of the Hauppauge.-The recorded sound is flawless. It sounds exactly like it does in games. This is one area where, regardless of my Wii recording problems, the Hauppauge has satisfied me completely. However, make sure you adjust the sound properly (I used 2 channels with AC3, not AAC) and do some sample recordings to get the best sound out of a recording.TEST VIDEOHere is an example video I recorded off of a Wii game (Technically a Gamecube game) using the Hauppauge HD-PVR: watch?v=utaiFZTSzzE (youtube video)The video is Tales of Symphonia's intro movie. I ended up recording it using the .M2TS format (which fits the Playstation 3 playback criteria) due to some issues with movie editing. The file size was amazingly small, but I'm used to Fraps recording on the PC and compared to that, it's miniscule.VERDICTMy standards for recording were quite low, so for now this is better than most things can put out, I imagine. I expect to make much better use of it for PC, PS3 and/or Xbox 360 recordings. Just be warned that it is not easy at all (possibly not feasible) to get HD or high-quality recordings of Wii games. The software is passable but not outstanding, yet it meets my needs for now. It almost never lags or has recording problems (aside from possible ones when you first press "Record"), and the sound it records is beautiful and seamless.In conclusion, the Hauppauge HD-PVR has a lot of potential, it just isn't realized when recording non-HD content.I will update this review more as I move on to other games or discover more tricks for recording well.--------------------UPDATE: February 2012I have procured a Playstation 3 and tested recording as high as my TV would go (1080i, which is not as smooth as 1080p but still HD) and it is very impressive. I recorded the intro and title screen for Rune Factory Tides of Destiny for the PS3: watch?v=7Mr5DuW1Kgg (youtube video).The recording is of absolutely breathtaking quality (at least in my eyes) coupled with smooth recording and amazing sound. However, it did take a bit of fiddling around with TV and capture settings, and I ended up using the YPbPr cable (the game console connection cable that came with the Hauppauge HD PVR) for Video input when capturing, which plugs into the back of the HD PVR. Still, it was hardly a problem and the result is amazing.This changes my rating for this device to 5 stars instead of 4, as now the full potential of the Hauppauge is apparent to me. Totally recommended if you plan on recording HD gameplay. You get what you pay for, and while the Hauppauge certainly looks physically mediocre, it's actually very powerful and smooth-operating.
summary: Amazing for HD content, satisfactory for non-HD content

reviewText: love this it works great love that it has hdmi and ipod hookups the sound is great would buy another with no hesitian woul recommend to anyone interested in buying one

I am typing this while I am enjoying the "Theater Sound" of the Vizio VHT215 Sound bar. The sound has all the feel of a movie theater, with clarity, depth, and the rich bass of the separate sub-woofer (even when turned down so that my family, relaxing rooms away, can hear their own thoughts). The sound is a clear, clean, immersion of sound that turns anything you watch into an experience. Be sure to follow the recommended placement of the sound bar: ON THE FLOOR and not on the TV stand in front of the TV! Surround-sound immersion from the floor is greatly enhanced!I have tried (without success) to watch and enjoy HD TV and Blu-Ray DVD's with the the woefully inadequate standard-equipment sound that came with the TV.So I carefully weighed my options, and then the options of each individual sound bar that I investigated. (I didn't want to run wires with an amp and speakers).  Then I went to where they were on display to hear them in person. The Vizio sounded great, and also had a few extra features in particular that won me over. First, it offers 3 HDMI ports, two input, a one pass-thru output port (ARC Compatible). It also has a digital audio input. But the selling point for me was its 3.5mm (iPod or similar) jack, so that I can hear my CD's and/or MP3's through these great speakers. Compared to the TV's original speakers, the VHT215 is the audio difference between VHS and Blu-Ray. It is just that good!Some previous reviews complained of problems with the HDMI pass-thru. Let me tell you my experience: I ran my DVD player's and my Satellite Box's HDMI outputs thru the Vizio, and into my TV input. When I did that, there was hesitation (processing?) when changing channels, and in the DVD Player's playing of movies. I did not like that.Then, (it may have been my own lack of familiarity with the Unit), but when a DVD was done, there was also hesitation in processing the return to passing thru the signal from the Satellite Box. Some times it ran the sound only, and then the picture finally came on after 20 or 30 seconds. To resolve the issue, I disconnected the two HDMI inputs, ran them both directly to the TV (as originally connected) and then I ran the sound from the TV to the Sound Bar through a digital audio cable. All of the positive aspects of the sound is now back, with none of the HDMI processing hesitations.However, I did not consider the above minor "glitches" enough of a problem to drop my rating down from 5-stars to 4-stars. I didn't buy this Unit to decipher High Definition and Blu-Ray visual signals. I bought the Vizio VHT215 Sound Bar for a better SOUND, and this Unit has lived up to AND exceeded my expectations. The sound is 5-star sound! And when you place it on the floor: 6-star!If you're not sure, buy it from a Seller who will allow you to hear it for yourself at home for a reasonable amount of time, and return it if not satisfied. But I am very satisfied with this purchase. And, I recommend it.
Worked well. just plug n play and had my PS3 controller working with my Transformer prime. woooooo must have. it's really awsome

I'm not sure what the difference between the 4 and the 4s models are, but the 4s model works well with the D700 and D800.  Highly recommended.
