reviewText: I'm ready to eBay my pocket wizards. I can exercise much more control with the ODINs than the PW system, plus I don't have to deal with the interference problems using the canon 580EX.I've used the Odins in both ETTL and manual mode, and love them. Only downside is I can't trigger them using the sekonics light meter (which I could with the PW units).It is great to be able to put the flash units inside a softbox and not touch them again due to the amount of control you get using the Odin transmitter. With the pocket wizards, if I wanted to experiment with flash settings, I had to open up the softbox and fumble round in poor light, with the Odins you can do whatever you want remotely.Also, they fire the flash unit every time. With the PW, the flash would frequently fail to fire due to interference.
summary: A great wireless system- Better than PW

reviewText: I am using this on a 2012 Macbook Pro and i have had this mouse for a month or two and its worked perfectly as a mouse. It always connects to my macbook with out any issues and if i forget to turn it off it automatically switches off which is one thing i really like about this mouse. As for comfort, it has the shape of a basic mouse and i don't suffer from any joint problems so holding it in my hand as never been a problem and i never press any of the calc buttons by accident with my palm but again the shape is nothing special. So the only reason i give it 4 stars instead of 5 is cause the calc is somewhat awkward to use since the buttons are on a slight curve with the body of the mouse. Then again i usually use it for doing my online hw (i press CAL/KP and just punch away, instead of constantly pressing SEND) and some light gaming which for that purpose it does ok. i think for $20 you can't expect much, it does the job of a mouse very well without having to plug anything in and i think the option to use the number keys are just an added bonus.
summary: it is not as bad as people are making it

They work great though and like I said, I highly recommend them for your kindle fire.

reviewText: Optical connection! and USB direct connection to your iPod (through a small 2-inch sync cable provided, or use your own).The Gain has three settings (bass 1 2 and 3 basically), two filters for DAC. The Digital to Analog Conversion was fair I thought (the only thing that wasn't off-the-chart exceptional). For what it is, this is really it. I wasn't afraid to throw down for quality and the mobility of this device is exactly what I was looking for.I've been using it with Beats Pro, which I am getting sick of (they're basically ghetto blasters), and plan on using this Fostexx with the Beyerdynamic Tesla's (at $1300).The other headcans I'd pair this with are the Denon over-ears for about a thousand bucks, they're great in the reviews I've found.One con: The knob is large/long. I have this feeling that one day I may accidentally hurt it because it sticks out too far. There was no need for it to be that long and therefore the weak link.SIX STARSUPDATE: I'm loving it still. So I purchased a Diamond sync cable from Audioquest, silver. There is also a Carbon, either way get a nice sync cable. This is the only amp/dac that is connected with a pure digital sync cable due to licensing and Apple proprietary tech. Headroom and cypherlabs all have this Wierd setup that is a large rig to include both amp and dac. This is awesome and unique. Only problem is the 1/8 inch plug. No 1/4..

I have several (6) IP cams as part of my security setup.  I was excited to get this one.  However, if you plan to rely on it's IR ability, you may be disappointed.  At night, the surrounding area looks like a wash of haze (like inside a cloud).  I can barely make out what's in the picture unless the subject is directly in front of the camera and only a couple of feet away.  I ended up just disabling the IR functionality.  My other cameras do not suffer this problem and blast out IR clean and clear.  I am not certain what is causing this on this particular model, but it's not usable in my opinion.
summary: Decent.  IR leads to washed out haze

reviewText: I was beginning to despair of ever finding a case to fit my Archos 70 tablet, which is just a little too much longer and narrower than the more popular Kindle and Nook to use most of their options.  This case, however, is perfect.  Clever elastic holders stretch to grip your device very securely -- waved it madly about and it absolutely doesn't budge.  The minimalist holding system means all ports and buttons are easily accessible.  Doesn't look as stylish as a "leather" case, however, I'm also less worried about the nylon developing creases over time as would happen with "leather."My favorite part is the stand feature, that gives you actually three viewing angles (two with the provided ridges, a third by laying it almost flat -- ideal typing position).  I watched an hour-long video last night in bed with it propped on my stomach and was in total comfort.Last, love the convenient elastic strap for holding it closed, which surprisingly the swankier-looking Poetic Kindle Fire case lacks.  The second strap for holding while reading is thoughtful, but it seems more comfortable to hold it open like a proper book instead.Could be better with a pocket for storing a charger or maybe small documents, but I don't think any of the tablet cases I've looked at had that.  This one does the job I need, and I'm really glad I took a chance on it.

After six years of faithful service I had to retire my beloved Linksys WRT54G router.  The next logical step is buy another Linksys product, they are very reliable.  The E2500 installed quickly and easily.  However my plans were to split  my video traffic and Internet traffic.  I then ran into a couple of challenges.  First, I assumed that my new Sony KDL60EX720 TV supported the 802.11N standard, it did.  However the TV will only function on the 2.4 Mhz channel and not on the 5 Mhz channel.  Ok, no problem I will place the video traffic on the 2.4 channel and put my Mac(s) printers, iPhones on the 5 Mhz channel.Then I discovered the very limited range of the 5.0 channel.  My daughters Mac is directly one floor above the E2500 router in a wooden framed home and the signal level occasionally falls below a single bar.  It looks like the 5.0 channel is well suited for people who live in a studio apartment, not a two story home.So I have abandoned the 5.0 channel and placed everything on the 2.4 channel and everything works OK, slight improvement over my beloved WRT54G.UPDATE,  March 24, 2012 experimented with changing the 5.0 channels and found a channel (161) that seems to have solved by problem.  But overall the speeds that I am seeing on both channels do not improve over my beloved Linksys WRT54G.FINAL UPDATE:  well I am back to the same old problem that I had with the WRT54G, having to power cycle the E2500 every few days.  Worked with Cisco "support" for a few weeks without success. Why companies staff their support centers without training the support staff is hard to understand.  call Apple Computers and see the comparison.  No wonder that Apple is making money and Cisco struggles along.A good way to judge the reliability of a router is to do a quick search on Craigslist.  You will find a large number of E2500 routers for sale, cheap, including mine.  So far no offers.

I got my Sony 3d Personal Viewer yesterday.  Since I do not have a 3D TV or even a 3D Blu Ray player (but have movies) at the same time I ordered a Panasonic 3D Blu Ray Player from Amazon.  They both arrived the same day.I am a 3d still photographer, not a gamer, not a videographer.  I have been shooting 3d pictures since 1988, first film (starting with a Stereo Realist and moving to more expensive and advanced 3d cameras) and for the last 2  years digital, starting with the Fuji W1 and gradually building up to more and better equipment.  I looked into this unit to view my own 3d pictures and also to watch 3D Blu Ray movies that I have been buying like crazy lately.Considering the cost of the Sony viewer, I had done a bit of research.  Reading user's impressions it was clear that the unit has a problem with comfort (the way it fits in the head) but most people were happy with the image.  It was not clear if and how I would use it to view my own personal 3d pictures.When my unit arrived, first thing I did was to watch parts of 3d movies.  Then I put an SD card to the Panasonic player and played some of my own stereo pictures.  Finally, I plugged the unit into my laptop.Here are my impressions:1. Yes, there is a problem with the way the unit fits.  Sony made the mistake NOT to distribute the weight but leave it all in the front.  I am a runner and I wear head-mounted LED lights to run at night.  The best units are the ones that have the battery pack in the back of the head, distributing the weight uniformly between front and back.  It is a mistake to leave all the way in the front.  In addition, the nose gap is not well designed and the weight puts pressure right on your nose.  And, if you don't position the unit perfectly, you get blurry edges in the image.  Positioning the unit perfectly is not easy.2. The resolution (1280x720 per eye) is OK. I can see the pixels, so there is room for improvement.  HD resolution would be great.3. Optics are OK.  But I can see chromatic aberration.  Sometimes I notice it, other times I don't so I can live with it.4. The unit has a menu where you can turn 3D on and you only have two choices, side by side or over under.  The side by side option expects an image that is compressed 50% horizontally.  It would help to have more options.  Plus, the headset is connected to a control unit that needs to be plugged to AC power and to the unit sending the signal, so the setup is not portable at all.Despite these issues, I love it.  :)There is nothing like that around and it is the first step in the right direction.  With improvements in the design and quality (resolution, etc), this will make a great digital 3d viewer, something that we are all waiting for.  No ghosting, vivid colorful high resolution digital images.Watching 3d movies was fun.  Actually, even the previews that were in 2d looked great in this unit.  Just like being in the theater.When I put the SD card in the Panasonic unit, it would only recognize MPO files as being 3d.  So I pulled the SD card out of my Fuji W3 camera and my Panasonic GF2 (that has MPO files from when I use the 3D Lens), and watched over 1000 stereo images.  That was fun! (Even though the MPOs were not aligned). I later discovered that I can even watch the .jpg images in the SD card in 3d, after I turn the Sony's 3D on, but only pictures squeezed 50% display properly.  This is not a format that I normally use.Finally, I connected my laptop to the Sony.  I was expecting problems, but I was able to make things work by playing with the resolution settings (under Windows 7).  I used these settings: - Multiple monitors, 1280x720 - Duplicate these displays.Then I turned Sony's 3D side by side mode on.  Stereoscopic Player and StereoPhoto Maker (both in full screen) displayed images in 3d.  But, in Stereoscopic Player I changed the aspect ratio to 50% (I could not find a similar setting in SPM, so SPM images are stretched 100%).  The resolution of the images in the Stereoscopic Player was not good.  In the process of compressing the image and then expanding it, something is lost, apparently.These are my experiences with the unit so far from using the unit for a couple of hours.  The unit works well for watching 3d movies. There are ways to see my own 3d pictures, either as MPO files in an SD card, or formatted at 50% aspect ratio horizontally jpg files.  I would like to find a better way to see my 3d pictures when connected to my laptop.I enjoyed the experience and I expect to use the unit quite a bit and then trade it for the next upgrade that will hopefully address some of the problems of this unit.  Ideally, the perfect digital 3d viewer should be more portable, higher resolution, fit nicely over the head or even be light enough to hold it in front of your eyes (if you elect to do that).I was debating whether to rate this unit 4 or 5 stars.  Since the unit is not perfect, 4 stars would be a more fair rating, but, without competition, this stands out as a league of its own, so it deserves a 5 star rating.
summary: Not without problems but a great first start

reviewText: Bought this to replace a run of a mil netbook, but I am having second thoughts about video playing which is quite detailed and specific.  The integrated GPU is the star of this machine, it is supposed to better than old ion that you see so many of.  It also plays h264 HD files beautifully when supported and once you turn on the settings for HD online videos, also the dual core processor is supposed to be fast for a netbook.Now my concerns, I was under the impression that the C 60 dual core would be pretty fast in comparison to the prevalent single core atoms, but I am struggling to see the difference really in everyday tasks including browsing and the usual work related task such as word processing and excel, in fact Firefox is noticeably slower to start which is puzzling.  If I play video that is supported by the GPU then it runs silky smooth, however you play video that are not supported such as 10 bit h264, or even 360p resolution VP3 youtube files then it seriously choppy.With my old netbook which doesn't have a media dedicated GPU, I could play regular common 8 bit 720p h264 video smoothly with the right settings, and my old netbook also gives a good account of itself with 10 bit 720 h264 .  However, I tried the same settings on this Acer machine and while 8 bit 720p video was silky smooth thanks to the GPU, the 720p 10 bit(which is not supported by the GPU) was a lot choppier despite the supposedly faster CPU.I want to use this machine for at least 3 years if I can, and video playing is important to me.  H265 (new media standard) products and adoption should be the norm by the end of 2013 b/c of the urgent need for compression for mobile networks.  With this upcoming turn over for online videos from h264 to h265, I am now thinking that there is no way the C 60 processor can handle h265, which I naively thought the C60 would give a good account of itself, but that is totally unrealistic.  Thus by 2013, online video will probably not work that well on this relatively new machine b/c there are no h265 enable devices on the market right now, and the CPU won't cut it.I put my old netbook on sale, with the intention using the funds from the sale to eventually paying off a large percentage of this purchase, but I am now thinking to keep my old netbook to hold me over to 2013, and return the Acer aspire b/c it isn't really a marked improvement in what I use my netbooks for which is Microsoft Office related work and video playing.
summary: Not Sure about this one, Movie Playing

reviewText: My Intel DX79SI motherboard comes with onboard USB3 using Renesas chipset but it doesn't function correctly.  I tried a less expensive USB3 add-in card which also used a Renesas chipset and it didn't work either.  This card is based on the TI chipset and works perfectly.  I wished it had two internal ports which is what I needed, but it only has one.  I've used all four ports simultaneously without issue under Win7.

For the size, as everyone says, its simply the best.  I've tried ALL the other Bluetooth speakers on the market - at home.  Side by side.  The best, of course, is the $300 Bose Soundlink II.  But even if money is not a problem, the size and weight were deal-breakers for me.  My use-case is for travelling - speakerphone and music in hotels and conference rooms.  I don't want to add 3 POUNDS to my travel bag.  The Foxl is perfect in so many ways, but, again, the price tag is a bit high at $230.  I also compared it with the Monster ClarityHD Micro ($200 at Best Buy) and found the bigger unit to be better all around.  The Clarity is still pocketable, but three times the size of the Foxl.  Like the Foxl, it also doesn't weigh 3 pounds and costs $100-150 less than the Bose and $30 less than the Foxl.  the sound is a bit bigger, with more volume and slightly better bass.  I think it fits the perfect sweet-spot for size/weight/price.  Butm having said that, it was tough to return the Foxl.  I really, really, liked it.  If I didn't already buy the Monster, I would have probably kept it.  But since I couldn't return the Monster, I returned the Foxl.  With no regrets, though, because the Mionster really does sound slightly better in certain ways.  It was like comparing the Monster to the Bose, where the sound was great on both units, but "bigger" on the bigger speaker.  No coincidence, I suppose.  For me, the ClarityHD Micro is still the choice, but if the Foxl was $100, I would have kept it and had both, just to see which one I grabbed the most when leaving home.

I first bought an OCZ Vertex II 64-GB SSD.  This was pretty much dead-on-arrival.  I replaced it with an OCZ Vertex Plus - not much better.  I could not get either drive to survive a system power-down and power-up.  Always "disk error" on boot, or complete system freeze after only a few minutes.  This was consistent whether I loaded Win7, OpenSUSE, or Ubuntu as the primary operating system.So I bought a Corsair Nova Series-2 SSD.  It was very reliable (it would boot and not freeze), but the performance was pathetic.  In my "Win7 experience" rating, my Corsair SSD was the BOTTLENECK in my system. A SSD ought to be the FASTEST component.  My rating was a pathetic 5.2 - because of my pathetic SSD.  Every other subsystem scored above 7 - but my disk subsystem (with this crappy SSD drive) pulled me down to 5.1.  The Corsair forums are full of people who are hopping mad because of the lousy performance of this drive.I had purchased THREE SSD drives from respected memory manufacturers, with poor results.  So I quit looking at labels and prices, and began an in-depth analysis of current SSD technology in terms of reliability and performance, as rated by respected authorities such as AnandTech and TomsHardware, and also by studying the published manufacturer's specs.One thing that I discovered is that size really does matter in SSDs.  Smaller size equals significantly reduced performance.  64GB drives are substantially slower than their larger counterparts. I have no idea why this is so, but it is plainly true - even the manufacturer's own spec sheets show this.I was never able to get either OCZ drive to boot long enough to run benchmarks.  I was able to run benchmarks against the reliable (but slow) Corsair drive - and the results were much lower than expected (and I had come to learn that I should not expect much from a 64GB SSD, but this Corsair SSD drive substantially under-performed 5400-RPM mechanical drives in the same system based on CrystalReport benchmarks).Samsung SSD drives were most highly rated in reliability, and almost as highly rated in performance. I bought this drive in the 128GB size.  My "Win7 Experience" rating went from 5.2 to a respectable 7.1 - and the limiting factor is now my graphics card.  My HDD performance is rated the highest of all subsystems (at 7.5 - 7.9 is the current upper limit).  I went from a SSD being the bottleneck to an SSD which is (rightfully) the fastest subsystem.I will no longer buy anything made by OCZ or Corsair - brands which I had previously trusted and respected.  My SSDs are Samsung, and my RAM is Kingston or Crucial.BUY THIS SSD, or maybe a larger-capacity Samsung SSD.  You cannot get better performance and dependability for the price.
summary: I first bought OCZ and Corsair - don't make my mistakes!  BUY THIS SSD!

reviewText: Both of my teenagers have iPods, one is the 3rd gen, one is the 4th. Both fit in this holder so it would be fine for either. Here is what we felt about this holder:Pros:The neoprene fabric is nice and offers some protection to the iPod. It has a key holder to hold a single key. The iPod fits snugly enough so that it won't fall out. You can use the touch screen enough to adjust your music.Cons:The armband was surprisingly large, big even for my (smallish) nearly 17 year old daughter. You can't have any sort of case or anything on the iPod, outside of a screen protector. Both the iPod and key take a little work to get in and out. Sometimes using the touch screen is a challenge.This case is nice looking but simply adequate. If you are willing to put up with the drawbacks, the case will serve its purpose.

I have a 2010 Mac Mini that I will be replacing soon with a newer Mini, which will have USB 3.0 but no optical drive. So this would appear to be the ideal drive for me. I don't need to burn or even play back Blu-ray discs on my computer, but I want to convert my Blu-ray collection to an Apple TV-friendly format, which will also play on my computer in iTunes.This drive plus the free MakeMKV app fit the bill nicely. MakeMKV converts the movie from the disc to .mkv format, then I use the free Handbrake to convert it to an Apple TV .m4v file.Power is provided with the usual wall wart measuring about 3" x 2" x 1". The provided USB 3.0 cable is only about 3 feet long, but works fine with my USB 2.0 hub. There's a plastic stand if you want to mount it on its side, like in every picture I've ever seen of this drive. I passed on that.With Apple's lack of Blu-ray support, I was impressed that the drive mounted quickly the very first time I popped in a Blu-ray disc, with no software needed. Drag your disc to the Trash, and the drive ejects it promptly.I am also impressed that when hooked up to my little old USB 2.0-only Mac through a USB 2.0 hub, it can rip an entire Blu-ray disc in 50-100 minutes.I wish I could tell you how it works as a Blu-ray burner, but I am unlikely to ever use it for that. This drive was so inexpensive that it beat the price for any USB 3.0 read-only Blu-ray drive I could find. I paid under $90 (including shipping) by adding it to my shopping cart and then watching the price fluctuate for a couple of weeks before buying low.If you want it for simply playing Blu-ray discs on your Mac, you'll have to invest in Blu-ray playback software, as I am unaware of anything free in this category.For Blu-ray disc burning, you'll need Toast or something similar.Only a couple of little things on the down side. This drive gets hot during a rip. The discs can come out surprisingly hot to the touch.The other negative is the placement of the eject button. If you use this drive lying flat on a desktop, like most people will, the button is low and practically hidden on the black, curved face of the drive. With the tray open, it's even harder to find.But those are small things, and since this drive has exceeded my expectations so far, I'm going with 5 stars.UPDATE: Drive occasionally does not eject disk. Manual shows "Forced Eject Hole" on front of drive, but it doesn't exist! Toggling on/off switch, then pushing eject button does the trick.Reducing my rating to 4 stars.UPDATE: The not-ejecting issue was my fault for not using the "eject" button within the software I was using, and using the physical button on the drive while the software was still running.I've had it for over a year now and it's still running strong. Although it's still weird that there is no Forced Eject Hole, I'm going back to 5 stars.

The price point suggests that the product is simply a case that protects your device. The design, however, is quite crafty. I won't delve into too much into the functionality, other than to say that all of the selling points on the folio cover's product page deliver without disappointment.There is one design flaw that should be mentioned. To fit the Kindle into the cover and expose all ports for connectivity, the power button must be positioned at the bottom - the same as the first generation device. Several apps, however interpret the buttons to be on top, making an odd feel with the "binding" on the right side with an upside-down stylus. I maintain my five-star rating in spite of this; the blame could also belong to app development for not adding the flexibility of direction and it's not too much of an effort to ...turn the Kindle around.In more than one way, this is a fantastic product with a shockingly low price. MoKo contacted me almost immediately and offered the opportunity to directly voice any concerns so that they could address them. I appreciate this and it underscored my belief that I had actually purchased a solid product.Well done, Moko!-Dave

This is a very good product with almost every feature fully functional.  Only rarely does the tablet pop out when I attempt to fold it in the reading position.  I highly recommend this item to all 7" kindle fire HD owners

I did  love this case at first. It did have a chemical smell but that went away. After a month of use though the cloth where it folds is ripping. The "leather" part that holds the kindle, the top layer is peeling off. I would return it but its one week past the return date.

This is a nicely made case. I cannot complain at all about material and workmanship...and looks.However, what finally got to me is that the little notch thingie on the back won't hold the part of the cover that folds back when you put this in stand mode.  It needs to be deeper or something. Mine kept coming loose and the fire would fall over.  I have some other cases like this for my other tablets and they all suffer from the same issue. This locking mechanism simply doesn't work well. I will be avoiding cases of this design in the future.

After receiving the Kindle Fire for Christmas,I knew I needed  protective cover. I found this cover and am more than pleased with it. Provides the protection needed to care for most day to day uses around the house or traveling, Thanks to the seller. Great
It is a lovely case but it didn't fit my kindle fire hd so I had too order another one that would fit.
Very good product. Sure looks like it can withstand stress. Good looking also. One snag though, wish it came with a re-usable casing. I'll recommend it in a flash.

just as described. have installed a lot of apps from the android market. my only worry is the fact that is powers off and on by itself sometimes and then you wonder if its a malfunction. is anyone also experiencing this occurrence?

This is my first Hoodman brand product. I bought it after an extensive research that included USB-3 products from my top three brands: SanDisk, Lexar and Sonnet. I eliminated all three brands, as two of them included some negative aspects and the manufacturer of the third one did not provide me with the satisfactory answer to my pre-sale technical question.There is not much that can be said about a product as simple as a dual (CF/SD) memory card reader. This one is USB-3 / UDMA compliant, includes 3-foot long cable with regular plugs (no mini or micro) on both ends. The CF socket is equipped with a drop-out door that opens automatically when a CF card is inserted. That prevents dirt from getting in and protects delicate contact pins. A card can be inserted as far as about 3/4 of an inch, so there is no worry about bad contact or inaccurate angle of insertion (cards in some other brands of readers can only be inserted by about 1/4 of an inch). The design is rugged and robust, with the aluminum body. Its size is bigger than the size of other brands' comparable products, but I do not care.I am using this reader with my Retina MacBook Pro. The reader works out-of-the-box with no problem whatsoever. I have no way of checking the exact speed of read/write, but the gain in speed over my old USB-2 and FireWire readers is significant. I just downloaded a firmware update from HoodmanUSA.com and it should give me even more speed with my future faster cards.So, for now, total satisfaction. I am adding Hoodman to my private list of top manufacturers in this category. I highly recommend the Hoodman RAW USB-3 dual card reader.

Did not work with my Canon 5D or 20D, but works as advertised on my Canon Rebel XT. The Rebel XT was the first camera I experimented with to see if the shutter release worked (works up to about 10-12 feet consistantly) The 5D/20D did not respond/receive signal from the shutter release. Unfortunately I did not look carefully enough at the spec/tech info..thought it would work on my other two cameras. Had to chage this review from a 2 star to five.
summary: Only compatible my Canon Rebel XT 8mp camera

reviewText: I have a Canon rebel T3 which is listed in the description. When i searched for T3 (not T3i) remotes this came up as one of them. when i clicked on the item and scrolled down, it had my camera listed. instead of researching my camera paperwork, I took this item at it's word and thought it would work. when i got it, only then did i research my camera manual and found that T3 does not support wireless remote control. so i returned it and plan on ordering a wired remote. there's probably an adapter that would hook to my camera but I have an external flash so that's not an option. Be sure you research your camera's paperwork and make sure it supports a wireless remote.

I was excited to get these headphones. There is no denying that they look sleek and streamlined. And the sound quality is excellent. Unfortunately, that is where the positive ends.Like other reviewers have said, I found the headphones to be extremely uncomfortable over time. I use them to watch shows and listen to music on my computer at night so I don't wake up my family, and even if I only use them for 1.5 hours, my ears ache. I've tried repositioning them over my ears in so many different ways, but it doesn't work.Also, the cord on these headphones is unbelievably short! Unless you are sitting at a table directly in front of your laptop, the cord length won't work. I bought an extender cord, which lets me move around more, but now the sound quality is drastically worse. If I don't plug the extender cord into my laptop just right, the sound on the right earpiece goes in and out.Overall, a disappointing purchase.

I just needed a 3.5mm stereo connector to plug an MP3 player to a Yamaha MCR-040 for playback. This jumper more than meets the requirements. Top quality components and packaging. The stepped ring at the end of the sleeve is especially nice for some devices that have a recessed socket.

I really loved this product because first of all its cheap, there well built and it gets me close enough to my subjects. I love how easy they work and if you stop down your DOP to your lenses highest f stop with all the filters on you can get a really decently sharp picture. There fun if you just want mess around in your back yard and capture some pictures of insects and plants. I recommend this product to anyone that's on a budget and doesn't want to overspend on a macro lens. Ill be posting some of my pictures I've taken with these macro close up filters.

My granddaughter has a habbit of dropping her Ipod which is an expensive toy. After she cracked the lens on her first one we decided to get her some protection. So far this has worked as she has dropped it many times and so far so good.

There are so many of these out there which are fakes... and this company is selling real ones. Super-speed. I would recommend people running a program which verifies that it really is a real USB Flash drive by writing to every byte of the drive and verifying that it is correct. Afterwards, you can be sure that it is a real drive rather than one of those fakes that have been glutting the market.
summary: Excellent order... Works like a Charm...

reviewText: I was looking for a 32GB class 10 micro SD card at first.  I was unsure if a 64GB would work. I decided to look anyways since I really wanted a larger storage capacity for my Samsung Galaxy S3. I found a couple that interested me. One was a class 6 and this one which is a class 10. I then thought that A class 6 would work fine for me and it was about $40 less than this class 10. As I read reviews from both, they seemed to be equally good, but then I figured that I might as well go for this one which would help me transfer files, photos and music a little quicker. Also, the camera in the Galaxy S3 is great and it just made more sense to me to get the class 10 over the 6 which helps the camera in HD video and photos.When I got the card I right away put it in the phone. I wanted to see if the phone recognized it right away or if I was going to first have to format it. The phone recognized the card immediately. It shows 59.8GB available. I then took out the card and inserted it in my laptop so I can transfer everything that I originally had on my older card. I was afraid after doing that the phone would have difficulty reading the card. Well, the card worked great. All my information was in there and now have a total of 73GB available including my phones memory.If you have a Galaxy S3 and have been wondering if this will work well with the phone, it does. I would recommend this for anyone who really wants to add a good amount of memory with good speed as well.

This is a nice monitor with great features. I'm very satisfied. The best part is the customer service. The kit is supposed to come with the different battery plates. Mine was missing one. I contacted Viviteq and they shipped out a replacement immediately; no questions asked.

This Topping TP20-MK2 TA2020 is nicely built and solid. It sounds great and feels solid. Nice connector outlets and a good power supply. I'd recommend it but there is another little amp out there that sounds just as nice and cost 2/3rds less money. The LP-2020A+ Lepai Tripath Class-T Hi-Fi Audio Mini Amplifier in my un-scientific side by side sound comparison returned exact results. Clear, warm and crisp. You wont shake the walls with either but they do the job for regular to party use. Now, I don't know if the Topping is better built with better parts but I can buy three of the Lepai's and keep two in the closet to replace it if it burns out. If you go by the product numbers they both seem to have the same TA2020 amplifier chip. Again, I'm no expert but I do know what sounds good and my wallet knows a deal. I deducted stars because of the high price.
summary: Nicely built and solid but there is another little amp out there

reviewText: This rig is a fun toy, but if your serous about DSLR filmmaking you will probably want to look elsewhere. The hex screws that are used to tighten the swing arms are A) cheap and weak, B) a frustrating way to adjust this item. An allen key is included to tighten those screws, but the heads strip out VERY easily, and don't stay tight through a couple hours of use. The metal and foam of this unit seem to be very well made, and I've gotten some good use out of the unit, but I recommend pulling out the bolts and replacing them the day you get this, you'll save yourself some headache.
summary: You get what you pay for.

reviewText: This Case Logic sleeve is structurally sound, with thick padding and a sturdy zipper.  The inside is soft, so I don't feel worried my screen with get scratched.  The outside is made of a thick, ridged material that feels like cotton to me.  I have the hot pink one, which is a bit showy, but makes it easy to find in a carry on bag filled with other electronics.One note, although Case Logic says this fits up to a 10.1" tablet, it does not fit my Asus Transformer (A 10.1" inch tablet).  It does fit my Touchpad though, with room to spare.  I would prefer a more snug fit with the Touchpad, but it does fit over my Touchpad even with the protective shell type case I have for it.Overall, this is a nice case, but do not buy this item for an Asus Transformer.
summary: Nice sleeve, but does not fit the 10.1" Asus Transformer

reviewText: I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this bag when I received it. I have a 15.4 laptop that fits perfectly in the bag! I did not expect it to fit. I also own aAcer Iconia Tab A500-10S16u 10.1-Inch Tablet Computer (Aluminum Metallic)that fits well into the inside pocket.The quality of this bag is superb! I own a lot of Case Logic and never have had a flimsy product. The stitching, zippers, compartments on this bag are excellent. I think it is also more of a dark gray, I know colors are different on each monitor but the picture in the description looks a lot lighter than the one I received.I have read someone say it is more of a woman's bag. I strongly disagree. It is for men and women. It is very business like and I can see someone using it to travel with. Speaking of, that brings up my second point. Someone said why carry two devices with this bag. Just that, if you are traveling you can have a tablet and laptop both in one bag and well protected. I know myself I keep different data on my devices and it is nice if I am out in the field to have both devices that fit in one bag. I only have to bring the power cord for my laptop since it does not hold a long charge and it fits perfectly in the outer pocket.My only complaint is I like my computer bags to go over the shoulder, with an adjustable strap. This has two handles on it which means you have to carry it at your side. If it had a shoulder strap, it would be perfect!Very happy with this bag and love how well made it is. When I have my devices in it I feel they are protected very well and am not worrying if anything is getting damaged. I would recommend this for travelers or even if you are out in the field, just keep in mind no shoulder strap.
summary: Very well made but wish it had shoulder strap

reviewText: Had a 2001 Moto surfboard cable modem.  Swapped it out, called comcast with the MAC and under 10 minutes my dslreporets.com speed tests (before & after) showed almost 3 times faster DL, 2x UL

4-20-2012  the uBee DDM3513 Docsis 3.0 Cable Modem  appeared to be a well designed unit;however, i could not get itto work with comcast.  The modem did not pass the comcast vpn information to the eithernet side of the modem.(perhaps this was the reson the eithernet lights were bluee instead of green?)I tried two different Comcast technicians on two different days to confirm there really was an issue with the modem.I will get a replacemtn and try again. reviewText: I have a black iPad 2 and when I ordered a black Firmir, I thought I would order a white one too to see what it looked like. You can find my review of Fimir 100% bubble free Guaranteed Anti-Glare Screen Protector film Mask IMP65B for Apple iPad 2 2nd Generation (Black) here http://www.amazon.com/review/R3F4NXW6EYHJTP/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm but these are my thoughts on the white version (note: the references to iVisor is theiVisor for iPad 2 - Black (99MO020908)which I also own).Appearance:The Firmir differs from the iVisor in that it has a slit for the camera/light detector rather than the cutout that the iVisor uses and I prefer. The Firmir does seem to be slightly thinner yet stiffer than the iVisor but that may be done to the length of time I've owned the iVisor.Application:As stated this could not be easier to apply. I suggest applying it in a dust-free room, such as a bathroom after you've run the shower for a few minutes, but all you do is clean you iPad screen (the included wet and dry wipes and microfibre cloth is a nice touch), peel off the protective backing and aligh and place on your screen - there will be no bubbles! Just like the iVisor, the Firmir is just a tad smaller than the iPad screen - there will be a tiny amount of screen edge plus the home buttom and camera slit visible. In all honesty, if I had wanted a white iPad I would have bought a white iPad but this is a cheap and cheerful way to change the look of your tablet. Compared to the Firmir, the adhesive around the screen edge is stronger meaning it takes more effort (especially if you are a nail biter like me!) to remove. However, as I mention above, once it is applied I suggest leaving it on.Use:This is an anti-glare screen so please understand that as a trade-off you will lose clarity due to the moire affect. You may notice this most reading web pages and ebooks. The iVisor is the same and I have never been bothered by the loss of clarity - the anti-glare and anti-fingerprint properties of these screens are more beneficial to me. If you are the type that must have a pristine screen, these type of screen protectors are not for you. The Firmir excels at anti-glare, more so than my iVisor. It also has a more matte feeling i.e. it is not as slick feeling as the iVisor which I actually prefer and also helps minimize any fingerprints on the screenSummary:This is an excellent screen protector if, like me, you have trouble applying the adhesive type and like an anti-glare protector. I've only 'dinged' a star due to the camera slit over a cutout. All-in-all this is highly recommended especially if you would like to turn you black iPad white!

Here are the results of CrystalDiskMark on the drive:-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0.1 x64 (C) 2007-2010-----------------------------------------------------------------------* MB/s = 1,000,000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300,000,000 byte/s]Sequential Read :  105.141 MB/sSequential Write :  24.829 MB/sRandom Read 512KB :  98.336 MB/sRandom Write 512KB :  3.133 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) :  12.806 MB/s [  3126.3 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) :  0.078 MB/s [  19.0 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) :  13.026 MB/s [  3180.1 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) :  0.075 MB/s [  18.4 IOPS]Test : 500 MB [H: 34.1% (5.0/14.7 GB)] (x4)Date : 2012/07/08 20:17:16OS : Windows 7 Ultimate Edition SP1 [6.1 Build 7601] (x64)Take it for what it's worth. As you can see, 4k write speeds are extremely low, but all of the read speeds are excellent for a flash drive.

I seem to always wish I had more free space on my several flash drives.  I figured I'd get a couple of larger ones so I wouldn't worry about it again for a while.  I'm also kind of cheap.  I wasn't familiar with ADATA and thought it would be a cheap, larger flash drive.  I'm pleasantly surprised. It's faster on USB 2.0 than all of my other drives, including the Kingston one I got at the same time. It's made of sturdy aluminum.  Unlike the Kingston it is reliably detected when booting from it.  It wasn't expensive, and on top of the rest it's USB 3.0 for future use.
summary: maybe one of the better buys right now

reviewText: We've read the other reviews for this item and stand behind what people are saying, so we won't be redundant. But we will add that though the documentation is not specific, we do use this with a Macbook. To accomplish this, we use a USB hard drive which is formatted with a FAT allocation table. This lets it be read by both a PC and MAC device. I am certain the performance is slightly compromised because it is not formatted in NTFS. But after about a month of use, we have not noticed any glitches or dropped frames in the capture video.The other adjustment we had to make to use this with a MAC is that we needed a conversion software to convert from the native format of the capture device to a video format that MAC can read. Since the files are recorded in HD and are relatively large, the conversion takes some time. But with a little patience, this capture device provides the quality video that we were hoping for.
summary: Can be used with a MAC!

reviewText: Using it with Dell Ultrabook XPS 13 running Win 7 x64 as a dock for 2 extended monitors (+ laptop display for 3 total monitors), 1GbE, audio, and a number of USB peripherals. Very solid product that never gives me grief. Nice performance and very reliable.Had problems with "Toshiba PA3927U-1PRP Dynadock U3.0 Universal USB Connect Docking Station" malfunctioning with this laptop which led me to return it and purchase this Targus dock instead.
summary: Works great with Dell Ultrabook XPS 13

reviewText: I've owned a DS 1511+ for about a year now so I was familiar with this product before it arrived.  The main purpose for the purchase was to create an offsite backup solution since the various cloud options are pricey and limited.  Along with this NAS, I purchased 2 3TB Seagate drives which are installed in a RAID 1 configuration.  The disk access seems to be sufficient, and single file transfers are in the 60MB/sec range.  The biggest downside is the CPU and RAM.  Doing an backup from my DS 1511+ will easily spike the cpu for the duration which leaves the box usesless for other operations.  If you plan to use this is SMB environment or have multiple users streaming, considering a higher end model that has more CPU and RAM.

With today's variety of phones and iPads that can charge at 500mA, 1A or 2A, and chargers and computer USB ports that can supply 500mA, 1A or 2A, it's hard to know whether the device you plugged in is actually charging at its best rate.For example, if you're using your iPad while it's plugged into a 500mA source, the iPad battery will actually *drain* instead of charging.Using your iPad while it's plugged into a 1A source will charge the battery, but barely — only about 1/5 the rate of charging with a 2A source. (Roughly speaking, with a 1A charger, the iPad takes about 750mA to run, leaving 250mA for battery charging. With a 2A charger there's five times more current — 1250mA — available for battery charging.)I bought this USB current meter to verify which of my chargers were actually supplying 2A, but something about this meter blocks the negotiation signal between the source and the device, limiting the current draw to 1A, thereby defeating the purpose of using it to tell which chargers can supply 2A. The Product Description says "Ranges: 0 ~ 50.0A DC" so I wasn't expecting it to have problems measuring a 2A load.

I bought this Kindle Fire Skin - Elegy to personalize my Kindle Fire that I received for Christmas.  It was not hard to put on at all and fit my Kindle Fire perfectly.  I don't know if it is worth the $20 I paid for it, but it is definitely a nice product and would buy again if the price was to go down some.

I got this for my Canon G12 together with a 420EX Speedlite and an off-camera flash sync cable. I tried to find the dimensions of this bracket because I didn't want too large of a bracket for my compact camera but it had to be sturdy enough to mount a 420EX Speedlite. It's 4.5 inches wide along the bottom by 5 inches high and ideal for my camera and flash. The bracket is thick with adequate stiffness. Each shoe mount was properly aligned and fastened to the bracket with three screws. My sync cable shoe was too loose in the mounts so I used pliers to adjust them. Concerning the odor of the rubber grip, it smells like "rubber."

I am quite disappointed. Spent about 3 hours on this little damn thing, and does not do its job. Installed the Windows7/ Vista mini CD that came with it fine. Then the nightmare starts. It does not recognize any 2.0 bluetooth device. I searched on Amazon, and someone said he enabled Bluetooth service and support to "automatic", and reboot. Did just that, and the Add a Device Windows GUI does not recognize the discoverable MonsterHD speaker.I suspect the Kinivo BTD-300 is NOT backward compatible with 2.0 Bluetooth devices?Anyone has better hint on making this damn thing to work?Updated July 27 21012.Today, I plugged the Kinivo back to my laptop ... and it instantly recognized my MonsterHD speaker. For some reason, my W7 was updated by MS, and it recognized this device. Hence I now changed my star rating to a 4 for this device.Thanks.

reviewText: This monitor is a great value. It was basically the same price as a lot of other 21" monitors. I don't hear any noise when I lower it below 90 brightness so I think the other reviewer that had that issue had a bad monitor.I docked 1 star for not including a DVI cable. Luckily I was just replacing a broken Samsung and used the cable from that one.

I will try not to repeat what I have read in other reviews. One thing I cant tell you is that my canon 18-135 mounted on my 60D does search for focus a bit before taking the picture. Another aspect that is important to describe to would be buyers is that the depth of field is a challenge. If you are taking a picture of the insect and you want its whole body to be in focus you will have to place you lens sideways to the insect or some parts of the body will not be that well defined in the picture. On the same token, this is going to be a good leans to use in any situation where the object has what you want to show at a similar distance to the front of your lens but if it is very curvacious, it will be a challenge to take the picture as you want it to be. This may sound very obvious for the experienced photographer but it is not so intuitive (how this lenses impact you macro shots)to the ones that are not doing this for some time. In any case, I recommend these. They are pretty good and deliver the result with no visible distortion. You are also going to find that using the +10 is very hard. Much easier to use the others but, it is a lot of fun and you will have amazing results with all of them

I've been a fan of Agfa products and film since I started shooting seriously; so when I saw the attractive price of these filters, I figured, 'Why not.' I wanted a set of filters that brought the subject closer as the images on the page implies; what I got was a very sharp set of optics that (for the most part) force me to get closer to the subject. Shame on me primarily for missing "Macro" in the title; but the images of the meerkat getting closer from a distance led me to believe the filters brought the subject closer... NOT SO.However, this actually is a pretty good deal for me since much of what I do when I'm not shooting family and landscape is close up and macro; and these are sharp filters. They showed me quite clearly that I need to clean my keyboard. There are, unfortunately, a couple of serious "detractors."Using any of the filters in the +2 and up range (you can stack the +1, +2 and +4 filters for differing effects) result in very noticeable distortion on all sides of the image - bowing inward to the center. Using the +10 is an interesting experience - I had to get within 4" of the subject (with my lens focused on infinity), and only about 30% of the image center is usable if you want a mostly undistorted image. The other 70% outside the center looks like a radial blur (zoom) effect. (I have placed an image with the testing I did on the product page for those who want to see how the different filters affect images.)Am I going to return them? Not likely. Like I said, they really are sharp and I do have a use for them... even the +10. I do believe Amazon/Agfa need to adjust the images to more accurately convey how these filters are really used. The distortion effect and incorrect portrayal on the product page cost them a star in the rating.
summary: Sharp optics, but incorrectly portrayed on product page

reviewText: ...and it's made of glass, and apparently quite decent glass. It is coated as described and appears well-constructed (not flimsy), with good threads and grip. Packaging was hard to open, thus four stars.
Simply the best. I have never regreted purchasing a Seasonic. Platinum, very stable voltages. single +12V rail.Full modular cabling. Powers my high-end system with ease.

To get the nastiness out of the way:Yes, the keyboard layout is different from most. This uses the layout where the backspace key is smaller and the enter key is a gargantuan beast. I advise looking up pictures of the keys to see what I mean and deciding if you can handle the change.That being said, I love this keyboard. It feels very solid (not afraid to break it). I'd read a lot of reviews that have said that the Cherry MX Black switches are not considered very good for typing, and are mainly geared towards pure gaming. Personally, I find that the CMXB switches are fantastic for everything. I tend to (apparently) type a little heavy-handedly. This is not a problem with this keyboard (at least not yet).The key "feel" is fantastic. It feels like someone dug up an old IBM beast-board from the monolith era and rebuilt it from scratch with the latest tech. The result is a very smooth, uniform key motion, and the only noise is the clack of the key backing hitting the end of the keystroke. It sounds awesome for those who like the sounds of yester-year. More importantly, it is responsive, durable, and well-designed.I haven't had any of the software issues some of the other reviewers have noted. I plugged it in, it installed a basic driver. I went to the AZIO website and downloaded the latest version software. I installed said software. Everything just works. I am running Win7 x64.If I had to make a feature request, it would be adjustable full-keyboard backlighting. As things are, the volume knob has a light, the numlock key is a short step away from being a lightsaber (super bright!), and the macro keys can light up.All in all, I highly recommend this keyboard to anyone. It took me a little bit of adjustment to deal with the backspace/enter key changes. Within a week, I was adjusted. I don't even notice when I switch back and forth between configurations anymore. If you're looking for a good keyboard and are concerned with the quality control issues of Razor (as I was), get this keyboard instead.

You just spent $500 plus on a tablet and the last thin you want is for something to happen to it. Apple comes to the rescue with their neoprene cover. its a very simple design that works well. It is held on by magnets and gives a strong secure connection. Other magnets on the cover keep it in place when you store it and also automatically goes to sleep and awakens when you open and close. I prefer this cover to others because its sleekness. I dont want to get a tablet and put a thick cover on it that makes it the same size as my laptop but doesnt have a keyboard. works great buy yourself one now.

This is a very nicely made, well thought out concept for tablets and other portable devices. And to offer 6 Watts total sound and nice bass as well, its not too shabby. However, the bottom platform (lip that holds the tablet) is not well thought out, causing some tablets to not be secured or angled properly. So this is why I didnt rate this any higher. Overall, its better sounding than most, and if your particular portable device fits, then this is a winner!
summary: This is VERY good sound, well made but holds certain tablets poorly

reviewText: We had the original magic jack which was very intermittent and really not reliable. We also hated having to have it plugged into the computer all the time, which of course, required leaving the computer turned on 24/7. We tried this one and have been quite pleased with it. Quality is fine. We are able to make and receive calls. And having it plugged into the router (which is on all the time anyway) without having to use the computer is great.Some folks have had issues getting it working, but we did not have any problems at all. You have to plug it into a computer to set it up, but then you just move it to a port on your router and viola. Done. Probably took me 20 minutes to be up and running and I have not touched it since. We have 4x cordless phones that rely on just one wired base. That base is then physically connected to the magic jack. This solution works great for us.

What I liked: 1)the rotational feature. Of course, my encased Kindle Fire have turned when I didn't want it too, but only because I wasn't paying attention and the way I was holding the case made it easy to happen. 2)easy to put the KFire in or take out, and it stays in. 3)I can prop it up easily. 4)the price was good, comparable to its material quality. What I would have liked: 1)the material to be a little more rigid. 2)a strap or a holder type of attachment that would make it easy to hold the KFire while I'm laying down. 3)the flap would be easy to fold back and secured if I wanted to hold it in my hands. 4)an easier way to remove the back portion from the case because with the button holding the two together, it was a little hard to disengage, which I understand to help keep the two parts tightly together, but still...That's why I don't take it apart and have a hard time trying to hold it in my hands when I'm laying down.

Bought this car charger when I got the iphone5 as my existing factory auto connector didn't recognize the iphone5. The charger protrudes out about 1 or 1.5 inches from the outlet which is not too bad at all. The 2 USB ports are labeled "A" and "S" - guess which one you plug the iphone into?  The charger is fast, it charges nearly 1% a minute even when running music via BT and GPS (waze app) on my commute into work.The upside I discovered is that using the iphone5 cord finally allows me to put my phone on the dash so i can look at GPS without having to take my eyes off the road! my factory auto iphone connector was only about 12" long which is ridiculously short.
summary: fast charger even w/ music and GPS

reviewText: i just built my own computer - and it was terrifying.  but this was the best reviewed fan out there and sure enough, it keeps my new LGA rocket ship as cool as a maine winter. it's also a lovely austrian brown, which for an artist type means a lot.

I'm totally confused why some people are rating this down because it won't hold the charger for the battery back.  It's advertised as the battery back case and it does that well.  Those same people that are now putting it down for not holding the larger strange shaped charger would then slam CaseCrown that the case was TOO big!The IMP1000 is a monster of a battery pack.  It can charge an iPhone and iPad for almost an entire weeks trip!  Why would you want to carry the charger for the charger with you?  Yes, if you go away for 2 months maybe you need the plugin charger, but get a life, why also if you were going to be gone that long not just take with you the mini-block charger for the phone and just plug the phone in?  The IMP is designed to keep you charged for very long flights, or mid-day top offs.  For that function this case works perfectly!Do people want a pilots flight bag that you can stuff anything into it including barf bags and a change of shorts or do they want a case that does what it says it does, perfectly fit and protect the battery pack?  Let's focus here on just what the products says it does, and in this case, it does it perfectly so it has to be 5 stars in opinion.

I live about 40 miles from 2 different cities, one East, one West.  I've had several HDTV antennas over the years.  My current HDTV antenna is a Winegard SS-3000.  It is a powered antenna but rather bulky, hard to hide beside/behind the TV.Enter the Winegard FL-5000.  This antenna is very lightweight, about the thickness of a 5 1/4" floppy disk, and has a white side and a black side.  Unfortunately the cable coming from it is black so it still doesn't hide too well on a white wall.  It also includes sticky velcro pads to stick it to whatever surface you want.Using the signal meter on my TV I tried 3 channels (including one I had trouble receiving) at 3 different locations.  The FL-5000 is much easier to try different locations than bulkier antennas.  I first tried it on the wall behind the TV but found you really need to decide the final spot before sticking it, because I pulled some paint off my wall when removing the antenna.  I wound up using thumbtacks after that, much easier to clean up after.  Second spot I tried was on the back of the TV, I didn't get good signal from there.  I wound up with the antenna mounted on the wall right below the ceiling.Here are the readings from my old antenna, on a windy evening:Channel 29:  72 to 82Channel 35:  83 to 92Channel 6:  32 to 65Obviously channel 6 was the weak one.And the Winegard FL-500 in it's final location, same windy evening:Channel 29:  63 to 75Channel 35:  71 to 78Channel 6:  78 to 83As you can see 29 and 35 got a little worse but still acceptable.  Channel 6 got a lot better.  Antennas tend to be a compromise, you'll never get every channel perfect.Overall I'm very pleased with the performance of this antenna, and it requires no power so that's a bonus.  Now I can rip some of the wires out from behind my TV.
summary: Good performance from a small non-powered antenna

reviewText: UPDATED 4/26/12So, originally I had no luck with this antenna and explained this in my old review which I left below. I switched tv's because I got a new one and said lets give it a try once more and WOW, I got about 20 OTA channels all in HD. I couldn't believe it, plus, I left the antenna on the floor and it still picked all those channels up. I'm going to permanently set it up properly and wouldn't be surprised if I get more. The small price tag is worth a shot.Old Review...Oh how I wanted this antenna to work. I have a room with a beautiful hd tv but don't have any cable wired to that room so its always been just a dvd player tv.While the antenna is very thin, (just a bit thicker than construction paper but made of plastic) no matter where I placed it, it didn't get a signal. I went to tvfool.com and got all the info for available stations and used my iPhone compass to find the correct coordinates, i still had no luck. Most of the main stations on the tvfool list said between 10-22 miles and if you've been to the site, they were green and just turning yellow meaning they should be able to tune into.The only station I barely and I mean barely cause it was all snow with a little bit of color was home shopping channel.I won't be moving the tv to try it in another room because the tv is big so I cannot really say if this antenna works or not other than where I tested it out. It would have been perfect as its small and thin and easily hide able which is why I gave it 2 stars. Wish I could review more about it.
summary: Very Thin and now I got it working

reviewText: I really wanted to like the EP950 but there are just too many disappointments and issues. The top-5 biggest issues for me are:1. The unit consistently locks up when playing MKV files from a network share;2. The unit refuses to handle widescreen ISO files correctly;3. The unit has inconsistent Upnp behavior;4. The unit has issues with forced subtitles; and5. The unit has odd issues with its power on function : more often than not it refuses to start up using the remote control.My disappointments are (top-3):1. USB ports on the side - very unaesthetic;2. Off-line firmware updates - a thing from the past;3. No on-line community or forum and almost no cadence of firmware or operating system updates.I gave up after the above and didn't even try the alleged 3D capabilities.  As a 2D unit it isn't worth the $150. The Pivos AIOS is a better choice and doesn't suffer from these issues.Finally, how in this day and age one can ship a unit without an HDMI cable and batteries for the remote control is beyond me.

Just got mine today, slipped my Fire into it for a perfect fit, and good to go, with a Velcro strap underneath to make it absolutely stay put and not slip around.  Nicely tailored not to cover usb, power button, or speakers.  Very stable, using foldable stand for landscape viewing, and easy to hold when reading, or whatever, in portrait.  Overall durability seems very good, and materials used don't add too much weight in your paws.  Flip the cover over the screen, and the magnets make a comforting 'thunk' - case closed.I really can't find any 'cons' for this puppy at first blush.  For the incredibly cheap price you can't find a better encasement for your cool Kindle Fire.  And - I received it from Amazon in just 3 days.
This item is great!  This item totally met our needs (ompact, easy to use) during our recent vacation.  Great buy, good price!

I got this case for my iPod 2g. I was really excited about it when it came because i had been looking for cases and i finally got one. When I got it and opened it up everything was fine so i took it out to put on my iPod. The case fits but it doesn't really snap into the back part of the case. Theres still a bit of space in-between where the two covers connect. The design is cool and it looks awesome but some of the paint around the volume buttons, off button, home button, and the place where you plug the cord in, is sorta scratched and looks very bad. On the back of it to the bottom left and top left there are these ugly square looking silver things ( you can sorta see them in the picture). The place where the border slants in towards the screen has the same paint issue. Other than that the design is really cool and so are the colors! I'd give this a 2 1/2 star rating if i could. Thanks!
summary: Its good but it has some flaws

reviewText: If you have an Acer A500 tablet and are unsure if this is adapter will work...rest easy. This works fine and has a much longer cord than the original charger. Nice price and it works.

At last!  A USB-3 superspeed external hard drive formatting and transfer device!  No more tearing apart my PC and dangling a new hard drive off the motherboard to wipe it or reload it. Take the proper anti-static protections and don't short any raw wires on the "internal" SATA hard drives you attach, and this unit will make your disk drive operations what you always wished they would be... EASY!  Requires a USB-3 port on your PC or laptop for full-speed usage and of course appropriate level of PC knowledge. Thanks Vantec!
summary: The Cars would say "It's just what I needed!"

reviewText: I've used several RAID devices for data storage over the years and I've always ended up wanting to go with four drive devices over two drive devices because of the jump in performance. The My Book Live does a lot to catch up with modern NAS devices on the features side, and certainly offers much more than I'd expect from any two-drive bay device.  However, it still lacks when in comes to actual performance, particularly with regard to enclosure design.  The difference in drive temperature between the My Book Live and a ventilated four bay enclosure is substantial and its hard to expect that it wouldn't make a difference in the lifespan or reliability of the drives.  The cost differential is also substantial.There are many good features in the My Book Live, particularly the cloud storage.  Network performance was surprisingly decent as well. Overall, its one of the better two drive NAS devices out there with the caveat that the lack of ventilation needs to be watched carefully to avoid overheating.

Western Digital My Book Live Duo 4 TB Personal Cloud Storage Drive by Western Digital reviewed here for Amazon is an Excellent Network attached data storage product. It is very simple to use and consumes very little power ideally suited for home media streaming environments and also doubles as a "Personal Cloud" Storage drive to access your photos and files over the internet.For your background information, I am an "Enterprise Systems Engineer" by profession and work for a global IT company and I have worked with many NAS and SAN products over the years and fully understand the limitations and expectations from customers who use these product lines. It is a nice offering from WD to combine "Personal Cloud" with a NAS product and honestly I am truly impressed by this My Book Live Duo.Here are some PROs and CONs first for some quick overview before we get to the nitty gritty details.PROS[+] Personal Cloud Storage + NAS all-in-one device - Love it![+] Plenty fast enough to play Hi-Def Video files over Gigabit Wired or Wireless-N networks[+] Super Efficient Power usage - Perfect for home environments![+] Extremely Silent operation - No FAN design[+] Capability to have Data Redundancy mode (RAID 1) - Peace of mind![+] High Quality Hardware - Pleasing nice looking "My Book Live" series design.[+] View photos and file with free apps for your iOS and or Android tablets[+] Connect up-to 7 USB HDD devices using a powered USB Hub for additional shares!.CONS:[-] No power off button - This is a minor issue (You can still power off using the GUI)[-] Setting up remote mobile or Personal cloud Access is "multi-step" activation process which can be time consuming and tricky for some - Thankfully you need to do it only once!.Before I talk in great detail about the software portions this product let me tell you that WD Live Duo is fully functional with 4TB RAID 0 SPAN right out of the box without using any software. For experienced users you can completely ignore the included software and get the basic functions as NAS device working without using the software CD (My Book Live Discovery Software + SmartWare etc;) that is provided with the product.If you know how to browse your network and discover the IP address of WD Live Duo you can map network drives and start using the "public" share to store and access you data as guest user without setting up users and additional NAS shares etc;The "public" folder also contains the needed software and you can install all the applications like SmartWare and other packages for windows and Mac to the attached PC's.For others who are not technically inclined, thankfully the include CD "setup" process guides you thru' the full process of setting up your WD Live Duo on your home network.The included "SmartWare" software provides features like backing up your PCs connected to your home network. Software works well and the user interface is simple to use. If you really want to use it to backup your PC files it does work. FYI - It does take considerable amount of time to do a full PC backup. But thankfully, you can customize the time and select the need directories and let it backup when your PC is idle.Personal Cloud feature:=======================This is new buzz word now-a-days that everyone wants to have it in their product. Let me explain what this is and what it can do for you. A "personal cloud" is your "own data" like photos and or that video file of your vacation that you secure at your own location and on your WD Live DUO hard disks and completely under your control. Unlike public clouds which are being offered by multitude of hosted services companies these days, a "personal cloud" feature allows you to keep all your data in one safe place inside your home. Other things you can do are sharing of these files with your family members, streaming these media files remotely, and ability to access your content via Internet from anywhere. Bottom-line: No monthly fees. No "unknown" strange location where your personal data resides. That is "Personal Cloud".WD's "2go" web access software app provides fee-free remote access from My Book Live Duo personal cloud storage. You need to register your device with your name and email, Instructions will be sent by WD via email how to activate it. Once you log in, WD "2go" software mounts My Book Live Duo to your computer like a local drive and your remote folders from your "personal cloud" are available on your Mac or PC.The speed at which you can access your files fully depends on how fast internet connection (Upload speeds are important here) you have at home as well as how fast Internet connectivity (Download speeds are important here) you have at the remote location where you attempted to mount your personal cloud.For most small document transfers, uploading downloading few photos and files it is just perfect. Just do not expect to stream that Hi-definition Blu-Ray Rip remotely :-)Suggestions:============In order to maximize performance you need to disable the services that you do not want to use. For example: I do not want this to be my "Itunes" Server so I disabled it. I also did not use the Media Streaming (DLNA) features so that the box is not busy with those additional tasks.Most of my PC's and Media streaming devices on my home network are capable of mounting SAMBA NAS shares. So there was no real need for WD Live Duo to stream via DLNA.If you want you can pair this up withWestern Digital WD TV Live Streaming Media Playerand you will be very happy with the results. WD TV Live Streaming Media Player is excellent when it comes to playback of multitude of media files and thisWestern Digital My Book Live Duo 4 TB Personal Cloud Storage Driveis an excellent storage device.Do not expect to change RAID 0 (SPAN) to RAID 1 (Mirror) instantaneously, the rebuild process takes a very long time (But you can still access the files while the rebuilt takes place in the background with some performance hit)Verdict:========This Product is awesome! - 4  stars!Important Information:======================FYI- There were some batches of WD Live Duo wherein WD did not populate the correct files in the software directory and users got "Runtime" errors when attempting to install the software. Please see my comments section how to resolve that issue.Thanks for reading my review and please feel free to comment if you have any questions.

1 May 2012 update: Battery and laptop doing well.-----21 March 2012 update: Both battery and laptop doing well.-----When my MacBook Pro battery died, I hopped on Amazon to find another one. Zillions of companies want to make a fast buck. Prices ranged from $20-odd to $130-odd, and those are only the ones I saw. The Wild West. Generic-this. Overstock-that. Reviews indicating high-priced batteries performing no better than cheap ones. Argh! What's a person to do? Apple's price of over $100 isn't a fair price; besides, Apple's battery got low ratings too.So, I kept looking and finding battery after battery until my eyes glazed over, some thirty such batteries. Then I bumped into Anker/LaptopMate, and said, ooh, ohh, I know them. I've had good experiences with Anker/LaptopMate before. I consider them reputable. This battery $45--reasonable. I bought it and I'm typing on my MacBook Pro now.So far, so good. A+ (the first day of use). I recommend Anker/LaptopMate brand. If something changes and this Anker battery somehow deserves a lower rating, I'll update this blurb.

I was happy with the fit/finish of the battery. It worked fine for about 4 months, then suddenly failed. I got the exclamation point beside my battery indicator on my MBP, and my machine shut down even though the battery was showing more than 50% charge left. Popped my old OEM MBP back in and no more problems. Will contact the company to see about warrantee replacement and update this post.***Update*** 11/5/2012 - LaptopMate contacted ME today and offered to send a replacement and a return label for this battery to do some testing. Can't ask for better customer service. Will update this review when I get the replacement and have given it some testing time.***Update*** 12/10/2012 - Raising my rating to 4 stars. LaptopMate replaced battery and have provided excellent customer support. New battery seems to be working fine after a month of daily use. Laptop mate is a great company to do business with.

This product has worked well since I got it a couple of weeks ago. It greatly reduces the traffic jam at the wall outlet when you have to charge a couple of devices. You can dispense with the devices' AC adapters and just use their USB plugs, keeping your three electric outlets free.The green indicator light is a little bright for a bedroom but I just put a folded business card over it at night. It would make a nice night light if you needed one where you installed it.

Great product and sturdily built - does what it says it should do - but beware putting in a bedroom - very bright light on the top of these.  It is a green glow that will definitely LIGHT UP YOUR LIFE.  Otherwise a great product!  Easily installed and works great.  Nice to have the USB charge ports and turns a two outlet into a three.

In my commuting bag, space is at a premium and an iPad plug would take up extra space along with a cell phone charger plug. The cables pack flat, and they are all I need now and I can charge my gadgets in my office very nicely thank you -incredibly handy if you are a surgeon on call and stuck in the hospital for more than 12 hours.
summary: Charges iPads and other gadgets, without need to carry plugs

reviewText: I'm a relatively inexperienced but enthusiastic photographer with less than 6 months experience.  I used this flash mainly with a Canon T2i and the Tamron 28-75 f 2.8This is my second yong nuo flash.  My other one is a 560 all manual flash.  I decided I needed TTL after seeing a few totally ruined photos that would've been perfect if I had remembered to change my output with my zooming.I really like the TTL.  I like the fact that you can take the flash +/- 3 Exposure Bias to drop down into the fill flash category.The AF assist beam makes the price alone worth it.  Are you tired of your DSLR 'hunting' for focus in dark situations?  The laser grid this thing projects is extremely useful.  To test how smart it was I went into my bathroom turned all the lights off and the beam made the camera grab focus in roughly the same time it did with the lights on.The quality of light is very clean and the head articulates for all the necessary angles.Works with all of canon's TTL Flash Control menus no problem.Build quality feels on par with the 18-55 kit lens that comes with the entry level DSLRs nowadays.  Not much metal but no foreseeable problems.This is a bit smaller than the yn560/canon 580 series which is nice.I highly recommend this to help get better focus in dark situations and forget about adjusting flash all the time.  Will I want something better in a couple years if I get good enough to utilize it?  Yes.  Will I have a better use of 100$ in the near future with regards to my camera?  No. If you've never used eTTL flash or external flash in general I'd get this to learn with.Hope this helps.

I got these on recommendation from a friend who owned a pair of HE-500s, and I was not disappointed. I paired these with a FiiO E9, but they're easy enough to drive that they don't need to amped. If you're looking for a neutral pair of headphones, these aren't it, but they're very well balanced for everyday listening. Even though they're plastic, the build on these is very nice, not a hint of rattle even at higher volumes. The cable is detachable, and is thick without being too thick. Finally, even the box was well done, they came in a cloth-lined black box. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend these at the price.

I buy this for about USD$10 more than a half of the licensed product to connect my Mac BookPro to a TV, now with this cable I'm able to use the mini display port to use my TV as an extended desktop, the cable fits in without any problem, the length of the cable is really good, is working fine under Mac OS X Lion, and Windows 7 that I use inside the mac with BootCamp, both systems uses the cable with full resolution and audio.
Works for awhile then doesnt work  but that may be my PC problem as it keeps losing my security key for the router, but when working it brings in a good signal, so it looks like it is my PC issue.

Transformer Prime is right now the best tablet out there but there are still problems that should give anyone pause when considering buying it - apparently the GPS issue is hardware related (the alluminium backplate is causing it) and the WiFi signal seems to be worse than on all other WiFi devices. Still, Asus promised unlocking the devices bootloader which makes it quite interesting Android tablet. Especially with ICS coming very soon.

Ok, so I've been in the tablet market for the last 3 months and I finally was able to get my hands on this product. Trust me when I say it wasn't easy but it was worth the trouble.
