This tablet is by far the most advanced and fastest tablet on the market (IOS or Android). That doesn't mean it's perfect because no tech product is. Those out there looking for a device that never has bugs or issues might as well stop now because you'll never find something to your liking. What I can say is that ASUS did a fine job with putting this together. I won't touch on every aspect of the Transformer Prime but here are some highlights:Screen- This screen is bright and beautiful. You can set the Super IPS display if you're outdoors but otherwise, the regular brightness is perfectly fine. The resolution is the same as most 10.1 inch tablets and is crisp and clear.Speed- This tablet has a Tegra 3 quad-core processor and it is blazing. You can multi-task to your hearts delight and it won't skip a beat. It opens applications faster than any phone or tablet I can think of. The encouraging news is that they are still really developing apps for the Tegra 3 so when that becomes more relevant this thing will be even better. Scrolling and touch sensitivity is "buttery" smooth with no lag whatsoever.Build- This is a very aesthetically pleasing device. What I mean is that it is an eye-catcher. Brushed aluminum backing and super thin, it looks fantastic. It's light and the weight balance is perfect when holding with one hand or two. Gorilla glass screen means that you won't have to worry about scratches. Those out there that complain about fingerprints need to realize that this is the case for 99% of tablets out there. (HINT: use the microfiber cloth that comes with it)Storage and Connectivity- One of the biggest selling points was the storage space. 32gb of onboard memory PLUS it has a micro-sd card slot for expansion. This thing can become an entertainment powerhouse.  It has a micro-hdmi out so you can connect to TVs or projectors. This means you can watch Netflix and other movies on a bigger screen if you'd prefer. You won't have to buy a proprietary cables just to connect. Of course, the big sell is the laptop dock accessory. I personally don't need it but its a great option if you want a netbook like experience. Oh yeah, you can also use PS3 or USB gaming controllers with this to play games!Battery Life- So I haven't done an "official" battery test but in my usage so far I easily get a couple days out of this tablet. It obviously depends on what the settings are (i.e. screen brightness, power mode) but trust me when I say that if you go on a long trip with this thing you'll be good to go with juice to spare.Ice Cream Sandwich- This may not matter in a month or two but it is currently one of a select few devices that has the latest operating system of Android 4.0, Ice Cream Sandwich. I won't get into all the details of what ICS is but I can say that it is user friendly and has loads of potential.Side notes:Ok, so a lot of people may have heard about certain users having issues with WIFI and/or GPS. On my end, I haven't had a single issue with WIFI. The signal is always strong even at a good distance away from the router. I think this just may be an isolated issue with some of the devices. I don't think this is indicative of all the tablets. I haven't used the GPS much but I can guess that the all-aluminum backing has something to do with the issues its having catching signals from satellites. Honestly though, it's ridiculous to use this as a standalone GPS device.As a heads-up, this tablet is currently (as of 2/21) extremely hard to come by. It is sold out at most, if not all retailers. I'm sure ASUS will eventually be able to keep up with demand but be warned that you may not be able to get one for a while. This obviously is a result of the shortsightedness of ASUS and should bear no negative reflection on the tablet itself.The Verdict:So is this worth $499.99 of your hard earned money? If you're looking for the best tablet available then the answer is a definitive YES. It's certainly worth more for your money than ANY tablet at and around its price.

A few years ago I purchased an ASUS Netbook based on the premise that it provided superior portability for web surfing at a reasonable price. Wrong. Yes, it was small and light, but the need to fold it as well as the limits of battery life in my experience significantly compromised what I could do on the road. Add to that the Windows operating system and an underpowered Intel Atom CPU and it made for a miserable surfing and computing experience, whether on the road or not.Fast forward to late November of 2011 when I first heard of another robust ASUS ultra portable computer in the form of a tablet running on the Android platform and you can imagine I was skeptical, especially at the price points mentioned in the press and with the claims that HD quality video would run smoothly, that surfing included fast screen updates, and that the tablet delivered an enjoyable gaming experience.  After considering that I had an Amazon gift card for $100, but recognizing that Amazon appeared to have stopped taking orders and the fact that I had an upcoming vacation trip for which it was necessary to travel light, I took my chances and ordered the Transformer Prime from B&H; on November 25. B&H; could not provide a reliable shipping date or even explain if they shipped on the basis of who placed orders first. Thus I indicated my travel destination as the shipping address thinking there was no way the product would take that long to ship. Wrong again. Weeks later, when it was clear that my vacation would end before I received the tablet, I asked B&H; to change the shipping address to my home. B&H; explained they could do that but that would place me at the end of the line, which was apparently established after my initial call. I had previously had good experience with B&H;, but it was very disappointing to hear this. Considering the experience and the still unused Amazon gift certificate, it was easy for me to cancel the order through B&H; to order through Amazon instead. I have never had a problem with Amazon and they just happened to have started taking orders again. I placed the order in late December and it arrived on about the 14th of January nicely boxed to prevent damage during transit.I unpacked, quickly went through the abbreviated user guide, charged the unit as directed, and the following day attempted to run the setup to link to my wireless home network. Based on news accounts and Transformer Forums I was concerned about problems with both GPS and wireless connectivity. I hoped my experience would be uneventful, but it was not to be. When the setup attempted to log into my Gmail account, it was apparent to me that I probably had hours of troubleshooting ahead of me. I had some hope, however, that since the Transformer Prime was connecting to the home network but failing at the point of internet access, that my problem would be easier to diagnose and fix. I did a fair number of fruitless Google searches before I resorted to ASUS customer support. ASUS had me reboot my router (which I had just updated the firmware for) and then walked me through the process of resetting the Android software. Still no luck. Customer support told me I had two options at that point: one, send them the Transformer Prime for repair since they concluded it was faulty or, two, return it to Amazon for an exchange or refund. These options were provided to me after no more than 5 minutes of conversation and I was surprised that ASUS was not suggesting other options. I reminded the representative that I was able to establish a wireless network connection and that the issue was simply internet access. He was insistent that the problem was the tablet and I didn't argue. Nonetheless I was determined to try other options before returning the tablet.I started by driving to a nearby mall, figuring that if I could connect to the internet there I would have some assurance that the tablet was not the problem. Within seconds of my turning on the tablet, I did indeed establish the internet connection while sitting in my car about 30 feet from the nearest building. I completed the setup, went to the settings menu, saw that there was an update available, and proceeded to download and install what turned out to be Android 4.0_. I then drove home monitoring the access points and signal strength along the way. I was very surprised by the number of unsecured access points in residential areas. I hope that people are taking precautions in safeguarding their privacy and data.When I got home I called my internet service provider to make sure that there were no service interruptions. I was assured there were none. I then powered on the tablet hopeful that the operating system update solved my problems. It did not. At that point I knew the problem was my router. Since I purchased my D-Link 655 from Costco at a time they had a promotion that provided free lifetime technical support, I wasted no time in getting them on the phone. Within 30 minutes of trial and error testing, we traced the problem to an IP address for the router that limited functionality. We changed that and immediately had the Transformer Prime on the internet.One thing I am extremely thankful for is the free router technical assistance. I have an extremely complicated home network with multiple routers, switches, and extenders for both wired and wireless connectivity. We also have multiple media servers and at any one time can have more than 10 devices competing for wired and wireless bandwidth. My technical knowledge is limited and as much as I enjoy tweaking, a prime consideration for me in any future router purchase will be the availability of free technical support for those times that I can't troubleshoot a problem.As to the Transformer Prime, now that I've put it through hours of use, I'm impressed. I have not taken it on a trip yet, but I can happily trip through my home and yard while surfing without problems. The available aps are numerous, performance far exceeds that of a netbook, the screen is gorgeous, and while I have experienced occasional browser crashes, they are thus far tolerable and I hope fixed in future software releases.This is what the Netbook should have been.I recommend a Griffin stylus and a stand to go with the mini HDMI cable in your accessory kit. I am still waiting for the leather jacket that I will protect the tablet in. If that allows me easy tablet access, this product is a winner since it seems I can use this product all day without a charge.

Although the product description says this is a "Photographic Equipment Bag", it isn't.  It's a tripod.  And it comes with a bag.This study tripod has legs that telescope up and down as most do.  The legs also adjust outward for a wider stance.  The default stance is 25, but the legs can also be spread out to 50 or 80 for a lower, more stable position.The head includes two bubble levels for leveling the camera front/back and side/side.  Or the entire head can be removed to change the mount altogether.  The ball head has a large knob for adjusting the ball's tension and a smaller knob to lock the tension of the 360 rotation.The tripod also includes very complete product documentation.  There is actually one user's guide for the tripod and a second one for the head.

This router is great. I won't go into the gritty details as other already have, however I previously had the E3000, and I tried both this and the Netgear N900 and for my money this Linksys wins hands down. I have my Xbox hard wired to the router, and my desktop connected wirelessly I frequently stream content from my desktop with no problems using this router. With the other 2 routers mentioned, the quality is spotty at best.
summary: Great Router, confused by the bad reviews

reviewText: Very inexpensive and poorly made DC adapter than can easily overheat those expensive Canon batteries!  Stay away from this brand and find one that has a thermal resistor protecting the battery and your car receptacle.
summary: DC Adapter But Quality Is Variable

reviewText: I pretty much am just going to confirm what others have already said, and that is the quality for the price you pay is superb.  I have owned a few other mechanical keyboards, but paid at least $40+ more for the same thing.  The size is excellent, and I actually prefer to not have the extra number pad.  I have never been a fan of wrist-rest, so that is not an issue for me, but may be for some.  If you are in the market for mechanical you cannot go wrong with this brand/model.
My Commando works for me non-stop so needs constant charging, however, sometimes I forget to recharge it sometimes and it is dead.  This hasn't happened since I installed this battery.

I was a little worried when I first purchased these chips - I don't have quad channel memory capabilities (sadly, lol) but I do have support for up to 32G of dual channel RAM in my machine and needed more to run more VM's during the day - finding 32G dual channel specific was more expensive than these (by a lot) so I rolled the dice. I had 16G of dual channel Corsair Vengeance, and I went to their website and, yes, in smaller print it does say this RAM can be supported in dual channel systems - so really I'm just here to assure anyone else that it does, indeed, work and work well in my AMD 8120 FX based board with dual channel memory capability. Great RAM, always top quality and takes being overclocked too!

Upgraded a 2010 13 inch MBP to this drive and upgraded to 8gb of RAM and boot time went from 45 seconds to 15 seconds. Most of the speed showed up after installing the hard drive. The drive did take a couple boots to cache information to the SSD and then that's when the speeds started to improve drastically. Upon initial installation the boot times were 1:30. But then they eventually dropped down to 15 seconds.

This is a bad time to be a hard drive maker.The tragic floods in Thailand have submerged one factory, and swamped another one that makes things like motors, so there will be a shortage of drives until next summer.Add to that people pushing cloud computing and Solid State Drives, and those price drops (that used to be so regular you could set your smartphone by them) are some way off.I'm surprised that Seagate is the only company that is strongly pushing Hybrid Drives - with a small Solid State section along with platters that hold hundreds of Gigabytes.Over the last year I've had all kinds of long-term storage in my own computers - plain 7,200 rpm hard drives, Seagate's first attempt at Hybrids (the 500GB conventional with 4GB SSD), a new computer with only a 120GB Solid State Drive, and now the latest Hybrid from Seagate - 750GB as platters and 8GB SSD.Intel is also pushing Smart Response in its latest support chips, so you can fit an SSD drive of any size with your platter drives (they recommend a 20GB-64GB SSD for Smart Response).These combination of two storage technologies work very well, because you don't need to adjust anything. You need to make the drive on your system go through two or three boots, because until you show it what files you use regularly it doesn't know what to speed up. The system works out which are the most-used files and makes a copy of them in the SSD area, so that when you come to start Windows, for instance, the files will be read instantaneously as opposed to the files being located and read from the platters. That speeds up things, but by how much? In other words, is it worth you getting some sort of SSD?The answer is definitely yes, but the speed improvement varies by the type of SSD setup you have. In order of my using them, the 500GB 7,200 rpm all platter drive worked OK. When I went to an equivalent drive with 4GB SSD, it seemed that boot times were almost cut in half. Then the new computer arrived, which had the latest performance chip (the 2500K), and everything was on the SSD. This gave a massive speed boost, with Windows and Application boot times at almost instantaneous speeds. I didn't check the times with a stopwatch, but speed times were down to the point where you couldn't ignore the machine, otherwise it would sit there waiting for you. The mechanical boot time (i.e. the time before Windows starts) is longer on my new machine, and Windows is 64-bit rather than 32-bit.It looks as though my 120GB SSD will run just about all of the programs I want. Windows 64-bit is around 30GB (Windows 32-bit is around 20GB). I also have Microsoft Office Pro (all programs, including Access and Publisher), Waterfox (Firefox for 64-bit), a bunch of freeware programs, and games like Civ 5 and Skyrim. All of that takes up 41.5 GB leaving me with 70GB for things like Photoshop, and lots of other stuff.So how does this Hybrid drive do? I was able to copy the old Windows onto the new 750GB hard drive, and got my new computer to boot from it. And the performance is amazing. 8GB of SSD is much closer to the sweet spot, coming in just a few seconds behind what the 120GB all-SSD would manage. My guess is that you may not notice the 500GB drive, but you would definitely notice the 750GB. Although the drive is rated for SATA 6GB, you can use existing SATA 3GB connections at the expense of a small amount of speed.I noticed a lot of people who used Mac laptops reviewing the 500GB hybrid drive. It would appear that the drive will work with a Mac, but part of the SSD area is reserved for particular Windows files. However, Mac users seem impressed with it, in fact the major favorable reviews of this drive on Amazon come from Mac users.So, is it for you? I must mention that right now, a shortage of drives has driven the price up, and I feel that this situation will exist through the summer until production reaches normal levels. In normal times, I would guess that this drive would retail for $150, but even paying the current price, the drive is worth it. All it requires is for you to install the new drive, copy over the old hard drive, and then tell the machine to boot from the Hybrid. If you have a laptop, you may have to do this on your desktop, but once it's done, that's the end of the installation.As someone said, all hard drives should come as Hybrids. Although all-SSD drives will fall in price, that drop in NAND pricing means that Hybrid drives will become cheaper and/or larger in capacity. Anandtech has a very positive review, and a dozen more can be found on Seagate's site.So install it and sit back. You won't be disappointed.EDIT - I hear that a 1TB drive in this series is in the works. No idea when it will be released, or what the price will be, but imagine it with 16GB of SSD.

So I read that this drive does not sleep in MacBook Pros.  I chose to ignore these posts assuming it was user error.Well, after getting the drive delivered and installing Lion, I can confirm it does not sleep.  You close the lid on the computer, wait, and hold up to your ear.  Yep, it's still spinning away, not sleeping.  Upon opening the lid of the MacBook Pro, it never went to sleep (remained powered on).  This means the batter will die very quick and the computer gets hot due to the HDD spinning away.Googled a bunch and found an EFI downgrade trick.  Didn't work.  Sadly, this drive is going back.  It's fast but DOES NOT SLEEP ON MACBOOK PROS.You've been warned.5/20/2012 update:It spins down sometimes in OS X.  No issues with Win7 in Bootcamp - spins down every time.Clearly there is an issue with the firmware and it's not known if Seagate is working on a fix. Until then, hope you hit the spin down lotto when you close your lid.  Works sometimes, other times it never stops spinning.  Strange, but regardless of this, I am keeping the drive and hoping Seagate realizes there are Mac users out there (and updates the firmware to fix).
summary: Will not sleep in Early 2011 MacBook Pro

reviewText: Installed in my mid 2010 MacbookPro and WOW. Faster for everyday tasks and inexpensive extra space. Cloned from original HD and installed easily. No difference from a regular HD as far as formatting, partitioning, cloning and installing. Recommended!

I love this drive so much. I wanted an SSD, but I need more than 256GB of space, and the 512GB + size SSDs are still a little too expensive for me. If you're in a similar boat, this is the drive for you. The 8GB of built-in flash memory helps the drive "learn" which programs you access most often, and helps open them with SSD speed. Same for booting. I can open Photoshop in 2 seconds. My boot time has dropped to 14 seconds cold, and I didn't have to give up space for the speed. This drive also comes with a beefy 5-year warranty. I dropped it in my MacBook Pro, and it's noticeably faster. Highly recommended.
summary: Blazing speed + tons of space = WIN

reviewText: Ok first of all the setup was very easy. It bypasses a lot of question most ordinary routers ask you. And you have the option to change settings later online. I ran the speed test thats included in the software and got 12 mbps. Then I followed the instruction everyones been talking about disabling the WMM in "Applications and Gaming" and got a whopping 15mbs. Great right? well the router said it needed an update so I clicked the update. After the router updated itself NOTHING WORKED??????? I was furious, it was late and I was not calling lazy customer support. So I reset the router and after going thru the whole process again I got less than what I had..14 mbs. Last but not least, I live in a three bedroom home and I lose a bar whenever I go to another room.....this routers range is terrible. Definitely not four stars.

Purchased this memory for a new computer build for my son.  I was skeptical at first since it was an unknown brand.  However the install went smoothly and no changes were needed to the BIOS to make it work.  Very happy and would purchase this brand again.
No issues at all, records HD just fine in my camera, no stuttering and no issues whatsoever. I would recommend this product.
summary: Works just fine in my Nikon S9100 camera(with adapter)

reviewText: Check out the pics I uploaded!This is a sturdy, well-built keyboard for Samsung's 8.9 Tab.  The buttons are a good size, and they are responsive.  I like the amount of shortcut buttons it has available: home button, volume control etc...  The only downside to this keyboard is the fact that it's exclusively for the 8.9 tab, and thus worthless if you sell, lose or break your tablet.  Samsung should have included a USB port on it as well.Pros:+ Well built, and sturdy.+ Responsive keystrokes.+ Useful array of shortcut keys.+ Audio-out, allowing you to hook up PC speakers for better audio quality.Cons:- Can only be used with Samsung's 8.9 Galaxy tab.- No USB port.- It's thin enough for easy portability, but I wouldn't recommend it to habitual "frequent flyers."- No water-resistance for an $80 mobile keyboard?Conclusion:I recommend this keyboard only because it's almost a necessity for the Galaxy 8.9 tab if you need to do a lot of typing.  ...I bought this used for $25 shipped, I recommend you avoid buying new, because it's a proprietary keyboard that can only be used with the 8.9 tab.

I guess the saying "you get what you pay for" applies here. This keyboard feels extremely cheap, the keys aren't alligned correctly. Also, some of the function keys don't work. Overall, I say buy a keyboard that may cost more, but is definitely worth it.
summary: A decent keyboard, not worth it for the price.

reviewText: Good: Fits accurately the size and shape of Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1. Works well as screen protector. Easy to pair with tablet via BlueTooth. Pretty stylish.Bad: Somrtimes inputs 2 to 5 identical symbols when I only press a key once. And keystroke is really short. So I need to delete extra symbols pretty often, which is annoying. Will try to find a solution, and if succeed, will update that brief review.

OK this Item said Made of anodized black Metal and plastic..... I just didn't expect 95% to be pure plastic..Like the other review the only part that its metal is the adapter that connects to the rod system....as a Sun shade its perfect not to be for real professional use only as temporary items......It does feel like ill break not to far from now.....But like everything its cheap and affordable to everyone....Im happy enough to give 3 stars, next time ill save and buy something that will be more sturdy and that will last a long time.....
summary: i was expecting a little more

reviewText: As a pro photographer I am always looking for products that improve my workflow, and this is one of them. Solid, well designed and super inexspensive make these a must have to carry multiple bodies around. I have them on all of my bodies making it easier than ever to use multiple bodies.
summary: I love the ExFoto SS D-Link

reviewText: I installed this into my 06 Matrix so I could listen to Pandora radio in the car.Its an inexpensive stereo that outperforms stock, ads front AUX, and is capable of adding a bluetooth adapter to stream wirelessly and make/receive calls hands-free over your speakers.I ordered the wiring harness and adapter bracket on amazon.con. Everything cost me $97, and I installed it on my lunch hour.Overall I'm happy with it, but based on the price, my expectations were not too high. I have no complaints, and aside from maybe buying a model with integrated bluetooth, I would not have spent more to get anything better.

Ive had this stereo for about a month now. I have nothing but good things to say about it.Bluetooth streaming from my iPhone is seamless. I haven't even considered the need to hook the phone up via USB.  It wirelessly connects within seconds of turning the car on. Even the gps app I use steams to the stereo. I'm able to stream any audio app I've tried. The iPhone acts like it's airplay after pairing with the stereo.One plus that I didn't even know came with it is an external mic for Bluetooth calls. Even in my jeep, people on the phone can hear me. I don't even have to get my phone out of my pocket to answer a call!Navigating the menu took a little getting used to, but after I used it a few times it works well. I navigate all music on my phone but sometimes advance a song from the stereo.Overall, I highly recommend this stereo for cost and function. Very happy with my purchase.

I mostly put this into my latest build simply because I couldn't bring myself to NOT put in an optical drive.  But, other than the OS install, I don't see this being used much at all.That said, it was inexpensive, went in perfectly and did the job I needed it to do.  For the price, its 4 stars.

This was super easy to set up. There are long screws holding each side of the band which you take out with the included screwdrivers and then after you get the band off, you then screw in the attachment with the same screws. This then allows you to quick change onto the band or bike attachment.It seems to be sturdy. The bike attachment is easy to set up too and is actually easier to arrange on my aerobars than what I was doing before with a bike computer attachment and then using the Garmin bike mount. It's much lighter than this previous arrangement too.I give it 4 stars instead of 5 only because the attachment, although less bulky than I imagined from the pictures still raises your watch ~7mm (or 1/4 inch) from the wristband. I'm no expert, but I'm thinking something could be developed which allowed you to take off the entire metal back of the device and replace it with something that gave half that clearance, or even have a quick release built into the base device since this is a multi-sport device.One added perk with this back, however, is that it has a notch cut out on the back, which fits the charging device perfectly and so I find it easier to clip on the charger getting it to make contact the first try instead of multiple attempts.
This cover was exactly what I wanted. It protects the Prime much better than the flimsy cover I purchased for my 8" Android. I am pleased with the quality and the reasonable price of this product.

These are bright, acoustically transparent and a pleasure to listen to.  Like most earphones, they required some breaking in...they initially sounded a bit dull.  After plugging them into my old iPod and letting it run for a day, the sound substantially improved.They're well constructed.  It's not particularly visible in the photos, but the wire is flat, not round.  It's securely attached to the plugs and at the junction where the right and left earphones separate.  The volume control and microphone work well when using it with my iPad and iPhone.Highly recommended.

I bought these earbuds after I read favorable a review on CNET.Velodyne advertises these as the earbuds for people who like bass, and on that point, they are right. These do have pretty remarkable bass for a small pair of earbuds. But other than that, there is little to distinguish them from other, inexpensive headphones.Other than the bass, the sound quality overall is a bit better than regular earbuds, but the construction of these headphones has some problems. First, the flat cords, intended to resist tangling, are really heavy, and bounce around if you move at all, even if you try to use the cheap plastic clip that comes with the headphones. Not only is this physically annoying, but you can hear the bumping of the cords louder than your music. This makes them terrible headphones for jogging or any other activity with a lot of movement.The headphones do come with a variety of sizes of replacement rubber tips--which is good, because they always seem to fall off and get lost (though I suppose this wouldn't happen if you always carried them around in the bulky case they came in, but I find most people just wrap their earbuds around whatever device they're using, and they don't fall apart). Also, the first day I used them, the plastic piece on the headphone jack fell off. It was just cosmetic, so it still works fine, it just looks kind of stupid.Overall, the sounds quality is good (but perhaps not good enough for the price), but the construction leaves a lot to be desired.

It's a beautiful thing to have 32GB at your fingertips- my first Mac had 55mb of storage! Even though my computer only has USB 2.0 ports, this USB 3.0 flash drive transferred several large video files quickly. The drive feels sturdy and durable, like it could take a fall and not crack open or damage the data. I've never had a problem with a Lexar drive, and can recommend this one to anyone needing a large amount of storage in a small package.

I got this as a simple backup USB drive.  Sadly, my awesome laptop with a solid state drive doesn't have USB 3.0 so I can't vouch for the claims of 100+MB transfer.  On USB 2.0 I get about 10MB/second of transfer which works just fine by me.  It's not something that I'm going to replace my laptop for but...Right out of the box, the drive comes with a little keychain fob but it's darn hard to attach.  That was pretty much worthless to me.  After fighting with the laynard for five minutes, it hit the trash.The USB does extend out so you need a fingernail to extend the drive.  That worked just fine by me.On Windows 7, I did not have to reformat the drive.  It was immediately ready for use.  The drive does have some heft to it.  The underside feels like metal.  Overall it feels like this should hold up well to any abuse.I can't speak for the faster speeds but it works just fine.
summary: Good drive but I can't vouch for USB 3.0...

reviewText: There IS English firmware available for this but only if it came that way from the factory. The Chinese firmware cannot be upgraded to English. That's not a big deal though. The illustrated English manual, should you need it, can be found at tp-link com resources document TL-WR700N_V1_user_gudie pdf and yes, the word 'guide' is correctly misspelled as shown.  Add dots before com and pdf and forward slashes in the blank spaces. The manual has screenshots to guide you in working with the Chinese firmware in the event you need to change from the default access point mode.The nice thing about this device is that, if you want to use it as an access point, just plug it in and you're done. Although the unit will operate in several modes, the main reason for buying this is to simply make a wired connection wireless as might be desirable in a hotel room.Some hotels , particularly overseas, offer free wired internet but not in-room WiFi. If you want to fire up your Kindle Fire to download a book you'll need wireless and this unit does the trick nicely. Although the flip out plug is the North American standard, it will work on 220 volts as found in many countries as well as 110 volts and 100 volts in Japan.The unit does its job nicely and couldn't be simpler to use. If you get the English version so much the better but it's not a big deal either way.
summary: English manual is available but not firmware.

reviewText: I could never get this router to work. I tried to set it up through my iMac, through my HTPC, and through my notebook. Nothing. I wanted to use it as a wired bridge for the Xbox in my oldest son's room, but could never get it up and running. I spent about 90 minutes on the TP-LINK website and customer service, and finally got to the point where I said it wasn't worth it anymore.
summary: For the junk drawer it goes...

reviewText: The great think about this is you don't ave to install any software and it works with any operating system.I unlock the key and the user writes the data I need to the USB stick. I lock it.Later on when I get to the office, I plug it in to my MacbookPro and unlock it and download the data.Simple, I format it FAT so Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux can write to it.  Larger files?  Not problem. I format it NTFS, WIN7 writes, and Mac OS Xor Linux can read NTFS, just not write it. Perfect.  For PC to PC it is a no-brainer as you don't even have to think about any of that.  When working between the 3 different operating systems, I find FAT to be so painless.As for encryption, I like this better than  my IRONKEY.  The IRONKEY will actually BURN out the chip by heating it if you attempt to access it 10 times.  The Apricorn Aegis will also destroy the contents of memory, but rather than burning the chip out so you have to buy another, it just wipes the drive in a Mil-Spec manner so the data is not retrievable. Far better idea IMPO.  As another user noted, it is epoxy filled, so there is no physical tampering.  As for another user saying the keys are too small, they are small, but it is not a big deal.  I have big hands.  I can press the keys and there is a definite tactile click response when pressing the key so you know you pressed it or didn't.  Also there is room between the buttons, so the size of the buttons is not an issue.  I also like that they have the letters on the numeric keys as well, so you can use a combination name/number sequence.The other benefit to a "no software needed" device like this, which even the IRONKEY suffers from, is you enter your code on the device NOT a keyboard.  Entering on a keyboard allows for interception by the very common and trivial "key capture" malware out there.Lastly, sometimes it is just the details.  So many USB devices have a string loop to put through the USB so you don't lose it if you are lucky, or it is plastic which is worse.  The Aegis has a nice 1" diameter metal braided ring, and a small cylindrical grip at the top so you don't have to pull the USB device out by the wire as the case is a nice snug fit. (You can see it in the photo).  It just shows that it was well thought out.Operationally, it has been flawless.  I have no con's.
summary: This is even better than my IRONKEY!

reviewText: I bought the 240 Gb version. At about $1/Gb at the time, it was one of the cheapest drives available in this capacity and the best performing. Highest R/W rates, high reliability and so far, it's definitely true. Win7 Pro loads before the Windows animation completes, even with a dozen games and other startup apps needed to load. I'll never go back to HDDs for booting, even RAID 0 wasn't even close for load times.If you're considering an SDD, jump on this one. 240 Gb is plenty for gaming and music. If you need more storage for pictures/editing/movies, get a SATA 3.0 external/internal HDD, but the load times with SDD are so fast, you'll wonder why you hadn't switched earlier.

I purchased this SSD to go with the Hard Drive Caddy Tray for Apple Unibody MacBook (also purchased on Amazon)  to go in my Mid-2009 Macbook Pro.  Prior to Install, my boot time with the original APple HD was over 3 minutes from start-up until I could navigate to a webpage.  With the new SSD, from start-up until I can surf is 14 seconds flat.  This SSD is great and the cheapest I have found on the market.  It may not be the fastest SSD but you are not likely to find a price on an SSD with a big name like SanDisk on it.  Overall, great buy, easy install and excellent value!

Most importantly, this memory IS fast, and no errors to speak of with my Core i7-2700K / ASRock Z77 Extreme4 setup. I have not attempted to overclock the chips at all, but for this particular price point, I don't think most purchasers would be interested in doing so (even though it does appear to be supported). You're buying these chips for value and speed as-is, and it delivers that well.One negative for me was the large heat sink. While it serves an important purpose and dissipates heat, it makes it a crunch to fit these chips in with a very large heat sink. So, make sure your motherboard allows adequate room for these large-in-height chips so you can utilize all of the available ports. That's the only reason I'm taking it down to a 4-star review, just need to do your homework on your case design and fan options before purchasing.
summary: Blazing Fast, Value Driven, Large Heat Sink Mixed Blessing

reviewText: The live viewfinder, at the end of the day does whats its suppose to, but with a little help from the user. First the viewfinders resolution Is great and its fast, but the ENORMOUS issue is that there is no  sort of covering around it so you can see on a sunny day. Without using your hand to cover the light around it the viewfinder is useless, and Panasonic does not even offer and sort of rubber eye cup to block out the light. I now know that for the Olympus M4/3 cameras they do offer a cup, but it does not fit this view finder. So I ended up making my own out of an old Cannon eye-cup.  I just shaved off the back and the bottom and squeezed it on, it now works perfect. But I have to say the viewfinder is an eye sore when its attached to a beautiful camera like the GX1. Another issue is that it does not clip down, the  viewfinder opens up to 90 degree position from time to time when I put it in my bag.My conclusion is that if these companies just put a bit more though into this viewfinder it could be more practical, but as of now it will do, I have changed it to my liking and I'm happy with it  but I had to adapt it, it does not come this way out of the box. ( The future of compact systems are in range finder type viewfinders or in integrated live viewfinders like in the Olympus OM-D)

Color, hi-res LVF for the GX1. If you use a DLSR, just get this. Trying to compose/chimp from an LCD screen is annoying and borderline frustrating to anyone used to a mirrored camera.All LCD menu features are also controlled from the LVF. Oddly, accessing the playback menu bumps you to the LCD panel and you will have to hit the LCD/LVF toggle switch to get back.The screen is a bit dim, but its brightness can be adjusted through the camera menu. It also swivels to allow composing of tough ground-level shots.One downside is that it makes the GX1 even larger, but that is relative to anyone used to lugging around a DSLR. The other is that you can't mount a flashgun to the camera with the LVF in place.Look around and get it on sale, many retailers offer it for 159.

I'm not going to gush over this one, its a cheap, but effective, way to protect your 8" tablet while adding a decent keyboard with a nice assortment of connectors to the mix.The keyboard wasn't the best for fast typing, often missing a few keystrokes now and again, but for short and simple note taking, it fits the bill nicely.Unlike other in this price range, though, this one includes a few different connectors. There's one for mini usb and one for micro usb, something I've not seen at this price point before, making this a more useful cover/keyboard than most.Summing up, this is a decent combo for the asking price, and it fits the bill for those looking for more than just a cover for their 8" tablets. Recommended!

Has decent status lights and status web pages (at 192.168.100.1). Seemed to work fine for a while. Then it would hang, lose sync, and reset itself frequently, like more than daily. So I replaced it with a Motorola cable modem which has been perfect.

I ordered the first one due to a deal I found slickdeals and that was the one without the power plug and I also received every channel HD. My brother came and saw the antenna and wanted it so badly I gave it to him. I now ordered this one and in my opinion is as good as the one without the powerplug.  Either one is amazing and you will not be sorry to purchase it. I give it 2 thumbs up and 2 toes.
Charged in an hour with little juice left. Works fast for using your kindle again. Good price and shipped quick.

I think most of us that purchased a Kindle Fire or Fire HD agree that a charger should be included. Let's put that aside and get to the review. The PowerFast charger absolutely charges much faster than using the stand-alone USB cable included with the Fire HD. I was able to purchase the PowerFast charger with my Fire HD 8.9 so I paid the $9.99.+ Promotion Price of $9.99 is appropriate+ Small and does not cover other outlets+ USB cord plugs into the bottom so the cord sits neatly against the wall and does not stick out.+ Charges much faster than the USB cord alone+ Can easily be placed in a pocket/laptop bag etc.+ Can Charge With Device Both ON/OFF_Bottom Line_ Yes, I would recommend the charger. I do not see any cons on this item. I chose to spend the money and buy the PowerFast and I am glad I did. My Fire HD 8.9 charges quickly whether the device in powered on or not. Without the PowerFast the Fire HD actually displayed a message that a "low power source" was connected and the device should be powered off to charge. I recieved my Fire HD before the PowerFast and it took many many hours to charge using only the USB cable connected to the computer. Worth $9.99 not $19.99 in my opinion.
summary: Compact, Does Not Block Other Outlets, Charges Much Faster!!

reviewText: I purchased the top of the line 8.9 4G LTE model.  I think it's deceptive for Amazon to sell the charging plug separately.  Yes, it lowers the initial purchase price but it surprises the customer with an unexpected charge.As you might have guessed, I don't have an actual issue with the product but I am protesting the additional unexpected charge.  If you feel the same way; I suggest you do the same by rating this item one star.
summary: You shouldn't have to pay for the power plug, especially on their flagship model

reviewText: This product does NOT include a stand for the drive, even though the photos often show one.  Also, the drive is a bit kludgy as it may require TWO USB ports to function fully.
summary: Be careful if you want a DVD drive with a stand

reviewText: One of the best Amplified Antennas I have tried. I have to adjust the the placement of the antenna from time to time, other than that good reception.

I had very high hopes for this product.Installation and Setup was easy. The downfall was the Execution. It simply FAILED. In ALL aspects. I am VERY Tech Savvy and this product to put it as simply as I can without violating Amazon's TOS for Review's is a Piece of "crap".It touts itself as being able to attach to an external Hard Drive and maintain an Online Cloud backup of all your files. One of their Product Taglines is 'We Challenge You to set up PogoPlug in 60 Seconds or less". Umm I challenge you to put out a Product that even if it take me 5 mins to setup actually WORKS as described,.I was using am Apple iPhone 4s, a Dell Studio XPS Laptop and my Home Internet that connects at 30+ MBps so the issues weren't on my end

I bought the pink one because, well, I'm a girl... It's a nice shade of pink; the stand works fine; the camera and other holes are all in the right place.The only thing I wish it had was a vertical stand, but that's not a deal breaker.
summary: Nice looking and keeps my tablet like new

reviewText: I picked one of these up directly from Cisco when they were selling some refurbished units and I have to say I was hesitant to buy it even at a great price after reading all the reviews.It looks like Cisco didn't have their act together with Comcast and pushed out a firmware update late 2011 that was not tested, and worse, took 6 months to fix.  Completely unacceptable, however I think you'll find it means they have a bunch of refurbs around that are perfectly good units.The unit I received has not dropped a connection since I got it, and for the price, I consider it a great deal.Why did I choose it other than price?  It's on the Comcast supported modem list and is listed with features such as IPV6 which are important for the future.  It's from Cisco, and if anyone knows networking, it's them.  Old Linksys hardware I've had has been good.  Not so impressed with recent Wifi routers, but thought it was worth a go.Note to Cisco as I see you read these reviews and respond to people:  Get your act together and focus on quality in the consumer market! Test Test Test!Anyways.  These units with the latest firmware (that Comcast automatically loads when you plug it in) appear to run well, and I'm glad I'm now not paying them $7 each month for modem rental.

I wish I would've had this 4 hours earlier.  My daughter is very careful with her stuff but one morning as she reached for her alarm, she bumped her Kindle and it fell hitting her bedframe and scratched the screen.  Things happen.. but if I would've purchased this when she got her Kindle, I could've avoided the drama. The screen protectors are a MUST for any device!!  and the prices are wonderfully affordable for anyone. PROTECTION IS A MUST...even if its for your screen.
Thi remote is very simple to keep in you case because it is so small.It also works like a charm,and has a very long range.The rande Of this remote is a good 20 feet or more. It is a must have!

I had to put together an emergency video conference for a board meeting for our small manufacturing company.  I had several days to put everything together and test it out.  Our conference room is about 40 feet long and 14 feet wide.  I used this camera connected to a mid-range laptop and displayed video on a 50 inch lcd television.  GoToMeeting facilitated the communication between sites.  The only additional hardware that I used was an external microphone as the mic built into the camera was not up to picking up a room full of voices.  I had about 8 people arranged across the conference table at a maximum distance of about 30 feet from the camera.The great thing about this camera was the fact that you could make out the faces of everyone in the room, even the people at the far end of the table.I didn't use any of the software that came with the camera, so I can't speak about how good that is, but I was impressed with the camera's functionality in an environment that was surely way beyond its intended use.

This speaker was purchased to use with the Nexus 7 Tablet and Samsung Galaxy Nexus cell phone when the tablet or the phone are used for navigation. The built-in speakers in both devices produce very weak sound even at the maximum setting and cannot be heard well over the music when we are driving. This little speaker totally solved the problem.  The sound is excellent, we have the volume set at about 1/3 level and it is clear, crisp and loud.  It produces no distortions and the sound quality is good not only for voice but for music as well.I am attaching a collage of three photos under customer photos number 1 through 3 that I will be referencing in this review.1. Despite the large sound the speaker is quite small. Photo #2 shows it my hand.2. The speaker has a small loop at the top, which can be used in many ways to hang the speaker in the car: from the mirror, from the GPS mount, or as shown in picture #1 from the hook on the side of the car.  This puts the speaker next to the driver's head and making the sound a bit louder to the person who is driving.Photo #1 shows the loop clearly, photo #2 shows the speaker attached to the hook with two wire ties.3. To pair the speaker with the device you need to turn the speaker on, then scan for blue-tooth devices on the your tablet/phone, when the speaker is found, all you have to do is select it. That's it.Photo #3 shows Nexus 7 navigating while giving us instructions over the DBEST London mini speaker.o4. Works about 20 hours wireless (40 hours when plugged in)5. Comes with a USB cable for recharging, no AC recharging cable. We purchased a USB plug so the speaker can be recharged at home from an AC outlet.Small gotcha:After a stop in driving, even when the speaker is left on, when we resume driving the blue-tooth pairing does not happen automatically. Turning the speaker on and off does not fix the problem.  We need to use to re-scan blue-tooth devices on the Android device to get the speaker connected again. It feels like a problem with the Android OS (running JellyBean OS in our case) rather the speaker.  However, compared to the great sound, no wires, and convenient options for hanging this is a relatively small annoyance.This is the third speaker we auditioned for this job and we finally have a winner!  I highly recommend it.Ali Julia review
summary: Excellent performance with  with the Nexus 7 Tablet and Samsung Galaxy Nexus cell phone

reviewText: I ordered this product and upon arrival I discovered it was a 46mm filter when I ordered a 49mm filter. I immediately contacted Amazon about the situation. They apologized about the error and began to fix the problem. I had to pay out of pocket for a new filter, but was refunded full price including shipping and handling when Amazon sent UPS to picked the incorrect product(46mm filter). They then offered one day shipping for free on my new order. I just received it and I am very pleased with the customer service and how they handled everything. It arrived on time, packaged nicely, and clean filter. Now I am ready to go out and take pictures on the brightest days with my new filter.

This was my first filter purchase and I didn't want to spend a lot of money. Based on my limited experience with filters I am happy with this one. Having recently returned from a hiking trip in Utah I noticed a marked difference in the quality of my scenic landscape photos. Overall I'm happy with this filter.

If you're a kindle fire owner looking for a handy carrying case for it, you may want to think twice about this product. It is basically a protective pouch, not the handiest thing for every day protection of the kindle fire, but it is certainly a great item for packing the kindle fire safely in luggage. It is sturdy enough to withstand the jostling around that luggage gets.For those who pack their kindle fire in a suit case when traveling or transporting it, this product should fit the bill nicely. For every day use, I think it's too much of a pain to get the kindle fire in and out of the case.

Pros:- Excellent video quality - but to get the best quality, make sure it's either set to "HD quality" in 60p or in 60i, be in FX (Highest Quality 24 Mbps); when you first receive it, it's default is set to Standard HQ and only 9 Mbps.- Dedicated External headphone and microphone jacks! Yes!- You can turn off the recording lamp and can also continue recording even if you close the LCD (go to Menu->Setup then the wrench icon "Power On By LCD" to "Off")- Built-in Light- Built-in USB is very convenient- 32GB internal memory- 3" screen is "Xtra Fine LCD" is VERY clear; if you're shooting in HD, you want to be seeing it in HD when you're recording!- Peaking/Zebra mode to know what's in focus/contrast- Lens hood- I like that the swivel screen is smooth and doesn't seem flimsy; sometimes I like to tilt the screen while I'm shooting and adjust from going from high angle to low; with a flimsy screen, it would mess up the shot but it's smooth.- Good stabilizer- Smooth zooming- Automatic lens cover opens/closes fast- Sexy body/look black finishCons:- Why don't they include remote controls on cameras anymore? They used to be a standard.- Videos are great, but photos aren't the strongest point of this camera. Don't be fooled by the 20.4 MP. Also, it takes awhile to capture a photo. For still pictures, stick with a real still camera.- 5.1 surround sound just sounds like echo for me.The camera uses 30mm threads if you want to attach a wider lens on it.Unfortunately, you can't have everything in this model. You have to go higher if you want that nice manual focus dial to be able to manually focus easily. No nightvision on this model either.Of course what differentiates an expensive camera to a lower-end one is when it comes to low-lighting. This camera isn't going to perform miracles in low-lit areas - it's quality really shines in bright daylight - but that is to be expected for the price. With video cameras, you really get what you pay for. I used to work in camera sales and it's really surprising how people expect really detailed super picky HD quality from cameras that cost only a hundred dollars. What do you expect?You also can't go by buying a camera just because it's advertised as 1080 HD. There's a lot of crappy "HD cameras" out there that even video tape/standard definition recorders perform better. I've owned HD cameras around this price range in the past claiming 1080p quality, but the quality on this camera blows them away. It's definitely time to upgrade even if you have an older HD camera. The quality is night and day.This is a true HD camera for consumers.
summary: Fantastic Video Quality at its highest setting

reviewText: Does what it says it would do. Very compact, easy to use and and just works. Very light weight as well.Great product.

I am a part time professional photographer.  When I go on vacation, I don't want to carry all my expensive and heavy equipment.  I was looking for something that will allow me to get good vacations shots and not have to worry that there will be a problem with the pictures or the camera.I got this Sony for just that reason and I have put it through the paces to see how it performs.In general I would say it does a fine job.  Pictures are clear and useable for prints and Facebook and the same goes for the videos.I always turn off any digital or software zoom on the camera.  I figure Photoshop and Lightroom can do a better job than the camera's firmware.  With that said, the 30x zoom performs very well.One of the tests I did was to take some pictures of license plates of cars more than 100 feet away with the 30x zoom.  Not only was the license plate numbers clear, I could read the numbers (easily) on the registration stickers.  So while it wasn't as sharp and my expensive lens might have shot, for this kind of camera, I was pretty pleased.The videos were nice and clear and I could not detect and sound from the lens when zooming during the video.  Focus stayed locked on until I had zoomed to 30x on something only a foot away.  But I wouldn't expect to actually have worked.The thing I personally like the most is the live histogram.  You get this by turning on more information as a display option.  I think it actually works better as a light meter indicating what range of values you would get if you shoot the picture. Most cameras will give you a histogram of the shot after you take the photo.This camera has another interesting feature.  Both a view finder and a rear display.  It also senses when you are using the finder and turns off the display as to not draw your focus from the view finder.  This is a nice feature.There are a few things I don't like.  The camera "feels" cheap.  It is made of plastic and just feels like it will break if you drop it.  The automatic settings seem to choose high ISO values even in bright light. And one thing this camera doesn't do well is control the amount of noise in high ISO pictures.  However, there is a setting on the camera to reduce noise after taking the shot, but this adds about 2-3 seconds to each picture and unless you are in multi-picture mode, the camera is as slow as most point and shoot cameras.  I also wish there was a raw mode.There are a bazillion photo effects, but I never use any.  If I want to do that, I do it outside the camera.Though auto works okay, I would suggest shooting in P or M mode with the live histogram.  But no matter what mode you shoot in, you can take some very nice pictures and video with this camera.  Just don't drop it.

Overall, this is a terrific, feature-laden compact camera. I have a Sony HX9V also and this is a nice, although small upgrade. The still photo quality isn't that much improved from the previous HX9V even though the pixel count is now at 18.2MP(as a matter of fact, most of the time, you can hardly see any difference at all, esp. when you print the photos). The video portion (now w/AVCHD 2.0) now has 1080p at 60fps which is very nice and looks amazing on a big HDTV (24p recording is also available). One of the biggest improvements seems to be the increase in zoom range--now at 20X. You can also view 3D images on the lcd screen now (without 3D glasses) which is cool. Build quality seems to have gone down a little bit....when compared to the HX9V....it's lighter and there's no chrome or metal trim...making it look "cheaper" and less elegant. However, overall, I'd say this is probably one of the best compact cameras in the market right now. If you already have a HX9V, it might not be worth the money to upgrade (esp. if your priority is still photo capability). However, if you need longer zoom and better video, it should definately be worth checking it out.

I'm a longtime Panasonic camera guy.  I have a couple small pocket ones, and aPanasonic Lumix Super-zoom, and have been very happy with all of them.  Pitting them (mostly the higher end, super-zoom Panasonic) against this Sony seemed a little unfair, but I didn't mind the unfairness enough to let it stop me.First of all, the Panasonic has a quality lense that about 4 times the size of this one.  While I'm certainly not an expert in all things camera, I have noticed one thing:  given high quality lenses, the bigger one is usually better at something.  However, this little Sony, smaller, easier to carry around, and much more attractive takes AMAZING pictures, sometimes right on line with the Panasonic, but usually better.  Low-light conditions are equally amazing - no pixelation or blurriness.Another great thing about this little guy is that, from the time you press the power button to the time you press the shutter button, you can do it all in just about 2 seconds (maybe a tiny bit less.)  Granted, that's an unscientific test from me trying it out while watching the second hand tick, but really:  when you press power, the camera is ready to get down to business.However, depending on the picture (and I'm not just talking about the special effects like "illustration" that makes things look like comic books or panoramas, but even in Intelligent Auto mode), you might not be able to take rapid-fire pictures.  Case in point:  when shooting in low-light, the auto mode did everything for me and took a great picture, but after taking it (and before showing me what it took), there was "Processing..." on the screen for a couple seconds.  Whatever it's doing when processing makes the picture look great, but there is a lag between your next picture possibility.On the same token, while the video also looks great, regardless of battery power remaining or amount of memory remaining, the video is limited to 29 minutes.  While this means that I won't replace myKodak PlaySport (Zx3) HD Waterproof Pocket Video Camera (Black)for use as my dash-mount car-cam, it certainly isn't a deal killer.  Plus, the waterproofing means I can take this Sony anywhere that I'd otherwise have to take a Panasonic (great stills, video, but bulky AND the Kodak (bad stills, good video, waterproof) - overall, a huge win.One comment on the touch-screen:  I had a touch-screen Fuji camera that was a total failure.  The menu's were horrible, the touching barely worked, and the entire thing seemed like a fluke.  This Sony?  The menu's are very intuitive, the touching works *almost* everytime, and now going back to the dial and small arrow keys of the Panasonic seems like I'm going back in time.At the end of the day, this is now my "default" camera.  Very few negatives to speak of:  I had to buy a new microSD card, even though I have standard SD cards laying around; the zoom is somewhat difficult to engage because the knobs' position and size; it's one of the coolest looking cameras I've seen, so somebody is probably going to try to steal it; I now feel a little disloyal to Panasonic, after years of a friendly relationship...  but given the quality of Sony, I think I found a new loyalty.Highly recommended.  The photo modes are a novelty (make people look like comic book characters; take black and white pictures, but extract 1 color...black,white,and red, for example; watercolor, etc), but they are tremendously fun and depending on the picture, actually make the photo better than just the norm.**UPDATE, 8/25/2012**Down to 3 stars from 4.  Turns out, the video on this thing is absolutely horrible.  MyKodak PlaySport Waterproof Pocket Video Cameratakes much, MUCH better video.  The biggest problem with the Sony?  If you move, or your subject moves (as in, you know...motion), you get nasty horizontal line shifting in and out all over the place.  There's probably a technical term for it, but all-in-all, it makes the video feature pretty worthless if you want to show it to somebody else.  The second biggest problem with the video on this?  The color saturation.  It's just not there:  the Kodak has it (less than 100 bucks), and the Panasonic has it...this one does not.And now, after extensive usage from it, there are two other major faults, in addition to the video capabilities being horrible.  (1)  The overall quality of the still photos, in many scenarios, is actually far less than the previously mentioned Panasonic.  In some settings (plenty of ambient, but not direct light), it looks on par...in low light, it still does great.  But day to day pictures, Panasonic is far superior when it comes to image quality.  (2)  When I take a picture in "Intelligent Auto" mode or the other "Super Intelligent" or whatever, after each picture, it sits there with a "Processing..." screen.  It takes a LONG time to snap pictures rapidly.
summary: Incredible camera, but not quite perfect

reviewText: This is an excellent choice for a camera in this category providing a 10X optical zoom and a variety of useful shooting modes (low light performance is very impressive, so are the panorma sweep, soft skin and background de-focus).  It touts the ability to take 3D pictures and underwater capabilities (though I've not tested either). Compared to the pricierSony Cyber-shot DSC-TX66 18.2 MP Exmor R CMOS Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom and 3.3-inch OLED (White) (2012 Model), this one provides more zoom; however the pricier DSC-TX66 provides a touch-screen control (OLED display) and is much thinner and lighter.  The picture and video settings are almost identical for both cameras.  Just like other cameras in this family, the battery compartment doesn't inspire much confidence with its flimsy looks.Having used to the touch-screen controls of TX66, the scroll-based menu in the WX150 seems less impressive - however, the controls on both are very intuitive - given the wide range of options, it will take some time to get used to all the command settings.  The video quality of both cameras are exceptional - and either will replace a handycam easily.  If you are more interested in a lighter camera with a touch screen and willing to compromise on the zoom (5X opposed to 10X in the WX150) and pay up for it (about 100$ more), DSC-TX66 may be a better choice. But if the touchscreen is not a critical requirement for you and zoom is of more importance, WX150 is a very compelling choice at this price-point. The DSLR-like quality with a very respectable zoom, plethora of picture settings options, and fairly intuitive scroll-based menus makes this a good value.
summary: powerful, versatile camera  (and a comparison with Sony Cyber-shot DSC-TX66)

reviewText: I've had these earbuds for a few months now and thought I'd revise my review.My main gripe with these expensive but ultimately underwhelming earbuds is that they make a "thwomping" sound inside your ear drum whenever you jog or walk fast with them. I was at the gym recently and the sound of the earbuds jostling about in my ears was distracting. I don't recall ever having that problem with cheaper earbuds. This sound persisted even after I customized the buds to fit the shape of my ear.On the positive side, the sound is decent though the bass and treble weren't that impressive. Its most effective feature was the noise-cancelling feature, which effectively blocked out any other noise. It worked so well that I would never use these buds while driving, crossing traffic or walking alone home late at night. With the spate of iPhone robberies, it's better to be able to hear a stranger's footsteps behind you. It's perfect, however, when you're on a subway or a bus and you want to block out that annoying person next to you who insists on complaining about her day.The set includes a microphone for your iphone, which I don't use that much but works well enough - I heard my friend's voice on the other end of the line in very crisp, clear tones.What's convenient is that the buds work with even the oldest ipods around. From the classic 2009 model to the most up to date Nano. Sony was smart to do this - that means a lot of people, not just techies with the most up-to-date devices, can use this. As an example, a friend of mine still has a working iPod mini (don't laugh, he's a Luddite!) and we tested the headset on that too. Surprisingly, it worked! - though the volume controls did not work with such an old, outdated model.Another convenience is the location of the controls, which are located on a box located on the cord, which prevents you from having to reach all the way down to your iPod or iPhone to adjust the volume. My second favorite feature is the included clip, which allows me to wind up any slack on the cord and prevent it from getting tangled easily. In the past, I've killed so many earbuds because I pulled too hard on the cord by accident, so this is a welcome feature.This deluxe model includes a pouch that offers an array of different sized earbuds - one set is noise-cancelling, while the other isn't. This is overkill, though. I tried out different sets of buds but none of them fit just right. And the "thwoping" sound I mentioned earlier still remained.So I have mixed feelings about this product. The "thwomping" (sucking) sound is its biggest drawback for me, as the buds work best when you don't move around a lot.
summary: Revised Review - "Thwomping" Sound of Earbuds is Annoying

reviewText: So who is this tablet for?  It's for someone who needs and demands a full featured operating system but wants a tablet.  This is also for someone considering an Android or iPad but has the ability to purchase this much more expensive option.The Samsung Slate runs Windows 7 brilliantly.  The touch gestures, keyboard, everything work really well.  I didn't realize how easy it was to navigate Windows 7 with touch until using this.I've been waiting patiently a long time for a great Windows tablet.  I run a lot of Windows only programs and just prefer having the power and flexibility of a complete operating system with me.  With the SSD drive, 4GB memory, and i5 processor - there is no doubt that this Slate is FAST.I have a Samsung Series 9 notebook as well with similar specs and it's about the same in terms of speed.  It's just fast, boots fast, loads fast, moves fast.For extra space, you can easily pop in little Micro SD cards which are very cheap nowadays.  But I have found the 128GB drive to be perfectly adequate for my needs.This is a fantastic option if you need or want a full operating system in the palm of your hands.  No complaints here.
Noriced after about 2 weeks that wire to the computer plug was frayed, but still works fine. Because of the low price, a return was not worth my time.

So many 1 stars and I still bought it.  I disagree, 4 stars.  In my 2006 GMC Safari it works as expected.  But in my 2011 Honda Insight when I turn the key part way the blue light goes on, but the Acer A500 power switch blinks, not solid like in the Safari, and the charge indicator app doesn't show charge.  BUT when I turn the key all the way on the Acer A500 power switch goes solid, like in the Safari, and the charge indicator app DOES show charge.  And I waited until the power app added 1% to be sure it was really working.  4 stars cause of the short cable AND the unit does NOT fit into a standard 2 way power splitter.  I had to cut .25 inch off of the receptacle.  It fits fine in both cars, but not in the power splitter.One other complaint is that the power cable uses a standard USB cable on the car side.  A standard USB cable has 5 volts on it, but this cable has 12 volts on it, so do NOT use this cable on any other devices unless you know what you're doing.Regarding the short charging cable, I just tried it, and you can use a standard USB extension cable to get a longer charging cord.  I checked voltage at the Acer tip side for the +12volts before I plugged it in.
summary: Works in both cars I own

reviewText: From the moment I took the case out of the package it had a very strong scent of shoe polish, and it didn't go away even after using it for a few days. Beyond that I felt that the tablet is not tightly secured inside the case, sometimes the case slightly blocks the camera view and the power button is not very accessible. Sent it back to Amazon for a refund and will look for something else.

The card arrived today in retail packaging.  As advertised though, it does not come with a little plastic storage box or SD card adapter.  I inserted the card into a spare SD card adapter and installed into the card reader in my laptop.  Using ATTO Disk Benchmark (see additional uploaded picture), I tested the card's read/write speeds.  It appears to be a genuine Class 10 microSD card with consistent write speeds above 10 MB/s for all writes above 128 KB.  The read speeds are pretty amazing as well (generally 10-23 MB/s).I'm using it in my Samsung Galaxy Player WiFi 5.0 and so far it works very well.  This is my third Transcend flash purchase over the past several years and I have, thus far, never had any problems.

In a nut shell the price is not worth what you get. The camera and receiver both have a cheap feel and lets be honest, there is nothing fancy going on here. Defiantly not worth the $249!Pro:* simple function if you push call on the camera it will call the other end. On the other end the user must press talk to stop the ringing then press talk again when talkingCons:* pressing talk on receiver should activate camera ... why?a) what if I want to see what is going on at the front door? I should be able to press talk on the receiver and see the camera viewb) what if the guest presses the original door bell button as opposed to the camera call button therefore I have initiate the cameraAgain not worth $249. Save your money and keep looking. There are better products out there.Happy Shopping!
summary: high priced, cheap feel and lacking in fuctionality

reviewText: Misleading:  The description says that this product is perfect for utilizing external hard drives.  What it doesn't tell you is that the hard drive must have a seperate power source, so small hard drives that receive their power over the same USB cable DO NOT WORK on Galaxy Note 10.1.YOU CANNOT CHARGE THE GALAXY NOTE 10.1 AT THE SAME TIME YOU ARE ACESSING CONNECTED MEDIA (YOU CAN EITHER CHARGE OR USE YOUR SD, MICRO SD, OR THUMB DRIVE, BUT CANNOT DO BOTH TOGETHER).Despite these two inconveniences, overall a really great product, I have tested a 64gb thumb drive in the adapter connected to the Galaxy Note 10.1 and it worked fabulously.  This had made my life so much easier when traveling and wanting to use my tablet to watch movies.  I no longer have to store the movies internally on the Note 10.1I have tested the SD and micro SD ports, and both seem to work just find with SD HC (high capacity) cards.I stongly recommend this, I would rate a 5 had the description said the harddrive had to have seperate power and that the charging could not occur at the same time as accessing media.
summary: Description is not fully accurate and misleading

reviewText: Excelente tarjeta Madre para un PC de uso común.Usada don un Atlhon II X3 y funciona excelente.Buena compra.

5 stars for this lappy, of course it's not the best laptop in the world, nobody said it was, but if you wanna great brand with an i3 processor, 500gb hdd, and 4gbs ram get this little badboy, you'll be happy with the look, feel and performance.

I was looking for a good quality camcorder with external microphone support at a reasonable price to record live piano performances for my daughter.I found this factory refurbished Canon Vixia HF M301 in Amazon for less than half the price of a new one. It has a full year warranty and it works perfectly.One key feature I was looking for, is the possibility to connect an external microphone via hotshoe and I found that very few cameras in the $300 to $600 price range support that.I got both the camera and the compatible external DM-100 stereo directional microphone for less than $400 from Amazon and I am very happy with the results so far.
summary: The perfect camera for my needs

reviewText: This is a great cover for the Nexus 7 (the one made by Asus, not the Galaxy one).  It adds just enough bulk to it to make it easier to hold without too much extra weight.  It is still very comfortable to hold in your hand.  If you wrap the cover around the back it has a elastic strap you can put your hand through to hold it better.  It sits up nice on its own and the month that I've been using it hasn't shown any signs of weakness.  The stylus holder is a nice added touch.  Keeps me from loosing it.  The cover makes it easy to throw the Nexus into my jacket pocket and not worry about it getting scratched.  I think it's a great value and recommend it to anyone who wants a lightweight cover for their Nexus 7.

I love this case.Pros:1) The leather looks elegant. Doesn't feel cheap.2) Multi-angle stand is very useful for landscape mode.3) Clean cutouts for speaker. All buttons and ports are accessible with the cover on.4) Elastic hand strap is handy too.Cons:1) When using hand strap, wish it could hold the back cover of the tablet to avoid the tablet flipping out when using just one hand. However, there is a workaround. You could use the elastic band to hold it in place.2) Support for Portrait mode would be a huge plus. But, I guess it's not a big deal since I would use the stand mostly for watching videos which look good in landscape mode.Overall, a very good cover for the price. I highly recommend it.
summary: Couldn't ask for more at this price

reviewText: As a multimedia designer and light PC gamer I've been very happy with my core i5 and i7 desktop and work laptop, which both have 8 gigs of ram and powerful dedicated video cards, but I wanted a personal laptop (not company owned) that could still perform much of the same tasks, with a 17" screen, and not cost too much. After much research and shopping, I picked up my HP G7 laptop at Staples for the unheard of price of $399 after $50 rebate(president's day sale). I was a little concerned with it only having a core i-3 and shared graphics memory, but after loading it up with all the games and graphics software I'm very impressed with it's speed and overall responsiveness. This past week the motherboard on my $2.5k work laptop (unfortunately also an HP) died and I ended up using my new G7 for graphics and animation work with impressive results (considering this PC has much lower system specs). Heck, it even wakes up much faster than my more powerful PCs. Sure it kinda bogs down when editing a 300 dpi photoshop file and I have to run newer games with slightly lower graphics settings, but it still runs like a champ and has never frozen or gotten the BSOD.Cons: After careful calibration, the screen isn't as crisp and a bit washed out compared to my nicer PCs. The plastic casing feels cheap and flimsy. I was thinking that flexing it enough might snap the motherboard or internal components, but that helps make it inexpensive and fairly light weight for a 17" laptop. Wish it had an aluminum case, fingerprint scanner, bigger battery, separate video memory, blueray drive, higher rez screen, and USB 3.0, but given it's core specs and at $399, it's a freakin amazing deal and more than powerful enough for most PC users out there! Thanks HP and Staples. Even in the $500 range in March 2012 it's still a freakin good laptop for the price...

This is a great computer at a great price.  Sound quality is awesome with the beats audio, plenty of memory and CPU power to handle all my multitasking (Excel, Firefox, Chrome, Dropbox, PowerPoint, Photoshop all at the same time).  I like how you can assign different shortcuts or passwords for each finger on the finger swipe. I haven't tested the battery that much yet as I just got the laptop, but seems to last for a long time.I am glad I got it, and look forward to using it for a long time.
summary: Great computer at a Great price!

reviewText: I bought thisTenergy Advanced Universal Charger (TN190)because I needed a smart charger that can handle high-capacity rechargeable batteries. Previously I have been using my old Rayovac PS3 Universal Smart Battery Charger for charging C and D cells. But the PS3 can only charge up to 3000mAh in each session, whereas my newer batteries (such as theTenergy Centura C Size NiMH Batteries) are rated for 4000mAh or more.Electrically, the TN190 is a very good charger. Here are several aspects I like:- It is a true 'smart' charger in that it monitors the voltage profile of each cell individually, and stops charging as soon as a negative delta-voltage signal is detected. Most other products in this price range (such as theRayovac PS20PL Platinum Universal Battery Charger) are timer-based and can only charge in pairs.- The AC power adapter accepts 100-240V AC worldwide voltage. In contrast, my old Rayovac PS3 charger uses an AC transformer that is heavy, bulky and only works from 110V AC.- The charger itself accepts 12V input. So with the correct CLA (cigarette lighter adapter), it can even be powered from 12V car battery.- The charger has a very nice LCD panel, which shows you the charging status of all batteries at a glance.
