Of course it is not as informative as the digital display of myLa Crosse BC1000advanced charger, but for the average user it is easier to understand.- The USB output port can supply 5V 500mA to charge an USB device such as cell phone. Beware that this output is only available when NOT charging batteries. As soon as you put a battery in any slot, the USB port turns off. USB power will resume after the battery is fully charged.- The charger is smart enough to detect and reject alkaline batteries. It will also reject old NiMH cells with higher than expected internal resistance.- The charging current is 1.3A for AA, C and D cells. This gives a charge time of about 2 hours for AA, which is a good compromise between shorter charge time and longer battery lifespan. For higher-capacity C and D cells, the charge time increases proportional to the capacity.- For AAA cells the current is 500mA, so the charge time is again around 2 hours.- The DISCHARGE button is useful if you suspect some of your cells are not performing to spec. What it does is to discharge all cells at 400mA down to 0.9V, then recharge everyone back to full. By repeating this operation once or twice, you can usually improve the capacity.Now for the not-so-great part: I found the workmanship of this charger to be quite poor.- The LCD panel on my unit is mounted slightly slanted.- I was having difficulty with one battery holder, which cannot slide completely down to accept D cell. I had to remove the bottom of the case to make sure nothing was jammed inside. It worked fine after that, however.- While I had the case open, I noticed a lot of sloppy soldering job, with solder flux splattered all over the circuit board. I have to clean it up with alcohol, or else the flux will cause corrosion a few years down the road.Bottom Line:The TN190 is versatile and well-designed. Nowadays it is getting more and more difficult to find a smart charger that can handle individual AA cells, left alone one that can also handle high-capacity C and D cells. So despite the sloppy workmanship, I still consider the TN190 to be a very good value.[Update on Dec 15, 2012]I noticed an odd behavior for this charger today. I put in a set ofSanyo eneloop AAcells that were completely drained to nearly 0V (they were left in incandescent flashlight overnight). The charger display shows charging action initially, but then flashes all status bars after a few minutes. When I check the battery voltages with a multimeter (DT830B DMM), they were all around 0.95V! This could be part of the design to 'condition' over-discharged batteries. After I re-inserted the cells, they were then charged up correctly.[Update on Aug 26, 2013]I have tested theChargeIt! Battery Station Proand consider it a better product. It is similar to the TN190 in price, but offers several advantages. Namely:- Able to recharge ordinary alkaline cells- Two high-current USB ports (1A/2A) that do NOT turn off when batteries are inserted- Better workmanship.See my review on it for details.

I like the microfiber nib of the caseen stylii, and my only complaint about this one is that the cap on the ink pen is a little loose. It rattles ever so slightly and spins around while you are using the stylus, which can become a little tiresome. But as for the performance of the stylus, that's five stars. After trying stylii from literally dozens of manufacturers -- brushes, discs, rubber nibs etc -- the microfiber ones are my favorites by far, especially for artwork.
summary: The cap is a little loose

reviewText: Makes a cute toy, but airmouse and buttons are nearly useless in practice.  Can't click on mouse buttons without the cursor jumping off the item you are trying to click.  I threw it out within 30 minutes.  User manual is a joke, as others have noted.  Seems all these mini keyboards are just junky toys to be sold to the masses and then tossed.I went back to a real Logitech wireless keyboard & trackball after trying 3 different mini keyboards.  There's a reason they cost $25 a pop.  They all appear to be junk.
These batteries are working well.  I don't have any issue with them, they seem to do the job.  The battery charger is a plus!  I don't see any need to buy sony brand.

For the price it had better be! Really though, no hiccups in the set up, the GUI is really nice (thanks Asus for understanding we need better GUI's, your mobos are great too!). I hooked up my external HDD to this and it was instantly recognized in the network. Some of the settings are beyond me, but I chalk that up to me not being a network guru. I would recommend this to anyone right now!

Purchased on Amazon for the best price around. Installation initially didn't pick up and complete the firmware upgrade since my router shipped with the .90 version firmware. Do yourself a favor and download firmware update .112 as of 04/27/2012 to a thumbdrive. Take a laptop or desktop and plug into the router directly. Type 192.168.1.1 into your browser and get to the Asus router page. Then browse for your firmware update located on your thumbdrive. Open the file and it will upgrade the router automatically. The .112 version also upgrades the "check for firmware upgrade" function in the router GUI so this will no longer be a problem. Then set up your ssid and encryption passphrases as usual. Restart the router with all the changes and you will be up and running. Fully compatible and buffering free with my PS3 and Apple TV linked to my home theater Netgear Bridge also purchase at Amazon.Netgear Universal Dual Band WiFi Range Extender (WN2500RP)4 stars for the firmware inconvience. 5 stars for everything else. VERY fast router, great wireless range, and easy to configure once you install the firmware.Asus needs to get the upgraded firmware into their product faster.This is the most powerful N router out there right now.But it looks like Netgear just announced a new router with the a/c standard which will be 3 times faster than N wireless..............ASUS RT-N66U Dual-Band Wireless-N900 Gigabit Router
summary: Great dual band simultaneous N router

reviewText: My RT N56U went south, so I replaced it with the RT N66U.  Wireless range improved quite some distance.  Dead zones are no longer dead and get at least one bar of signal.  Basically it is the same as the RT N56U for me except for the range.  Throughput is just as good with either device for my applications.  Solid contender, have had to restart it twice over a few months now.  Overall good product.
This case was a perfect fit for the Archos tablet, but there was a problem with the build-quality of the tablet. The case was returned for a no-hassle refund.

I've gone through four golf GPS's in the past year and all of them were so bad that I just ended up getting a rangefinder. I was reading the reviews here and elsewhere about the new Approach G6 so I decided to give a gps one more shot.  Well, I am extremely satisfied!Pros- Easy to use.- Easy to see. I'm in my 50s and I have no problem seeing this device. In bright sunlight, the screen is extremely easy to view!- Battery life is excellent.  I played only 9 holes this evening and when I plugged in the G6 to charge it again when I got home, there was still 80% battery life remaining.- Distance measurements were right on the mark.- The size of the unit. It is small and it fit in my hand perfectly.Cons- Just one so far in only one round of use, but it took quite a while for the satellites to connect. I live fairly close to the course, so I'll just turn on the device at home before I leave and by the time I get to the course, it should be connected. Also, once it did connect, I never lost signal during the round. I recently tried the new Callaway MX+ and it shut off in the middle of the round.  I returned it to Amazon.Overall, the G6 was a pleasure to use.  It responded quickly and the scoring was easy as well.  I didn't read the manual and I was using it like I had it for months! I'm very happy with my purchase.  This one is a keeper!

I only had this camera for a few days. Had one major use for it and it was at the long end of the zoom. I felt my example just was not sharp enough at full zoom to satisfy my needs. (Yes, I used a tripod to test.. a very solid Bogen.) I confess, I had high expectations for my 800 bucks!If you are interested in the shorter focal lengths, especially wide angle, you may like the camera. Exposures and controls were all good and really wanted to like the camera but .. I couldn't. My Panasonic FZ35 is far better at its long end. Even the Panasonic EZ mode is sharper than the Fuji at full extension.What's the point of a long zoom camera if it's not sharp at the long end? I did not see the "orb" problem or lens flare mentioned in other reviews in any of my 250+ images.The Fuji build quality is a step above and feature set is extensive. Maybe this is a "teething" problem for Fuji and will be addressed quickly and easily. I hope so. It's obvious a lot of thought and careful manufacturing went into this camera. As a "flagship" camera they must have high expectations too.Bottom line is that no matter how "nice" a camera is, if it doesn't produce the kind of images you want and expect then it has to go back. Mine did.Maybe I got one that was not quite tuned properly. I'll wait and see and see how other buyers fare. I may try another in a few months if reviewers have more positive comments.If you need a good long zoom bridge camera I would start with the Panasonic FZ150 or perhaps wait for the latest 16MP Nikon P510 with a whopping 42X zoom. Both are substantially less cost than the Fuji.You might also consider a Nikon D3100. Price is less and it is more flexible. Buy a "body only" and the best lens you can afford that meets your needs.
summary: Not a Dream Come True For Me

reviewText: The adapter works good, has a micro card and a SD card slot. I achieved tranfer rates in a USB 3 slot and a class 10 SD card of >20 MB/s. Compared to the average 6 MB/s in a USB 2 adapter, quite nice. Even in a USB 2 slot, this card performed much better than the old USB 2 adapter and delivered an average of 14 MB/s.The only downside are the covers - they are very thin plastic and one side broke during first use (which is not a big deal, cause I will not use them anyhow).
summary: Works good, but is cheap thin plastic

reviewText: This lens is a work of art.  It focuses fast enough for most shots and is great in low light.  The colors it produces are vibrant and sharp.  I feel it is very quiet in operation and its uses are limitless.  I use it on my D7000 and it is match made in heaven.  I found it is sharpest at F/2.0 and up.  The bokeh is pleasing and appears smooth and creamy.  You must get used to it not having VR and you will have some blurry pictures when first using until you get used to it.  All in all, I am quite pleased.  BTW - I must comment on the packaging.  It was well packaged and shipping was fast.

As usual, Amazon has come through.  We needed a laptop for a young man going to college, and decided to use Amazon because they always come through.  The Toshiba Satellite C655D is the laptop my wife chose, and we thought it would be an in-expensive solution to a young college student with serious Internet needs.  This is the solution.

This is good basic router; an excellent value for most home networks.It is relatively easy to set up using either the manual method or the automated method that the included instructions recommend.  We've only been using it for a couple of days so far, but no dropping or intermittent connection issues for our 11 devices.  It is not dual-band, which isn't really an issue for us, and it does NOT have IPV6, which some descriptions indicated it did have.  That's not really a problem for most home networks at this point, but it could be a problem in the future if / when we run out of IPV4 addresses for stuff...  At ~$40, it's a solid, reliable option for a basic home router.The caveats:- The 'my dlink' service touted by dlink as a way to (remotely, if you prefer) manage your connections is not very robust.  The options to configure the router are minimal at best; the connections list is extremely slow to respond to requests to refresh it, and the 'blocking' capability requires that you know the MAC addresses of all the devices in your network- which might be easy for some people, but isn't very intuitive.  It identified one of our Android ereaders as a 'suspect' device and recommended blocking it with no other information except a MAC..  It seems to drop some connections from the displayed list of connected devices without explanation or reason, even though I've physically verified the devices are still connected to the network.The 'my dlink' service also allows you to connect remotely using an Android device...which seems to me to be inherently full of security problems that I'd personally prefer to avoid.- The speed of the router is just "OK".  It's fine for most networks in a smaller household, but it is nowhere near the specs listed on the box. Several organizations' testing has verified this.- You can't remove the dual antennas and add bigger/better ones to increase the gain; they are large and permanently fixed to the router (whatever happened to those nice 'screw on/off' connections?).Hope that helps!
summary: good basic router with some caveats

reviewText: We purchased this primarily for the wi-fi Netflix functionality, but also as an extra blu-ray player for the bedroom.  It was fantastically easy to set up, and it's been easy to use.  Plus, we purchased it for the low holiday price, so it was an exceptional value, too.  I don't know if we'll ever use the 3D functionality, but if we do it will be nice to have.  Very nice player for the price.

Previously had purchased one for our son in law as a gift.  This is the next generation to the one we had purchased as a gift.  Our son in law gave me a great recommendation for this.  So when we needed one, we of course bought the lastest generation.  Great price.  Couldn't find it cheaper at local stores or on line.  Great delivery.  Works great.

I had originally bought the cheapest Sony Blu-ray player S185, but I soon discovered that I really liked all of the streaming apps like Pandora, Netflix, Youtube, etc.  I was bothered that it didn't support wifi, but it was originally for our 5th wheel trailer where wifi is irrelevant.  I bought this one because it was only $5 more than the 390.  What I really liked is that it fully supported NTFS and a large 1.5TB external drive AND it plays VOB files from DVD's on the harddrive.  I have a PS3 in another room that also plays VOB files, but the PS3 gets loud and annoying after being on for a while.  The 590 is whisper quiet and loads really fast compared to the PS3.  I wish the PS3 would support the apps, but you have to go through the PS3 browser which is a pain.  I've been very happy with the 590.  I don't care about the 3D.  By the way, it plays all bluray disks I throw at it, and the upscaling is just as good as the PS3 upscaling for my DVD collection.  I like others were looking at the Panasonic, but I'm glad I didn't.  Being able to use the same remote on both players is a plus

If you buy this thinking you will get a navigation tool with waypoints, maps or other advanced features you would be disappointed. This is essentially a digital compass that remembers 3 points of interest. That's all it claims to be and that's all it does, but it does it well!I've had a number of GPS devices before and sometimes the time it takes to lock onto the GPS satellites takes forever, with this compass it locked on within 60 seconds of turning it on. I was able to figure out how to use it without the included instruction manual but did eventually break down and flipped through it to make sure I didn't miss anything.The cool part about this is it tells you what direction to go to get to the places you set. It doesn't navigate you via trails or roads, it is a as the bird flies navigation device. It points and you go, if you can't go where it points you go in the general direction and try to get back on course.The only downside to this is the backlight. It's a dark blue which I found hard to see. I would have liked it if they went with an orange or even white color backlight instead of blue. But that's a minor complaint.I like this compass, I'll be strapping it to the shoulder straps on my day pack and keeping this handy to find my way back to my car after a  long day of hiking.I can't say how long the batteries last. I will be carrying an extra set with me the first few times I use this just to make sure I don't have a battery issue half way back, but the compass has an auto off feature after 10 minutes which would help prevent battery drain.

I bought this for my father's new iPad 3. It fits and looks great.One con would be that the grooves the case uses to to the 180 stand are starting to wear out and the iPad is starting to slip out of them, causing the iPad to fall.That's under normal wear and tear I suppose.
summary: The case is nice fitting and good looking

reviewText: I have been through a number of 300 HS over the last year, namely because I vlog daily with it (video blog) and that takes a toll on these cameras. I took one in to be repaired and they sent me back the newly released 110 HS model since they had just discontinued the 300 HS.While the photo quality on the 110 HS seems to have taken a nice little bump up in improvement, the video has take a serious downturn as compared to the 300.The sound is just terrible. It picks up all hand movement on the camera, the zoom button sound, and it also seems to have trouble adjusting between far away and close in sounds. It sometimes sounds completely muted, like maybe wind noise reduction kicked on for some reason and then when someone talks close by you only hear muffled noise (and my hand is NOT over the mic). Its frankly horrible. I was seriously disappointed the other day in the mountains when we had elk communicating back in forth around us, they were quite loud (the equivalent of someone talking), and when I downloaded the video it picked up NADA. There was no wind, it was completely still, but nothing. I cannot even enhance the audio to pick it up.The auto focus while videoing I thought would be better as it seemed to pick things up quicker to focus on then the 300, but instead, it just adjusts constantly. So you can be sitting completely still and it will randomly focus on your face, then on the background, then back to your face again. So tired of thinking I got a shot only to find out halfway through it decided to focus on something else for awhile. So while the 300 HS had some delays in its focus time, I would take that any day over the random changes of the 110 HS.Lastly, the camera body quality has also taken a serious nose dive. While the 300 seemed sturdy and solid, the 110 feels cheap and flimsy. Hard to describe, but pick up both cameras and you will see.I may take the 110 HS in to see if the audio issues I am experiencing are a manufacture defect, but I do know for sure that the auto focus is an issue with these cameras in general based on other videos I have seen.
summary: Better photos, but video performance reduction over 300HS

reviewText: Canon Vixia HF R300 Full HD Flash Memory Camcorder with 51x Advanced ZoomI fully charged the battery that came with this camcorder and found that the battery last only 35min if you let it sit without using the zoom, have the camcorder set at the best quality and use the simple light setting on the screen.  If you can find another battery you better get another battery since my battery ran out without using the zoom. The best part about this camcorder is that you do not have too adjust for the different types of lighting since this is done automatically.  This is how any digital device should work, especially their high end cameras like the Canon 7D.  This camcorder did not come with the dual memory card slot as first advertised.  I brought this to the attention of Amazon and received a $50 credit that was put back onto my credit card.  Great job Amazon!  Amazon has since revised their advertisement to reflect the change in their description of the camcorder to show only one memory card slot.  I guess they were misinformed by Canon.  I will have to wait until the battery charges to find out more problems or benefits.  They need a car battery charger and a stronger batter with this unit.  Canon went cheap with the stock battery.  You can buy extended batteries at another expense, to you, that currently cost more than $100.

No problems at all with battery power or performance.  I applied a piece of cloth tape to them to create the same snug fit as the OEMs (I shoot motorsports and prefer not to have rattles on the audio feed).  Strong recommend- you get a lot for the money.

Setup was easy - Drive comes setup with RAID 0(both working together) I'll be using another drive as a TimeMachine Backup for the Lighting drive. Since with RAID 0 if something dies - you'll lose everything. WD software is easy to understand and installed with no problems.PROBLEM EXPERIENCED - MICRO-SEC INTERMITTEN VIDEO FLICKER WITH VIDEO PLAYBACKI have it connected to a MacBook Pro (Non -Retina display with a single Thunderbolt port) I have found that running an external monitor and this drive my video playback(H.264/MP4)  has a  micro-sec weird drop-frame like flicker. But its so fast that is tolerate-able. I think this problem is because I am using a single Thunderbolt port for my harddrive and daisy chain to an external LCD widescreen monitor (Cheap monitor $150 bucks) using a thunderbolt adapter to DVI. I notice this flicker on both the external monitor and my laptop LCD monitor.PROSSuper quietWorks out of the box (RAID 0)CONSI have heard that that the Green Drives inside are expensive to replace if not under warranty.No cable, but that is a feature of the Thunderbolt option hardware. I bought a long one.

Although it was even tinier than I expected, it was exactly what I was looking for. And when others say that it has a snug fit, believe them - at first I didn't think it was going to fit into the USB connector ... and then I had to get a really good hold on it to get it out. But all of that is good! The only thing I discovered that was wrong in its description was that it CAN be used with an older iMac running Mac OS 10.4. I was able to transfer a few gigabytes of data files onto it from my PowerPC iMac and then plug them directly into my Windows 7 laptop without any problem. The only surprise there was that when using a 16GB thumbdrive it takes several minutes to move all those gigs! But with 16GB capacity it doesn't fill up very fast. I didn't have to worry about having enough space.

Billed as a "fast, flexible workflow solution" Aftershot Pro begs comparison with the more expensive Adobe Lightroom.  Workflow solutions imply that a photographer has a "workflow".  As people idle in their hobbies or progress towards a more professional stance, these types of programs can come in handy... not only to learn what a workflow "means" but also how you might progress further than you thought possible.Truthfully, and as a matter of disclosure (and bias), this photographer uses Corel PaintShop Photo Pro X3 (and prior versions) and more recently photoFXlab more than just about any other photo programs.  More on what and why later...This photographer, as with many who take pictures for enjoyment and as a profession, simply wants the camera to be the window you look out of and into. What you see is what you want.  That translation with any given camera, lens set, filters, etc varies significantly. Add in what a person does with basic and more advanced hardware (camera) settings and the number of variables is nearly infinite.  This is difference between photos that are good and those that are great.  In the end, the majority of people want a simple way to quickly remove errors, improve quality, or add a flare of creativity.This is where workflow programs excel.Workflow allows you to do editing in a sequence that often results in the best photo possible.  These same programs have learning curves, especially for those that may not have ever picked up this type of program. In the same way, it is totally unrealistic for a review to provide a comprehensive view of anything more than what a given photographer generally uses on a regular basis.  These programs can be expansive, feature filled, and daunting.What do you normally do with your photos? If you do a single fix and move on, you may have no interest in workflow.  If you do a couple of things with every photo, or have a batch of photos that require the same fixes, "workflow" is definitely something you need. In fact, all photographers suffer from the "whole roll" ruined by some wrong setting.  The younger crowd probably is wondering what "whole roll" means, but that terminology is as fresh for digital as for "tape that show" in regards to DVR recordings. It is easy to ruin a batch of photos and workflow can fix that entire batch.AfterShot Pro has a similar feel to Lightroom, along with its similar feature set.  Files to the left, organizer and photos in the middle, and processing to the right.  It is easy to get started and figure out what a feature does, along with interactively making the change and reversing it if necessary.  AfterShot Pro is easy to use.  Lightroom has a more significant learning curve.  Again, you have to ask what you want to do.That same question answers what this reviewer does with photos.  For some, plug-ins is where the magic happens.  Good photos, bad photos... the proper plug-in can make your extensive skill shine, or cover up your lack of skill.  I want to sort through photos quickly and tweak them. That is my workflow. This is my fundamental problem with all paint and/or workflow programs--how many steps does it take?  What plug-ins are loaded in, how tweakable are they, and how accessible are the plug-in you may want to load from third parties? AfterShot (and Lightroom) do not have anything but standard none too exciting plug-ins. That leaves you with how easily you can access third party plug-ins.  AfterShot installs these plug-ins simply and provides them in the far right tab in the main workflow.  Processing speed on normal computers (with a discrete graphics card) is acceptable.  My go-to for tweakable plug-ins at the moment is Topaz Labs. AfterShot does provide an acceptable way to accomplish my workflow.It is obvious that this review is not going to delve into the details, and for the majority looking at this particular program, those details are unnecessary.  There are a lot of programs out there for workflow, general processing, and photo tweaks. People swear by the expensive ones like Lightroom. The major advantage of AfterShot Pro is its price vs feature set.  It is not "cheap", but it is very cost effective compared to the alternatives.... and it stands up to a Lightroom comparison.AfterShot is an excellent way for those interested in this type of program to learn more and progress in their craft.

This cpu was worth it, loading and speeds, no lag or any hickups, while multitasking.This cpu runs cool, Although it just might be my h100 with four Excalibur's running, but my idle temps are 26c at 20c/70F room temp (Although I have not oc'ed this processor, really I have no reason too.)Those who want a low budget, cpu to throw on your 3.0 board, so you can wait to utilize the new GPU's and get that extra gaming margin percentage when available, This is a must buy.And remember if you buy this, There is no Cpu cooler.. well most of you who research this much know this Good Luck :D, if you get a bad egg, you can always replace or return :D!
summary: i7-3820 Best Price Cpu on market!

reviewText: I have an eMachine DESKTOP, and a Toshiba LAPTOP.BE AWARE that they Both take 2 Different Sizes of CPUs.You must buy a Processor labeled for DESKTOPS for your DESKTOP, and LAPTOP for your LAPTOP.Desktop CPU Will Not Work in a LAPTOP !- You're Welcome.

My 9 year old loved everything about this bundle for her Ipod touch.  She frequently changes the cover to match whatever she is wearing that day.  Everything works as it should and much cheaper as kit vs. buying separately.

It has not given me one problem. It is fast and it seems to do everything my laptop does..."So Far" I downloaded a app to make the sound a little louder because the sound isn't really good, but neither is my Dell Laptop. I am pretty impressed with this. I purchased a All-winner from NMR and it was a piece of crap. In less than a week the adapter broke off in the tablet, The thing wouldn't ever turn back on, then the USB connector just fell apart. This was only 35.00 more and is well worth it. I both the case with the keyboard in it and it is like having a smaller laptop.  Also, unless your REALLY good at applying those screen protectors, buy the ones that come with 5 of them. I went through 2 before I got it right. I also bought a 16g SD-card. I haven't used it yet. It is really easy to set up and I am so glad I sent the other one back and got this one.

The Acer A200 overall is a good tablet. However, in working with Acer Support in trying to resolve a minor problem, I discovered something all potential Acer customers ought to know.Acer has officially announced they will not be upgrading the operating system on A100, A200 & A500 devices beyond Android 4.0.3 - Ice Cream Sandwich. There will be no Jelly Bean - Android 4.1 or Android 4.2 upgrade!The good things about this tablet are:1)Though not the fastest tablet on the market, nor does it have the highest video resolution - considering what I paid for it, (I bought it on sale for $225), it does a great job for the price.2) You can download and install apps from Google Play, the Amazon App Store, as well as other sites. Thus, there are literally thousands of apps in all categories one can utilize.3) The video is more than suffice to watch movies, TV shows, etc from Netflix, Amazon Instant Video, etc. in HD.4) You can connect a keyboard, mouse, or an external speaker via bluetooth.5) You can easily customize it - background photo, and app and widget layout - to your liking.6) This tablet is also good enough is serve as a backup for my desktop.The negatives are:1) No android upgrades will be available for this tablet beyond android version 4.0.3.2) After setting up the tablet to work with my bluetooth keyboard & mouse, now - even with bluetooth turned off - the tablet defaults to the physical keyboard, instead of the built-in one. Thus, after turning on the tablet, I have to manually set it to use the android keyboard.3) At random times and for no apparent reason, the tablet loses it WiFi connection. This can be easily fixed by turning WiFi off and turning it back on and reconnecting to your network. But, at least for me - it does seemed to be an unnecessary hassle that so far, Acer Customer Support has not been able to resolve without me sending them the tablet.4) And lastly - With all tablets running android 4.0.3 and newer, while you can store documents, music, photos, backup of your apps, etc. on an SD card, you cannot move an installed app from main memory to your SD card and run the app. Thus, your main memory is all you have for installing and running apps. This used to be a greatly memory saving feature in Android version 2.3.Considering the fact that most people upgrade whatever tablet they buy to a newer one about every two years anyway, I would recommend the Acer A200. Just don't be disappointed when you cannot download and/or install the latest/greatest version of Android on it.

As with the other reviewer, I bought mine yesterday at Costco for $179. The costco bundle includes a 4 gig class 6 sd card and a carry case.I have only had a couple of hours with it but I think it is a good value. Depends on what you want it for of course.I changed my old Kodak 850, a similar priced/featured camera because it was giving some issues and the newer cameras offer some terrific technology upgrades. (And I am a Kodak retiree......when I was working Fuji was the enemy!)I specifically wanted a better zoom, with image stabilization. (I have an old man's tremor.) We spend some time in Hawaii during whale season. You really need high zoom if a lot of your whale watching is from shore. We also want Bald Eagle pictures when they land is some trees 200 yds from our house.Another "nice" feature for my usage is the option of iso 6400. Also handy is the 1/2000 fastest shutter speed.Several relatives have dslr's but I wanted the zoom without the bulk, and without the expense.I have done some experiments with the 30x zoom. I found I could take sharp daylight pictures at 30x zoom (the equivalent of 500mm focal length) by using the 6400 setting and 1/2000 shutter speed, using shutter priority. I handheld the camera for these. I judged sharpness subjectively on my computer, from the pictures of bare twigs high in trees.The only problem I experienced is that at such high zoom even the slightest movement can take you off your intended subject, same as with a telescope. So in the future I think I will use my walking stick, which has an optional male screw mount and the stick can become a unipod. And of course one can always use a tripod.There is a "digital" and "optical[default]" zoom selection in the menu. I tried both and the sound seemed similar. I was assuming the digital zoom would lose sharpness in telephoto. It did not seem to do so, as viewed on my computer screen.A feature I like is the fuji-unique "f" button. Without going into the menu you can change iso and several other settings, in many of the shooting modes.Some caveats: The largest lens aperture is f3.1 in wide angle and f5.6 in telephoto mode. If you want to take really neat blurred background photos portraits this may not be large enough (to reduce the focus range).another caveat; file size. With my old Kodak I was happy with the 2.1mp (mega pixel)setting. That setting resulted in file sizes in the 3/4 MB range. I have gotten good enlargements up to and sometimes including 8x10 with that mp setting, and that is all I need, so why take up more memory? With the 4500, you only get to choose Large, Medium, and Small for mp settings. On the small settings I am getting file sizes in same 3/4 MB range, maybe slightly larger but certainly under 1 MB.Another caveat: Zoom motor noise in video mode. I like to take a lot of video, editing them into dvds after major family get-togethers. There is some zoom motor noise with the 4500. the good news is that the experiment I did had no voice narration other than my comments. The verbal narrative seems to be much higher level than the motor noise so I do not think this is going to be a significant drawback.

Verso's Prologue cover is a beautiful accessory for your Kindle.  I used mine with my new Paperwhite, and the case fits perfectly. In fact, but a few significant details, I would prefer this case over the Amazon standard case.  That said, if you enjoy changing out our case, or if you like to use your kindle outside of the case, then this case is better than the standard.PROS:+A small pocket inside the case is great note cards, business cards, or a small piece of paper+Leather covers are beautiful with an old-world inspired design+Soft leather insides protect the Kindle and prevent scratches.+Stitching looks luxurious and gives the case an appearance of quality+Elastic bands hold the Kindle snugly, but also allow for easy access. I enjoy putting a new case on my kindle to fit my mood.CONs-As much as I loved the elastic bands, over time elastic bands may leave marks on kindle, and the elastic may wear out.-And the biggest shortcoming for me was that there is no magnet to hold the case closed (or strap or band or snap or anything)
summary: New Cover for Your New Kindle

reviewText: I purchased a Photive Original LP-E6 Ultra High capacity Li-on battery for my new Canon 60D. I knew I'd need more than the original battery but didn't want to pay what the dealer was asking for a typical Canon replacement. I found this battery online and decided to purchase one. Glad I did because the performance is every bit as good as the Canon brand at a fraction of the price.Charging is fast and efficient, in fact, can't tell the difference between this model; and the high-priced one.

In my humble opinion, this is one of the best value for your money TVs on the market.  The picture quality is excellent.  It's very lightweight and low profile (I have it mounted on the wall).  I also own the earlier version of this TV (in another room) and I can tell you that this new version has a better user interface.  The only thing I don't like is that my old TV came with both the standard remote and the motion wand.  This new TV only has the motion wand.  Having said that, it's worth noting that the wand is great.  It's a very good way to interact with the TV.There's no question that 'smart' TVs are going to be the future.  But they are still in their infancy.  The user interface is pretty good, considering, but navigating to a website (for example) is a torturous process.  There are still times when a keyboard is the way to go.The 3D is very nice, but don't expect much from the 3D converter hardware.  It kinda sucks.  3D Blu-Rays look great, though.I don't love Tru-motion so I turned it off.All in all, this in an incredible value.
summary: Excellent option if price is a factor in your decision

reviewText: I went with this LG 47LM6200 47-Inch Cinema 3D 1080p 120Hz LED-LCD HDTV with Smart TV and Six Pairs of 3D Glasses to replace my Samsung PN50C680 50-Inch 1080p Plasma 3D HDTV which I acidentally cracked the screen on.. As good as that tv was, I have to say this one blows it away.. I've always loved Samsung tv's an this is my first LG, but I couldn't be more satisfied. For one the features and contrast ratio (6,000,0000:1) are a lot better and more advanced. The different picture and sound features once configurated will bring the best out if this HDTV. I actually have the tv connected to my Directv receiver, Sony 7.1 receiver, and Yamaha speakers. The AV Sync mode the tv offered helped out a whole lot to sync picture with audio, considering I'm using an external audio mode. The only flaw I've noticed is the slight audio/image delay caused by the fact the receiver puts out dolby digital audio and me not having digital optical cables from tv to audio receiver directly. I have digital optical cables from Sony audio receiver to Directv receiver, and from Sony audio receiver to PS3 but not directly to tv. Everything connected via HDMI picture wise, but I am going to have to get digital optical cables so they go directly from tv to Sony audio receiver. I was told this will stop slight audio/picture sync issue.. The passive 3D is pretty badass and a lot more in depth than the 3D I got from my Samsung Plasma with active glasses. Definitely a cinema feel to the 3D. The only flaw once again was the 3D channels on Directv, especifically ESPN 3D, show the audio/picture sync issue I mentioned about earlier because of cable configuration. Smartv apps are cool but I haven't tried them much. I rather watch Netflix directly through my PS3 but Youtube and Skype included in Apps for tv is cool to have. Haven't tried all the apps content but will review when I do. Last thing I'd like to mention is the Trumotion feature this LG HDTV offers. It definitely makes a difference watching Football games (or other sports), Bluray movies, and Pixar/Dreamworks animated films! For that type of viewing leave Picture TruMotion feature at Smooth, clear, or User. You can make your discretion to see which one looks best. For regular HD programming and HBO movies and such leave Trumotion off as having it on gives off a Soap opera/play like look to movies and programs.. By the way this tv is Trumotion at 120HZ and the different Picture Trumotion options show that. The 60Hz you see in the tv info when watching programs is the source of your satellite or cable provider.. Even Blurays come at 24Hz but this Tv does give you Trumotion option features up to 120HZ. Apologize for the long review, but truth is this HDTV is badass and has a lot of features to touch base on for review.Update August 18,2012:As I had figured it would be the case, I was able to completely sync the audio/picture issues perfectly by connecting optical digital cables from the Sony audio receiver to the tv! Even the 3D Directv channels specifically ESPN are synced perfectly. Makes this tv even more enjoyable now. At $899 hard to beat and I am almost certain it's up there quality, feature, and picture wise with other HDTV's a lot more costly.
summary: Best HDTV I've owned to this day period!

reviewText: LG has the best looking TV's. I love the 2D and 3D features. It looks like I am standing right next to and walking alongside the people on TV. The magic wand remote control takes a little getting used to but it is so cool once you get the hang of it. I highly recommend this LG TV or anything LG.

We could not be more pleased with our purchase.  And the price was FANTASTIC value.  Far better that even the largest on-site retail discount stores.  Of course, the LG name, itself, means superior product and customer long-term satisfaction.  Further, the TV has all of the features we wanted, and it works FLAWLESSLY!  Purchase without anxiety.

Yep, you read the title right.  We ditched the cable and satellite money grabbers a while back and have never looked back.  All our local channels come to us via the free over-the-air (OTA).  And I have to say, the OTA signal is fantastic and the picture quality is just as crisp as what cable was offering.  The best part is, I get to see a touchdown a solid 5 to 10 seconds well ahead of my cable user counterparts as they wait for their signal to be routed to their device.So back to the TV.  Without 3D channels why in the world would I purchase this?  Simple.  The 2D upconvert I saw at the store was awesome and watching 3D movies and as a bonus, I get everything on a 55" LED 240hz screen that will suck you into whatever you are watching...or playing for that matter.  That's right, I also use this for my Xbox 360 and if you play Gears of War 3 in 3D...you won't ever want to go back to normal gaming.All in all, this set is a huge improvement over my 46" LCD which was showing no signs of wear after 3 years, but to get this TV, along with a 3D blu-ray player and 12 pairs of glasses...that's right, 12 pairs of glasses for $1500 was a no brainer.  Not to mention my local big box store happened to be running a 3 year no interest financing package on anything over $999 so bingo!Now for the 2D to 3D upconvert.  Here is what I've noticed, it is not the cinematic 3D you get while watching movies or shows that were specifically shot in 3D.  What it does is have the 3D going into the TV (if that makes sense) so the depth is more inward than outward...but still crazy.  I've tried settings inside the TV (as there are many:  3D depth, 3D field) and no setting really gets the picture to jump out at you.  At the most extreme settings, the picture is a little difficult for my eyes and brain to make into one since the double image trick is so far apart.  When you watch a 3D blu-ray, the double image is just barely there to produce the 3D.  How do they do it you ask?  I think I've figured it out.  The TV upconverts every image it sees to 3D.  While in the blu-rays I've seen so far, only certain things are coded 3D for the glasses to work on.  So the TV isn't smart enough (yet) to know when you're watching football, don't code the field, lines in 3D but do code the players so that "pop out" effect works.The remote is nothing more than a WII remote from Nintendo for those that are looking for a comparison.  It takes a little getting used to, but once you've found the sweet spot, it's pretty basic.  I love how I can be watching TV and turn on the Xbox, then a popup comes on and says, new video source detected, would you like to switch?  Click yes, and I'm playing the Xbox.I would make this purchase again in a heartbeat.  The fact that it is a smart tv which allows me to surf the web, share music, pictures over my network is also a plus.The best part was with all of the money I've saved not paying Comcast awhile back, that savings unknowingly allowed me to purchase this TV.
summary: Even without cable or satellite, this tv is amazing!

reviewText: It's a bit to get through the set up, but once you do, it's great. It's a lot of fun.

I bought this specifically to use as a baby monitor, so if that's not your intention for it, you don't need to read further.I spent a lot of time researching baby monitors when I started to come across wireless network cameras.  Brilliant!  The idea of being able to view from my computer/smartphone/iPad was appealing since one of these things is usually near.  That means I don't have to carry around a video monitor unit that I have to worry about being charged or losing or whatever.  Plus, it means my husband can spy on the baby from work, too :)The Foscam seemed to have pretty good reviews overall, so we decided to give it a shot.  The price far beats some of the top-rated video baby monitors and offers viewing flexibility that a technologically savvy family can appreciate.Without further adieu, here's my quick break-down:Pros:- Love the ability to view baby from multiple devices.  There are several options for apps on both IOS and Android for viewing on this camera.- Infrared works GREAT.  I can get clear views of my daughter from her nearly-pitch-black bedroom.- Infrared lights are very dim and not too distracting (though I don't have experience with other infrared lights...just saying that they're not super-bright or an issue in a baby's room)- Totally silent adjusting.  Yes, this camera is all ninja when you're panning around the room.  The only times it makes noises is when the infrared goes on/off, it makes a quiet clicking sound.  Otherwise, it's quiet enough to give you the confidence that it will NOT wake a baby when you adjust it.- Wireless feature allows for you to use without being hooked up to a computer--something a regular webcam cannot deliver in this situation.Cons:- Set up (as many have mentioned) can be a PAIN.  If you are not familiar with tinkering with your router settings and all that, I'd say get help from someone who does.  I consider myself to be intermediate with technology, and when following the instruction manual, I got frustrated.  My husband finished the job quickly.  Though, when we got a new internet service provider, he had a more difficult time when a new modem/router came into play and it took him quite a while longer to get that figured out.- It's big and ugly.  I can't lie, it's not the prettiest thing to have in your baby's room and certainly much bulkier and less aesthetically pleasing than a lot of baby video cameras...but you sacrifice beauty for functionality.  You'll soon forget about that when you're giggling at your ridiculous baby's antics in clear view.- I'm not sure why, but we have issues with it regularly resetting.  (You know this because when it resets, it runs through a series of panning around and will finally stop at a pre-designated position which is always pointing away from the baby's crib).  Sometimes this happens multiple times a day, sometimes we go days without it happening.  I'm not sure if the camera is to blame or if it's my ISP/modem/router.
summary: Spy on the baby?  Yes, please!

reviewText: As the subject stated, when the IR-Cut filter is "activated", there is a clicking noise that is QUITE LOUD. I am watching TV and I can still hear the clicking sound.I connected to the camera via Firefox browser on my laptop and left it on while watching TV. I noticed that the clicking sound comes out when the camera try to set the "brightness" of the picture, evidence of the camera trying to get its IR-Cut filter to work.This is a major flaw design, because this camera become useless as security cameras and baby monitor, due to the loud clicking sound.
summary: Clicking noise when IR-Cut is ON

reviewText: The sound quality of this unit is excellent. I bought a 32GB memory chip and have loaded about 50 albums (all WAV files) and they have played flawlessly.  Voice recording is also excellent.  I have also bought a noise-masking microphone.
summary: An excellent recorder for the price.

reviewText: I'm using this device to record lectures and round-table discussions. I'm surprised at how much I like this. The sound quality is surprisingly good. When I took it out of the box, it felt a little flimsy, but it works like a champ. It's easy to operate after you reference the user guide. It has different folders, so you can save lecture recordings for different classes in their own folder. The only downside is that there doesn't appear to be a rewind or fast-forward option. So you have to start the recording over when you want to rewind or keep listening instead of fast-forwarding. However, you can easily download the recordings to your computer and use your audio program (Quicktime, Windows Media Player, etc.) to rewind/fast-forward. The recorder comes with a soft carrying case and a USB cable for download. I highly recommend this recorder.
summary: Surprised at how much I like this!

reviewText: I have an older (2005) Compaq Presario SR1610NX running XP that I wanted to connect to our home wireless system without much trouble or cost and this worked perfectly.  It installed in 5 minutes without a single glitch, and I was immediately able to connect up to my network with a 99% signal strength.  Web browsing is amazingly fast using it - no problems at all. Installation instructions were clear, easy to follow, and accurate.  And all for $10.  What a deal - wish every product lived up to my expectations like this one :-)Update 7 Dec:  Thought I'd try this on a (2009) HP Pavilion p6228p-b AMD quad core running Win 7 64 bit and once again the installation and operation were simple and flawless.  I recommend this highly.
summary: Works like a Charm on XP and Win 7 64 bit

reviewText: This little gem sounds amazing. It produces realistic, rich, vibrant, unboxed sound -- for under $200! Vocals sound especially real. It's unique design makes it fun to look at too. Congratulations and thanks to the inventors for making true audiophile sound affordable.

***This is a follow up to my initial review.  Still amazed at the sound especially now that I've had a chance to break it in for hundreds of hours.  The new model works perfectly and is not flawed like the first unit that was returned and replaced with another a3.I did add some Audioquest Golden Gate Interconnects this time around and that made just enough improvement to the muddy base (tightened up the bass just enough ) on some recordings to add another half star to the review rating.  If it had more power and more outputs I'd give it a 5 star rating.  I'm sure a more expensive interconnect would tighten up the bass even more on the bad recordings but at least now the muddiness is gone and won't overwhelm the rest of the recording.***ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOWHooked this up to a pair of Mirage OM 10 speakers with AudioQuest Type 4 cable.  CD Player is a Cambridge Audio D300 SE.Replaced the stock tubes out of the box with JAN GE NOS 5670 model.  Later after a burn in period of about 20 hours of operation, I replaced these with the stock tubes.  I observed the following.  Stock tubes have a nice sound but with less enhanced bass and a slightly brighter mid range and highs.  Definitely a bit of improvement over the sound I had previously when using my Cambridge Audio A 300 integrated amp.  Overall a slightly smoother sound with the A3.I noticed a clear improvement though when I used the GE 5670 tubes.  Initially the bass was pretty boomy on some songs but that cleared up after about ten hours of playing music.  The audio had a very mellow sound and the bass was much improved over the stock tubes.  Mid range and highs were smoother and individual instruments were easier to pick out in most songs.  The clarity of the music also improved and previously hidden details with certain instruments started to emerge with these tubes in place.I used a variety of music during the the 20 hour break in period.  Classical was the least improved music over the Cambridge Audio amp.  It became slightly smoother but not overwhelmingly so.  Noticeable improvement was heard to older rock, R&B; and Soul recordings especially those from the 60's and early 70's.  It was a night and day difference.  Bass became much tighter, instruments were more detailed and exhibited certain sounds that previously were muddled or not heard at all.  It was as if the recordings had been remastered or re recorded at a later time in the studio.  I also noticed a great improvement to most Jazz recordings as well.  Used Smooth and Contemporary Jazz recordings from the 70's through the late 90's.  Almost as much improvement as with the older rock recordings but not quite as dramatic.I think I would have seen even more improvement over the older amp if I had a different set of speakers.  I purposely bought the Mirage OM 10's in 1999 because they were well known for having a mellow sound.  They have a 90 db sensitivity which is ample to drive this amp.  My previous speakers were Klipsch Heresy's and I am certain if I still had those, the sonic improvement would have been dramatic to say the least.  They had a harsh sound that resulted in listening fatigue after a couple of hours of use.  But since tube type amps are known for creating a more silky, smooth sound and I did not pair this amp with more harsh sounding speakers I did not see quite as much improvement as might be expected with more traditional box speakers.  I also have a pair of Castle Conway 3 speakers in storage and those being a more traditional box speaker might very well show more improvement to the audio once I can pair them with the A3.  Still, the improvement is noticeable with the OM10's and worth the $199.00 price tag.The negative.  One channel started to cut out on some songs that had heavier bass when I moved the audio playback level to around a quarter length turn on the A3.  I tried swapping cables and also switched the cables to the other channel but to no avail.  Even trying the 1/8" mini plug did not help.  Audio at a low playing level was fine but at a moderate level the problem started.  Never tried a high volume level.  This was a defective unit that will be returned but I plan to replace it with another A3 and will hope it is free from defects.Overall I am very pleased with the sound and it seems evident you could spend ten times as much money for a solid state amp that still won't offer the same kind of sound that you get from a tube type amp.  Even one that is integrated with a solid state amp like the A3.  If you want a mellow, silky sound to your music then this amp will not disappoint you.  This component offered the biggest improvement the sound of my system since I replaced the Heresy speakers with the OM 10's.  Arguably the improvement created by the A3 even exceeds that level of quality realized with the change in speakers.After I receive the new amp and have a chance to break it in even longer I will follow up this review with another.

First of all, headphone amp performance is highly dependent upon the headphones in use.  No amp review is complete without stating what headphones you listen with.  I use Grado SR80.  These are 32 ohm headphones, which makes them easy to drive with just about any source device.I listened to a variety of mp3 and FLAC music (rock, electronic, acoustic, jazz) through foobar with all effects and EQ turned off.  For comparison, I switched back and forth between the E17 and the default soundcard in a Dell desktop machine.  Oddly enough, the Dell soundcard is my benchmark - in previous comparisons I found no difference at all between the Dell and a Nuforce UDAC-2, and the Dell is much better than a Creative X-Fi USB DAC/amp I bought on the cheap.  Having been unimpressed with other headphone amps I've tried, what I really wanted to get was the highly regarded, open source design Objective Desktop Amp (ODA), but this would have cost nearly three times as much as the E17 and lacks many of the E17's useful features and inputs.Differences in sound between the E17 and the Dell are minimal.  My first impression was that the E17 was a bit warmer and a bit more veiled than the Dell, but more careful volume matching between the two devices eliminated that perceived difference.  After listening to quite a lot of music on both devices, I can't decisively say that I hear any difference between the two.  That's certainly not to say that the E17 isn't good, but unless there are noticeable problems with your current sound setup, the E17 might not make any audible improvement.Nonetheless, I'm planning to keep the E17.  It will replace the inferior Creative X-Fi as my home headphone amp, and I also plan to use its SPDIF inputs to listen to audio from my PS3, DVD player, and CD player.  That kind of versatility is hard to beat at this price.  I also tried connecting it to my Sansa Clip+ player (Sansa headphone out to E17 AUX in) but get no sound at all through the headphones.  I know that this hookup is not ideal because the sound is amplified by both devices, but I'm not sure why there is no sound at all; I might need to test with another device to make sure the AUX input is not defective.As a final note, I'm sure some people will assume my ears just don't work right since I didn't hear differences between the E17 and a stock soundcard.  I don't claim to have golden ears, but I know what well-recorded and well-reproduced music should sound like, and I do my best to eliminate as many sources of bias as possible when listening.  Plenty of research literature exists showing that people are not nearly as sensitive to different audio components as they believe they are, so it's important to take all hype and fawning reviews with a grain of salt.UPDATE: The AUX input does work with my Sansa Clip+ player.  To my surprise, at a given volume on the Clip+, my headphones sound louder directly through the Clip+ than when played via the E17.  In any case, sound quality using the setup is good, but I'll have to do more detailed comparisons to see if there's any sound quality benefit to the Clip+ and E17 combo.

I've been waiting to replace my trusty eeepc 1005HA for a while now, and while looking for another ASUS netbook with a 12 inch screen, all of a sudden Amazon offers this a 13-inch model for very little more than I paid for the 10-inch netbook almost 4 years ago. To be honest, I was expecting to be disappointed because the 1005HA has been so dependable and functional. But the U32U-ES21 is such an enormous improvement that it is really in a class by itself. I am still getting used to it and especially to Windows 7, but here are my first impressions:- the screen angle issue is real, and obvious when compared to the excellent (matte!) LCD screen in the eeepc, but not a huge problem. Maximum brightness is about the same. The view angle might have to do with the U32U screen being LED-backlit, which probably saves battery drain. The much higher resolution and of course the extra "real estate" more than makes up for this, and blacks are richer too.- It's a joy to have the additional keyboard size and especially a more conventional layout of the right side keys. The keys are a bit on the stiff side but I am making far fewer typing mistakes. (The eeepc also had some repeated key problems that I am happy to find absent now). My eeepc had a black-on-white keyboard, which is easier to see in dim light than the new one, but that's only an issue for hunt-and-peck typists in darkened bedrooms, like me.- Fan is much, much quieter and the unit runs cooler than the eeepc!- Windows7 is a great advance over the familiar and reliable but now clunky XP. The 4GB standard RAM seems to handle it fine.- I've had no wi-fi problems at all so far, although I get different strength indications with the 2 laptops side by side.- I have not put them on scales yet, but it is about the same weight as the eeepc with an oversize battery.- Video playback is perfect at full screen, but I have not tried and HD yet.- The Caps Lock and Num Lock lights are very welcome features, avoiding errors and/or the need to install an on-screen program.One star down from perfect because of the stiff keyboard and screen issues, and the truly TERRIBLE Asus website, but really quite an amazing value.  Yes, I have to add that I have never even succeeded in registering my computer, getting access to their cloud storage, or even finding a list of models, on their website. I can only hope that I'll never need any type of real assistance. (Their webpage for driver downloads can't even recognize the model computer - I had to get drivers from other sites!  Boooo ASUS)Six weeks later:  I'm noticing how flexy the keyboard is, but it doesn't matter to me. More worrying is that I had to reinstall the keypad driver a couple of times before I got the 2-finger scrolling feature to work right, and also the default settings have to be changed for it to work right. (Forget about the "Scrybe" junk). And if you switch between a mouse and the trackpad you will find a little program called Change Mouse Speed very useful.To compensate for a slowish AMD CPU I installed another 4 Gb of RAM ($25), and disabled most of the Win7 screen animations. Now I am more than satisfied with the snappy performance, including HD videos (I'm not a gamer). I have rigged all my peripherals into a sort of quick docking station when I am not on the road - mouse, backlit keyboard, big monitor, backup HD. I have some issues with how Win7 handles its "Libraries", and can't for the life of me understand why ASUS makes the "OS" drive partition (C:) the default for data rather than the "Data" partition "D".Maybe that is why the Mac Airbook is so popular - it's not a do-it-yourself project like ASUS always seems to be.Now if Amazon would only quit changing the price every week it will be a great little laptop for about $400.
summary: Giant step up from eeepc, pretty nice laptop!

reviewText: I work outdoor and this is perfect for me. The solar charging is awesome because I can leave it in my work truck (NO radio and AC) to charge and use it during break and lunch time. The solar really charges the battery unlike the eton I had before. All the other feature will be useful when I needed. Love it and use it everyday at work.Pro:- All the details listed by manufacturerCon:- Could use some Radio Preset

Received the my TV yesterday, set-up was fast and easy. I read through all the reviews here and made some display settings they recommended, made a huge difference. Out of the box the picture was dark but after the setting changes the picture really popped!If this is your first HDTV and you are using cable or Dish, check your box settings, I have uVerse and my uVerse box was not set for HDTV output, changed one setting and it improved my TV viewing immediately.The exact model number I received was: UN32EH5000FXZAThe version# was TS01  (Samsung made panel)

As HDTV sets are growing in size and dropping in price this Samsung TV is a real steal. The angle at which you view this TV isn't much of an issue at all. I've stood across the room, low to the ground and to the far sides of the TV and the quality did not diminish nor did the color.It features 2 HDMI ports, composite cable input as well as a usb port.The bottom right directional button for using the TV's menu and turning it on without a remote is a different an fun feature.This TV was really easy to put together and the stand has been very stable. In less than 5 minutes I had this TV out of the box, stand screwed in and into my wall unit connected to my cable. The color and size are perfect for almost any modern.One notable part of this TV that I very much enjoy is the volume. At just 7 the volume is quite loud and great for watching alone if you don't have a surround sound system set up in your home. At 15-20 I can hear it over people making a large amount of noise whether it be construction upstairs from my home or people cooking and chatting sitting right next to me while I watch.This TV is fantastic for home entertainment for a family of any size and very affordable for it's large size.
summary: This HDTV was a fantastic buy. Low price + High quality

reviewText: I purchased this adapter since so many new laptops are not shipping with the old standard Serial port (DB9). I do a lot of Cisco router and switch configuration work, and a serial port is needed for the console cable.My only struggle was finding the correct Windows 7 driver. I use x64 Enterprise and the driver that came with the adapter didn't seem to work. My Win 7 didn't find the correct driver either.No problem. Simply Google this make/model and go to the manufacturer's website to download the latest compatible drivers. Easily done.
summary: Works well once I had the correct driver.

reviewText: I have tested dozens of SDHC and micro-SDHC cards. One disturbing trend I noticed is that: the speed class rating for micro-SDHC is typically inflated. For example, a 'class-10' rating means the card must deliver a sequential write speed of at least 10MB/s. But somehow, a class-10 microSDHC cards is always slower than a class-10 SDHC card from the same manufacturer. Case in point: thePNY 32 GB microSDHC Card (P-SDU32G10-EFS2)claims to be 'class-10', yet it can only write at 8.6MB/s maximum, while the full-sizePNY P-SDHC16G10achieved 13.4MB/s according to CrystalDiskMark v3.01.ThisPolaroid 32 GB micro SDHC (P-SDU32G10-EFPOL)did better than the PNY microSDHC. It achieved a sequential write speed of 10.3MB/s in CrystalDiskMark. So strictly speaking, it does qualify as a 'class-10' card. However, a closer look at its random write speed revealed its weakness. For writing small files, this Polaroid class 10 card is actually much slower than theSanDisk class-4 microSDHC SDSDQM-032G. See the benchmark results I uploaded to 'Customer Images' for details.When you use a memory card in a digital camera to record HD video, it needs to store a huge video file each session. That means its sequential write speed is most critical. So you should always choose a class-10 card over a class-4 (assuming both speed ratings are honest, of course).When used in a tablet or a smart phone, however, the card's random write speed for small files is more important. That's why in such applications, theSanDisk class-4 cardwill actually perform faster than thisPolaroid class-10 microSDHC card. The Sandisk card is also priced lower as of this writing.[Other Notes]- Polaroid Corporation went out of business 4 years ago, so I have no idea who actually makes this 'Polaroid' card. The back of the card says "Made in Korea".- The size of this '32GB' card is 29.9GB according to my computer. This is actually normal because computer people count one Gig as "2 to the power 30", which is 7.3% larger than one billion. So 29.9GB translates to 32 billion bytes, which is '32GB' according to marketing people.[Update on Jan 7, 2013]I have tested theSanDisk Ultra 32 GB microSDHC Class 10 card(SDSDQUA-032G-U46A), and found it to give faster all-round performance. It is better suited for use in cameras and tablets alike.
summary: Meets minimum requirement for 'class-10', though not necessarily the best choice for your tablet

reviewText: Batteries in electronics have largely been rip-offs for many years. A couple of extra batteries for some digital cameras and camcorders may come eerily close to the cost of the complete, brand new unit. Panasonic has been one of the worst offenders, suggesting that their Chinese batteries are somehow better or "safer" than aftermarket.To "protect" the consumer, they sometimes ensure that aftermarket batteries are not recognized in their units, so they can sell you a three dollar battery . . . for $85 or so. I regularly use three Panasonic camcorders: TM55, TM80, and a HDC-SD90. They all use the same batteries. I did buy a "factory Panasonic" VW-VBK360 extra life battery at a nosebleed price. It is made in China, rated at 3580 mAh. This battery is rated at 3800 MaH and does last about ten percent longer than the overpriced Panasonic. Battery life remaining shows properly in all three camcorders, just like the OEM battery. A fabulous value and highly recommended.
summary: Better than OEM, Just 1/4 the Cost

reviewText: The transformer fits well in the case, and it does work well with the cut outs for the camera.  The only problem i had with it, initially, was seating the tablet correctly in the case so that the power button would not cut out.  I found that I needed to make sure that the screen was pushed all the way into the holder, to make sure the leather strap did not overlap with the on-off switch.  Once i did this, it worked great, all the way around.

I've had a few low and mid-range point-and-shoots.  Usually I'm disappointed, but I read the reviews for this model and decided to give it a shot.  Camera is small, sleek, sturdy, and takes great pictures.  Incredible value, very happy.

I am an advanced amateur photographer and wanted a pocket size camera when carrying my larger one would be awkward. I have had 3 Panasonic cameras and have loved every one. The quality of the pictures is excellent, reflecting the great Leica lens. There is plenty of flexibility in settings to give me the range of photography that I want. The flash, while not as strong as an external one, is certainly adequate for most shots. I can recommend this camera without reservation.

First off, I must say this camera's large sensor and full 1080p recording are not understated. This is the same sensor as cameras twice as expensive in the panasonic line, and the quality is superb. Overall I am very happy with this camera, but I will share a few thoughts that might influence your purchase decision:Pros:- Great wide angle zoom range: I almost bought the canon but this went nearly twice as wide allowing you to get close or film indoors and still capture the full scene. Plus, even with the wide angle the long optical zoom range exceeds what you should practically be using anyway as fully zoomed in the camera shake on anything but a solid tripod makes the film nearly unwatchable so this camera truly has an optical zoom range that gets as wide as you could need, and closer than you practically should be using.- Great sensor: the images are recorded at 60 frames a second at full 1080p, eliminating the trailing lines you get on a 1080i camera. Don't expect to be shooting cinema quality footage, but the quality is sufficient that I went out and got a blu-ray burner and blank blu-rays because there was simply so much more detail that this camera captured that I couldn't bear to part with when archiving & presenting it to friends and family.- Off brand batteries: I immediately bought an off brand charger and extra battery for ~1/4 what panasonic sells them for. If you do this with canon or with some other manufactures you will be missing a coded chip and unable to see the battery status (esp. how much recording time is left) but with panasonic there is no such chip so for less than half what a small extra battery would cost I got a large (3hr) extra battery and an off-camera charger. Accessories are one of the major ways a camera gets more expensive (the canon battery/ charger combo is nearly two hundred dollars) so having a cheap alternative (I spent less than forty) is critical component in decision making when are trying to be price conscious.- Simplicity: I handed this camera to my wife with no directions and she started taking footage without issue. The auto-on when you open the LCD and the obviousness (and standardization) of the zoom lever and record button mean that while you have access to more manual features, it is still something you can pass off to an inexperienced person and not be concerned about them getting confused.- Memory card access: I would HIGHLY recommend this camera over one with internal storage. First, the internal storage is only accessible if you remember your cable and plug your camera into your computer, while the memory card can be removed and inserted into a memory card reader present in nearly any computer made in the last 5-10 years. It does mean you need to be sure you have the memory card with you, but it is worth the convenience in my opinion. Furthermore, Memory has dropped below $1/gb so a 64gb card that could hold more video than 2-3 batteries would allow you to take can be had very cheaply and keep you shooting for days.- Compactness: this is a camera that could easily be thrown in a purse, or in my case added to my DSLR camera bag in less space than a single extra lens would have taken. It is not quite pocket-able, but for carrying with other items it is small, light, and easy to fit in a tight space.- Playback: Many camcorders have pathetic speakers for playback. This one is certainly nothing to write home about quality wise, but for total volume during a quick check to see if you got an important moment it is wonderful and far better than I expected.- LCD: Many have suggested you by a lens hood, but I might suggest you hold off on such a decision. I took it out apple picking on a sunny day and put the lens hood on automatically, but when I took it off I still had no issues. If you are headed to the beach or desert or somewhere with a lot of sun and glare I can see it may become an issue, and the lens hood does help with being able to closely track focus, color & framing, but I was actually perfectly contented outside on a sunny day without a lens hood. Having the lens hood in my bag though does give me the safety net of know I will always be able to see my screen in any circumstance.- Auto-closing lens: I will admit my last video camera is ~10 years old, but having a lens cap that closes on its own whenever the camera is turned off is wonderful to protect the lens from dust and scratches, but is never in the way when you want to shoot. Its pretty much par for the course today, but I just had to say I like this feature.Cons:- Audio Quality: I want to play with the settings more, but I was somewhat underwhelmed by the audio quality. To add to my disappointment, the camera has an add-on cold shoe (where you could mount a mic) but it sticks out at the far back of the camera, so any mic mounted to it would hang over your zoom control. Overall, the audio quality is fine for a personal camcorder, but given the spectacular video results I think I set my expectations too high for the audio, and sadly there isn't a convenient way to bring the camera's fair audio quality up to match its superb video quality.- Touch Screen: for 99% of what you do you won't even use the touch screen, but as others have rightly pointed out, it is not a sensitive touch screen at all. It requires a solid push, and for tasks that involve sliding or dragging it frequently mis-interprets your gesture. Ultimately, I don't find myself using the touch screen much so it is livable, but if you plan on digging into the menus for every scene you may want to look elsewhere for a camera with a more responsive screen.Conclusion:This camera takes excellent video, which is ultimately what I bought it to do. Its audio quality leaves a little to be desired, but it does the job and is more a problem of unrealistic expectations than the audio being sub-par for a consumer camcorder. The compatibility with 3rd party batteries makes the camera cheaper to complement with accessories, and the price for a camera with this good (large) of a sensor is truly unbelievable. Finally, the zoom ranges means you won't find yourself too close or far from your subject allowing you to unobtrusively capture the moment. There are a few trade offs in a camera of this price and size, but on a budget this is a wonderful option for capturing important memories.

I have done my research for a long time. I have always wanted a double din unit, just didn't want to have to toss in 5 or 6 hundred dollars. I found this at the price I did and jumped on. I am blown away by the quality Pioneer seem to always deliver. This unit works fantastically. I wish I had pitched in for the extra inch, but I am so happy with this, I will be able to live on without it. Thanks

This is my first netbook and it's marvelous-- for its size and lightness, sturdy built, handsome design and great performance--FAST! And to top it all is long, incredibly long battery life with this wonderful little machine whose price just too good to be true; it even looks expensive. Well, so far so good--HP, THANKS!

This is the third case I have used with my Toshiba Thrive and is by far my favorite. Substantially thicker than other silicone cases and a perfect fit with openings for every port on the Thrive. Even the docking port has an opening even though it cannot be put on the Toshiba dock with this case on. The grip is much better than the textured back of the Thrive itself and it feels very secure in any orientation.I would highly recommend this case to any Thrive owner.
summary: Best case I have tried for the Toshiba Thrive

reviewText: I only have had this camera for a little over a month, but have taken some beautiful photos with it already.  I do own another "bridged" camera (different make) so I am a little familiar with this type of camera.  I am very impressed with the results of the "outside" shots I have taken.  I haven't taken any shots inside yet.  The photos I have taken are of popular photographed areas and objects.  I think my photos are as good as any other amature.  I have been reading the manual that I printed from the PDF.  This is a requirement if you want to understand all that this camera can do and operate the camera correctly.  It is really amazing what it can do for a "bridged" camera and the price for this camera is wonderful.  I have had SLR's in the past, but didn't want to haul all that equipment around again.  I wanted a camera that could give me "professional" looking photos without all of that costly equipment of a DSLR.  If you are looking for more professional and extensive processed-photos, then you may want to get a DSLR.  But I think this is the perfect camera for someone who loves to take "professional" looking photos without the big investment of the DSLR.

I set up this TV over the weekend with my 8-year-old Sony LCD projection TV on the side to compare. The Sony was still quite good when the scene was bright but it just could not show anything in the dark areas, which I hates since the start. Sony TVs do have the most nature color so I used it as reference for new TV adjustment. Basically you need to dim it to a certain level for movies to be more natural. With that said, the TV is perfect as far as in meeting my expections. The remote is not as bad some users have indicated.One minor issue: the TV did not sit on the base firmly and wobbled from side to side when I push. Will see if that will be an issue in the long run. Toshiba seems cannot make a solid base for their TV's as our older 32in also had some issues as it tilted forward since the base was not strong/solid enough.)
summary: Great TV - But you need to dim it

reviewText: TV value is top of the line.  Am very satisfied with this TV.  Lowest Cost that I could find.
