I followed the settings as suggested by previous valustion, and then experment a little  till I found what I liked the best. For my ears, the sound was certainly okay. Delivery was very fast, and arrived in excellent condition.  I recommend this to everyone

Real briefly, I wear glasses. When I shoot with the standard Canon OEM viewfinder eyecup on the 7D, I have to really peer into the viewfinder and my glasses tend to fog up and it's not always easy to see focus while I'm shooting. Not a problem since I installed the Hoodman Glasses eyecup. It installs in 20 seconds and stays on until you decide to take it off. The good news is that it works. It works really well. I consider it indispensable for my work.Thank you Hoodman.
summary: 100% Recommended for Shooters Who Wear GLASSES - Thank you Hoodman!

reviewText: Based on specs, and previous experience with Ipad 1 and Ipad2 and other Tablets, this is the best and easy to use. Look at the support by other products, even apps for high end Audio receiver along with Apple TV support. I hope windows 8 gives better specs and some great hardward by its vendors.
summary: Best IPad, nothing come close to

reviewText: You could just build your own computer thats better for 300-400 bucks...save your money, this is WAY overpriced. I recommend windows but its up to you.

To sum it up, the Macbook is one of the best computers I've ever owned. It's fast, light, and is perfect for media editing, which is mostly why I bought it in the first place. One problem does emerge though: the price. At $1899 to start, this is no cheap machine. Though you are getting an excellent machine and paying a decent price for the parts, many other machines can match if not go far past this one in terms of graphics preformance and other factors and run you a lot less. It is my belief though that if you intend to use any computer as a media editing machine, or even as a daily driver, then an OSX machine is certianly worth it, and with this now taking the top spot in screen size on the Macbook line I would definatly recommend this to anyone who asked.

We have a small company in Tampa.  We used to buy the iMacs but now have switched over to Mac Mini's.With a Mac Mini you have buy a Monitor, Keyboard, and Mouse.But when you upgrade, you can use the old Monitor and such.We love these machine and they are great.

I preordered this for my wife along with the case and the rapid charger. She really likes it! She got it today as an early birthday present and hasn't been able to put it down. My wife isn't a technology geek, but she is competent with android, windows 7, os x, etc... She immediately commented on the screen quality - the picture is really sharp. She liked how all the content options were easy to find and how the device was light in the hand. She has, on several occasions, commented negatively about the ipad, this 7" screen size is more comfortable for her.My only comment is that rapid charger thingy should come included. It is pretty ridiculous that a product which is frankly built for a very large range of consumers doesn't come with a wall charger. How are you supposed to travel?

I am a Mac user and considered staying with Apple for a tablet, but decided that I liked the features of the Fire HD as well as the price.  I am not disappointed--it is user friendly and intuitive, has wonderful clarity and great features.  I do wish Bridge Baron was available as an app!

I've had my Kindle Fire HD for a while now, and I've been doing a lot more reading since I got it. The Fire HD makes it easy to sit back in a comfortable chair and read for a while. The color display is necessary for many of the books I read, and they look great on the Kindle Fire HD screen. I bought the Fire HD mainly for reading, so I haven't done much web surfing or anything else with it. One problem I ran into with an arts and crafts book was that the book contained a couple of basic sketches that I was supposed to trace and then use for a project. I have the Kindle reader app on my notebook computer, so I opened the e-book to that drawing, taped a sheet of tracing paper over the display and traced the picture. That was somewhat awkward, but it worked out.I've subscribed to a couple of digital magazines that get delivered to my Fire HD; when I opened up one magazine up and saw the page view I was afraid I had made a mistake by subscribing but I quickly discovered the zoom capability, which makes it easy to read the fine print.Although I have been accustomed to organizing my e-books into collections and that feature isn't available on the Kindle Fire HD, I still think the Kindle Fire HD is a fine product.

Amazon you've done it again, I felt the same excitement starting up the Kindle Fire HD as when I got my first Kindle e-reader a few years ago. I had so much fun looking at everything and learning how to use it that I forgot to eat lunch! I finally told myself to "step away from the Kindle" and get to work. The HD screen is awesome; the audio book sample I listened to was yummy thanks to Pete Townsend reading his memoir, and my past music purchases showed up and sounded great. Can't believe such little speakers put out such clear sound, amazing. Took some time to get Skype set up, but the calls went through perfectly. Got into my FB account, and with a little research, I signed into Twitter account too. Some interesting things I've found out is that the old e-reader versions of my games don't work on this Kindle and that to use the camera I need an app, other than that this is pretty close to perfect. In the last few days I watched 2 episodes of one of my favorite BBC series thanks to the free month of Amazon Prime. The Kindle Fire HD deserves more than 5 stars; mine was a gift from my husband and I'd recommend this to all gift givers.

This is the 4th Kindle I've owned ( Kindle 1, 2, and the Fire) and I'm more impressed each time! My favorite improvements with the Kindle HD have to be the screen and the SPEAKERS. I watched my 1st HD movie the night I opened my Kindle and wow. The picture was amazing and the sound was even more impressive. Now all I'm waiting for is my cover which comes in today and my screen protectors which should ship soon. Then my Kindle will be complete.I'm very pleased with my Kindle HD and would recommend it to anyone!Only negatives thus far in my opinion:-The power and volume buttons are a bit too close together. (Really I'm just happy that the volume buttons are there this time around)-No power adapter in the box so order it when you order the Kindle and you should get it 1/2 price.
summary: Very Pleased with the Kindle HD

reviewText: This is a great product! I am using it on my exercise bike. I use the suction cup on the device to attach it to a piece of heavy Plexiglas that I affixed to the bike timer and then I can watch movies on my Kindle Fire while I exercise. I also bought one to use in the kitchen for our granite island counter. The kit comes with a disk which has adhesive on one side to attach semi-permanently to a car dashboard then you can mount the cradle's suction cup to the semi-permanent disk. So far, the suction cup alone has work great for me. I also can take the cradle and use it to hold my Kindle Fire for presentations. I mount the cradle to a conference room table and am good to go. The adjustments are plastic and have limits, but none that bothered me yet. Well worth the money.
summary: Works great with exercise bike and conference presentation

reviewText: Bought this wonderful little camera a month ago and have put it through its paces.  Went to the beach to see how it handled beach and water scenes on different f-stops and different settings on speed preferred, auto, manual, etc.  Went to Atlantic City day and night shots and very impressive especially with a borrowed panny 12-35mm zoom micro 4/3 zoom, which may be a little price at 1,300 but well worth it hooked up with this fine camera.  Price may come down when it becomes more readily avaiable. Tried auto focus and manual focus also.  For a neat little package the camera performed absolutely fantastic, just about as good as my Nikno D700 which totally blew me away - especially weighing in at about 1/6 the weight.  The lens that came with the camera was OK, not great but also not bad for a 14-42mm lens f3.5-5.6.  However a friend who was in Tokyo Japan came back with a Panasonic 12-35mm lens for his Panny camera and let me use the lens for a few days------that is really what blew me away and when it becomes available will be my stay on lens.  The lens is not too big for the OMD but may be too big for the pens and some of the pannys, but not on the OMD.  The photos shot at all different combinations of f stops and speed, as well as ISO performed stunningly.  This combination of camera and lens will be my constant companion, I like it better on the OMD than the primes available through Olympus and Panny and I am a diehard non-zoom lens photog, or was until now.  Not going to go into a complete technical review since that has been hashed over by many on this blog.  If you love your current DSLR, you will be madly in love with this combination of the OMD and the 12-35 panny lens - and you can carry it with you constantly.  Of course the oly primes 24mm and the panny 25mm f1.4 are great primes if you insist as I used to on primes over zooms, both produce excellent results.  This is the first time since I purchased my Contax G2 that I was this impressed with a little camera, granted one is a rangefinder and one is a minature dslr.  I still have the Contax and will probably keep it since it still performs well and I just cannot seem to want to part with it.  Good Luck and Good Shooting.PS...Gave this camera a 5 star would have given it higher if possible, with the panny 12-35 would give both extra star ratings.

Hi guys i received mine today and the tv it`s great but you had to be careful to clean or touch the front panel, to avoid dead pixeles in the near future.had an issue with the previous model the UN55DS8000 affter 5 or 6 days of the purchased i noticed a 4 red dotes line appears on the left bottom corner, i don't give it much importance cause was at the bottom but l20 days latter the line grows and turns black some of the dotes and comes more and more  like 4 inches and turns from red to black, so i calling the samsung service at that time and can't replace the screen and decided to refund the money, so i take the risk and bought this new one,  the representant from samsung said that CLEAN OR TOUCH THE SCREEN CAUSES AND OVERBURN OF PIXELS IN THE ZONE THAT YOU PULL OUT THE TV PANEL IT`S VERY SENSITIVE AND DELICATE SO YOU HAD TO BE CAREFULL ON THIS, THE SAID THAT SHOULD TURN OFF THE TV AND UNPLUGGED FROM OUTLET TO AVOID THIS.Hope that this can ressolve futures issues, causes of this i gives the tv 4 stars but you had to be carefull with this tv.Oscar
summary: GREAT TV BUT BE CAREFULL WITH TOUCH OR CLEAN THE PANEL VIEW

reviewText: These are great.  I almost ordered ONE stylus from another company for about $15 and although I don't have that one in hand to compare, I just find it hard to believe that it would be so much better as to warrant costing twice the price of SIX of these, which work great, are fun colors and seem to be good quality.  I'm very happy.  Shared two already and have 4 left over in yummy colors! So far, just fooling around with them on my iPhone (much easier to type without typos) and my new iPad is scheduled to arrive tomorrow (the real reason I decided to get a stylus) so I anticipate more fun and getting great use from these.
Just had to comment.  Bought a stylus with iPhone and iPad .  These require more pressure to get the same result.  Different (cheaper?) material on the tips.  Really?  Yeesh.
It works great.  It was very easy to install. Havent used the Netflix feature yet.  Have no complaints, I would recommend this player to anyone that is looking for a nice reliable blu ray player.

This is the first time that I have ordered a TV online. I was a little concerned, but everything turned out great.This TV is on my wireless network, uses DLNA perfectly with my iPad and the 3D is great. Panasonic has an app that lets me control everything from my iPad.The screen resolution is almost like being there.I also ordered the Johnny Depp 3D Blu-ray Alice in Wonderland. Ther were quite a few times that I flinched or ducked because I thought that something was coming right at me! The blue butterfly at the end was the best. It actually looked like it came out of the screen and was in my living room!So far excellent!Update 08/06/2012: I watched the Olympic opening ceremony in 3D! Words cannot describe how beautiful it was on this TV!The ONLY complaint that I have is where the speakers are. They are in the back. The volume has to be turned way up because of this. I've moved it further away from the wall, but it is still muffled at times. I am planning on getting a surround system but am waiting for Panasonic to come out with a system without a blu-ray player as I already have their DMPBTT-220. Maybe the sound is better if it is mounted on the wall which is something that I do not want to do.

Camera surface is too slick, risk of dropping it is way highLarger than average screen is why I chose it, but do not like the on-screen featuresWould prefer an optical viewfinder1o Megapixels is enough for almost every person

After using my Canon SX260 on a trip to the southwest my overall impression of the camera is very good.  However, I do think they could make a few improvements.  The major complaint I have is the flash.  It is in a very poor location.  When holding the camera my left hand usually restricts the flash from popping up and even when it is up, it is difficult to hold the camera without interfering with the flash. Also there is no way to force the flash on for fill in light in the Auto mode (you only have a choice of auto or off).  You have to change to one of the manual modes to get the choice of flash on, auto and off.
summary: Canon  SX260 good but not great

reviewerName: Jeffrey S. Lewis "Jeff In Spanish Lakes"
reviewText: Canon D20 good features:ruggedwaterproofgood quality stillsgood quality videoOK zoom range with no lens pop-outBad features:slow at multiple shotsslow focusbulky (I understand must be to be rugged & waterproof)
summary: Good photos, but slow and bulky

reviewText: I have to be completely objective when writing this, in brief:1. The tablet is very sensitive, comes with a new rubber casing which is good really; but not as smooth as its predecessor intuos4.2. The surface is rough and resembles real paper lot but will run through nibs quickly, usually one nib in a week for heavy usage e.g. 40 hours a week, for this reason I used a protective surface for less than 5 USD.3. The multi touch technology lags often and not sensitive enough. I purchased intuos5 instead of intuos4 for the multi touch technology but I feel it's a little bit disappointing e.g. in Photoshop I have to give the command more than once to zoom or pan.4. You have to be careful when plug in the cable, the port on the tablet is a mini usb which is really small and sensitive and may break inside if you use force to plug in/out the cable.5. I don't like the new touch buttons, sometimes I have to press hard that I get the feeling I might actually break them.Conclusion: The tablet is great in its sensitivity but it doesn't have much to offer more than the intuos4 except for the paper feeling, the rubber casing and the clumsy touch technology.
If you use photoshop on the road with your laptop, it doesn't take up much space and is great to draw with.

Bought this for my parents to replace an old CRT.  They're impressed because it's new to them, but when I went home to visit I was impressed.  I have a Samsung 50" plasma at home and this LED picture quality is comparable.  I played around with Netflix streaming with the built in Wi-Fi and seemed to work well.  Good price for a high-quality picture.

I like this case... almost.  I've had it for about a week and, for the most part, I like it, but it needs a bit of polish.I like that there are 3 different angles at which you can prop your iPad up. I have found a use for each angle, which has enhanced my productivity and enjoyment of the iPad.I like that you can turn the iPad 360 degs. When I first bought it I didn't think I'd use it vertically, but it was only marginally more expensive than the other case I was looking at that only allowed horizontal placement.  I am SO glad that I spent that extra money.  I use it vertically probably 30% of the time, which easily justifies the added expense to me.I like that the iPad clips in securely and the case is substantial enough to give the iPad good protection.I like that there is a stylus holder.I like Targus' customer service (I know, weird, eh?).  Please see below for a bit more on this.And now for the drawbacks...The slots that the iPad rests in are fairly smooth and rounded.  When tapping the screen, especially at the top, the iPad has a tendancy to pop out of the slot and fall flat.  I think this could be resolved rather easily if the slots were a little deeper, or perhaps angled in slighly.The stylus holder is rather small so it's difficult to get the stylus in.  I'm hoping it will loosen up over time.I feel the stylus holder is located in the wrong spot.  I don't always use the stylus and when the case is folded out for use the stylus is on what becomes the bottom.  This causes the case to be tilted back and to wobble slightly.  I think the case would be more functional if the stylus holder was located on the top side of the case or maybe along the edge.The magnetic on/off feature doesn't work particularly well.  Targus is aware of this.  They have offered to send me a replacement case to resolve the issue.  In fact, the customer service regarding this issue was awesome.  I was only on hold for maybe 30 seconds.  The rep was very polite and professional and I had the whole thing squared away within minutes.The iPad is difficult to get out.  I suppose this is a good thing most of the time, but I don't always want the iPad in the case.  It'd be cool if there was a way that you could pop the iPad and the back off at the center ring and then reattach it when you're done.  Obviously, this isn't really an issue, just something I thought would be convenient.Overall, I think this is a good case.  If Targus could iron out a few issues I think it would easily be the best, most versatile one out there.UPDATE:I got the new case from Targus about 4 days ago.  They said it was going to take 6-8 weeks but it only took 2.  Not badThe new case is much better than the old case.  It closes completely so it lays flat and the magnetic on/off feature now works.  Also, the lining is not quite as slippery as the old lining and the notches are more square.  This allows the iPad to remain in the notches more effectively.I still don't like the placement of the stylus holder, nor does it work very well.  I haven't been able to find a stylus that fits in it.  That's the only thing that keeps me from giving this 5 stars.

I previously purchased the same type of case for the iPad 2. So, I was hopeful that this case be just as good. Unfortunately, the two new features this case offers, the leather tab and magnets, are defective. The leather tab is designed to prop the iPad in a position ideal for typing. In practice, this usually causes the iPad to fall down from its position. The magnets may be misaligned, or not strong enough as they rarely succeed at turning the iPad off and on.  Also, in general the build quality of this case seems to have gone down from their previous offering.
summary: Magnets defective and leather tab doesn't really work

reviewText: What I like:It looks great.  It has the look of canvas but the feel of vinyl and it's easy to spot.  Looks very classy.The magnet on the smart cover works great for me, and the iPad wakes up and sleeps as I open and shut the cover.It stays on the iPad very well, and I think it will do a good job of protecting it.What I don't like:It's hard to open.  I have to dig my fingertips under the edge just to get it to open.  The handle that's there to pull on just doesn't work very well.The stylus holder.  I don't use it and it just annoys me.Some of the holes along the edge don't make sense to me.  I understand why they don't cover the speakers, input jacks, etc, but there are other uncovered areas that don't have anything particular on them.  Why not cover those edges, too, to keep them from getting scratched?This case is advertised for the new iPad, henceforth referred to as the iPad 3, but it didn't seem to fit as well on the iPad 3 as the iPad 2. The iPad 3 seemed a little to big for the case and the corners were falling off. On the iPad 2 it was a snug fit.I also don't like how there is no way to use the case to prop the iPad up, at least no way I have found.

Nikon deserves to sell very few of these and indeed a lot of us will skip it or wait for aftermarket. This is a fine grip, just like previous models. It offers absolutely nothing new yet costs FAR more (twice the price!) of the D700 grip. 3rd party companies will have a BIG business building a better grip for less money. This accessory is a real shame in light of the very fairly price D800.Like the MB10 the grip feels sturdy and all controls work well. The battery compartment comes with a tray for AA batteries and another for Nikon's battery. This will also get you the 6 FPS in DX mode. But the price is insulting. There's just no other way to look at it.

Bought this for my new MacBook Pro late 2011 refurb that came with 4GB (2 x 2GB). The first set of this Corsair Vengeance memory I received was defective. I would get a kernel panic either during or right after the boot process. I reinstalled the original RAM and the MacBook ran perfectly. Seeing the success of others and knowing with the specs this memory should work fine in this MacBook, I returned this set to Amazon and ordered again.Amazon was great at taking the memory back since it was defective, even paying for return shipping. This new set is working like a charm. Even though the Late 2011 models are to support 1333MHz memory, the quad-core i7 processor allows these to run at 1600MHz in the MBP.This memory is a fantastic buy. Coupled with a Kingston HyperX SSD, my MacBook Pro flies!
summary: First set didn't boot; second works like a charm in MacBook Pro Late 2011

reviewText: I bought 4 8GB sticks to replace the 2 4 GB and complete 32 GB total on my Thinkpad W530 with Windows 7 Ultimate, 64 bytes and Intel i&-3820QM @ 2.70GHzIt was a snap to put (two sticks on the bottom, 2 more by removing the keyboard) and booted right up, recognized all memory and I can handle now much larger Excel spreadsheets much faster.

All this is a excellent product and service (it arrived within 5 days), the package was good and the memory fit within my Dell Latitude #6430 just fine. The laptop has been working with the new memory for about 3 weeks with no glitches.The reason I got this memory is my laptop would hangup if I opened too many windows on my W7 Dell laptop, I am an engineer here at work with two monitors, so this was pretty easy to do, 4Gigs was just too little memory. Also this has made going to disk when you are running out of main memory disappear, when your laptop goes to disk it slows the laptop considerably and decreases your laptop hard disk life span.Now with 16Gigs, I don't even come close maxing out the memory even when I have a plethora of windows open and am running a memory intensive program like Mathematica.I would highly recommend this memory and upgrading your laptop main memory to the max.
summary: Excellent product & Service recommend to anyone

reviewText: The Samsung 830 Series is comparatively reasonably fast, and very usable. Unlike many SSDs, it exposes useful and relevant details via the SMART interface. It is also reasonably durable, and doesn't appear to lose reliability over time like some of earlier generations of SSDs. I have several of these running my computers, and one started experiencing errors within several days of putting it into service. I returned it and got a new one, without any problems. So like all computer equipment, a burn-in period of fairly heavy usage is always advisable to flush out any DOA components.

I just got done watching transformers in 3d on the pn51e550,let me say it was incredible! I have zero buzzing excellent colors and PQ out of the box with a few minor tweaks,changed to movie mode with warm2 setting,I turned down contrast brightness and cell light for break in.I can't imagine the picture looking better but after break in and calibration I'm sure it will be amazing.I had a c550 for 2 years and the smart features wireless lan and slimmer lighter design Samsung has a winner for under a grand.I didn't believe the bad posts and I am so glad I got this TV.Still playing with all the new features!EDIT-I've been watching this set every day since I got it,and it plays everything beautiful,the usb plays my hi def downloads and 3D is amazing,the only issue is it has some glare,other than that i love this TV!After break in Im going to calibrate this and Im sure it will get even better.PQ is outstanding for a set under a grand.*****EDIT*****11/27/2012*****Well it's now over 6 months and PQ is even better and no buzz at all.I had tv calibrated after about 300 hours break in and for the money,this TV is a great buy.3D still doesn't have much as far as quality programing however the colors and hi def picture are great for a 51in tv under a grand.I use the usb share daily and play blu ray rips right through the tv without need of a 3rd paty device and plays almost every file I tried.The only thing is a glare from direct light during day viewing,not an issue for me.And same as every thin flat screen,the speakers are mediocre at best,get a 5.1 Ht or even a soundbar and what a difference. I took a chance and bought a refurbed vizio soundbar as this is my bedroom TV and no room or need for a dedicated home theater and now with the soundbar my tv viewing has become even more AMAZING! Very happy with my purchase and the price and features of a smart tv and 3d are a bonus.Built in wireless and 2 pairs of 3d glasses,cant beat this for the money.Atleast until oled and 4k,8k etc become mainstream.That wont be anytime soon,especially at consumer level prices.

If you are looking for a good LED television with a great picture and viewing angle but can do without all the smart features that come on the higher priced televisions then this is the television for you.  The only gripe I have is there is not as many settings you can change for picture/audio etc as other televisions, but overall for the price of this television I'm very happy with it.
summary: Great TV at a Great Price

reviewText: This card was okay. but it wasn't what I was looking for.  I believe the Geforce cards perform better, and the EVGA brand provides better support and build quality. I'd look elsewhere unless you are stuck on an ATI card.

The picture quality is superb.  The small bezel makes the picture seem like its floating in air.  The interpolation of frames is odd at times, with some motion appearing unnaturally fluid.  Also, I've noticed some flicker on fine details.  The elimination of an HDMI port (3 versus 4 in previous models) is unfortunate.

I have purchased several Onkyo products over the last five years.  I have two cd players, a DX-7555 and C-7030 (these sound fantastic); I have the A-9555 integrated amplifier and the TX-NR809 AVR.They have all performed at three times their price point or higher.  Onkyo knows how to design modern electronics for music and video.  But their AVRs are quite complicated in what they can do since they are state of the art in the very newest WiFi, HDMI connections, iPod connection and 3D video.  I have just bought the TX-NR616 AVR for my son and it worked perfectly right out of the box after updating with a usb WiFi dongle. It took five minutes.  I downloaded the manual before it arrived since the manual is not included with the receiver. We printed the manual and punched holes to put it in a three ring binder (144 pages).  It is my opinion that this is what is causing some less than stellar reviews.  You cannot know how to operate this AVR (or any other without reading the manual) and perhaps Onkyo should put the manual back in the box.  Our TX-NR616 is performing beautifully for stereo and home theater.  We read and followed the manual during any set-up procedure after the initial updates.  Actually, we read the manual before updating to know the correct procedure.

I do not like this at all. The speakers plug into the blu-ray player so there is NO RECEIVER with this product. I cannot hear low voices and have tried to adjust things and have also asked questions to customer support w/ terrible responses. I am VERY UNHAPPY!!!!

This camera bag is built to hold a camera and two extra lenses.  There is also a small compartment up front for a charger or what-not and a mesh zippered area on the back.  It's definitely sturdy but a little bigger than I had hoped.  At first the bulk stopped me from using it for day-trips, but it's perfect for longer trips when you need a little bit more with you.  The inner sleeve is nice if you want it - it adds extra protection while the camera is in the bag and pops out and can protect your camera if you're just taking that on the go.  Obviously, it's meant for a bigger lens, actually, the whole bag is set up for someone with larger lenses (it easily holds my Canon 24-70mm, 100mm macro, and a 70-300mm zoom), but it will be too small to hold the longest zooms, and if you're carting around a 35mm or 50mm prime, you're wasting a lot of space.Once again, it's outstanding feature is it's ruggedness.  The zippers are strong, the nylon fabric is tough, and the bottom is made of stiff soft-touch plastic that should make it ok for setting down on damp surfaces.  There's a cushioned handle and a shoulder strap as well.  The strap is actually the weak link here, as its's thin and the pad slides around a lot, but it's hardly a deal-breaker.
summary: Bulky but well built, will keep your camera dry

reviewText: Camera rocks!  Easy learning curve and yet lots of great features which don't take much to figure out or set.  Picture quality is awesome and many have complemented my pictures.  Rough and rugged for all your outdoor activities.  Have plunged it fully underwater already on numerous occasions and taken great underwater shots!  Love that feature.  Plus I never have to worry about getting it wet.  Clip it on the kayak and go! In the pocket and off backpacking.  Bike riding, running, hiking, perfect camera for these and many more activities.Manual is the usual long-winded dictionary but using it really is easy and doesn't take much to figure out.  Love the lights around the lens both for close-up shots and for counting down timer shots.  Already dropped it several times and didn't phase this camera.  Really happy with this purchase!!

Used this product to upgrade from a 9600GT.  Installation was effortless and the performance increase was substantial.  The dual fans really helps keep the fan operation much quieter than the previous product.  Overall very pleased not to mention it looks much beefier than the 9600GT.

this replaced my old Sony blu-ray player to upgrade to 3D player.Set up was quick and painless with my Asus wireless-N router. Streaming was good. 3D content playing was also great. I didn't really got into Internet App section since my TV has better options (same brand)I also like the remote shape and button layout.It's a descent mid-entry level full HD 3D player.
summary: Great 3D blu ray player that plays many other

reviewText: I purchased this unit for a 2002 Toyota Highlander.  The unit fits very well and provides numerous enhancements over the factory JBC 6 disc changer unit.  Overall, I am very happy with the product, with one exception.Pros:iPhone/iPod/iPad integration is excellent!  You can fully control your iOS device from the headunit, including selection of playlists, videos, etc.Pandora works great, including album artUSB support - can play MP3s from USB drive, BlackBerry phone (USB drive must be formatted as FAT, no NTFS)Bluetooth is great, provides hands-free phone service in car, full integration with phone contact list and even streams musicCons:Really, the only disappointment of the unit is the SiriusXM features.  I installed a SXV200 unit with this to provide XM Radio and while it does good with playback and song info, one of the main features I wanted was the ability to pause and rewind XM music.  The SXV200 provides this feature, but the JVC unit doesn't support it.  For a unit that costs this much and claims to support the SXV200, this simple feature should have been implemented.Overall, happy with this unit and was a major upgrade.  Just disappointed JVC chose to not fully implement the features of the SXV200 that it "supports".
summary: Great unit, missing some XM features

reviewText: item is already broken....amazon says itll take a month to send me a new one.samsung claims its under warranty, and will send someone out to fix it.  still no contact from said "authorized repair center"so after paying 1500 bucks, and it taking weeks to be delivered, I think I got to watch it perhaps 2 days before it broke.

These are the only type IV tape, metal tape, that is, in the USA. Well, as far as I know, anyway.  They seem to be made well enough and sound great. If you use a good cassette deck with Dolby then for this price buy these for Pete's sake! They are a BIG step up from Maxell or TDK SA ferrichrome. Nothing beats metal. On my Dolby S deck a good vinyl recording and the copy are so close as to be nearly identical. There is no brand of type II tape that I can say that about. These are worth every penny. Don't expect them to last forever...

Perfect, I've used the older version for 2 month now (Yongnou 560) and just purchased Yongnou 560 II. I've also carry  with me a couple of SB900 which has failed me numerous time, problem overheating, which has never happen with either version of my Yongnou. Needless to say I've sold both SB900 to Ebay and kept my 4 sets of Yongnou. Sure they are not built as solid as Nikon, but guess what I can have 10 Yongnou in my bag that will last me for 10 to 15 years instead of purchasing 2 Nikon for a $1000. Hey guess what both can do the same job, you'll just have to learn how to use them in order for you to benefit from it. My suggestion for now, get a remote flash trigger and don't place you flash on the hot shoe of the camera, so you'll have more room to be creative. No one can teach you that, so you will have to keep practicing with it until you begin to see how much power, lights, and distance land on your subject. Sure doing manual is a lot of work, but once you become one with your device, eventually it will become second hand and now it's time to be more creative instead of just bouncing the light. I'm an upcoming photographer, in fact I am going in 4 months. You're probably thinking this guy don't know what he is talking about. Well having 4 months experience in Photography, I have done 8 weddings, 23 Single and Family portraits. My first month practicing with my Nikon D300 I've put almost 20,000 actuation on my camera, the right way of course. Now my D300 act as a backup. Tested Nikon D7000, D700, and D800. I came to conslusion, it all boils down to the image. If you know how to compose your shot, lighting, and the technical aspect of the camera, you don't need to purchase anything beyond D7000. DX vs FX? Take your DX and step back a couple, now you have your self a full frame.......I have more to say but this is getting to look like a Novel. If you have any question email me at PDasalla@Yahoo.com with a subject "Photography do not delete"

I ordered one and received it in 2 days. Really fast shipping, however the camera stopped working after 10 minutes. I emailed for replacement and received another one 2 days after that. This time i plugged the camera on my TV and a 12volt power supply and let it run for about an hour. So far no problems. Install is pretty much straight forward. There is one video cable that has a red cable coming out of it that connects to the positive of the backup light and the other side to the back of your stereo or external monitor (thats what give the monitor the signal to automatically switch to the rear view). That cable it pretty thin and long enough to easily reach from headunit, toward driver side, down the footwell panel, underneath the door sill covers, behind the rear seat backrest and finally up the trunk lid arm with about 2 feet to spare. (05 Toyota Corolla S). There is another cable, about 3 feet long that powers the camera. That needs to be connected to the positive and negative of the reverse light. The negative can also be connected to any part of the car body.Some headunits require you to pick if the signal to switch to the rear-view video is negative, positive, or off if you dont want it to switch automatically.(keep that in mind before you blame the camera for you video not switching automatically).Day performance is extremelly good. The way i have the camera doesnt get hit by the sunlight so i dont know if it would glare alot or not. Low-light performance isnt that good but its good enough when you get closer to an object which and can clearly see how far you are. You can purchase some LED replacement bulbs for your vehicle and get alot more light and alot better low-light video quality. Superbrightleds.com is a good source.

MyKindle Fireis a tough little unit so far--I haven't actually dropped it yet, but I've carried in my coat around town, in a busy laptop case, and on a car seat on long drives. So if I'm going to invest in a case, it better do more than simply protect the device. The Marware Vibe is a basic case with a few handy features.I plucked it off the Vine first and foremost because of its ability to act as a bookstand. The cover articulation is simple and it works, but is designed for `landscape' orientation. The case is generally unsuitable for standing the Fire in `portrait', but it will work in a pinch if you really need to view something in that mode. I find the former handy for browsing the net while playing a game or writing a paper. I can also use the stood-up Fire to type notes with a stylus while reviewing a game or a movie. However, take care not to tap the touch screen too hard because it causes the cover to bend. Over time, I imagine the folds of the cover will weaken; however, it is shaped so that the bottom of the Kindle touches the non-skid pad on the inside cover to help keep it in place.That non-skid pad is also handy for placing things. I've got thick, manly fingers so hitting buttons on my Fire can sometimes be a mashfest. TheAmazonBasics Stylus for Touchscreen Devicesis a good supplement and it sticks to the pad well enough. I can tilt at about 30 degrees before the weight starts to slip it down. Dirt and dust also sticks to the pad very well, so keep that in mind.The trim size of the case suits the device. It doesn't overlap, which also means there no handy place to tuck a stylus or a pen--even the spine is too tight. I was able to tuck the encased Kindle into my Levi's denim jacket inside pockets, and walk around listening to music. Completely filling my pocket, the assembly didn't bulge, though it was still noticeable if the jacket was being bent or blown.Inside the case, the four point attachment harness is a cheap plastic and it gets the job done. Shaped like a letter "H" it Holds the unit steady and the four clip points are easy to snap on and off. The elastic band is tight enough to keep the case closed, but like all such bands I've encountered on consumer products, looks and feels like it will hyperextend after a couple years.The Vibe is one of several Marware cases for the Kindle Fire, retailing at about 25 bucks. While there is no pocket or clip for a stylus, and no zipper or magnetic latch, you could do a lot worse for your five-and-twenty payment. Just like it looks on the product page, the case feels and opens like a hardcover book.
summary: Been a While Since I Stepped into Good Vibrations

reviewText: Very solid.  Well made.  Only critique is a little bulky.  Very nice finish.  Red color vibrant.  Sets up for reading position easily.  Like the elastic holding bands.  Very secure. Would buy again.

I was one of the first people to order the Kindle Fire last year. At the same time I ordered a case for it also made by Marware, called the MacroShell Folio. See it at the link below:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005HSG3TC/ref=oh_details_o05_s00_i00It was the lightest in weight at the time, and was offered in a charcoal gray color. The case looks great, and I've liked it, as it hasn't added to the weight and has kept my Fire protected. I don't have a scratch on it and don't have a film over the screen. This one is light too, just slightly heavier than the MacroShell Folio, but the material looks like vinyl, whereas the MacroShell-Folio has a nice sleek look, that never buckles. It looks great. They both hold the Fire in place with the brackets provided and both have a strap.The biggest advantage in this "Vibe" version over the MacroShell-Folio is the stand feature. This one stays in place so well. The original one I got, (the MS-Folio) stand is supported only by a groove in which the flap fits to support the stand. It often times slips out of that groove. This Vibe just folds into place and stays put. If you're reading in bed like I do, this is a good feature. You can set it on a pillow in front of you, and it's quite sturdy and handy. All you have to do is tap the right side to turn the page.  The M-Shell Folio needs a flat surface like a table to keep it from moving so it will stay in the groove that supports the stand. If I'm reading in bed I can't put it on my lap or pillow.  I have to hold it in my hand like a book.  If I nod off, which is pretty likely, I read so late at night, I could drop it.  This model is better for reading in bed, or anywhere you need for it to stay in the upright position.So, these are the positives for this one:1) The Stand2) Color: this one is red and easy to spot in a bag or car.3) The price is good on either one. As of this writing they are similarly priced.The negative is that it looks like vinyl, not like real leather. The red is a bit bright too, I would prefer a darker red. My thanks to Amazon's Vine Program for the opportunity to preview this case. I think I will end up using this one more. I haven't taken it off since I got it a few weeks ago.PS: I also love, love, my Fire. I use it more than my iPad.

This unit is the same as a Loftek CX220 or the similar looking Foscam. It can be had for under $50. I use it on a wired Ethernet connection and am happy with the performance. Wireless use of any of these IP cams is pretty shakey, slow, may dropout, unless positioned right next to the WiFi router. Recommended for wired use.

When it comes to screen protectors for computers, smartphones and tablets, I've become a skeptic. The idea of keeping a screen clean and free from fingerprints is good, but getting one to fit, then figuring out how to keep the bubbles out can be an exercise in complete frustration.TheMoshi iVisor AG Anti-Glare Screen Protection for Kindle Fireclaimed to offer a bubble free installation, but I had a high level of skepticism when I read the claims. However it was worth a try, and here are my subjective results.Likes:+ Good glare reduction in sunlight and bright overhead illumination+ Excellent fit; 7.2" x 4.4", no cutting or fiddling right out of the package+ Truly bubble-free; easy and fast installation+ Does not interfere with stylus use; smooth on the screen+ Fingerprints are eliminated; no more screen smudges+ Good "feel' on the screen; responds well to the touch+ Excellent instructions on the package; easy to follow+ No effect on color balanceMixed:* Price is high, but better in the long run than disposable protectorsDislikes:- Some very fine details are lost in images & print due to matte screenSetup:The Moshi iVisor AG Anti-Glare screen protector come packaged in an easy to open envelope. The four steps for installation are printed in English and other languages on the back of the envelope. Following the directions, this can be installed within 60 second including cleaning the Kindle screen.In Use:This was picked up here to be used with my 1st generationKindle Fire, and do note that it's not designed to fit the newer HD models. As much as I like the original screen and it's accurate rendering of details and colors, there are times that when handing this device to friends and clients, I get it handed back with fingerprints and smudges all over the screen. This has an effect on what one can clearly see on the screen, so it becomes a maintenance issue.One of the things that I wondered was if the screen protector would interfere with stylus use, and found that theamPen New Hybrid Stylushad no problems at all on the surface. It didn't interfere with theMarware Vibe Cover, and I didn't have to remove it for installation.The Moshi iVisor AG is effective as an anti-glare screen protector in bright sunlight and heavy overhead light that we encounter in convention centers and such. It offers additional protection to the screen surface of the Kindle Fire, reducing fingerprint smudges and the potential from scratches. On the downside, there is a moderate reduction in screen clarity in fine details found in photos, and because of its matte surface this can almost be expected. It looks frosted when held up to light prior to installation, but it's far better once installed.Summary:This skeptic was impressed with thisMoshi iVisor AG Anti-Glare Screen Protectorfor the Kindle Fire, and it does live up to its claim for a bubble-free installation. It does an excellent job protecting the screen from smudges & fingerprints, and a good job on reducing glare. It's downside is that very tiny details can be lost in images and such, but that's not as bad as it might sound, as it is acceptable. In its favor, image color is not altered at all, which was good to find. This screen protector is the best I've found yet, and other than the softening of tiny image details, it's recommended for overall screen protection and glare reduction.10/22/2012
summary: Moshi iVisor AG Screen Protector: A skeptic's experience

reviewText: I have tried so, so many screen protectors for my Fire, with uniformly unsatisfactory results. This is the first one that (so far, at least--I've been using it for just a few weeks) meets all my requirements, the most important of which is that I an unaware of it. Other protectors change the viewing experience, mainly by adding a murky layer or shiny distortion. This one does make the background to the text a little more like matte paper than glossy but I did not find this a problem.Basically, all these screens are just an enhanced piece of Saran Wrap or acetate that you stick on. It seems so simple. But, too often, like Saran Wrap, it tenaciously produces bubbles, is hard to position, and requires a very careful placing, smoothing and pressure to make it fit. This iVisor protector positions very simply and firmly on the Fire.The purpose of a screen protector is to protect the screen. Again, so simple a notion, but protection should not mean making the display harder to read or turning it into a thumbprint trap or smudge enhancer. I use my Fire very heavily and it is always in my briefcase, on my lap/desk/table and I don't treat it tenderly. What I most like about the iVisor is that it is almost literally invisible. It doesn't indicate its presence through distortions that remind you it's there. The frame fits absolutely perfectly to become an integral part of the Fire. It remains clear and tightly fitting and needs no attention from me.OK, so it's not life-style changing and is just a transparent rectangle that does nothing in and of itself. But it's a little like anti-virus software on your laptop -- you have to have it as a basic necessity. It's just a utility. Heavy Fire usage needs a screen utility. For me, the iVisor just does its job, keeps out of the way and can be taken for granted, as a utility should be.Excellent.
summary: At last -- a screen protector that works

reviewText: This cover installs the easiest I have ever seen.  It is well made, precisely measured, and goes on without bubbles...and you can take it off and wash it and put it back on again if needed.  I like that.  The edges don't ride up and it fits under my cover without slipping around.  It has cut down on the glare immensely indoors and out and it hasn't diminished my screens brightness that I can detect.  I don't see the finger smudges that plagued the old protector either.  So in the future if my Kindle Fire needs a new screen protector you can bet I'll be ordering one of these babies.  I highly recommend.
summary: Excellent Protector - Does What It's Supposed To

reviewText: Was easy to install and works great. If your purchasing a Kindle Fire I recommend the Moshi iVisor. Arrived quickly with no damage!

BLAM! I opened the box with excitement and anticipation for the build that was to come: A Home Theater PC that would pack a huge punch! I began the project carefully purchasing parts that would suit my needs. I began with the case... Home Theater in mind:Silverstone Tek GD08B Aluminum Extended ATX / SSI-EEB / SSI-CEB HTPC Computer Case Cases - BlackSexy. I found this motherboard, but what about the processor? low power, low cost, high value:Intel G530 CPU 2.40 GHZ 2M CACHE 2.4 2 LGA 1155 Processor (BX80623G530)Slapped that guy in this board - So far it's routine. Let's apply a cooler (screw stock cooling)Cooler Master Vortex Plus CPU Cooler RR-VTPS-28PK-R1Ahh, that felt good. Now let's go with some great RAM:Corsair XMS3 8 GB (2 x 4GB) 1333 MHz PC3-10666 240-Pin DDR3 Memory Kit CMX8GX3M2A1333C9Hmm... we want to boot fast- Let's get a value SSD!Crucial 64 GB m4 2.5-Inch Solid State Drive SATA 6Gb/s CT064M4SSD2I need this PC to not only be a HTPC, but also... a NAS!!!3 of Western Digital Caviar Green 3 TB SATA III 64 MB Cache Bare/OEM Desktop Hard Drive - WD30EZRXI want some silent cooling...4 of Cooler Master 120mm Case Fan - (R4-C2R-20AC-GP)I want a full keyboard for this baby... Wireless- put a track-pad on it too.Logitech Wireless Touch Keyboard K400 with Built-In Multi-Touch Touchpad (920-003070)I want it to connect to the home network, without wireless... can't run cable... hmmWestern Digital WD Livewire Powerline AV Network KitFixed!And of course, I have to get something to open the case with!Pure Komachi 2 Series 9-Piece Knife Set with Blockkidding- for my wife.And some old parts also:600w PCUAMD Radeon 5770First boot? Not so good... figures. Play with wires- now it boots! Yay!The boot screen was simple- very new age. The bios has the new UEFI tech that gives you mouse functionality within the menu... very nice. I like the overall feel of the bios, and it was hard to get lost. I like that. Easy to navigate, functional, and simple!I load up Windows 7... It's alive! Look good!The motherboard is beast. It has some capability. You can slap one high end video card, and maybe some small expansion cards to add some more functionality. You also get 2 SATA3 ports, 4 SATA2 ports, and frontside USB2 ports (no 3 guys...) It's  all good though, because you do have rear facing USB3.0 ports to make up for it. You also get the ability to slap in higher end hardware like an i7 processor if you wish, which is great for future proofing.I really like this motherboard. You get Value, Function, and of course a great brand! I love Gigabyte boards. Go with this purchase. There are cheaper options, but you don't get the bios, you don't get as much rear I/O and you don't get as many SATA ports! This is the value board for my build.It appears to overclock easily as well. Not that I want to do that with this build, but I can.I would use it again if I had something else to build! Questions?

ATI drivers and software for this card don't support Windows XP, and Linux support is poor.  You may need to reboot Windows XP more often when using Skype and playing a game, due to video artifacts.  Windows games like City of Heroes refuse to run under Wine with this card, even though they run fine with older ATI cards.  Downloading Linux drivers and Catalyst software from the ATI web site wrecked havoc on my Linux installation.Edit: The fan's power wires started rubbing against the fan, because the card ended up upside down inside the case (the wires sagged down on the fan).  That was easily fixed, but disapointing.
Long battery life, works great with my Samsung laptop and MS Streets 2009.  Great deal for a Bluetooth GPS!  Used this on several trips and loved it.
summary: Works with MS Streets and Trips and a win7 laptop

reviewText: I initially didn't want to pay $20 for a cover for my Bamboo so I was looking at the reviews for the $10 one made by another company. Some were good, some weren't and what concerned me was how the carrying pocket was just barely big enough for the pen. Then I read the two reviews for the "official" Bamboo cover and decided to get this one instead. Since I'm an Amazon Prime member, I didn't have to pay any extra shipping costs and I received the item in two days, so I figured what the heck, it's just a difference of $6 since the other model had shipping charges.The product itself is very nice - it is made from heavy felt in a medium smoke or charcoal color. The inside material is smooth. The tablet fits snugly inside and there is a loop at the inside top for the USB cable, which also fits snugly. The pen fits snugly in the loop on top of the tablet, so you've got a bunch of snug-fitting things. The top folds down and is secured by strong velcro. Note that if you drop the tablet on a hard surface I don't think this cover is going to protect it that well, but then that isn't what it is made for. It is made mainly for transportation and storage purposes, as well as to prevent it from being scratched.Only drawback: if you use a longer USB cable, since the one supplied with the tablet is pretty short, it may be too large to fit in the loop of the cover.Other than that, this is a nicely designed and constructed, and well thought-out product.
summary: snug as a bug in a rug

reviewText: For under $100, this soundbar was worth what I paid and it does an adequate job.  Don't expect window-rattling bass or surround-sound effects but I did get a significant improvement in sound quality when compared to the speakers in my flat-panel TV.  The sound is much richer and the separate bass unit adds significant depth to the sound.  It really is easy to install -just a couple of plugs and in a couple of minutes it was ready to go. Someday I'll pay (a lot) more money to get an actual surround-sound system but for now, this sub-hundred-dollar unit will fill the gap.
summary: Not great but still better than my TV speakers

reviewText: I have plenty of speakers, docks, etc. to use with my iPhone.  This one is handy because it is a simple design - round.  Easy to carry around and use wherever.  Because it is round, it also puts out sound well, even though it can't technically be stereo sound, it comes close.This little speaker is very easy to pair up with my iPhone.  It charges through a USB port plugged into my MacBook.  I love that it has a lock on the bottom of it that prevents it from being on without you realizing it.  It's a simple switch underneath that is for the lock, an aux-in connection, or bluetooth connection.  It comes with the aux cable and USB port recharger all connected in one tidy bundle with a built in clip to keep the cord neat.I have no complaints about it, it is just what I love in terms of design - simple shape, no extra parts to lose or break, and sounds great.  And of course, it's simple to use, which is perhaps the most likable trait of this little speaker.

I've had countless consumer-level camera bags, an enthusiast-level bag, a hard-shelled padded case, and now this Vanguard professional travel bag. This is definitely the best of the lot; very high quality with a thoughtful design.I have no trouble getting two SLR bodies, 5 lenses, and a flash unit in it. Could get another lens in there, or if not carrying a second body, a larger telephoto or two more lenses.PROS:* High quality all around that should stand up to many years of use.* Sturdy extendable handle* Widely positioned, quality wheels* Lots of space, configurable compartments* It looks like a soft bag, but offers a lot of protection, The sides are over an inch thick, sturdy inside, with nicely padded surfaces.* Two external straps for attaching a tripod (there's also a hidden pouch in the front that when unzipped and pulled out makes a great base for holding the tripod upright and secure.)* Comfortable, padded handles on three sides, providing many convenient ways to carry the bag.* Nicely padded lap-top pouch* Come with a combination lock and an accessory pouch* Pockets for memory cards or accessories* Claims to be waterproof (but I'd consider it water resistant)* Great for air travelCONS:* As nice as the bag is, it's hard to justify the price tag for a typical hobbyist.* I would have liked a few more pockets, either on the outside, or more compartmentalization in the front storage pouch. Other than the memory card pockets, there's really only one other miscellaneous pouch, so extra accessories like cables, chargers, filters, tend to just get thrown in together. A little more organization for those items would have been nice, and could have been accommodated.Great bag. I'm sure it will become my new all-purpose travel bag, likely replacing my bulky hard-shell case for good. If you feel spending a little extravagantly on a bag to protect your expensive photo gear is a good investment, I would definitely recommend this bag... it's almost as strong as a hard shell, waaay stronger than a typical hobbyist bag, and a lot more stylish and easy to transport.

This cooling solution is, by far, the most superior solution I have implemented in any PC to date. The stock fan in my HTPC wasn't too quiet to begin with, but had gotten increasingly whiny over time. I really wanted:1) A way to keep the CPU cool2) A low profile cooler that would fit into my Silverstone GD05B case3) Most importantly - a fan that was as close to silent as could be, without spending big bucks on liquid coolingYou can tell that this company takes pride in their product. The first thing that struck me was the packaging. The design and layout of how this product was packaged told me a lot about how effective it was going to be. From the flip out box to the color instructions, this company put as much thought into packaging as they did into the product.This fan fit my needs, and then some. First, please know that I do not overclock or do gaming on this PC, so I can't comment on how effective it would be for that type of use. I use it strictly as an HTPC to record and watch TV, stream netflix/Hulu, and convert recorded tv to a more manageable format (this is CPU intensive). For this application, my stock cooler would keep the temp at around 60C. I installed this cooler, and the temp has not gone above 40C since. Temp aside, the most important factor for me was noise level. YOU CAN NOT HEAR THIS FAN AT ALL. I put my head directly next to it to see if it was on. At about 3-4 inches a way, you can only hear it if you really concentrate and listen. Zero noise from across the room.Installation -Installation was a little tricky. You will most likely need to remove the MB to secure the brackets to the backplate if you have an AMD chip, as I do. I used Artic Silver 5 compound, as I have had really good results in the past with it. Couple of notes about installation:1) Make sure you connect the MB connections prior to placing/securing this cooler. Some of the connections (CPU fan and 4 pin MB power) would not have been inaccessible after installation. Plan accordingly.2) Once you place the cooler onto the CPU, you secure it to the brackets with two screws. To access these screws, the screw driver is actually threaded through the heatsink fins (there are 2 square holes on top of heatsink). This is incredible engineering, but it felt a little dangerous, as you could not see exactly where the screwdriver was going. Just take your time with it, and it will work out.3) I used the low noise adapter. I did not test the installation without it, so I am not sure how much impact this had on the noise level. If you want a silent implementation, I would recommend using it. It does not appear to impact cooling performance, and in this configuration, was dead silent.4) I used the 1 fan configuration. This provided all the cooling I needed, so I didn't even try it with the 2nd fan.Couple of pros/cons:Pros:1) Incredibly engineered - Does what it is supposed to - keeps everything very cool, and you cannot hear it2)Packaging, at least to me, justified the higher cost.3) With the 6 year warranty, you can tell that this company stands behind their product.Cons:1) If I had to list one, the only con I would say is that it is pricey. For me, the price for blissful silence is worth it, so not really a con for me.If you are looking for a completely silent CPU fan for you HTPC, I have no hesitation recommending this product. I am overly impressed with Noctua, and will be a repeat customer.

PROS: Great lookin and I love the size of the screen. Lots of information I especially like the capability of entering the size of my coach. POI is packed full of destinations to assist on any trip one would make. The GPS was very accurate and showed the best routs, the way I would have taken. The large screen made it east to see and no problems with the screen being wash out by the light of the sun. The mounting arm is the best I have ever seen, its easily adjustable.CONS: In the last year or so some states has increased its speed limits and many of the speed limit displayed on the GPS were too low, also additions to the some roads had not been added to the mapping software. reviewText: This is a new generation projector for showing computer or DVD images on a screen or wall.  It's new generation in many ways: first of all, it's much smaller than other "portable" projectors.  It actually fits in one hand and is very lightweight.  Yet it's just as powerful, even more powerful than previous market standards.  It uses an LED rather than halogen bulb, so it's cheaper to run, less delicate, and much less likely to need an expensive bulb replacement.  You can also connect it to wireless devices like iPads or phones with a wireless adaptor (not included).  On the top of the device, you'll find standard focus and adjustment controls to compensate for keystoning effects.  And there is a small foot on the bottom for raising the front of the projector. On the back there are numerous connection sockets: VGA, miniUSB, HDMI, or video/sound, and you'll find cables for each of these included in the box.  There is also a slot for a micro SD chip (not included), allowing you to use the projector all by itself. The only documentation in the box is a small easy-start card.  Most surprisingly, you don't need much more to get going--the projector actually works right out of the box.  Just plug it in and there's your image on the screen!I've been using an Epson projector for about 10 years.  It was a good projector that gave me few issues.  But after using this new 3M projector, I don't think I'll ever go back.  My old projector produced a good image, but this new one is much, much clearer. The 3M projector is fitted for a tripod connection on the bottom.  A tripod makes a much more convenient and adjustable projecting surface than a table--it's lightweight, easily movable, and you can carry it with you rather than searching for a suitable table or cart at your venue and clearing it off.  With the 3M projector on a tripod, I can easily get the projector to exactly the right height to fit the image on the screen.  The size and weight of the projector make it incredibly easy to carry around.  When I took my old projector on the road, I had to carry it in a separate bag that was as big as a large laptop bag.  The carrying case for this device (included) is about the size of a thick portfolio or book.  It fits easily inside a briefcase, backpack, or other luggage.Some reviewers have noted that the internal speakers of this projector are less than adequate.  While the speakers don't provide much volume or quality, they are, at least, present.  If you're going to do a presentation or show a movie, you'd always want larger, more powerful external speakers anyway.  Here, the speakers are provided just for the sake of convenience since devices like DVD players usually don't have any speakers at all.  So if you're trying to watch a movie just with a DVD player and this projector, at least you'll have some sound.Overall, this is an amazing little projector: simple to set up and use, versatile in its connection possibilities, convenient to carry around, all while producing a sharp, bright image.

we've been looking for a 40+" tv for a year. my only prereq's were: full 1080p, at least 120hz, must not cost an entire paycheck, and must knock my socks off. it took me a year of searching before i decided to pull the trigger on something. in short, this tcl 48" wins hands down. now, for the long review...first, the shipping. it took me two tries to get an intact delivery. the first one arrived, in only one day with free prime shipping, but with two giant holes in the side of the box. i pulled the tv out, and it had a big gouge in the screen and the lcd panel was cracked and bleeding out. i refused the delivery and immediately called amazon, and within 10 minutes of phone time, they had processed my replacement order at zero cost to me. the second tv arrived two days later, and in perfect shape. kudos, amazon customer service!now, the tv. i was afraid that a 48" tv would be too big for the space i had made for it on my wall. however, so little real estate is taken up by the thin bezel that the tv's physical dimensions are comparable to an lcd that only has a 46" screen. that little extra wiggle room made all the difference.the only other hdtv we own is a 23" led for the bedroom, and we had an old 32" sd tube tv in the living room before this purchase, so i don't have the ability to compare this tv's picture to some other big screen hd model. having said that, i am absolutely blown away with the viewing experience on this tv! i tweaked the preset controls for a few minutes before queueing up "batman: tdk rises" in 1080p (we simply had to go out and get something stunning for our first viewing experience). this is where that WOW comes into play.i'm no expert on 60/120/240 refresh technical details, but i'm not a novice either, and i do know when i see judder and soap-opera effect. i have to say, i didn't notice either. all the people complaining in the reviews about this tv being 60hz only, they fail to understand that what the tv is telling you on the display is the input stream quality, not the output to the lcd. almost no input signal is going to go higher than 1080p60hz right now. the tv takes care of the rest. and this particular tv takes care of the rest very well. from the high-action scenes to the sweeping slow pans across vast landscapes, my eyes never told my brain anything besides "this is awesome!" nothing about pixels or refresh rates crossed my mind. and that's the point, right?a couple other things. the remote has received a bad rap for some reason. first, have you seen the standard remotes that come with most electronics these days? they're all cheap, plastic, and basic. that's what you get with a free remote nowadays. at least this one takes AAA batteries instead of buttons. the real question is: does it give you access to all the functions in the tv? the answer is yes. if you're concerned about controlling all your devices with one remote, get a harmony.also, the glass base stand. i never used it, as the tv went right onto the wall, but the base appears to be very sturdy. i'm sure it would be more than adequate to hold this relatively light tv securely on a sturdy surface.the ac cord is hard-wired into the tv and cannot be removed, which i was not entirely happy about, but oh well.there's also just a tiny bit of light that leaks out through a bottom vent on the tv and onto the wall behind it. i've only noticed it once, when i had all the lights off in the room with the tv turned on, and only when the giant tv wasn't blowing my mind with stunning video. it's not a bother to me, but it could easily be fixed with a bit of black electrical tape.i already have an older surround sound stereo system that i hooked the tv up to right away, so i can't comment on the sound quality too much. i did test the built-in speakers out to make sure they worked, and they were the typical-sounding flat panel speakers: tinny, thin, and weak. no surprise there.to anyone scared by the brand name on this tv, i can't convince you that your tcl won't fail after a few months. you will have to rely on the reviews of others who have had it longer than myself, and the provided 2-yr warranty. if it does fail, i will update this review accordingly.i bought this tv for $479. i also signed up for the amazon rewards visa, which included a $50 credit. that $50 covered the mounting bracket, low-voltage wall plates for running a/v cables behind the wall, and a recessed wall receptacle to power the tv without showing any cords. i'm tech- and construction-savvy enough to install the whole setup comfortably by myself. in the end, i walked away with a professional-looking install on a tv that looks like it could have cost well over $1000, all for less than 500 bucks.tl;dr-if you're even halfways considering getting this tv, do yourself a favor and just buy it. after a year of searching, i don't think i could have done any better.

I have the iPad 2, Zaggfolio, Targus Slim Case, and the Apple Smart Cover.  Of those 4 options - this is my least favorite.  But let me start with the pros.Pros:1.  Easy to pop the iPad onto the 4 rubber corners that hold it into the folio.2.  There is a light elastic strap to actually hold the folio closed.  This is a unique feature and I like it!3.  Automatically shuts off iPad when folio is closed.  This is actually a basic feature that I think every folio should have otherwise it's an automatic FAIL.4.  You can fold the lid into a triangle to use as a landscape oriented base.5.  Nice colors6.  Nice suede-like, soft feelCons:1.  Has a cheap feel to it.2.  Has these strange stains in the interior that I have no idea where they are coming from.  Another reviewer speculates that it may be the glue staining it from the inside and I would have to agree.  I don't even like this folio so I haven't used it or touched it in weeks.  I went to look at it again now to write up my review and there are all these stains on the inside of it.  Now the Targus Slim Case that I actually like and have been using every day for months now is still looking like new.  So I'm really not happy with this folio.3.  It just doesn't feel all that secure or protective.4.  No stand for portrait oriention, only landscape.5.  The elastic band that holds the case shut is a nice and unique feature, the band feels cheap and feels like the elastic will lose it's shape and stretch out quickly.6.  Even with the elastic band, the lid does move around a bit.Bottom line - this would be a nice gift for that co-worker that you see and work with every day, but you don't like that much.  The concept of this folio is greater than the reality of it.  The Targus Slim Case is so much better and yet it's still the same basic design.  It's all in the details.  If I had only this folio with nothing to compare against, I would probably like it a lot more.  But since I DO have others to compare against - it doesn't stack up all that high.  It's basic and just feels a little on the cheep side.  Definitely nothing to brag about.  It does it's just if you're just looking for a very basic folio type light case to give your iPad a little more protection.  But there are better ones out there if you care to look a little further.

reviewText: I am pleased with this KeyFolio.  The keyboard has a good touch.  The angles for the iPad are good.  I like being able to use it in the landscape and portrait mode.  Negative aspects:  the iPad screen lays against the keyboard.  But the keyboard is plastic and probably will not scratch the screen.  I also have a screen protector and that takes care of that possible problem. The shift key on the right side is a little small and I sometimes hit an arrow key instead of the shift key and cause the cursor to jump away from where I am typing.  It does not sleep and wake the iPad when you close and open the folio.  I wish it did.Despite the negative aspects I think this is the best key folio available.

LensPen products and their private label variants are well know to many photographers, as they've always proven to be reliable, easy ways to perform lens and filter maintenance while in the field. These are products that have lived up to their reputation.This newLensPen MiniPro Lens Cleaner NMP-1was designed for compact digital cameras and to fit into smaller camera bags. It's one of those rare products that lives up to the "new & improved" note that appears on the upper right portion of the package. This MiniPro has a fully retractable fine brush and a flexible chamois tip that uses a proprietary carbon-based cleaning compound that won't spill or dry out.Likes:+ Small carbon tip cleans the lens in ten seconds; fits where larger cleaners don't+ Compact, tight design; fits into the camera bag or pocket easily+ Lens is cleaned without fluids; fingerprints and dust are gone+ Screw-on cap protects carbon cleaner; won't fall off in the pocket+ Retractable dust removal brush; very handy and protects the brush+ Good price on an excellent product; very competitiveDislikes:- None so farIn Use:The new LensPen MiniPro Lens Cleaner was specially designed for compact digital cameras. Think of it as the smaller sibling of my old favoriteNikon 7072 Lens Pen Cleaning System, which is also made by LensPen... check the cap. If you have a DSLR, you want theLensPen NLP-1or the Nikon Lens Pen, as both of these have a larger carbon cleaning pad.The retractable dust removal brush does an excellent job of eliminating general dust and the environmental residue that we seem to collect when we're out taking photos. But where this LensPen stands out is its use of the dry-carbon cleaning pad on the other end of this product. When I was a kid, we used to clean windows and mirrors with crumpled newspaper. Black printing is made with a carbon compound, and the carbon molecules have the capability of absorbing oils, grease and contaminants. It's the carbon that does the cleaning, and why the dry cleaning of this improved LensPen works as well as it does.It was easier to clean the lens of myNikon P7100with the MiniPro Lens Cleaner than with the larger versions as the tip is designed for smaller lens surfaces. Ever have a youngster touch the front lens on your camera with sticky fingers and ask, "What's that?" or hand your camera to someone who wants you in the photo, only to get it back moments later with fingerprints and smears on the lens? With this LensPen MiniPro, all you do is dust off any residue with the brush, then remove the screw-on cap on the other end and gently swirl the carbon pad over the lens surface. Within seconds stubborn fingerprints are gone; your lens is clean. It's that simple, and no liquid cleaners are needed.Summary:The newLensPen MiniPro Lens Cleaner NMP-1is fairly inexpensive, and this with the other LensPen products are a very cost efficient way of maintaining your photo gear. It's new compact size and features are evolutionary of a well-designed product in the first place, and it fits quite easily into your pocket or even into the smallest camera bags. It would make a great gift for a photographer who has a smaller camera, and is usually quite appreciated. For the price and value received, the MiniPro is a highly recommended 5-star product for keeping the lens on your compact digital camera clean and sparkling.9/14/2012
summary: LensPen MiniPro: Excellent for compact digital cameras...

I have had this incarnation of Steve Jobs hobby product since it went on the market. It has been an improvement over the past version mainly because it can display in 1080p rather than just 720p. For those uninitiated into the mathematic of pixels, 1080p offers twice the resolution of 720p. And that increase was why I added the new model to my home.MyRoku 2 XS 1080p Streaming Playeralso offered 1080p and unlike Apple TV offers Amazon Prime Instant Video as a channel. Why then has my Apple TV suddenly jumped out front?The answer is Mountain Lion a/k/a OSX 10.8.Mountain Lion has a feature called AirPlay mirroring which streams anything on your Mac to your Apple TV. Anything means anything-movies, documents, web sites. At 1080p the resolution is amazing. Your big screen LCD will suddenly become the biggest monitor in the world. And since Amazon Instant Video plays on a Mac. that Amazon content is now available.Now is the time to buy the 1080p Apple TV!
It's an iPad.  Everyone has used one.  And if you haven't, go find a friend with one.  Or better yet, just buy an Amazon Kindle Fire, because you won't know what you're missing.

I bought several of these drives to back up my personal files. It's easy plug and play and super fast on the USB 3.0 port. I currently have Windows 7. I got several of them because they were stackable so it saved me a lot of desk space.

What can I say I love this camera.  Being a lover of all things Sony, I was excited to be offered this Alpha A57 to review.  After two months of playing with it almost daily, I think I can now do a fairly good job of it.What's in the box?You get the camera, body cap, 18-55mm kit lens, strap, battery & charger and a usb cable.  It would have been nice to include a rear lens cap for the lens, but those are cheap enough I picked a few up elsewhere.  You will also need to provide the SDHC card.Stills:This camera takes awesome, clear, sharp and beautiful stills at 16.1 MP.  The shutter speed is fast, press the button and your picture is captured.  The A57 takes pictures as fast as you can press the button.  Auto-focus mode takes all the guesswork out of shots.  Just point and shoot.Manual focus lets you, the photographer set everything from aperture priority to shutter speed, which is perfect when swapping the lens to a manual focus Alpha lens.You can add various effects by simply changing the option wheel on the left side of the camera.  Here you can select portrait, sunset or black and white mode among others.There are still many options this camera offers that I have not and may never try out as they either don't appeal to me as a photographer or I don't see the need.Video:Shooting in full HD, video from this camera comes out just as stunning as still pictures.  You can choose to shoot at 60p fps or go for the cinematic 24p.
