Either way, you can easily create video that rivals more expensive professional cameras.And you can do all this with just the kit lens included in the package.  But for more fun, I invested in a 70 - 210 mm and a 500mm lens.  These two lens give me even more versatility than I've ever had before in a camera.  Want a beautiful moon shot?  Snap on the 500mm (with a 2x multiplier) and you can focus on the craters of the moon.  Want to photograph or video the birds at your feeder - give the 70 - 210mm a go.  You'll love the results.I cannot say enough good things about this camera.  It rivals the capabilities and quality of the Canon 7D that many of my friends rave about.  If you are looking for a new DSLR - you just can't go wrong with the Alpha A57.

I AM AMENDING THIS REVIEW FOLLOWING A TIME WARNER SERVICE CALL TODAY. PLEASE READ.WHEN I INSTALLED THIS MODEM, I USED TW'S MODEM FOR THE PHONE.  FOLLOWING THIS, MY PHONE CALLS STARTED DROPPING.  TOLD TODAY THAT THE SPLITTER RECOMMENDED BELOW IS NOT OK FOR THIS APPLICATION.  THEY REPLACED THE SPLITTER AND COAX JUMPERS, AND EVERYTHING IS FINE.THE CABLE COMPANY WILL GIVE YOU A SPLITTER.  NOT SURE WHY THEY DON'T TELL YOU THIS UP FRONT!---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The modem istalled fine, as reported by others, other than the multiple calls to TW to get the modem on line.  It finally worked, however as I was transferring the cables from the old modem to the new, I noticed that there was no place to plug in the telephone.  Aha, I said to myself, there must be a different modem that supports internet and telephone!I was half right.  There is no combination internet and telephone modem that TW supports for purchase.  However, if you have phone service with them they will allow you to keep their modem to use for phone only AT NO CHARGE!  However, you must do the following:Prior to switching over, have available:(THIS IS MUCH EASIER THAN IT MIGHT SOUND)1)  Your new modem2) 2 short lengths of coaxial cable of EQUAL LENGTH, e.g. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0018BQR84/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i013) A 2 way coax signal splitter, e.g. RCA DH24SPR, available on AmazonPlug the incoming cable into the "IN" terminal on the splitter, and one piece of the coax onto each "out" terminal.Attach that other end of each piece of coax, one to the new modem, one to the old.  Plug in the new modem power supply, move the network cable to the new modem, and you should be there if TW properly configured your modem.  No more $4 a month, and nothing to take back to them,With the DOCSIS 3 modem, I have noticed an improvement in my internet speed!
summary: Great Modem, BUT READ THIS FIRST IF YOU HAVE INTERNET PHONE AS WELL!

reviewText: Bought this when Time Warner started charging a monthly modem fee (because the modems break and cost a lot to be maintained, they said.  but their 2006 model modem is fine and doesn't break so you don't have to pay rental if you have their phone system ...)Set up easily.  Performs a bit snappier than the 2006 antique Time Warner was charging me for, based on bandwidth tests.  Gave it 4 stars since I haven't used it too long and have no idea about durability.

Apple has deceived me for the last time. They sold this to me when I got my iPhone 4 and then released iOS 5.1 which removes the ability of the adapter to mirror what you see on the screen (get nothing but a blank screen now). This is a very low blow, considering that I purchased the iPhone and apps specifically for this purpose (giving presentations) and now that the return and warranty period has expired on this PoS adapter, phone, and apps, I cannot get my money back. I'm done with Apple. This was the last straw for them in my book. Don't waste your money on this, Apple will take it and then laugh at you with the next iOS version. This should be illegal.

Very difficult to get apart at first.  Once it goes on the iPad, it's not loose and holds very well.  I put it on the 4th Generation iPad, and it fits well.  All the buttons seem to match up.  The screen protector doesn't seem to distort the picture at all.  My one and only complaint is the home button.  You really have to push it to get it to work.  I'm hoping as I use it, this will get easier.  I couldn't give it a full 5 stars because of this button.

I have been using this cover, on my iPad 3, for nearly six-months now.  I consider the iPad as a multipurpose tool. Thus, I have subjected my iPad, and this cover, to a number of professions and hobbies.  Some as low-impact as reading books, to use in a garage or while on construction jobs.  Before the Otter Box, and the protection it offers, my iPad had a very limited use.  Never before had I owned a device which was both beautifully designed, fragile, with so many possibilities as a daily aid.  This cover is the bomb! While taking some of the beauty away from the iPad, it certainly made up for it by opening up so many care-free features.  Now, I have no fear bumping, dropping (low-altitude), or using the iPad in nearly any hostile environment.  The silicone backing is a real device-saver.  It easily absorbs most any abuse I can dish out.  I certainly do not want to convey the thought that i abuse the device or condone such treatment.  all i am professing is that whether you are a delivery person, auto mechanic, or construction worker, this case will definitely protect your investment.As with some reviewers, I am not to thrilled with the screen protector.  While adding a great deal of protection to the iPad, it can be improved upon.  It can scratch with abuse.  however, the slight beauty it takes away from the new retina display is far exceeded by it's durability and worry-free use.  Unless you are using the iPad as an artist, or professional photographer, you'll not be dissatisfied with the screen protector.Other than this slight flaw (of which is no concern to me-but added for others), I wish I can give the Otter Box ten stars!  This should be a no brainier for anyone who plans to use the iPad as a tool, in other than in-house use, and is serious about protecting his/her investment.**Update: 26 Aug 2012 **Well, as previously stated, the only part of this product which may need some work is the screen cover.  After a few months of "brutal" use, I decided to see whether I could remove the Otter-box plastic cover and new install a new cover to the iPad.Once I removed the iPad from the case, the plastic screen, which came with the Otter-box, can easily be removed.  Gently, press on one of the from corners until the plastic begins to separate.  Then, continue to work around the cover until fully removed.I feel the ArmorSuit MilitaryShield is perhaps the best cover for the Retina display on the new iPad.  Easily installed (bubble-free, might I add), this cover allows the full Retina beauty to sine through.  Very durable, and resistant to fingerprints, this cover is the clear winner.  Feel free to read more about this cover at Amazon's site: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004RDWVUS/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00.

I suppose discouraging people from using something is the ultimate protection, but it's not what I wanted.  The screen protector renders the Retina display pointless; it would degrade the quality of low def screen.  The two piece design is awkward and inconvenient.  I was honestly shocked to find out that's how it worked.  And now the worst part: the silicone cover over the home button is so poorly designed that I feel like I'm going to break my iPad--through the dang OtterBox--because of how hard I have to press it to work.  You literally need to align your finger with the center of the button, hold the back of the OtterBox, and squeeze it to make it work.
summary: So inconvenient I've stopped using my iPad.

reviewText: This product is great.  Other reviews accurately capture it's benefits, especially the rotation feature. Would highly recommed it to anyone.

Bought this a couple months ago to serve primarily as a stand and occasional case that might be more frequent depending on work.  Product was shipped same day and arrived 2 business days later with regular shipping.  At first, I have to admit I was a little skeptical of the vegan leather, but after using it for a few hours any questions about the durability faded.  As a case, I find it perfect for carrying from room to room, slim and you're able to hold it in one hand like a loaf of bread.  I haven't used it in this manner yet but it seems very suitable for stashing in a knapsack for travel.  Because it doesn't completely cover the iPad it can't be used in rain and it doesn't haven't any handles or straps for carrying.As a stand, the design allows it to slide effortlessly, in either horizontal or vertical mode. The iPad slides snugly into a plastic portion and can be detached fairly easily though. None of the buttons or openings on the front or the sides such as power or volume are covered or are hard to get to.In its primary stand mode, it allows for two angles via ridges on the bottom.  This is the only weakness IMO - ideally 2 extra ridges would've allowed for greater flexibility for those times you want a steeper angle for reading or a very decreased angle for typing.  However, this is mostly mitigated by the fact you can fold the case over so it can be a stand whose angle you can choose at your leisure.  For those like me who use your iPad mostly on your bed, sofa or on your chest, this is ideal.  If you use it on your desk or table, this second stand option might be less ideal as the stand has less traction on lacquered surfaces.A few weeks after I purchased this item, the stand started sliding down, sometimes with minimal pressure, when inserted into either of the two ridges.  A few days after I received the item, Devicewear sent me an email that politely asked how I find the product and to contact them should any trouble arise.  I bring this up because 1) it shows their confidence in their product as well as commitment to customer satisfaction and 2) after having so many negative customer service experiences over the years the last thing I wanted was to argue or wait on the phone or even by email, and my first instinct was to look online for replacement cases/stands.  However, I emailed Devicewear, received a response a few hours later, and within a couple of days the problem I had was resolved to my complete satisfaction.I would not hesitate to purchase another case as well as any other products from Devicewear I the future.
summary: Great product, even better customer service

reviewText: I recently purchased a Garmin 3590 has a very reflective glass screen. When the sun hit it the glare can completely wash out the screen and I can't see a thing so much so that I considered returning the GPS and buying a model with a different type of screen. Since as I said the screen is glass I also needed to protect it from any scratches.  The only thing that will accomplish both of these goals is a screen protector. This is not the first screen protector I have used and I didn't have good luck with the others but based on the reviews I had read I decided to give this brand a try before I returned the GPS.  The shipping costs are a little less if you order directly from the manufacture site. The confusing thing was in ordering it gave me the option for glare reduction  protector and crystal view. I don't know if they have different protectors but I selected glare reduction.In the package they send they also include two rubber covers for your fingers. I just used a pair of disposable latex gloves so that I would not smudge the face of the GPS when applying the cover. Others had said it didn't cover the face of the Garmin but I didn't find that to be a problem.  As with any of these screen protectors applying it without any air bubbles is a major task I was successful in getting most of them out but there are still a few on the edges and I know over time dust will get in those areas and I will have to replace the protector (that is why you should buy 2).Does it work?I have found that it does cut down on the glare from the sun.  The 3590 has a very crisp screen since it is made out of glass and the protector does cut down on the crispness of the screen but I am willing to make that tradeoff. Another Important part of these screen protectors is that they do not interfere with touch screen operation of the GPS unit. With screen protectors I had used in the past after applying them to the face of the GPS they did seem to impede the responsiveness of the touch screen function. So much so that I removed them and threw them away. So far I have not found that to be the case for this protector. Touch screen operation seems to work normally.Would I buy again?Definitely (and probably will since I only ordered one to test it out) . It does what it claims to do, now if someone could invent a fool proof way of applying it so there are no air bubbles that would be great!

I have two of the IPAD 3's and consider them apendages !I have spent a snall fortune on cases for strength,pretty cases,cases that can stand a tankrolling over them,cases with color on one side and another product for the back.I have tried every product here on Amazon,it's like dressing a kid !My engineer son took forever to buy a case for only one,he's always gotta checkevery thing out to the tiny degree,while color has sold me on everything practically.And then to combine color and good strength,wowzer I will take two of them !!I went over to my son's home and was anxious to show off my latest hot color cases,plus thoughtI would jump up and down on them to show them off.There he sat with his plain black case,no spare case,no showing off,just silently sat thereonly lifting his head to say..oh Lord mother,more cases ?? (We call them cases,sleeves,whatever)He then  handed me his plain black IPAD.The first thing I said was,wow..I like the feel of this !I loved the way I could hold onto it safely with one hand with my hand down at my side,likeholding a book. I really liked the way the stickiness of it allowed me to lean it against somethingand it didn't slide out at the bottom. I liked the superb fit !It's good looking,really fits great,except for something weird on black ones that fit slightly looser at thebottom. Not enuff to turn me off it.Well,to wind up this long story,I now have a box full of very well built,pretty cases,sleeveswhatever you want to call them. And by the way,there is nothing wrong with any of them,it's just that my new blsckand white cases are better !!I can't imagine getting any thing else,and I did notice now they have a very pretty pink one that's just come out.HahaSo I have total of 4 products from Amzer,and not only do I have my beautiful colors,but I feel I have the best case by far.And I paid less for it than any other cases I bought.Simply the best and the most beautiful colors !!  I  give their product a 5 !!The color of blue,white,black,hot pink are gorgeous rich colors also,best I have seen.

This is a great inexpensive clear iPad cover!I bought this for my new iPad 3 and fits perfectly!  All ports are accessible and the cover does not obstruct anything!  I bought this primarily to cover the back of my iPad since i am in between getting cover/case keyboard combo. So far, this is working out just fine by protecting the back and just using my iPad soft sleeve.If anyone is just looking for soomething to protect the back only, then this is just for you!

This card is beyond amazing. I used to have an xfx card it sounded like airplane having trouble lifting off. Even with fan control with afterburner it was still very loud.the sapphire 7870 is not only absolutely silent but it does a terrific job27-35 degrees C for idle.. and after Guild wars2 at max settings for 2 hours, it was at 37 degrees.it gave 7.9 on windows 7 index score.my computer is so silent now that all i hear is the keyboard typing. simply awesome.If you are looking for a quality card with some power yet silent, you cannot go wrong with this card.my only problem is that it only has one DVI plug = no more dual monitors for me.it has 2 mini HDMI and also comes with converters + crossfire cable as well.I will try to run more "stress" test and let you guys no. but so far I am very happy with this purchase and  I can finally leave my computer on for the night .. it's so quiet!

This is a great little item that is very easy to use, and I'm sure it will provide years of helpful service.  The only negative issue I have is that I ordered a Green model, but a Gray/Black one was shipped to me by Amazon!!

The first impression of the Eton ARCFRX2WXR Am/FM Weather Radio Solar NOAA by Eton is CHEAP. The materials are cheap, the construction is cheap, the feel of the controls are cheap and it's low end in a world of high tech. I live a half hour from town and pick up very little of the AM/FM stations and NOAA is barely audible with sunny skies so I really doubt it'll work during a storm when I need it. Fully extending the antenna did nothing to help. The station controls are mushy and lack any smooth dialing. The flashlight has three LED lights which are extremely weak which may be good if you're under a house destroyed by a tornado but not so good if you have to walk through miles of woods at night to get help. All external parts are plastic - even the crank. In my testing I found the solar power to be very poor. I placed the unit out in direct bright sunlight for half the day but received less then five minutes of radio time when turned on. The instructions say I should get around 3 hours of play out of 10-12 hours of solar charging.The crank is not hard to turn and works well. The instructions say five minutes of cranking will get you 10 minutes of low volume play. My tests show five minutes of cranking will give you hand cramps and about five minutes of play time. In an emergency that is fine but my concern is will this unit work when you need it three years from now. I've owned nice crank flashlights that didn't work after sitting for more then a year without use.Why are batteries not an option? Would that have been to hard to add? With battery technology today one could get hours of play time from a radio. However the radio does come with a headphone jack in case you want to listen to NOAA Radio in private.I do not have a smart phone that I can test the charger on. The instructions say 10-15 minutes of cranking will get you 1 minute or more of talk time. Of course you'll have to catch your breath first.Overall I do not feel comfortable keeping this radio as my sole emergency unit. My advice is to spend the extra money and get an emergency radio that takes batteries and has much better reception. This radio would be better kept in your tackle box then your basement.
summary: Wouldn't Want To Trust My Life On It

reviewText: I pulled this out of the box, noticed the warranty seal was already broken (sent me a refurbished unit?) so I opened it up to have a look. Been obvious on-board re-work that has taken place (grease all messy and strong indicators of being re-worked.Fired it up, regulated nice voltage (set to 13.8V). I dropped on a 0.5 ohm load (~28amps) and within about 15 seconds the PTC thermistor on-board started smoking and stinking.Shut it down, replaced it with a known good slightly higher current one (it was rated at 6A and was north of 200C in temp when I shut it down) The one I removed was an NTC 5D-15.Fired it back up, things looked good.Bridge rectifier didn't have a heatsink so I added one (for good measure).Other heatsinks were loose-ish so I tightened things down and got proper placement. I added a small heat sink to the new PTC thermistor and called it good. (idles in room temp with the fan off at about 100-120C and 80-90C with it on). Fan turns on after about 30seconds of full load output. It's pretty quiet. Voltage dip is minimal (and adjustable up to almost 15 volts).Not sure how this is going to do with large (>20A) loads regularly but we shall see. I am using it at 13.8 to float charge batteries however not sure how well it is going to current limit itself.Main board is single sided kinda crappy (but what you expect for the low price). The power supply 'brain' is off-board in a corner (obviously some other vendor's device). That's all SMD (the rest of the unit is through hole).I'll report back if/when it blows up. It's replacing an application where I've had THREE (3) 'current limited' >$200 13.8V supplies blow up (two switching, one linear) all in the 20-30A range.
summary: Okay for the money, if you add some parts

reviewText: Plain language:The picture on my 19" HD Samsung TV using the Joey was not as clear and clean as it was when I used Dish's older receiver.  On a scale between a Standard TV's picture and a HDTV's picture, the Joey produced a very nice "Standard" picture on my HDTV. Sometimes I could see some High Dif...The Hopper itself produced a decent picture, but between using folders and looking for info on the guide, it had a tendency to black out for about 10 seconds only to bring you back to the picture your watching.  You can create all the folders you want, but only a few actually worked.Did you notice I used the word "had"?  After 2 weeks, I had Dish change out the Hopper and the Joey for the older equipment.  Now I have a clear, beautiful picture on both tv's.  I have basic DVR functions without all the bells and whistles of the Hopper and Joey.I think Dish knows there is a problem with quality of the Hopper and Joey.  They didn't even questions my desire to change.
summary: Not quite ready for Prime Time

reviewText: So far this card seems to destroy any games I throw at it. Put it in my x79 system and I have had it benched at 380fps. Card looks nice and installed with no issues.

This is the worst motherboard that I have ever had the misfortune of owning. It is unreliable and I'm at the point now, where I have to hard start it every half hour or so due to freezes. Overclocking? Don't even think about it, as this motherboard can't even handle normal clocks. It's just cheaply made and a quick money-maker for AsRock. When I bought this motherboard, I had checked all of the professional reviews which were praising this board. I had never owned this brand before, but naively thought that I would take a chance and if anything ever went wrong, I could just RMA it. Don't kid yourself. Just go with a better board and save yourself some money, time and headaches.If you notice, this motherboard has great reviews from all of the big reviewers. However, don't be fooled. These professional reviewers get a sample in, test it and then report their findings. They says nothing for the board's quality, which is where the Extreme 6 suffers. On paper, the features look great and you will likely even be pleased for the first week. However, when the MB starts breaking down after that, you are going to be sorry that you wasted your money. There is nothing like having a computer that you can't rely on. I'm in college and so couldn't get any work done on my computer, as I couldn't rely on it not freezing every 20 minutes. Sure, you can send it back to AsRock for an RMA, that is -if you can get a hold of anyone. I had to call the vendor where I bought this MB, and have them contact AsRock on my behalf. Then, it takes several weeks for them to receive the board that you mailed in and to ship out another one, refurbished that likely has the same quality issues.Save yourself a lot of headaches and go with a better brand, even if you have to spend more money. It will save you headaches and ultimately save you money. I had to shell out even more money for a different motherboard from a more respectable company. I wish I had never took a chance on AsRock or this board. Oh well, I'll chalk it up to a lesson learned.
summary: Worst motherboard that I have ever owned

reviewText: Compared with the last version of the Audio Technica nose reduction headphones, these provide much better noise cancellation when set at its highest level.  There are three modes which are selected by pushing the button below the power switch.  Changing modes take about 2-3 seconds as the noise cancellation turns off then turns on again in the new mode.  Each mode has its own color light but which is which is not mentioned on the headphones themselves so you need to remember.  Also comparison between modes is difficult because of the lag in change and the fact that noise cancellation turns off completely for a couple of seconds when you switch.  If the switching between modes was instantaneous and without turning off it would make the headphones much better.Another down side for travelers is that for some reason the case has become noticeably fatter.  Where the old case slimmed down a bit where the headband portion of the headphones was stored, the new case does not and instead has about a 3/4 inch shelf for the band to rest on and a commensurate increase in case size.  The headphones themselves are a bit bigger also so the rest of the case is also fatter. This is a definite negative for frequent travelers.Another negative I have found it a humming feedback when I use on the highest level with my notebook computer.  When I touch the notebook case the hum goes away so there is a grounding issue with the headphones or my notebook and I am not sure this is happen to everyone.I have been using the Audio Technica noise canceling headphones for about 10 years and this is my third pair.  I have the Bose ones but like Audio Technica better and they are a much better value.  If you are inclined to upgrade, you may want to wait until the next model when hopefully the above problems are solved and the case slimmed down to its former size.
summary: Better noise cancellation, bigger case, some flaws

reviewText: I was working on a DIY (do it yourself) glidecam and this product was just right by price and functionality. I tried to make DIY slider myself, but I would never could make it with that high precision.These are two sliders, connected one over another, can slide your camera in two axises very smooth and pretty accurate. It's important, when you adjusting delicate balance with glidecam. The slider has a scale, so you can remember position for different lenses. I gave 4 stars because in my opinion the fix screw does not seem to be holding firm enough. You have to put an extra afford to fix the slider at chosen position. Other than that, I'm happy, that I got this sliders. The only draw back is 2.5 weeks of delivery from China to California.The dimensions of one part are about 160mm long, 50mm wide and 20mm high. So it's 40mm high, when you connect them together. The moving part slides within 80mm (8cm). The screw bolts and holes fit for standard camera or tripod.

The capacity of thumb drives keeps going up and the sizes keep going down.  They are so convenient for off-site backup.  This is probably about as small as is practical.  I think it is about the smallest flash drive I have seen.  About the size of a stick of Dentine gum.  This is not particularly high capacity by today's standards, but 8 GB is not that small either.  It's good for transporting a number of small files or a few larger ones or a backup of data if you don't have too much data.  Great for a key chain too, as it has a nice big loop on the end.  After I inserted it on a Windows 7 PC, it was up and ready to use in seconds.  On XP it wanted to reboot after it had been inserted, but I tried it without rebooting and it appeared to work fine.  Two minor issues with this drive.  It doesn't have a conventional USB plug.  Instead it looks like a little 3-contact connector.  At first I wondered how I would insert it into my USB port.  Believe me it does go in, but one problem I had was which direction to insert it.  It fits into one side of a USB connection in either direction.  In one direction it works of course and one it doesn't.  The other problem is that the connection hides under a little bendable rubber piece and my USB ports are recessed, so I couldn't bend the rubber enough to easily insert it.  If you want a very tiny storage unit that works great, this is for you.  I have always had excellent results with any Verbatim products too and I full trust their quality and reliability.

The unexpected feature:  The cover magnetically attaches to the back when you have it folded around.  I don't know of any other cover that does this, which is handier than you would think.There is also a way to fold the cover in half to use it as a more steeply angled stand.  This doesn't work too well, except for watching videos or other applications where you don't have to touch the device much,  but it isn't advertised as a feature, either.I like the fact that this cover protects all the way around, and is just a little "grippy."The holes are just the right size for charging or ear phone listening.I don't hink that there is a better case of this kind anywhere, and the web sites that make a living reviewing and comparing the huge number of alternatives agree.  It's probably not fair to mention those sites on here, but i looked at several, and this guy made the top ten, top five, top one.
summary: Perfect fit, Great protection, One unexpected feature

reviewText: I bought (I was longing for a tablet like that for a long time) the Note in an effort to minimize my paper use and better organize my notes. I am working on multiple projects, and having multiple notebooks or using loose paper (for archiving) is a big hassle. The S-Pen works fantastic! The supplied software works great, except one thing: the PDFs produced by S Note are not vector based, i.e., when you zoom they get pixelated. If you care about having vector based PDF output, you can get "Papyrus" and/or "Quill" from the Android market. Both work awesome for note taking!The battery holds up very well, I was using it pretty much constantly between 9am and 4PM and it was only down to 50%. It is very fast and smooth. The only that bothers me a little, is the custom charging cable that needs its own power supply (no computer charge).Edit: it turns out that the note does charge on any USB charger despite the red x that might appear. Keep in mind that this is a very slow charge and if you are doing something intensive on the tablet it  may not charge at all. At least is better than nothing.

Comparing the Note to the iPad 3 is like comparing a multifunctional Range Rover to a Lexus sedan. Both nice, but not in the same league.  The iPad is a quality device, but the Note just does so much more; it's in a completely different league. If you're looking for something iPad-like, look elsewhere. The Note is much more than an app tray.It's not just the S-Pen either. It's the split-screen multitasking, the customization, 2mp front camera (iPad is VGA), quad core processor, removable/expandable memory card slot, full flash browser, live widgets. Then there's the floating video option which floats a video so you can 'watch' whilst multitasking. iPad 3 has none of this.The S-Pen is so exacting, making the Note ideal for editors, students, artists & business folks. If you just hover the pen over an email or movie, a preview will pop up. Most laptops don't have these goodies.To be fair, the iPad has nicer hardware and a higher pixel density screen. iTunes is far superior to Google Music, however, iTunes is quite limiting. The Note allows me to download free music from 4shared or beemp3 & send it w/o having to purchase it. There's a torrent app called aDownloader which can download free movies because Android isn't as locked-down as iOS. The iPad is a quality tablet, but, like the iPhone, it's just an app tray.I would recommend the iPad for kids or older folks who want something simple & don't need all of Note's goodies. For those who just want to surf the net, send emails, watch movies & play with apps, the iPhone is much more simple and direct. Grandma could pick up an iPad & start using it. That's precisely Apple's charm. There's nothing to configure or customize - squares on a screen & very well executed.The Galaxy Note 10.1 is a high-tech device that Samsung just doesn't know how to promote or market. The iPad is a high quality tablet, but it operates like a big iPhone with limited memory. With all the Note's tech, customization and unique features, it is simply in a league of its own.

I just received this tablet 3 days ago & would like to offer my first impressions. The SGN 10.1 is my second tablet, the first being the original Kindle Fire. Sorry Amazon, I really enjoyed my Fire, but there were too many "cons" on my list to consider purchasing the new Kindle Fire HD.When researching my new tablet, I looked at all available options.  I decided I really did want the larger screen, so it boiled down to choosing the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 or SGN 10.1.  What really sold me on the Note was the hardware: 1.4 GHz QUAD-core processor and 2GB of RAM. I have a need for speed and thought the additional expense would be worth it. I wasn't really concerned with the S Pen at all, but now that I've had a chance to play with it, I can see how I will use it frequently. The micro-SD expansion slot and volume control buttons were also very important to me. And, I am looking forward to taking my first road trip and using the GPS.This tablet is super fast. Several pre-loaded apps have the ability to multi-task and the tablet doesn't slow down when doing so. Wi-fi is incredibly strong in areas of my home where other devices have weak signals. There's a great selection of apps optimized for tablets from Google Play, Amazon App Store, and Samsung Apps. The front 5MP camera (with LED flash!) takes decent photos and videos, especially for social networking apps like Instagram & Twitter. I haven't used the front facing camera for video calls yet. The Peer IR remote easily synced with my Sony TV and Brighthouse cable box. I have read other reviews of people complaining about the screen resolution. I really don't understand.  The screen is bright and the colors are vibrant. Pictures and videos are stunning. And from what I understand, the lower (comparatively speaking) resolution helps save battery consumption.The only disappointment I have so far is the proprietary charge/data cable.  I wish it had a micro-usb port.So if you have the cash in your budget, I highly recommend the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1!

This tablet is without a doubt an excellent product. I've had it for about 8 months and I can't really say there's anything that bothers me. I paid full price and I believe it was worth it. So far battery life is just as good as it was when the tablet was new and I believe even when watching videos ans playing music, the battery holds up pretty well. Aside from the obvious, which would be sending email, browsing the web and streaming music and video, which this tablet does well, there are a few features that I love. First, I love being able to search my files just like I would in a computer by using folders. The integration between the Xbox and the tablet is awesome, being able to use my tv screen by having my Xbox on and controlling music, video and picture slides from the tablet is amazing and it makes everything so easy. Being able to access files from my Samsung galaxy s3 and send files directly to the phone works great as well. There's 2 Samsung tablets and 2 Samsung phones in the house and all the products work great together. Other than that I think the touchscreen and keyboard are both fast and responsive, the system crashes rarely and the tablet seems to handle all apps without any lag or any major issues. I still ask myself, what's not to love about the galaxy tab 2 10.1? I love everything. If I were to get a tablet now, I would get this tablet again. My boyfriend just got the smaller one and he loves it just as much!

On the surface, this looks like an ideal photo accessory.  It's a tripod, a monopod, a min-tripod, and even more.  However, in execution, it's just not ready, yet.Premise:  I purchased this so that I could have a compact, lightweight monopod to travel and hike with that could also be used as a tripod in a pinch.Weight:  VERY heavy considering it's size.  My full-size carbon fiber tripod with ball head weighs about the same.  This thing would make a good police night stick.  The upside to this is that it feels like a solid, high quality product.Ease of use:  The twist-lock extension is extremely hard to work with.  When you twist it to lock , it can become very difficult to unlock---so much so that Sony had to drill a hold in the side for a knob so you can get extra leverage.  On the other hand, I once had a section collapse down when I didn't twist lock enough.Size:  It's not that compact in reality.  I have a small Manfrotto tripod that I use for flashes that is shorter than this monopod.Tripod Stability:  This was the final decider for returning the multipod.  When used as a tripod at full height, it's just too wobbly.  I put my Nikon D7000 with a small prime lens on it and was scared it would tip over.  This camera/lens combo is below the 4 pound limit Sony suggests and the center of gravity is almost directly over the mount point.  To be fair, the wobbliness has nothing to do with the rigidity of the multipod; it's the small tripod portion supporting weight at that 5 ft. height that's the issue.  Even with a small camcorder or point and shoot (or even nothing at all attached), it's still going to be wobbly just because the multipod is top heavy and the footprint of the tripod portion is so small.Monopod:  Too heavy and too "indoor" to use walking around.  For a wedding, it might be OK, but so would any simple monopod.Ball head:  The included ball head is very basic and small.  I had difficulty getting the camera mound locked into the head at times.  The multipod does have a standard screw-on top, though, so you can fit any head you currently own to it.Versatility:  The multipod does all it advertises--and that may be it's biggest flaw and the reason it and any others designed to do everything will ultimately prove unsatisfactory.  You can't make a minivan into a sports car and maybe you can't make a single camera mount into every mount you might need.Price:  I got this during a Black Cyber Friday Monday deal for a great price.  At it's regular price point, and given it's limitations, it's not worth anything close to what Sony believes.  I can certainly see how much R&D; is tied up in this and how much attention was paid to quality control, but it's just not worth it.Positives:  The tripod portion makes a GREAT tabletop tripod.  The bag reconfigures into any size you need and is very very cool with it's ability to be used as a "flag holder" (see the pics).  Construction feels very high quality.Recommendation:  If you are thinking about ordering this, I'd look at it as a great table top tripod with an occasional use as a monopod or tripod (if no kids, dogs, etc. will bump into it).  Also, if someone breaks into your house, you can always beat them over the head with it.Maybe next time, Sony.

The USB ports were not working in the original device that was shipped to me. I received an email from Mediabridge asking for feedback about my purchase. I replied to the email and informed them that the USB ports were not working and they sent me a fully functional replacement product without any hassle. I didn't even need to waste time shipping the faulty surge protector back to them.I am completely satisfied with the fully functional replacement that I received. The 3 prongs that plug into a power outlet can fold in for easier storage and they pop back out relatively easily. I can charge my Kindle Fire and my cell phone at the same time. This means that I don't need to travel with both AC adapters. Additionally, I have the benefit of surge protection in the 3 power outlets so I can protect my laptop while I'm traveling.

I was waiting for the inevitable price drop for the Radeon 7950 series so I latched onto the MSI Twin Frozr version when it came down. It was easy to install, is quieter than a stock 7950 and has a fairly aggressive default overclock so I don't have to mess around tweaking the frequencies. It was a good deal at a bit over $300 net after the rebate.

I purchased these after my gym set of headphones died, I have never heard of Vsonic but being that they had such great reviews on headfi.com I decided to give these a shot. The headphones I have owned are: Shure eC3 (My favorite set of all time..but had durability issues had 2 pairs each died after only 1 yr), Creative Aurvana (stolen), Klipsch S4 (Hated those), Creative Aurvana 2, UE TF10's (Still have them but never was wow'd by them, Sony MDR EX600 (Amazing just hated fit and how I looked wearing them) and now Vsonic GR06. In terms of best value the GR06 wins hands down, I actually prefer them over the TF10's and Sony MDREX 600 for outside of the house use. The Fit is excellent they give you a bunch of different tips although I still couldn't get one that gave me a snug fit, I purchased Sony Hybrid tips and they gave me the perfect fit and seal (for use at the gym). The profile or look of the headphones is also excellent, my major gripe with the Sony Ex600's and TF10's was that I couldn't get over how big they looked or how dumb I looked wearing them outside, I tried to get over the who cares how you look as long as they sound good but in the end couldn't. I also couldn't get a good fit with the Sony Ex600's or good isolation (picked up the most outside noise). The TF10's stick out of your ear and got uncomfortable over time, but the Vsonic GR06 fit the best providing the best fit and isolation (prob rate 8-10 you can still hear some outside noise once in a while). In terms of sound quality I would give it a 9/10 (for the price), I remember purchasing the Klipsch S4 and being extremely disappointed after all the hype but I was extremely impressed after not knowing what to expect from this little known company. The only headphones that sounded better to me were the Shure eC3, Sony Ex 600 and TF10's, the GR06 is either half or 1/3rd of the price. Some cons is that the GR06 doesn't have replaceable cables, although I have read from numerous forums that Vsonic has excellent build quality and no one has and an issue with the wires it still would've been nice just in case, but then again replaceable cables are only found on higher end headphones (I ended up getting the GR07 as well for non gym use to replace my TF10's and they don't have replaceable cables either..fingers crossed).I wouldn't consider myself and audiophile, I don't understand the concepts of soundstage, drivers and etc but I do know what sounds good to me and these sound good to me. I would highly recommend these for anyone looking to replace apple headphones, stock headphones or just want the best bang for your buck headphone under $100, there maybe some better options right at the $100 during amazon sales (TF10's, UE 700, etc) but there is nothing normally under $100 or even at $50 for that matter that can compete with these. Don't hesitate to buy them you won't regret it!

We originally had the 'Motorola SB6121 DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem' but had too many problems with dropped connections.  We replaced it with this modem and have not had any dropped connections.  We've had it for about 10 days.  Works flawlessly.
summary: Linksys DPC3008-CC Advanced DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem (Comcast ISP Only)

reviewText: I bought an adapter for my Dell 1555, however that one didn't work (it had the warning of not recognizing adapter). So I bought this item, although it didn't have any review yet, this one works perfectly!

This tablet is very fast, even faster than the Asus transformer prime! However it has some things that could use improvement. First off the cameras, mediocre front facing NOT HD for sure and back camera has a weak flash and bad image quality. I wouldn't take pictures with this tablet. Then you have the LCD light bleed problem, mine wasn't as bad as others I saw on reviews but still bothers me. Would you like to see YELLOW spots on your tablet corners when displaying black? Then the battery life! Holly **** , Toshiba has let me down before in the battery department but this was out of proportion.Total of 5:45 hours browsing with wifi (45min playing angry birds or listening to music without wifi) All of this with auto brightness, no GPS or bluetooth. Whats up with 10 hour claims made by Toshiba??? This is not acceptable. I bought this after having wifi problems with my Asus Transformer Prime and a really bad GPS. After returning this thing I don't if tablets are the way to go. I'm seriously considering sticking to a laptop, Apple isn't a choice for me. Remember, all tablets(exception Toshiba Thrive) have non removable batteries.. Battery life is very important in these devices.

Received this product after returning Vizio Vtab1008. Product is working great for the most part. It runs fast, 64gb sd works great. no problems the first week or 2. now 3 weeks later the bottom of the screen byt the right speaker looks to be lifting up like it was held together by some kind of sticky adhesive. I am very protective of anything i buy and i do not let my wife or even my 4 yr old play with this. This item has no scratches and never been dropped. this is un exceptable for $450 tablet. going to send back and hope new one does not does this.

After trying out 3 ten inch android tablets I consider this the most practical and useful in the current flock.For the price and features it can't be beaten.Used the HDMI output, USB for Bluetooth mouse/keyboard and external HDD, SD card for memory expansion and viewing images taken on my camera.Toshiba upgraded the os to 4.1Good screen, good battery life and good performance.Minor light bleed does exists.

reviewerName: TyCo "Learn to accept rejection and reject ac...
reviewText: I received this tablet (the 32GB version) on Tuesday and after a couple days to get used to it here's what I found;Overall I really like the tablet.  It's fast, very fast, very thin & light, runs most apps without any issues (some apps won't work with it but this is only because the developers haven't put it on the list of compatible devices.  i.e. Lets Golf 3 won't run on it, I'm sure it will be updated to work though.  This tablet definitely has enough power to run it).  There's no way I've found to root it yet though.  I'll keep it as I'm sure someone will come up with a way sooner than later.Some other reviewers have said the sound is too low.  This is fixable by going into the audio enhancement settings and click on SRS sound boost.  With this on the volume is just fine.  The stereo separation is very good too (two speakers located on the bottom side of the device)This tablet has a pretty big proprietary connector on the supplied USB cable. It should last a while, it better be tough for the size of it.  This brings up an interesting point.  When you plug in the tablet with this cable to your computer, nothing happens other than it will charge the tablet.  On all of our computers (5 of them) windows wouldn't recognize the tablet was attached.  When you plug in the tablet with a micro USB cable the computer will recognize it.  It's a bummer they use a huge connector on a cable that only charges the tablet and then only at 5v.  Takes a long time to charge.  On the upside you can use external battery pack chargers (you can get 10000+mAh batteries for around $60 on Amazon that will provide a lot of spare power.Toshiba tech support from my limited experience with them is awful.  I called about transferring files via the supplied cable and they were no help.I also had an issue using the USB host functionality trying to use an external hard drive and found via their tech support it will only support drives formatted to exFAT, FAT or FAT32.  DOES NOT support drives formatted to NTFS.  This is very odd...  I had to back up a 750GB Oyen Digital hard drive, reformat it and then transfer the files (mostly movies and TV shows) back to it.  Took forever.  Now that the drive is formatted to exFAT it works perfectly.  Just plug it in using a micro USB host cable (purchased separately) and viola, it shows up on the file explorer (both the stock file explorer and ES file explorer).PROS:* It's very light and thin* It's super-fast.  I scored a little over 10300 on AnTuTu benchmark, and this is with the tablet loaded up with apps (my xoom would only do 6700 or so).  Once I can root it and overclock it a bit I'm sure it'll be one of the fastest tablets around.* Full sized SD card support.  I'm using a 64GB card and it works great.  I'm sure it'll handle a 128GB card.  If I spring for one I'll update this review if it doesn't.* Some of the bloatware is un-installable (the demo app, games etc.).  You don't need to unable them, but that is an option if you want to keep them on the device.* Screen image is sharp (although there is a fair amount of light bleed - see the cons)* Gorilla Glass* Handles 1080p video well, although the native video players doesn't handle many video formats. Use "MX Player", free on the market and will play anything.* Screen is very responsive.  Almost too responsive, when you go to touch an icon if your finger is moving at all left or right it will start to scroll the page and you'll need to touch the icon again to open the app.* Very good wifi and GPS reception.* Stock browser works great.  Haven't had a force close yet (this would happen all the time on my Xoom, even after I upgraded it to ICS).* USB host functionality is great (many devices need to be rooted to get this to work).* Charging off of a standard USB port is nice, but it takes a long time to fully charge.* Battery life is pretty good.  I've been getting around 8 hours of actual use (mix of streaming vids, checking email, etc).* Boot time is fast.  I clocked 55 seconds from off to the lock screen showing up and then another 10-15 seconds for widgets to load.CONS:* Lots of light bleed.  Not very noticeable if you're watching something with a lot of light but during dark scenes it's a little annoying.* Proprietary charging cable that only seems to charge the tablet.* Charging takes a looong time* No way to root yet.  After some digging around it looks like it might be awhile before a rooting method is released... This is a real bummer.* Can only handle FAT formats if you use an external hard drive.* Some apps aren't compatible with it, yet.* You have to click the notification area a few times sometimes to get it to open up.That's about it.  Overall I really like this tablet and can't wait for a rooting method to be released.  If I notice anything else that needs to be addressed I'll update this review.  Feel free to ask any questions and I'll help if I can!
summary: The good, the bad and the ugly... (it's a great tablet overall)

reviewText: So far I've owned the ASUS Transformer Prime (TF201), Acer Iconia Tab A510, and now the Toshiba AT305. The TF201 had build quality and wireless/GPS issues and the A510 had a "grid effect" to the LCD and some bad heat issues (106+ degrees). And now the AT305, which has light bleed issues. The sad part is that despite this annoying "issue," it's still the best Tegra 3 tablet out there.As with the Acer and Asus, I've already gone through two AT305's just to make sure these issues were consistent. But let's go into a bit more of a detailed review first on the AT305 that I've been using for a few days now.DESIGN:Out of the box, initial impressions are very good. The tablet has a great solid feel to it, it's comfortable to hold, thin, and yes, even light weight. The back has a hard, smooth, plastic feel to it - although I hear its aluminum. If so, it probably has some type of coating on it. Basically, it's one nice looking tablet.I won't go into details regarding where everything is or what feature it has, as you can easily see this from the pictures. Although the one item I must point out is the SD Card Slot, which is on the right side. There is a blank filler card that must be removed when you want to use your own SD card. While the addition of a full-size SD slot is very welcome, there is nothing to cover the slot once your card is in there.So your hand will frequently rub against the sharp inside edges of the plastic casing. I'm normally not a big fan of plastic covers, but in this instance, it would have been very nice to have. If you're planning on getting a case, this won't likely be an issue.WIRELESS:I've tested both wireless and GPS extensively and found them to both perform very well. I'm able to maintain a solid WiFi connection even at the furthest reaches of my Access Point. And GPS can actually pick up a few satellite in-doors, which is always impressive. Outside I can get accuracy down to less than 18ft, within 1-2 minutes. This of course was verified with the GPS Test application.PERFORMANCE:Overall the device is very snappy and I haven't had any issues that I didn't run into with the other Tegra3 devices on Android 4.0.3. There are still a few occasional bugs or glitches with ICS, which I hope they'll resolve soon. Otherwise, nothing specific to the AT305.Antutu scored a 10,313 and Quadrant is right at 4,000.  I've seen slightly higher Antutu scores on the A510, which was closer to 11k. Although as I recall, this is the highest Quadrant score I've seen to date. Keeping in mind that both devices I had scored nearly identical. And in either case, the scores are subjective and personally don't put a whole lot of faith in them.Until they have some new benchmarks that really take advange of the quad core CPU and Tegra3, they're just something to give you interesting numbers to look at. :) Real world tests are where it's at. Speaking of which, playing Tegra 3 games is smooth and they all run expectedly nice. Surfing the web, running apps, and other such tasks are all as expected. Quite good.After watching movies and playing games, I got temps as high as 93 degrees on the back, right side. This was determined by my infrared thermometer. It's not as cool as the 85 degree TF201 but also nowhere near the 106+ degree A510. So I consider that to be on the warm side, but not uncomfortably so. I think the material on the back Toshiba uses helps to dissipate the heat so it doesn't "feel" hot or uncomfortable.While surfing or running normal apps, the temps were staying in the 80's where it should be.DISPLAY:Starting positive here, the LCD does look very nice. In fact, of the TF201 and A510, it's the nicest I've seen. Even though it's not IPS (it's TFT as I recall), it looks great. The images are very crisp, colors are vibrant, and it has surprisingly good contrast ratio. The best part is that they've found a very nice color temperature balance.While the A510 was very cool and the TF201 was on the warm side, I found the AT305 to quite neutral. This makes it very pleasing to use whether you are reading, surfing, playing games, or watching a movie.But of course we can't ignore the negative part of this. There is light bleed, and it just makes me very sad. You won't notice this on any normal colorful image. But if you're watching a movie or looking at a picture that has a black background at the edges, you'll see a very uneven amount of light emitting from the sides. And the more you turn up the brightness, the worse it is.In fact, just powering on the tablet, you'll see this on the Toshiba logo as it has a black background. It was exactly the same with both AT305's I got. And it's not something I ever experienced with any other tablet I've owned or used. Normally, this is considered a defect and swapping it out would resolve the issue. But based on my experience and countless other reviews/posts on-line, this is quite common with the AT305.Whether you call it a defect, poor build quality, or a cheap display, it's not desirable.BATTERY:Just in general, when you make something smaller, you tend to make some sacrifices. In this case, it was the battery life. To test it out, I started with a fully charged battery. Then basically used it non-stop until I got down to 20% remaining, at which point we were right at 6 hours of usage. This isn't very good. Although keeping mind this is "heavy" usage. I was downloading a bunch of apps, playing games, watching movies, and even ran a benchmark or two during that time.So I'd say heavy usage, you're looking at 7+ hours. Personally I don't like allowing the battery get much lower than 20%, so that's normally about the time I'm looking for a power cord. And yes, the power adapter is straight out of the 90's. There's no reason it needs to be that big; but it is, and I got over it.For me, with "normal usage," I'm easily lasting the entire day on a single charge. This is mostly because I don't use it non-stop and spend most of the time checking e-mail or surfing the web. And overall, it's a fair compromise for its light weight and thinness.SPEAKERS:As with the A510, the AT305 has down-firing speakers at the bottom, and there are in fact two of them (unlike the TF201). They are backed by Toshiba and SRS enhancements, which are definitely needed. If these sound enhancements are turned off, the sound is horrible. But with them on, the speakers actually sound pretty descent.I do suggest turning on the "boost" function if it's not loud enough. Surprisingly even with that turned on and volume maxed out, there is no distortion. The A510's speakers still sound noticeably better as there is most detail and they have a fuller sound. The TF305 has a tendency to sound a bit muffled at times, depending on how you're holding it.I still wish they'd put them forward facing. Otherwise, I find them perfectly acceptable and wouldn't mind watching a few shows or demoing the device to friends.So let's wrap this one up.Pros:+ Looks very nice+ Light weight and thin+ Tegra 3 Performance+ Full-size SD Card Slot+ USB functionality+ Descent stereo speakers+ Gorilla GlassCons:- LCD Light Bleed- Only "OK" battery life- No SD Card Slot Cover (when in use)- Considering specs (16GB model), could be a bit cheaperCONCLUSION:So how bad is the light bleed? It's annoying enough that this is getting returned. I've been in the IT field for nearly 2 decades and have repaired so many computers and electronics (including many LCD's), I wouldn't even want to guess as to how many. In other words, I know a defect when I see one. :)  However, my lovely wife did play with this for a while and she did "volunteer" to take it off my hands - even after showing her the light bleed. It didn't bother her one bit, which I'm sure will be the case for many other folks out there.So my search for a solid Android tablet continues. On the plus side, I think we're getting closer! Just give me all of the good features from Asus, Acer, and Toshiba, and we'll have one killer tablet on our hands. Come on folks, it can't be that hard to spend $400-$500 on a tablet without making compromises.
summary: Best Tegra3 Android Tablet So far... unfortunately.

reviewText: Upon arrival this unit did not work. I rapidly traced the problem and found that the batteries are held firmly enough in the tray that there can be a gap between the end of the batteries and the contacts. Once I pressed the end batteries up against the other batteries, the unit worked perfectly.It reduces the cycle time on my canon 600 speedlite from 4 seconds to 1 second at full power.When shooting under "average" conditions with ETTL fill flash subject at 10 feet, it recycles fast enough for me to hold down the shutter release for at least 5 frames and every shot fires the flash.The cable and plug appear to be of good construction, the positive lock on the tray is a plus. The belt loop holds the unit either vertically or horizontally - a nice feature.All stitching and construction appears excellent. Unit fits well and cable routes nicely out of the belt pack. You can also screw it to the bottom of your camera if you wish.The positive latch on the battery tray is well-thought and not prone to accidental opening.I'm looking forward to trying this unit in long shoots.

I played with one of these today at the Coast Guard Exchange and was very impressed.  It sat along side several other higher priced tablets (7" and 10") and performed a lot better than the others.  The speed was pretty good (of course, that depended on the store's wi-fi).  I had been looking at the New Kindle Fire HD, but might just go for this device, instead.  Every app that I tried to find was in Google Play (most low-end Androids don't even have Google Play) and every website that I searched came up quickly.  I will update this review after I have bought one and tried it out for a few months.  But, my first impression was very good.

This tablet does everything I wanted it to do and more.  Had another brand (Viewsonic Viewpad) for a year but ran out of storage space so had to delete some of my apps.  I've had this one for about 6 months now and holds tons of apps and is not even close to using all the space.  Also much quicker than my old one and supports Adobe Flash Player (which the Viewpad did not).  Also the price was less for this one. Can't think of anything I would need that this tablet does not have.  Plan to keep this one for a long time.  I love the 7" size since I take it everywhere I go....it fits in my purse.  I use the google calendar and it automatically syncs with my computer so my schedule is always up to date.

While I waited for the new Kindle HD to come out to replace my old Kindle Keyboard 3G, I had been reading about all the different tablets that are out there.  The more I used my smartphone, a Droid Maxx, the more I wanted a tablet so I could do the same stuff only on a larger screen including reading my Kindle books.  After the arrival of the  new Kindle I got serious about comparison tablet shopping. I decided that I wanted to keep the same size as my old kindle - not the screen size but overall size as you can hold it in one hand and its very portable in a purse etc.  I also didn't want the high price iPad or the new Windows tablet. (I have a laptop for serious work.)  So I eventually narrowed down the choice between the Kindle Fire HD, Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7" and the Google Nexus. After much analysis and reading reviews I chose the Galaxy for the following reasons: While I love Amazon, I prefer to stay with the Andriod OS so that I don't have to learn a whole other way of life and can set up my devices similiarly; For about $40 more the Galaxy is expandable with a 32GB memory card and it has a front & rear camera;  the Nexus costs more isn't expandable and only has one camera. These are just a few reasons.  I have forgotten the rest cause I am so pleased with my choice.  I have owned it for 4 days now and have some basic things set up on it and will start to play with the camera etc. I had no problems with it recognizing our WiFi. I just have to remember to turn off the WiFi to save the battery life as I did on my Kindle.I bought the Supcase cover for it which fits perfectly and allows for 3 viewing positions and great protection.  I had purchased clear screen protectors but have now ordered non-glare ones as I like to read outside and prefer not to see my reflection while reading!  I spent alot of time studying all the information on the tablets, screen protectors and cases and I am very pleased with my choice and the prices from Amazon.10/10/12  Yesterday I received the Clear Shield Utra Matte finish screen protectors.  It works great...no more glare but you do loose a litte in clarity but worth it outdoors.  The protector was easy to put on and a perfect fit.  My husband is now playing Bad Piggies on it and I think I may have him convinced to get this tablet too.  Wait til tries the TV remote set-up!

I bought the little tablet computer primarily for e-mail and browsing.But - after installing a few handy apps and discovering just how useful it is in so many places,it has become indispensable to me as my primary mobile device.

This tablet, along with the Transformer Prime have horrible GPS lock issues. Now, you can register with ASUS and get a FREE GPS dongle, problem with this? It adds a serious lump to your otherwise slick tablet, and you HAVE to claim this before you use the ASUS unlock tool on your tablet, because if you use that tool, the user agreement exempts them from any all faulty hardware or software. Like the tablet didn't have issues before you unlocked it.I don't believe a company should screw their customers like that.

There are definitely issues with this product and it's wifi card, but they present themselves quickly and Amazon exchanges are a breeze.  ASUS support staff is hit or miss, but the replacement unit is excellent and has no issues.  I would certainly give this product 5 stars based on the second unit, but the fact that an obvious quality control issue is present in these models is a big problem, especially if this product is intended as a gift.  I would buy another for myself, but I would not do so without doing the setup and using it for a week myself to determine if the problem exists on the particular model shipped.Again, 5 star product with 1 star quality control and 5 star Amazon return service.

Two months ago, I had no interest in a tablet of any kind. I had my laptop, and my smart phone, and couldn't see how a third device could fulfill me any more than what I already had. Enter the Kindle Fire. After many months of hinting/cajoling/begging/whining I made sure my wife got a Fire for Mothers day, which of course required some setup by me, and I said to myself, "Self, this is almost a really good device. With a bigger screen, a little more storage space, and a little more customizability, this would be awesome."I almost made a misstep. I very nearly purchased a refurbed Motorola Xoom, but fortunately did my homework, and landed on the Asus Transformer Pad as the device for me. The hardware packaged inside the Transformer Pad appears to be unmatched in a dollar/performance comparison with any other tablet currently available, and the package itself is very attractive to my eyes. The features available both software and hardware wise have seen me using my laptop much less, and my tablet much more. So far I have purchased a very nice, and inexpensive case for protection, and the dock/USB adapter. The USB adapter has allowed me to connect storage devices from USB thumb drives, to a USB floppy drive - and they all just work. I connected an XBox 360 controller USB wireless adapter, synced a controller, and it worked. Every app I've thrown at it, works. The video editor "Movie Studio" works. Battery life is phenomenal whether the Pad is on, or off. Threw in a 32GB MicroSD card and loaded it up with music, and again, everything works. Overwhelmingly, I have had pleasant experiences with the Asus Transformer Pad TF300T, and am looking forward to a long time enjoying my purchase, especially if I can ever bring myself around to getting the keyboard/dock to go along with it.Of course, not everything is roses. For completeness sake; a list of the foibles that I don't care for.The dock connector: I would much prefer a standard micro USB connector - since that's what every other device I have uses for charging and communications.The speakers: Sound quality is great, but with the speakers right next to each other there's no stereo separation. Which begs the question, why have two speakers?The MicroSD card has popped out once. I don't think it will be a problem in general, but I did manage to hit it just right once to unintentionally pop it into the ejected position.Charging: Due to the large battery, it only charges correctly when connected to high voltage/USB3 connections.The internet Browser: As mentioned elsewhere, the browser does "hang up" for several seconds many times just before the page completes loading. Not every time, but it can get annoying.It's too big to use comfortably as a reader sometimes - like laying down to sleep - this is the one area where the Kindle Fire comes out ahead.None of these issues I have are anywhere near deal breakers, and most likely there will never be a device that is perfect, so my recommendation is definitely to buy if you're in the market. Again, I am very satisfied with my nearly four-hundred dollar purchase, and in comparison with the similar devices I've seen (the "New" iPad, Galaxy Tabs, Kindle Fire), I think my Transformer Pad takes the cake.

Despite being a professional geek, I have held off on a tablet until now.  I've made do with a laptop and a smartphone but, due to some physical disabilities, I've decided to finally move on to a tablet.After using the tablet for a bit more than a week, I am quite happy with my Transformer TF300T.  I still carry my smartphone, a 4.3" Android device, but I find myself using it only when not in range of a WiFi signal.  The tablet performs incredibly well for all tasks, being quite snappy even on Power Saving mode.  I typically leave it in Performance mode, though and haven't had it die on me despite using it pretty steadily throughout the day.  I even have it set to leave the WiFi on while "sleeping" in order to get email alerts, etc.  I tend to take it off the charger around 9:30 AM and it still has 20% or more battery left at midnight when it goes back on.  The GPS stays on throughout the day, also.  That's pretty hard to argue with.The screen is bright and crisp.  The touch interface is very responsive, having no lag whatsoever.  I'm very impressed.  I look forward to tinkering with some games on it once I get past the transitional period of moving all my applications to mobile versions.I have yet to pick up the "dock" for it (Multi-Functional Docking Station for ASUS TF300T Tablet, Blue (TF300T-DOCK-BL)) but plan to, at this point, sometime soon.  While not being absolutely necessary, it will allow me to replace my laptop with this as my main mobile device.Well done, Asus!  Well done.

I bought this to put in one of my lenses.  It has the safety pins.  It has sure-grip rubber inserts.  It even works on my Really Right Stuff clamp.  A very economical purchase!  I have since started using it to put on the bottom of cameras that I am photographing.  It's all good!

I can't speak yet to how the case will hold up over a long period of time, but the quality seems good and it works as advertized (sleep functions work, the ridges work well for tilting the iPad).  It has a nice leather feel and the stitching is good quality.  We were worried, based on the pictures here, that it might be more pink than red, but the color does seem to be more of a red and is nice.It took me a bit of fiddling to get the iPad completely seated in the plastic base and there was no click or anything that confirmed that it was seated, but, now that it is in it seems secure and has not come out.I don't know about the protection if it is dropped, we try not to drop it, but it seems like it is substantial enough to afford reasonable protection.All of the openings are properly aligned for the new iPad.It would have been nice if there was a place to put a name/address somewhere on the case, but there is nothing like that.
the faux leather looks cheap and saw at least one imperfection in the back.  also the sleep awake engages accidentally too often. beware. this will drain your battery.  stay away from this item.

Let me start by saying I did have a iPad 2 with an Otterbox case which I loved. However when I got the mini I was looking for a folio as I thought I would be taking it away from home more. Also the Otterbox cases are at the upper end of what I want to pay.The iPad Mini has thin vertical bezels and reading reviews many people have issues with the case impinging on the mini's touchscreen as it overlaps the bezel. So my first need was to make sure all the smaller iPads screen was available. Secondly if I bought a folio I wanted one that bends back on itself, reading reviews I was struggling to find anyone that mentioned this.Anyways...This case looks great, the stitching and quality are excellent.I really like the way they have bonded a poly carb clamshell onto the leather folio. The clamshell holds the iPad firmly however it barely impinges on the front face of the iPad Mini.The magnets work perfectly and switch off the iPad every time. The stand is simply and works well offering multiple viewing angles.After a day of use the cover has lost a little of it's new stiffness and folds back perfectly.This iPad Mini folio cover scores 10 out of 10 in my eyes.

I have been using this product daily for several months.  It has performed as intended with no problems of any sort.  It takes a bit of breaking-in because of the process used to waterproof the ipod.  Rolling a pencil over the buttons, as prescribed by the company, will resolve that problem in short order.  This has done wonders to eliminate the interminable tedium of swimming laps.  I listen to books sometimes and music sometimes, and before I know it, the deed is done.  This and a lap counter will make your workout much more something to enjoy.

I use alot of wireless mouses - a few years ago I decided a mouse cord was just more clutter around me so I switched all my mouses at home & work to wireless.  I've got about 5 wireless mouses from logitech, microsoft, and some lesser know brand.  My Microsoft mouse stopped working after about a year and really ate up batteries.  My lesser known brand mouse is very sluggish.  My Logitech mouses have been the hands down winners - they seem to be built like tanks, they all still work for me, they are very responsive, and they are good on battery life.So I put this new Logitech M325 through the paces and this is my hands-down winner among my mouse (mice? meese?) collection.#1 I love the very small size USB dongle that I can just leave in my USB port and still put my laptop in my shoulder bag.#2 I love that Logitech is now making the USB usable across more of their devices so I don't have to constantly be switching out USB dongles and trying to keep track of them all.#3 this mouse is lightning fast - no lag.#4 it's a great size in my hand but still not too bulky if I want to throw it in my laptop bag.  Plus I already mentioned that I have had great durability experience with Logitech.#5 if the advertising is true it should last 1+ year with the same battery which is very impressive.So what's not too like - well I can't ding it for color because that is up to personal preference.  To be honest I think I might buy a few more of these mouses in more general neutral color and toss my old mices if no other reason that just to transition over to a universal USB dongle.  Did I mention that I really like this mouse - 5+ stars from me.
summary: Logitech Makes Great Wireless Mouses & Good Value

reviewText: I was quite impressed with the ease-of-use of this keyboard. I own the older model of this very product and I like the changes. This version is ultrathin (8mm thick) making it less burdensome to carry around in my bag. The magnetic clip makes it very simple to attach the iPad. It clicks shut with no issues. I really like how it instantly wakes and sleeps my iPad when I open and close it. That is a neat feature. The keyboard is great for writing emails when I am on the go. I also think the size of the keys are arthritis friendly.  The viewing angle of the keyboard is pleasing to the eye. As an added bonus, the keyboard keeps its charge for a long period of time.  Overall, I am very happy with the new product. I would highly recommend it to iPad users.

My Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Cover came in today, and I've had the opportunity to play around with it.  It's mostly all good, with a couple of minor negatives.The good:-Attractive compliment to the Ipad.  Take away the Logitech logo, and you might think this was designed by Apple. The front cover is the same color and finish as the back of the Ipad, which is nice.  It is slim, and not bulky like the Clamcase.-Super easy to set up.  Literally place your Ipad in the grooves, rotate it a few degrees until the magnets catch (with an audible clicking sound), activate the bluetooth (the first time only), then you're good to go.-Ipad is VERY secure in landscape mode.  The magnets are strong and sturdy.  The Ipad is not going anywhere.-Unlike many other reviewers, I had absolutely no issue with the magnets used to connect the cover to the Ipad when it not being used.  This was my biggest worry, but it is an absolute non factor for me.  Maybe Logitech corrected an earlier design flaw, or maybe the magnets will weaken over time.  Who knows.  I can only tell you that the cover stays closed and secure for me.  I even tried to make the cover and the Ipad slide apart and I couldn't (without a **tremendous** amount of effort).-Keyboard is obviously not a full size keyboard, but I found it very easy to type on.  Good tactile feel, and dead on accuracy.  It takes a slight bit of getting used to, again because it is not a full size keyboard, but nothing that will bother you.-Special function keys unique to the Ipad are nice-Very quick and easy to remove the case if you want to use the Ipad by itself.-Supposedly you get 6 months of battery life per charge.  Pretty amazing.The negatives:-This is not a case that offers any kind of real protection.  The back of the Ipad is totally exposed, and in the event of a drop, I can't see this offering very much protection to the front either.  Just know that going in.  There are other cases that are bulkier and less attractive, but that offer greater protection.  I didn't buy this cover for the protection, so I am ok with it. I may eventually get a protective sleeve for travel (anybody have any good recommendations?).-Black piano finish is a fingerprint magnet.-Not really an option to use your Ipad in portrait mode with this case.  You can do it, but it not very secure because the magnets are designed to hold the Ipad in landscape mode. Not a big deal for me, but just be aware.-Pricey @ $99, but in my opinion, worth it.Overall, even with the few negatives, I am giving this a 4 star rating.  I like it, and as long as it holds up, I am a happy camper.  If I run into any durability issues, I will post updates.**Update 8/9/12** Bought the Targus Hughes Leather Portfolio for Ipad (available here on Amazon) and it is the perfect companion to the Logitech case. With the Logitech case on, my Ipad fits securely and attractively inside the Targus portfolio.  I will really only use the extra protection when I (or my kids) are using the Ipad away from home, but it's nice to have when I need it.  For those of you who are worried about scratching the back of your Ipad, or about the Logitech case failing to securely close (which has not been a problem at all for me), or just looking for some extra protection, then I highly recommend the Targus case.
summary: Love it for what it is, but just know you're not getting any real protection

reviewerName: TyCo "Learn to accept rejection and reject ac...
reviewText: Not a whole lot to say other than this charger set works as advertised.  Both units feel solid and well built.  No funny burning smells (as with some other cheap chargers during initial use) and all the connections fit very well.The wall wort for the AC charger is larger than the USB wall adapter provided by Asus with the tablet (with a longer cable, this is a plus) and the DC car charger is a little large too (with enough cable to charge the tablet while it's being used in the back seat).
