I'm not complaining, just fyi.If you're looking something very compact for travel you may want to keep looking, but if size isn't an issue you can't beat the price and functionality of this set. A+++If anything changes (i.e. breaks, burns out, dies, etc...) I'll update this review.
summary: Great charger set, better value than Asus brand

reviewText: I purchased this Vizio for our bedroom and am very happy with it.  I assume I would be happy with it in the family room too.  It has a very good picture and the sound is decent.  The apps are ok as I haven't really used them for much yet.  The built in wifi is a plus.  I haven't tweaked the picture color or anything like that as we are happy with it out of the box.  The remote is weak, having made it hard to try to log into apps.  Maybe that's why I haven't gotten into them.  I would recommend this Vizio to anyone.

I purchased a Pioneer AppRadio2 and was disappointed to find out there was no easy way to bypass the parking brake sensing function like there was on my old Kenwood, but this did the trick perfect. I used three quick taps to connect the wires and now I can use all apps without doing to stupid parking brake procedure.
summary: Works great, quick and easy install

reviewText: This is a simple and well made (for three pieces of plastic and a circuit board) little Bluetooth device at a decent price. But...The audio levels it puts out are too low. Adjusting sound levels from the iMac's various OS X audio controls (System Prefs, iTunes volume, or Audio MIDI Setup) had very little impact. I had to turn my remote speakers up to full volume just to hear the music at normal volume. This is obviously a problem as, when I would switch to radio (usually at another time or day), the speaker would be at full volume!Also, a human body can impact the Bluetooth signal. While 10 meters is accurate for a distance. You'll want the space between clear at all times. With that in mind, you really should have your Bluetooth enabled device on the same counter as the speakers or a nearby shelf with no walking people in between.Forget about having speakers on one side of room and the Bluetooth device on the other.On my particular device, the red and blue LEDs (under that white bit on its corner) would not stop flashing if the speakers were turned off. Presumably to alert you that, it is not getting a signal. But, if the speakers are off, it should just be "off" itself. The flashing can be quite annoying. The only solution is to unplug it each time. Forget about leaving it in all the time.With these problems, I ended up returning it.I wonder: are the more expensive variants of this are better with sound levels, flashing LED, and Bluetooth? If so, they would be worth considering. I think this one uses a version of Bluetooth that is 1.X but the more expensive variants use 2.x which has A2DP (Advanced Audio Distribution Profile) for true stereo sound.If there were a Wi-Fi version of this device, it would be much better and not all that much bigger. It could even be enabled with Airplay - which works great in all other instances I have used it.

I purshased this Vizio E191VA TV yesterday and was able to set up the TV and install the base in about 10 minutes.  The audio is very good for a small TV.  The picture is also better than expected.  I was most impressed with the auto-scan feature that resulted in well over 100 channels with only the cable line plugged into the back.  For $148, this is one of the better deals that I have taken advantage of as a long-time Amazon shopper.  The individual that was unable to install the base should not have rated this TV so poorly.  The base slid on and locked with ease.  Buy this TV and you will be very pleased!

I have been putting off moving to a new computer for a while.  I actually bought a new computer and just need to move everything over.  I just haven't had the time but my old computer (still using it now) was slowing down primarily because of the hard drive.  I purchased this SSD and wow, my computer is new again.  It is super fast and good enough for anything I am doing.  I haven't had any issues since.

Greetings fellow amazonians I have been busy upgrading my computer when I jumped at the chance to get this vertex 4. I thought that I was going to be able to access my files from any device while working at the carnival. Too bad this is just a plain old hard drive. Why don't they specificly state that in the decription. Since this has a five year warranty I am going to let the knifethrower I work with use it as target practice and send it back to the company. Thank goodness I found out now and not after the warranty expired!

Bought this when it was on the gold box deal for $189.99 a few days ago. First one was dead on arrival. You could update the firmware but that's about it. Any time you partitioned the drive, it would disappear again shortly after. I managed to get it to work in an external enclosure, but it would erase everything after shutdown (if it even saved in the first place). RMA'd it with Amazon, new one was sent overnight and arrived the next day in working order. This current drive works and I'm hoping it stays that way.Not terribly bad for the price, but given my experience and other reviews, this one may be a headache waiting to happen.***Update 1/5/2013***I just wanted to update this review. I've owned this product for a few months now and honestly, I would not recommend it. I put this drive in my laptop after I received my replacement drive. I used it for a few months, then the drive pretty much killed itself in December. It functions briefly, but it decided to forget half the tables on the drive and will no longer boot properly. Reinstalling the OS will fix this, but its likely plagued with firmware/controller problems. I really like OCZ, hats off to them for trying to put out a performance leading product at a great price, but this product is simply not ready for prime time consumer use. Perhaps the next series will fix the issues associated with the drives, but for the time being I would look elsewhere. It is simply not worth the hassle for anything important, but it is incredibly fast when it works. Only environment I would recommend it in is gaming, particularly when you don't care what data is associated with it and don't mind losing everything. Storing photos, important documents, things that would suck to lose, I strongly advise looking elsewhere.Due to these issues I'm dropping my review from 3 stars to 2. Perhaps other people have luck with these drives, but after two bad experiences with this particular one, I would not recommend this particular product to others.

Great speed and compatibility when it comes to my i7 desktop but I purchased this to go in a 15" MacBook Pro (Early 2011) and it is not recognized as a drive by the bios. Went to do a fresh install of OSX 10.7 (Lion), it does not show in Disc Utility. Went from very excited to very disappointed. Ran some early benchmarks on my windows desktop got 531 Read 375 Write so a little better on the write than I thought I would get in sequential tests.Update:OZC is aware of the problem and it does not seem to effect all MacBook Pros[...]
summary: Not Made for Apple MacBook Pros

reviewText: Got my Vertex 4 256GB during the recent sale from Amazon.  My drive already came with the v. 1.5 firmware pre-installed.  It works great right out of the box.  This drive is very fast.  I have owned three other SSDs before:  OCZ Vertex Turbo, Intel 510, and Kingston HyperX.  This Vertex 4 feels perceptively faster than them.  I am very happy with the purchase.

I had been waiting to upgrade my aging Q6600 setup for when Ivy Bridge came out, and when it finally did it was time to settle on a motherboard. After searching the various motherboard vendors I finally settled on this H77 full ATX motherboard, which, while it has its layout issues, has otherwise been a fine choice.I looked at how I use my computer, and I only run a single, good video card, and I planned to swap out my raid-10 with a raid-1 with a solid state drive for caching using Intel's SRT. The money I saved over a Z77 motherboard afforded me the SSD, and I can assure you that it's well worth the ticket price to get one. I rarely hear the hard drive these days and everything loads faster and smoother. The H77 and Z77 (along with the Z68) provides this feature, while the overclocking Z75 does not. I also realized, as you can imagine, that I don't need a heck of a lot of ports - only running three things that would need a SATA port, a USB hub provides all of the USB 2.0 connectivity that I need, and this motherboard comes with the header port to connect my front case USB 3.0 ports, so all set there. Nothing was especially difficult to connect or work with when installing the motherboard. The BIOS upgraded without incident using a USB stick.First, the good: It's been up and running without a hitch since I installed it roughly a month ago. Everything works as advertised, which is primarily what I'm looking for in a motherboard. I chose to go with a separate SATA for speed and cost reasons, but there is an mSATA port which would likely work out quite well if you went that route. The Atheros LAN chipset, which I hadn't previously experienced first hand, has also run without incident.Now, the not so good. Rear port layout is an issue with all of the Ivy Bridge motherboards, primarily because they want you to use the Lucid MVP technology, which the general assessment is hit or miss. So they provide a ridiculous amount of video connectivity options in the back where there should be USB ports or something similar. This board is in that same boat, with what I'd call a dearth of USB ports - simply a sign of the times. The next is the full x16 PCIe slot - PCIe 3.0 capable. If you run a dual-slot video card, as I do, it effectively stops you from using the x1 PCIe slot underneath it. If you were to run two video cards, depending on the length, you would likely run into issues trying to work with the SATA ports. Lastly, the choice of two PCI slots at the bottom of the board is hard to fathom - I'd much rather have seen them slide one of the PCIe x1 ports towards the bottom rather than letting it sit there unused.
summary: Excellent board for those not needing overclocking

reviewText: Amazon's leather cover for the Kindle Touch was an innovative and smart design that was marred by two big blunders:First, the leather itself, lacking any cushioning or texture and simply glued to its stiff backing, looked and felt incredibly cheap. Pleather would have been no worse. And this was inexcusable--even a bit insulting--in a pricey cover. Surely Amazon could have done better at the price point.Second, the cover flap on the case lacked any sort of closure, which left the screen vulnerable to damage when being carried in a bag. I ended up using a rubber band around my cover, but again, Amazon should have thought this issue through considering the price.Well, I'm happy to report that Amazon listened to its customers, and corrected those two mistakes in the Paperwhite leather cover. For my priorities (which may not be yours), it's now perfect.It retains the snap-in, form fitting design from the Touch cover, which means that it adds the absolute minimum in size and weight to a naked PW, while still providing total protection.The leather is now cushioned a bit and textured, giving the case a much more luxurious feel in the hand. It now looks and feels like a case worth its price.The magnetic closure insures that the cover flap stays shut when not in use, protecting the screen, and also serves as an automatic "off" switch when you close it.With the PW bezel now virtually flush with the screen, that extra bit of holding room the case provides around the bezel really helps to keep your fingers off the screen. (And fingers inadvertently hitting a touch screen can be a real pain.)I would highly recommend this case to anyone for whom the price isn't an issue, except for those who prefer to use their Kindles naked. Once your PW is snapped into this case, the fit is pretty snug--as it should be--and taking it in and out regularly is probably not something you'll want to do.Thanks for taking the time to read my review and I hope you found it helpful.
summary: AMAZON LISTENS AND MAKES A GOOD COVER GREAT!

reviewText: On my first two e-Ink Kindles (Kindle 2 and Kindle 3), I bought the "official" Amazon covers, and they served very well in protecting the Kindle, and they looked good as well. When I ordered the Kindle Paperwhite, I didn't even think about it, I went ahead and ordered the Amazon Paperwhite cover. I'm glad I did. It's made exclusively for the Paperwhite, and it fits like a glove, with a very positive snap-in holder. The automatic magnetically-activated sleep-wake function of the cover is a great feature that saves time holding down the power switch and should extend battery life for the Paperwhite.All-in-all, a very well thought out, well made accessory for the Paperwhite.
summary: An essential accessory for the Kindle Paperwhite

reviewText: This drive just stopped working on me gave me Disk I/O error booted to a different drive and watched in windows the drive connection drop and the system beeped indicating it was gone.. I had hopped for better from a SSD. Now I have to go through the RMA process for this dead SSD what a pain.
summary: Drive dead after a month of use

reviewText: This is the best antenna I have tested.  It consistently gets all of the stations in my area, including those broadcast over VHF.  Unfortunately, the picture here is not of the correct model.  This is the "V" model, that includes a horizontal bar not included with the normal Clearstream 2.  It makes a huge difference.  I'll try to post a better picture.

I'm installing this router in a small pharmacy w/10 computers and a surveillance system. Other than the upcoming difficulties with configuration, I have alot of confidence in Cisco's small business equipment.

I purchased this router as i have a 4 story building with a professionally installed network for everyone to share one internet connection. I upgraded from the WRT54G as it couldn't keep up with our internet connection speed 100/50 ( we were only getting about 25 down on WRT54G). I saw this on small net builder and purchased it because of the routing performance (700+ MBPS), so this will last me years to come as we upgrade our internet connection down the line.I didn't need wireless because i have dedicated WAPs mounted on the 2nd and 3rd floor ceiling for better converge. As for the routing performance, I haven't had any problems yet, i only did notice i couldn't get into the web interface once when users were downloading large files, maybe enabling QOS might help. The gui needs a bit of work in some places, as some of the menus are not intuitive im hoping that will come with future firmware updates. I haven't tried the VPN but i hear it works well. I am using a third party VPN server on another machine because it does not have a layer 2 VPN server which i need for certain other apps that work on broadcasts. So i can't comment on the router's VPN performance or functionality. Setup was easy right out of the box and i had no issues with getting this thing up and running.From reading the reviews about the interface being slow, its NOT TOO BAD as some say. I'm using firmware 1.0.1.9 and it takes about 5 seconds on SOME tabs to navigate. Others are snappy, i guess it depends on what section you are in. Boot time is about 1 1/2 to 2 minutes, not 5 as someone has stated. Once this is setup and done, you really wont need to go back in ever unless you need to add port forwarding or such, but otherwise one might get frustrated at the speed if they had to go into this thing every other day. I hear users complaining about it being complex... this is a business router with business features. If you are not familiar with the terminology, you shouldn't be shopping in this segment. With complexity comes power and flexibility, which is why Cisco is on top of others in the router business.As a sum up, I mainly bought this for routing speed which it does deliver. It does need work on the gui, but over all not bad. There's not many vanilla routers out there these days without wireless as most people are looking for an all in one solution. I see a lot of potential in this product and room for improvements, mainly around gui usability.Here are some missing features that would make this a 5 star router.* Add button next to the DHCP clients to add a mac to the static pool, you currently have to copy manually, a pain if you need to add multiple static entries.* Better DHCP client name detection (My old WRT54G detected more device names under the DCHP users than the RV180) This make it easier to identify a DCHP client by computer name and such.* Better Bandwidth Counter, the one included is simple counts bandwidth total from a specific date. Would be nice to break down to days, weeks, etc.*  A current traffic meter page to show you how much traffic is going through the wan interfaces at a given moment, a must for a business router.* Current Bandwidth usage breakdown by IP, nice feature to find bandwidth hogs* Total downloaded MB by IP* Speed improvements for gui would help* SSH for basic commands* Layer 2 VPN server (Not likely but would be nice)it's not a bad product does the job but could be better with the above improvements.

I bought this to use with the 5D for video. I shoot handheld a lot. I used the cropped sensor version of this same lens with a 7D for two years and it worked great, but this version has a very stiff zoom and it was impossible for me to zoom while shooting handheld without twisting the camera, thus tweaking the composition. It's way too stiff. My arms were tired by the end of the day from all the muscle it took. Aside from that, it's a nice lens. For stills, it finds focus fast, looks good, etc. It's also the ONLY option that I am aware of for an IS 2.8 24-70 full frame lens.

NOTE!!! this review was written prior to putting this lens on the new 5D markiii...i have had to send in this lens for autofocus lag and stall on the 5Diii...tamron fixed this problem under warranty...the review below was on the T2i...i have a lens serial number of 008XXX, which is low and indicates lens was made prior to the 5Diii coming out, so this lens was not apparently optimized to work with the 5Diii. tamron fixed and now the lens works as well on my 5Diii as the review notes on the T2iNOTE#2 when i bought the lens the warranty card was missing, replaced with a blank piece of paper with the serial number on it. when i realized i needed warranty service on the lens i tried to register it and found the merchant who fulfilled the order bought on amazon here, were NOT the authorized dealer and i couldn't register it. they did make everything correct, and registered it through the original dealer, BUT be sure to make sure you have all the original info and warranty card when you buy your lens or any item on amazon as amazon allowed this seller to sell the item as new and they were not the authorized dealer, and the warranty card was missing. i should have tried to register right away so i could have returned it immediately. amazon says they would have refunded my full price, even though this was 5 months after purchase, if the seller didn't fix this situation, and i tend to believe them...but be proactive and make sure you have bought from an authorized dealer as a lot of these amazon items you think are being sold by amazon are actually being 'fulfilled' by another party that may not be advertising the item properly with all information correct in the ad.best wide to mid-range zoom out there.[NOTE: i am adding this bit of info on 9-4-12 after having shot with this amazing lens for over a month...i've noticed the image stabilization is better than the canon red stripe lenses i have shot with, better than the canon 17-55 efs 2.8 image stabilized...but the tamron still seems to transmit more light to the sensor than image stab or better glass alone can account for...i wondered if perhaps its bigger size might be allowing more light to transmit, having an 82mm diameter vs. canon's 77mm...googling that concept i found articles stating the larger diameter of a lens (vis a vis another lens) would allow more light and make the lens faster...this has been noticeable with my night/low light photography i am happy to report...back to the original review]this takes into account my having shot with the very sweet canon 17-55mm 2.8 image stabilized EFS (for crop cameras only, will not fit on full frame), and having bought and rejected the canon 24-105 4L lens. the canon 2.8 24-70 may or may not be sharper (it could be as good, but i doubt it's much if any better after having shot with this tamron), but it does NOT have image stabilization...so it default loses all else being generally equal...tamron's newly designed VC (image stab) for this lens is superb...don't believe any net discussions that fear over-vibration...if this was ever an issue with tamron's VC, it is NOT NOT NOT with this lens.either is focusing speed. does NOT have the image distortion i found in my brief shooting with the 24-105 4L.i'm primarily a night shooter, so that's where this lens sings.
summary: best all around zoom out there, warranty fixed PROBLEM ON 5D MARK iii  !!!

reviewText: It does seem to suppress echo/feedback better than some microphone-speaker combinations and for the price it is very good but, of course not as good as higher priced units sold, for instance, by Yamaha. But the microphone is directional - the microphone is located on one side of the unit, and speaking at other sides gives substantially lower volume and sound quality. So it's not ideal for a small conference room as I had hoped it would be.

As I was of the opinion that dvd-players for the children in the back are not something of this time, I wanted to create a simple and cheap solution to play videos from my portable (apple) devices.I mounted this monitor to the headrest (some creativity might be required), and connected the AV cable to a standard Apple AV adapter. Now I can easily put on a video from the front seat on my ipad, ipod or iphone for the children to enjoy in the backseat.- Picture quality good enough for this purpose- wide viewing angle makes straight positioning possibleConcerning my set-up:- Screen comes with loose wires for power (fuse included); connection to 12V plug or directly to car wiring required- No clear instructions, but most is easy. Power is red, blue and black wire. Red is +12V, black is Ground. Blue might be a power-on 12V, but I installed in such a way that it only receives 12V when the car is on. (knowledge of electronics/cars needed to do this)- No sound from screen; you still need to connect the apple cable to your stereo's aux-in

I first read about these on cnet's list of best headphones under $50. I've been auditioning headphones for some time and haven't been moved by any pair under $125.00. I had a pair of headphones I paid $50 for and was very unimpressed with them.Right now I'm on a budget so seeing these for this cheap along with the many great reviews seemed too good to believe. Well, it's not a joke, these are very musical and very versatile. I have a very diverse music collection and haven't found a genre that doesn't sound good with these.Even if I can afford nicer headphones later I'm glad I  bought these. At the worst they are a solid back up pair for anyone who runs though headphones regularly. Just get em and tell us what you think!

I do quite a bit of editing; text, photo and video. Old computers could handle text with adequate speed, but photo editing takes time and videos mega-time. This processor is fast with the photos and handles videos well. It is nice to have the integrated, video "board" in the processor. I plugged in a PNY video board that I like, the integrated video shut down and the PNY seemed slower, so I removed the PNY.

The Targus C4 Laptop Backpack is a good all around case for your laptop. It is a rich midnight blue color with black accents and back. The interior is also a matching blue. The Targus C4 has a lighter blue horizontal stitching to add a bit of style to an otherwise ordinary looking pack.There are several pockets and compartments that make this bag quite versatile. The smaller front pocket unzips with holders for pens, ID cards and credit cards, as well as an expandable pocket to hold something like a hair brush.The next pocket is the one with the stitching on it, it goes down to the entire length of the pack with another internal pocket that goes about half way down. This pocket would be useful for carrying paperback books or similar sized items, while the larger full sized pocket might be good for larger text books or anything of that size.The last pocket has a padded laptop slot as well as a tablet / iPad compartment which lies on top the padded laptop slot and it bordered by a pleasant light blue border (see pic). Why the iPad compartment is not heavily padded is puzzling. If the adjoining pocket is packed tightly, there is little protection for the iPad other than light padding between the layers of nylon. The laptop compartment seems adequately padded, as does the back of the pack.The Targus C4 Laptop Backpack is a good pack for overall use, like going to class, the library, coffee shop, etc.. For more extensive traveling you may want something a little bit more protective, but you certainly could use this pack if you wish.Oh, and there are also two outside pockets to hold water bottles or similar items.
summary: A Nice General Use Laptop/Tablet Backpack

reviewText: I purchased this card for a upgrade from onboard sound. The sound quality improvement was awesome. I have noted several reviewers having volume issues with front panel audio. The solution is very simple: I purchased a headphone/speaker switching unit and it works fine.
summary: One of the best Sound Cards I have ever used in this price range.

reviewText: I returned this memory as I needed two channel memory.  I'm sure the memory was fine.  I never tried it.

The item is mis-advertised. The magnetic sleep function doesn't work with the 3rd generation iPad. I've tried two of them and neither works, so either this is a knock-off or the product is incorrectly labeled.Either way, avoid the hassle and don't buy this if you've got a 3rd gen iPad.Other than that the case itself is very nice. I'm going to buy directly from Sena from now on.
summary: Doesn't work with the 3rd generation iPad

reviewText: I purchased the ArmorSuit MilitaryShield for my 12-year-old grandson. He had just gotten the tablet PC for use in school. (It amazes me what kinds of technology kids can use in school these days, even at the middle school level.)I thought it would be a good lesson for him to install it himself and learn how to do things right. I just watched him and followed along with what he was doing.He read the directions and followed them step-by-step.  They are very good, by the way.He took his time cleaning the screen (potential error 1)and watering down the film & the screen. if you don't do this, you will have problems - (potential error 2).He laid the ArmorSuit MilitaryShield over the glass and carefully squeegee out the moisture with the tool provided.This step is so important and probably overlooked by people who gave negative reviews -  (potential error 3).After wiping down the excess moisture, he left it alone for 18 hours - (potential error 4). He honestly couldn't tell the difference, before and after.This was over a month ago and he says it is still as good as when he applied it.If you don't commit errors 1, 2, 3 or 4 I don't see how it cannot be good unless it happened to be an isolated piece of defective product. With a lifetime warranty it should be easy to get replaced.It has been my experience that Amazon is very good at replacing defective products.
summary: ArmorSuit MilitaryShield Lives up to its claims

reviewText: I recently got a ultrabook without a Ethernet port. So I bought this device to transfer files from my other machine. Since both computers use SSD, both have Gigabyte adapter now, and I am using Gigabyte cable, I am expecting the speed to be >65M/s while transferring 1 big file. But only get 30M/s. Quite disappointing result.While it is still be faster than those usb 2.0 or 100m adapter, it's not worth the price to get this speed. I will update if I find myself wrong(maybe some settings)Updated 5/7/2013I got the speed back. It can transfer at 80m/s now. Apologize for the misleading comment.
summary: Updated: I apologize for my own mistake, not it's 80m

reviewText: (Copied from http://www.amazon.com/DEFENDER-21006-Resolution-Outdoor-Security/product-reviews/B007ULV8I0/ref=dp_top_cm_cr_acr_txt?ie=UTF8&showViewpoints;=1, my review of the 4-pack)Installed a set in the front yard (the hard part is determining best location) connected to a video server (http://www.amazon.com/IP-Network-Server-Broadcast-without/dp/B000HBVTCA) and running 'motion' on my Linux server and liked the results so much that I bought another set (and another video server) for the back/side yards.  The daylight color looks quite good, the nighttime black/white IR is also sharp (for about 25') and then fuzzy but recognizable shapes (cat v human) until about 50'.  I liked the idea of no moving parts (i.e., less chance of breakage) so choose the Defender brand.  I'm glad I did, they are metal (no plastic) and fill solid, hide the cord and perform well for my needs.
summary: Liked it so much I bought a second set (of 21006 4-pack)

reviewText: I have a SiriusXM XPress RCi which is a great fit for this portable speaker dock. It is easy to set up & operate. The sound is crisp and clear, for the most part. However, I did notice that the speaker dock seems to over heat while using the battery supply when setting on a solid surface & will shut the system down. When you plug the power supply cord in, the speaker dock begins working again. This would be very inconvenient if you were not close to an outlet. So far this has not been a significant issue yet because we have only used it on our deck where a power outlet is available. I have not tried elevating the speaker dock on something like a cooling rack which would allow air to circulate around the speakers. This might help to keep the bottom of the speaker dock from getting too hot. All in all this is a great way to enjoy your SiriusXM service other than in a car!

First, let me say that I think it is REALLY tough to find companies that stand behind their products without question and really work with their customers voluntarily. The guys and gals at Skinomi really set the bar for me. I know that sounds like hyperbole, but I was really impressed.In a nutshell, I flubbed the install of my screen protector (lots of lint and dust got under the screen). Daringly (or stupidly?), I pulled that protector off my Galaxy 2 after twenty-four hours and with zero application solution left. On the plus side, it was reassuring that the protector not only was a beast to pull off, but as much as I pulled and pried it, it did not loose its shape. So to me, that says its quality and that I got what I paid for.At this point, I thought I was done. I destroyed the protector (it was covered in lint and junk), I have no more application solution, and overall, I felt kind of dumb. I emailed the Skinomi CSR's for guidance and they sent me out a brand new one! But because I'm very good at ruining a free lunch, I replied that I really just wanted some more solution (I am but a man, and I therefore had to make that first protector work. It was a matter of pride. Guys are weird like that). The rep told me that I could just wash off the protector in lukewarm water with some dish soap and let it dry (I let mine dry in a Tupperware container so that the dust in my house wouldn't adhere to the film). The same rep also said that a bit of lukewarm tap water in the solution works fine due to the residual solution. It would likely work only once, though.As you can guess, I was able to reapply the original screen protector, this time without a hitch. And the second one is still en route!What I guess I'm saying is that the people at Skinomi could have taken me for a ride and not even bought me dinner. They could have told me that I need to buy another kit. They didn't They essentially lost money by telling me how I could rescue my botched install. I think that alone is worthy of high marks. That, and the way that protector fought me when I peeled it off my Samsung, and the way the shape always bounced back...well, like I said, I'm actually pretty thrilled with the whole situation.Great product, great company to work with. I think you will be pleased, too.Cheers!

Update (May 2013): After only a few months of intermittently regular use (sometimes not at all), the rubber tip began dragging, squeaking, and finally collapsing beyond recovery. From what I've read, a stylus is a fairly short-lived instrument, with a life expectancy of only a few months, so this, I suppose, falls within "acceptable" bounds. Sadly, though, I now have this very well-made barrel, with no way to repair the tip. It's too nice to just simply toss, so now it just mocks me. I'm pleased to see the emergence of styli with replaceable tips -- that makes much more sense to me.Original review (Dec 2012): I specifically ordered this stylus because it claimed to be "slim," because I'd like a finer touch than either my finger or regular stylus can provide. I had hoped for a firmer, smaller "point" for detail work, but this stylus has the same-sized rubber bubble as the ones I bought at 3/$1.That said, this stylus is very well made, of much higher quality than the cheap ones, with nicely finished details such as the bezel surrounding the rubber bubble. This stylus is roughly the length and circumference of a regular gel pen, and I find it more natural and comfortable to hold than the smaller versions.Are these refinements worth $10? Only you can decide. The cheap ones do the same job, and if the rubber tip comes off, at 33 cents it's no tragedy. Had this been a *slim* stylus as described, I would have considered my $$ well spent. As is, I won't be returning it, because it's nice and I suck at returns, but I wouldn't have bought it, nor would I recommend it to anyone not specifically searching for a higher-end stylus.My rating is high for the quality, but the misleading description was a disappointment.
summary: Good, quality stylus, but definitely not slim.

reviewText: I can't believe how cool this is!!! I used it on with my D3200 and G2 android... now with my new Samsung Galaxy S3, even better!!! It is instantaneous! Unlike the remote, you have 'live preview' prior to shooting which benefits me when I travel with my husband. No more asking people to shoot images for us... we can set up the cam on a tripod ourselves and shoot! Definitely worth the money. No more bad pictures!JANUARY 8, 2014I don't use this much anymore, it takes forever to download images. I only use it if highly necessary, like when I had a trip with my husband in Paris and wanted to take very nice shots with the Eiffel Tower behind us. That's it! I love the Wi-Fi connectivity is releases.

I got this - well, asked my wife to get me it as an early Christmas gift - to replace the cheaply made Blu-Ray USB External Player DVDRW I had picked up a while ago which stopped reading CDs/DVDs and was having issues with Blu-ray discs. I'm currently limited to 6-7x max as my system is only USB 2.0. I currently have the drive in aVantec USA NexStar DX External 5.25-Inch Optical Drive Enclosure USB 3.0 External Interface  Optical Drives 14700365 (NST-530S3-BK)so I can take advantage of more speed when I upgrade my system.This drive has been rock solid so far, reading Blu-rays around 3.5x-7x (modern drives ramp up in speed as they get to the outside of the disc). The aforementioned drive started at ~0.7x and topped out at 3-ish. Both using the same USB 2.0 connection. UPDATE: I've since switched to a desktop and installed drive directly without the USB limitation and the speed has increased nicely.This drive will pretty much burn any type of disc on the market. Aside from the usual CD/DVD assortments, M-Discs (which are special DVD+Rs designed to last 1000 years), it'll burn Bly-ray discs and re-writeable ones - including the massive 128 GB re-writeable BDXL discs (which are about $99 a disc right now!). The only thing it can't do is LightScribe, which is a bit of a shame but it might simply be incompatible with the different laser used for burning the M-Discs.The only reason not to get this drive would be if you're really going to need M-Disc Blu-rays in the future (and are too cheap to buy another drive later). Currently M-Discs are only DVD+R sized and the company is working on 25 GB models. When will they be out? Who knows. But almost certainly you will need a new drive to burn them.Mac OS 10.8 detects the drive and burns to it using the Finder, Disk Utility and Toast. No additional software needed to read/write Blu-ray discs (although Toast does work nicely with it for some $$$).Drive information as reported by Mac OS:HL-DT-ST BD-RE  WH14NS40:Firmware Revision: 1.00Burn Support: Yes (Generic Drive Support)Cache: 4064 KBCD-Write: -R, -RWDVD-Write: -R, -R DL, -RAM, -RW, +R, +R DL, +RWBD-Write: -R, -REWrite Strategies: CD-TAO, CD-SAO, CD-Raw, DVD-DAOUPDATE: One thing I forgot to mention is this drive doesn't support LightScribe or any other type of disc "printing". I think LG products have an LS in the model number if it is supported.

I bought the Polaroid tablet soon after I also bought a Nexus tablet.  I bought the Polaroid just to play around with, whereas my Nexus is my "real" tablet.  I've owned both for less than a month.  My evaluation admittedly compares the Polaroid to the Nexus.  This may be an unfair comparison, since they are not really in the same league.I give the Nexus five stars, and the Polaroid tablet about half that.  The Polaroid is not a bad tablet for what it does and what it cost (I got it for $72, which included a 20 percent discount off the advertised price).  Thus the Polaroid cost me less than one third the cost of the Nexus.The Polaroid is noticeably slower to start up, and has frequent response lags.  I'm not sure what it's doing when it pauses.  The Polaroid screen often switches off for no apparent reason.  But, the Polaroid Wi-Fi actually seems to be more sensitive than the Nexus.  At least the Polaroid reports a stronger and faster signal.  The Nexus has a slightly better operating system (Android 4.1), whereas the Polaroid has Android 4.0.  However, the difference may not be that significant for most users.It's actually possible to read tiny fonts on Web pages on the Nexus.  Not so with the Polaroid.  The Nexus display is sharp and beautiful, compared to the grainy resolution of the Polaroid.  The Nexus also has important features, like GPS and Gorilla Glass, missing on the Polaroid.I installed Google Market and Amazon Apps Store on the Polaroid, I downloaded all the free apps I'm likely to use, and there is still plenty of RAM to spare.  The Polaroid accepts up to a 32 GB micro SD card, so storage of music, video, and other files should not be an issue.  I haven't even tried out the music and video capabilities on either tablet.  My Nexus and Polaroid tablets have pretty much the same apps, and can do about the same things.  However, the Nexus is much faster and the display is prettier.The main issues I have with the Polaroid are the slow processor and poor screen resolution.  But, if the Polaroid is half as good as the Nexus, at one third the cost, is it a good value?  You be the judge.  If I lose or break the Polaroid tablet, I won't be out much.  I'll cry if the same happens to the Nexus.  I love the Nexus, whereas the Polaroid is merely OK.Sept 24, 2012 Update:  Since the Polaroid has no GPS, GasBuddy App won't install.  I miss that.  The Web version of GasBuddy can be used, however the functionality is not as nice.  In many applications, the Home key doesn't function.  I have to use the Back key to get to Home.  Slow processor performance and slow Web page loading are gettting more exasperating.Aug 17, 2013 Update:  I still play around with and try to use this tablet, but I am about ready to abandon it to the electronics recyclers.  It simply is too slow to be useful.  The Home Key (both physical button and screen icon) is totally dead.  Web pages of any type are so slow to load, the browser times out.  I downgraded my rating to one star.It pains me to see the once-proud Polaroid name attached to such a product.I still love my Nexus tablet, and there is a new improved model available.

I love my Kindle Fire, and I love the gorilla glass touch screen. Even after a year of (believe me) daily use, it has never failed to clean perfectly with a simple micro-fiber cloth. I bought a cover for it, which is almost a necessity if you want to hold it comfortably in your hands to read, or to pop it in purse or suitcase to take it any where.So, why would anyone need a plastic screen cover? I really don't think we do. It was tedious to apply - peel the thing, position it just so (this is pretty much impossible to get 100% correct), peel and lay the plastic down, then use the little piece of cardboard to smooth out the air bubbles. I did all that, but the whole time I was wondering...why?I tried the touch screen with the plastic covering it, and it felt different. The gorilla glass itself feels beautiful, cool, clean, smooth as...well, glass! This drags a little, like plastic. I didn't like the appearance, what with the tiny air bubbles I couldn't get out no matter how I wielded the little piece of cardboard. Off it came.Recommendation: This product feels to me like plastic on lampshades. What are you saving them for, people? Take the plastic off your lampshades and enjoy them. Same thing with this. Enjoy that expensive, technologically perfect gorilla glass touch screen. No need to put plastic over it.

Works great and price was not too bad either. Worked perfect with out having to format it. Transfer rate was fast when I loaded 20 movies and 9 GB of musice and 2 GB of pictures all at the same time. It took a total of 30 min. probably because I had multiple transfers at same time but works great for my new bought Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1. Thanks

Monday, November 26, 2012I put this in the Galaxy S3 without formatting, restarted the phone and it showed 59.4g GB of space.  I transferred all the files from the old 16 GB card and then moved all my music to the card with the phone connected to my computer by the USB cord.  Still lots of space left and the various music players seem to see all the music.Tuesday, November 27, 2012The card didn't show up on the phone this afternoon.  No message, just no songs to play and no card according to everything I could check on the phone.  I restarted the phone and got a notification that the SD card was corrupt, needed formatting and that I would loose all data on the card.  I restarted the phone again, without formatting, and the card came up like it had never been missing.  I am writing this on Thursday, 11/29 and I have not had another issue with the card.December 6Well, I don't know what to think.  The card disappeared again and I reformatted it FAT32 in an attempt to fix the problem.  The whole point of getting this large card was to have my music on my phone and not have to stream it from the cloud.  I tried several music players and went with PowerAmp because of the good reviews and that I could specify the folder to play from.  So PowerAmp is looking for the folder /mnt/extSdCard/Music and playing the songs in all the subfolders.  It is PowerAmp that tells me that folder is not available.The card has gone missing one other time and restarting the phone fixed the problem.Today, PowerAmp would not play and when I got home I found the Music folder was gone.  I also had Ringtones folder and it was also gone.  Now, I may not be the sharpest saw in the shed, but I know I did not delete those folders.  The card had other folders but not those two so it had not been reformatted.I am starting to think the problem is with the Galaxy S3.  I had a 16 GB FAT32 card in this phone that had been in my previous HTC phone.  That card was not large enough to held my music so I don't know if it was disappearing or not.  I wish this combination of phone and 64GB card was more reliable but just don't know where the problem lies.I lowered the stars from 4 to 3 but I really don't know if the problem is with the card, the phone or both.  All I know is that they do not seem to be playing well together.December 7There was a notification on the phone this morning that the SD card was corrupted and needed to be formatted.  I restarted the phone several times and got the notification each time.  I reformatted the SD card using the phone, a step I don't think I have tried yet.December 8Another MINOR problem I have is that the message counter gets stuck on 1 when I have no new messages.  The only fix I have found is to restart the phone.  That happened this morning and I got the corrupted card message again, but restarted again and the card came up OK.December 11So, the files on the card keep disappearing.  The card is mounted and the phone shows the correct free memory but PowerAmp, and file directory programs do not see any files on the card.  I restart the phone and the files come back.  Very strange.  I played music on and off all day today without a problem and then this evening all the files disappeared again. Restarted the phone and all is well again.December 15My phone upgraded to 4.1.1 yesterday and the same issues remain.  It is a crap shoot as to if music will play.  I take a lot of photos and use the service Zenfolio to store and display them.  I have an app that syncs with Zenfolio and keeps a phone size version of the photos on my phone.  I set this app to store the photos on the Samsung SD card and have similar issues with it when the data on the phone goes away.  This morning the SD card came up as corrupt again after a restart to get the data back.  It took a total of 3 restarts to get the music and photos back.December 18I have been trying to play music stored on this card today and my phone has reset several times.  Very frustrating.  I ordered a SanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFP today for about $25.00 and I'll see if I have the same issues.  Very disappointing.December 28I purchased and installed theSanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFPand copied all the files from the 64GB card to the new 32GB card.  No formatting, no fuss, no muss.  I have not had a phone reset since, have played music through Bluetooth for hours in the car, have viewed photos.  Everything just works.  Half the memory but what I have is always available and the phone works, a good trade off.  I am still disappointed that the 64GB did not work with the SG3.  I have purchased aelago Mobile Nano II USB 2.0 microSDHC Flash Memory Card Reader (Black)to use the 64GB MicroSDHC card as a thumb drive.
summary: Did not work as external memory for Samsung Galaxy S 3

reviewerName: Tommy "Some Days You're The Dog ; Some Days Y...
reviewText: I ordered two 32GB and two 64Gb versions of these memory cards (but I can write only one review per Amazon). Two 32GB cards went into a camera and a cell phone which only accept up to 32GB cards -- and one 64GB card went into my Samsung Galaxy S3 cell phone. The second 64GB card's a spare.The Galaxy S3 phone accepted the 64GB MicroSD card with no problems -- except for the fact that my Galaxy S3 only recognizes 59.7GB of the 64GB MicroSD card. I have no idea why it does that and why I lost over 5GB of an empty MicroSD card but I'm okay with that -- I guess. 60GB's is still plenty. The transfers of music, videos, and pictures between the phone's internal 16GB memory and the 64GB MicroSD card is wayyy faster than the old SanDisk 16GB MicroSD card that was in there. The same noticeably faster speeds between my desktop computer and the 64GB MicroSD card were also smile inspiring.As for the SanDisk MicroSD cards -- they work great and seem to operate pretty darn fast. They're definitely faster than the old 16GB SanDisk MicroSD cards I had installed in my camera and cell phone(s).Now -- as for the shipping -- dismal! I ordered two 32GB along with two 64GB MicroSD cards on August 21 during an Amazon Gold Box sale. According to the tracking feature they didn't even transmit the shipping info to the carrier (USPS) until August 31. All four were shipped together. I didn't receive them until September 6 -- a full 16 days after I ordered. A little over two weeks for four tiny items that were indicated on the Amazon page as being -- "In Stock. Ships from and sold by Amazon.com" -- at the time of purchase. They also shipped all four tiny MicroSD card packages in a way over-sized box which the USPS couldn't fit into the mailbox so I had to make a cross-town trip to the US Post Office and stand in a very long and slow moving line to pick up the box. They could have all four EASILY fit in one small envelope. Even a small padded envelope. I left packaging feedback on that already.This is the 3rd straight time that Amazon shipping was horrible over the last several months -- and that is why the 2-star rating. This is not the Amazon shipping that I remember.
This is a wonderful product.  May not hold my whole library, but close enough.  Works great with the Galaxy Note 10.1, just need to reformat it as FAT and you're good to go.

I got mine from tiger direct.Pro's-  Windows 7 Home Premium, The i5-3450 rates very well in benchmarks, Lots of RAM, Lots of USB Ports, Room to upgradeCon's-Only 300W power supply, Amazon sells a 480W upgrade for the PowerMan fsu300-tha(1)DDR3 1333 Mhz, when the board supports 1600 MhzLimited to one monitor and one TV. Not two monitors, but space to add a extra video card.I plan on adding a better video card, upgrading the power supply and considering DDR3-1600Mhz, at the 16GB Maximum. For about $200 more this will be a top notch i5, and will blow away some of those low end i7's.  Also If you want to upgrade to the Ivy Bridge i7-3770 you can.This is how it rates in windows experience from 1.0 to 7.9Processor Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-3450 CPU @ 3.10GHz - 7.5Memory (RAM) 10.0 GB - 7.6Graphics Intel(R) HD Graphics - 4.8Gaming graphics 1696 MB Total available graphics memory - 6.3:UPDATE: a month in, still a great system.  I did a PSU Upgrade, added a blu-ray drive, got 16GB of ddr3 12800, usb video capture device.  A few other usb accessories. Will go with a 650 Ti CPU when it gets cheaper.One thing to note, in the BIOS there is some graphics adjustments to be made for performance improvements.  After those adjustments and installing the faster ram, my video performance improved quite a bit, able to have streaming video on both the monitor and tv as extended desktop, it was lagging a little previous to bios fix and ram upgrade.Did more research on the motherboard & chipset etc. The B75 is a nice chipset with, as others said "some limitations".  The B75 chipset usually doesn't allow for overclocking. Also being a ATX (micro) replacement boards don't have quite as many options when it comes time.  I wonder if I will ever use all those SATA ports on the motherboard or even if the computer has room for all those expansions.I recommend Searching for the M3985 Desktop Service Guide pdf for all the information you need.
summary: Great Price for a nice system.

reviewText: Bought this blu ray player at Walmart without looking at Amazon reviews first. Should have known better. Anyways, for $138 (Walmart price) I find this player to be mediocre at best.I loved the idea of it having a full internet browser. That was my main attraction to it. Unfortunately, not only did the internet portion of the player run entirely too slow but it never would even bring up the browser. Most of the other BR players in its same price range had the other features that it did (3D ready, Wireless/WiFi Ready, Standard DVD Upscaling, internet Apps etc.)So naturally I was disappointed from the get-go. The internet Aps ran slow or not at all from the start. The initial setup took FOREVER. I contribute these issues to the distance my player was from my Cable internet router. I have the fastest service Time Warner sells but because the router and player are on separate floors of the house, I believe the distance caused a bad/slow signal. Funny that my Xbox 360 had zero issues and actually gets a 4 bar connection (the best possible) most times when playing on it. My next step is to hardwire the internet connection to see if that helps. If not, this will be going back to Walmart.As far as the actual Blu Ray disc playing it performed like most would. The player started fairly quickly. The picture and sound were great, as expected. When I inserted a standard def. DVD the upscaling was quite nice. It performed those discs MUCH better than my XBox360 with HDMI OR my component cabled Samsung E360 DVD player. I have also yet to find a disc of any kind that will not play. This whole paragraph was a big positive so I gave the player one star for that and one for the other features (even though they didn't work right.I also hate not having any kind of standard audio or video out. It has HDMI and optical ONLY. The Onkyo TX NR709 receiver that I have this running through does not allow digital signals to come out of Zone 2 so I would not be able to listen to my CD's with this player in both rooms (the other room houses my pool table.) Not good. It would have been worth the sacrifice IF the internet browser had worked.Almost forgot... the Disc to Digital feature... not so much. Non-existent for Samsung as of yet. Probably wont ever happen.I'm still undecided but most likely this will be going back and will be replaced with a Panasonic BDT220 which has gotten LOTS of great reviews both on here and AV Science. Stay tuned. I will update this review.
summary: Great Features but internet anything doesn't work well

reviewText: I bought the others available from BestDealUSA and saw these later on. These were about .40 cheaper than the other item available so I thought I'd see if there was any difference...there isn't. These worked without issue. I plugged em into a USB 3 port with an Adata 16gb USB 3 thumb-drive and the read and write speeds were dead on with specs. 100mbps read and 22mbps write.Just way too cheap to not try these if your USB ports are a bit cramped. Especially on a laptop. These worked perfect for me.
summary: Why pay more for others when these work just the same?

reviewText: This is one of those items that I always feel like I'm taking a risk when I order it.  Will the eSATA adapter I ordered separately be compatible?  Will the cable not reach?  Will the drives I have somehow not be compatible because of some feature I didn't know to check for?Well, it arrived well packed and protected, the instructions were straightforward (even if a bit small for my eyes), and the device activated all four 1TB drives and showed a blue LED as each one spun up.I installed it on a server running Windows Server 2012 Essentials and initially all of the drives spun up then only the top drive remained active.  I put in the driver CD and used the "Update Driver" function and it found what it needed on the CD and all the drives lit up and stayed on.  Easy enough.Initially, I could see all the files from my last RAID array which was very surprising.  I didn't trust that, though, so I formatted the entire collection of drives as a new Storage Space with parity, and it has been good to go ever since.

If you realize that you are buying a product that runs google's OS, relies on google products (calendar, gmail, google+, etc.) and has limited functionality offline, then you will be happy with this product.  If you are anticipating buying a fully functional netbook or a macbook air, then you will not be happy with this product.  A number of reviews that I found online badmouthed the Chromebook and would constantly compare it to the macbook air.  At half the cost, this product is amazing.  This boots and loads webpages faster than my Lenovo Thinkpad, is lighter and cooler (temperature) than my Thinkpad and is ultimately a lot more portable.  Although a lot of the processing and accessibility is compromised, this is a great product for browsing the internet and just relaxing.

I bought this from Amazon and it is fast delivery.  It fires up fast wakes up fast in seconds.  It has youtube magic such as auto movie mode, auto HD action etc.  It makes viewing youtube so much more fun.  I am 73 years old.  I rely on youtube for all international entertainment not available from main stream.  This Chrome box is perfect for viewing youtube.  I would rate this five star plus.10/23/2012 updateAfter extensive test and use I now love my chrome box even more.  For those who just bought the Chrome box you may not realize that the  Chrome box can support three TVs at the same time technically.  This is not mentioned in the instruction.  However, a look at the outlet at the back one realizes that there is one DVI and two displayport outlets.  All of them can be connected to TVs simueltaneously.  All you need are the right digital cables.  I invested in three cables display port to HDMI and DVI to HDMI.  With these cables I am now connected to three TVs in my large living room.  I can sit in the rocking chair and watch TV on my desk or across the room.  With a wireless track ball I recently purchased through Amazon I can remotely control all three TVs without leaving the comfort of my rocking chair.

This is a fabulous flash drive.  The speed is faster and USB 2.0 and the capacity is great.  It's small, lightweight (as expected from a flash drive) but it performs flawlessly.There's not much more to say.  It's great, works as advertised, and I found no negatives.

This is a very good small graphics card, I am acostumed to bigger, more power hungry video cards, my main desktop uses a HD7970, but i have a secondary desktop that my younger brothers use and it was long overdue on getting a video card, the case is a small mATX with a good enough PSU, however i would not risk a card connected directly to it because of its sketchy claims (CoolerMaster 500, advertised as a 500W PSU, really a bad 420W one that cannot give accurately corrected power on PCIE lines) so i wanted to get a powerfull enough video card for the old monitor on it (17'' 1280x1024) so i went for this as it just uses 55W, uses the latest AMD architecture and is very slim, i have not yet tested the temperatures of the card on the mATX case while my brothers are playin, but just as my HD7970 on with the same kind of cooler, I know it will get hot on the VRMs, i will update as soon as i can measure the temperatures.
summary: Good Performance on a low power Card

reviewText: Bose really has you on this one. It is needed if you want to use your Bose Wave radio for its tremendous sound,without searching all around for different adapters. Because it says Bose you pay a hefty price,no discounts here.
summary: over priced for what it does.

reviewText: So I received this item on October 10th, 2012, set it up, and fell in love with it. I've never owned a desktop for gaming before, and I was looking for something reliable, decent specs, and within price range and boy I have to tell you, this just takes the cake. Beautiful machine. I've had it for about a month now and haven't ran into any problems whatsoever. Perfect for my level of gaming, and it can also of course be upgraded. The processor is great. Computer runs very fast. The video card is beyond decent, and handles high-grade games fairly well. (Skyrim, GTA, Crysis, etc.) The auto-setup for most games reads as high or ultra high, and runs such with very little lag. The only downside is the lack of HDD space. While it says 500GB, keep in mind the Operating System does take up 35GB of space alone, so when it arrives you're left with 465GB of HDD space, and that can fill up fast depending on any files and such you transfer from an old system that had beyond 500GB of space. The upside to that is this tower comes with many HDD bays, so it is not a problem to add your own new ones if you wish. I also was a bit edgy about the power supply. 400W is about pushing the bare minimum to run the CPU itself, so for anyone who is going to have a high end keyboard/mouse or stick LED's in the case, and things to that nature, you might want to consider upgrading to a 750W PSU like I did. Overall, this computer is great, and I HIGHLY recommend it if you were in my position with not a lot of money, but wanting a decent machine, and not entirely knowing what specs to look for, and this would also be a WONDERFUL gift for the holidays coming up! Especially with how great Cybertron's Customer Support is, should you run into any problems. 9/10!Edit: Just a note if anyone else is having problems with this. I noticed that sometimes upon startup, the front 2 USB ports out of 3 don't work. It seems that the USB drivers weren't installed correctly or something to that degree, but after troubleshooting and re-installing the driver, I haven't had any problems since!

I have AT&T; DSL and 2 computers running Windows 7 one 32bit and one 64bit. I bought this because my old Belkin wireless G couldn't handle 2 computers,Playstation 3,Blu Ray player and a kindle Fire. The setup was extremely easy and I'm a novice when it comes to wireless networks.The main thing is to READ the guide before you start and download the user manual from the Netgear site. I did have one problem. My wired computer would freeze up for a few second when I would start it and click the explorer icon but I changed the timeout setting in the genie to 0 and all is well.* Update 7/22: My network started hanging on startup and I'd get the blue circle over the connection icon. I found the culprit to be the Netgear Genie they wanted me to install on setup, I un-installed it and everything is working good. Other than that I'm very pleased with this router  the performance is awesome!***Update*** 8-19-2013 This router has been going strong for a year now with zero problems, the firmware updates flawlessly. I would recommend this to anyone needing a good fast router.

This router was extremely easy to set up!  Unplug modem.  Attach router.  Plug in modem.  Plug in router.  Search for new connections and enter password (both provided by Netgear - They recommend not changing them.  They are unique for every router they ship).  The speed wirelessly tested faster than connected straight into the modem.  Unbelievable!Pros:The fastest on the marketIncredibly easy to set upCons:No way to obvious way to mount it.  It sits on a surface - that's the way it is designed.I highly recommend.

What I used this router for is media sharing. I have a main laptop which is connected to the router via Ethernet and has three hard drives connected to it. I stream media from the main laptop to my "portable" laptop. The router is very fast when using 5GHZ. I get a  transfer speed of 16Mb/s and it goes up to 21Mb/s. I thought the router was perfect 10 minutes after I had installed it. However, a few hours later, I noticed it reboots on me and the movies or the video I'm watching stops. I had Amazon kindly send me a replacement. Only this time, in addition to the rebooting problem, the LED lights that show you whether or not the router is turned on, were defective. So there was no way you could know the status of the router without having to search for it using your computer. I asked Amazon to send me another replacement, which they kindly and quickly did. The last one I got had the rebooting problem as the first two. However, it did not have the LED lights problem. I finally decided to contact Netgear about the problem, they said the router was defective and I should have it replaced. I tried three of them for God's sakes! I finally got tired and just returned the damn thing. I hope nobody goes through what I went through. Definitely not recommended!

I'd been using the NR1403 for the last 6 months, which was a huge improvement over the Onkyo it replaced, so I was hoping the 1603 would be another huge step forward. The 1603 improves upon & adds quite a few options not available on the 1403, some are small improvements (better GUI, more customization options, updated face, etc.), and some big ones (7.1 vs 6.1, 7 HDMI vs 6, USB port, networking, built-in Pandora, SiriusXM, Spotify, Android app, etc.). I've only had it for a couple days, compared to the 6 months with the 1403, but so far, I haven't noticed any significant difference in A/V quality. The improvements & additions are great, though, but whether or not they're worth the additional 250 dollars really depends on how important those features are to you.Another noteworthy detail is the 3-year warranty, compared to the industry standard 2-year warranties from Denon, Yamaha, Onkyo, Sony, and others.The Android app is pretty good - ignore the ratings on Google Play. Apparently, some people who have higher-end Marantz receivers are angry because the app doesn't work with those models (nor is it advertised as such). For some reason, they think it's perfectly reasonable to give the app 1 star because it wasn't made to work with their equipment.

Amazing cinema sound and easy to use GUI. My only gripe is music does sound good, however I felt like my older Yamaha did a better job with the music. I don't know if to blame the speakers (Martin Logan MLT-2) or if it is the receiver.
great case good quality delivered on time ...wish speaker opening was a litle better other then that great case.slots are placed well very easy acces to all features of tab. a must have for your tab.
Bought a windows 7 operating system after Windows 8 was released so I was able to get it for a great price.  The laptop works great, just like the one I bought for more money 2 years ago.

I bought this to use with a desktop PC rather than bother with installing a wireless card. It replaced a TP-Link TL-WN722N High Gain Wireless Adapter that was rated for up to 150Mbps. Obviously the On Networks N300, at twice the rated speed, is faster. I expected that. What I didn't expect was how much it would improve my connection strength, given that the previous adapter had an external antenna. My PC is upstairs at the opposite corner of the house from the router, about as far away as far as it's possible to get. The N300 basically doubled my connection strength. It never shows less than full strength, which is great, and it runs much cooler than the other adapter.  And all of this in an incredibly tiny package at a great price. I can't recommend it enough if you need to add wireless capability to any computer. Despite the tiny size, it is definitely not just for laptops.

The price of this unit is very reasonable considering what you are getting in the USB 3.0 portable external Seagate Backup Plus hard drive. The unit also comes with a 2-year warranty.I used this drive to back up a very large music library which took quite a number of hours to backup. During that time, the unit stayed cool and was relatively quiet. The one issue I had is the USB wire length which could have been longer.There is software installed which aids in backup replication and social networking functionality. Additionally, Seagate has its own cloud backup but I didn't feel the need to use it.I backup my files multiple times because I worry about hard drive failure over time but generally trust Seagate products to last over time.I would recommend this drive without hesitation. Very nice.
summary: Used for backing up a huge music library

reviewText: It's fast, it's quiet, and best of all it's small.  Very easy to cart around between office and home.  I might get another to back up all my family photos and important files for storage in my tiny safe-deposit box.

Let me begin by saying this is not meant to be a portable drive. It needs to be plugged in to a USB port on a computer *and* into a standard power outlet to work. So just make sure you know what you are getting: a hard drive that sits on (or in my case, in a cabinet under) your desk.The Seagate comes with a USB 3.0 cable, which is fast enough for my needs (and works in USB 2.0 ports as well), but you have the option to use FireWire or Thunderbolt connections as well (these options require you to buy an additional adapter).This drive can function in one of three ways: as a simple drive, as a backup drive, or a combination of the two. To do the first is simple: plug it in. My Windows 7 machine instantly read it as an external drive.If you want to use the drive as a backup, either wholly or partially, there are installation files on the drive (no CD ... nice, and environmentally friendly :) )for the "Seagate Dashboard." After installing the program and rebooting the computer, you get a very intuitive interface with backup options. Within about thirty seconds I was able to set four custom folders for backup, but if you want a general backup that gets all your non-system files (pictures, music, etc.) it takes one click.You can also determine how often the backup occurs: a snapshot (back up the files as they are now and that's it) or a range of time periods (if you want to backup changes you make; you're given the option of monthly, weekly, daily, hourly or continuously). I also love the fact that you can have a variety of backup plans, so if I wanted to I can save a snapshot of the "Pictures" folder while backing up the "Music" folder every week and keeping the "Documents" folder on a constant backup.The drive backs up everything within a Seagate Dashboard folder on the drive, so even if you are using it as a backup you can use the free space on the drive as a regular external hard drive.Lastly, there's a series of lights on the front that indicate how full the drive is. It's a nice touch to be able to tell at a glance at the drive itself to get a rough idea of how much space you have free.For the range of features, a ton of usage options, and a generally good design, I give this an easy five stars.
summary: A flexible option for a non-portable external hard drive

reviewText: Purchased this drive to store all my HD videos. I've transfered about 1.7TB to it so far and it is working just fine. (Knocking on wood) I'm currently using the USB 3.0 connection to a USB 2.0 port, and there seems to be no performance issues playing the movies off of it.I'm hoping to get the Thunderbolt adapter at some point to test that out, but until then this seems like a nice high capacity storage solution.

I've always had good luck with Seagate products performing well, and while this Seagate Backup Plus desktop model is stable on the hardware end, it could use a little refinement in the software area. The USB 3.0 connection is fast and stable, and the 2-TB size is plenty of space for my needs. The device has a small footprint, but the glossy black housing is a dust and fingerprint magnet. The drive could use some silicone feet to help reduce drive noise transmitted into the desktop surface though, using it on an old steel industrial desk amplifies the noise the drive makes considerably.About 50% of the time during computer bootup, the Seagate Dashboard Agent stops working and has to be restarted; the same when trying to launch the app from taskbar. While it is said that it backsup online photos from Flickr and Facebook, only the Flickr backup works. The Facebook app just gives a message that it is still under development and won't back up anything from off of Facebook. It would have been nice if they'd have released the product for sale AFTER all the advertised features were fully functional, not still in development stage; this was a significant let-down.Longevity of the drive is hard to foresee, but if it is anything like my internal Seagate Barracuda 7200.10 drives that are still functioning fine going on 5 years of constant use, then I'll be happy enough.Buy the device for the hardware value, but don't expect the backup software to be stable.
This has worked flawlessly even on my mac. Just exactly we needed for all of our music, photos and movies!!!! Lots of storage space, Interchangeable connection adapters. Highly recommended.!!!

I chose this from Vine because it could also be used on Windows PCs, even though it's specifically formatted for macs. I read the directions, downloaded the file from Seagate, installed it, and rebooted my Windows 7 64bit laptop (the entire process took less than 10 minutes). The drive was recognized immediately, and I took a look at its contents. There are a few videos included on the drive, showing you how to use a few of the features, and after watching them, I realized I had no use for any of the pre-installed software. I copied all the files from the Seagate drive, and pasted them to a folder on my laptop, just in case I wanted them later, and then I began setting it up the way I wanted it.First, I deleted the EFI system partition (reclaiming 200MB), and then deleted the other partition, enabling me to create different partition sizes based on the entire drive. I decided to split it in half, and used TrueCrypt to encrypt one of the partitions.After getting everything sorted out the way I wanted it, I started using it, and it worked flawlessly. I brought it to work, where we're still running XP machines, and tried it there - again, no problems at all. It's USB 2.0, which may be a disappointment to some people, but it's good enough for me, for now.I have no opinion about the included software, since I have no use for any of it, and I can't comment about the longevity & durability of the drive, because I've only had it for a couple days, but based on what I'm using it for & how it has performed so far, I like it.It's a really nice size (just slightly larger than my phone, a GS2), and it seems to run pretty quietly & coolly, so no complaints there, and as far as using it on a Windows machine - no problems at all.
summary: Using on Windows 7 and XP, no problem.

reviewText: This is the smallest 500 gig hard drive I have yet owned.  It is very well built and of good quality.  It is fully backward compatible with earlier USB protocols and it can write from USB 2.0 at well over one gig per minute on multiple medium size file transfers; that is quite good... I have seen much worse, with bigger names on the outside of the drive.Overall, this is a great drive.

This portable external drive is pre-formatted with the MacOS HFS+ file system.  It has an aluminum top and a white plastic body.  On one end of the case there is a mini-USB port.  A foot-long white USB cable comes with the drive.  Overall the appearance matches my Macbook Air nicely.  The size and weight are typical for any 2.5" portable drives.Upon connecting this drive to the Macbook Air, the computer automatically recognized the new drive and offered to use it as the backup drive for the Time Machine backup utility.  I accepted the offer and Time Machine started backing up the Macbook Air two minutes later.  The initial backup of roughly 25GB of data took about 3 hours.  This was not because the drive was slow, but because Time Machine ran at a slow pace and low priority in order not to slow down any work I was doing.  Incremental backups are fast because Time Machine only adds what have changed since the last backup.Overall the experience with this drive is very smooth.  It worked out of the box as promised.  In addition to the full compatibility with Mac and Time Machine, the drive also comes with software that integrates with Facebook etc. to back up your social network content.  Since I am not interested in those and do not want any unnecessary software to slow down my computer, I did not use the extra software.I highly recommend this drive as a companion to Macbook Air, for its simplicity, ease of use, and matching appearance.
summary: Works out of the box with Time Machine on a Macbook Air

reviewText: This device is made especially for Mac and as a time machine backup drive it is OK. The crappy software included brings this slow product further down. It has a drive action light that belongs in a Sci-Fi B movie. Tutorials that I was directed to were for Microsoft and not relevant. I prefer the much faster Western Digital external drive.
summary: Crappy software brings this slow product further down

reviewText: After having a hard drive fail (granted something fell on the laptop so the fault was mine) I have always been religious about backing up my files.  This external hard drive marks the 4th I've owned.  Of course, even that sometimes isn't enough as I once had an external hard drive fail as well.  My solution has been to have two external hard drives, that way if one fails I still have everything stored somewhere else.  My other external hard drive is aWD My Book Studio 1TB Mac External Hard Drive Storage USB 3.0that I purchased first in 2010.  That one is thankfully NOT one of the ones that failed and has been going strong ever since.I found this drive to be comparable.  The speed of downloading data seemed similar as does the noise level when it is running.  I love that like my My Book, it is plug and play for Macs.  All you have to do is hook it up to your computer and you'll quickly be backing up your data.  I've been using it for a few months and so far it has been very reliable.  I haven't had any issues with it crashing or any other problems and most importantly, it hasn't died so for now, my data is safe.  I find the 2 TB size generous enough to back up everything from my computer.Overall I've been satisfied with this hard drive to date.  To me the main features are that it has a long hard drive life and doesn't suddenly die on me (so far it hasn't) and that it isn't slow as molasses at downloading my data (speed seems fair).  As long as it fulfills both I'm a satisfied user!  The only things that kept this from being a 5 star external hard drive, for me, were that while the speed is fair it isn't exceptionally fast and the design to me is lacking.  I know the latter won't matter to some people but since excessive handling killed previous drives I've been extra cautious and don't move it much from its home, but it isn't exactly something I am that thrilled to have out on my desktop.  In an ideal world, since it is meant to be used with a Mac, I would have loved something that mimicked the design of my computer.  But you can't have it all!
summary: Works as well as my existing WD My Book Studio 1TB Mac External Hard Drive

reviewText: Thin, sleek, simple to use, portable and dependable. The USB 3.0 cable is included.The problem is there is no 'cloud storage icon' in the Seagate Dashboard software - the Mac version of Seagate Dashboard doesn't have either the Cloud or the Protect features. For Mac systems, Seagate recommends backing up your system using Apple Time Machine. This is a Windows drive with limited Mac functionality.The Seagate Dashboard software isn't easy to install on a MAC OS 10 and above. To do this, you need to do a custom install.
