This drive is NOT totally Mac compatible nor is it fully functional (using ALL the extra features).The Seagate Backup Plus is a good BASIC backup drive for your Mac.If you want to automatically backup from the Cloud, you're out of luck (at least using a Mac).The Seagate Dashboard software is useless for a Mac user.So, for the price...I'd have to say I don't like it. It's nothing more than a dependable, portable, hard drive when it comes to Mac OS 10 (and above).
summary: Mac Users are OOL When it Comes To Special Features!

reviewText: This Seagate Thunderbolt Backup Plus for Mac is a must have. If any of you have ever experienced a loss of data or inadvertently deleted an important file, you know that such a purchase is essential. This desktop unit stores an incredible 3 TB (terra bytes) of data (any and all of your files) is works perfectly with Mac's Time Machine. It is an attractive design and comes with the Thunderbolt cable. This Seatgate external hard drive for Mac comes with an impressive three-year limited warranty. Please do remember that your initial backup will take quite a long time subject, of course, to the amount of data you have on your Mac. Once the initial backup is done, the unit continues to store and protect your data seamlessly and invisibly.
summary: Essential & Impressive external hard drive backup unit for Mac users

reviewText: I'm using this for Time Machine on an iMac. works just fine. When I first received this drive, I couldn't get any of my computers to recognize it. I returned it and Amazon replaced it quickly. No problems with this one!
summary: A Fine Drive for Time Machine

reviewText: 15" Samsung Series 9 with 256GB SSD, i7 processor and 8GB RAM. The specs are great and the Series 9 has an elegant, slim, solid unibody-type design. I couldn't live with less than 256GB storage and I'm really glad I didn't settle for the 128GB flavor.1) Machine is very fast - boots from cold in less than 10secs, resumes from sleep in less than 2. Incredible. Screams through any task I give it.2) Screen is about right at 1600x900 - enough pixels for side-by-side documents while not requiring a microscope to read text. Screen is matte which is nice but I am not as impressed with the color rendition as others seem to be - it's ok but nothing amazing.3) Battery life is very good - I regularly achieve 8 hours or more which for me effectively equals all day use. Very impressive.4) Audio is OK but I wouldn't use for listening to music. I did have to make a change in the audio settings to boost the max volume to a more usable level (Speaker Properties > Enhancements > Loudness Equalization).5) I liked the fnLock key with its LED which allows me to use the Fn keys for screen system controls (brightness, sound etc) without requiring the Fn button each time.While the Series 9 has a lot going for it I had to make a few adjustments to really enjoy the machine properly:-1) Downgraded from Windows 8 to Windows 7 - just couldn't get on with 8 and needed this to be focused 100% on the desktop experience. During this process I also reclaimed all the drive space partitions which gives me 230GB of usable capacity. Much happier now. YMMV.2) Touchpad - I'm used to a MacBook Pro touchpad which is pretty much perfect (even when running Windows in Bootcamp) and the Series 9 touchpad was unpleasant at first - sometimes selecting when I wanted to scroll, right-clicking when I wanted to left-click etc. In the end I found a different driver for this that solved all these issues (ironically NOT the latest version - the best was Elan version 11.6.4.001 for those interested for themselves). I also disabled right corner clicking and reversed scroll direction ("natural"). Feels better now.3) Keyboard backlight - there is no manual control over this if the sensor decides the room is too bright. In my experience there were times I wanted it on but the software refused me (why? let ME decide!). So I blocked the light sensor with a small piece of tape and now I have full control over brightness. Works but I really shouldn't need to do this.4) I had a key (BACKSPACE) that was temperamental - sometimes didn't register key-presses at all. I was almost going to return the machine but thought I'd try a blast of compressed air first from one of those pressurized cans with a straw. Out popped a microscopic piece of plastic debris and Voila! - now it works perfectly.5) The micro-ports are a bit of a pain - not happy about carrying adapters around for Ethernet and VGA but I got used to that with the MacBook Pro VGA dongle (didn't like it there either) and the Series 9 is much thinner - Samsung at least provide the Ethernet adapter in the box. Charger port isn't as elegant as Apple's mag-safe but it does the job.So as you can see with a few software tweaks Samsung could have had a 5-star machine - basically ship with a better touchpad driver and backlight software that gives full control to the user and you're golden.Overall though I now love my Series 9, it just needed a little TLC at the start.

I have a similar Moko case for my 3rd gen iPad and it's been nothing but pleasant to use.I purchased a similar rooCASE for my iPad mini (I think it was a dollar or two cheaper) and it is nice. Unfortunately, the first version does not have the sleep/wake function. However, the seller is sending me a revised cover that will have the sleep/wake function.The Moko is everything the rooCASE is, but better. The finish is much more pleasing to the eye and feels better, too. It also has an elastic band that helps keep the cover folded behind the iPad. This is convenient when I'm using my iPad in bed.All in all, the rooCASE is fine. But for a couple dollars more, the Moko is the way to go. I'll be keeping both cases, though (it's not worth returning the rooCASE.
summary: Moko nails it, again! Excellent case!

reviewText: This external hard drive is very easy to install and use, with no additional software required. Just plug in and you're ready to start using it. For those who may need it, a very brief Quick Start Guide is included in the box.I have been using this drive to supplement the meager 160GB on my aging laptop to store my ever-growing photo, music and video collections. When I bought the laptop, even 1 TB was unheard of, but in this digital age, 2TB of storage is never too much. Of course, as was mentioned by another reviewer, (and which I think is very good advice,) you should always keep at least two copies of your important files on different drives in case of hardware failure. This drive has a large enough capacity to back up the computers in my household for now.I would not use this drive as a portable device as mentioned in the product description. The product is described as a Desktop external drive, and in my opinion it is too bulky to carry around in addition to a power supply cord, since it uses external power. There are smaller external drives, albeit with less storage capacity, that are better designed for portability.Users should note that even though it might be plugged into a power outlet, it only powers up when it is connected to a computer. Once disconnected, or if the computer is shut down, the drive powers off.Amanda Richards, November 10, 2012
summary: Great for storage, tough to tote

reviewText: The Seagate Desktop Expansion 2TB drive provides tremendous storage capacity which [in Windows 7's case] is as easy as plugging it in and waiting for the initial recognition and driver installation.The drive is quiet for the most part. I've heard two tiny mechanical noises coming from the unit during initial use, but it has operated in complete silence ever since. If anything serious happens, I'll come back to make it known. So far it's working great.The drive case has most of its air vents on the underside, so make sure it sits on a hard flat surface for proper ventilation. The small rubber feet are very thin and allow only about an eighth of a centimeter of clearance from the surface the drive sits on.Though the setup guide makes it appear as if the adapter comes with interchangeable international plug ends, it does not. It comes with a one-piece, standard North American plug. I'm not too excited about the way the plastic, which surrounds where the two prongs come out, is extruded from the face of the plug. Instead of the entire plug's weight being supported by a large flat surface against the wall, it's relying on the 3 cm x 2 cm rectangular area to hold it in place - I hope it doesn't fall out while writing files to disk.I love the massive storage capacity. It is simple to use. Other than the balancing act the adapter does to hold itself in the wall, it's great!

One of the many great things about this Seagate Expansion Portable External HardDrive is the size.  Good things really can  come in small packages!  Another thing is its ease of use.  Everything works with the USB cable...no external plug-ins.  It transferred information fast and easy.  I love knowing I have a backup for personal and important information.  Highly recommended.
summary: You Don't Have To Be Tech Savvy!

reviewText: My version of this hard drive shipped without software, so it's an additional, external drive, rather than an automated backup.  Suppose that tech savvier-people than me could work around this, but I don't know how.So I copied over all my photos, and it took a long time, and OK.  Wasn't doing anything else and I didn't have to sit there and watch.But:  The USB is upside down.  That is, the little icon that tells you which side of the cord goes where is on the underneath of the cord that plugs into the drive.  USB connections are stupid and frustrating enough to have developed their own following on Pinterest, and I'm old enough that I can't see those little icons without glasses, and I don't understand why manufacturers can't be consistent.  (A gold paint pen or Sharpie, BTW, is the answer...)Sigh.  I love technology.  I got a review "copy" of this drive for the cost of writing a review.  If I had a way to NOT buy products with backwards USB connections I would; I don't know how to know this fact about a product before you buy, so this is a fantasy revolt rather than anything actionable.  (But Seagate is reading their reviews...)Incidentally, the packaging is cardboard, easy to open, and recyclable.  +1 for that.

The Seagate Expansion drive is awesome. It does everything it should, and I even waited a couple months to write this review to see how it behaved after a good bit of use. So far, so good. I haven't had a single problem with it- though I do wish the warranty was more than one year. That's my only complaint thus far.Side note- The formatted capacity is 465gb. This is fine with me, as I won't be using all my space anyway. Though if you need the extra space, delete the utility after registering. (I usually keep the autorun.)Other Pros:1. Very cool- doesn't heat up2. Super fast USB 3.03. Affordable4. Backwards compatible5. Very quiet

I bought this motherboard to replace a failed HP motherboard and so far, I'm very impressed with the implementation of this motherboard. I mainly bought this board because it was one of the most inexpensive AM2+ mATX motherboards on sale and it's a very good quality board for the price. The dual AM2+/AM3(DDR2/3) option is really nice if you have an older processor/RAM because it offers the possibility of upgrading. The trade off is that an AM3 processor will only work w/ DDR3 RAM and an AM2 CPU will only work with DDR2 RAM but it is a small trade off. The on board graphics works as it should and will easily support a 1920x1200 screen resolution but don't expect to be playing many games unless you add a video card to the PCI express slot. As a side note, this mobo will only support AM2+ processors of 95W or less so be sure to find out what type CPU you have before purchasing.
summary: Well designed and reliable mATX mobo

reviewText: We thought we were buying a case back and cover - especially since the cover was shown in three different pictures and the name "cover" was in the product name. But it's simply a back. And for the price? I think it's extremely overpriced.

reviewerName: K. Salinger, MSN, FNP, RN AHN-BC
reviewText: I originally bought the rooCase for my husband's Nexus 7rooCASE Multi-Angle (Black) Vegan Leather Folio Case Cover for Google Nexus 7 Tablet (Automatically Wakes and Puts the Nexus 7 to Sleep) Lifetime Warrantyand this Moko cover for mine.My husband thought the rooCase felt too thick so we put them side by side. Sure enough, the rooCase is about 3-4mm thicker than the Moko case. Part of this seems to be because there is actually an extra layer to the rooCase that is behind the nexus and is used to hold it up when setting up the rooCase in it's tripod type positon (not sure what else to call the position). The cover also has a puffiness to it - like a thin layer of padding under the fake leather or something - and we didn't really like the feel/look of that either.In addition to preferring the thinness of the Moko my husband also liked the card holders, hand strap, and the overall feel of my Moko case better. The speakers are louder in the Moko because they arent blocked - there are holes over the speaker area, whereas the rooCase covers them completely.Consequently, the rooCase went back to Amazon and we ordered a Moko case for his just like mine. The bummer for me is that now they look identical & we can't easily tell which one is which.In my opinion, the Moko does indeed look nicer than the rooCase. It has white detail stitching and doesn't have the puffy feel of the rooCase and so looks/feels more professional (I use mine in a professional context as well as personal...). I too prefer the thinness and like the card holder slots.Summary: This Moko cover for the Nexus 7 is superior to the rooCase.
summary: Comparing this with the RooCase for Nexus 7 - this Moko wins

reviewText: I ordered the cords to have a charger for the car. It's wonderful to get an order and have everything work like it should.  Thank you amazon for another great product.

This small bluetooth speaker packs a mild punch and sounds good to the average listener.  If you were hoping for sound like the bose soundlink or jawbone big jambox, its not even close.  This speaker puts out about 50% of the output the soundlink and big jambox would.  Its a little cheaper but not by much.I returned this item as it didn't come close to competing with the soundlink I had recently bought.  I would buy this product if it were priced around $100. No way will many people buy this for $200. Simply not enough sound/volume/loudness to justify paying that.  Best Buy has this speaker along with a couple others that it simply can not compete with.  Yes, it is smaller and if thats all youre looking for then the Jawbone little jambox produces just as much if not more sound than this at about the same size and cheaper.Again, a nice small simple BT speaker but costs too much for too little sound.

Denon AH-D400 Urban RaverTM Over-Ear Headphonesprovide a decent sound but the extra bass can be a bit too much.. and there seems to be no way to lower itIt's great for an ipod or portable music player... But I would not recommend using these on a cell phone or on facebook while on a computer. the bass is too much. when ever my phone rings while I use my phone for music or while I use them on my computer and I get messaged on facebook - I jump up out of my seat because of how Alarmingly loud the sound is and how high the bass is.. and they the only way to fix it seems to just turn the switch off. There doesn't seem to be a bass adjuster and that's a disappointmentThe other issue is that the packaging claims the battery lasts up to 12 hours... I get maybe 5 and a halftechnically, its an excellent pair of headphones. but it has way too much bass and no way to adjust it.. which is why I can't rate it 5 stars
Not stable, no night vision,no Android. The setup is easy, but I had few compatibility issues. The design is OK. They just copied iZone to replace them at the apple store.

This is the thinnest, lightest notebook I've ever owned! The battery life is great, and the processor is very fast. The only thing I wish was different was that it had a cd rom drive. I own an external drive, so it wasn't a problem for me. It came with Microsoft office standard for free, and that was great for me, because I'm tired of paying for the parts of office I don't use. I can't speak highly enough about this computer, and recommend it to anyone needing a lightweight notebook that works great!
summary: Unbelievable notebook at a phenomenal price!

reviewText: I'm using this TV as a monitor for my other gaming computer.I don't know how good this is for watching tv, but i've been using it as a monitor with no problems.The quality (Once again, as a monitor), is good (But big due to it being 720p, if you try using it as you would a 1080p tv, it won't be that great)Great for the price!

This Korean-built, Samyang-sourced, 8mm Rokinon lens has a maximum 2.8 aperture, and is therefore, faster than the 3.5 versions intended for Nikon, Canon, etc. (I bought the otherwise identical silver version of this lens.)Its optical construction is a fairly sophisticated system of 10 elements arranged in 8 groups, including one aspherical and two ED elements, according to the literature.The lens is high-contrast, with excellent flare control and color rendition for the price, as is its quality of construction.Its maximum angle of view is 180 degrees on the frame diagonal, so it is, indeed, wide angle, but also covers the full frame.The lens has a thin, red highlight ring that distinguishes it from native black Sony E lenses.It is a manual lens, and does not have the anti-shake OSS mechanism of some, but not all, of the Sony E-mount lenses.All in all this lens a worthwhile purchase.
summary: A Fast, Ultra-Wide Lens for Sony NEX E-Mount Lens Cameras

reviewText: Good decent replacement battery for the low price.  Phone works much longer like new.  No problems at all even after months of use.

I was impressed with the ability to extend wireless networks into rooms where the strength of the signal was not the best. It creates a new SSID with "_Almond" after the network SSID you are extending. There were a couple minor things that were not show-stoppers. One was that the question mark (?) was not available as a passphrase character, so I had to change a passphrase on an existing router to accommodate the Securifi Almond. The other was in typing in long passphrases, when you fill up the field on the screen, you can no longer see what you are typing in the field. I was expecting that it would roll the letters to the left so that I could see the latest characters in the field and be sure that it was all going in correctly. Hopefully they will change this behavior in future releases. I didn't try using it as a router, so I can't speak to that. Very happy with this.The other thing I noticed (that is actually a problem in many products) is that I wish the passphrase would go invisible and stay that way. At least the entire passphrase can't be seen because of the problem already stated above. I would like it if you could only see the passphrase when you enter it and cannot see it after that. Not too secure if anyone can walk up to this and find out the passphrase ... especially if I had used a shorter passphrase that fit in the window. Little things like this make a huge difference.Still love the product and I recommend it.

For under 150 this tablet is not bad at all.  I ultimately mine failed and I had to return it but I think this was more bad luck than anything.In reverse order I'll do the cons first.No Bluetooth.  Maybe not a big deal.... it wasn't for me.... but there it is.It died.  As I pointed out above I think this was just luck of the draw.  It's got decent review here on Amazon and there are websites dedicated to it RUN by hoards of adoring fans so it can't be too bad.When using in portrait mode the viewing angle can be bothersome.... not too bad but definitely something to be aware of.I don't know if it was just MINE or what.....  I've heard no other complaints but the orientation sensor is sometimes finicky when going from one orientation to the other.Now the Pros.VERY solidly built, I was impressed.  Aluminum case even.From the  factory it was running Android 2.3.something but there is a free update to 4.0.3 that installed easy as can be and works like a charm.  Also from the factory it just has an offbrand market, BUT when you perform the ICS upgrade it's got the Google market so all is good.Very responsive.  After seeing many MANY cheap sub 150 android tablets running 800 or 600Mhz CPUs I was very pleased with this unit's 1.2Ghz AND dedicated GPU.  It ran several games well, streamed video and played local content smoothly.Other thoughts:I do mobile app testing and support for a living so this table was put thru it's paces being rebooted and reset, apps added and removed with alarming frequency, etc....  It never missed a bit.  Boots up fast, wireless performs well.  When this one died I had to have another so simply replaced it locally but I imagine had it not died I would have been using it for quite some time.
summary: Mixed feelings.... But not a bad product

reviewText: Pros:- Image quality superb, better than a lot of DSLR (and m4/3) and light years better than compacts available (I've already had the flawled Canon S100, Canon G10, Sony TX100V, Sony HX9V, Fuji 550, Sony DSC-N2, Panasonic ZS-10). Sony created a whole different category.- F1.8 Lens amazing at low light, tele end f4.9 not so much- Tiltable flash with 90 makes amazing indoor pictures.- The video is unbelivable, I burn AVCHD DVDs to play on blu-ray and it is better than my store bought blu-rays.- Full manual controls.- Microphone's position perfect for low noise during windy days.- Pocket size with a 1" sensor is amazing, 20 MP picture simply perfect at 100% crop, even at low ISO.- Super quick and smart focusCons:- Pop-up flash have to be manually closed.- ZOOM WHILE VIDEO IS REEEEALLY SLOW!!- COLORS ON AUTO MODE ARE WEIRD LOOKING (COLD AND DARK), IF YOU ARE NOT A PROFESSIONAL, PICTURES COLORS MIGHT LOOK A LOT DIFFERENT FROM THE POINT-AND-SHOOT CAMERAS... On P mode I set the colors to Landscape, they got a lot better! I also recommend using the soft skin effect for a smooth skin pictures.- FLASH IS A LITTLE OVER EXPOSED ON AUTO MODE, I set to -1.0 on P mode.- Not the best camera for Macro pictures, the closest distance is 5cm. Other premium compacts allow you to get as close as 1cm.- Not as wide as some other premium compacts (28mm vs 24mm like Canon S100 and Panny LX7)Still the best compact camera ever made!
summary: The best compact camera ever made!

reviewText: Simply here are some cons and pros.Pros1. Build Quality. Yep! It's Sony.2. High Contrast with Good size for printing.3. Good User Interface4. Customizable buttons5. Portable6. New Battery X takes over 300 shots (Usually I took over 500 shots with full charged)7. Mini usb charge8. Carl Zeiss T coated lens. I don't care about F. my favorite A setting is always F5.6 or 7 (yep. depends on people)9. iso 100 through 800 or even 1600. hard to find noise10. Great Movie recording feature. Mostly better than any dslr or mirrorless ones.11. CompactCons1. No External flash or VF connector (I think it is understandable issue. Because I saw Panasonic's LX7 design yesterday. And Design is so ugly. To me Don't want spend money to get expensive accessaries for compact camera. People doesn't want to spend extra money for that.. I believe. Instead of that, Internal flash is really working great.)2. Grip? (I am a big fan of gr digital or lumix LX series grip but for this camera. Without rubber grip, it makes much sharper and cool design. Yes. I want minimized design from Sony. I believe Leica X series has same issue and they are selling extra grip with very expensive price tag. And original leather case is supporting for this part well)3. No battery charger? Yep. I want battery charger.4. No WiFi? Um.. Actually Heavy photo files can be transferred by usb cable I think. no necessary with 20M pixel camera especially. This is seriously compact for professional or mania. GPS? yep... with gps and price higher is not good solution but same price with GPS feature. that will be great.5. Price... well. little expensive..6. 28mm Wide. 24mm or 25mm is very common spec now a days. First, Yes. I like 24mm Wide lens for landscape but also I like 28mm classic wide lens. In my memory, 28mm, 35mm, and 50mm is my old basic 3 lenses always. 28mm is better than 24mm's distortion and low light at corner issue and feel that is enough. also it is very useful for 5-6people shot at short distance. 35mm lens is classic. it is great for everywhere. portrait or landscape, especially street snap. 50mm is really good for portrait. Most of baby photo is from 50mm. On Automatic mode of RX100, easily change. there is 28mm-35mm-50mm - something like this. If there is 24mm option that will be great but without 24mm it is okay. This is luxury coated lens and classical 28mm.Thank you.
summary: How close your camera with you? Everyday Point and Shoot. Compact but Strong.

reviewText: First of all here are some of the basics of how this product was tested.* Home office* One computer running Windows Vista 32-bit w/ a wired connection to the router* Comcast cable Internet (non fiberoptic connection)* iOS devices for wireless testing* Router is in a finished basement of a ranch style home (1 story)* Older router being replaced:Linksys Wireless-G 2.4 GHz Wireless RouterPROS================================+ Dual band support, so you can run both a 2.4 gHZ and 5 gHZ wireless network. This is useful as older routers had the option of catering to the lowest common demoninator, but with a dual band router you have the best of both worlds.+ Wireless speeds were blazing fast close and far away from the router. I tested using an iPhone 5, iPad 1 and iPad 2 and all remained consistent in download times of websites right next to the router and on the 1st floor. With the previous router I had issues where the wireless would drop out in certain spots on the 1st floor, but I had no such issues or decreased throughput on this router.+ My job is technical in nature, so I can navigate the advanced setttings on the router pretty easily. However, the quick setup was a breeze and I can see it being very useful for the average user. The ability to auto-detect your Internet connection was especially nice, since it immediately picked up on our cable modem. Most cable modems require a MAC address clone. An average user who plugs in a router doesn't realize this and may end up spending money because the router isn't working. The TP-Link quick setup detected this potential issue and immediately made the suggestion to avoid that problem.+ The support for an external drive or printer via USB is a nice touch at this price point for a router already supporting dual band and great wireless range. I tested this out with a thumb drive and it worked very well. I was able to plug in the thumb drive, enable the drive for internet FTP access and then test it using my iPhone (with the wireless disabled) using LTE. I was able to login and browse the files on the thumb drive. There is a limit per device of 10 folders to share.+ Parental controls were nice at a free price point. Linksys charges for the parental controls on its routers, but the TP-Link allowed setting up some basic controls with no additional cost. I will concede that the Linksys service offers some advanced monitoring features, but it's nice to have basic controls at no additional cost, which for our family serves the purpose.+ Advanced options were extensive and included everything I might need and had with the previous router. For those interested, there is support for Dynamic DNS built in through dyndns.org, comexe.cn and no-ip.com.CONS================================- Size. Footprint on this router is larger than the 4-port wired & wireless router I was previously using. This wasn't an issue for me, but may be for others.- The power cord was about 1' shorter than my previous router, so it's a bit stretched to keep in the same position. The included cord is 5' in length.- This is more of a product improvement for the quick setup, but I think it's worth noting for anyone not very technical. The quick setup does not include the option to change the default username and password. This is a must and I think it should be required as part of the setup. Make sure to click System Tools and then Password to change the defaults.Overall, this is a great router and there are very few shortcomings. I took away half a star for the minor items I listed under the CONS heading. If you are looking for a router above entry level, but below the $100 threshold look no further.********* I received this product for free as part of the Amazon.com Vine program. Nonetheless, I review the product in the same manner as I would if I had purchased it myself. *********
summary: Great Router w/ Dual Band and Extensive Range for the Price (4.5 out of 5)

reviewText: Pros:+ Fastest dual-band router I have used by far+ Lots of configuration options in admin panel+ DLNA server, FTP server, USB printer server and USB storage serverCons:- Physically large- Admin user interface can be confusingFor the last two-plus years I have been using the Netgear WNDR3700V1 dual-band router. At the time I bought it, it was considered one of the fastest dual-band routers available, and it had lots of features. It does work very well, but Netgear has revised it twice and the subsequent V2 and V3 releases have diminished functionality and performance.  While I have used many brands of routers in the past, TP-Link was new to me so I was curious to see how the TL-WDR4300 compared.The router itself is a large box.  It's attractive and has a nice design, but it is much wider than competing routers. It is also very lightweight. Perhaps the width is so that the three dual-band antennae can be physically separated more - I don't know.  There are keyhole slots on the bottom in case you want to wall-mount it, but as with most all routers, the wiring all goes to the back where the antennae are, so this might be awkward if your wiring comes from below.TP-Link provides a setup "wizard" on a mini-CD (you can also download it from their web site), but I just connected to it directly and configured it through the admin panel.  I was delighted to see that the wireless networks came up pre-configured with WPA security and an 8-digit password - many routers are simply "open" when first configured. This encourages users to maintain security.  You can set the wireless to WEP or even open if you want, but that's generally ill-advised.Unlike a certain other brand of router I have tried two examples of (cough - D-Link - cough), the TP-Link had no trouble negotiating with the Ethernet feed of my FiOS optical network box (the equivalent of a cable modem).  Some of the configuration features it had that I liked were:- Dynamic DNS support (though the selection of providers was limited)- Separate and easy to understand configuration of 2.4 and 5GHz bands- Ability to reserve IP addresses to specific devicesSome of the things I didn't like:- Only a single display of DHCP clients connected, rather than separating wired from wireless- IP reservation page did not let you select from known connections - you have to type the MAC address- No "guest mode" - this is a feature the Netgear WNDR3700 has that adds a second network which can be configured to give Internet access only and not access to your local network.  This is great for houseguests and the like [Edit - TP-Link added Guest Mode in a later firmware update]The admin user interface is straightforward, though it uses submenus and some of the pages seemed to duplicate others.  For example, there were two different pages where one could enter DNS server addresses, and changes to one did not carry over to the other. While each page had pretty good instructions right in the dialog, some of the options were a bit confusing as to how to set them. But what really got me were the pages where I did not notice at first that a frame of the dialog had a scrollbar, and I had to scroll to the right to see additional links, even though there was lots of space for them to show otherwise.  A full manual is on the CD as well as on the web site.Once set up I tested performance at a distance of about 25 feet through two walls. First I ran tests using the Netgear and then the TP-Link with the same remote server.  The TP-Link delivered speeds 30-50% better than the Netgear on both the 2.4GHz and 5GHz bands. The Netgear is very good about coverage in my house - it has eight (I think) internal patch antennae where the TP-Link has three, rather tall stick antennae. I found coverage to be at least as good as the Netgear, even about 50-60 feet away and through multiple walls.  I could only go by "bars" of signal strength but it seemed to me that the TP-Link's signal was stronger on both bands. Many dual-band routers are particularly weak on the 5GHz band.As the three antennae suggest, this router supports the "3X" mode of some Wireless N adapters for a theoretical maximum bandwidth of 450Mbps on the 5GHz band and 300Mbps on the 2.4GHz band.  Add those together and you get the "750" emblazoned on the router.  The spec sheet I got indicates tested speeds of 241Mbps and 135Mbps respectively, still not shabby. The Ethernet ports are all Gigabit, and the test indicates LAN-WAN speeds as much as 935Mbps.  That's fast.The TL-WDR4300 has two USB 2.0 ports on back.  These can connect to USB storage or to a USB printer.  For storage the router will make the storage available as a network share, or you can enable an FTP server that can, if you wish, be accessed from the Internet. (The default is off.) Unfortunately, only standard FTP is supported, not SFTP over SSH, so your login information (you can set a username/password pair) is sent unencrypted.  My advice is to NOT use this feature over the Internet.I did not test the print server, as my printer is already network-enabled. For Windows there is a utility you install that, if I understand correctly, pretends to be a USB port and relays information to and from your USB printer.  Scanners are also supported.I did test the DLNA media server.  You can specify up to six folders on the USB storage to serve and it will relay audio, video and photos to DLNA clients on your local network.  I fired up Goodplayer on my iPad and played a movie from a USB hard disk - it worked beautifully.  The promotional material claims that it can serve media over the Internet, but I think this is incorrect - there's no setting to enable/disable it and no instructions for how you would access the media from outside your local network.  I will verify this with TP-Link support and update this review when I learn more. (Edit: TP-Link confirmed that media serving is local network only.)TP-Link's documentation takes the unusual step of saying that one can install and run the freeware DD-WRT router software on some of its routers.  I checked at the DD-WRT web site and while the WDR4300 is not yet officially supported, there is a beta version that at least partially works, and development for the WDR4300 is proceeding.  According to the spec sheet TP-Link included, the WDR4300 has an Atheros chipset that runs at 560MHz, 128MB of RAM and 8MB of flash - these are rather high values for routers in this price range and suggests great performance and resistance to locking up after being on a long time (a problem I have seen with other routers.)Lastly, as I do for most products I test, I looked at power consumption. For a device you'll leave on all the time, this can matter. I was pleased to see that the WDR4300 maxed out at 4 watts with wireless on, where the older Netgear router was averaging 6-7 watts. Excellent.Not only does the TP-Link router seem well-designed, but their web site is easy to navigate as well, unlike those of some more well-known brands.[Edited February 6, 2014 to note that Guest Mode was added after my initial review.]
summary: Super-fast, great range, lots of features

reviewerName: John Salazar "I do NOT review books, stop ask...
reviewText: Wasn't sure about this when I ordered it but there just aren't a ton of options out there yet for the A510.Came yesterday and was at first surprised it came "bulk" meaning that it was wrapped in a plastic bag and that's it.What I was looking for was something that would protect the tablet making sure that if it gets accidentally dropped or bumped up against something damage would be mitigated.The case attaches by laying your tablet into it and the case corners (just the corners) grab onto the corners of your tablet. The 4 edges (sides) of your tablet are completely exposed offering no protection.The main feature that i saw and liked was the built in "handle" where your hand can slide in to hold the tablet. I'm an average sized guy 5'10" 220lbs and don't have huge hands. Yet when I tried to use the handle it just didn't feel right. Part of the problem is that the handle is sewn in at a 90" angle well who sits there with their elbow up and your arm laying perfectly flat and down so that you can read?if they had attached the handle at lets say a 30 degree angle it would have made a world of difference as you would be able to slid your hand up into it and hold it more naturally. (Look at the stock picture where the hand is holding the tablet. Now hold your hand like that. Now move it over so that your hand is more directly in front of you. ITS NOT COMFORTABLE! Now do it while keeping your hand straight up so that your not looking at a crooked screen.All in all I think there are some concerns here:1. Doesn't attach as securely as I would have expected.2. no protection for edges3. poor integrated handle4. ZERO protection to the face of the tablet when open. (the "clamps" that hold onto the corners do not stick up above the surface of the tablet so if you were to drop the tablet on its face it would be the same as if it had no case at all.Pluses1. it looks ok2. if you travel on planes the integrated stand is cool.I don't know what these 5 star reviewers are thinking. I see a few of them never reviewed another product besides this, leaving me to think they work for the company or something.Personally, I want my money back! BUT its not worth paying for return shipping on a $15 item.

Have had my system for about a month now and am very pleased with it so far.  Very pleasant aesthetics, clean lines, looks great on the desk, and good performance for general office and school type applications.  I'm not a gamer so this review won't include any comments on the subject.Another nice thing about the system in addition to its clean lines is it's very quiet which adds to the appeal of the system.  The 24" monitor is beautiful and although I was blown away by Mac's monitor, this one is definitely no slouch and is very beautiful in its own right (HD monitor).Performance:  I use it for general MS Office type applications along with surfing the web and doing school work.  Wife and I also use it for doing some low-level video editing (we're amateurs so can't give you any full-blown reviews with Photoshop Elements or anything like that) with photo editing software that's part of our HP Photosmart printer suite.  The screen's clarity and size make it a breeze to look at the pics in great detail and work any flaws that are worth removing.Bottom line, for $1K this is a fantastic buy and one I recommend for someone looking to do similar activities as we've mentioned above.  You won't be disappointed.

The protectors themselves are really decent, but even armed with canned air, I used 2 of the protectors just to get my phone's screen covered, and still got lint in it. Just no easy way to do it, I guess.

I purchased these as an addition to the provided protector that came with my Ballistic case. If you follow the instructions (and watch the provided installation video) putting these on is a snap. I had a problem with two of the three protectors, but after contacting the vendor, replacements were sent out the next morning at no charge! The look is wonderful, you can't even tell they are on. Fit was perfect. Would recommended these for look as well as customer service...Update.. I fully expected only the two replacement protectors. Upon opening my mail, I was surprised to see a complete kit with two cleaning cloths!!!  Highly recommend this seller...

I just recently got back into collecting vinyl and purchased a new turntable (AT-LP250). I did some research which narrowed it down to this or the Shure 97x. I pulled the trigger on this and I've been extremely happy. Very full sound, no dynamic loss or muddy bass like I've heard about the Shure stylus. I'm using this to listen to records or several quality levels and origins from the 60s through today, it makes all of them shine like new.

I upgraded from the Canon T2i to the T4i, the swivel and touch screen is really well thought out and the touch screen is extremely responsive. The screen has a really wide viewing angle which is really nice. The new Digic 5 processor is fantastic as well.

i bought this with my new MacBook Pro. I have to say that this was the first time I felt like Apple was taking advantage of me. Eighty bucks for a drive that is slow and has difficulty tracking discs that are not perfect and does not read all formats. Apple should price their peripherals correctly as this one is no better than any cheap external drive but priced at a premium. I could live without the sweet form factor on an occasionally used peripheral in exchange for better performance and/or a realistic price.

I bought this drive to accompany my new MacBook Air 11.5.  After watching two movies on it, it seems perfectly fine.  The length of the USB cable seems just right.  It could only be better if one could order a soft case for it as a add option.

The Macbook Airs and Pros introduced in June 2012 come with the new MagSafe 2 power adapter.  It's identical to the original MagSafe adapter except the plug size is different.If you have an original MagSafe power adapter that's the correct wattage for your new Macbook, get this tiny adapter and you'll be able to use it.If you want an extra power adapter for your new Macbook and don't want to pay the full price of a new MagSafe 2 power adapter, you can probably find an original MagSafe power adapter for much less (just make sure it's the correct wattage for your computer), and then use it with this converter.I've posted a few pictures in the "customer images" section, have a look if you like.One word of caution:  this adapter is so tiny, the size of my thumbnail, it could easily be lost.  For now, I'm keeping it in its box in my laptop bag.Another reviewer said that this adapter won't charge your computer while you're using it.  That's not my experience.  I have used this adapter many times since getting my 2012 Macbook Air, and it always charges the computer while I'm using it (unless the battery is already fully charged).At the time I'm writing this, Amazon's price for this converter is higher than the suggested retail price.  This is a brand new item, I've emailed Amazon and they will hopefully correct the price.  But until then, don't pay more than the suggested retail price.
summary: Very handy, does what it's supposed to

reviewText: Goes on easy and looks perfect. After a couple of days bubbles begin to appear. After a month- many bubbles.

When i took this antenna out of the box i thought it looked like a cheap flimsy piece of junk. Then i connected it to my small portable tv. using the wip that came with my tv, i could maybe get 1 or 2 channeles. Without even holding this antenna very high, i am recieving more than 30 channels. This is near a window that faces away from the tv signal.and i think the nearest tv signals come from 50 miles or more distance.I also own the flat rca antenna. it is in a better position to recieve signals but does not do as well as this antenna and it cost more. For the price of this antenna, it is an excellent value.. THANKS..

I recently purchased the 18mm-300mm AF-S DX Nikkor Zoom lens from Amazon Prime.WOW! It was delivered in less than 24 hours! I mounted it on my D300s and that's where it will stay. I have been using Nikon cameras and lenses for nearly 40 years now, and this lens is something I wish I'd  had 40 years ago! YES, it's a hefty lens (over 2 lbs) and YES it's expensive! But, hey, it's the only one of its kind - 16.7 power optical zoom! (That's 27mm to 450mm in 35mm film terms.) I took several test shots at both ends of the zoom range in RAW format, opened them up in Photoshop CS5 RAW editor and the results were AMAZING! The vibration reduction (VR) has two settings for different shooting situations and you can lock the zoom at 18mm for carrying and easily unlock it to zoom. The VR II in this lens is the best yet! The old-school rule for shutter speeds (use a minimum shutter speed equal to the focal length of the lens) is out the window! I shot several hand held pics while zoomed to 300mm using shutter speeds at 1/15 and 1/30 of a second...no problem. It requires a 77mm filter size - YES they cost more, but the front element of the 18mm to 300mm is close to the end of the lens barrel, so a UV or Sky 1A filter will offer some protection...get one! The lens comes with a hood, pouch and front and rear lens caps, so all you need is a filter to protect it. The lens is about the same overall length as the 55mm - 200mm DX lens, so it fits in my camera bag just fine. The barrel is much larger, tho.So, if you are debating on buying this zoom - buy it! It's the most versatile lens out there for a DX format camera. Did I mention that it will focus to about 18 inches, even at the 300mm setting? That is most useful if you like close up pictures of critters that might bite you! If you have a DX format Nikon, this is the lens to own.Update: The price I paid thru Amazon prime in December, 2012, has dropped $300! It first dropped at B&H; and after I contacted Amazon customer service about it, I have been ignored. Their automated response to customer service is all you can expect. This doesn't refect on the lens - it just reflects on Amazon's way of doing business and ignoring their customers. The other thing that irks me about the situation is that I sold 2 more lenses (to my brother ans a mutual friend). They both spent about $3K based only on my recommendation! I am hoping they will not count on Amazon being competitive - even within their own store! $300 is a chunk of money - that's a 33% drop in price in a 3 month span of time. If you don't care about Amazon customer service - that's OK because they don't care about it, either.
summary: An amazing lens - sadly the price dropped $300 since I purchased mine in December, 2012. Amazon won't do anything about it!

reviewText: I have already ordered this in gray but decided to get the red one for a roommate that loves red everything. It came promptly with the 2 day free shipping by being a Prime member (I recommend joining Prime ya'll it's worth it because once you start ordering from Amazon you just can't stop and free shipping is the greatest).  It is a vivid red but not too candy apple to make it look cheap.  The feel of the polyurethane case is pleasant and soft and my friend's iPad 2 fit perfectly in it.  The auto wake/sleep function in perfection and the inner microfiber lining keeps the screen relatively clean and protected.  The device feels secure in it and it seems to be able to handle normal wear and tear.  Overall, though it is a little pricey it is worth every penny because of its sleek design that adds hardly any bulk, comfortable to hold material, and overall build quality.

The case was OK.  However, the opening to the USB port is not well aligned and I have to adjust the USB connector every time I access the USB port.  This I can live with.  However, the protective sheet that came with the product had a defect.  When I contacted the vendor about the protective sheet, the vendor, CellKase, claimed that it has nothing to do with the protective sheet, and I had to contact Incipio for a replacement.  I contacted Incipio, and they claimed that it was the vendor's problem and that Incipio had nothing to do with the protective sheet.  Looks like both Incipio and CellKase has a blame problem and does not want to deal with its problem.  So now I am using an Incipio Faxion case that has a not well-aligned USB port opening and a protective sheet over the screen on my Samsung Galaxy S3 that has a bubble on it.
summary: Incipio 308 Faxion Case for the Samsung Galaxy S3

reviewText: This device has an innovative double sided remote for Google TV with a large touchpad on one side and a full keyboard on the other.  It takes some time to learn all of the buttons and commands but it works well.  The box itself is surprisingly small and compact and combines web surfing with Google TV and the Sony entertainment network.The set up can take some time (30 to 45 minutes) which will frustrate some users.  Many commands are hidden under menus and sub-menus.  It is best to explore all of the icons and search google itself when help is needed.  The first time I used it, I walked away from it for a short time and it inexplicably shut down on its own.  I thought it overheated.  However, I found that it was set to shutdown automatically after 30 minutes and after turning this setting off it has stayed on and worked flawlessly ever since.  The unit will update the software automatically the first time it is used.  I found surfing the web to be better than other devices I have used like the PS3 but it is still not as easy as using a computer and a full sized keyboard.  The remote has small buttons that my large fingers could not easily handle but it has a backlight and a "feel" to the buttons that help a great deal.The remote itself is very well designed and helps immensely with google search.  It automatically lights up when turned over to the keyboard and has a touch pad on the other side along with some key buttons.  It takes some time to learn to use and feels overwhelming at first and more than once I flipped the remote over so the keyboard was upside-down.  However, this remote is not great for simple tv watching.  I still use my Logitech Harmony for that.Google TV still needs some work but it is improving. It does not support Hulu Plus.  Hulu, ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox, Comedy Central, and MTV all still blocking Google TV from streaming video on their Web sites.  The $45 offer of free movies is not that good considering the selection is very limited (only 12 movies are offered) and includes older movies or outright junk.Overall, I am still learning to use it and feel it should be much easier for the non-techie to get up and running on.  Hopefully, future software upgrades will address this issue.  At $200 it is pricey and will have to come down in price to be more competitive.  This market is still evolving and it will be interesting to see which device ultimately dominates.UPDATE 1/7/13:  Since posting the above review the device has received several updates that have added content and improved ease of use.  It now has an icon for Amazon instant video which brings me to the Amazon sign in page. There are several other icons for video services most of which require a sign up for a fee or a rental fee per video.  I continue to use Amazon so I have not tried the other services.  Overall, I am happy with this device and expect it to continue to improve.UPDATE 4/5/13: The device continues to receive updates and more programming choices including an Amazon app, Pandora radio and others.  The updates have continued to improve this device and I am very happy with it.
Definitely not one of Samsung's market leading products but it works ok. Keys are tacky to the touch. But you get what you pay for so cannot complain.

I have Verizon Fios. I am set up in the basement of a 3 story single family brick home built in the 70s. The Fios router is on the top floor in the opposite corner. There is no internet wiring in the house other than the coax that is used for the TVs. I was using a Belkin N750DB USB wireless adapter which was giving me downloads of 16MBs. I am now getting 44MBs with this device which is only slightly larger than a wallet. Fios service is MoCA already so only 1 device is required. (a second device is not needed at the router) I used a 5-2050 MHz splitter from the coax out in by basement. 1 output went to the Cisco Fios cable box, the other went to the Actiontec adapter. Run an rj45 ethernet to the computer and that's it. NOTE:The coax output from the Actiontec can NOT be used as a pass through to go to the cable box. Doing so will block a portion of the MoCA signal to the cable box, disabling the channel guide and VOD service. I almost bought model ECB2200V which is Verizon specific but more expensive. The EBC2500C is an updated version with all wiring on the same side and not Verizon specific. It can be used with other MoCA CABLE systems as well. (No Satellite) This is an excellent solution. Inexpensive, simple, and works like a charm. I have nothing but praise for it. Here are the results after installation [...]
summary: I Wish I Found This Sooner, My Internet Speed Tripled

reviewText: PRO :  good apps for chinese userscan play various media filecan stream files from other computers on your networkCON :  CAN NOT PLAY YOUTUBE filesERROR : "Can not play file"  well...after this error, the "return home" button stops responding, and it loopsinto other youtube files it tries to play. but of course it cant, so itdisplays "can not play file" again and again...WTF software team? this is the dumbest s*** ever.Other available english apps: YAHOO FINANCE.yes, im sure this is what people want.wheres the support for AMazon video? hulu+? netflix?  NONE AVAILABLE.The hardware is good: can support different video standards, wifi link is good.the software is TERRIBLE... frequency crashes, return button doesnt respond.this can be a good product, just needs some work.
summary: horrible software and no app selection for english users

reviewText: This is the best headphones i have ever seen. I just love this color! The shipping was fast and made me feel happy. The headphone is wonderful. I use it everyday! The Beats are the best!

I'm a Cisco Small Business fan boy these days after they sent me a replacement for a second hand switch (SF300-24)that had a flash memory issue. No questions asked and at their expense (overnight shipping too!). So I returned to Cisco SB when shopping for a new router.I purchased the RV042G because it offers gigabit connectivity and two WAN ports coupled with customer service that is miles better than the usual phone tree/call center BS that you get with most consumer grade network gear(including Cisco/Linksys home products). I'm an AT&T; U-verse customer and while their service is good, it's not quite quick enough (12mbps) for my family of iPad/netflix/HBOgo addicts. So the ability to put the router in "load balancing" mode and add on a cable modem to give us extra bandwidth was the biggest reason for the upgrade. There is no wireless on this router and for me that's perfect, could be a drawback for some.Setup was very straight forward. I didn't even use the "set up wizard". Just changed a few settings through the web interface and it was online in a jiffy. It's probably not as easy as the setup on a typical home unit (ie. airport or Cisco Connect), so a little knowledge of protocols and ports is needed. There are not a lot of parental type controls on the unit. You can block specific domains and key words but I haven't seen any MAC or IP based filtering options in the menus yet, but I wouldn't really expect that given the intended audience for this unit. I'm not using the VPN functions right now, so I can't comment on those. There is only one thing I've found that seemed like an odd limitation of this unit. The DHCP server is limited to 50 clients, additional IP's would have to be assigned static. Overall, I'm really happy with the unit.One last thing. Since this item is not available from Amazon proper, be careful who you buy it from. My first purchase was from Amazon seller "Nu Image". Waited more than a week for the unit and when it arrived, it was destroyed. They shipped it USPS packaged only in a plastic bag. They promised me an expedited replacement but days went by and nothing till Amazon issued a refund. When I asked about my replacement, I was told to just start over and order another one. I reordered from Amazon seller "The Nerds". Router was shipped via Fedex and was at my door (packed in a proper box) in 2 days and was cheaper to boot.UPDATE 10-12-12:In my previous review I said that I hadn't found a way to set parental controls or do IP based filtering.  I have since discovered how this is done on this router. There is not a parental settings page or anything like that but under the firewall option in the menu, you can set "access rules" till your heart is content. As with the basic set up of the unit, some knowledge of TCP/IP ports and services is required to get this set up. Mine is now configured to disallow traffic to my kid's ipods, Nindendo's and TV's after bed time.I'm still very happy with this unit. Every function I have set up has worked great, even Xbox Live and in game chat have no NAT issues at all (port forwarding required.

So I just purchased this case for my brand new Nexus 7 after reading the great reviews. Unfortunately mine has a problem by which the built in magnet turns off the device when the case is opened and folded back to read with. The magnet is apparently so powerful it turns off the tablet with as much as  an inch gap between the tablet and the cover. Therefore I can't even hold the device with the cover behind the Nexus using my fingers to keep the cover slightly away from the case. It still puts the Nexus to sleep.We tried with my Wife's new Nexus 7 as well, and the same thing occurs.Very disappointed with the case. If there was a way to turn off the "auto-sleep" mode I would use the case without it.[UPDATE 8-22]I got in contact with the manufacturer and they said they will send me a replacement case. I will revise my review of this case if I get a working version.[UPDATE 8-27]I got the replacement case and I wanted to update this review to reflect that the new case works as it should. The system does not go to sleep when the case is opened back flat as the first case I got did. I'm happy about that, but in the meantime in order to protect my Nexus 7 I ordered a completely different case and am trying to decide which I prefer. So while I have increased my rating, I won't go any higher than 3 stars as having a defect that made the case unusable is something I find inexcusable. Clearly these companies don't do sufficient production testing when such a defect gets out even after it has been reported for some time.

The pictures are slightly misleading.  This product is merely a plastic plate to assist in holding your iPad for certain types of photography.  The plastic plate is attached to a wooden screw mount to attach to your tripod.  No tripod or tripod extension comes with it.  Nonetheless, it's fairly priced for a specialty item.The iPad holder cradles the iPad, but does not secure it very well.  As such, you will need to use a couple of rubber bands for safety if you intend for the iPad/holder to be in a vertical position, which, of course, you will most of the time.The main use of this iPad holder for a tripod is in keeping the iPad stable when doing time lapse photography (see the Lapse-It app) or photo-stacking time lapse images.  It does this function very well (as long as you have the rubber bands mentioned above).  Of course the holder helps the iPad in conventional usage, such as getting yourself into the picture with a time delay, eliminating camera shake during low light situations, etc.  Since I doubt most people use their iPad camera for any serious photography, these other holder uses are marginal in utility.That said, I would buy it again, but encourage the designers to include some retaining straps to more securely attach the iPad on to the holder.
summary: Good if you need it, but some design flaws

reviewText: I received this case as a birthday present and it looked good on Amazon.com but when I got to using it I must say I was a little let down. The clip is a good idea but when its on it completley covers the charging port. I do like the fact that it swivels and acts as a prop to hold it up but the clip also will lock closed if gently pushed and reqires two hands to open it. Also the flaps that cover the charger port and headphone jack are very hard to open until the case is stretched a little bit. Mine actually ripped off about 2 months after i bought it.I will admit the material it is made out of is VERY durable, I have dropped mine several times from 3-5 feet high and never had any issues. I actually wanted this case because of the clip so i could carry my Ipod a little easier than shoving it in my pocket but 9 times out of 10 the clip is more of a pain to work and I end up throwing in my pocket anyway.
summary: Good quality case but had a few negatives

reviewText: This is a nice little golf GPS and definitely a solid alternative to the SkyCaddie. I took it to my favorite course which is an out of the way Executive course that's been in operation a long time. It didn't find the course in it's database, which accounts for the loss of 1 star. IZZO is coming into the game a little late so I expect they'll get better over time as they continue to update their list of courses. That's the only con I could find however. The design is rugged and easy to use. Large buttons and large, high contract readouts are a must for me as I don't wear my glasses when I play and playing in full sun can make screens hard to read. No such problems encountered with the IZZO. It comes with a charger and charges for 24 hours first time through. The charge lasts a good long time and recharging is pretty quick.Where this device shined was in measuring distance from my location to the green. I found it to be very accurate and it definitely saved me a couple shots when I clubbed up or down based on the readout. This goes in my bag from now on and I would expect my scores to lower by 3-4 strokes per round. Definitely recommended.
To me this was difficult to put on (although I am a newbie at it) but the real kicker was once I was able to get it on my screen halfway decent, the touch screen didn't respond.  I returned it.
summary: Touch screen didn't work after application

reviewText: Works awsome does great on finger prints.Easy to put on.Fallow the directions just like is says and installes perfect.Still has same touch response even without the protector.

I'm usually not a fan of the "Beats" series of headphones, so this will be an honest review of the Mixr.For starters, this is a newer headphone made in conjunction with David Guetta's seal of approval. While Guetta may not use these headphones for his own mixing, he'll wear them in support of the Beats name.Now to get to the headphone.In my opinion this headphone is an upgrade from the well known Studio model, but you're probably asking "If this is an upgrade, why is this cheaper than the Studio?"The answer lies in the build of the headphone, the sound quality, and the fact that they're non-powered.The build of this headphone is almost comparable to that of the Beats Pro which has a metal casing and a driver that cleans up the muddy bass and low end of the amplified Studio model. I like to call this the little brother of the Pro. It's a sturdy, yet compact headphone that's good for listening to a wide variety of music. Mostly Beats is targeted for the audience that listen to Hip-Hop, Rap, R&B;, and anything Techno, Electronica, or Trance related, at least with this guy it is.The sound on these is much brighter than it's predecessors. Monster's Beats by Dre focused primarily on the Mids and Low frequency and equalizing the Bass output on most of their headphones. This headphone however fixes that. The headphone maintains the highs and mids while offering a tighter cleaner bass and treble, so nothing gets completely drowned out. For anyone who listens to different genres, you need a headphone that can do that, and do it sucessfully. Oddly the Mixrs do a good job ( not great ) for that.The last thing I wanted to hit on is that the headphones are in fact non-powered, which is a plus for those who don't like the battery use Studios. The headphones do sound isolated incredibly well for a compact size; even if you crank the volume up to max, they barely bleed out ( I'd say about 2-3% ). The Studios however have a driver that output the music, but because air needs to go through the driver to drive the bass, those bleed out like crazy after you put the volume pass 70%.This isn't a perfect headphone however.Although compact, the headphones are rather tight on the ear, which for some can irritate the heck out of you if you're wearing for long hours. The second issue is the wiring design built into the headphone. Although it's a ribbon cable, I can't shake the fact that it feels flimsy and that it can break at any accidental moment. The last and most important thing is again the price.Most high end headphones these days will hit the 200 Plus price point. This one normally retails for 250 to 280 wherever you can get them, and it might drive people to steer clear from the Beats or any high end headphone to begin with. Personally however if you wanted to get a "Beats" headphone, this would be it. You won't need the Solos, the Studios, the Pros, etc. Just this one, because it's not a bad headphone.It's a fun headphone for those who like a little punch in their music. The build is quite good, but if you try comparing it to a Westone or Shure headphone, you're honestly better off buying those instead.  That's all for now :)
summary: Not a fan of Beats, but these aren't too bad.

reviewText: I wrote a really nasty review on the Beats Mixrs, and I'm about to do something I didn't believe I would...and that's compliment the Beats Studios.First, let me say I'm not an audiophile -- I'm a casual music enthusiast and listener that has tastes ranging from dubstep to classical, and even video game soundtracks. I'm also Caucasian, and I'm only stating that because there is a stereotype that this brand is only for the more "urban" among us. For awhile, admittedly, I felt that way too. My experience with Beats by Dr. Dre has been abysmal, and I have only ever thought that they were average sounding headphones with an above average border lining excessive price tag. In many respects, that assumption still stands.I, however, am now an owner of the Beats Studios silver color, and I'm thoroughly impressed. I have to say that I was gifted these and did not shell out the money for them, but had I known these we're actually as good as they were I would have definitely considered it. I must stress that the ones I own are not the Monster ones, but the most recent Beats by Dre version. I can tell a difference in build quality as these, with their matte finish, feel and look significantly more stable than the glossy plastic Studios when Dre was still under the Monster label with them. There *is* a difference with these. They don't feel or look as cheap as the ones you see in the retail store demo kiosks.These silver ones not only look good, but they have a classy neutral appearance that works well in an environment where flashy isn't welcome. They are of a medium weight, as in not too light and not heavy at all, and they are extremely comfortable to wear. I wear glasses and was able to wear these for around 3 hours with absolutely zero ear fatigue.Now on to the sound. As I said, I listen to a lot of music from dubstep to classical and video game soundtracks. I am very, very pleased with how everything sounds. The bass is heavy but clean and doesn't seem to explode over everything else. There is some sound leakage around 50% volume on an idevice, but I'm not terrible concerned about it. The noise canceling...it isn't Bose Quiet Comfort 15 quality. If anything, it's active noise reduction instead of cancellation. I'm happy with the quality of it, though, as it does block out a lot of external noise and sound when I am listening to music.Overall, I love these new Studios and I recommend them. I give them 4 out of 5 stars because of the price point. I still believe $299 is a bit high, but if you're going to get a pair of headphones that are Beats by Dre then get the Studios. I stand by my belief and experience that the Beats Pros, Mixrs, and Solo HDs are uncomfortable and have questionable sound in comparison to the Studios.

The display is nice, much better than my old Samsung Galaxy tab 10.1. Bright. Color is a bit off but acceptable. The keyboard support is better than Samsung. Almost a notebook replacement. Since I already have a desktop, I am happy to use this Asus tablet with keyboard as a notebook replacement. Current generation iPad has a more vibrant colorful screen but not as bright.Graphic is not faster enough to power such high resolution. I am having a hard time loading a big pdf file. It was slow on my Samsung Galaxy tab but it is slower on this Asus. I can only think of the the higher resolution is the culprit. The pdf file is 38 MB. Cranking up to the high performance mode helps. Think I will keep it.
summary: Good enough for a notebook replacement. Graphic not fast powerful enough for such high resolution

reviewText: I had previously owned an ASUS TF300 which unfortunately developed a fault and was refunded via a Squaretrade warranty. I had deliberated for a few weeks over whether to buy another ASUS product or an alternative brand Android tablet. Eventually I decided to buy the TF700 Infinity, primarily because there was very little else on the market that came close to the specification of the TF700 and I was impatient to get another tablet as I really loved using my TF300. Overall, I am delighted with the TF700, it is a truly wonderful tablet. I've been using it daily for over ten days now so thought that was long enough to give my thoughts.The new full HD Super IPS+ screen offers a fantastic resolution and brightness. While it is true that few Android apps support such a high resolution directly at the time of writing, uses such as the Kindle app and general web browsing look incredible and it is impossible to see any pixelation at all in text and hi-res photos. It really is a joy to behold. However, the primary reason I'm not giving this tablet five stars is also because of the screen - the bottom of my screen suffers from relatively minor light bleed in about four or five places an inch apart from each other and the left edge has two patches on the edge which are darker than the rest of the screen. I can live with this - it's certainly a common problem with tablet screens, (and desktop LCD/LED monitors/TV for that matter.)Having upgraded from a TF300 I was a little disappointed some of my previously bought apps didn't work on the TF700. Most notably, Tiger Woods 12 is listed in the Google Play store as incompatible with the TF700. That's a shame as it was one of the games I loved on my TF300 and I hope EA eventually get round to fixing their code to work on the Infinity and other newer tablets. It's worth saying that most of the apps I'd already previously bought for my TF300 worked fine on the TF700 though - at a rough guess out of over forty (non-Google) apps, only two or three refused to install, or installed then crashed upon running. Of course, all the Google apps work perfectly.Before I bought the TF700, I was a little concerned as to whether the 1.6ghz Tegra 3 would be quick enough to drive the 1920*1200 resolution in 3D games and the like. I needn't have worried - every compatible game I've played on the TF700 works wonderfully. System intensive games such as Riptide GP work great even when upscaled with no noticeable drop in frame-rate, (if there is a drop in frame-rate, I don't notice it.)If I was to pick fault with the tablet, I'd have to say the most disappointing thing is the speaker and its positioning. Being placed on the back, the sound is already directed away from the user and sounds feebler than tablets with front mounted speakers, but when used in a case, (folded open), or when the tablet is laid flat on a desk, the sound is obviously further muffled. It's still audible when used at home, but harder to hear properly when outside or somewhere with ambient background noise. This is nitpicking though - and something that using headphones obviously solves!Android 4 Ice Cream Sandwich is a joy to use. That said I am looking forward to the 4.1 Jellybean upgrade when it becomes available after having used it on my wife's Nexus 7. I'm in no particular hurry though as ICS is very stable and well featured. (EDIT 13th October 2012 -- I received the 4.1 Jellybean update wirelessly from ASUS over a week ago and absolutely love it! The upgrade install and setup without any issues and was a very nice surprise.)One thing I was particularly interested in using this tablet for was video calls and plain voice calls using Skype as I have a lot of family in Europe. The Skype app works perfectly - the audio sounds perfectly clear and the video streams without any hiccups.Compared to the TF300, the TF700 appears to be better constructed and solid. The majority of the back of the unit is metal rather than plastic and the unit feels much more sturdier than the previous model. The inclusion of Corning Gorilla Glass is very welcome too compared to whatever the screen covering was on the TF300.If you are looking for a high specification tablet, I would definitely advise you to consider this product. It's great - not perfect, but certainly much closer than any other Android tablet currently available at this price point.
summary: The best Android tablet for the money...easily.

reviewText: *** Update 11/3/13: So I decided to do an update to my review since there are still people buying this tablet.  Just my two cents.  I do like this tablet, but it has a major I/O bottleneck issue.  You can research this yourself to find out what it really means, but what it comes down to is that the device will slow down and even become choppy.  There are workarounds for it but from what I see it is only minimal performance increase.  As I stated below, when you pay over $500.00 for something, you should be able to install as many apps that you want from the PlayStore and it shouldn't slow things down.  I hear using different browsers helps and uninstalling some apps, but once again, why have a tablet if you can't have all these apps installed, especially when you get a 64 GB model like I did.  I have not rooted, and have not unlocked.  I'm over my year warranty but I'm not one to delve into modifying a device and risk bricking it.  It is still usable, and games run smoothly.  It just isn't up to par with my standards for being really slick.  It started out smooth, but moved on to being jittery and unpredictable at times.  I don't have any screen issues like others have reported.  I have moved my star rating down yet another notch because of these consistent I/O bottleneck issues that haven't been fixed and not sure they can be fixed by OTA updates.  I still like most of the things about this tablet, but I feel that today, there are probably better devices out there.  Maybe they don't have the keyboard dock with the SD card slot, or the Micro SD card slot on the tablet,  HDMI output and USB port that we all love to have, but when it comes down to it, I want a stable smooth product and this just isn't quite living up to my expectations and I am clearly not the only one who loved it at first then became disappointed after a while.*** Update 4/5/13:  Jellybean 4.2 came out the other day, I updated and it works fine.  Please note that Photosphere is not included, apparently this is only on Certain tablets like Nexus 10.  I was hoping for it, but it isn't there.  Also, my tablet is slowing down a good bit and hiccups more than I would like.  I'm considering doing a clean slate format to see if that clears things up a bit.  Overall I'm still happy, but for the specs and money we pay, you would think it would be consistently smooth and it just isn't.  I'm dropping my rating by one star for this.  Keep in mind this is just my experience.  I hear other people say they have no problems at all.  Maybe I have just too many apps installed, but isn't that the purpose of having a tablet?  I have also installed some apps from Amazon's free app of the day, so those can slow it down too I suppose.  I may just format it and only install the stuff I regularly use and see if there is a performance boost.  If I get around to it, I will update to advise how the factory reset worked.  At times there are no issues at all, so who knows what I will do.  PS, mine is not rooted.  I've only done the push notification updates from Asus.*** Update 1/21/13:  Thought I would update to say that I still love my non-rooted Infinity.  There have been a few updates since the Jellybean 4.1.1 came around, and so far everything is going pretty good.  I still notice some hangups here and there when using certain websites on the stock browser.  Many people prefer other browsers so you might want to try those out if the stock it sluggish for you.  The current build number on mine is 10.4.4.25 which is supposed to improve MicroSD card compatibility, guarantees that the music played in the background will no longer have lag if the user is switching between tabs in the browser, and also fixes an issue where some exported videos cannot be played to the end, a few bugs for the camera, Mio map, and movie studio app are fixed.  I have seen a few apps in the store that were not compatible with this tablet.  At this time I don't recall which ones they were, games, or Live wallpapers, or what, but I was surprised.  Most games run silky smooth, but there are some that have glitches.  Facebook is horrible on this tablet, and I'm not sure why.  Pictures are HUGE in your regular news feed.  I wish those were reduced in size unless you click on it, but that is most likely the app, not the tablet.  The latest Youtube app is no longer able to play full screen since it is missing that button, but I hear they may be working on that.  Workaround is to uninstall the updates.Photos have been really smooth in transitions since the latest updates, so now when flipping thru, it is really snappy.  I currently have about 349 apps installed overall.  I'm sure things would run more smoothly if I uninstall some, but where is the fun in that.  I have stuff there for me and other people.  My TF201 keyboard dock works great.  It used to be a tight fit, but now it works perfectly.  I don't notice any other problems with the dock.  GPS locks on lightning fast.  I get over 31 Mbps on Speedtest.net's app.  I do notice significant decrease in Wifi thru just a few walls, but it still works well.  Mt favorite wallpaper, which I chose to buy the full version, is called GyroSpace 3D.  But Planets Pack is great too.  Battery life is great alone, and even better with the keyboard dock.
