I still highly recommend this table if you like customizable options.  If you are a stickler for stability, then you may prefer the Apple line of products, but I am very content with my Infinity.Still waiting on the official Jellybean 4.2.  Hope this helps everyone.****Update 10/1/12:  I just received my Jellybean update to version 4.1.1 and so far so smooth.  I do notice a smoother experience while scrolling on the homescreen and in the default browser.  There are a few enhancements to the lock screen and when you press the power button in for a few second you get a few different options.  The upgrade did not delete any apps for those concerned about it.  But it is usually recommended that you backup anything you are concerned about losing.  The Gallery scrolls much more smoothly now.  Very nice.  They added Asus MyFrame in the Live Wallpaper.  Just an overall improvement so far.  And Adobe Flash seems to be working fine on mine.  I will test out more of it tonight and report any odd findings or any cool features.  I'm sure they will be posted somewhere though.  Have fun everyone!!!****Update 8/29/12:  Sorry for the constant updates, but I forgot to include in yesterday's update that I have been experiencing an odd behavior with my Infinity.  I usually use the keyboard-docked Infinity and when done, I just close it to put it to sleep, then when I open it later, all is fine... I may do this a few times, then suddently, here and there when I open it, I get a blank black screen and I have to press and hold the power button for about 10 seconds and it restarts.  This is a little annoying when you want to open it quickly to do something, so I have no idea why it does this.  I always have it docked to the keyboard, so I don't know if that is the underlying problem or if it is something else.  Thought it was worth noting, but not enough to cause me to drop a star rating.****Update 8/28/12:  Time for a much needed update.  So first I'd like to start by saying that I'm very satisfied with the tablet.  It isn't perfect, but it suits my needs.  I have no regrets getting the Infinity.I will let you know that a new problem that I have noticed is sometimes, during some web browsing, the default browser will freeze up and then just close by itself.  The good thing is that when I reopen it, it takes me right back to where I was.  Some sites that I use with a login have quirks that make it annoying, but not enough to make me mad.Another thing I noticed is when playing videos that are at 720p, I notice a little stutter now and then, as if it pauses for a millisecond, but the audio stays in sync.  Doesn't happen all the time, but still happens even when on the Performance mode setting.  I haven't read anything about anyone else having this issue, so maybe I have to adjust something or turn off other apps running in the background.  I thought it was worth mentioning.Games run smoothly, most web browsing is smooth, Youtube plays nicely.  I'm Still happy.****Update 7/27/12:  First off there was an firmare update over the weekend.  For those that don't know, Asus is very good at pushing out updates. This seems like a big one and it only stated that it was to improve performance, but I found an online comment of the changelog, and it was a lot of stuff.  For info, look it up.  firmware v9.4.5.26 should help you find the info.OK, regarding my comment below about Riptide, turns out that it only needed the options tweaked to higher graphics and now it looks a lot better.  I guess the default is the lowest settings to improve performance.  But the Infinity has no problem handling the graphics boosted all the way up to the highest setting.  I'm sure we will still run into some problems with the apps not being enhanced for the 1920  1200 screen.I'm still loving my Infinity.  Hope everyone is having a good experience with their tablet as well, regardless of which brand or model you chose. There is something for everyone.****Update 7/28/12:  Sorry for the constant updates, but I figured some people would want to know any additional info as I find out more info. I loaded Draw Something app and it will not open on my Infinity 64GB.  It loads the company logo then just closes.  I've seen several apps in the Playstore that are not compatible with this device.Also just be careful with the case you order if you get one because several say they are for the Prime and Infinity, but the buttons are located in different places, so it won't work.  I found a nice one which I will review as well.  Fits nice and snug.  It is the Poetic Infinity Case TF700 PU Leather Portfolio Stand for tablet and keyboard dock.  All cameras are viewable without any blockage, just no magnet holding it closed.  I ordered it here at Amazon.After several days playing with the Infinity, i can say that there are slight glitches, but I love it.  I feel that it was well worth the money and the wait.  Just my opinion.****Update 7/26/12:  So I purchased the full version of Riptide GP, and when I started it up, I was disappointed in the graphics this time around.  It looked great on the Prime, very crisp and clean. But on the Infinity, the edges of everything are very jagged including the water splashes on the screen.  I assume that this has to do with the HD screen, and the game wasn't designed for that 1920  1200 full HD screen.  It runs smoothly, but looks crappy.  Hopefully an update will come out that fixes this.  I also got the demo of Puddle, and it looks really bad too.  Let me rephrase that, it doesn't look as good as I thought it would.  Plus the physics of the liquid isn't as smooth as I think it should run.  I'm mentioning these games because I think it has to do with the games not being enhanced for the 1920  1200 screen.  I don't blame the device itself, just the lack of support for now.****Update 7/24/12:  I've browsed some websites, played some games, played some lower res .avi clips, watched some Youtube videos at different qualities, and everything seems very nice and smooth.  There were some minor hiccups in watching some videos at times, but could have been due to many other reasons, like the internet connection at the time, etc.  I've seen that happen on the iPad 2 also.Also, when viewing high resolution photos that I've taken on my digital camera, as soon as you pull up the photo, it starts out looking kind of low resolution, but about 1 second later, it pops into really clear resolution.  So if you flip through pictures quickly, you won't necessarily see them in their full glory, unless you allow it a second to fill in the detail.  This is true even with the default sample photos on the Infinity.  I believe my Prime (when I had it) did the exact same thing.  No worries to me.  I think when I viewed the photos on an iPad 2, they showed up straight away without having to redraw the details like that.  I will check later tho about the iPad 2.  I don't know anyone with the New iPad to compare there.And can anyone else download the Starlight Live Wallpaper Free version and let me know if it is all screwed up now?  I think it has to do with the wallpapers showing the full image and remaining static vs. scrolling side to side as you swipe the main screens left and right.  I really hope this gets an option to switch to either option in the Jellybean OS update, which JB has been confirmed for this tablet with no set release date as of yet.****Update 7/22/12:  So while typing on Amazon comments, I had some weird glitches happening where the cursor would jump suddenly to another part of the text field and it really was annoying.  I will try another virtual keyboard other than the default one that I'm currently using.****Update:  I forgot to mention the charge time for the tablet.  I charged it fully as recommended before using it initially.  Then I let it run down to 1%.  I timed it to see how long it would take to fully charge back to 100%.  Time taken was 2 hours and 5 minutes.  This is just the tablet, nothing to do with the docking keyboard.___________________________My initial review:  So after many months of waiting since returning my Asus Transformer Prime, I finally received my Infinity.  For the most part it looks similar, but there are some noticeable enhancements.  I'll start with my pros and cons and will only mention things that matter to me, and I may miss some things that you find important.  Just ask in the comments if you need any questions answered and I will do my best to get back to you.__________________________Pros:*I opted for the Amethyst Grey color this time around, and although I really like it, I think I prefer the Champagne Gold.  But regardless, both colors are very nice.  I don't think you can really go wrong either way.*The screen is very nice and higher resolution to the previous Prime.  I hear people complain about it being a fingerprint magnet, but I've used many tablets, and they ALL are fingerprint magnets.  Using a good stylus can help here, and the cloth that comes with it works perfectly for cleaning those nasty fingerprints.*Asus did not load too much bloatware, and the stuff they did preload is mostly useful.  Some people may not agree, but at least there aren't too many really large preloaded apps.*I got the 64 GB model, and that is plenty of storage, plus the MicroSD card slot adds to that, and the cloud storage.  We should be good to go for a while.*Sound is excellent for being a single speaker.  Using headphones sounds even better yet for music or games.*Power button is easier to use than the Prime, and the volume rocker is placed in a better location IMO.*So far apps have run smoothly.  I'm sure there will be glitches but none yet.*Web browsing is smooth so far also.  I'm using the default browser for now to test it out.*As most people know, it supports Flash.  This was important to me.*Both cameras were upgraded and are very nice.  I still have to play around more with it to get to know it better.*ICS OS runs pretty good.  This can get better if and when we get JB.*GPS locks on really quickly for me.  It took forever on my Prime when I had it, so this was nice to see that it works now.  In less than 5 seconds I have 5 satellites, then a few seconds later, I have 14 in view per GPS Test app.  And this is in my apartment on an overcast day.*WiFi Analyzer app shows that the antenna is working better this time around also.*Anything I bought previously on the Google Playstore shows purchased and ready for me to download again without buying again. Some people may not know that.________________Cons:*There can sometimes still be lag when scrolling, but nothing serious.  And I hear JB OS will help that out too.*I think there are plenty of apps, free or paid, available for Android, but some people may prefer the Apple store for iPad since they have "more" apps.  I do think Google Playstore should have a section exclusively for apps enhanced for tablets rather than having us rely on telling each other, or finding out for ourselves.  But so far, no problems.*Sometimes I feel like the tablet can dig into my hand when holding it and can be uncomfortable.  But it feels better than the Prime did due to the slight redesign.*Some random crashes here and there when closing the docked tablet to the keyboard when reopening it*Some random crashes while using the default browser. As well as some quirks while trying to click on data input fields on some websites and pulling down dropdown menus.*I noticed some slight stutter while playing back 720p videos out to my HDTV.  Very slight though._______________________________________________I have to say that I am impressed with this tablet, however I don't notice a HUGE difference in the screen, since I don't have the old Prime any longer to compare against it.  Yes it is very nice though.The redesign is very nice.  I prefer the location of the volume rocker and headphone jack, and I like how the edge isn't as beveled as the Prime, so the plugs aren't as exposed, and the MicroSD card doesn't stick out at all now.I have read some people's reviews complaining about the plastic strip and the power/volume buttons looking and feeling cheap.  I don't find this to be true.  It fixes the problems that the Prime had, and I think they did a great job redesigning it to blend well with the color.  It feels very solid to me.The one minor complaint that I had, which didn't change my rating, it that Amazon listed this as available for order and available for 2 day deliver, which they did not hold up to that quote.  I have Amazon Prime and should get the 2 day delivery, however, I ordered mine Monday morning and received it Friday afternoon.  According to my calculations, that is more than 2 days.  Come on Amazon.  Don't post what you can't deliver.Eagerly awaiting the availability of the keyboard dock.I will update my review as needed depending on my findings.

I am really enjoying this tablet.  Because it has the latest version of the Android OS, I am waiting for some of the apps to catch up; however, that has not posed a problem for me.  I carry it with me everywhere I go.

I've had this for about 6 weeks.  I am very pleased with the functionality of this tablet.  I was torn between this and the Ipad 3 or saving some money and getting the Asus T300.  I felt like this was the best bang for my buck.  Very solid, well made and good quality.  Everything has worked smoothly.  Love the camera and video camera.  Nice clear quick photos.  Not too cumbersome like I worried I t might be.  Plenty of apps.  Turned it into a phone and can make/receive calls/texts.  Wifi signal is better than all my other wifi capable devices.  Not sure why others complain about the speaker.  It's quite loud for a tablet.  No complaints there.  Upgraded to jelly bean, a bit smoother but IC sandwich was pretty smooth anyway.  Enabled the remote through splash top so that I can access the desktop.  Pretty much does everything.  One thing I don't care for is the placement of the charge port.  It's right at the bottom which makes it cumbersome with the case that I bought for it.  I can't stand it up in the slot.  Haven't gotten the keyboard yet, haven't had a need too.  Did order a USB adapter.  I really like that it is expandable.  Excellent resolution.  I couldn't see much difference from the Ipad.

I have researched all tablets to date, and this one was the best.  I ordered it and received it within two days.  It had an issue with the screen getting what I would describe as a 'Ghost' press on the screen and I called and talked to Amazon letting them know I had a problem with the tablet that I just received.  They immediately set up a return for me and even scheduled the UPS driver to pick up my tablet the next morning, which was great being in my line of work, I really did not have much time to hunt around for a UPS store to drop it off myself.  They also sent me a new replacement tablet which I received a few days later.  This one is flawless.  I am absolutely impressed with the tablet itself as it does everything as advertised, and then some.  The screen resolution is awesome and even better than the Apple 3's in my opinion, and it has more processing power for any app. that I will ever use it for.  As a side note, I downloaded a few of the games made for this tablets processing and graphical capabilities, and WOW!!!, it is hard to believe they can make games that complicated for such a small computing device.  The graphics are awe stricking for a tablet, and, they even have "The Bards Tale" for those of us "old-timers" from the eighties era Apple II or Comodore 64 gamers.  I am, as stated before, absolutely impressed with Amazon, and of course, Asus.  In my opinion, if you are looking for a tablet that is both powerfull in processing and graphics, along with expandable, than this tablet is for you.  You will not be disappointed.  Asus really came to bat with this tablet and pretty much gave us everything we wanted in a tablet computer.  Thank you Asus, and thank you Amazon, for going above and beyond in your customer service.  Bob S.
summary: The best tablet on the market.

reviewText: The great: The Nexus 7 Google tab fits perfectly into this. It also looks great in the black and red contrast and the rubber band that pulls around to secure it all is a good addition. Plus the felt/suede feel of the inside red lining is really good quality and seems to be gentle on the tab itself.The good: It does switch off and on the screen when you open and close but once every eon it will switch off when you flick it the other way around. This is a rare occurrence and so does not bother me in the least.The blah: I never ever use the stand because 1. the nexus seems to prefer vertical viewing which isn't so handy in this horizontally adjustable viewing system, and 2. the indents which are supposed to hold the thing up when horizontal are a great idea but do not work quite so well - it keeps sliding down. It actually looks great when you finally figure out the positioning - just don't jolt too hard or it all collapses; That said, I would buy again since I have it in the case for protection not for viewing. Four stars!UPDATE: If you do want something for viewing handsfree: I bought an external folding stand instead from Arkon which is great and works with or without a case for any tab. Also, its now over a year later and the edges are wearing off (little rubber strips peeling off) at the corners. Still a great buy for the price.

I bought this item thru Amazon from the seller named "BestDealUSA" for $59 but it's a Meike grip nevertheless. I put the grip on my lovely D800 and so far it's worked flawlessness. Moreover, unlike the knock-off D7000 grips, the aperture screw turns the right way. The grip attaches just fine to the body and seems everybit as solid as the Nikon grip on my D3.So from my point of view, I could have spent $400 for one that says "Nikon" or $60 for one that does not leaving me with an extra $340 that I can apply to my next lens purchase! Gotta love it!
summary: Not bad at all for the money - seems to work just fine

reviewText: Don't waste your money on this. This grip failed on me during my first wedding using it. Unit will be functional for 5 mins after which the empty battery indicator goes off and I can't use the camera (regardless of the fact that both the grip and the camera batteries are fully charged). Would be a great value if it actually worked.
I was looking to be able to connect my Macbook to my older Epson digital projector.  I must say, this did the job quite handily.
summary: A Great Mini DVI to VGA Adapter Cable for my Macbook

reviewText: I have a canon 7d which is an aps-c format sensor.  This causes the field of view to be cropped very closely to the portion of the lens's sweet spot with only a small portion of bokeh in the corners.  Since the lens is a fixed focal length and f ratio there is not much you can do to change the size of the sweet spot.  Moving the sweet spot towards the extremes of the field of view is somewhat helpful.  That being said the sharpness of the sweet spot is something more than I was expecting for such a low cost lens.  I plan on trying out one of the other lensbaby's systems that supports interchangable apertures in order to change the f ratio of the lens.
summary: Not suitable for smaller frame cameras.

reviewText: I picked up the Google Asus Nexus 7 7" tablet a couple of weeks ago but wanted a great case for it.  I searched a number of sites for the perfect case and found dozens of cases but none seemed like they had been made specifically for the Nexus.  Except one.  The I-Blason case not only was made for the Nexus but was made exceptionally well.  It's got custom holes is the back for the speaker on the Nexus, it's got easy access for all the buttons and connections.  It also has a little loop on the side for the stylus that also came with it.  The case closes with a nice magnetic click (two magnets in each corner).  It also has some feature where the case closes and automatically puts the Nexus to sleep, and when you open the case, it automatically wakes it up.  That's such a cool feature !  The case is also molded to be able to fold backwards while the Nexus is in it and hooks into a slot on the back of the case to act as a stand for watching movies in landscape mode.  I can rate this case as a solid 100% buy, plus it comes in several different colors (my daughter wants the pink one), and I got the grey one which is a nice medium grey and looks as classy as it is functional.  If you have a Nexus, you need this case.  Plain and simple.

OK... after a month, seriously considering downgrading the KINDLE HD (so it went from an initial four stars to two... on way to one) ... because of it's pain in the butt software glitch.  Seems you recent, or most accessed apps are on a CAROUSEL .. great, but it doesn't work ... turn the KINDLE off, or close it for a while and every thing in the favorites, or cloud, is subject to random insertion on to the carousel ... so, if you have five items you want there, you might find them buried among fifty apps, books, or documents, you have made available. [updated 11/04/12]For the price, I really didn't know what to expect.  When it arrived -- in same package as my pre-ordered Kindle Fire HD -- I discovered it really is custom designed for the Kindle.Kindle dropped into the case and they just belonged together.  The case is beautiful, compact and I have no issues with it ... except ...Yep, usually and except ...  As of now, the biggest problem is that the case has no place to store for a touch-pen ... they could easily have added a standardized clip over Kindle, so hinge wrapped around it when lid closed.  It would have caused no distortion and allowed geeks like me a place to store the touch-pen.  Worse came to worse, they could have included a pen with the case.  At most, the whole thing would add 2 percent to the cost, but have been a fantastic add -- given that many of us order touch-pens as an extra.  That small addition would really have made this a classy luxury addition to what is proving to be a fantastic Tablet computer.  Hence 4, rather than 5 stars.
I checked this product before it was a gold box item. There was none review. The first review was a 1 star review.However I bought it. I am going to revise my review later and give you a real opinion

Nice case, fits ALL of the various GPS parts and POWER cord in one case.  Good Price, good product; and it really does have enough room for the cord, the suction mount, and protects the GPS unit.  Dropped it off the roof of my car and GPS survived.

This item does what it claims to do - removes smudges and fingerprints from screens.  What it does NOT do is remove any other matter that has adhered to the screen.  However, nowhere on the packaging of this product does it claim to do so.  It clearly states that this eraser is to be used for removing fingerprints/smudges.  Given that it does what it claims to do - and does so very well - I have no choice but to give it a good review with regards to that matter.  However, there are two things about this product that I do not like:  the price and the size. Personally, I think $14.95 is steep for a fingerprint remover, but that is just my humble opinion.  The eraser measures 3"W x 4"L x 1/2"H so it would be rather bulky to carry in a pocket or small purse.  Having it sit by the computer, tv, your reading chair (or wherever you use your iPad/iPod), would be good...and its size would probably prevent it from being easily lost.Bottom line:  this removes fingerprints/smudges.  It does NOT remove dried matter that is adhered to a screen.
I love how quickly all the smudges come off. The only question I have is "How do I get a pink one?"I will probably order more of these around Christmas time for my friends and family.Sylvia

reviewText: This product is excellent! I had the version of this case for my previous tablet (the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7, which I gave to my wife) and was very pleased with it. The N7 version is of the exact same quality. Like the other version, it needs a little breaking in but that is to be expected of a device constructed in this way.The tablet fits snugly in the grips. The hardened material of the case is of a ballistic quality (though not actual ballistic materials). The microfiber lining is of the stiffer type but not too stiff. Though seemingly redundant because of the clasp, the elastic band is nice for holding the case open securely so the tablet doesn't go flapping about with the potential of falling out when using the hands strap. The hands strap is perfect for providing additional grip on the device.As others have cited here, the magnet activating the sensor through the back of the tablet issue is marginal. If you want to use the case with the cover folded over to the back for reading and such merely flip the tablet upside down in the case and the magnet will not interfere with usage.This case is perfect from my perspective.
summary: This case is like an armor suit for your tablet. N7 indeed!

reviewText: The dimensions and cut-outs were very precise, but the film has an awful rainbow swirl pattern that's noticeable when the screen is off. When the screen is on you don't notice the swirls. The product was so affordable, and there weren't many options at the time I bought it, that I decided to just keep it. Maybe I'll replace it with a better protector when this one gets scratched. For those having difficulty applying any kind of dry-application screen protector, try the "hinge method" (search the web & youtube).

It only cost $9.95, but I had high hopes after ~5 other reviewers said it was good. It is not good, and probably not even worth $1. The "stand" part of the case is unstable and will not hold the tablet up because the design is unbalanced. The rail on the right does not sit flush against the tablet. It feels and looks cheap (though it is cheap), but my Acase is a million times better and was only a few dollars more.I suppose I could contact Amazon for a refund but I have a feeling it won't be worth the $9 back (plus I would have to ship it back anyway). Lesson learned.

Had the case for about a week now. I love it. Fits my Galaxy Tab2 7 inch tablet perfectly. Because of the way it holds the tablet I'm not sure how long it's going to last, guess I will just have to wait and see. Would have been nice to have a stylus holder, but I knew it didn't when I ordered it so I didn't take anything off for that. All buttons and connectors are accessible. Stand function works great. Construction is high quality. Look and feel is very nice. Adds very little extra bulk to the tablet. I would definitely buy again and would have no problem recommending this to anyone looking for a tablet cover.

I ordered my set of these 4 cables on 10/22/12 from Amazon. I received them quickly, and they all worked at first. The black one made it through maybe 4-5 charges of my iPhone4 and then went intermittent. Now it will not charge the phone anymore.The green one seems the most reliable since it will successfully charge every time, and the phone recognizes it instantly each time I plug it in.The cables are quite a bit less substantial than a real Apple sync cable. Much thinner and cheaper feeling. Like I said I ordered mine on 10/22/12, so not sure if I got the old ones or if what I have are the new 'thicker' ones. But the ones I have are 2 stars I would say due to thinness and one of them failing so quickly. We'll see how long the 3 remaining ones last. Thanks for reading.
summary: the green one seems to work, the black one died pretty fast

reviewText: Extra long cords that seem well made and are reasonably priced, but the cord is not as thick as I expected from the photo. Can't say personally how well they sync, but the neighbor who paid me to get these for him says they work fine.

This antenna worked perfect even with my apartment being very hidden between buildings. This is antenna has a great reception and is super cheap compared to the other alternatives in Amazon (priced $60+).
summary: Excellent antenna with an excellent price

reviewText: While this is not nearly as fast or as crisp (screen wise) as the Nexus 7 - it is a fabulous deal for the price. There are two things that make it for me 1) The keyboard, which is perfect for middle/high school work that my children do and 2) the MicroSD slot which expands the tiny 8GB that is on board to something that allows local movie and music storage. The deal is so good I'm picking up another one as a Christmas gift!

!Well I looked at the useless 7 (j/k) oops I mean nexus 7  I am sure its fine for those that don't need the ability to expand memory. And have money to blow on fog storage I mean cloud storage. This tab served my needs well. If I need to do more I can just use my laptop. This tablet works fast the key board is nice when you want one the usb adapter is handy. Also I did not want to risk the screen problem some people have reported on the nexus 7. I could go on but the other 4 star and 5 star reviews cover most of what I would say. Also technology changes almost every week now so some clown pushing the latest tech. must have load of money to keep updating. I'm all for new stuff but I can wait a little bit to get it.8/30/12 UPDATE: I found I can use a sandisk 64 micro sdxc card in it!!! At first it did not see the card at all. So I just formatted the card in a old samsung mesmerize. Put it back in the tab and worked right away. That was all I had to do. This "old tech" sure seems to work well with the newer tech. So my memory is now 72gb with nothing extra to drag or carry around! Well unless I want to.
summary: What a great deal and tablet WAIT it gets better see update below

reviewText: I was an engineer for 43 years in service of the federal goverment, so I feel I am more in tune with the need for a high standard of quality in a product such as the Samsung replacement cable for the Galaxy Tab 7.0 plus. With a product like this, you expect it to just work...fortunately, it does. I have known a couple people who have purchase after market knock off versions of this cable and either ended up with a cable that had to be forced into the port or (in one instance) didn't fit at all because it was made for a different product.In short, it doesn't make sense to try to save a dollar or two on a cheap knock off when the real mccoy is so reasonably priced.I highly recommend.

Picked one of these up for $99 at local store.  I had just sold an 8" Coby Kyros, which I liked but it had the older Android OS and was a bit bulky for my needs.  This one has the new Android OS, Ice Cream Sandwich.  Touch screen works well.  Small print on some websites looks a bit smudgy but this is probably true of most tablets in this range.  Fast enough and stock Browser works very well.  Nice Email App included as well and Amazon app market comes installed, once you run the Zeki "Install Apps" app.  There is a very easy to do mod out there to flash the tablet and be able to access Google Play apps, however you will have to have a micro SD card (preferably 16mb or larger) to do this.  Only real shortcoming I see so far is that the Accelerometer does not function with some racing / motorcycle games for steering.  This is probably due to the type accelerometer used from what I've read.  It does fine for automatically orienting the screen though, and some other games such as the maze games and Temple Run seem to function ok.  Battery holds up decently for a few hours of web browsing and general use, which is probably about as good as you can expect for this type tablet due to size limitations for the battery.  If you want something compact to do email and basic web browsing and play a few games, it will serve you well.  I also tried netflix on it, which works but video quality leaves a lot to be desired...it is watchable though in a pinch I guess.  Youtube works but can be a little jerky at times...again, pretty much typical for a $100 tablet.  If you have never used one of these just go in with realistic expectations...if they were as good as a $500 Ipad, Apple wouldn't sell very many.
summary: OK tablet for what it cost

reviewText: Tons of features, amazing performance. Couldn't be happier!Dont hesitate with buying this board. Its incredible.I have it running with an i5, EVGA GT 640 and 16gb DDR 3 and an SSD. This thing just screams!

My SystemSony VAIO SA3 Series VPCSA3AFX/SI13.3-inch LED-backlit display with 1600 x 900 resolution for native HD 720p viewing2.4 GHz Intel Core i5-2430M dual-core processor (3.0 GHz with Turbo Boost Technology; 3 MB L3 cache)8 GB of installed DDR3 RAM 1333 MHzMy read  214.4 mbMy write 229.7 mbU have made all the tweaks like trim anabled and all that other good stuff.[...]
summary: Trenscend 356 not as fast as my kinsgston 120 v+200

reviewText: Packed this little gem in my bike pack today and took it to Papago Park for some fun. The camera is very easy to use. I love the external controls, the ND filter and the iA additional controls. The scenes are fun to use and provide additional options for controlling depth of field (blur) and overall color of the image (WB).  Menus are very easy to navigate.  The camera feels very sturdy, easy to hold, has a hot shoe and external viewfinder (which I have just purchased).  I wanted a small camera to carry everywhere as a supplement to my Panasonic G3 and other bigger SLR's that could shoot in RAW.  The big news, of course, is the f 1.4 lens. It is wonderfully sharp and extra wide (24mm equivalent). This allows for handheld low light photography at lower iso's.  The shots taken with the zoom and extended zoom look quite good, much to my surprise.One of the most fun scenes is "panorama" which takes a burst of shots and then combines them. (This is a lot easier than shooting the panorama by matching up edges as in other cameras).  PDF Manual is well written and easy to use.  Higher ISO's (320 and above) are noisy, but that is easy to cure in Silky Pix. Other problem, Lightroom and/or Picasa don't recognize this RAW file type yet.
summary: Good things come in small packages.

reviewText: great little fill-in flashes that work every time as theyre supposed to when using as slaves as slaves.  highly recomended.

This newMonster Outlets to Go USB PowerPackis a fascinating device for a number of reasons. To start with, it's a true 2-in-1 charger that will allow you to charge just about any two USB devices at the same time. It has enough punch charge tablets, smartphones, MP3 players, digital cameras and more.It's truly flexible in that when you plug this PowerPack into a wall outlet or power strip, it offers two USB ports that will deliver up to 15W of power, so you can charge two devices simultaneously. Add to this, when you need true charging for when you're mobile in your car, you can easily remove its built-in cigarette lighter adapter (see the one with the round silver ring) and have a single USB port in your car that provides "up to 10W of rapid-charging power" as noted in the specs, so this gives you very flexible charging options while at home, work or when you're on the road.The plug has retractable prongs that fold away neatly when not in use, and it also offers one of the narrowest form factors that this user has seen when plugged into a wall or a power strip. Unlike many similar two-port (or even many single-port) USB chargers, the narrow design allows it to be plugged into the same space that you would use for a simple two-prong lamp... it's that narrow.TheMonster Outlets to Go USB PowerPackhas the thinnest form factor that this user has found for a two-USB charger, and that make it handy when outlet space is at a premium. Being a hybrid vehicle/wall charger makes it quite versatile, but don't leave the part that goes into the cigarette lighter in your vehicle or the versatility will be lost.10/24/2012
summary: Charge two USB devices, and also from your car

reviewText: The case does sort of make the kindle look like a composition book (albeit a small one), but I didn't like the way the cover folds over: the "spine" seems too wide and flimsy. In addition, the overall feel is very plastic-y and cheap. I almost think it would have been better to make the cover out of actual cardboard than with whatever thin plastic sheeting Verso used. The cover is not very thick, either, so do not look to this for any sort of protection apart from normal usage/storage (in a bag, etc.).This product is probably worth $15 -- not $40.
summary: Not great, but not bad either.

reviewText: The Verso Trends Darwin Red Croc for Kindle Fire is a pretty Cherry Red color with a subtle light brown in the lines of the croc pattern.  The picture of it is the same as the one you get.  It has elastic holders in each corner to hold the Kindle Fire in place.  It has a inside pocket to put notes, etc. in it. It is hinged so the front cover folds back to read. The cover is light weight alone but heavier after you put your device in it which only makes sense that it would be. The Croc cover comes in other styles and  colors.  I put my Kindle Fire in the cover and it fits like a glove.  It says you can use this cover for the Kindle keyboard,  Samsung Kobo, Sony Tablets and most other 7" tablets.  We tried my husbands Pan Digital E reader, Length was fine but it was too wide by an inch for the cover.  Make sure your tablet will fit!  The Kindle Fire is 7.5"L X 4.75"W and it fits perfect.  It does have the overseas odor but I aired it out overnight and that helped.  I have another cover that doesn't have the odor anymore so I am relativly sure this one won't either. I really like this red cover, it is so smart looking and I might add easy to spot if I lay it down somewhere.

This device would not convert HDMI to analog video.  It did convert DVI-over-HDMI to analog video.  So you may be able to use it to view computer or Apple TV output on an older HDTV, but it absolutely will not work with stuff like HDCP-compliant cable boxes.  When I could get this device to work (converting a computer HDMI signal to YPbPr), it introduced severe video artifacts, so it was basically useless for me.I got an HDFury instead and it works flawlessly for displaying HDCP-encumbered content on my older non-HDMI BenQ projector.

This center channel speaker along with the Pioneer AJ sub-woofer works like a dream.  The price was right.  Set-up was a snap with Monster speaker wire.  I would give it five stars but the terminals are awfully close together.  For people like me, with big Jethro hands, that is not a good thing.  I recommend Pioneer AJ speakers without reserve to folks who don't wear a size 16 ring.

This works great on my Ipad 3 and Iphone 4s.  Let me just throw out the disclaimer that if you are purchasing this to use with HBO.GO you will be sorely disappointed.  Hbo.go has disabled all adapters that project from your device to a TV.  They don't want YOU stealing THEIR services! Even if you pay for them...  So, if you try you will just get a message on your TV screen saying that HBO.GO has disabled this service and you must now enjoy whatever you are trying to view on your phone or Ipad.  Other than that, everything else will work.  The device itself works flawlessly so far.  I have owned it for a few months.
These work as advertised but, are a little expensive. They do work well though as I travel frequently and they are handy in my luggage keeping things organized.

I purchased this TV during a Black Friday Lightning deal.  Got it cheap.  I did not have overly high expectations for the quality of the item, based on my purchase price.  I was pleasantly surprised.  It was extremely easy to set up and program.  Just a few adjustments to my first generation ROKU box, outdated DVD player, and some creative cable usage I am getting a very good picture via regular antenna, streaming, and DVD player.  I did not purchase an HDMI cable yet.  Plain old RCA and RGB cables are getting the job done quite well.  No need to spend the extra cash on cables so far.  Time will tell about the service life of this item.  I plan on purchasing an extended warranty to cover any possible future issues.  I don't know if I would shell out 179.00 for this TV.  If you can get it under 150.00 I believe it would be worth it.  In addition to the great deal I got on this item, Amazon did a great job processing my order and responded to my email inquiries in a timely manner.
summary: So far so good.  Can't beat the price when it is discounted.

reviewText: I'm a working professional with a demanding lifestyle. I need a case that goes with me everywhere without getting in the way. The KaysCase  Slim Hard Shell is harder and clearer than the leading competitors, allowing me to work harder and be clearer in life. Buy KaysCase today.
summary: A Serious Case for Serious People

reviewText: I purchased these screen protectors based on the large amount of positive reviews, that and they were inexpensive.  They were really clear but the protectors are made of a plastic that is somewhat sticky, it isn't as smooth as other screen protectors (the invisible shield line is smoother) and they all left a residue on my iPhone 5 after removing them.  The worst aspect of installing these protectors is that they would not sit flush with my iPhone 5.  It took me a while to finally get one of the screen protectors completely straight only for there to be a hair right in the middle of it.  I threw that one away and opened up the second screen protector.  I installed it fine but then it came up whenever I installed a soft gel case on my iPhone 5 simply because it wasn't sitting completely flush around the edges of the phone.  It was crinkled so I threw it away.  I couldn't even install the 3rd one as it never stuck to my phone.  I ended up throwing all three protectors away, driving down to a retail store, picking up different ones, and they work much better.  I don't recommend buying these as they are inexpensive for a reason.  I'm not sure how people are using these with cases on their iPhones as I could never get it to work.

This is the first screen protector that I install without leaving bubbles on the screen. I cleaned the surface very well before install the screen. I hope you have the same results. I'm 100 percent satisfied.
summary: I don't notice the screen protector

reviewText: Almost seems to leave more finger marks then the bare screen but I only notice at an angle, with the display brightness set on the factory default. Installed easily and I had no issue removing the half a dozen bubbles. As a 3-pack it seems a good value since the Nexus 7 doesn't have Gorilla glass.
summary: Installed easy without bubbles and very clear

reviewText: These screen protectors do a great job for the price.  Very easy to install and my daughter loves the way it looks and does not impact operation (she would tell me, trust me).  LOL
I had no issues installing the cover, pushing out a few bubbles and so far so good.  I would recommend this cover and brand.  I expect to buy others for my parents new tablets.

I hate to say it but I don't think the ADIXXION was finished when JVC put it on sale, it almost feels like they rushed it to market to compete with the GoPro2, Contour+2, and Sony Action Cam.For me the WiFi was a big selling point, I plan to use this camera mounted in a remote location and being able to stop and start it from my phone is a big plus, however it has been hit or miss. The WiFi app "WiVideo" crashes endlessly on my iPhone 5, on my old iPhone 4 still running iOS 5 it's better, but it still has problems that prevent me from being able to use it as intended. Also on the WiFi front, UStream is hit or miss too. I've tried several times, half the time I start UStream the camera turn off after one minute having never sent a single frame of video (and NO my battery WAS fully charged and I was on my home WiFi with a full signal), the rest of the time it seems to work fine, but note that you CAN NOT record and stream at the same time, it's one or the other.The construction of the camera feels fine, it doesn't feel flimsy and the dual mounting points are a big plus. But, the four side buttons don't always register presses, and the screen has a limited viewing angle so you need to look at it straight on. Also, I've had a hard time getting the lens protector off, it snaps on and off of the camera and it doesn't come off easily, which is good on the one hand it won't fall off, but when water gets under it, it can be a pain.Video quality is big for me, and on that front the ADIXXION in my opinion is a disappointment. I shoot video for a living, so I know an action cam isn't going to look as good as my main camera, but, compared to my ContourHD 1080p from 2009 the ADIXXION doesn't look as good (I'd love to post a side by side comparison but my ContourHD bit the dust, hence the need for a new action cam). The image isn't as sharp, there are more compression artifacts in the video from the ADIXXION then the video from the ContourHD, the exposure control is a little slow but not bad, and on auto White Balance the color temperature isn't as nice as the presets. Overall the image lacks detail, tree bark, grass, and foliage in general just become a blur. Sound goes hand in hand with video and the microphone on the ADIXXION isn't great. Wind noise is a big problem and it has no wind cut feature, so if you are moving with some speed you'll just have the sound of wind recorded, and there is no microphone input.Overall the ADIXXION is a disappointment, it's built well, but the WiFi is flakey, and the video quality is subpar vs my old ContourHD and even my old iPhone 4 with its 720p video has more detail. JVC should have kept working on the ADIXXION before releasing it, it could have been so much better then it is. I've posted a sample from the ADIXXION on YouTube search for JVC ADIXXION test Day - Rain - Night

I have been looking for a sturdy case that gave me a choice of both landscape and portrait stands and this one fit the bill.  The five-inch back cover has a wide, two-inch strip of velcro lining the whole length of the inner edge.  Perpendicular to it is an approximately three-inch wide velcro strip spanning the width of the inner front cover.  The Kindle Fire fits in a removable case with a hard nylon backing composed of a two-inch furry strip running lengthwise, attached to a window insert that frames the front.  When using the entire case normally to just cover the Kindle, the removable case securely attaches to the back inner cover.  To use as a stand, the back cover bends right at the edge of the strip, which is creased so that the top half of Kindle can rest against it while its bottom edge rests against the back cover.  Both the landscape and portrait views work effectively and securely at an approximately 45-degree angle.  I love that I can still access the bottom controls even when the Kindle is in the portrait stance.  The Kindle felt secure in both views while I surfed and turned pages.  I also like the tweedy exterior look, but wish that it spanned the whole of the front, as well as the binding.
Smells like leather, sturdy, fits the camera well, provides adequate protection. Why pay extra for Sony's fake-leather case? I recommend it highly.
summary: As good as the $90 Sony case

reviewText: I bought this case for a few reasons. The looks, the price, and the ability for it to hold a lot of drives and full sized components. However, once it had everything together, it was pretty sad to see the temps. While idle, my GPU temps were in the mid 60s and my CPU temps were in the mid 50s. In hopes of dropping the temps, I removed the I/O shield and installed an additional 120MM Cooler Master fan in the available space on the opposite side of the drive cage and flipped the power supply over to draw any additional heat out. This did help a little, but not as much as I thought it might. Part of the problem with this case is the 120MM front intake fan is a bit weak and the front face plate blocks the majority of the air that's trying to be drawn in. Add to this, the fact that the bulkiness of the drive cage structure also blocks a great deal of air attempting to be drawn in. As for my motherboard (Asrock H67M-ITX), the connectors sit right in front of the side 80MM fan, this was doing nothing to help either. That fan is pretty weak also, so it probably wouldn't help much even if it wasn't obstructed.If you can deal with the higher temps, then you probably wont mind this because other than the things I've pointed out, this is a pretty decent case, especially at this price. I'm running an i5-2500K Sandy Bridge, 8GB Kingston RAM, 120GB Kingston Hyper X SSD, two 2TB Western Digital Blacks, an Nvidia GTX 480, Corsair 600 watt power supply and an Asus dvd burner. You might say, ah no wonder his temps are hot, he's running a GTX 480! No doubt that's a contributing factor, but I also had all of this inside of a Silverstone SG07 and my temps were 20+ degrees cooler across the board. There was a lot more thought put into the layout of that case, with the power supply being mounted in the front and a 180MM fan in the rear blowing down over the CPU/GPU pocket.  I'm planning to move everything back into the SG07. The review of the Elite 120 on AnadTech pretty much reflects my experience.
Perfect for extra files for my mini itx in the spare room. This carries my files, music and photos without need for large HDD

I am constantly using USB drives to carry files and move them around between different computers and servers.  I build a lot of computers and I use the USB drives to carry BIOS systems, drivers, firmware and utilities.  In order to test this USB drive I used a USB 3.0 port on a powerful computer using an ASUS Sabertooth X79 mother board and an INTEL 3930K CPU overclocked to 4.4  GHz with 32 gig of RAM.I took the memory stick out of the package and I transferred 55.4 GIG on files to the stick that averaged 660 MB per file.  The files were transferred to the memory stick in 20 minutes and 24 seconds at an average speed of 45.2 MB/second.  The stick is rated at 50 MB/s writing speed so this was a good resultI then wrote the same files to a SATA III hard drive and using 2% of the computer's CPU capacity.  It took 9 minutes and 10 seconds to read the data and write it to the SATA III drive at an average speed of 100.1 MB/s.I then read the USB drive and wrote 20.1 GB of files to a SSD SATA III drive and the average speed was 112 MB/s.  This memory stick performed very well under these tests also.  The stick is rated at read speed of up to 180 MB/s and the max I saw was 137 MB/s which is a respectable result.I liked the fact that the drive has a retractable USB cover and it is nice to protect the USB plug from damage.  The rubberized coating also makes it easy to hold onto.I rate this product as a five star for its memory size, speed and overall performance and construction.  It is a good tool to have around to help transfer files between systems.  This memory stick does come with a 5 year warranty.  I recommend it to you!I was provided a sample unit for test and evaluation and I promised to give a fair and honest review.
summary: Extremely fast, large capacity and packaged nicely for a portable USB drive!

reviewText: The power supply unit shipped out in a PC is usually not intended for heavy use - one of the areas where costs get cut.  I like to run multiple monitors for efficiency and entertainment.  That alone requires more power, and forget about getting video on the fourth monitor while working on the others.  Therefore, it's prudent to upgrade the power supply on one's own.This power supply is probably way more than needed for most people at least in the first couple years.  A 600W supply will usually run the high-end video cards with ease, and this one is 750W.  But that's great because it's pretty efficient for so much power, running quietly in my setup at least in the beginning for now.  Also, as it degrades as all power supplies do over time, it should continue to meet requirements for years.Others have written about the cables and connectors - best I've seen.  These cables are long and thick.  There are 8 serial-ATA power connectors, a long motherboard connector, 2 long EPS+12V 4+4 connector, 6 peripheral connectors, 2 PCI-express 6pin connectors, and 2 PCI-express 6+2 pin connectors.Bottom line - this will more than run any video card.

I got this to replace a failing power supply in an NZXT case. I've purchased two NZXT cases (without power supplies) in the last year and have been extremely happy with both of them. The quality standards over at NZXT are apparently very high, and it continues through with their power supply units as well.I was immediately impressed by the packaging... a nicely designed box that's well-packed to assure that it would take a LOT of damage to the box to affect the unit itself. I always take notice on how companies package their products and when they go the extra mile protecting their units with 1-1/4" foam padding, I feel like there's a concern for quality beyond when the unit leaves their factory.My computer case is quite large, and allows for running all cables under the motherboard panel to reduce clutter. The problem with that is, I had a lot of trouble with my last power supply as the wires weren't long enough to be routed under the panel and then to their destinations. With the Hale82N power supply, I had no problems routing the wires... the cables fit perfectly where the last unit came up short. The only downside is, since the cables are longer, there's more bulk when it comes to the unused cables. Smaller cases may have space issues. My daughter's case is much smaller then mine, and the power supply sits at the top, right behind the drive bay... there's little room for extra cables, so I used a modular PSU so I could remove the cables that aren't needed. This power supply would fit, but it would require a lot of unpleasant 'stuffing' of cables rather then orderly cable management.The unit is also noticeably quieter then my last one. With dual video cards and four hard drives, my last PSU use to get louder under heavy gaming. This unit doesn't seem to have any trouble whatsoever... if it's winding up at all, I'm not noticing it.Overall, I love the NZXT Hale82N... I would have loved it a bit more with removable cables, but for the case I'm using it in, it's not a problem at all.
summary: The usual quality I've been expecting from NZXT

reviewText: Got this for my wife but she hardly uses it yet.  I am a Apple person and she a PC so it fits what she needs.

Bought this to try it out and was surprised by its functionalities. As many people have indicated, it is way better that you have a hard wire to the device and not depend on a wireless connection. If not for anything, connecting a wireless adapter to it takes away the USB port. Now that a recording app is available, you need that port to attached a storage device to it. One big complaint I have is the responsiveness of the remote function. I know it is not the remote control itself since I have taught it to control my TV and it is very responsive in that regard. The problem, I think, lies in the signal receiving end of the operation. It can be very frustrating and is probably one thing that prevents me from recommending this to family and relatives. Hopefully they can fix this via software.
summary: Very useful for the Asian folks

reviewText: This was my first case for a raspberry pi so I do not have anything to compare it with but I am satisfied with how sturdy it feels and how well the Pi fit inside the case.The only reason I did not give it five stars is because it is very hard to read the descriptions of the LEDs because the case is clear and the text is clear as well. Other than that, I would recommend it!

I have owned Kindles since the first model became available, and have consequently tried a variety of screen protectors. The Tech Armor Protector which I recently purchased for my Fire HD is without a doubt my favorite. It attaches easily and no bubbles. reviewText: I put this on with 0 bubbles none. Best screen protector i ever bought, 100% satisfied. Will buy from this company again. Also this is case friendly. And the fact that it comes with 3 is even Better!
