Thanks to the other quality and detailed review posted here, I knew exactly what I needed to get my new HDTV to output audio to my old amplifier.  My particular decoder has busted RCA (red+white) jacks, although the mic jack works great, and I was able to splice from there to the amp.
summary: Crucial for Digital Audio Out -> RCA

reviewText: I finally located information regarding benchmarks pertaining to games/gaming, the results are impressive.unfortunately the link I tried to post wont post, so if you go to Google and search for the following...Google search:hardocp readycache benchmarkit should be the first thing that pops up, on the site go to page 6 and also check out the vantage benchmarks, and on page 7 you get the PCmark7 benchmarks showing gaming performance while using the readycache.Even though the Readycache has 32GB of SSD space it still triples to quadruples the read performance on your larger Terabyte drives.The big issue people see in games is load times, zoning times, and latency due to objects not loading fast enough. Load times can kill you if your playing on drives that have little cache and low RPM. Load times actually effect Frames Per Second in games and applications. If the textures don't load quick enough into the video ram your FPS take a hit and the game(s) run poorly.Someone mentioned you could not use these in laptops, and to that person I say, if you have room in the system and are able to plug in the Readycache then why not? The statement just makes no sense, plus I found several people running benchmarks using laptops as an example, it cut their boot times in half.Bottom line, if you have 10K RPM drives with SSD or other caching solution Readycache won't help much. However if you have a 7200RPM drive or those horrible hybrid or energy star 5200-5400RPM drives then you will see a fantastic performance increase with everything from boot times cut in half to games loading and running more efficiently, and it only uses 0.5Watts while in use, and 0.05watts idle.My level of expertise? I'm a computer network technician for 15 years, plus I help manage several servers, do cabling, and many other things.***UPDATE***I had a chance to test things like boot speed and read performance, here are my results.WinBootInfo (Measures boot speed in seconds, using 5400rpm 1.5TB drive SATA2)Before Installing ReadyCache123.4secondsAfter Installing ReadyCache87.5secondsHD Tune ProBefore ReadyCache (Avg of 3 tests)1GB = 92.23MB/sec  15.20ms (access time, in milliseconds)2GB = 99.80MB/sec  8.69msAfter ReadyCache1GB = 96.37MB/sec  7.51ms2GB = 109.30MB/sec  7.47msNow these results don't seem miraculous, but what did improve significantly was the Access times. Game play-ability is much better, while loading speed and zoning are greatly improved. Faster Access time results in faster Frames Per Second.Now imagine the results if I was using a 7200rpm drive and actually had a motherboard with SATA3 support. The results would be much higher.
summary: This should help people decide wether or not to purchase a Readycache

reviewText: Update (One month after receiving the product):My CrashPlan cloud backup of ~510 GB completed within the past 24 hours.  When the CrashPlan backup engine isn't actively backing up, I'm seeing between 2% and 10% CPU utilization and right at 40% RAM utilization (because Java continues to be running in the background).  This little box plowed right on through until all the data was backed up to the cloud.Odd thing happened last night with about 8 GB left to backup, though.  I kept getting the error when launching CrashPlan desktop that it couldn't connect to the backup engine.  I launched the DSM web interface and sure enough, the CrashPlan package wasn't running.  It hasn't stopped on its own before.  All it took was one click to start the service again, and it's run just fine since then.  One thing I noticed is that the desktop application has been upgraded from 3.2.1 to 3.4.1 in the past 18-24 hours.  I don't think upgrading the desktop app would've required doing anything to the headless Linux install on the Synology, but maybe the two things are related.  I'll update again if the problem continues to occur.VPN server functionality continues to work well.  I did have to change DDNS providers because the service I was using (No-IP) apparently didn't recognize the Synology was actively using the service even though the Synology was successfully registering itself every 24 hours.  I got an e-mail from No-IP stating that I had to click a link every 30 days to keep my DDNS hostname active.  Either that, or pay a small yearly fee to avoid the hassle.  No thanks.  I've changed to Synology's DDNS service and it seems to be working just fine as far as DDNS resolution is concerned.  I've disabled the "Heartbeat" function for now, though.  Heartbeat seems like a cool feature because it will send you an e-mail when your Synology goes offline and when it comes back online.  It seemed to work for the first few hours I was using it.  Then, I got an e-mail stating that my Synology had gone offline.  However, I was still able to access it through my Synology DDNS address,  About 12 hours later, I got an e-mail that the box had come back online.  I may try the Heartbeat feature again in the future, but for now I'll leave it turned off.Update (Almost two weeks after receiving the product):The DS213 has been humming along now for almost two full weeks.  I continue to think this is the best purchase I've made this year for my home network.Time Machine backups continue to work flawlessly for both my and my wife's MacBook Pros.  My CrashPlan backup to CrashPlan Central is still running and shows about 10 days left before it's done backing up the full 510+ GB of data to the cloud.  I'm happy to report that if a CrashPlan backup gets interrupted during a power failure (I intentionally pulled the plug), once the power comes back on, the CrashPlan service starts automatically and the backup picks up right where it left off without any user intervention required.On the subject of CrashPlan backups, I would recommend that you purchase a Synology with 512 MB of RAM as a minimum if you plan on using CrashPlan much at all.  This DS213 has 512 MB of RAM.  Java (which is required to be installed on the Synology for CrashPlan to run) is a RAM hog.  According to the Resource Monitor in DSM, my DS213 is averaging anywhere between 50-85% RAM usage when the CrashPlan service (and therefore Java) is running.  I can't imagine trying to use CrashPlan on a Synology that only has 256 MB of RAM onboard.  Folks are saying they've been able to get it to work on Synologys with 256 MB of RAM; but I have to believe that a Synology with 256 MB of RAM takes a hit in terms of multi-tasking when the CrashPlan service is running.I've transitioned my main 1.5 TB external drive to the DS213, so I now have two external USB drives connected.  I set up a local backup in DSM so that every morning at 5 AM, the main contents of the internal 3 TB drive are backed up to the 1.5 TB external drive.  I'm happy to report that, unlike some of the reports I've seen online, using the "Backup and Restore" feature that's built in to DSM is doing incremental backups for me.  I'd seen conflicting reports online that using "Backup and Restore" caused the entire backup to be done from scratch each time.  This clearly isn't the case for me because the first backup took about five hours and each successive daily backup has taken 5-10 minutes tops.  So, the Synology is clearly examining what's already been copied, comparing it to what's on the internal drive, and only copying what's new or changed on the internal drive.I can't say enough good things about this device so far.  In every respect, it has met or exceeded my expectations.  The VPN server continues to work flawlessly and has allowed me to mount my home network shares and access the DSM web interface while on the road.  The device continues to remain in sync with my DDNS account without any issues.  All-in-all, I continue to be extremely satisfied with this purchase.Original review (October 2012):I will begin my review with a caveat -- I've only used this product for three days.  I can't speak to the reliability of the product yet, but I can share my initial impressions.For the past three days, I've been continually amazed at what this little box can do.  I paired it with aWestern Digital 3 TB Cache 3.5-Inch Internal Bare or OEM Drives WD30EFRXand it's working exceptionally well.  It took less than five minutes to unbox the Synology, unbox the Western Digital hard drive, and install the drive into the Synology.When you first power on the Synology, it's just a dumb box (literally.)  You'll need to either go to the Synology website and download the Synology Assistant and the DSM (DiskStation Manager) OS or insert the included CD and install the Synology Assistant and the DSM OS from there.  Actually, I think maybe the CD just has the Synology Assistant and if you insert the CD, you still download the OS from the web, but I'm not sure about that.  I opted to download the Synology Assistant and the OS directly from the Synology site so I was sure to be installing the latest versions of both.It took about 15 minutes for the DiskStation OS to install on the box.  Once that was done, the process of "initializing" and formatting my 3 TB drive began.  That took about 8 hours.  While the Synology is busy initializing the drive, you can create user accounts and modify network settings (i.e. assign a static IP or configure DDNS), but you can't create any folders (or shares) or download any packages from the Package Center.  Just set up the Synology an hour or two before you go to bed and let it initialize the drive(s) while you're asleep.  That's my recommendation.While the hard drive was initializing, I took the opportunity to get the Synology registered with DDNS so if my IP address changes, I'll still be able to access it remotely.  It took less than five minutes to get this box added to my existing DDNS account.Once the drive was initialized and I could download packages, I set up the Synology box as a VPN server so I can mount the shares on this drive locally anywhere in the world.  That took all of a minute and a half including the time it took to download the VPN Server package from the Package Center.I've transferred the contents of my primary external drive (~500 GB) to the Synology.  Worked flawlessly.  Last night, I installed CrashPlan on the Synology so I can have its contents continually backed up off-site.  I had to follow some instructions to get CrashPlan working (it's not a one-click install), but the third-party support for the Synology platform is impressive.I plugged in one of my external 1 TB hard drives.  It took about 15 minutes for the Synology to format it to ext4 format.  Once that was done, the drive showed up in DSM, and I was able to share it out to specific users and use it as a local backup destination for the 3 TB drive inside the Synology.  Once the CrashPlan backup of the internal Synology drive is complete, I will format my main 1.5 TB external drive as ext4 and also attach it to the Synology.  That will bring my effective network storage up to nearly 5.5 TB.  Pretty impressive.I'm ashamed to say that a couple of years ago, I purchased aPogoplug Multimedia Sharing Device.  I was hoping at the time that the Pogoplug would be a reliable NAS-type device that would allow me to access my files from anywhere and easily share files with family and friends.  This device runs circles around the Pogoplug, and it's silly to even mention the two products in the same sentence.  Of course, the Pogoplug is $30 and this Synology box is $300 as of the writing of this review.  Sure, those prices are nowhere near in the same ballpark, but in this instance, I truly believe you get what you pay for.  You can read my detailed review of the Pogoplug here on Amazon, as well.Unlike the Pogoplug, the Synology works as a destination for Time Machine backups.  One word of caution: set up a unique account for Time Machine backups (or multiple accounts if you'll be backing up multiple computers via Time Machine).  Then, be sure to enable disk quotas on the Time Machine account(s).  This will set a threshold for how much space Time Machine is allowed to use for backups.  Otherwise, Time Machine will gladly eat up all the space on your NAS.  My wife and I are both backing our MacBook Pros up to the Synology and I created a Time Machine account for each of our computers.  I gave both Time Machine user accounts a quota of 250 GB.  So far, Time Machine backups are working flawlessly on both of our computers (she's using Snow Leopard and I'm using Mountain Lion.)On the subject of noise, the Synology box is dead quiet.  I've had it on 24/7 since plugging it in three days ago and it's quiet and running cool.  The OS is highly configurable and if you want, you can set it up so that the Synology will power off and power on at specified times every day.  I'll probably just leave mine on all the time.  I was happy to see the option in the OS for the Synology to automatically restart in the event of a power outage once power is restored.  I don't currently have it connected to a UPS, so if the power flickers or goes out, I'm glad to know that the box will automatically power back on once power comes back on.  Don't get me started on how much of a nightmare the Pogoplug was if, God forbid, the power went out.  I tested the Synology by purposely pulling the plug.  When I plugged it back in, the box booted up and it was ready for use again in about three minutes.I will continue to update this review (as I did with the Pogoplug) if my experience with the Synology box changes over the coming weeks and months.  So far, though, color me impressed!!
summary: Easily the best purchase I've made for my network recently

reviewText: I've used backup solutions from Buffalo, Fantom, NetGear, Seagate and Western Digital and so far the Synology DiskStation package is by far the easiest and most feature rich I've worked with. It may appear that all NAS storage devices are the same, but the Synology adds a rich app universe that makes adding/updating new features quick and easy, so whether you want a cloud sync solution or a media server or both, its as easy as a few clicks of a button.I kitted my DiskStation with a couple of Seagate Barracuda 7200 3 TB 7200RPM SATA drives. Just plugged them in, let Synology format them and setup its proprietary RAID and I was good to go with 3TB of redundant storage. A couple more clicks and I'm running an Audio Station, Cloud Station, Photo Station, and Video Station all shared across my network so I can stream content to any computer on the network or even my XBox 360 or PS3 systems.Overall I'm loving the features and ease of setup. If you want a feature rich storage solution, Synology is where its at. If you're just looking for a RAID based backup solution, Synology supports varous RAID configurations, but you can probably find dedicated RAID devices without all the bells and wistles that Synology provides for much cheaper. My setup has been running smoothly for a couple months with some failry heavy use, but if anything changes I'll be back to let you guys know about it... so far so great!!

Glad I ordered a screen protector that comes in a two pack!  I have installed tons of screen protectors on iPhones but this was my first iPad install. Messed up the first one with particles under it during install. My fault not the products. Second one (in two pack) worked great on my kids iPad4.Install Tip: spend 5-10 mins and watch a youtube video or two to learn how to best install. Clean work area before starting. Clean screen to remove ALL dust and debrie. use 2-4 pieces of scotch tape to add more holding tabs on the sides of protector (like the pull tabs protector comes with). This helps a lot when trying to align.

I love composition notebooks. I've filled hundreds of them in my lifetime (I laughed when I saw John Nash's house filled with notebooks). And for me, it's a nostalgic item that brings back my school-boy days.Verso is definitely a solid manufacturer of covers. I have 3 now and each was a different style, but all have been very high quality.EXTERIOR: The patterns and textures are accurate. Even from up close, it looks exactly like a fresh composition notebook. The difference is in the actual material. Whatever is underneath the skin is stiff, but compliant. I've said it before and I still believe it may be Kydex or something similar. The skin has a hard matte texture. The spine has the same cloth-tape look and feel as the original. The theme is complete front to back.SPINE: The spine is very flexible, enough to lay flat when open. It can be folded back too. Easily the most flexible cover I've encountered, but doesn't feel weak or disjointed at all.INTERIOR: The inside cover of an actual composition notebook should be white, has manufacturer's details, and a box to scribble additional details about the rightful owner or class schedule. However, on this Verso cover, the inside looks like college-ruled notebook paper. The texture is the same suede-like material as other Verso covers. However, there is no pocket, which I personally welcome because there's not enough room to stick more than a folded scrap of paper in those pockets anyway.FIT: I do not own a Kindle Fire HD. I own a Hyundai A7 and Skypad Alpha 2. Both fit well. The elastic straps are thinner on the HD versions than on the non-HD versions. They fall easily between the volume rocker and power button on the Skypad. However, both tablets are much smaller in exterior dimensions, which makes them look a bit small inside this cover.BOTTOM LINE: I know I'm not the only one out there that loves compositions notebooks. If you're a fanboy like me, and you can spare the money, this is an excellent cover. I've gone through 5 covers now, and I've finally found a winner.

As a long-time owner of the original Bose earbuds (complete with crumbling cords), with a more-recently acquired pair ofJabra SPORT buds(great tape/cords, lousy audio), I wished outloud more than once that I could put the Bose speakers on the Jabra tape. Apparently, Bose heard me.These earbuds are extraordinary. Not only do they stay in and feel comfortable (thanks to the new vulcan-style eargels), and have kevlar-reinforced cords, they sound AWESOME. Some classic tracks are intolerable without low-end response (Desert Rose, Hotel California, Daddy Sang Bass, anything disco, etc.). Not only do these buds render the low end tolerably, they also have excellent sound imaging. I'm truly impressed.I find that I am kicking my player volume up a few notches when using these, so there is some sound loss by not having the gels tight to the ears, but that's minor (the urge is the push the gels into your ears, but as Bose rightly points out in their instructions, if the buds sound better this way it's because you need to turn them up).I got my set at the Bose store (sorry Amazon), and they took back my old set to be recycled and gave me a bit of trade-in value. My only complaint is that the armband smells kinda plastic-y, and will need to be aired out (I probably wasn't going to use it anyway - I'm glad I still have the little case from my original pair). Minor issue. The new sport buds themselves are all around impressive.
best camera can see across the street. 4 big led awesome at night and day i would reccomend this for others.

Intro:The initial setup wizard was very easy and quick and should get most typical users setup within 2 minutes including a reboot of the access point.just type setup.ampedwireless.com into any browser and follow the extremely easy prompts!The AP20000G has features like MAC filtering, WPS, access control schedules,etc...The AP20000G features 4 guest networks per band (frequency)The AP20000G Also features USB storage  also which is extremely easy.Wireless performance (quick overview):We are mostly going to do real world performance tests on the AP.First test.... streaming video: I went outside around 175 feet from the AP20000G and I was able to stream YouTube videos with little buffer. This amazed me. Please note that there are 5 other networks near my house and my AP is placed at the opposite end of the house! HD did have some buffering at that distance, however it was actually tolerable. HD had NO BUFFERING/pausing at around 75 ft and pre- loaded 25% of a 35 min video is about 8-15 seconds. It takes 35-45 seconds or more for that much prebuffer to fill on my Netgear WGR614.  Very nice!2nd streaming video test: was able to stream SD video and at a decent speed with little buffering at 230ft!!! AWESOME!!!!HARDCORE COVVERRAAGE!!!!!Gaming test: We setup an Xbox 360 with the built in WLAN controller on it and we put it through a few online games and it performs on par with the wired Xbox 360 that doesn't have the WLAN controller! No lag related to the wireless at all even with other APs using the same channels and microwaves have been used close to it as well. AWESOME!!!!Browsing on all wireless devices is on par with wired throughout the house.I highly recommend this Access Point so far!

Pros:PortableCons:Need large unobscured white wallVery little actual free contentInternal speaker is pitifulRequires a dark roomThe image quality is "okay", nothing like using a real HDTV.  The maximum resolution is 720p (according to the setup menu) which may or may not look good depending on how large you make the projection and how good the surface is which you are projecting onto.  There is a fairly severe trapezoid distortion issue which can't be adjusted.Portability is excellent, especially considering it can run for a couple hours on battery power.Working the menus and bringing up content is a bit slow (but not unexpected considering the network communication going on).  Keep in mind this requires you to have a wireless access point to provide Internet access.To sign up and activate your device you *must* provide a credit card (they promise not to bill you unless you buy anything) and a credit card *must* remain on file with them."Membership may be required for some content." is an understatement.  Almost all content requires paying for it either "on demand" or via subscription.  That might be okay for Roku connected directly to a HDTV but for a low quality projection there is no way I would pay for content.I have a large house and I was surprised to realize that I don't have a wall upon which I could project this!
summary: Clever Idea not much real use

reviewText: There aren't too many radios that pick up HD stations. Insignia is one of the very few companies that include HD in their tuners. This is the best HD radio I've seen. It's compact, takes four AA's and is very selective and sensitive in receiving signals. You probably have to be thirty miles or so from the station transmitter to receive the HD signal and it's subchannels.I live about 50 miles from Wilkes Barre,Pa and 70 miles from Harrisburg. Most of the signals come in where I live, but the HD signal does not. This morning I was 35 miles from Wilkes Barre and two HD channels registered. I look forward to bringing this radio with me on the road to see what I can pick up.This radio also has an RDS feature that displays the call letters and the song that is currently playing on stations that do have that feature. Only other portable that has this is Sangeans PR D5. Now, if that radio had HD capabilities, that would make that model the tops in it's field.Finally, an easy, convenient way to listen to HD radio. Now, only if there were more of these sub channels and the industry began promoting them.This radio is FM only and also features an Aux In, which is a bonus.At $30 plus on Amazon and $40 at Best Buy, this is a very nice receiver.

First off I think that the price that I paid for the screen protectors were good since I was trying to find the cheapest ones. These were the cheapest ones and also came with 3 screen protectors which was good because I messed up trying to install my first one and successfully installed the second one so now I have one spare. The screen protectors are not even noticeable on my ipod since I installed it correctly and I am happy I purchased from this seller. Anyways, I will be buying from them again if I need any.

This is equivalent to the stock antenna provided for Wouxun and Baofeng (and others) dual-band 2-meter/70-cm portable radios. The connector fits great, it's durable enough for everyday use in the field, and it's electrically equivalent to the stock antenna, but much cheaper. There are better antennas available, but they're almost twice as long. If you need a new dual-band antenna, buy this one.

This is a very good sounding basic amp. It is on par or better than the Fiio E9. On very efficient headphones you may get a little noise when you move the volume pot same as on the E9. This amp easily drives my AKG 702 headphones, somewhat of an accomplishment. Yes this is on of those cheap Chinese amps, just like your expensive Chinese made laptop and other electronics. Who cares where it's made so long as it sounds good. I like it much better than my D1 for headphone use. Pair it with a good DAC (D1 in my case)and give it a listen.
This is not the greatest of the product, the quality is not high but for the size, portability and the price, I will give this a 4 star.
Works as advertised. I'm currently using it to connect an audio cable from my Apple TV to a LG stereo. So far, I haven't had any trouble with it, so it's good value.

I have a couple of other stylus?styli?  Those feel very sturdy and substantial in the hand.  This one, although very similar, feels much lighter.  Now, my preference is the heavier feel but for anyone who has difficulties with their hands or fingers, this one might be perfect.  LOVE the color!

I waffled back and forth on this item because I really didn't know how much I'd use it. I finally decided to throw it in with my Kindle order, and I'm glad I did. The screen responds to it just like a finger tap without the downside of fingerprints. I can wipe the screen clean and use this, and afterwords its still crystal clear.I've had it for a month now, and I've had no problem with the clip. I've seen some reviews complaining about it snapping off, but I clip this on my jeans pocket all the time and the clip is still tightly attached.

I had high hope for this arm but it doesn't fit. It fits so snug that it is impossible to attach it to any of my mounts. The other end that connects to the camera is fine. As a result, it is useless. I returned it to the seller for a refund.

First of all, I went from an old 21" Samsung monitor to this 27" 1440 display.  What can I say, everything looks gorgeous on it.  The graphics when using windows, the movies, streaming Netflix, all look great.  But the biggest difference was editing photos.  That is where I believe this monitor shines.  Photos are vivid and the colors are great, I did not have to make any adjustments to the factory settings.  I have plenty of real estate to open the photo and have my editing tools open beside it without feeling like I'm running out of room or having to zoom in and out.  Great!  Playing games is awesome, I did not notice any blurring or shadowing, but I'm not a hard core gamer.  I just play an occasional game.  The stand is solid, although it does take up some room on your desk, it's not a deal breaker.Overall, I am extremely pleased with it and recommend it to anyone.
I am having the same problem with my Corsair 650. The noise is extremely annoying and I, too, thought I could just ignore it but it's impossible. I will be returning the product for a different model

I bought Nikon S01 because I couldn't resist it! It's a very small and cute camera, with the respectability of Nikon brand name!It takes pretty good pictures for its size. I cannot say that it is an outstanding camera by any measure of imagination. But takes nice pictures and is a good conversation starter, too. I have several cameras including Nikon, Canon, and Olympus, but I think this little one is going to be in my pocket when I travel. it's really a handy camera to take pretty decent pictures.

Bought this to power something that needs 5 volts at up to 1000ma.  The info that came with it says that the voltage is between 5.2 and 5.6 volts (5.6 is way out of range of the USB voltage spec: 5 volts +/- 5%) and the current can vary from 830ma to 1000ma.  Can't hook it up because the overvoltage may damage my device.  Not worth the cost of shipping to return it.  Granted, it's only guaranteed for the devices listed but the actual power numbers should have been listed so folks know that it doesn't really meet the USB specs.Just took a look at the device itself and it is labeled as 5.3 volts at 1 amp output.  Just more evidence that the listing is incorrect.Update: I received a call from the seller and they offered a full refund without the need to return the product.  That was a pleasant surprise.  First, that they care enough to read reviews about the products they sell, and second, that they would offer that level of customer service.  Kudos to them.Update: The technical specs on Amazon have been changed now to reflect what the adapter actually has printed on it (5.3 volts).  Still out of spec for normal USB use but at least the buyer is forewarned.  Upgraded to 3 stars.
summary: Power specs not exactly as advertised

reviewText: I love this unit deh x6500bt/deh65 bt it allows me to use the Bluetooth and never remove my phone from my pocket in the car. It has a Bluetooth speakerphone that people say they cant tell i'm on speaker phone when i'm driving with the windows up. The unit also can play the music from your phone via Bluetooth. Both the phone and the Bluetooth music stream will auto connect and can be set to auto answer incoming calls also, which I love! The radio shows all the Radio station info song name band name and call tag of station the iPad or USB port charges and allows the unit to display song names and info. JUST FYI the Bluetooth WILL DISPLAY THE SONG ARTIST INFO even in APPS liek pandora and it will control pandora also  The Bluetooth does display the incoming caller info stored name and caller id info. You can pause skip stop the Bluetooth music or just grab the device and change the song on it or run Pandora app the unit will skip stop using the units buttons also in Pandora. The display can be hard to read in bright sunlight even on bright display. And also the People at Pioneer need to put a lock on the MC knob to stop it from being a MC knob while changing volume you will push it and start changing setting when u went to turn up the radio, i use the remote because this seems to be a huge safety issue as u have to look down and fix it and look to see if it is not on volume mode anymore.includes external micUsing the USB cord with Ipod/phone is Great and charges it also.You can set favorite phone numbers to the station buttons for faster dialing of people on speaker phoneor the aux input also allows people like my mom still rocking a Walkman tape play to plug the 80s tech/odd tech into the unit and play it.I find the power and tone of this unit to be perfect. Kids will need new speakers and amps but as a 40 yr old I skipped the other stuff this time and got the head only and I'm glad i DID the factory speakers sound great and have great tone and response.*********** THIS IS NOT THE EU VERSION with the nice OEL display ***********display is nice has song name and artist even on appshooks up in s sec just order the wire harness plugin (found one on amazon for a penny plus $4 shipping) and the mount frame ($12 amazon free prime shipping) and spend and hour and your rocking.Miss under $1 a gal gas so i could just fill up and drive to hear the radio but since it is $3.50 or more a gal i will just have to wait and hope for a reason to go somewhere! Roadtrip? anyone? anyone? lol
summary: got this to replace my deh 6400bt it fixes all issues with teh 6400bt

reviewText: The only reason I replaced the factory radio was to have a line in port so I could listen to my ipod as I drive. This stereo is great for people like me. If you just casually listen to the radio and want to use the line in port now and again, this is a great option. There aren't a whole lot of other bells and whistles, but that saves me money in the end. I purchased a dash kit and wire harness from Amazon as well making the install really quick and painless.
Nice and long for a wall mounted Samsung 7500, but had to ream the plastic out of the holes a little bit to get it fully into the power socket.

I must say I'm really enjoying NeoTV. The out of the box setup was as simple as one, two, three. Easily connects to your wifi and if you already have a subscription to things such entertainment streaming providers such as Netflix, you will love the easy options to view on your HDTV. Even those who don't subscribe to such providers can enjoy features such as pandora music play, youtube connection, and even facebook directly playing through your television. I do wish however that they found a way to make it easier to key in alpha/numeric entries being as most instances you have to log into an account. If not a full keyboard on the remote, perhaps some variation. I also didn't care for the immediate software upgrade that came on screen shortly after connection. It caused some of the initial setup steps to have to be re-entered. Overall though it's a very good product and doesn't take much space at all.
