keyboard in its design elements.փ The 5.3"x5.1" glass surface feels smooth, just like a touching a touchscreen display, without being too slippery.փ This is a far better, more expressive, and spacious touchpad than using a laptop's touchpad.փ If you either suffer from repetitive-stress injuries (RSI) or hope to avoid them, using a touchpad or trackpad is better for your hand and wrist than using a mouse, giving your hands and fingers a wider variety of movements compared to the few repetitive hand and finger movements that you make when using a mouse.փ While this touchpad is optimally used with Windows 8, if you use it on different Windows 8, Windows 7, and Windows Vista computers, the gestures are nearly identical except for four operations, three of which are specific to Windows 8, making it easy to move this touchpad between different computers.փ The touchpad uses Logitech's USB "Unifying" nano-receiver that can be paired with up to six Logitech devices simultaneously so you do not use up extra USB ports if you use multiple Logitech Unifying-capable devices.փ Even though Logitech officially lists this touchpad as being compatible with only Windows 7, Windows 8, and Windows RT, I have confirmed that it works great with Windows Vista :-) (I do not know about Windows XP compatibility.)ჯ Negatives:ჯ The "Pointer Speed" slider option in SetPoint really also needs a "Pointer Acceleration" or "Enhanced Pointer Precision" setting that dynamically adjusts the sensitivity of the pointer based on its acceleration. Otherwise, unless "Pointer Speed" is set really slow, there can be far too much jerkiness and lack of precision compared to using a mouse.ჯ There is no right-click-n-drag gesture available on this touchpad, which is needed to effectively use Microsoft Excel, graphics/photo programs, Windows Explorer, and other applications.ჯ Because of the above two drawbacks, this touchpad cannot be efficiently used with Microsoft Excel, photo/graphics editing programs, or other applications requiring either right-click-n-drag or very precise pointer positioning/dragging/clicking. Hopefully, an enhancement to a later version of SetPoint can fix this?ჯ When used with Windows 8, swiping the touchpad's top and side edges perform Windows 8 functions. But when used with Windows 7, the touchpad's outer edges have a half-inch wide "dead zone" perimeter where nothing happens.ჯ The two left/right rubber feet buttons underneath the touchpad at the bottom left/right corners really would be more ergonomic, adaptable, and durable if they were located as buttons on top of the touchpad, instead of being clicked by pressing onto the rubber feet.ჯ This touchpad has no moving parts and should last a very long time, but its rechargeable proprietary lithium ion polymer battery is not user-replaceable (and Logitech does not offer a service to replace it).ჯ Small nitpick, but I would have preferred a Bluetooth version of this touchpad, especially since I use this touchpad with Logitech's K810 Bluetooth keyboard, so there would be no need to plug in a USB receiver.What is in the box package?✵ Touchpad T650✵ USB "Unifying" nano-receiver that can be paired with up to six Logitech devices simultaneously✵ 6-foot USB-to-Micro-USB recharging cable wound around two plastic cable clip guides to keep it organized✵ 10-page English-language "Setup Guide"With the release of Windows 8, Microsoft altered the Windows user interface to accommodate tablets and smartphones, welcoming in the new era of Windows touch-oriented computing. But by doing so, Microsoft also drove countless users of regular Windows computers crazy, forcing the mouse-oriented computing world to live by the rules of the touch-oriented world. This touchpad is essentially like the touchpad on your laptop, but with a surface area at least 50% larger than even the biggest laptop trackpad and enhanced to understand all of the common finger gestures that are now used on touchscreens and, in particular, Windows 8 gesture commands. Note that this touchpad is still just a pointing device, like using an oversized laptop touchpad that is enhanced with Windows 8 gestures. If you want a more-intuitive where-you-touch-is-where-your-cursor-moves-on-the-screen Windows 8 experience, you need to get a Windows 8 tablet or computer that is equipped with a touchscreen, in which case you would not need this T650 Touchpad. So adding this T650 to a Windows 8 computer not equipped with a touchscreen is not quite the same as using a Windows 8 touchscreen.One thing should be clarified regarding this touchpad's compatibility with Windows versions. Logitech states that this touchpad only works with Windows 8, Windows RT, or Windows 7. But I have confirmed that this touchpad works very well with Windows Vista; on my 32-bit Windows Vista (Service Pack 2), both the hardware and the SetPoint software are working perfectly. I have been using this touchpad for the past two weeks with 64-bit Windows 8, 64-bit Windows 7, 32-bit Windows 7, and 32-bit Windows Vista (Service Pack 2), and it works flawlessly with all of them. This touchpad's operation on Windows Vista is nearly identical to its functionality on Windows 7. I itemize this touchpad's behavioral differences between Windows 8, Windows 7, and Windows Vista later in this review.More of this Logitech Rechargeable Touchpad T650's notable product features are described and rated below:► Packaging, Style, Appearance: ѾѾѾѾѾ Excellent 5-fuzzies ratingѾѾѾѾѾ This rechargeable touchpad charges using a USB-to-Micro-USB cable that is included in the box package. The supplied 6-foot cable is wound around two plastic cable clip guides that keep the cable neat and tidy. Most electronic manufacturers do not include cable guides/clips to neatly store their cables, so this is a nice touch by Logitech.ѾѾѾѾѾ The touchpad is sleek and stylish with a gray-colored glass surface that complements the gray/black color theme present on all of Logitech's other mice and keyboards. I am using this touchpad with Logitech's excellent newLogitech Bluetooth Illuminated Keyboard K810 for PCs, Tablets, Smartphones - Black  (920-004292), and it is obvious that both products were designed at the same time to work together because the touchpad matches the style of the K810 keyboard. Both have a similar gray color, similar depth measurement, slim sleek profile with similar low heights, and similar rounding of their four corners. This touchpad looks very nice placed next to the K810 keyboard.This touchpad's measurements are:Width: 5.3 inchesDepth/Length: 5.1 inchesHeight: 0.34 inch front, 0.47 inch rearWeight: 7.3 ouncesѾѾѾѾѾ The touchpad's glass surface feels smooth, just like a touching a touchscreen display, but without being too slippery. The glass feels like it has been lightly sandblasted to give your fingers a bit of traction and tactile feedback. The glass feels durable, scratch-resistant, and also smudge-resistant, which is nice because my fingers are constantly tapping and swiping all over its surface. If you use this touchpad in a cold room such as a data center or office with turbocharged air conditioning, the glass will feel cold to the touch.► Construction & Build Quality: ѾѾѾѾѾ Excellent 5-fuzzies ratingѾѾѾѾѾ As with the matching K810 keyboard, this touchpad has excellent build quality. The glass surface mounted on top, all seams, and the bottom panel are all precisely and tightly fitted with no exposed screws. The four corners underneath the touchpad have four small rubber feet for traction. The two lower left/right rubber feet also function as buttons; they press into the interior of the touchpad with a slight clicking sound when you press on the lower left/right corners of the touchpad. The right side of the touchpad has a sliding power switch, and the rear edge has the Micro-USB port for the recharging cable.► Installation & Setup: ѾѾѾѾѾ Excellent 5-fuzzies ratingѾѾѾѾѾ A 10-page "Setup Guide" is included. This touchpad is easy to set up. I just plug in the USB receiver, and slide the power switch on the right edge of the touchpad to turn it on. When the touchpad is first turned on or when it wakes up from standby/sleep mode, a small battery status LED light in its upper right corner will temporarily glow green if the battery has power, or it will light up red if the battery needs to be charged through a USB port. While its USB cord is plugged in to recharge the internal battery, the LED light blinks green. After two to three hours of charging time, the battery status light turns off. I can continue to use the touchpad while it is plugged in for recharging. The battery status light normally is unlit and stays hidden. The touchpad that I purchased already had power in its battery. Logitech states that a full two to three hour recharge of this touchpad will provide up to one month of power.There is no software included with this touchpad, and no drivers need to be installed to use it. As with all of Logitech's keyboards and mice, you can download their SetPoint software from Logitech's Web site which will allow you to customize this touchpad's functions. When you turn on the touchpad, it would prompt you to download and install SetPoint. If the automatic download does not happen, the "Setup Guide" lists the URL Web address where you go to manually download the latest SetPoint software. With most of Logitech's keyboard and mice, using their SetPoint is optional. But with this touchpad, I think that installing SetPoint on your Windows computer really enhances, customizes, and tutors your touchpad usage. I talk about how SetPoint interacts with this touchpad later in this review.When downloading the SetPoint software from Logitech's Web site, the download section only lists "Windows 7" and "Windows 8" versions of SetPoint. But I have confirmed that the "Windows 7" version of SetPoint can also be used on Windows Vista.ѾѾѾ This touchpad utilizes Logitech's USB 2.0-protocol 'Unifying Receiver' that can interact with up to six Unifying-compatible Logitech keyboards, mice, or number pads, and it has a wireless range up to 33 feet. However, there is no place to store this small thumbnail-sized USB nano-receiver unless I leave it always plugged into a USB port. On some of Logitech's mice and number pad models, there is a storage slot on the device that securely stores its USB receiver. But there is no way to store this touchpad's USB nano-receiver on the body of the touchpad itself, and if the nano-receiver is stored and carried separately, its tiny size increases the risk of losing it. The rear edge of the touchpad seems thick enough that a USB receiver storage slot could have been molded into it, or have a molded inset underneath the touchpad where the USB nano-receiver could be stored when it is not in use. If I want to transport the touchpad with its USB nano-receiver unplugged, I have to place it inside a pouch that ensures the tiny device does not get lost.ѾѾѾ I wish that Logitech also offered a Bluetooth version of this touchpad. I would have purchased a Bluetooth version of this T650 Touchpad if it was available. I use this touchpad with the awesome newly-released Logitech Bluetooth Illuminated Keyboard K810. Logitech's K810 Bluetooth keyboard has a unique and very useful "Easy-Switch" feature that lets it pair with up to three Bluetooth-enabled devices. Since this touchpad works so well with the K810 keyboard, what would be really cool is if a Bluetooth T650 Touchpad was made that had three buttons on the front edge of the touchpad that, when pressed, could also quickly switch to one of three Bluetooth devices, which is what the K810 keyboard can do. And since the gestures and movements are nearly identical when using this touchpad between different versions of Windows, its use would be effortless when hopping back and forth between three different Windows computers.► Design & Features: ѾѾѾѾѾ Excellent 5-fuzzies ratingѾѾѾѾѾ The following lists the full set of clicking gestures, navigation gestures, and window movement gestures that are available for Windows 8, Windows 7, and Windows Vista. Logitech does not include Windows Vista in its compatibility list for this touchpad, but I have confirmed that the touchpad gestures listed below work great with Windows Vista.For the gestures listed below that have multiple listings, the first listing is the default operation for that gesture and the other listed methods can be used by customizing them using the Logitech SetPoint software. For the actions that involve a "tap", this means using the fingers to briefly tap on the glass surface. For actions that involve a "click", this means using one, two, or three fingers to press down on the surface with enough force to cause one of the two rubber feet buttons on the underside of the left and right corners to trigger a click. The force that is required to press down on the surface for "click" actions is slightly harder/firmer than the left/right button clicks on a mouse. Logitech's SetPoint software is very flexible in letting me customize gestures so they only involve tapping, only involve clicking, or can involve either of the two actions. I have my SetPoint configured so that I never have to press down to perform clicks at all; all of my gestures are configured to only involve either taps or swipes.Left Click (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Click and/or tap with 1 finger.Left Click and Drag (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Move pointer into position with index finger, press and hold down either the left or right corner button using another finger while moving index finger to drag the pointer.2) Double-tap with 1 finger. On the second tap, do not raise the finger, but keep it in contact with the touchpad and move it to drag.(Both left-click-n-drag options may be used interchangeably without needing to just solely use one or the other. The second "Double-tap with 1 finger" gesture requires SetPoint version 6.51.8 or later.)Right Click (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Tap and/or click in lower right corner with 1 finger.2) Tap and/or click in lower left corner with 1 finger.3) Click and/or tap with 2 fingers.Middle Click (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Click and/or tap with 3 fingers.Vertical Scrolling (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Swipe up or down with 2 fingers.Horizontal Scrolling (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Swipe left or right with 2 fingers.Back/Forward (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Swipe left or right with 3 fingers.Zoom In/Out (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Spread or pinch with 2 fingers.Go to Windows 8 Start Screen (Windows 8):1) Swipe 3 fingers up.orSwitch Applications (Windows 7/Vista):1) Swipe 3 fingers up.Show/Hide Desktop (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Swipe 3 fingers down.Maximize/Minimize Desktop Windows (Windows 8/7/Vista):1) Swipe 4 fingers up or down.Snap Windows Left or Right (Windows 8/7; not available in Windows Vista):1) Swipe 4 fingers left or right.Switch Applications in Windows 8 (not available in Windows 7/Vista):1) Swipe 1 finger right from left edge of touchpad.Open/Close Charms sidebar in Windows 8 (not available in Windows 7/Vista):1) Swipe 1 finger left from right edge of touchpad.Open/Close Application Menu in Windows 8 (not available in Windows 7/Vista):1) Swipe 1 finger downward starting from top edge of touchpad.ѾѾѾѾѾ From the above listing, if you compare which gestures work with which Windows versions, it is easy to memorize. Windows Vista works identical to Windows 7 except for the swipe-4-fingers-left/right "Snap Windows" gesture since Windows Vista does not have snap functionality, neither Windows 7 nor Windows Vista work with the three 1-finger swiping actions from the left/right/top edge of the touchpad, and neither Windows 7 nor Vista use the Windows 8-specific swipe-3-fingers-up "Go to Windows 8 Start Screen" gesture. Other than those five differences, the other ten gestures work exactly the same regardless of whether you use this touchpad with Windows 8, Windows 7, or Windows Vista.Here is a tip if you are having trouble getting consistent use of the 2-finger, 3-finger, and 4-finger tapping or swiping gestures: Keep the fingers level and pressed side-by-side with each other, without having some fingers slightly tipping upward and other fingers slightly tipping downward. Do not use the very tips of your fingers near the fingernails for multi-finger gestures. Using the very tip of the finger is fine for 1-finger gestures. But for multi-finger gestures, pretend that the touchpad needs to fully scan all the fingerprints of those fingers as you swipe or tap them on the touchpad's surface.ѾѾѾѾ The zooming gesture of spreading and pinching with two fingers is not quite as smooth and fluid as when I zoom on Apple's Magic Trackpad. But the other gestures work very well and I think it is comparable to Apple's trackpad for fluidity and ease of operation.ѾѾ Note that the above list has no "Right Click and Drag" gesture available! Using Excel, I cannot move the pointer right onto the border of a spreadsheet cell, right-click-n-drag, and get the usual "Move Here / Copy Here / Shift Down and Copy ..." dropdown menu, and I cannot right-click-n-drag on the lower right corner of a cell to get the "Copy Cells" dropdown menu. The touchpad only supports left-click-n-drag, not right-click-n-drag. This is one of the two reasons that this touchpad will not fully replace my mouse. There are various other applications, including Windows Explorer and many graphics/photo editing software, that also utilize right-click-n-drag to perform operations and selection functions. For example, I also use a Firefox add-on that lets me right-click-n-drag to highlight a section of a Web page and then I can simultaneously open all the links within that highlighted box. But to not be able to perform right-click-n-drag on Excel, Windows Explorer, or graphics software may be a deal-breaker for people who frequently use these applications. I use Excel on a monthly basis and must still use my mouse for Excel. I wish that this can be fixed with an enhancement to a later version of SetPoint. Apple's Magic Trackpad also does not have a right-click-n-drag operation.Prior to SetPoint version 6.51.8, left-click-n-drag could only be accomplished by moving the pointer into position with an index finger, and then pressing and holding down either the left or right corner button using another finger while moving index finger to drag the pointer. With SetPoint version 6.51.8 and later, I can now use the easier method of double-tapping with one finger, and on the second tap, I keep the finger pressed onto the touchpad and move it to drag.So now that the new SetPoint version 6.51.8 lets me left-click-n-drag using 1-finger-double-tap-n-drag, the issue with lacking a right-click-n-drag gesture could be fixed if SetPoint was enhanced to allow right-click-n-drag to be operated using a 2-finger-double-tap-n-drag movement. I already have my SetPoint configured so that the primary left click is "Click or tap with 1 finger", right click is "Click or tap with 2 fingers", and middle click is "Click or tap with 3 fingers". So adding a new 2-finger-double-tap-n-drag option to SetPoint to perform the right-click-n-drag would be a very intuitive gesture based on this 1/2/3-finger left/right/middle approach.► Ergonomics, Usability & Ease of Use: ѾѾѾѾ Good 4-fuzzies ratingѾѾ When this touchpad is used with Windows 8, swiping the top and side edges perform Windows 8 functions. But when used with Windows 7 (or Vista), the touchpad's outer edges have a half-inch wide "dead zone" perimeter where nothing happens. Ideally, the touchpad, or SetPoint, should be adaptive enough to realize that it is being used with Windows 7, and since the three edge-swiping gestures do not apply, it should make this "dead zone" fully usable for all the other gesture movements. I am a touch typist who rarely looks down at the keyboard, and since I often use this touchpad with Logitech's new backlit K810 keyboard in a dark room, when using this touchpad with Windows 7, I sometimes notice that my pointer movement or navigation gesture stops working, and I realize that my finger has drifted over into this "dead zone". This can be annoying at times.ѾѾ Along with using one, two, three, or four fingers on the touchpad for gestures, the bottom left and right corners of the touchpad can also function as buttons. The two small rubber feet at the bottom two corners of this touchpad can be optionally configured to activate the 'Left Click' and 'Right Click' functions. They are basically like inverted mouse buttons placed underneath this touchpad. I wish that Logitech had designed these two buttons to be placed on top of the trackpad near the bottom left/right corners instead of being activated by pressing onto the trackpad's surface, which causes the rubber feet to click into the interior of the trackpad. I think that these two rubber feet buttons have three weaknesses in their design with respect to ergonomics, flexibility of usage, and durability.The ergonomics of these two rubber feet buttons are not that good for a touch typist who stares at the screen without looking down at the keyboard or touchpad while typing. Because the entire touchpad is smooth and flat on its surface, there is room for error when quickly reaching my thumb or pinky to click on the bottom corners because my hand may be sliding and swiping all over the touchpad. If the two buttons were made as slightly raised circular rounded buttons located near the bottom left/right corners, that would provide positive tactile feedback to my clicking finger regardless of where my other fingers may be sliding or swiping.By having the two rubber feet serve as buttons, this touchpad also loses flexibility in its positioning. I have to always place this touchpad on a flat surface. If the buttons were located on top, I could still reliably use this touchpad while it is placed on my lap, on a sofa/chair cushion next to me, on a bed mattress, or on a carpet. But I cannot activate these rubber feet buttons if the touchpad is placed on an irregular surface unless I find a book or flat item to place underneath it.I also have concerns about the long-term durability of repeatedly pressing on these two rubber feet buttons. All four rubber feet at the four corners underneath the touchpad are tiny, about 0.2" in diameter and 0.05" high. They are also not that firm, about as soft as a pencil's eraser. Either from the user repeatedly pressing down onto the bottom two clicking feet, or from the touchpad being slid along the desktop over time, these small soft rubber feet could be worn down over time so that they are level with the bottom surface of the touchpad and they would no longer activate the clicking action. These two rubber clicking feet should have been made larger in diameter and/or with more of the two feets' height protruding from the bottom for better long-term durability.Luckily, I can configure SetPoint to never need a reason to click either of the two rubber feet buttons. By default, the right-click action is performed by tapping or clicking the lower right corner with 1 finger. But I used SetPoint to configure right-click to be "Click or tap with 2 fingers". Using that in conjunction with "Click or tap with 1 finger" for left-click and "Click or tap with 3 fingers" for middle-click is very intuitive, and there is less hand/wrist/finger movement required when compared to reaching for the lower right corner. With right-click configured for "Click or tap with 2 fingers", both the left and right corner buttons perform the same left-click action as "Click or tap with 1 finger". But because SetPoint version 6.51.8 now lets me double-tap-with-1-finger-n-drag for my left-click-n-drag motion, I can always ignore those two rubber feet buttons, and I can now use my touchpad placed on my lap or any irregular surface :-)► Performance, Durability, Reliability: ѾѾѾѾѾ Excellent 5-fuzzies ratingѾѾѾѾѾ Because of the solid build quality of this touchpad and the fact that it has no moving parts except for the two rubber feet buttons, I expect it to last a very long time.This touchpad uses a Li-Pol rechargeable battery is not user-replaceable. Logitech does not specify how long this battery can last or how many times it can be recharged. Most lithium-ion polymer batteries initially recharge using a so-called "fast charge" method and then switch to a "trickle charge" method as the battery voltage reaches its maximum. But the battery's maximum capacity is diminished slightly with every recharging back to full voltage. In the "Setup Guide" for this touchpad, there is a "Battery disposal" section with instructions on how to unscrew the bottom of the touchpad and remove the internal lithium-ion battery in order to properly dispose of the battery. This touchpad has no moving parts and will likely have a much longer lifespan than a keyboard. As with all lithium-ion batteries, this touchpad's battery will eventually not be able to hold a charge, and instead of being able to replace the battery myself or even be able to send the touchpad to Logitech for them to replace the battery, I am then left with a non-rechargeable device that I presume I can then still at least continue to use by keeping the touchpad always plugged into a USB port, thereby permanently making this a wired device. Using rechargeable batteries in a wireless device is more environmentally responsible than using disposable batteries, but being able to replace that rechargeable battery is far better. Apple provides services to replace the rechargeable batteries in their products and they then properly recycle the old batteries. And Apple's Magic Trackpad uses two user-replaceable AA batteries. So I wish that this touchpad's battery could be replaced when it eventually wears out.ѾѾѾѾѾ This touchpad comes with a 3-year limited hardware warranty.► Logitech SetPoint Software Quality: ѾѾѾѾ Good 4-fuzzies ratingѾѾѾѾѾ Logitech's SetPoint software lets you configure and customize their keyboards and mice. While the installation of SetPoint is usually optional, albeit recommended, for most of Logitech's keyboards and mice, when used with this touchpad, it really does improve your experience using this touchpad, both because of its numerous customization options, and because as you customize the various clicking, navigation, and window movement gestures on the "SetPoint Settings" window, it also repeatedly plays a quick video showing how to perform that gesture option which you have selected. Logitech also has these same gesture videos on their Web site, but to have all of them displayed from within SetPoint is really useful and convenient.ѾѾѾѾѾ If you already have an older version of SetPoint running on your Windows computer, you should update it to version 6.51.8 (or later) to ensure that it works with this new touchpad. SetPoint version 6.51.8 lets you accomplish left-click-n-drag using a 1-finger-double-tap-n-drag movement. With older versions of SetPoint, such as 6.50, you could only left-click-n-drag using a more cumbersome method of moving the pointer into position with an index finger, and then pressing and holding down either the left or right corner button using another finger while moving index finger to drag the pointer.ѾѾѾѾѾ From within SetPoint, I can launch Logitech's Unifying Software to pair up to six compatible Logitech keyboards, mice, number pads, and other peripherals so that they all use the same single USB receiver, so multiple Logitech Unifying-compatible devices share the same receiver to only use up one USB port.ѾѾѾѾѾ Along with customizing or being able to disable the various gestures I listed above, SetPoint lets me adjust "Pointer Speed". This is similar to the "Pointer Speed" slider option on mouse software. There are three scroll options that can be configured in SetPoint. The 'Speed Increment' setting lets me adjust the scrolling speed by line increments or by screen. Normally, scrolling moves the window's scroll bar in the same direction as my finger. But if I set the "Synchronize scroll direction" checkbox, the direction is reversed so that the page contents move in the same direction as my two fingers; this is analogous to a "panning" action. The convenient "Scroll with inertia" option lets me flick my two fingers across the touchpad to quickly scroll longer distances; this flicking action is used by most tablet and smartphone touchscreens.ѾѾ SetPoint lets me configure the touchpad's "Pointer Speed". But it really also needs to have a "Pointer Acceleration" or "Enhanced Pointer Precision" setting, implemented as a checkbox or slider option, that dynamically adjusts the sensitivity of the pointer based on its acceleration. The touchpad's pointer currently translates finger movements with more of a proportional linear tracking, but for using this touchpad with applications such as Microsoft Excel, photo/graphics programs, and other software that require a delicate high-precision low-sensitivity finesse of movement, adding a "Pointer Acceleration" setting would give me a nice balance between high-precision low-pointer-sensitivity movements, needed when my finger is moving slowly around cells within a spreadsheet or using the freehand drawing tool of a photo/graphics program, and quicker high-sensitivity movements of the pointer across the screen area for most other kinds of clicking and screen navigation movements. Having an adjustable "Pointer Acceleration" or "Enhanced Pointer Precision" feature would also improve the precision of just tapping to click on links or using the 1-finger-double-tap-n-drag to perform left-click-n-drag operations where I do not want the pointer to slightly shift while I tap. I have my "Pointer Speed" in SetPoint set to one notch faster than the middle setting, so it is not set very fast. But I sometimes have to repeat a 1-finger-double-tap-n-drag to perform left-click-n-drag because the pointer's position slightly shifted off a border that I was wanting to drag or off a letter in a word that I was wanting to drag for highlighting/selection purposes.NOTE: My review does NOT end here, but continues on the 'Comment' section of this review. (go to the 'Comment' section to continue reading :-)
summary: Good for Windows 8 (and also works on Windows 7 and Vista), but it cannot replace my mouse unless two important issues are fixed

reviewText: The is a great double case. It has the hard plastic inner core, and the gel outside. It fits the iPod Touch great. Be aware that the double case makes it harder to connect the cable for charging.

This screen cover fits perfectly to ipad mini, I was surprised there is no bubble at all.However, this ANTIGLARE cover takes away the glass-transparency the original screen was offering.I feel like typing and swiping across the screen with clearly something that in middle. The cover seems to have its own texture that makes the screen look pixelated!Also, the screen is not as bright as before! This cover stands in between as an unpleasant animal skin, it does offer the anti glare effect, but in sacrificing the brightness and contrast.I would not recommend this product if you really love the rich color of your ipad.
summary: Ipad users! If you like the original texture quality of ipad, read this!

reviewText: I like the free 3d modelling software package "Blender 3d" and recently it went to a new rendering system called "cycles" that works better with a Nvidia video card that has CUDA technology.I could do a cycles render with just my CPU but doing so took a very long time.  I got this as I wanted to make renders in a reasonable time and needed as much RAM as I could afford on the card.This card came quickly, kudos to the shipping but a big thumbs down to the delivery mad who left it on my porch as he left it where it could have been blown off  and fall several feet to the porch if I hadn't seen it quickly.It installed quite painlessly, there was a minor issue but it was with my case, not the card's fault and it was easily overcome.I rendered out a full raytraced scene in cycles that took over one hour in CPU mode using the graphics card instead and it rendered beautifully in 7 minutes.The card has a fairly modest power demand and my current PS seems to be handling it easily. I didn't have to go buy a new high wattage card to feed this beast.All in all my only complaint is that right after I ordered it as 135$ and before it arrived it went to 110$. That kind of left me steamed.I hope it has  good longevity, that's the only other thing that could make me feel bad about getting it.
I got this case fits very good doesn't mess with my tech armor hd screen protectors def worth the money
My wife's iPhone looks neatly in this beautiful case. It is not bulky but protects iPhone very well.Fits perfect.
The iPhone 5 does not fit completely inside of armband.  It is not appropriate for bad weather.  Had I known this, I would not have bought it.
summary: Do not buy this for use in the rain.

reviewText: Nothing about this card feels cheap, or second rate. The build quality is exceptional. If you wish to believe the marketing materials, then all the capacitors are solid aluminium core, which are not prone to bulging or leaking. There is a metal shim across the top of the card that prevents excessive flex. Each output is given a protective covering to prevent dust build-up when not in use. Even the packaging is very well done and safe.The heatsink shroud appears to be aluminium instead of the cheap plastic found on many other cards. A substantial heatsink with decently quiet fans keeps the card sufficiently chilled. Furmark pushes the core temperature of this card to ~65C in my stock Antec 902 case. While the heatsink should receive most of the credit for keeping the GPU cool, it should also be noted that the GTX 660 is not at all power-hungry. Power consumption is roughly equal, if not lower than the direct competition (Radeon HD 7850).A GeForce GTX 660, even over-clocked, is not likely to be the best performing card that can be bought in the 200-250 dollar price range. With only a 192 bit memory bus, the card is somewhat bandwidth constrained as well. However, I've had no trouble playing current games at the highest (or just below highest) settings at decent and smooth frame rates. The past few driver releases have given me no trouble whatsoever, and there are several useful rendering and performance features that can be applied using either a global profile, or game specific profiles. Adaptive V-Sync is my personal favourite.Despite being a great product overall, the silicon is still mid-range. You won't be using it to play Battlefield 3 on three 1440p monitors. For single-monitor gaming though, this card should be sufficient for most gamers.

I took the leap and installed Windows 8 Pro. I didn't do a clean install due the complex system I have and the number of programs and hardware that would have to be re-installed. I chose the upgrade from Windows 7, keeping existing settings and files. This process took longer almost 55 minutes. The install asked one question, uninstall MS Security Essentials? The anti-virus is now part of the OS. I did the whole install within Windows 7. Upon completion Metro appeared, when I flipped to my desktop it was as the same original 7. Wallpaper, folders and programs were all there. MS Office, Chrome and Firefox. IE10 is remarkably fast. Plus works great with a mouse.So far I'm extremely pleased, almost high.
summary: The best version of Windows yet.

reviewText: This screen protector is very good for the new Kindle Fire HD . It goes on very easy and does a good job of not distorting the screen. There are no instructions with it but it is pretty straightforward on how to apply it. I would definitely recommend this to people who have a new Kindle Fire and want to protect their screen.

I've had my Kindle Fire for almost 2 weeks now and delayed ordering the screen protectors. They came in on time and application was easy. For the low price, I got the three protectors, a screen cloth, bubble card....all in a small envelope.I didn't get it on perfectly; the circle small open circle that goes around the camera was covered with a tiny bit of plastic. Removing it again to repply was easy, though I had to be careful not to contaminate that side. The 2nd application went much smoother and all the air bubbles are out. The screen protector itself has a soft, smoooth feel to it and doesn't absorb fingerprints!As for being anti-glare, not completely.It reduces it greatly, but strong light nearby can show up on it. Now if I hold it a certain way, it has almost a mirror-like look to it when the screen is OFF. When it is ON, it looks great and the ceiling fan light above me, will show up if I keep it at the right angle.NOTE: During application, the protector covers themselves (those pieces you peel off) might get scratched and all, but that's to keep the protector covered. I saw a few scratches on them, but NOTHING on the protector.Major bonus for price and three protectors!

I ordered this grip along with my black Nikon V1, and I am glad that I did. This grip fits the camera perfectly and there is no "play" at all. Since my other camera is a Nikon DSLR, I immediately appreciated the design of this grip. It is, in my opinion, a must for this Nikon V1 camera which does not have any grip at all.The grip is very well designed. Unlike the Nikon GR-N1000 grip, this grip provides access to the battery chamber and SD slot without removing the grip, and that is a big advantage when you need to replace a battery or a SD card in a hurry. It has a top "groove" on which the middle-finger rests, and the pinky sits comfortably on the grip and does not hang out.The only gripe I have is that the tripod socket below the grip is not in the center, but way to the left. It seems to me that it should not be a problem with a heavy tripod, but if you have a small lightweight table-top tripod, it may create a balancing problem. You may need to take the grip off for using the V1 with a lightweight tripod. Since I mainly purchased the Nikon V1 for shooting videos, handheld and using a heavy full-size tripod, this should not affect me, and hence the 5 stars.Update on 7 December 2012:I tried it with a couple of tripods (a small table-top tripod as well as a full-size tripod), and it did not have any stability issues. The 5 stars are fully justified from my perspective.

I think I was too hard on this recorder in my initial review, so I have added one star and edited my comments to reflect my current appraisal of this machine.I have deducted one star out of five for two drawbacks.  First, the feature most highly touted -- the automatic recording mode suggested by the Voice Tracer name -- has at least one significant problem. While the recorder is making the adjustment -- which takes a few seconds -- it doesn't record anything.  This means you are going to lose a few seconds of a recording.Let's assume, for example, that you want to record a lecture.  You must begin the automatic setting procedure when someone is speaking; you can't take a sample of the quiet room.  If the speaker is someone introducing the main lecturer, you will lose a few seconds of that introduction.If there is no introduction, then you will lose a few seconds of the primary lecture.  In either event, you lose.It is unclear from the included PDF manual if Philips has incorporated Automatic Gain Control into this recorder -- a standard recording-level-setting feature which has been around for years.  At least that technology works on the fly, allowing instant level adjustments according to real-time conditions.You can, however, turn OFF the automatic setting function, instead adjusting the recorder for a particular situation, say recording a conversation or a lecture -- or you can record manually, setting the recording level according to a meter.Other features include a wind filter, noise reduction to help eliminate background noise, timer and voice-activated recording, an alarm clock or appointment reminder function, WMA and MP3 music playback and equalization, and more.The recorder offers a number of sampling rates, from PCM with no compression enabling 6 hours of recording, to LP that runs up to 1,140 hours.  Unfortunately the instructions don't give the frequency responses of these various "speeds", just the sampling rates, from 44.1kHz for PCM to 16kHz for LP.You can also plug in a microSD card for more recording capacity.Two NiMH rechargeable AAA batteries are included (which can be charged in the recorder from your computer using the short USB cable provided), enabling battery life of up to 42 hours of recording using the internal memory or 16 hours using a memory card.The second drawback for which I have deducted one star is the poor-quality built-in speaker.  It introduces a fair amount of distortion into the playback, which I had initially assumed was resident in the recording itself.  Not so -- I connected the recorder to my computer and discovered that the distortion had come from the speaker, not the recording level.So I will give this recorder a provisional thumbs-up, assuming that you use it with a computer or headphones to provide distortion-free playback.PROS:* Attractive design.* Good value for the money.* Stereo mikes built in.* Ample built-in memory storage.* Sufficient battery life.* Rechargeable NiMH batteries included.* Many useful features.CONS:* Automatic recording setting feature cuts out audio for several seconds.* Poor quality built-in speaker.
summary: Decent Digital Voice Recorder with Two Minor Drawbacks

reviewerName: Rexomus "One man with courage makes a majority."
reviewText: The Lorex video baby monitor is simple and easy to use. Right out of the box all you have to do is power on the camera and the monitor and you are instantly viewing a live audio and video feed from the wireless camera. And that maybe as far as some people needed it to function but the unit does come with some very cool extra features and functions, please read below.Features:Live wireless Audio and Color Video feed of any room you place the wireless transmitter/camera.Monitor up to 4 cameras at once (video only) on a single monitorView camera feed from anywhere via internet SkypeNight Vision equipped Camera senor and infrared light source (not light needed to view camera feed)Wireless range up to 100 feetCamera comes enabled with two-way audio between video monitor and cameraCamera equipped with regular night light to help kids sleep at nightCamera also can play a limited selection of factory stored music; i.e: Brahms and MozartMusic can be activated from play button on monitorUnit can be easily used as audio monitor onlyScan mode automatically activates monitor once desired audio level is detectedMonitor displays room temperature, audio level, signal strength, date and time.The wireless range is great from one end of the house to the other. The monitor also comes with an extendable antenna that neatly hides away on the top of the device and is easily released and extended at the push of a button.The monitor can be switched to scan mode which sets the camera's microphone to continuously monitor the audio feed from the wireless camera. Once the audio reaches a certain level the monitor will automatically turn on showing the viewer what is happening in view of the camera. This is a great feature allowing the user to turn off the monitor screen at night so you can sleep soundly without having a bright screen on all night.The system can also be switched to audio only to conserve batteries.No light is needed to still have a great view of the room because the camera is equipped with a night vision sensor and infrared light source. The night vision is so good it's hard to tell the difference between the room day or night.I highly recommend the Lorex Wireless Video Baby Monitor. It is so easy to use and has many great features at an affordable price.

Of the two in the package, one had streak marks and a black speck on the adhesive side; the other created annoying bubbles that would not go away regardless of how I applied it or wiped it.  They would disappear and come right back.  What a waste of time.  My understanding is that they are more nuisance than protection

My old second generation Shuffle has served me well and still works great.  I have gotten so much more than my money's worth out of it over the years.  I had to figure out a good reason to get another one.  And I had to get another purple one, because, well, I'm just addicted to this in purple.So my reason for getting a second identical one is this.  I can now have one in my purse, with my music on it, and it goes to the gym and beach with me, and the second one is next to my bed, with my audio books on it, for listening to at bedtime.  I usually fall asleep with this.It has been updated with Siri, and will talk to me, but I don't need or use that feature. This is tiny and cute and lightweight.  It has a good sturdy clip to attach to my clothes.I've considered getting a Nano, but it's just so big compared to this.  Sometimes smaller is better.  And it's so simple and the controls are so easy to use on the Shuffle.  I don't need to look at it to change songs or turn it on or off, or change the volume.The new colors are nice, and that slate color almost won me over to it.  A couple more gigs would have been nice but still, 2 gigs is enough.I use this with my Bose earbudsBose MIE2i Mobile Headsetand the sound is excellent.After the simplicity and tiny size of this, as well as the way this clips to any part of my clothing, I couldn't bring myself to switch to a Nano or Touch.  This does exactly what I want it to do in a simple easy way.  The touch is too complicated to work the controls on after being so used to this.  One big button for both the volume and changing songs, and I don't even have to look at it to work it.  What could be better than that?I don't need the Siri voiceover feature on this.  I already know the names of the songs as I hear them and can switch rapidly from song to song on this.It's perfect.  And it's smaller, and for me, that's better.

All that I can find with the new release is the updated colors, the rest looks the same. This is still 4th generation Apple iPod Shuffle (from wikipedia, this new color refresh is still under 4th generation category).This product is small, actually very small. I know you can use your iPhones or Androids and even get more storage space than this, but shuffle has a different target of users, mostly for active and on the go users. This is perfect for exercising, running, walking, etc. Just clip it to your shirt and your ready to go.If your the type of user who wants to put all your mp3s to your mp3 player, then you might want to find a different player thas has larger capacity , as this one has only 2gb of space. You should still be able to put hundreds of songs here especially if your songs bitrate compression is not very high.Some of the basic functionalities:Shuffle switchLeft - shuffle musicMiddle - play in orderRight - turn offVoiceOver buttonSingle click - hear current track and artistSingle click and hold - hear playlist menu.Double click - hear battery statusPROS:- Tiny (this can also be a con, in a way like since it's tiny, it's also easy to lose or misplace)- 15hr play time- Colors refreshed for the 2012 release model- Physical buttons- High quality anodized aluminumCONS:- Expensive (In my opinion, $49 for 2gb is expensive)- No option for a higher storage capacityWhat you get in the box:- iPod shuffle- Apple Earphones- iPod shuffle USB Cable- Quick Start guideI'm highly recommending iPod shuffle. But do your research first if you want this kind of mp3 player..

I've been waiting for this upgrade for 2 years. I had bought the 3G Touch about 2 months before the release of the 4G so I didn't experience the 4G. So going from the 3G to the 5G Touch was amazing! I love the camera. I also like that it is lighter than the previous generations; you barely feel it in your hand. Plus the faster processor and retina display are awesome. I have the blue one and I like the color because it's more of a turquoise. I love the Touch because it's the portable little computer; you can check your email and look on the web, listen to music, watch videos, play games all on this small handheld device! I highly recommend the 5G iPod Touch!
I loved mine so much that I bought a set of them for my daughter-in-law and she also liked them very much, said it was faster using that then the cable that came with our Kindles.

reviewText: Based on the overwhelming number of very positive reviews, I ordered this case.  Even when you allow for the fact that it is dirt cheap, there is a flaw (at least with the one I received) that makes it useless.  The problem I've had, and it happens under all sorts of conditions (e.g., on my table and not being moved), is that the case apppears that it is fully closed (and the screen turns off), but at some point the case opens up as a result of the non-secure clasp and as a result the screen turns back on and then the battery drains.  The fact that I have mhy Kindle HD's screen timeout set to "never" means that when the screen comes on, it stays on until the battery is fuly drained.  I will look for a case that allows me to feel confident that when I close the case (and the sceen turns off) that the case will remain closed. I hate to give such a poor review (you will note from my other reviews that I rarely do so), but I wanted folks to know my experience.
summary: Sorry to rain on the parade - but this case has a major flaw

reviewText: I love Samsung. My wife and I both have Samsung phones and I order the Samsung Smart TV's all the time for clients that want to use Skype. My dad purchased the 500T for my mother for Christmas to go along with her new Samsung Galaxy Note II (which she loves and works great). And I was looking forward to setting it up it because I was likely going to purchase the 700T for myself in January.When I opened the first box I noticed that the gray tape had already been cut open. And when I turned it on it was in the middle of a recovery. I went ahead and tried to configure it anyway. It wouldn't take updates and it would fail on installations. We contacted Amazon and they sent a new one out the next day. Amazon was great about it.The second one was sealed properly and looked perfect. I turned it on and set it up and was very impressed. Ran all the Samsung and Windows updates and then suddenly the touchscreen stopped working. The pen worked. But no touch. Did a complete rebuild of the OS and it resulted in the same problem. No touch screen.This device is not ready for prime time. I usually tell clients to stay away from 1st generation devices and I should have taken my own advice. Do not buy.
summary: Returned Two Of Them - Do Not Buy

I am a proud owner of the Pentax K-5 and very happy with everything about it.  I just received the Pentax K-5 II and tested it out.  I tried it in a low light situation and the images are better.  In addition, the LCD screen on the back of the camera is much better and I can better determine if the image is tack sharp or not.  I would highly recommend to spend the extra amount and go for the K-5 II instead of the K-5 at a discount.  PS - I believe Pentax is giving Canon and Nikon a run for their money.  My advice would be to buy the body only and then invest in a good prime lens.  The one to have is the 31mm.  It is unbelievably sharp!  I have the 100mm micro and the 55mm lenses.  Both very good but, the 31mm is in a league all to itself.  I hope this review helps.

Pros:Easy to use point-and-shoot cameraFocus after the fact, focus stackingSee cool image effects related to depthCons:Offers absolutely minimal camera featuresA final 2D output image is 1024x1024 - approximately 1.2 megapixelNo video capabilityNo easy way to just SAVE a JPG (But exporting to Facebook is easy?  What?!)The coolest feature is, obviously, being able to focus after the fact.  The sensitivity is very poor, so that rules out action shots, and therefore the time saved from not having to focus really isn't relevant.  Regardless of the post-capture focusing, the camera still does need to perform a pre-capture coarse focus so that the focal depth is at least reasonably close to the subject.  If it matters to you, it's pretty quick.If you want to imagine what the camera is really capturing, it is analogous to taking many identical pictures while changing your manual focus - this camera does it all simultaneously.  By analyzing what is blurry or focused in each image, the software is able to determine how far away each object is, which allows for rudimentary 3D-space computation, such as the perspective shift and depth-based image effects.The zoom feature is nearly impossible to use - I haven't figured out the trick to get the touchscreen to handle it reliably.The PC software is quite oversimplified, but it lets you fiddle with focus and various depth-related filters.  While these filters definitely can improve your photo, it's far from the kind of filtering you can get even from cheap Photoshop knock offs.  And then, it makes it easy to post to Facebook, but I can't find any kind of "save this picture" menu item.  It seems easier to capture a screenshot.After all of the above, your final Lytro pictures are the low-quality equivalent of photos taken with any other camera.If the camera is good for anything, it would be its ability to perform focus stacking, where multiple focal depths are combined to form an image that is not just perfectly focused, but focused on everything in the scene simultaneously - something that is impossible to do optically.  This is almost never relevant; the quality is too low for professional photographers, but perhaps people who need the macro feature would be able to get everything in the shot fully focused.

The one review stated that Amazon correctly lists it as XP-compatible.  The Amazon product page includes a table that says it is XP compatible. reviewText: UPDATE: My camera has oil spots on the sensor. I sent it back to Nikon and it is taking for ever for them to clean or fix the issue. I sent it to them 2 weeks ago and they finally acknowledged that they received it 7 days later! They would not disclose what was wrong and only send back a note saying "THERE ARE OIL SPOTS AND IT IS COMPLIMENTARY SERVICE" mind you, I have only had it for six weeks, changed the lens once and, I am meticulous with my gear. The fact that I will be put out with a camera for close to 30 days is a bit ridiculous. They should refund or send a new camera. It's BS after spending $2,500.00! That being said it was amazing up until the oil spots.I was a D7000 user and was very satisfied until the D600. I can't say enough great things about this camera. It is just what I needed since I started getting commercial work. If you are a D7000 user you will be able to navigate this easily. I don't really recommend this camera if you are just shooting and posting to the internet. The D7000 is more than sufficient. At the end of the day it's still about the lens quality. Remember that is you use the D600 you will have to start getting better FX lenses which are much more expensive than DX. Although you can use your DX lenses on the D6000. I would say if you could afford it I would go for it.Nikon D600 24.3 MP CMOS FX-Format Digital SLR Camera (Body Only)

I upgraded from a D7000, which I purchased in January 2011. This camera is an easy transition from the D7000 as the controls are very similar, as is the weight, and the grip. There is no need for me to speak about the technical aspects as they work as they are suppose too.  I did not and will not test anything. If the features do not work as they are meant to work then I will send it back.  However, this camera is not showing any signs of having to be returned.****** 10/1/2012: 14bit depth Problem.Following the instructions on page 94 in the D600 manual, I tried to set the "bit depth" to 14. I had the camera set to "Aperture-Priority" when I tried to enable this feature. No matter how I tried the 12bit remained.A fellow Nikonian walked me through the procedure as he followed the same on his D600. We both took 5 pictures and his image's metadata showed the chosen "bit depth", while all of mine were "12 bit".I received this camera on 9/19 from Amazon and I am returning for a replacement. Other than this , the D600 is a very good camera.

My go to headphones are Sennheiser HD 595s for when I'm by the computer and Westone UM2s for working out and traveling.  While the Sony MDRX8600 are on-ear the former are over-the-ear and in-ear.  Both the 595s and UM2s are recommended; after countless hours of listening to music and audio in general, they have proven their worth.  But I was looking for something new to experiment with and was happy to try out these Sony headphones.  I devoted about half the day to listening to music and watching movies/shows and have to say that I did not come away impressed.  First off, aesthetically, the pictures on amazon are not representative of the actual headphones, which are much more muted and bland compared to the advertising shots you'll see.  Size wise, they aren't too big, although I was not comfortable with their fit.  They seemed big for my head in their smallest/tightest position, while the 595s I have to actually adjust to my head's size.  Furthermore, after several hours of using these headphones, with minor breaks, my ears began to noticeably suffer from the pressure of the headphones and I had to switch to the Sennheisers which have never given me such a problem.  Sound quality wise, there is no comparison with the 595s (unfortunately they are no longer available so for those interested, go for the new 598s).  But that's not a fair comparison as the Sennheiser headphones cost twice as much.  If I had to run errands or needed to use a pair of headphones for an hour or less, these would be fine, but why set such limits on a 100 dollar pair of headphones?  Personally, I don't think they're worth it and I'd recommend investing in something else at this price point.

reviewText: This iHome speaker/lamp measures 10-1/8 inches tall and 4-3/16 inches across at the base. It consists of a sealed 4-watt LED light and a downward firing speaker. Control buttons are sparse. At the back, there is a 5V DC power socket, a 3.5mm mini-plug socket, and an OFF/ON switch for the speaker. A 100-240 VAC to 5V DC adapter is included. At the front is a touch-sensitive lamp button. A gentle tap turns the LED lamp on or off. Holding down the button dims or brightens the lamp. At low level, the lamp can be used as a night-light. At maximum output, the lamp is bright enough to illuminate a desk or a corner of a room.The downward firing speaker sounds good. It is on par with most of the mp3 speakers on the market. The output is loud enough for personal use. There is no volume control. The sound output must be adjusted at the mp3 player. I found that inconvenient. I took off one star for that. Connection to a mp3 player is made by a 3.5 mm male to male mini-plug cable (included). There is no dock for an iPOD. All in all, this iHome speaker/lamp is compact, functional, and esthetically pleasing.  It is a good product.Note: The owner's manual is wrong regarding how to operate the dimmer. It states: "The light is turned on by tapping the touch sensitive dimmer. Keep tapping until the light reaches the desired brightness." Tapping the dimmer will only toggle ON and OFF. To dim or brighten, one must hold down the button.

The typed instructions are by some Chinese person who doesn't speak fluent English--in other words, abysmal. The instructions have drawings which is the only way we figured out how to get the iPad Mini into the case. I give this case only 3 stars, being it is *VERY* HEAVY. The case + iPad Mini weighs double the weight of the iPad Mini itself. It feels as heavy (or heavier) than regular (bigger) iPads.In case you were wondering if this case has any sort of screen cover, it doesn't. (I hate screen covers, and don't want a screen cover). This case is NOT be particularly appropriate for kids, since the case leaves the screen and orifices open to the elements--which for a rational and careful adult, is fine.My favorite product line is Amzer's Silicone Skin Jelly Cover/Case, which when becomes available for the iPad Mini, I'll replace the Amzer for this case, and donate this i-Blason case to the Salvation Army--they'll re-home it.This case does give a relatively good grip, although not as good as the Amzer mentioned above. At least the iPad Mini can't slip out of my hands til then. Not being able to get one's favorite case is part of being an early adopter--it goes with the territory.-----14 Feb 2013 UPDATEOver time, this case was a hassle and a headache. The on/off upper-right button was hard to find. The bottom-center button was hard to find. I did go ahead and get theAmzer Soft Silicone Jelly Skin Fit Case Cover for Apple iPad Mini - Green (AMZ94586), which I much prefer. I use several of this Anzer silicone product-line (one for each device), and see no reason to not use it the iPad Mini.I have to warn you, once the i-Blason case is on the iPad Mini, it's nearly impossible to remove--we had a heck of a time getting it off the iPad Mini (my hubbie cut himself with a letter-opener, where we finally pried the case open using three miniature screwdrivers simultaneously).A suede zipper case that fits the iPad Mini with either this i-Blason or the Amzer, after looking over several hundred case descriptions is (drum roll):Green Trim SumacLife Micro Suede Protective Sleeve Cover with Neoprene Bubble Padding for Motorola Droid Xyboard 8.2 inch Android Tablet(in lots of different colors). The SumacLife is about 1/2" bigger across and 1/2" bigger down, and plenty thick.For a stand, I use theArkon Portable Fold-Up Stand for Apple iPad, Galaxy Tab, Kindle Fire, Playbook, Xoom, Toshiba, Acer, Nook and Other Tablets (IPM-TAB1). Now I'm finally set.
web camera for Mac, iPad and iPhone - that IS stated but NOT where it belongs, in the Title for the unit. I expect more accuracy from Logitech. Beware Non-mac folks.
summary: Not clearly stated it is only for Apple. I am a Droid Guy

reviewText: OVERALL: I got this laptop for a friend that needed a portable computer for regular usage (internet, Word, Excel).  It is fine for those purposes but you should not get it if you are doing heavy processing or memory-intensive tasks.FEW COMMENTS: You may need a faster processor and more RAM for more intensive work.  For regular daily usage this laptop is affordable and a decent option.  I'm still not sold on Windows 8.  I have a feeling that older folks or less computer-savvy people will not appreciate the new operating system.  I have grown up on computers and worked in IT but it took me an hour or so to get used to the different movements back and forth between screens.  I don't think either of my parents would have such patience.  Battery life holds up pretty well with the first few uses---much longer than my current laptop.  Glad it has a USB 3.0 port but only 2 total (one 3.0 and one 2.0) seems a little bit on the low end.  Comes with a webcam but only 1.3MP.NOTE: There is NO DVD/CD player.  You will have to purchase a separate USB drive if you want to install programs or hope to watch movies from a DVD/CD.
summary: not high end but decent for regular usage

reviewText: So I received this case today and I was very excited because of all the positive reviews that it got. I took it out of the package and opened it up and immediately noticed that the inside of the case was all morphed. It looks like whoever made this case pressed their fingers in the back of the front and there are deep indents that are crater like. Also, I put the iPad mini in the case and it didn't snap in right away and even when it did it was VERY loose. So much that I am worried the mini might fall out.Also, I tried the Smart Cover on / off feature that is built in and I could not get it to work for the life of me. This was very disappointing.Overall I can't believe the number of positive reviews for this case as it is very cheap and doesn't seem like it was well designed. I hope the company is not leaving these positive reviews themselves as people like me that order the case are misled and this is not right.
summary: Even the low price doesn't justify this case.

reviewText: I purchased this model a couple of weeks ago. I have purchased four Asus netbooks since 2007 and I still have all but the first one I bought (which was still running fine but had become obsolete in many ways, so I donated it).  So as you can tell, I was a big fan of Asus netbooks.  While the netbook era seems to have ended, I still wanted something that was a lot like a netbook: Highly portable, lightweight, sufficiently powerful to do most anything I need to do on a laptop, highly affordable, and durable enough to be taken on airplanes, to coffee shops, or wherever.This new Asus does the trick!Positives:First of all, at approximately $500, you are going to have difficulty finding this overall set of features and performance in a very small footprint laptop - period.  Now if you want to spend $1000 or more, you will get a more upscale set of components elsewhere (including the Asus Zenbook offerings). The question is whether you need or will even notice the better performance. But assuming you like the notion of a modest, $500 investment, the Q200E is very worthy of consideration.The upsides of the Q200E: Very thin profile, weighs less than 3 lbs, nicely responsive 11.6 inch touch screen, runs Windows 8 and applications swiftly, starts up fast (like most of the "ultrabooks"), solidly built with an aluminum case, very good keyboard - especially for its size, attractive design (looks more expensive than it is), 3 USB ports (1 is 3.0), excellent sound from the speakers (surprisingly, the best I've heard - including from larger, more expensive laptops), a highly portable power adapter (no "brick") and a 500 GB hard drive that's more than sufficient.The downsides: The Intel i3 processor (1.8 GHz) is fast enough for anything I might do on this little computer, but folks who have very intensive computing needs will want a higher end, faster processor.  Again, for my needs, I haven't experienced any limitations, but I'm not running computer aided design software or creating animation...  Also, this unit comes with 4 GB RAM, which is not upgradeable.  Would you need more? I don't, but if you think you will, you need a higher end laptop with more RAM or at least expansion capability.  As for the screen, it is supposedly HD and I would describe it as "decent," it is simply not the kind of ultra HD screen you will get on a $1500 laptop.  But then, if you want that level of resolution, you might also want a 13" screen or larger so you can really enjoy the advantages. I find that the 11.6" screen, while an upgrade for me personally from the 9 or 10 inch netbook screens, is still a bit smallish in terms of either serious movie watching or working for more than a few hours at a stretch. The battery life is unfortunately not in the realm of the little Asus netbooks with 6-cell batteries -- this unit has a 2-cell Lithium battery that is good only for 3 to 4 hours. It's also not easy to change it without unscrewing about 10 screws, so this unit will not provide those 6 or 7 hour marathons like the aforementioned netbooks. (If Asus were to come out with a replacement 4-cell battery for this unit, it would be a major upgrade! I'm going to keep my fingers crossed). Finally, I noted that some reviewers commented about the fan running frequently. I can tell you here and now that first of all, once I completed all of the Asus software updates, the fan seemed to run much less often. But regardless, the fan is very quiet. Unless you are working in a sound isolation chamber and are very distractable, believe me -- fan noise is not going to be an issue for you.The verdict: If you are comparing the Q200E to l1 or 13 inch laptops that cost $1000-$1500, you will find it lacking. No surprise!  However, if you are not a "super user" and evaluate this unit in terms of its $500 price tag, you will be pleased. I give it 4.5 stars!----------------------------------------------REVISED REVIEW -- 2 WEEKS LATER----------------------------------------------Well, I am revisiting this review because about 2 weeks after my original review (and only a month into owning this Asus), the hard drive failed. Up to that point, this little computer worked great -- just as I described above.  But one day, upon being shut down, the hard drive made some funny clicking noises.  I thought it was strange but paid no heed until the next day, when I tried to power it back on.  I could get only the system setup (Bios) screen, and nothing would work from there. Various tests returned messages about System Failure etc.  I called Asus technical support, and spent 35 minutes wasting my time with the protocol, only for the tech to conclude what I knew: the hard drive had failed.  He directed me back to BestBuy.  The technical guy at BestBuy examined the computer to make sure I hadn't tampered with it and he booted it up and checked it out.  Same conclusion.  Because it was so new, they actually offered me to exchange for a new one, or issue a refund.  My confidence in Asus a bit shaken, I took the refund.As a result of my experience, I'm knocking off a star.  But I'm not giving an even lower rating because every brand does experience a failure rate. The BestBuy tech told me that it was the first Asus of this type to come back; he noted another brand that he saw returned frequently for failed hard drives (I won't repeat the brand here, since this is basically hearsay).  He noted that his experience so far had been that this model Asus (and Asus in general) are quite reliable, but as he pointed out, if they make 100,000 of them and there's a 1% failure rate, that's still a 1000 defective units....So it might still be worth a try, despite my experience. This Asus seemed very solidly built and has a great form factor. It's too bad this happened but you might have better luck.  (I decided to go with a higher end Sony Vaio S series 13.3", which was twice the price, but ultimately had some other features I wanted and stronger performance...so far so good with the Sony Vaio).
summary: Very solid, all around travel companion; great value -- REVISED REVIEW
