reviewText: This is only the third monitor that I have ever owned.  The first was a fugly Compaqyello-grey CRT POS.  The second was an old TN, 1440x900, fluorescent-backlit, made byHANNS-G.  I thought the latter had a pretty good picture.  I used it to watch movies,and play games such as Bad Company 2 and Skyrim.  For quite a while, I had beenpondering the thought of upgrading to 1920x1080.  I was worried that my frameratewould drop in these games while at 1080p, due to my older hardware.  Three weeks ago,I decided to pull the trigger anyway.Needless to say, in going from TN to IPS, 1440x900 to 1920x1080, and fluorescent toLED all in a single upgrade...I had high expectations.  Unfortunately, three days afterreceiving this monitor, my "older hardware" mysteriously fried itself...and I have yetto receive my shiny new Processor/Mobo/Ram/etc.  For the short duration I was able toplay Skyrim, I was awed by the picture quality.  To my eyes, my old monitor now looksas if a color-blind three-year-old were scribbling on an unevenly painted wall withoff-brand crayons (I am seriously not exaggerating here).  And to my surprise, myframerate in a majority of the games I play actually WENT UP (GPU taking load off ofthe processor due to higher resolution?).There are only two things that I could possibly mention as cons...one of them being the"IPS glow" that is characteristic of ALL IPS monitors.  The other is that, given a fewmore of these panels, I could probably build a working model of Archimedes' death rayand use it to fry squirrels from a mile off...yeah, anyway, they are highly reflective.Expectations?  Exceeded.  Bravo, Dell...you finally did something good for humanity.

Owning Tv's for several years Vizio is the perfect balance of Cost/Price. Picture quality is Amazing and having internet apps where you can watch youtube videos and connect this tv with Facebook and other web applications is great. For $999 you will NOT find a better TV, purchase and enjoy!

Spent a couple of hours online with an HP tech in India (surprise!) to get the updated video driver for the dual monitor thing to work and spent a couple of hours in Staples arguing about the DVI-I and DVI-D outputs on the computer (finally found one on the shelf and SHOWED them what I was talking about). The computer is great, really--and the price is great, too. I'm still having a little trouble with the dual monitors in that on startup sometimes everything's fine and sometimes it only sees one of the monitors. And in Windows 8, you have to sign-in so I have to sign in to an invisible screen--then hit the Windows key and press "P" at the same time to get the second monitor to work.  This has happened a few times, most recently after a Windows Update. If you turn both monitors on first, it's usually okay. I kind of like the dual monitor thing--but if you don't need it, then the computer is an easy 5-star. If you do need it, it's a 3.5 to 4. Windows 8 is okay after you get used to it--don't be afraid of it. I didn't like the absence of actual CD's for booting up if there's a problem, but making my own was fairly easy and straight-forward. Also didn't like the computer forcing me to use Windows 8 "apps" but you can get around that easily enough. Learning curve? 3 days.
summary: As Usual, Needs a bit of tweaking - otherwise GREAT!

reviewText: Over the course of the past 2 years; we've replaced all of our TV's with those manufactured by Vizio. Our first HDTV was a Samsung 40" that we purchased in 2007. Recently, a problem developed in one of the circuit boards, rendering the picture unwatchable. Since new TV's have come down so much in price; it wasn't worth spending the money to fix it. I've been so pleased with the performance of our other Vizio TV's, that I decided to purchase this one. Our Samsung fit into a cabinet that we wanted to use for our new Vizio, and we found that since the actual size of the TV is about the same as the Samsung; it fits into the cabinet perfectly. We also get an additional 2" of screen, which makes a difference. Setting up this TV is a breeze, and to say that I'm satisfied with its performance would be an understatement. What I especially like is the ability to watch football games without having to see a blur when the players are running down the field. I'm no expert when it comes to technology, but I think that this has something to do with the increased refresh rate over older model TV's. All I know is that the picture is magnificent and crystal clear, the speakers are decent(I'll be connecting my own), and the Internet Apps are out of this world. It takes just a few minutes to set up a wireless Internet connection, and once done: you have access to an endless array of movies, TV shows and apps from many different sources. I'm so impressed with this TV that I have nothing negative to say about it. It has everything that I was looking for, was easy to set up, and works flawlessly. I couldn't ask for anything more.
summary: VIZIO is setting a new standard for excellence at a bargain price

reviewText: This is an external drive to compliment your iPads, Android tablets or smartphone.  The biggest bragging right? Wireless.  You can fill it up with all your songs, pictures and movies, as well as documents and your limited device space will be almost limitless.  This unit came with a built-in 320G hard drive.  You can have up to a 2 TB of memory by  replacing the drive, only requires removing 4 small screws at the bottom. If that is what you want, you can save by getting thePatriot Memory Gauntlet Node Wireless Hard-drive Enclosure (PCGTW25S)without the built-in drive.The unit is equipped with USB 3.0 for direct connection (a USB 3.0 cable is included as well as a DC wall socket adapter for charging) which is amazingly fast provided you already have a device equipped with USB 3.0.  The lithium-ion internal battery is estimated to last up to 5 hours, but my actual experience playing media around 3 and a half to four hours.  You can check the battery status by pressing the button on the side.  Four tiny LEDs indicate how much juice is left; each light representing 25% of the capacity.Pros:- Can beef up your mobile devices memory capacity up to 2TB- Wireless- Fast.  Media play almost instantaneously.- works great for movies, pictures and songs.- It can act as a hotspot for multiple devices.  Useful when you are away from home.Cons:- Interface is a bit clunky- Movies and pictures are reduced in resolution.  My pictures don't rotate.Sample item was provided by the distributor for this review.

There isn't a thing wrong with this case, functionally.  It will protect the iPad inside and function in the manner for which it was designed. It's not going to come apart. The cover folds well and the case works fine in both stand positions.  Sleep/wake work. Magnets hold the cover in place when it is folded back (like a book). I would say it is worth the $15 I paid for it.  I think the manufacturing used give it a bit of style, compared to a more refined look that some $35+ cases give.I must be state, however, that I won't be using this case. Reason: it is a bit too heavy, IMO. As soon as I put my iPad mini in this case I noticed hand/finger fatigue. Unfortunate for me.  On my scale it weighs 138g / 4.87 oz.  I need it to weigh under 4 oz.  After all, the reason I bought an iPad mini (I have an iPad 3 too) is because I want a lighter device to hold for long periods of time. This case prevents that.Others may and do feel differently on the matter.  IMO, the main reason for the mini is because you want portable, and that means light and small.  If a case adds too much bulk, then it defeats the purpose (for me).  Sure, I can see some putting a mini into a Otterbox or other style of heavy duty protective case so the kids can abuse it, but that is not what I'm after.  I don't beat my stuff up.

I recently purchased an EVGA GTX 660 after reading good reviews about it.  I was very impressed with the results, and noticed a massive improvement over my PNY GTX 550 Ti 1GB.  I used my GTX 550 Ti for a build I was working on, and was disappointed with the temps I was reaching and the inability to play newer games on higher settings.  I enjoy tinkering with stuff a bit and most of the reviews I've read show the new Kepler powered GTX 650 ti is a pretty capable card, so I figured why not give it a shot.First I will point out, this card uses way less power than the Fermi based GTX 550 ti.  About 40W less power, which is significant considering theirs also a big boost in performance.  Another key advantage is this card is much smaller, about 2.5 inches less in length.  It's surprising because the next step up in the GTX 600 series is the 660, and that card is about 2 inches longer than the 550 ti, or nearly 4 inches longer than the 650 ti.  This makes the 650 ti ideal for those using small cases as it's small, cool, and uses little power (great for small PSU's in ITX setups).  I am using a Silverstone SG04 case with a front mounted radiator for the CPU cooler, so I was limited to cards less than 8 inches long for my case, the 650 ti fit with plenty of room to spare.  I think the other advantage this offers is it keeps the rest of the case fairly cool too as air flow is less restricted.I figured rather than talking about differences I noticed, I'd just run a 3D Passmark 11 and let the results speak for themselves.Setup:Silverstone SG04 mATX CaseSilverstone ST50F 500W PSUAsus P8Z77-IIntel Xeon E3 1230 v2Intel Liquid Thermal SolutionG.SKILL 2x8 (16GB) Ares DDR3 1600MHz RAMCrucial M4 SSD 64GB1st Test: PNY GTX 550 Ti 1GB2nd Test EVGA GTX 650 Ti 2GB SSCGTX 550 Ti Scores:E4582 / P2773 / X854GTX 650 Ti:E8067 / P5282 / X1603Frame rates were nearly double vs the 550 ti if not more in every benchmark test on 3D Mark 11.  The other important thing to note is that the EVGA GTX 550 Ti 2GB is still about $160.  If you're upgrading from a 550ti or 450 GTS, I think this card is definitely worth the price though I would recommend going with the GTX 660 if you can fit it, because that is a significant step up from the 650 ti for only $50 more.  The 650 ti walks all over the 550 ti, so if you're planning on buying the 550 ti don't even bother.Pros:FasterCoolerLess PowerSmallerCons:The GTX 650 Ti 2GB SSC is kinda pricy, AMD makes cards nearly as good for quite a bit cheaper, but they're also very large and use a lot of power.

great value and wooks great VERY EFFICENT ITS GREAT FOR THE MOTHER BOARD ASUS77 I INSTALLED. I would recommend this to every one who cant spend a lot for a vedio card but still need a no glitch gameing card.

It took a while but I was fortunate that someone returned one of these to Amazon and I was able to pick it up for less than the advertised retail cost. I have been sitting in front of computers for near on four decades now. Spent plenty of time using Windows machines at work and even had some early windows 'ultraportables' such as the Sharp Muramasa. For home use, I went with AAPL at the launch of OSX more than a decade ago and have a house full of those machines, both desktop and laptop. This Chromebook just amazes me with that history.This thing is1. amazingly affordable. 2. amazingly light 3. amazingly energy efficient 4. amazingly high performing. What you need to understand about this machine is that performance is fully a function of your internet connection speed. Below 10Mb/s it gets a little laggy. With a wifi signal above 10Mb/S it works like a champ. My other laptop is a 15" MPB with a processor rated at about double the speed of this machine and more RAM but can you tell a difference at internet speeds above 10Mb/s? No. Would I rather take this machine with me when traveling and have full access to every web site that I normally access via laptops and desktops in my home? Yes absolutely. Should you get one of these? Yes. Sure, if you spend a significant amount of time on the machine you now have using some local software program, this is not the machine for you. If you, on the other hand spend the majority of your time in a web browser. You want one of these. Just don't be an a$$ and pay more than what GOOG or AMZN is selling them for new from some scalper. Get one when you can get one for 250 or less.

The pocket for the cable is really handy.If this holds up as well as it looks like it should, this is the perfect sleeve for the iPad Mini.

reviewText: If you want a nice keyboard for your iPad this one works well, holds the iPad securely and the programmed keys are handy.  One the other hand, if you are looking for a cover for transporting your iPad safely and using the automatic turn on and off feature, keep looking.  The magnet that attaches the keyboard to the iPad is not strong enough.  Every time I open the keyboard cover to start the iPad it comes loose from the iPad.  Hang on, or you may drop both of them.  Now that I have this thing, and having spent $100, I am still looking for a cover to protect during transport.

I just received mine, on Blue, by the way is not an electric blue but a softer one, but fancy still.Depending on your taste, let's say your EQ preset are more Rock than Vocals. This is a rock solid. This means high frequencies are not that crisp but the rest is just Epic. The bass, the bass... Oh my!!! the bass. Just played [...](Levels by avicii), Mind blown... literally, my head is vibrating still by this powerful headset.I owned the Sennheiser HD205 and the high frequencies are more clear, like a 10%. But compared to the bass and comfort, Bomboras are the winner by far.Also the memory foam is sweet, just like Bose does.I highly recommend it, the best price/benefit I could find. I gave them a try because J5s are the best earbuds I have tried and Bomboras are now the best headsets I have tried too.

reviewText: Marware continues to make fantastic products. Sturdy, protective, easy to use. I purchased this case because it will rotate my Fire horizontal or vertical, a great, easy to use feature.

I was looking for a case for my Kindle Fire and this one looked like a good choice. The reviews are favorable.The Marware Case arrived in an environmentally friendly Green packaging. Easy to open, and biodegradable. Inside the case was protected. The case itself feels hefty. Directions for installing the Kindle into the case were explicit except for one tiny item. You must make sure to slide the Kindle where the charging side is to the right. There is an open space on the case so the charging side is apparent. I slid the other side into the hard shell, and it was very difficult to remove the Kindle to change sides. The hard shell is just that and it took some strength to remove the Kindle. Once the Right side of the Kindle is in place, push down the left side into the hard shell until you hear it click. The Kindle is very secure! The directions for moving the Kindle to a vertical or horizontal view are explicit and easy. These features are excellent! There are small 'feet' that fit into the inner shell to secure the Kindle in the exact position you favor. The leather is well padded and quite attractive. There is an elastic strap to keep the cover closed. Like all good cases, this case turns the Kindle on when the cover is opened and turns the Kindle off when the cover is closed. There is also a small handle to carry the Kindle if needed.This case is an attractive, easy to use case. Including the hint to place the Kindle charger side down to the instructions would be helpful.Highly Recommended.  prisrob 11-27-12Marware Vibe Case Cover with Stand for Kindle Fire, RedKindle Fire Lightweight MicroShell Folio Case Cover by Marware, White
This tablet is fast, has plenty of memory, is easy to customize, runs android jellybean, and generally makes life much easier/smoother!  I love this tablet =)

This is among the best bluetooth keyboard cases available for the ipad mini today -- It works right out of the box and the case is wonderful -- The keyboard can be lifted out so that you can lighten the case when you don't need to type -- Only complaint is with the dye used on the leather -- The kickstand left a small black line on my nice white leather furniture --

Looking to put your new Google Nexus in a cover worthy of its caliber, then you may want to invest in the Supcase Ultra Slip Fit Multi-angles Leaver Cover Case. This sleek cover fits just right for your Google Nexus. Not only does it fit the device, but it gives you the option of fitting your Nexus up right as if you had your very own personal PC.  The cover is as nice looking as it is versatile and it should fit comfortably with your Google Nexus 10.
summary: A Great Cover For A Terrific Device

reviewText: This is a great external card reader that I have used on three different computers. Although most  people might ask why an external card reader is needed anymore, most cameras or phones require specific programs to be loaded before they can be used. With this any card can be managed through the file manager on the computer.Pros18 different sized memory cardsSmall compact size allows for easy travelIncredible priceConsOne more thing to have to remember to pack on trips but if you don't have a card reader built in you should get this.

I know that this is only $10.  I realize that you get what you pay for.  This thing is pretty much all plastic which is good because it makes it lightweight but if you have a lighter weight camera like a go pro you might have an issue with there not being enough weight to keep the camera steady.  I would opt for a metal one if I had it to do again.  Also, I am using this with a gopro camera and the gopro camera tripod mount.  The threads on this handle are a little too long for the gopro adapter so that the camera won't really tighten down. I fixed this by putting a large washer between the gopro tripod mount and the handle base.There are plenty of adjustments for this and I do think it is worth the $10
After about 10 minutes of struggling I did get this on my 3rd gen iPad.This might be obvious to some, but for some reason I overlooked the fact that this case does not support Smart Covers.

The overall installation took me less than a hour. This barebone is clearly for people that can use for work. It has two COM ports, something that would allow me to do J-tag and connect to Cisco routers or any other equipment uses com ports. That's something you can't find in modern computers unless you still kept on really old laptop or computers around for work. I probably going to build another one of these in the near future.The installation was super simple. Just have to buy 4 items and your done. CPU, Memory, HDD, Slim DVDRW drive.My BuildIntel core i3 3225DDR3 16GB500gb Sata hddslim dvdrwWindows7 rates 5.9 only cause of my slow hdd.everything after shipping and tax came down to under $500.This is a purely for work setup, I'm not planning it for HTPC or gaming, but it should work just fine.My game system's side fan 1x230mm (CM HAF X) is about the size of this case, which is pretty sad.The case clearly shows how modern M-ITX can be fast, powerful and very useful.Other comments:The difference between the XH61 and XH61v that mattered to me, was getting the two com port, the USB3.0 was a Bonus.So if someone just wants a HTPC or small gaming desktop, get xh61, it save you a few bucks.

I've had this grip on my D7000 for nearly a year.  I love it!  Yes, the control wheels are reversed.  No big deal, just turn them the other way when you notice your shutter speed isn't adjusting the way you thought it would.Yes, the battery compartment twist tab thing is plastic.  So what.  So is half of my Honda that I drive every day!  Just don't go all gorilla on it and you should be fine.  BTW, I do NOT baby mine.  However, I'm also not out shooting war stories or skateboarding SoCal with my 10.5mm fisheye following the next Tony Hawk over every curb, ramp and bench.  I'm a casual, everyday enthusiast who doesn't mind getting a little nick every now and then.  This thing is actually built very well.  However, when it does eventually break, I'll just buy another one.  In fact, I can buy 5 and still be under the cost of the Nikon grip.Just sayin...**  edit 05/23/13  **I have now had this grip for over a year and a half and it is still just as good as the day I bought it!  It is always on my camera except when I need to charge the batteries (btw, I rotate my batteries every charge from the grip and camera).
summary: Still works great after 1 and 1/2 years!

reviewText: Plug and play on mac mini... I really like the idea of using two usb ports for power instead of a power adapter.
